translated: It is therefore vital that this House establishes as strongly as possible the principle of applying the EQUAL programme to all refugees. In conclusion, I would like to say that I had some qualms last week when we discussed the formation of the Austrian government. But when it comes to Austrian refugee policy, and we have to criticise it, I no longer have any qualms. I hope that Parliament will be just as committed this time. Mr President, under the 1994-1999 financial perspective, when 13 different initiatives were being implemented, the Interreg II cross-border programme was an important initiative. The fact that the next cycle of structural funds, 2000-2006, includes the Interreg initiative, I believe, demonstrates very clearly the importance that the national Member States of the EU attach to it. The Interreg programme for the period 1989-1993 and the Interreg II programme for the period 1994-1999 proved to be real successes in bringing together the economic and social development of border Member States. I come from the border counties of northwest Ireland, so I have seen over the years the important role that Interreg I and Interreg II have played, and I welcome Interreg III. The Commission is providing £67 million through the Interreg III programme, which will be spent on the further development of cross-border economic projects between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. The European Union has played a key role in the development of the Irish border counties region over the years. The European Union is the major contributor, with £80 million allocated to the International Fund for Ireland. The European Union contributes 75% to the Peace and Reconciliation Programme. Overall, Interreg, the International Fund for Ireland and the Peace and Reconciliation Programme have all played an important role in the developing peace process. Mr President, I will speak on Interreg, limiting myself to a few critical points, and of course, to respect the time allocated to me. We all expressed our support for the confirmation of this programme and for the extension of the sectors of intervention, in addition to cross-border cooperation, to transnational and transregional cooperation. This does not, however, prevent us from being aware of the fact that the majority of resources – 50 to 80 percent – will be reserved for cross-border cooperation, for component A of the Interreg III programme; moreover, we continue to believe that the choice made to consolidate the current sectors of cooperation on this component, in terms of the choice of eligible regions, is wrong and contradictory. We hope and wish that, on this point, the Commission will acknowledge in substance, and not by formal tribute, Parliament's position. Cross-border cooperation continues to consider almost exclusively land borders and, where there have been exceptions with reference to maritime borders, these exceptions are not transparent in their choice and often benefit from compensation through other Community policies. The discrimination is truly much more serious for islands whose regional status can only be linked to borders of an exclusively maritime nature.

Unfortunately, the European Commission has already made progress on its guidelines and the position of the European Parliament has little influence on the programmes for the period 2000-2006. In the meantime, it is necessary to insist that the main priority of these funds should be the development of the countries and regions with the greatest difficulties and of the outermost regions, of which we have an example in Portugal with the Azores and Madeira, in order to achieve economic and social cohesion. In reality, however, the Commission's guidelines do not fully meet these objectives. On the other hand, it is important that there are precise indications and sufficient funds for sectors that create quality jobs and with recognition of rights and for those in which equal rights and opportunities are effectively promoted, for support to the social and solidarity economy, for rural development, for small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, for improving the quality of life of urban populations in deprived areas, particularly with regard to social housing, with a view to sustainable urban development. If the contents of Article 158 of the EC Treaty are aimed at promoting the harmonious development of the whole of the communities, we must say that the achievement of the elimination of disparities is still far away, indeed, in some cases, such as for the areas of Italy included in Objective 1, paradoxically the disparities are increasing, above all because of the still poor capacity of the structural apparatus to approach the Community procedures and the continuing cumbersomeness of the procedures; despite the regulatory interventions, in fact, the streamlining of the Community structures has yet to be achieved. If there is not first of all an administrative simplification, it will be difficult to achieve the Community objectives of reforms based on efficiency and concentration. In this sense, the Commission document is lacking, as it lacks any recommendation for the Member States aimed at simplifying the procedures and national regulations on the presentation and examination of projects by the national authorities, as well as on financing, implementation and control. SMEs, micro-enterprises and artisans in particular are still "weak subjects", given that for them the regulatory and administrative constraints imposed by some Member States, including Italy, represent major obstacles to accessing the Structural Funds. A handicap of considerable importance is the inability and impossibility of the Regions and other subjects to plan in advance, so that the Commission, which according to the decision on the guidelines 97/99 (Howitts report) should have consulted the Parliament in advance, in fact found a sort of convenient alibi in the establishment of the reduced planning phase in the Member States and published the guidelines already in July 1999, even before the newly elected Parliament began its legislative activities, thus preventing the Parliament itself from influencing the current structure of the guidelines. For this reason, the intermediate evaluation of Article 42 of Regulation 1260/99 will assume no small importance. The current guidelines do not generally have the merit of clarity and transparency. They only touch on the important issue of the possibility of measuring the progress made in terms of verifiable objectives and in full harmony with the strategies of Community policies and do not dwell adequately on the implications of enlargement, so much so that they do not contain specific provisions or clarifications on the matter either for regional and national authorities or for the candidate countries.

All the Commissioners have pledged, whenever they must travel to a country, not just their home countries, to a region—I do this three or four times a month—to dedicate a moment of their time to direct dialogue with citizens, not just the prominent figures or institutional representatives we meet regularly. They also pledge to establish direct contact, in a university, a secondary school, a factory, to meet with people, answer questions, and listen. That will therefore be our participation, as will the honourable Members of Parliament, in this necessary effort, in this burning obligation, to reduce the democratic deficit, that is, the distancing of citizens from what we do. We wish to carry out this initiative in cooperation with the Member States, in contact with the European Parliament. We will periodically summarize this matter so that the state of public opinion can be accurately assessed and it can be adjusted or reoriented. We also wish to carry it out in consultation with members of national parliaments, local representatives, non-governmental organizations, socio-professional groups, and the media: opinion makers, political groups and parties, MEPs, national representatives, representatives—I just mentioned—of local authorities or national parliaments, the Committee of the Regions, the Social Committee, civil society organizations, and academic circles. I must also recall—and I need to do so—that the European Parliament itself took the initiative on February 1st—and I would like to thank Mr. Napolitano again for this—to organize an initial working meeting with representatives of national parliaments, that is, representatives of citizens in each of the Member States. The Commission will propose to the Member States that they participate in this operation, either within the framework of specific cooperation or a more structured partnership. We are preparing a plan for the media, in close contact with the Presidency of the Union and the European Parliament. I have already mentioned the conditions under which the Commissioners themselves will participate during the meetings and field visits. What we want is to hold public debates. Allow me—without intending to give lessons, of course, or even advice—to recall that, when I had the honor of serving as Minister of European Affairs in my country, I felt the need to engage in direct dialogue with the citizens, and that, by holding this dialogue every week in each of the regions, directly, I realized there was an urgent need for the European Union to have a face. So, I went every week, together with a European Commissioner—not just the French Commissioners, but also ambassadors accredited in Paris, MEPs—to engage in dialogue, and I realized that the questions were countless and intelligent, that people needed to be respected, to be listened to, and to be given explanations. That is what we are going to do, supported by a budget of around four million euros, if you, the honourable Members, would be so kind as to make it available to us.

We understand your concern and will take it into account, particularly in our future contacts with Turkey when defining the agenda for Turkey's planned accession strategy. This issue will, of course, be at the heart of our concerns, and the European Commission will certainly take it into consideration. Mr President, allow me to thank the President-in-Office of the Council. I am sure that the President-in-Office is a very good man and is very kind to his wife, children, and dog. However, you will forgive me if the answer you have just given leaves me a little skeptical. I do not believe that the public has immediate access to statements and votes in the Council. Could you therefore promise to write to me and tell me, before the next plenary session in February, where I, as an ordinary citizen, can find this information immediately after the adoption of a legislative act by the Council, instead of waiting for it to appear in the press weeks later? Will you write to me before the next plenary session to provide me with this information? Mr. Deputy, first of all, I would like to say that I exempt you from making personal comments such as the one with which you began your second question, and I would be grateful if you would refrain from doing so in the future. As for the substance of your question, we get the impression that the criticism leveled at the Council, apart from its specific form, which we also note, does not relate to the opacity, let's say, of the legislative process, but almost to an excess of transparency. I would like to tell you, Mr. Deputy, that the results of this type of transparency process are clear to us and beyond doubt. We will not hesitate to repeat this information to you in writing, Mr. Deputy, but we will not be able to go beyond what we have said because it corresponds exactly to what the Treaty requires. We therefore believe that all the information that the General Secretariat of the Council is currently making available to the public is essential information regarding the Council's functioning as a legislative authority. It seems to me that the Council has not attempted to answer my question. I did not ask what its opinion was on the proposal that the Commission has not yet presented. My question concerned the interpretation in principle of Article 255 of the Treaty of Amsterdam. Does it mean that transparency legislation must also be adopted at national level, and not just within the three European institutions mentioned in the article? I would like an answer to this question. Does the Council believe that it is possible, on the basis of Article 255 of the Treaty, to regulate national legislation on transparency, apart from that which should govern the European institutions?

Next week, I will be going to the Bundestag in Berlin. I have already been to the French Senate. Throughout this debate, I will therefore also, whenever possible, visit the national parliaments directly. Dialogue with citizens is not about propaganda or marketing, or even public relations. I am aiming for a genuine dialogue, and after a short film objectively explaining the institutional reform, those on the podium will be able to speak and respond, with the microphone open. We will, as I repeat, carry out this initiative in ad hoc or ongoing cooperation with the Member States, and I very much hope that the governments of the Fifteen, with your support, will participate in this dialogue initiative under the conditions they consider most appropriate and appropriate. Mr President, I would like to join Mr Barnier's study group of 700 interns so that a discussion can take place. It's not really that interesting to debate the Intergovernmental Conference and openness with oneself. In connection with the Intergovernmental Conference, Mr. Barnier said in Parliament that social policy would not be subject to majority decisions. However, on page 63, it states that the fight against discrimination, the right to freedom of movement and residence—that is, the Residence Directives—the entire social security system, the renewal of Regulation No. 1408, and social policy measures, with a few exceptions, are to be decided by qualified majority voting. Does Mr. Barnier have no concerns that he is interfering in the electoral process of the Member States? Citizens go to the polls precisely for issues like these, thereby creating new majorities in the Danish Folketing and other parliaments. Can this be controlled from Brussels? Is this part of the radical decentralization that Mr. Prodi spoke about this morning? I was very pleased to hear last week that the Commission intends to devote more attention in the coming years to subsidiarity and its application to relations not only between the Union and the Member States, but also between the Union, the Member States, the regions, and cities. I hope that Commissioner Barnier, on his dialogue tour of the European regions, will explain this idea in more detail and will himself listen carefully and draw lessons. Commissioner, I refer to your answer to a previous question in which you discussed the possibilities of making the Treaty—as I shall call it—watertight in the face of the risks of undesirable developments, and in particular the diversification of the sanctions that can be imposed on a Member State under Article 7 for infringing fundamental freedoms. Do you consider that these proposals, or proposals of this kind, are part of the mandate of the Intergovernmental Conference laid down in Helsinki? I, for my part, do not have that impression. Aren't you concerned that such sanctions could be misused not only against human rights violations, but also against mere differences of opinion, against crimes of opinion, or deviations from the prevailing European ideology of unity? Yes, Mr. Bonde, we will begin this dialogue with 700 young people in Brussels who will work in the institutions and the Commission, and I believe that starting with motivated young people is a good start for this dialogue.

Competition between regions will certainly strengthen the European Union, not weaken it. Here, I'll cite the issue of GA funding, the example of savings banks and state banks, and the example of quality seals. Here, a region has created something on its own to market its own products. This initiative must not be destroyed at the European level. I also think an increase in the de minimis rule is necessary. We should do everything in our power to encourage competition between regions. The second is a discussion about competition and the social market economy, although I'm not talking about market failure here. I've already touched on the area of state banks and savings banks, but I'll now summarize what one hears again and again from one side or the other. A resident of a retirement home today is housed in the social sector. But I can also consider them as a customer, and I think we should discuss quite clearly and in a timely manner where the social sector, where established structures, represent a barrier to competition. Otherwise, I can name any customer, any sector, as a customer, thereby severely damaging social sectors. Finally, I would like to say something about the principle of subsidiarity: I consider it urgently necessary that where Member States allow regions and municipalities to levy taxes, this should be maintained and not be regulated uniformly by Europe. Thank you very much, Mr. Colleague. I congratulate you on what in German parliamentarism is, in your case, inappropriately called a maiden speech. Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I take the floor on behalf of my colleague Robert Goebbels, who unfortunately cannot be here due to political commitments. Within the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, the Jonckheer report has sparked fierce controversy on the functioning of the market. A narrow right-wing majority has succeeded in removing any reference to market deficiencies from the report. If the majority of our Parliament were to follow this ultra-liberal concept of a supposedly perfect market, the world would not change for that reason. Real-world economic relations make it abundantly clear that the elimination of any government intervention in the market by no means leads to perfect competition and optimal resource allocation. While the market has been the preferred forum for human exchange since time immemorial, it has never been perfect. The market favors short-term business and quick profits. In the market, the balance of power between supply and demand generally skews the weakest—consumers and workers. To function, the market needs rules. The necessary and valuable entrepreneurial spirit needs a counterbalance, a sense of responsibility toward society. We, as European Social Democrats, are in favor of a social market economy. The market is not an end in itself; it must serve to improve living conditions. The European Union and states must not replace economic actors, but governments must establish the rules and objectives that enable the economy to develop sustainably. Ultimately, aid can be used to facilitate restructuring, provide training, and save jobs and thus know-how. The main objective of the Union’s competition policy cannot be to reduce the overall level of aid.

I would be delighted, Mrs Schroedter, if you could consider the inclusion of this proposed amendment positively, and also in the interest of subsidiarity. Mr President, Commissioner, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has remained unanimous in saying that it is strategic and a priority to support interventions from the Structural and Cohesion Funds aimed at providing better employment opportunities for the unemployed and promoting equality between men and women. Unfortunately, Schroedter's excellent report did not take this criterion into consideration, despite the numerous proofs, and we will see this later in the Berend report, that these funds do indeed make a tremendous contribution to the most backward regions in reducing the gap between them and the most developed regions in Europe. They are growing, but in terms of GDP. Their competitiveness is increasing, but the increase in wealth does not benefit everyone because employment is not increasing and the difference in employment opportunities persists in certain regions. Commissioner, read the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and give it priority, because that is where the main problem for citizens lies. In the revision, in the allocation of reserves, take strategic account of the need for jobs, because that is, ultimately, what the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Funds require. Mr President, it is important that the guidelines provide the right direction and strengthen the effectiveness of the programmes for the crucial seven-year period 2002-2006, so that sustainable development and support for employment, particularly for women and young people, finally become a reality, and that a balance is ensured between economic, social and environmental policies. It is particularly important to tackle acute urban problems, to safeguard employment in rural areas and, of course, to offer, as Article 158 of the Treaty specifically provides, equal opportunities for development to the islands of the European Union, including the Greek islands, which represent half of it. The Union's cohesion policy must be further strengthened, because a Europe whose regions have enormous disparities in living standards can be neither credible nor viable. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to tell you how much I have listened carefully to the observations, and sometimes the criticisms and suggestions, that some of you have just made in your speeches, based on Mrs Schroedter's report. Everyone understands, Madam Rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, the reasons, the deadlines - I will come back to this in a moment - and whatever these deadlines or delays, since we are discussing this report now, I believe, on behalf of the Commission, that it comes at the right time, as regards the 2000-2006 guidelines, since we are starting the new regional programming. Madam Rapporteur, you rightly pointed out that, although it is indeed primarily up to the Member States and the regions to define their own development priorities, the co-financing of programmes by our European Union requires, justifies, that account also be taken of Community priorities as they are debated and approved here, in order to promote this Community dimension of economic and social cohesion that many of you have so forcefully recalled.

It is recognized that there is an inconsistent policy. Good intentions are made time and again, but in fact, nothing happens. It is therefore right that we highlight this today. I would like to give some examples to illustrate these contradictions. Some developing countries produce sugarcane for sugar production. Sugar is also produced in the Union using sugar beets. In order to prevent this cheap sugar from developing countries from competing with the more expensive EU sugar, a severe regulatory levy is imposed on it. The result is a severe restriction on sugarcane imports from these countries. At the same time, we provide these countries with very significant development aid. A minister from one of the Caribbean islands that produces this sugarcane once told me: "If you allowed our sugar to enter the European Union normally, we would not need your development aid at all." Another example: cocoa. The European Union wants to allow the use of 5% alternative fat in chocolate to harmonize the internal market. Zero percent could also be agreed upon, and the internal market would still be harmonized. If 5% is established, which for now seems likely, it is known that hundreds of thousands of small cocoa producers in developing countries will almost certainly be harmed. However, this seems to be the direction being taken. What are we doing? It is the typical policy of which our citizens say: really, what is Brussels doing? It seems that European companies are more important than our own principles, our own coherence, and the interests of developing countries. Likewise, in the area of sanctions and embargoes, there are striking examples. Why a boycott of oil supplies to Haiti and not against Burma, where an elected president has been arrested, parliament has been dissolved, and some MPs are in prison or even murdered? Why not a boycott of oil supplies to Sudan, where armed clashes continue, with the weapons, mind you, being paid for with money from oil companies operating in the territories where the refugees are located? The inconsistency is obviously colossal. Mr. Nielson has given us a fine example of the new Lomé Convention. If the new Lomé Convention is simply implemented, without all the inconsistencies being resolved, a policy is built on feet of clay, to use a biblical expression. The Council has repeatedly mentioned where the error lies: in agriculture, trade, conflict prevention, peace operations, fisheries, immigration, the environment. Commissioner Nielson, what we hope for is a good report on these inconsistencies and some concrete proposals to end them. I repeat, otherwise your beautiful examples, all your wonderful policies—and I say this to the Secretary of State as well—will be built on clay and, quite rightly, won't achieve much.

Paragraph 11 states that symbolic measures can replace the political agreement, the political perspective that being a candidate represents. But this is not only a masterpiece of hypocrisy, it is also an aberration, because, dear colleagues, if the negotiations begin tomorrow, this agreement will be signed in a year and will enter into force in three years. And I challenge you to think that, among the Balkan countries, within three years, you will not have, from Croatia, Macedonia, Bosnia, formal applications for membership. Mr. Racan announced, a few days ago, Croatia's formal application for membership by the end of the year 2000. I am certain that we will have other applications for membership and therefore that this fine work, this fine intellectual architecture will collapse, because it will be overtaken by events, just as we have been overtaken for twenty years by everything that happened in the former Yugoslavia. This would not be serious if there were not the problems that we know about in this region of Europe, if there were not the problems that are being faced but have not yet been resolved by the new government of Macedonia, the problems of cohabitation between the Macedonian majority and the Albanian minority, with the related problems of Kosovo, if there were not the economic problems that we know about, the neighborhood problems with a particularly large mafia in Serbia, if there were not the problem that is a veto that should be denounced for what it is, the veto of Greece which, after almost ten years, continues to prevent this country from being called by its name, and I hope that the interpreters did not use the term FYROM when I was talking about Macedonia. This is absolutely absurd. I think this is an offense, first and foremost, to our Greek colleagues, to Greek citizens. It is urgent that this issue be resolved. Finally, by a happy coincidence, I received a letter from Mr. Georgievski, President of Macedonia, to Mr. Fischler, dated 8 March, in which, referring to Article 0, now Article 49 of the Treaty, he requests that Macedonia be allowed to join the European Union. Why did the Council not inform us? Why did the Commission not inform us of this formal request from Macedonia? Mr. President, Commissioner, the Balkans are not just a dark abyss, politically speaking. One only has to look at the clearly positive developments in the Republic of Macedonia in recent critical years. The abominable ethnic escalation in neighboring Kosovo has not had a knock-on effect on its territory. Paradoxically, but nonetheless true, the war on the battlefield of Kosovo Polje has had exactly the opposite effect: the dangerous gulf of mistrust between the Macedonian majority and the Albanian minority has narrowed significantly. In the view of the former, the latter behaved loyally toward the common state during the international outbreak of the Kosovo conflict. And in the view of the Albanian minority, both the Macedonians and the Macedonian state have largely fulfilled their obligations as neighbors to the hard-hit Kosovo Albanian majority. This remarkable outcome of the Kosovo conflict can therefore rightly be described as the second pillar of internal politics in the Republic of Macedonia.

And all this is in accordance with the principles that we have always supported. Thank you, Mr Segni, I will gladly do so. Indeed, this is entirely in accordance with the position that our Parliament has always supported. Madam President, I would like to draw attention to a case that Parliament has been following for a long time, namely the case of Alexander Nikitin. We are all pleased that the court acquitted him, reiterating that in Russia too, access to information on the environment is a constitutional right. Now, however, he will be impeached again because the public prosecutor will appeal. As we know and as we have pointed out in countless resolutions - including at the last plenary session last year - this is not simply a court case and it is a serious mistake to accuse Alexander Nikitin of having committed crimes and criminal acts, especially since we, as the interested parties, have benefited from the results of his research. These results form the basis of the European programmes for the protection of the Barents Sea. I would therefore ask you to look at the draft letter in which the main facts are set out and to support the position taken by Parliament with the Russian authorities, in accordance with your resolutions. Yes, Mr Scroedter, I will gladly look into the facts relating to the matter you raised as soon as I receive your letter. Madam President, allow me to begin by congratulating you on having kept your word. The number of television channels available in our offices has indeed increased enormously in this first part-session of the new year. However, Madam President, my request has not yet been followed up. It is true that we now have two Finnish channels and one Portuguese channel, but unfortunately the Dutch channel is still missing. And that is precisely what I had asked for, since we Dutch parliamentarians, when we are sent into this monthly exile, would like to be able to watch the news in Dutch. I repeat my request once again: please ensure that a Dutch channel is also made available. Mrs Plooj-van Gorsel, I can tell you that this item is on the agenda of the Quaestors' meeting on Wednesday. I hope it will be considered in a positive spirit. Madam President, I would like to know why this Parliament does not comply with the health and safety rules that it itself approves. Why have there not been any tests of the air quality in this building since we were elected? Why has the Health and Safety Committee not met since 1998? Why have there not been any fire alarm tests either in the Parliament buildings in Brussels or here in Strasbourg? Why are there no instructions to follow in the event of a fire? Why have the stairwells not been improved since my accident? Why is the smoking ban in non-smoking areas not being enforced? It is absolutely shameful that we, of all people, do not comply with the rules that we ourselves approve. Mrs Lynne, you are absolutely right and I intend to check whether everything you have said has really not been done.

The question is therefore: what requirements should possibly be placed on a monopoly or on part of the services controlled by a monopoly? On this point, most Member States have always refused to make any progress, and I am pleased to note that in my country the new government is concerned with a subject that should have been dealt with long ago, and that the Belgian Post Office and the Belgian Government are now taking the necessary steps to ensure that the Post Office is, in part, ready to compete by 2003. As a new Member of Parliament, I am therefore trying to familiarise myself with the matter, and I must frankly admit that this is causing me a great deal of difficulty. I have consulted a series of studies that were commissioned at the time by the European Commission, but at the same time I am finding documents from Post-Europe which state that these studies are not correct and that the basis on which they were carried out is erroneous. I think that the Commission could at least have been a little more active on this point and could have provided us with a little more information. She could also have sent us the studies she promised us and which we also requested. As far as I know, this has not yet been the case. I therefore ask you, Commissioner, to help a new Member like me with his difficult task. Like Mr Miller, I would greatly appreciate it if, in the coming months or weeks, and even if possible in the coming days, you could explain to us how far we have come with the implementation of the 1997 directive. Second point: what is the state of progress of the universal service, how much does it cost, how is it organized, how do you intend to organize it, what proposals can you make? I would like to receive more concrete information on this subject. Apparently, the postal service is a very powerful lobby, and rightly so. Hundreds of thousands of people earn their living at the post office. Furthermore, as Mr Miller also pointed out, my country will not be wiped off the map either, despite its population density, if the postman no longer comes every day. However, we have a large number of people in our country, elderly people for example, who only see one person during the day, and that is the postman. So let's try to take that into account as well. The post office is much more than just the transport of parcels and letters. For businesses, too, the post office is particularly important. A study shows that 90% of postal traffic is between businesses, compared to 10% between people. What do you actually want to liberalize? I would like to be better informed about this, because the most important question is how you can better serve the customer with the services that exist. There are postal companies that have a monopoly and still operate in a very valuable way.

Reports must be submitted to Parliament's Committee on Fisheries before decisions are taken, otherwise we are simply an approval body. I know that this is hardly the intention of the Commission or the Commissioner, but we must learn from past mistakes. Mr President, we are faced with a proposal to transpose into Community law an ICCAT recommendation – which, as has been said, dates from 1998 – which should have been in force since June 1999 and which only reached Parliament at the end of last year. The Commission's legislative laziness on certain issues should not surprise us, except that we are faced with a recommendation from one of the most important international fisheries organizations on the protection of a resource as threatened as tuna. The Mediterranean, and in particular one of its areas, is a very important breeding ground for bluefin tuna, the commercial value of which is enormous. This is why ICCAT recommended this fenced area in the Adriatic and tightened the conditions for catching age-free tuna. As the rapporteur rightly said, both measures are fully and amply justified, which is why we can only ask for their approval. But I also agree with Mr Gallagher, who expressed his frustration at the Commission's slowness in getting the ball rolling and converting the recommendations into Community regulations. We are still waiting, for example, for the proposal for a regulation on the ban on imports of bluefin tuna from Honduras and Belize, a recommendation that dates back to 1996. According to my information, it appears that the Directorate-General for Fisheries sent a note to the Directorate-General for Trade in January, and that the latter has already begun the preparatory work. But four years to implement the ban on imports from countries known to favor flags of convenience is an absolutely intolerable delay, Commissioner. We have heard the Commission's explanations regarding the lengthy internal process of transposition, and the image that remains is one of exasperating bureaucracy. Regarding the sole proposal to speed up what is currently on the table, by which the Council and Parliament are excluded from the procedure, I have some doubts. In any case, it is clear that we will eventually have to find a solution to the problem, either within the framework of the Commission's report on regional fisheries organizations or, if possible, as quickly as possible. I assume that no one in this House is opposed to the principle of protecting juvenile marine organisms. Indeed, it is often pointed out that one of the general objectives of the common fisheries policy must be the protection and conservation of living aquatic resources. All of this is praiseworthy. Likewise, there can be no doubt about the enormous environmental and financial importance of bluefin tuna. As a seasoned fisherman myself, I wish for a return to the good old days of the 1930s when fishermen at Scarborough Harbour in Yorkshire caught bluefin tuna weighing up to 830 pounds. I don't know the metric equivalent.

Competition, that is, the war between large companies, constantly results in layoffs, factory closures, not to mention the immense waste in the use of productive capacity. We have yet another example with the ABB Alsthom Power trust's plan to cut jobs in Europe. 18 million unemployed, 50 million poor in the European Union, yet one of the richest regions in the world: this is the result of this competition that the European institutions intend to foster. The Commission's desire to regulate the conditions of competition on the European market is derisory, because the only law competition obeys is the law of the jungle where the most powerful crush or devour the weakest. This is especially revolting on a social level. The European Commission's report crudely shows that the Union's institutions are only interested in the large capitalist groups that are engaged in this economic war and not at all in the victims it causes. Nothing to prevent the spread of unemployment, nothing to protect employees, nothing to prevent large companies from pushing a fraction of the population into poverty, simply to enrich their shareholders even more! So, if we recognize one merit in this report, it is that it shows that the working majority of society has nothing to hope for from the European institutions to preserve, let alone improve, their living conditions. By voting against this report, we are speaking on behalf of all those who have expressed their rejection, in Seattle and throughout Europe, of a world reduced to a strict market logic. We are voting against this report in the name of developing public services, and in particular, in memory of the victims of the Paddington train crash, who were killed not by fate but by an absurd determination to introduce competition where regulation was needed. This report is, at bottom, a primitive text inspired only by the law of the jungle, because competition cannot resolve any of the problems facing humanity at the turn of the century. Whether it concerns the balance of the biosphere, the promotion of culture or cooperation with the developing world, cut-throat competition is a factor of regression and insecurity. And do you think that the 18 million unemployed in Europe are victims of an overly timid application of this competition policy? We are convinced of the opposite, and we also do not believe that state aid is by definition too high. Compared to what iron rule, to what criteria of effectiveness would it be? Finally, after Seattle, do you seriously consider it necessary to advocate a greater role for the WTO? Only the legal advisers of multinationals can be so stubborn. Jonckheer report (A5-0087/1999) I welcome the quality of the seventh report on state aid in the EU, the fact that it is now published annually and the fact that the Directorate-General for Competition publishes general and specific information for the public on its website.

I believe the European Union must do so. I believe the embargo against Serbia must be lifted and that, for its part, Serbia must release the political prisoners. Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I fully endorse Mrs. Pack's impassioned speech. What she said here is absolutely accurate. In Kosovo, there is not just one truth, there are several. I refuse to accept that we can speak of a reverse genocide, since to do so would be misleading. I fully support the motion for a resolution before us. In it, we condemn all forms of violence, as is right, but we cannot speak of a genocide in which the roles have been reversed. Obviously, the situation in Mitrovica is very dangerous, and we all know why. Important economic interests are at stake, and we cannot forget the tragedy of the Trepca mines. We have already referred to the fate of the political prisoners. There is much pain, much suffering in Kosovo. People are demonstrating, people are sending us emails. They are asking us where their children are, their sons. We must offer them a reasonable answer. The case of Flora Brovina is one of many outstanding cases. It is positive that we are addressing it in the motion for a resolution, but like Flora Brovina, there are hundreds, there are thousands. I ask the Commission and the Council, which is absent, to intervene without further delay on behalf of the political prisoners. The fact that they are imprisoned in Serbia is one of the factors at the root of the unrest and violence in Kosovo. Mr. President, paragraph 10 of the joint motion for a resolution before us rightly urges the Council and the Member States of the European Union to redouble their efforts to raise the necessary personnel and financial means to strengthen the United Nations police forces. This request is perfectly in line with the vision of the UN High Representative in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner. In order to successfully carry out his mission of restoring and safeguarding public order in Kosovo, he needs, according to his own estimates, at least 6,000 foreign police officers. The UN has promised, however, a police force of 4,800 men. However, for now, Kouchner only has approximately 2,000 police officers at his disposal. Moreover, half of this group comes from the United States and Germany. It is understandable that the UN High Representative is not at all happy with this situation, especially given the endemic ethnic violence in the area. Particularly disconcerting is Kouchner's virulent criticism of the French government in recent days. Paris is abandoning its compatriot to his fate in the midst of a crisis zone after sending him a handful of police officers, no more than 37. Kouchner points to none other than the Minister of the Interior, Chevènement, as the culprit for this dishonorable French stance. According to Kouchner, the Minister is preventing the deployment of French police officers to Kosovo for ideological reasons.

They therefore concluded that the voting system must take into account the demographic dimension and that the United Kingdom will not give up its right of veto. Is the Council examining this issue? Is it prepared to maintain the democratic right of veto, based on the actual strength of the population, or is it still leaning towards a simple majority vote by the members of the Council rather than a vote that reflects the European population democratically represented by them? Have the United Kingdom representatives communicated their decision and proposal to the Council and what consideration, if any, has it received? Since the issue of voting is fundamental to the democratic future of the Union, it should certainly be given the utmost attention. The way in which decisions are taken is of the utmost importance. Mr President, I thank the Council and the Commission for their statements this morning, but I would like to focus on policy coherence because that is the subject on the agenda. While I agree with the need to have a debate on the coherence of the different Union policies with development policy, I wonder whether this is the right time. However, the Council statement has given me hope for the future. It is clear to me, as someone who deals specifically with development policy, that there are many areas where the lack of coherence has dramatic effects in developing countries. I will give a few examples shortly. However, I would remind the House that as early as June 1997, a Council resolution recognised the existence of a serious lack of coherence between certain Union policies and development cooperation policy. In this connection, the Council asked the Commission to submit annual reports, the first of which was due to be examined in 1998. We are still awaiting the first report, and that is why I believe that the debate is premature, given that the Commission has had very little to say about coherence this morning. The areas identified by the Council are specific areas, where policy coherence is particularly important, such as peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution, food safety, fisheries and immigration. Some of these issues have been the subject of in-depth analysis. Personally, I believe that issues such as peace-building and conflict prevention and resolution are the responsibility of African heads of state, who should be given the support of the European Union, with the Organisation of African Unity acting as arbiter. The issues that do suffer from a lack of coherence are in areas such as agriculture, trade, the environment and biodiversity, but that is the real problem: these are highly sensitive areas in the European Union in general and in this Parliament in particular. MEPs will have different views, even within the same political parties, depending on (a) their country of origin or (b) the committee they are members of. There are aspects of coherence that I would like to look at as a member of the Committee on Development that would probably horrify some members of the Committee on Agriculture or the Committee on Fisheries.

My task as draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection is a very simple one. I can agree with the rapporteur and say that the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection has asked and urged the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development to approve the Commission's proposal. This has gained me a great deal of time, which I would sometimes like to have for other things and which I will now use in anticipation, as Mr Böge has already done. My report on TSE has not yet been submitted to the House. We were somewhat undecided at first, although we regret that. But I have come to the conclusion that it is actually quite clever timing. It is actually quite good that we can already give the Commission a few things to think about on the basis of this debate, Mr Byrne. Since we perhaps did not interact so positively with one another earlier on Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf's report and certainly will not come to such close agreement, it may well be that things are somewhat different in this area. Let me say up front that the part of the complex report that Mr. Böge dealt with—incidentally, a form of good cooperation between two committees, where one committee takes the lead while the other issues an opinion, and vice versa, which could perhaps serve as an example for the future—is relatively simple. Things will become more difficult when we look at the TSE proposal, Mr. Byrne. If we then ask questions directly, the questions that Mr. Böge has already mentioned will arise. The question will arise—and I will have to ask this of you and the Commission representatives in the committee—what the BSE status of the Member States and other third countries will look like. How will the BSE status actually be defined? Will you possibly also consider the willingness to use a BSE test when considering the question of BSE status? And then my constant question to you, Mr. Byrne, which you certainly already know and which will not surprise you: What about the BSE test? When will you make it mandatory? Perhaps you could even do so before this Parliament debates the TSE report. Not that I want to delay it, but it would be a gesture, so to speak, if you could say: And here is the legislative proposal for BSE testing for you! I know I'm tormenting you with this, Mr. Byrne, but sometimes it has to be done. I say quite emphatically—and this also after Mr. Graefe zu Baringdorf's report, which is certainly linked to the overall idea—animal nutrition, animal husbandry, and animal production must be such that, on the one hand, it is species-appropriate, but, on the other hand, it must above all be such that it does not harm or endanger humans. It cannot be the case that you exempt cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and other products on the grounds that no harm can occur or that they are not dangerous. That is certainly too brief, too concise, and too little. You are fortunate in Mr. Böge's report that he only touches on this in passing. But the problem you'll have with my report is that you'll have to justify yourself a little more, and you'll have a little more trouble with it.

Otherwise, I believe we are working on the symptoms but not combating the causes. The public is very critical, particularly regarding the use of GMOs. We must address the growing public awareness of GMOs and regulate their use in animal feed accordingly. Firstly, if an additive consists of or contains genetically modified organisms, it can only be authorized if it poses no risk to human health or the environment. Secondly, it is wise to lay down provisions for genetically modified additives in animal feed, similar to the rules in the law on the release of seeds, as the rapporteur has already mentioned. Thirdly, and finally, in order to have a transparent consumer policy, we need labeling for animal feed that is genetically modified. This explicit statement regarding the composition of animal feed therefore allows a dual freedom of decision, both for users of animal feed and for subsequent consumers. I believe that the decision should be up to the citizen. We are all talking about citizens who are shaken by scandals, who have lost confidence in the safety of feed. With consistent regulations on additives in animal feed, we can make a vital contribution to restoring confidence. I am therefore also very much looking forward to your response to our amendments. We will therefore naturally vote in such a way that we can possibly refer the proposal back to committee. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this proposal to amend the directive on additives in animal feed, which dates back to 1970, is the first in a whole series of proposals on the subject of animal feed. Over the coming months, we will therefore be discussing some of these here in Parliament. The major attention that the European public has paid to the scandals involving dioxin, antibiotics, sewage sludge, etc. proves the crucial importance of this issue. It is therefore an important element in the protection of public health. This is why we believe that Article 152 should be used as the legal basis, and not Article 37, as proposed by the Commission. The amendment proposed by the Commission, namely equal treatment of additives that were authorized before and after 31 December 1987, is incontestable and has our full support. The Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development has, however, unanimously made some important amendments to the Commission's proposal. The regulation proposed by the Commission carries the risk of monopoly in the marketing of certain additives. The right of petition is granted only to the party that received the initial authorization, but companies that subsequently received authorization are excluded. We should avoid such a monopoly, which could, for example, lead to higher prices for animal feed, by granting provisional authorisation to all companies that placed a given substance on the market before 1 April 1998. This authorisation is then valid until the re-evaluation procedure is concluded. The main change compared to the Commission's proposal, however, concerns the adoption of provisions on genetically modified organisms in the Additives Directive, recommended by the rapporteur. He took as his starting point the compromise negotiated between Parliament and the Commission on the authorisation of GMOs outside the Release Directive. This compromise already forms the basis for the authorisation of GMOs. It is therefore logical to also include provisions on additives in genetically modified animal feed in this case, in line with the regulations we have already adopted in other areas – I will mention only the area of forest reproductive material.

I would like to point out that considerable progress has been made in this area in Italy; we were probably the first in Europe to adopt a regulation encouraging the take-back of end-of-life vehicles, but we also have a fairly obsolete vehicle fleet in our country and are therefore seriously concerned about the market problems that this directive could cause. I believe that the situation must be carefully analyzed. In Italy, approximately 80% of end-of-life vehicles are taken back and recycled, but we have a market problem which, given that Italian industry often resorts to furloughs and layoffs, could lead to employment crises and cause serious difficulties for workers in various parts of Italy. Therefore, I believe that we should try to reconcile the two requirements—I sometimes detect a somewhat extremist attitude in this Parliament, that is, either radically green or diametrically opposed positions are being put forward—and to find a synthesis, which, in my view, is essentially what the efforts of Mr Florenz and other Members to reconcile the two positions represent. As a result, we now have the interesting amendments before us; on the basis of the position advocated here, I believe a balanced solution to the problem can be found, reconciling environmental concerns with market and employment needs. Mr President, this directive addresses the growing but relatively minor problem of scrap cars, as well as the issue of more systematic disposal of all vehicles when they reach the end of their service life. For this reason, the directive may seem desirable, even if it is not urgently needed. The key questions that now arise are: who will pay the EUR 262 per vehicle for the nine million vehicles disposed of each year? Who will cover the costs of collection, dismantling, disposal, etc.? And should the directive apply retroactively to all vehicles ever produced? In the common position, the Council proposes that the cost should be borne entirely by the car manufacturers. This would amount to billions of pounds, or rather euros, being borne by the major manufacturers in each country of the European Union. The costs would inevitably be passed on to new car buyers. Since European car manufacturers have been in business for considerably longer than Japanese, Korean, or other companies, the burden on older European firms would be much greater, giving their competitors a significant competitive advantage. I support Mr. Florenz, Mr. Lange, and others on both sides of the political spectrum who have sought a compromise based on cost-sharing. I recommend that you support the amendment tabled by myself and my colleagues from Germany, Italy, Ireland, Spain, Sweden, and the United Kingdom to remove the retroactive effect from the proposed measure. Retroactive legislation is bad legislation; it is unfair and often unworkable. It is rejected on principle by the majority of democratically elected parliaments throughout the free world unless there is an overriding public interest, which is clearly not the case here. That is why I have asked for a roll-call vote on this matter.

This is the area where the ideological battle for Europe is concentrated. I think the debate has made this clear. Tonight it has become very clear where the political divide lies, and it is therefore not surprising that this issue has polarized the debate in a House known for its striving for consensus and its policy of reconciliation. And I am pleased that this difference of opinion is so pronounced, because we are dealing with a radical report. This report is intended to shake Europe up. This report contains radical measures that will ultimately ease the labor market. It's that simple. The reason unemployment rates in Europe are so alarmingly high is that in many cases it is too difficult to recruit staff due to bureaucracy, the existing framework, and the inflexibility of the labor markets. The only way forward has now been shown. Social justice, and that is ultimately what we are all concerned about here, can only be achieved in Europe if there is prosperity, opportunity, and jobs. This report shows very clearly how these goals can be achieved most effectively, because Europe must wake up. You can't create jobs with government spending alone. You can't create jobs by legislating for reduced working hours, as if jobs were a cake to be cut up and divided among the citizens. The real world simply works differently. And if Europe is to be left behind, if it is to persist in stagnation and unemployment, in standstill and the estate system, then feel free to vote against this report tomorrow. But if you want Europe to develop further, to develop in such a way that its citizens benefit from it, then I call on all of you to support this report, because it will create the jobs and opportunities it needs. There is no other option. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, The great advantage of the original version of Mr Giorgos Katiforis's report was that it derived from the specific findings of the Commission's report on the EU economy important recommendations for a European Union strategy which could have given continuity and stability to the prospects of sustainable development which were emerging in 2000 for all the countries of our continent. These recommendations concerned the need for effective coordination of economic policy at Union level, that is to say, overcoming the separate management of economic and social policy which has hitherto seriously hampered the definition of a coherent strategy for combating unemployment, aimed at achieving full employment. It is this vacuum of economic management at European level, Mr von Wogau, which is at least partly responsible for the weakening of the euro. The report's recommendations also concerned the creation of a common European research area and the promotion of consistent policies in all Member States in the areas of research, lifelong learning, and employability, while eliminating all forms of unfair tax competition between states. Finally, the report updated and adopted the proposals of President Delors' White Paper promoting a European project for the creation of a single network of infrastructure and services. These recommendations, which largely coincide with the orientations of the Portuguese Presidency's program document and will therefore be discussed at the Lisbon Summit, were rejected or distorted in this Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs by a majority that found its fragile unity solely in ideological hostility to a European Union based on the convergence of national policies rather than solely on a market structure.

Many Member States have not ratified the Convention on the Protection of Financial Interests or made any commitments in this regard, and therefore it was clear that something more radical had to be done. We need to take this responsibility seriously. We need to be able to prosecute those who commit fraud against the European Union. The question is: who prosecutes? This is where things really get tricky. Who is responsible when you are dealing with a structure that crosses so many borders? We also need to listen to the concerns of Member States. The proposal to establish a European Public Prosecutor's Office is very sensitive. We are all aware that a comprehensive federal approach and a European judicial authority prevailing over national judicial authorities are too premature for some people. However, the discussion must be started, and we therefore invite the IGC to do so. How we respond to the staff of the European Union institutions is of crucial importance to Parliament, the guardian of the European Union's budget. At a time when we are reviewing the entire reform process, it is essential that we send the right signal. Those committing fraud must understand that they will be prosecuted, which is not currently the case. Mrs Palacio raised the question of whether we have the legal authority to do so. I would like to make it clear that my group will be proposing an amendment to remove the details of how the Commission should tackle this problem. We know this is a delicate debate. We know that the Commission may need the opportunity to negotiate a situation that would be acceptable to all parties. Let me make it clear that there is no commitment here to a corpus juris, nor to a European Public Prosecutor. There is, however, a resolute commitment to a change in the status quo that is completely unacceptable. Mr President, I shall begin by congratulating Mrs Theato on her report. I believe it is an excellent report that will largely receive the support of my group. I only have the very clear impression that it would have liked to go even further. After listening to the debates of the last five or six months, that seems quite possible. We all know that in 1995 it was agreed that there should be better criminal protection for the financial interests of the European Union. Unfortunately, the Member States have not played along. This is purely a political matter and, at the moment, there is little we can do about it, it seems to me. There is, however, still the possibility that the Commission could take new initiatives on the basis of Article 280 of the Treaty and I would suggest that the Commission do so as quickly as possible. Unlike the previous speaker, who has already left us, my group is very much in favour of the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor.

Thank you very much, Commissioner Solbes Mira. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon. Excessive deficits annexed to the Treaty establishing the EC The next item is report A50013/2000 by Mr Knörr Borràs, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 3605/93 on the application of the Protocol on the excessive deficit procedure annexed to the Treaty establishing the European Community (COM(99)0444 - C5-0174/99 - 1999/0196(CNS)). Mr President, I also have the pleasure of welcoming the Spanish Commissioner, Mr Solbes, whom I have congratulated several times, both inside and outside Parliament, for the excellent work he has carried out in the Kingdom of Spain in the area of European convergence. The proposal to amend this regulation, relating to the application of the protocol on the excessive deficit procedure annexed to the Treaty establishing the European Community, raises a fundamental question concerning the adaptation to the European system of accounts ESA 95 which, as you know, replaces the previous system of accounts integrated in 79 and, above all, a question concerning the emergence of new ranges of financial products, the consistency in the calculation of the proportions between the public deficit and the gross domestic product in the light of this European system of accounts 1995 and, finally, concerning the taking into account of the importance of the calculation of interest expenditure and their consistency with this new methodology. In my opinion, the proposal for a regulation aims to update the definitions and evaluations of certain economic operations involved in the calculation of the deficit within the meaning of the Treaty of Maastricht, which sets maximum percentages for the deficit of general government in relation to GDP at market prices in the various States. Until now, the Member States have calculated this GDP in accordance with the ESA 79 methodology. The latest estimate we have is the one submitted in September 1999 and which referred to the 1998 accounting year. Therefore, if this Regulation is approved, the estimate corresponding to March 2000, the first estimate of the deficit for the 1999 accounting year, will already be made in accordance with this new system. We know that the Member States have done their homework, so to speak, they have calculated and prepared their national accounts in accordance with ESA 95, and their corresponding estimates have already been published. This has meant, in addition to the incorporation of the new methodology, the nominal revision of most of the aggregates and accounting operations due to the methodological changes and more refined statistical information incorporated in the estimates. Naturally, these changes are likely to alter the public deficits in terms of the Member States' national accounts. And very briefly, I will outline the five areas that are perhaps subject to the most significant changes. First, the adjustments in the delimitation of what is meant by the institutional sector of general government according to ESA 95. This is important because the public deficit refers to what, in this case, the general government as a whole obtains.

Together with him, I thank those who collaborated on the project and all the staff working in the Commission, who took part in the widest debate ever organised within the Institution. I would like to underline that this method of debate is extraordinarily new and, in my opinion, has forced us to make radical changes in our way of thinking too. The White Paper, which we have before us, is also the fruit of their contribution: they have understood that only a profoundly reformed Commission can return to being that internationally admired institution which was at the basis of the history of Europe. With the adoption of the White Paper, a chapter of the past is closed - I hope, I trust - definitively. Now we look to the future, to the challenges that await the Union and to what we have already indicated in recent weeks, here before you, for the 2000-2005 programme. The reform finds its profound political raison d'être in these objectives of the five-year plan. We need - the whole Union needs - a strong Commission, a Commission that recovers the capacity to act as a political entity, recognisable as such in all its actions. This is why we are redefining all the priorities on which to concentrate our work. This is why - this is another important chapter - we are freeing ourselves from activities whose management we no longer deserve to be responsible for, consistent with a principle of decentralisation and subsidiarity. This is why we are reforming the administrative machine, so as to create the conditions to carry out our tasks effectively. We will make the best use of our resources, which are already very limited and which we are using up to the last part. If the need arises, however, I do not rule out coming back here, before you, to ask for additional resources for the new tasks that exist and that will be entrusted to us. In September we made a commitment to reform with the presentation of the White Paper and today we are respecting the commitment made, in the terms we made before you. The Commission wants to be judged by the facts, only by the facts, based on what we achieve. I would like to remind you - and this is my final reflection - that the Commission is not the only Community institution. Parliament and the Council are equally called upon to fully accept the challenge of these reforms. The Commission has resolutely opened the way: I hope that all the institutions will follow it to the end, in the service of European citizens, for an ever stronger and ever more transparent Europe. I am pleased to take part in today's debate, together with Commission President Prodi and my colleague Commissioner Schreyer, to present the White Paper "Reforming the Commission" adopted this morning by the Commission itself. As the honourable Members will be able to see by reading the document that will be made available to them today, the consultations (which are an absolute novelty), carried out with Commission staff, with this Parliament and with the Council since January when the consultation document was approved, have been very productive and have resulted in useful improvements.

It is for this reason, esteemed Commission, esteemed Presidency of the Council, that we urge you to seize this political initiative to prevent us from once again finding ourselves in an emergency situation that forces us to restore our ability to pay after a month. On the contrary, we must develop a long-term aid strategy for the region. I hope that you will finally fulfill your political obligations and that the situation we have experienced in recent months will not continue! Mr. President, when the Alliance intervened in Kosovo, it did so with the aim of restoring conditions in that province that would allow those who wished to remain there or return to it, to their roots and their own culture. The Alliance is present on the ground today with the same objective. The day before yesterday, I listened with satisfaction to an interview given by the KFOR commander, who indicated to what extent things were beginning to improve in this regard in Kosovo, to what extent crime rates had returned—particularly in the area of security—to an acceptable level. Those on the ground representing Europe in pursuing this objective—and I am thinking in particular of the Special Representative of the United Nations Secretary-General—are on the verge of discouragement, precisely because, as things are improving, there is less talk about Kosovo and the urgency of the aid that must be provided is less evident. We must work to ensure that in that province, and throughout the Balkan region in general, the era of merchants replaces that of warlords. It is true that financial aid in this regard is undoubtedly an essential element of the possibilities for action that will be offered to those on the ground. I echo here the statement just made to us by Mrs. Pack and I insist that we in the European Parliament must fulfill our responsibilities in this regard, but I ask, of course, that we not be the only ones. Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. Brok, for his report. It is true that if the Council had worked with the same speed as Mr. Brok, we would be further ahead. The Council's delay in this matter is truly unforgivable! The rapporteur and the report rightly assume that we urgently need to provide assistance, although they also rightly point out that this cannot be unlimited or arbitrary aid. I would like to refer specifically to Amendment 5, which unequivocally stipulates that only those Kosovar budgetary needs arising from public, semi-public, municipal, and other administrations and institutions controlled directly or indirectly by UNMIK may be financed from the funds provided by exceptional financial assistance. This must be clear, Commissioner: we support UNMIK, we support the institutions established by the United Nations, paying particular attention to the Fourth Pillar, of course. It is therefore inconceivable that we should support the parallel structures that have been created in Kosovo and that continue to operate in the same way as before.

Therefore, if he has any lessons to teach, they had better be in this House. He knows me well enough to know that at all levels at which we have worked together over the course of five years, there has not been a single occasion when I have refused to respond fully, formally, and in detail to everything I have done. Mr. President, let me begin by paying tribute to Mr. van Hulten for the painful work involved in preparing his report, which, moreover, from what I have heard, has been a suffering he willingly accepted. Although relatively new to this House, he is also relatively experienced in some respects, certainly in his familiarity with the institutions as a former civil servant—and I think the value of this is evident in his skill in dealing with this issue, which, as several Members have said, is of such importance to all our institutions. I thank him and wish him a long and distinguished career as a Member. Mr. President, as you will know, Mr. van Hulten's report on the second report of the Committee of Independent Experts is necessarily long, and since I wish to provide a comprehensive response, particularly on the issues relating to financial management and control, I appeal to your indulgence. Naturally, I will not use the House's time beyond what is absolutely necessary. When this House dealt with the second report of the Committee of Experts last September, on behalf of the incoming Commission, I promised that the report would be considered as one of the key ingredients of the Commission's reform proposals. Our efforts to honor this promise will be evident to this House when we proceed to debate the reform package approved by the Commission today, well within the demanding deadline we set ourselves four months ago. I am sure this will encourage Mr. Pomes Ruiz. Most of the proposals in the document are very similar to those outlined by Mr. van Hulten, and—I address him and Mr. Staes—the document includes a very explicit timeline of the actions to be taken to undertake the reform. There is, therefore, nothing left open or vague about the report I have had the honor of compiling. The perspective of this Parliament in the consultation period of the next four or five weeks will be, for obvious reasons, of great importance. I would say to Mr. Elles that we are definitely in a position to listen. But I am sure he will appreciate—with his customary generosity—that for us to hear the response to what we are proposing, it is necessary that we first transmit what we are proposing. Therefore, here is the transmission. Although time prevents me from commenting before the Assembly on each element of the resolution in this debate, Mr. President, I can immediately assure you that the details will be treated as an important contribution to our reform proposals throughout this consultation period and, certainly, to our work in other relevant areas.

On the other hand, investor protection can often be better ensured by an actively managed fund. Ladies and gentlemen, my Amendment No 47 goes in this direction. As regards the proposal for a new provision that would limit investments in a single group to 15 percent, I would like to point out - apart from the fact that this limit is too low - that the text does not provide any definition of the concept of a group, a concept that does not exist in European law, because it is impossible to implement and equally impossible to control in practice. I will therefore vote against this proposed amendment. In conclusion, Mr President, allow me to remind the honourable Members that, although the directive needs a new look to make UCITS even more attractive, it does not need a European corset that would suffocate them. Mr President, with the advent of the euro and the increasing liberalisation of capital markets, a larger and more solid European financial area has already emerged, which contributes to expanding markets and increasing price transparency, but also to creating fiercer competition. We must also take into account the economic weight of financial transactions, especially those under discussion today. At the end of 1999, there were almost 15,000 investment funds registered as UCITS, with a global value of more than EUR 2 billion, corresponding to approximately 75 percent of all fundraising. The economic weight was therefore rightly put in the foreground by the Commission also in its proposals for draft directives, and I must say that the Commission's proposal seemed particularly convincing to me. We all know how difficult it is to improve the regulatory framework for investment funds, and how difficult it is to also define the European passport for management companies on the basis of specific criteria that are interpreted by everyone in the same way. The proposal therefore represents progress in terms of the rules and provisions for monitoring financial markets and products. I also believe that the main aim must be maximum consumer protection, and I think it is very important that this is explicitly stated in the Commission's proposal, in the European Parliament's proposal, and in the compromise proposals. As regards OTC products and derivatives, I believe that it is not possible to assess the risk inherent in them, and I think that the European Parliament should let consumers know this. They think that investment funds are comparable to traditional savings instruments and that they can offer long-term security, so much so that they were also known as investment and savings funds. The European Parliament must continue to explain that these are different things, and for this reason a minimum level of protection is necessary. Why not take inspiration from the system of minimum protection contained in the Securities Trading Directive, for example that of Article 11, relating to fair conduct? In my opinion, this is therefore another step forward that we can take; it would be appropriate if consumers and investors could already get an idea of its risk structure based on the name of a fund.

We should also judge the Lisbon Summit in the light of its contribution to achieving this objective. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, do you know how Archimedes expounded his theory of leverage? He said: "Give me a fulcrum and I will move the world". Clearly, in Lisbon you will try to move the world, or at least our world: the European world. As for leverage, you have described all its mechanisms in the course of your enthusiastic speech, which was enthralling in many ways. The fulcrum remains. The fulcrum is the means. Well, you are now before an Assembly which includes many Members who still have a vivid memory of what I would call the White Paper syndrome, a formidable initiative by Jacques Delors which crashed into the accountants of ECOFIN. And we would not want you to have the same misfortune today, because the project you are offering us is so exciting that it could really revitalise Europe, giving it the future that our colleague Goebbels reminded us of. But we need to have the means: means that, I fear, you are sorely lacking today. It is up to you to create them, then. And it is certainly not from the Agenda 2000 corset that the necessary resources will emerge. You will therefore have to persuade your colleagues to ensure that the proposals that are addressed to us are actually financed. One example among others - and relating to a relevant aspect of what you are proposing - is that of the information and knowledge society. It is clear - and you have illustrated it adequately - that the social divide is a problem against which we must fight. But we must be careful not to add to it what I would call the digital divide. In fact, to whom do you intend to propose this information and knowledge society?
