To an increasingly older or increasingly senescent population, to a population that remains, despite everything, poor and to a population, alas, increasingly less educated. It will therefore be necessary to intervene at the base, if we do not want this knowledge society to turn into a race for profit by a few start-ups as dynamic as they are necessary. But that is not your objective. In the device that you have envisaged there is an absence, which I deplore: that of public services. In the history of our European social model, public services have played an essential role. Today, in fact, it is no longer the time of monopolies and the Commission has initiated a process of liberalisation, of opening up to competition in a series of public sectors with the aim of making them more modern and efficient. But we cannot stop there. We must now define more precisely, in the context of competition and the information society, what will be tomorrow's main public service functions required of public companies, but also of private operators in that same sector. In this respect, more incisive initiatives will be needed, which are not yet included in the Commission's work programme, but which you could promote: this would, in my view, be an extremely important signal. Finally, the knowledge society is based on research and development; in this context, I would like to welcome the Commission's initiative to create a European research area.

The measures envisaged in this resolution are, however, derisory in their attempt to stop the policies of large industrial groups that are cutting jobs and increasing unemployment. Moreover, these are only words, because socialist governments, which are in the majority in Europe, are just as incapable as right-wing governments of taking the necessary measures to prevent layoffs. The real problem is not finding legal arrangements that further complicate layoff procedures, but to prohibit them. The only way to stop this infernal mechanism that produces financial surplus value on the one hand and unemployment on the other is to prohibit layoffs in all large companies that make a profit, under penalty of expropriation, and to make the accounts of large companies public and subject them to the control of their workers and the entire population. Society must have the means to impose its own priorities on large companies and their owners, including, first and foremost, the eradication of unemployment. The sums needed to create useful jobs in public services, as well as to finance the distribution of work among all, without a reduction in wages, must be taken from the profits of large companies. This is infinitely more important for the majority of society than waste in financial operations, or the scandalous enrichment of a minority of large shareholders. I cannot support this resolution, because in point 8 it mentions the case of an Italian factory which it is hoped will be preserved, while at the same time, the current management of the company is advised to try to sell the factory to a European tire manufacturer. It is not for the European Parliament to say which factories in the fifteen Member States of the European Union should be preserved or closed, in which workforces should be increased or reduced, whether to maintain their current location or relocate them, whether to sell or not sell, or, if necessary, to decide whether they should be sold inside or outside Europe. Ultimately, these are areas of competence in which the European Parliament and its Members do not have the legal power to change a given decision, nor do they even have in-depth knowledge of the situation in the factory concerned. The Swedish Christian Democrats reiterate that it is important that the European Union and the European Parliament devote themselves to their basic mission and do not weaken the value of their action in these areas by exceeding their competences. Potential of tourism for employment The next item is the joint debate on the report (A50030/2000) by Mr Viceconte, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, on the Commission communication: "Increasing the potential of tourism for employment - Follow-up to the conclusions and recommendations of the High Level Group on Tourism and Employment" [COM(1999)0205 - C5-0112/1999 - 1999/2115(COS)]. , rapporteur.

We need a streamlined approach to tourism, one that covers all policies. I am confident that we will make progress on this in the future, when we have a good report from the High-Level Working Group, the support of this House's report, and also when the tourism sector comes back into the spotlight of enterprise policy. Why is this so important in this sector? Because, in enterprise policy, the main focus will be on helping new businesses to start up, on making it easier for young people to start their own businesses. That is where the potential lies. If we can remove barriers and lower the cost of starting a business, make it easier to access finance, and change the attitude of society so that it has a more positive entrepreneurial spirit, I am sure that the tourism sector will be the first to benefit. This is one issue that I hesitate to mention today because I am new to this sector. I have worked in all sectors of industry and services, but when you look at the organizational structure of the tourism sector, it is almost impossible. It is very difficult for a Commissioner to try to work in a sector with dozens of organizations whose representativeness must be checked every time. To strengthen the role of tourism in Europe, organizations should do what has been done in most economic sectors: seek better convergence, better coordination, and concentration of activities. We could then begin a serious dialogue in our daily work. This is the main difficulty we need to overcome. As for the Treaty, the Intergovernmental Conference started this week, so we do not yet know the results. I want to be very frank: I have not noted a great deal of enthusiasm for this Conference or for the proposal to expand the EU's powers. Tourism is also on the list of subjects that are not among the new areas of competence for the EU. We will see what happens, but for the time being, that does not seem to be the case. Finally, the Commission welcomes the resolution that aligns with the High-Level Group, the Commission's communication on increasing the employment potential of tourism, and the related Council conclusions. The general agreement reached between the two institutions in this area should not prevent the Commission from following the most pragmatic approach to achieving our common objectives. Thank you very much, Commissioner. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 9 a.m. (The sitting adjourned at 11:45 a.m.) Adoption of the minutes of the previous sitting The minutes of yesterday's sitting have been distributed. Are there any comments? Mr President, naturally, the minutes of yesterday's sitting will have included the speeches relating to the so-called "Strasbourg Declaration" aimed at implicating this European Parliament in considerations which, literally, come to the conclusion that this MEP is a Nazi. The declaration - which, as I say, implicates the European Parliament, although such a declaration was not made before the European Parliament - is a completely unacceptable manipulation.

There must be a willingness to cooperate. If, in a certain sense, it should not be understood as an obligation, but as a willingness, a possibility, that each country should take advantage of, then this approach is the right one. If we look at FYROM/Macedonia, we will see that with some neighboring countries this cooperation, for example, in economic matters, is very complicated, as with Kosovo and Albania, or is difficult from a political point of view, as, for example, with Yugoslavia. On the other hand, collaboration with Bulgaria and, in particular, with Greece, has developed positively, which also deserves our recognition. In this context, the European Union must reflect—it began to do so at the beginning of this week—on how it can, despite everything, include neighboring Yugoslavia without overlooking any criticism of this terrible regime of regional cooperation. Therefore, tomorrow I will submit an amendment in which we declare ourselves in favor of sanctions being imposed on the regime and, on the other hand, nevertheless alleviating the situation of the population and the economy through economic cooperation. In this regard, I am grateful—and I allow myself to mention it here, given that I am from a country through which the Danube flows—for the reflections put forward by the Commission, that is, by Commissioner Patten, but also by Vice-President Palacio, with whom I recently met in Budapest, on the possibility of making the Danube navigable again, thereby promoting a minimum economic recovery in this region, which would undoubtedly also be important for Romania. In my opinion, this regional approach, if I have understood it correctly, that is, as a method of contributing in some way to the economic recovery of the region, is the right approach. As I have already said, it cannot be interpreted as an obligation nor imposed as a precondition. Secondly, I would like to make it clear that we want FYROM/Macedonia to be opened up and offered the path to the European Union. We maintain that it is illusory to believe that it would be appropriate to submit the application for membership now, but we also consider it wrong to say that we will discuss it someday. FYROM/Macedonia wants the answer that, in principle, it will have the opportunity to do so when the time is right. The country fears being somewhat abandoned on a dead end. In the complete reorganization of support instruments, it sees no danger in being the last carriage on a train heading towards Europe, but rather in that train continuing towards Europe and Macedonia ending up on a dead end. But I believe Commissioner Patten will show understanding for the problem. I urge him to make this point clear in the discussions in which he participates. Third: In my opinion, FYROM/Macedonia has shown so far, beyond any doubt, that it is capable of making good use of the instruments at its disposal. Although, of course, changes will occur, FYROM/Macedonia will continue to demonstrate that many of the tasks currently being addressed in Brussels can be undertaken in the future in Skopje, in the country itself.

However, it was agreed that other points could be included, which is why the representative of the northern part of the island, Rauf Denktas, proposed three new topics: the question of sovereignty, the question of confidence-building measures and the lifting of the embargo on products from the north of the island. Two main developments have emerged from the discussions held so far: first, the possibility of establishing a direct information channel between the European Union and the northern part of the island - without this necessarily implying its recognition as an entity with legal personality at international level - which aims to facilitate the adoption of a Community acquis for the possible accession of the whole island, should a solution to the global problem of the division of the island be found in the meantime. The second development, which we consider important, is the statement made by the Secretary-General of the United Nations at the end of the first day of the talks, in which he stated that if a global settlement of the situation were to be reached, this would imply recognition of the specificities of the north of the island. This is the position taken by the Secretary-General of the United Nations and it is an element that we will have to take into account in our future analyses. There are many expectations regarding the third round of negotiations, given the scenarios that are emerging and in which the intervention of representatives of the United States and the United Kingdom is contemplated, particularly in the area of security and the constitutional framework. It is expected that these issues will be addressed in this round of negotiations with the mediation of the Representative of the Secretary-General of the United Nations, which should take place after the elections in the north of the island, scheduled for 18 April. The Portuguese Presidency of the European Union has decided, among other things, following the example of choices made by previous Presidencies, to appoint a representative to maintain contact with the various parties involved. This representative has already contacted the parties and is following, in close connection with the Representative of the Secretary-General of the United Nations, the work of the various rounds of negotiations. In particular, it is our intention to maintain a constant presence of the European Union in this area, especially, of course, since Cyprus is a candidate for accession to the European Union on the basis of a rather advanced negotiation process, which naturally raises many expectations and ensures that the European Union has a significant role in this context. The approach followed in the discussion and our participation in the discussion itself have been marked, in principle, by taking advantage of a certain easing of the climate of tension, due to the conviction, apparently shared, that it is necessary to continue negotiating and that the continuation of the negotiations and the maintenance of the expected pace represent in themselves an essential element of hope for reaching a final solution. There is still another important element, which I already mentioned at the beginning of my speech, which concerns Turkey's commitment to contribute to the preparation of the accession of the north of the island. We are of the opinion that it is not enough to read carefully and cautiously the conclusions of the Helsinki European Council, but that we must also verify what might be the willingness of the Turkish authorities to contribute to the solution of the issue.

It simply offers, and only where certain requirements directly related to the activity are required, the possibility of selection. This is, therefore, positive discrimination. In the example you have given, in the Catholic school, it seems logical that the teachers should be Catholic. Only this type of exception can be accepted. Question No. 41 by (H-0813/99): Subject: Employment promotion for women in highly disadvantaged areas. In view of the enormous difficulties women face in accessing employment in some highly disadvantaged areas, and taking into account that they very often lack the minimum economic capital, a business or cooperative tradition, or training facilities, and live in rural areas where the poverty line affects up to 80% of the population, what measures or actions are planned to enable these women to overcome the social barriers in their environment? Will the Commission propose minimum policies appropriate to these extreme but real situations? Will these women once again be left out of the new employment policies? - (EL) It is clear that for the most disadvantaged areas of Europe, there is cohesion policy, and for cohesion policy, there is the collaboration and joint action of the Structural Funds, the European Social Fund, and the Agricultural Fund. It must be said that the resources available for troubled regions represent a third of the total budget. These regional policies, which are implemented, following commonly agreed guidelines, of course, in each of the Member States—that is, each country is responsible for implementing this program—pursue the objective of increasing job opportunities for both men and women. We must point out that 70% of the funding for the period 2000-2006, which amounts to €195 billion, will be granted to the most disadvantaged regions of Europe. Turning specifically to the issue of women's access to the opportunities that arise, it must be said, first, that the European Social Fund includes a whole line of action, which must be implemented by the Member States, that relates to equal opportunities, that is, specific policies for which Social Fund funds must be used and which concern women. Second, the LEADER initiative, which is currently still under review, gives special priority to development strategies that propose specific support for women in small businesses in the agricultural sector and in rural tourism, with the aim of increasing women's participation and involvement in rural areas. Thank you, Commissioner, for your well-intentioned response, delivered with rigor, which I value in its terms. However, I assure you that, with the existing resources—to which you refer—we are not reaching these very disadvantaged areas. Because these are areas where the deprivation overlaps, and we must compare them with the areas where we work in cooperation, where there is almost nothing. Therefore, my question is whether you could study the possibility that some of the microcredit policies, which have been successful in cooperation, could also be applied to these women in very disadvantaged areas, where everything is against them.

The aim of the current regime was to eradicate ISA as quickly as possible. The reality is that the policy of forced culling has failed to contain, much less eradicate, ISA. While the current regime has failed to achieve its objective, it has had devastating economic consequences for the industry, without any compensation or commercial insurance. Two main changes are proposed. The first concerns the authorization of vaccination as a weapon in this fight. This is a necessary change that should be accompanied by efforts at the European level to initiate and fund research to develop an effective vaccine. The second proposed amendment proposes a gradual culling of fish from infected farms, based on the severity of the disease on each farm. This strategy has proven very effective in Norway, where the number of new cases has declined to a handful per year, following a peak of 80 to 90 cases per year in the early 1990s. I therefore support the amendments proposed by the Commission and call for their immediate adoption and implementation. I also draw attention to the issue of compensation and call for an amendment to Council Decision 90/424/EEC to explicitly include ISA in the annexed list of diseases. This will allow compensation to be paid 50% by the Member State concerned and 50% by the European Commission. I thank my colleagues in the Committee on Fisheries for their overwhelming support for my report, and I particularly thank my Scottish colleagues on the committee for their valuable input. I reject Amendments 7 to 13, which were also firmly rejected by the Committee on Fisheries. They are either largely superfluous or already included in my text. I have highlighted in particular the need to investigate the extent of any interaction between farmed and wild salmon, to research the causes of ISA, and to test wild stocks more extensively for the virus. These amendments, tabled by the Greens in the Green/European Free Alliance Group, are intended to provide justification for Amendment 13. This amendment is completely unacceptable and inappropriate, as it not only seeks to maintain the immediate compulsory culling of all fish, but also prevents the sale of fish from infected farms, whether infected or not, and I must stress that, under current policy, no infected fish will be put on sale. There is no proposal to change this, and under the proposed new rules, the sale of infected fish is completely out of the question. Amendments 7 to 13 completely ignore the reality, which is reflected in the stark contrast between the situation in Scotland and that in Norway. Scotland has a draconian regime in place, but it has failed to achieve its objective. In Norway, where they have considerably more experience, 100% eradication was abolished years ago, and thanks to a series of measures, the situation has improved immensely. It is in all of our interests that we succeed in containing ISA in Scotland and preventing its further spread.

During a recent visit to Brussels, the duly accredited representatives of these fishermen traveled from Northern Ireland and were threatened with exclusion from the meeting when they sought to plead their case, which they had prepared very well. This is scandalous; attention must be paid to their case. This must be stated publicly, and I want to state it publicly. I was at the meeting where the scientists told us that haddock would disappear from the Irish Sea, and at this very time, haddock reproduction was experiencing a particular and dramatic increase in the Irish Sea. So the scientists could be wrong. As I said, all parties in Northern Ireland agree on this issue, and those responsible for this cod quota regulation should reconsider this decision, the consequence of which can only be the ruin of the fishing industry in Northern Ireland, not the conservation of fish, which will affect all fishing industries in this Union. Mr President, the reports by our colleague, Mrs Attwooll, are of great importance, as is the availability of as much data as possible on the Member States' fishing sectors, especially as the Commission approaches its obligation to draw up a report on the review of the Common Fisheries Policy in 2002. However, the fact that these updating and submission obligations are merely optional and relate to very different data and sectors may distort the ultimate objective of the Commission's proposal. Thus, as has already been pointed out here, it has been shown that, within the framework of the MAGPs, countries that have complied with them to the letter and submitted their data to the Commission have been significantly disadvantaged compared to those that have not complied with them or simply have not provided such data. It should also be pointed out that not all Member States have the same amount of data. Some people have different sectors and, given the volume of data they have to submit, they might feel disadvantaged compared to those with a smaller volume if they are given the same deadlines. Therefore, we believe it is necessary to adjust these submission deadlines. As has already been pointed out here, much of this data is also confidential because it concerns the very competitiveness of the sectors involved and their companies. We must therefore act with great caution in this area and guarantee the confidentiality of this data. Some of it is inappropriate, as has also been pointed out, particularly that relating to business taxation. In any case, Mr President, and since I do not want to go on any further, aware of the time constraints, I would like to congratulate our rapporteur, Mrs Attwooll, on the considerable work she has done in our committee. I would like, in turn, to congratulate Mrs Attwooll and say that I agree with most of what she has said. I consider it a weakness of the proposal that reporting is not mandatory in all Member States. I cannot understand a proposal to establish a regulation that some Member States could dodge without incurring a fine, nor can I understand that within a European Union that is only 50% self-sufficient in fisheries matters, there is highly sensitive information and that by drawing up the necessary reports, the national or regional interests of certain states or fishing communities are being put at risk.

This is essential for the correct and reliable determination of deficits. This adjustment will enable a more precise assessment of deficits and debt levels in the Member States. This technical adjustment will have very concrete effects on the actual situation of the countries, as the data will be automatically adjusted according to the government deficit. I also welcome the fact that the assessment of deficits for the 1999 financial year, to be published in March 2000, is already being prepared according to the new ESA, which means that the analysis will be based on consolidated aggregates that are relevant from an economically significant point of view. However, let me also briefly use this debate to appeal to all governments and political parties to do everything possible to ensure that the excessive deficit procedure never has to be initiated. It is good that the procedure exists. The procedure is necessary because it gives our criteria the necessary seriousness and credibility. Citizens are asking: what if the criteria are not met? With these procedures and other measures, we can demonstrate that we are serious about the criteria and about ourselves. A second essential point is the question of whether we must do everything in our power not only to prevent excessive deficits, but also to further reduce public deficits. I know what I'm talking about, and let me conclude by saying why I'm so glad we're having this debate! In my own country, we're currently having a debate about whether the figures given by the former finance minister about the deficit actually reflect reality. In my own country, Austria, new elections were necessary in 1995 to meet the Maastricht criteria and to persuade our political partners to rethink their position. I must also say that in 2000, when so much is being said about us, the coalition negotiations with the SPÖ—I say, unfortunately—failed because the negotiated austerity and consolidation program was overturned by the Socialist Party. Not least of all, the new government had to be formed in Austria because the ÖVP wants to continue to be a guarantor of the stability course, because the ÖVP wants to continue to ensure compliance with the Maastricht criteria and the reduction of the public deficit, as we have agreed here. Mr. President, it is gratifying when statistical data are not only reliable but also comparable. This is of great importance, above all, for European integration and the completion of the internal market. That is why we have before us a politically substantial report, for which we sincerely congratulate the rapporteur. The report also gives rise to a number of political observations. The Stability Pact is a fact in Europe. With this Stability Pact, all countries participating in the euro have committed themselves to striving for a budget that is balanced or has a small surplus in the medium term. This does not mean, of course, that it cannot be somewhat more or less in the event of an unfavorable economic trend, but in the long and medium term, there must be a balance or a surplus. The more consolidated the position of the participating countries becomes, the stronger the euro will be. This means that exceeding the three percent norm will rarely occur, even under unfavorable economic conditions, or so the argument goes.

The Atlantic coast's two most important resources, fishing and tourism, are both severely affected. The season will most likely be loss-making, which would lead to a serious crisis at the end of the year. It is therefore entirely justified for our Parliament to adopt a new resolution, to which our group has made a very substantial contribution. It highlights several points that are considered to be of absolute priority on the ground. The first is that the polluter must accept full responsibility. Our resolution calls for the application of two principles. First, the principle that the polluter must pay for clean-up, because it is unacceptable that the clean-up of coastal areas polluted by a tanker's cargo should be borne not by the owner of the cargo, but by the local authorities, the taxpayers, the victims. Second, the application of the polluter pays principle. The polluter's responsibility, our resolution calls for, must also extend to fishing, marine culture, and aquaculture companies. This is of fundamental importance and implies that the polluter cannot limit the amount of compensation paid to those affected by the ceiling set by FIPOL, that is, at the arbitrary discretion of the major oil companies. If the FIPOL ceiling is insufficient—and it is clearly too low—it must be increased. This is also what our resolution calls for. If the increase is still insufficient, the polluter must bear the remaining damage himself. It would be highly unjust for an oil company, which has made 10 billion francs in profits this year, to refuse to pay 100% compensation to its victims, the vast majority of whom are small businesses and employees. The suffering population, Commissioner, awaits concrete signs of solidarity at Community level. Our resolution calls on the Commission to take the necessary measures to help repair the damage in the fishing sector affected by the disaster. Blue Europe, the CFP, must make it clear today that, in addition to the constraints they impose on fishermen, solidarity is not an empty phrase for them. The European Union must also contribute to restoring the natural environment in the affected wetlands and coastal zones, which are of biological importance to the Union as a whole. Mr Fischler has just announced that he will welcome requests from France, which I can only welcome. We must play a pioneering role on this important issue of marine pollution. Twenty years after the Amoco Cadix disaster, negligence and irresponsibility still prevail in Europe, with new oil spills as a result. This time, inertia must be overcome. A general framework for maritime safety must be established without delay, taking into account the principle of subsidiarity, and the vicious circle of widespread irresponsibility must be put to an end. Mr President, the economy of the French Atlantic coast has been seriously damaged by the oil pollution resulting from the Erika accident. Fishermen, shellfish farmers, oyster farmers, tourism operators and local and regional authorities are eagerly awaiting aid and the removal of the wreck, which is apparently still leaking oil and is therefore a veritable time bomb.

The truth is that the European Parliament still fails to earn the trust or even the interest of national public opinion, which persists in not thinking about Europe, as evidenced by the level of abstention in the recent elections. Therefore, what is needed is to strengthen the mechanisms used for cooperation between the governments of the Member States, giving them greater coherence, transparency, and a more democratic character. We welcome Romano Prodi's efforts to improve the Commission's public reputation and the need for it to reach agreement with the EP and the Council. However, we believe that the priority should be the reform of the mechanisms for governmental cooperation, particularly through the creation of a Council of Ministers for Europe which, in coordination with each other and with the other European institutions, would be responsible for transforming the political decisions of the European Councils into concrete actions. Corrie Report (A5-0032/2000) Madam President, the work of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly in 1999 was marked by increased concern about the continuity of the cooperation model resulting from the Lomé Agreements. Already in 1994, through an initial resolution that enjoyed the broad participation of our colleague Domique Souchet, the Joint Assembly expressed alarm at the foreseeable consequences of the Uruguay Round, which had come into conflict with the very principle of Community preference, which is essential for such cooperation. For the past two years, these fears have materialized. The banana dispute is the clearest expression of this. Developing countries are being asked to adapt to trade liberalization, despite the fragility of their economies. While Mr. Corrie's report rightly denounces this situation and reaffirms the Joint Assembly's commitment to the Lomé model, it does not sufficiently emphasize a second problem, which, in fact, also stems from the free trade error: the inconsistency of the regional trade agreements concluded by the European Union. The Cooperation Agreement with South Africa is the best example of this. The Council approved this agreement, negotiated by the Commission, when even the agricultural chapter, which is essential, was not finalized. As our colleague Paul-Marie Coûteaux rightly pointed out in his speech yesterday and in his proposed amendments, one wonders what the political coherence of this blank check is. This is very worrying, especially when a similar agreement seems to be on the horizon with Mexico. Nor can we support the rapporteur when he calls for the incorporation of the European Development Fund into the Community budget. We wish to maintain the clear commitment and responsibility of each Member State that the intergovernmental nature allows. Unfortunately, there are too many examples of collective aid being diverted for which no one feels responsible, and we do not want to extend this disastrous system to the EDF. Madam President, I welcome Mr. Corrie's report because it represents a balanced assessment of the work carried out by the Assembly over the past year. The report comes to us just after an agreement was reached on the renewal of the current Lomé Convention, which expires at the end of this month.

There is no freedom without rules. We have ruled out so-called master-feeder structures. These feeder funds exist in the United States, but in an area with only one supervisory authority and a single jurisdiction. In the still fragmented European market, such structures would inevitably create problems. The Socialists, like the Commission, doubt the advisability of authorizing investment funds to also invest in so-called over-the-counter derivatives, products traded over-the-counter between professionals. Since these operations are generally not subject to prudential supervision, the risks are all the more obvious. In order to control the risks for investors, the Socialist Group has introduced amendments proposing safeguard clauses, both quantitative and qualitative. By adopting these amendments, Parliament will authorize the use of OTC derivatives, while limiting the risks for private investors. Mr. President, there is currently much talk about the principle of good governance. This principle should guide not only the public sector, but also the private sector, particularly financial companies. Mr. President, the objective we are pursuing in creating a framework for SICAVs and other UCITS is to ensure investors the best and safest possible return. This is why I want to address the issue of derivatives in my speech. I firmly believe that, used prudently, derivatives can provide safer and higher returns. Despite the risky image they inspire, derivatives are usually used by portfolio managers as a shield. A contract that pays out, for example, a large sum if the NASDAQ or CAC 40 stock index falls, results in an additional payment from the investor if it rises. Is this speculation? Absolutely not. Imagine that you have spent several months building a portfolio of shares in companies you have confidence in: they are well managed, have good prospects, and represent a worthwhile investment. Then you fear the occurrence of a stock market collapse as a whole, like the one in 1987. You have the option of liquidating everything for cash, but that would mean ruining the fruit of your research in favor of the winners. It would also involve all the transaction costs incurred by selling your shares and then buying them back after the market crash. The solution is to turn to a derivative that pays off in the event of a fall in the NASDAQ or the CAC 40. But a custom-made or over-the-counter derivative, which is less expensive and perhaps protects you against a relative loss of your portfolio compared to the index, still allows you to keep your portfolio and the shares, but also to protect you against the risks of a collapse. In exchange, you also give up the risks of market increases. In this case, which is perhaps the most common among portfolio managers who own derivatives, you reduce your potential gains but also your potential risks. This is a desirable development for a well-managed fund. Experience shows that investors benefit from a liberal and flexible approach to regulation.

(The sitting, adjourned at 1:05 p.m., resumed at 3:00 p.m.) Oil spill in France The next item is the Commission statement on the oil spill in France. I now give the floor, on behalf of the Commission, to Mrs. de Palacio to open the debate. Mr. President, I am speaking on behalf of the EPP, but also in my capacity as an elected Breton, directly affected and appalled by these events. Together with Françoise Grossetête and the EPP, we have tabled a motion for a resolution. Here we are today with a compromise motion, which I am pleased about. The sinking of the Erika is truly a European issue, on the one hand, because it mutilates and litters some of the most beautiful European beaches, with very serious consequences for tourism, seafarers, and environmentalists, and on the other, because what is at stake is regulation and control, which have a clear European dimension. Such a catastrophe, almost certainly, would not have occurred off the coast of the United States. Why? Because the Americans learned the lesson of the Exxon Valdez disaster and because in 1990 they enacted the Oil Pollution Act, which has a broader scope of responsibilities, because it can involve the liability of the charterer, is more binding, and above all, is better controlled through various regulations and, in particular, due to the existence of the United States Coast Guard. Without such provisions, I repeat, the catastrophe would undoubtedly not have occurred. That is why we believe it is necessary to review the applicable texts and, in particular, the 1992 protocol, which has exonerated charterers, in this case the chartering tanker, from all liability. However, if the charterer is exonerated, it will certainly be less involved in the controls that are the responsibility of the oil companies. Therefore, the regulations must be reviewed, and I thank you, Commissioner, for pointing out all the current shortcomings of the European provisions. Furthermore, as you have said, we must above all strengthen controls: controls by the flag state and those of the classification societies. You have told us that RINA is an Italian classification registry recognized by the Commission. Under what conditions is this recognition carried out? What are the guarantees of reliability? The Commission will send a mission. We await the results with great interest. We must also strengthen controls by maritime authorities and controls in European ports. It should be remembered that there is a Paris Memorandum that requires a minimum of controls: a quarter of the ships calling at European ports must be controlled by the maritime authorities of the country in question. This obligation is not respected either in France or in many other European countries. Why is this? What consequences has the Commission drawn or intends to draw from this situation? I also consider it necessary to strengthen the control of the charterer, in this case, the oil tanker.

Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Commissioner Patten and express my appreciation for the remarks he has made here today, in particular in relation to the role of the European Union in the peace process, and for reiterating that our role is not just that of "banker" to the whole operation. I was deeply disappointed to hear this week about the suspension of talks between Israel and Syria. I very much hope that a compromise can be found to overcome this obstacle so that peace negotiations can resume as soon as possible. However, we cannot deny that some positive political progress has been made in the Middle East recently. The fact that, for the first time in their respective histories, the Syrian Foreign Minister and the Israeli Prime Minister recently sat around the same table in the United States is a sign that old hatreds and animosities can be overcome. Political leaders must show real courage to create conditions that can lead to a comprehensive peaceful solution in the Middle East. I know that even if an agreement between Syria and Israel is possible, the Israeli Prime Minister will still face strong opposition to any new agreement with Syria in any future referendum. The settlers in the Golan Heights will demand compensation and security guarantees will have to be provided. If Syria is willing to offer concessions on the security issue, the prospects for a successful resolution of the Israel/Syria issue could be promising. On the Palestine issue, I recognize that there are still some difficulties in implementing certain aspects of the Wye Plantation agreement. The main problems at present include the difficulties of troop withdrawal, as well as the transfer of land. The small number of Palestinian prisoners released and the fact that the Israeli Government appears to be willing to suspend work on building permits already granted, as well as to refuse to issue new permits, pose further obstacles. These issues have clearly slowed down any progress in the negotiations on the final status, although I believe these talks cannot be postponed indefinitely. For the time being, the main difficulty in negotiating seems to be that the Palestinians insist that the border issue must be agreed upon first, while the Israeli government says that it should be settled only after the settlement and security issues have been resolved. Currently, both sides seem to have recognized that nothing will be agreed upon until everything is agreed upon. In conclusion, while other countries in the Middle East have expressed reservations about the overall direction of the peace process, now that the Syrian government has been involved, Egypt and other countries in the region are willing to move forward. I sincerely hope that, in the interest of improving the security and quality of life of the people living in the Middle East, all key players will move forward quickly in the immediate future so as to reach a comprehensive agreement on all the key issues that need to be resolved.

As for the questions and problems raised by the Members, I have summarized them in four areas. First, the expansion of the thematic areas. There are four, as in the employment strategy: employability, entrepreneurship, adaptability, and equal opportunities. We agree with the expansion of these thematic areas in accordance with the proposals put forward by Parliament. Furthermore, the concern has been expressed that a country might use all of its resources for only one of the categories affected by discrimination. I would like to respond to this by saying that the initiative clearly states that Member States must propose a thematic action for each group affected by discrimination. The second point is flexibility and simplification. I agree with Ms. Lynne—the initiative is truly written in very complicated and extremely cumbersome language. The services are therefore already in the process of reviewing the text, streamlining it, and making it more understandable. As far as flexibility is concerned, we propose development partnerships and cooperation, both at the geographical level, where different groups in a specific geographical area work together to eliminate discrimination in the labor market, and at the thematic level, meaning that cooperation can take place, for example, in a specific economic sector. Member States have considerable scope here to adapt development partnerships to their own particular circumstances. This is, of course, conditional on effective cooperation between Member States and on networking to promote the exchange of experience. Finally, I would like to mention technical assistance. We are endeavoring to ensure that four aspects can be financially supported: first, preparation; second, implementation; third, interoperability to encourage the exchange of experience; and fourth, technical assistance. Since there have been numerous comments on this topic and considerable interest in how technical assistance is provided, I would like to point out that external offices will be used for this purpose. As Mr Barnier has already explained, Commission staff cannot handle all the work that has previously been done by external staff alone. The aim is to set up large action groups at national and European level, to be put out to tender, and to obtain a full description of the project requiring external assistance and a detailed description of the product we expect from the TAO, so that the work can be monitored and evaluated. Let me stress the importance of pushing ahead with this initiative as quickly as possible, both in view of the political circumstances and because we consider it essential that it get off to a good start and that we are therefore fully prepared by the end of 2000. Thank you very much, Commissioner. I will convey to my colleagues in the Bureau and the relevant committees your wish for the rapporteurs to be appointed promptly for the dossiers you have mentioned. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon. (The sitting closed at 8.40 p.m.) Approval of the minutes of the two previous sittings The minutes of the sittings of Thursday, 3 February, and Monday, 14 February, have been distributed. The minutes of February 3 have already been distributed in Brussels. Perhaps that's why some colleagues haven't received them yet.

Water is a renewable and limited natural resource. It becomes scarce when it is not well managed and when geographical and climatic conditions are unfavorable. In the Union, this issue is of decisive importance in the Mediterranean region, but also in other European countries, where we are witnessing the progressive drying up of wetlands. Delicate, humid, or arid zones, inequalities between States, inequalities between different regions within States, climatic, economic, geographical, and geological specificities—these are all examples we wish to highlight, but which should not, however, lead to distortions of competition within the Community. However, we have tabled amendments to emphasize the importance of the specific relationship between agriculture and water, a key factor in land use and valorization. There is no doubt that the needs of agriculture in the South are far greater, so this framework directive must take this specificity into account. Furthermore, solutions to these problems are not only being sought in the Member States of the Union: in October, the countries of the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership in Turin resolutely called for a Marshall Plan for water on the southern shore of the Mediterranean. Fortunately, we are not in that situation. However, in Europe there are droughts, desertification in certain regions, but also floods, as the directive clearly underlines. We have recently experienced them in France, and also in the Rhine Valley and Central Europe. We need this framework directive as an essential element of a sustainable development policy, which must make the different uses of water compatible. But it is necessary to integrate the protection and conservation of biodiversity into this new management. In any case, the water issue will not be concluded today. Indeed, the issue of enlargement and climate change open up new perspectives. Mr. President, good-quality water may acquire even greater strategic importance than oil in this century. This is reason enough to thank Ms. Lienemann for her dedication to maintaining surface waters in good condition. Adopting an appropriate European legislative framework seems rather complicated. With the Water Framework Directive, we aim to put an end to the dispersion of legislation on this matter across the Union. However, despite everything, we have not been able to prevent the directive from being long and complicated. This requires the bodies responsible for its implementation to be very careful in its application. In particular, we must take advantage of the possibilities offered by the river basin approach to implement a specific policy by Member States and bodies responsible for water management. The most important objectives remain combating surface and groundwater pollution, protecting ecosystems, promoting sustainable water use, combating floods and droughts, and ending the discharge of hazardous substances into surface waters. Regarding the discharge of substances into surface waters, I believe the Council's objectives are too uncommitted and too unambitious. I find the current proposal from the Environment Committee to reduce discharges to near-zero levels commendable and worthy of support.

Thirdly, we welcome the fact that the common position has introduced, for the first time, the development and regional planning of coastal areas among the priorities of LIFE "environment". However, Mr President, Members of the European Parliament, despite all its merits, the LIFE III regulation fails in the area which is necessarily the most important for a financial instrument: its budget. By maintaining their proposal of EUR 613 million as the reference amount for the period 2000-2004 and by not taking into account the European Parliament's proposal of EUR 850 million, the Commission and the Council are taking a decision which, in our view, no longer meets the fair and rational criteria which they had rightly introduced into the other provisions of LIFE III. As far as we are concerned, the Commission and the Council should know that we will not abandon our intention to provide LIFE with the budget it deserves and which best guarantees the environmental results which such an instrument aims to achieve. We justify our opinion on the basis of four very simple arguments. First, LIFE is the only direct financial instrument intended to promote the environment in the European Union. There is no other. Second, LIFE is an instrument that has produced good results, has enabled the development of innovative methods and techniques, and its implementation rate is excellent. Third, the LIFE budget has declined in real terms and has not kept pace with the dynamism and creativity of demand. Fourth, given the credit it grants to LIFE, the European Parliament has earmarked increasingly large allocations for this programme in its annual budget. Therefore, approval of the proposal put forward by the Commission and the Council would lead to an unacceptable reversal of this trend. However, our concern is not only about the budgetary issue. Climate change and water policy are issues of great concern to European citizens and have received sustained attention from the European Parliament. This is why, in our view, it is essential to approve our Amendments 5 and 6, which aim to make the sustainable management of groundwater and surface water, as well as the reduction of greenhouse gases, objectives of LIFE "environment". A final word to congratulate Mrs Lienemann on her report and to inform her that we will vote in favour of her amendments on comitology, because, although we prefer, as has become clear in the Environment Committee, that LIFE be monitored by an advisory committee, we do not wish to contribute to the adoption of the Council's solution, which is decidedly less good. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, LIFE is the most important instrument, the only financial instrument, in fact, of the European Union that is exclusively devoted to the environment. This shows that this tool must be equal to our ambitions, ambitions that come at a price, of course.

But, regardless of that, we would like to emphasize that strengthening the coherence of European Union policies within the current framework and in the current situation the Union is experiencing presupposes serious reflection on certain aspects related to the dynamics of the European Union itself: certainly, the internal dynamics of the European Union. We know that the European Union experiences its own dynamics, stemming above all from the Treaty of Amsterdam, which strengthens its political dimension, which certainly has an important consequence regarding the premise of policy coherence in the area of development. We will also have to wait for the development of the Intergovernmental Conference to see what dynamics are adopted with respect to enlargement, in order to verify to what extent the internal dynamics of the European Union are oriented toward strengthening the coherence of its policies and, particularly in the area of development, contribute to appropriate institutional arrangements also with a view to that objective. The second aspect to consider regarding policy coherence: development policy within the framework of the Union's foreign policy. We know that the Union is experiencing a new dimension in its foreign policy. We know that with the creation of the High Representative, the Rapid Intervention Force, and the Military Crisis Management Center, there is a whole dynamic of affirmation for the European Union that we cannot underestimate when addressing the role of development policies. We also know that there are aspects related to political dialogue, the adoption of common positions or actions, the preparation of common strategies, preventive diplomacy, and the development of regional capacities for crisis prevention and management. There is no doubt that all these aspects, in their implementation and development, will undoubtedly make important contributions to strengthening the role of development policies within the framework of the European Union's foreign policy. We must say that, also at this level, at the level of the European Union, the framing of development policy within the framework of foreign policy will undoubtedly have to follow the same path as development policies in many Member States, within the framework of their foreign policies. This affirmation necessarily presupposes the need to strengthen decision-making mechanisms and institutional structures for CFSP resources, which allow for better coordination between the instruments of development policy and those of foreign policy. In this context, we are convinced that we need to move from a postcolonial to a European paradigm of development policy, knowing, as we do, that in the latter, such policy has been heavily conditioned by the policies of some Member States, based on their postcolonial references. The third aspect to consider: the policies of the European Union and those of the Member States. Policy coherence at the European Union level undoubtedly presupposes better coordination between Member States' policies and that of the European Union in the area of development, and if it were not possible to establish better mechanisms for coherence between national policies, it would undoubtedly be more difficult to reflect on a framework for greater coherence for European Union development policy.

Amendment 4 specifies that the purpose of the exercise is the assessment of fishery resources in general. Amendment 7 calls on the Commission to report annually on the use made of the data collected in accordance with the regulation. It is also intended to give greater impetus to the process through more rapid and frequent reporting by the Commission on the progress of the data collection program in general. The other area of concern relates to the range of data that must be collected in accordance with the regulation. First, with regard to economic data, Amendment 2 introduces two amendments. One seeks to ensure that the data requested are not more detailed than necessary, so that they serve the intended purpose. The other replaces a reference to profits from sales and other income, subsidies, interest received, etc., with only a reference to sales volume. It is considered that without these amendments, Member States could incur excessively high and undesirable costs in the data collection exercise, and that serious confidentiality problems could arise. In conjunction with these modifications, Amendment 5 removes a reference to the corresponding accounting headings. Secondly, with regard to environmental data, the original proposal refers only to biological and economic information. The Commission, however, has made it clear that it intends to conduct studies and pilot projects with a broader environmental focus. It has also clarified that it may wish to expand the range of data collected by Member States at a later stage. Amendment 3 brings within the scope of the current regulation the types of data needed to monitor changes occurring in aquatic ecosystems. This will undoubtedly facilitate the introduction of a new regulation on environmental data and may even make it unnecessary. It should be emphasized that the amendment in no way requires the Commission to include the collection of this type of data in either the minimum or extended program it establishes in due course. It simply contemplates the possibility for the Commission to do so if it so wishes. As already stated, the proposed Council decision is divided into two parts. The first relates to the financial participation in the expenditure incurred by Member States in the implementation of Community programs. The second is to allow the Commission itself to fund studies and pilot projects. There are some minor amendments: Amendment 2 seeks to ensure that the financial participation in the expenditure incurred by Member States can cover not only the costs arising from data collection, but also those related to its management, compilation, aggregated data, etc. Amendments 3 and 6 aim to make the deadlines more flexible, given that Member States will have to wait for the publication of the implementing regulation to know the exact content of the programs, as well as to adapt the deadlines to the dates and the regulation. Amendments 4 and 5 aim to ensure that financial information is regularly submitted to the budgetary authority. More significantly, in Amendment 1, the Committee on Fisheries accepts the recommendation of the Committee on Budgets that funding should be placed under Heading 1(b), and not under Heading 3, of the Financial Perspective.

Finally, I would like to point out that since July, we have been calling for vigorous action from the Council and the Commission to secure the release of the 3,000 Kosovar prisoners, including Ms Brovina, Mr Kurti, and Mr Hoti. I note that the Union is preparing to lift certain sanctions, and in return, we have not had a single release of these prisoners. Why? Mr President, the events taking place in Mitrovica, Kosovo, are atrocious and unacceptable. Violence breeds violence, and revenge breeds revenge. The contingent of police forces sent is insufficient to prevent these massacres. Chief Police Commissioner Svend Frederiksen has expressed his despair, stating that he is still short of more than half of the promised troops. It has fewer than 2,000 officers, whereas it was promised nearly 5,000. The police force must be such that it is visible in the landscape, that the population believes that it can stop violations, and it must be of such a magnitude that it is able to shed light on the crimes committed and punish the guilty parties, otherwise the door is open to vigilantism. That is why local police officers must be trained, and it was planned that 2,000 to 3,000 officers would be trained, but the police force still has only 200 trained officers capable of contributing to investigative work. We already saw, a year ago, what happens when agreements reached and decisions taken are not respected. I was in Kosovo on October 27, 1998, at the time of the Serb withdrawal. It had been agreed that 1,800 OSCE observers would be sent there to guarantee peace. A month later, there were only a handful. By Christmas, there were perhaps 100, and by spring, there was still only a tiny fraction of the promised strength. The violations could not even be noted. Then came the war, and the observers withdrew. So my question is this, Commissioner: Can you really do nothing to prevent a repetition of our stupidities in Europe? Can you not guarantee a 5,000-strong police contingent and the training of local agents, who could obviously solve crimes more easily than foreign agents? I will add one further question: When do you think they will be in place? And when will you delegate more responsibility to local democratic forces? I ask this last question because it is the solution we must consider as quickly as possible so that peace has any chance of being established. Those who are in touch with the reality of Kosovo agree: a tragic and desperate situation of democratic vacuum and the impossibility of coexistence between the various ethnic groups - Mitrovica is a tragic example. The policy pursued by Milosevic in Kosovo before NATO's military intervention was certainly reprehensible, and the demands for autonomy for the regions of Kosovo emanating from the non-violent forces of the Rugova era were justified.

In the future, funding will no longer come from three funds, but only from the EAGGF Guidance Section. It will therefore be necessary to improve the quality of the programs, as the EAGGF is intended to be an effective financial instrument. Greater precision in selection will lead to greater effectiveness, as money should not be wasted haphazardly. I would particularly like to emphasize the point that forms the basis for an integrated and environmentally sound development strategy. This sector holds great employment potential for the future in rural areas, and we must exploit it if we want to offer people in rural areas a future. Therefore, rural policy is more than just a policy for farmers. LEADER+ is intended to complement existing programs, avoid overlaps and double funding, and thus contribute to the most comprehensive development possible. In this way, LEADER+, together with the programs under Regulation 1257/99, can further underline the second pillar of the CAP and achieve the best possible impact for rural areas as a whole. Mr. President, Dear colleagues, I'm not always happy about this kind of hectic activity promoted by Parliament, but the URBAN program is one of the best examples, as it was created precisely at Parliament's initiative. The Commission would have discontinued URBAN, but in this case, Parliament had the upper hand. The continuation of the program is to be welcomed, as it has produced positive results at the local level. The problems facing Europe's urban areas are increasing. Fortunately, we now have an agreement with the Commission. A large proportion of Europe's population lives in cities. The resulting problems are important issues for regional policy, rooted in a variety of causes. The risk of infrastructural neglect is high. Many English and French cities already have slums where unbelievable deprivation prevail. None of us wants South American favelas in Europe. We must act now, before it's too late. Cities are also of great importance to the European economy. We keep encountering the same fundamental European problem: our economic life is insufficiently motivating individuals and is not dynamic enough. We need a strong economy so we can care for our fellow human beings and our environment. This isn't about politics, but about the simple logic of life. When it comes to using resources, it's a good idea to concentrate them, because too much of it ends up being wasted if we distribute it indiscriminately. We must now address the problems of small and medium-sized towns, as they lack sufficient critical mass. This would also allow us to accelerate the development of the surrounding rural areas. It is often forgotten that the problems of towns and rural regions are interrelated. One basis is always the task of promoting innovation and entrepreneurship, as the mass movement emanating from individuals renews a region from within. Granting financial aid without an economy already standing on its own two feet would be like pouring water on a well: drinking water would be available for the moment, but tomorrow the well will be dry again.

We cannot rule out accidents 100 percent, but prevention must be optimal and in this sense the coherent directive we are considering is an important step. I hope that my Liberal colleagues will consider between now and tomorrow whether - also for reasons of parliamentary identity - they will give us their vote at second reading, as they did at the first, because we will have to go to conciliation anyway and that will be where the Council's willingness will be seen. I believe that tomorrow we should approve the amendments by a large majority as they were discussed in committee, for environmental reasons and also for reasons of competition, but also in line with what we decided two months ago in January. Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, my compliments on your report. As you have just said, this directive is of the utmost urgency. Ports will be required to have waste collection facilities and the necessary checks will finally be carried out. Furthermore, and very importantly, Member States will have to impose fines in the event of non-compliance. All this will benefit the environment. The first investments are already being made, even before the directive comes into force. For example, a large new plant is being built in Antwerp, near where I live. In a certain sense we can say that the directive is already having an effect. There is only one point on which our opinions differ, as Mr Jarzembowski also pointed out, and that is on the method to be applied for allocating costs. No one is opposed to the principle that the polluter must pay. But the question is whether he should automatically pay the full amount by integrating it into high anchorage fees, or whether it would not be better to opt for the flexible rule proposed by the Council. It remains to be seen which of the two systems integrates the best economic incentive. I have had the opportunity to speak to several people about this and I must say that the positions are quite divergent, as are the habits. Different systems and percentages are even used in different ports in the same region. There are also ports that, if I may say so, change percentages at the last minute. I therefore believe that this Parliament should not be fixated on a fixed percentage. A flexible system under these conditions, as you said, must include a substantial contribution to the costs, and 0.01 percent is clearly not a substantial contribution. It must also be an encouragement, since part of the system remains flexible and open, so that it can operate in an environmentally friendly way, provided that the Commission exercises the necessary controls and ensures that the system works. If the objectives of the directive are not achieved, you, Commissioner, must intervene with the Commission and propose the necessary changes to ensure that the system works. Ladies and gentlemen, it is our duty to save this directive at all costs, we must not let it slip away. I hope that we will not jeopardise the entire directive just because of a question of principle relating to one point.

The common position, adopted by the Commission and subsequently confirmed by the Committee on the Environment, but which was accepted with great difficulty by the Council, meets environmental requirements in every respect, so I find it very strange and incomprehensible that members of the Committee on the Environment should have tabled amendments aimed at reducing environmental requirements and mitigating the liability of car manufacturers. If these amendments are adopted, I believe that the Assembly's credibility in environmental matters will be seriously undermined. The Assembly has so far played a positive role as a catalyst for environmental protection, but adoption of the amendments by Mr Florenz and Mr Lange would be a negative factor for environmental protection in Europe. On the other hand, if we mitigate the liability of producers in this case, this will have serious consequences in cases that we will examine later in other areas, for example, with regard to the future directive on electronic and computer waste. That is why I warmly recommend that Members disregard their affiliation to any particular group and vote against all amendments to the common position that seek to weaken environmental standards and restrict manufacturers' liability. That is how we will achieve a worthwhile environmental result. Mr President, this excellent directive will put an end to the dumping of old cars, encourage recycling and, above all, encourage manufacturers to design cars that can be easily recycled. The key is to decide who pays the costs. Whichever system is adopted, the price will ultimately be passed on to consumers. The best way to achieve our environmental objectives is to make manufacturers our instrument both for collecting the money and for the disposal and recycling of cars. The manufacturers have, through subterfuge, persuaded Mr Florenz and Mr Lange to propose amendments that seriously weaken these proposals. Don't be fooled by the car manufacturers! If you want to fully benefit from this directive, use your vote to reject these amendments. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this debate, contrary to what we might think, is not technical. It has become eminently political. Yesterday, we honored our institution with a political debate. Today, if 314 Members were to give in to the power of the lobby of certain car manufacturers, we would dishonor ourselves. By asking consumers to cover half the cost of taking back end-of-life vehicles, as stipulated in Amendment 38, while the common position requires that the entire cost of taking back vehicles be borne by the manufacturer, for the first time, Parliament would not be presenting itself as the guarantor of the defense of consumers and European citizens; it would become, in a way, a sounding board for the lobbies. We cannot accept this. This would set a precedent that would leave the door open to all kinds of pressure in many other areas. It would also be the first time that the European Parliament would weaken a Council position, whereas I believe that we generally criticise the Council's position.

This approach to involving all European institutions and citizens is transparent and effective. This White Paper is a response to the challenges that enlargement poses for us. It requires us to reexamine the functioning of all our institutions, to reexamine our policies—all our policies—and, above all, to reexamine what we should continue to do at Union level when we have 25 or 30 Member States, and what it will be more appropriate to do at national, regional, and local government level. But enlargement is not the only factor pushing us to this new thinking. As I have just said, the globalization of the economy and of politics itself is also forcing us to do so. We must govern Europe in such a way as to be more effective, closer to citizens, by promoting the participation of everyone, starting first and foremost with the major problem of female participation. One of the major differences that emerged in the comparison made during this period between Europe and the United States is not so much the mobility of workers or the problem of venture capital, but rather the participation of women in economic life, a much higher participation in the United States than in our country. This is an area where Europe has always been at the forefront and we must conduct a deep, open reflection, and all the institutions - Commission, Parliament, Council - will have to think about their own role, their own policies. We will therefore immediately return to work on this White Paper, even if we will have to wait for the results of the Intergovernmental Conference to complete it. It will therefore not be possible to present it before the spring of 2001. It will not be a book of philosophy, but a concrete book, rich in precise proposals. We - the Commission - are the first to know that we must completely review our organization. This is why we will do two things: we will work and are already working completely to initiate internal reform, and we will thoroughly re-examine our policies. I have asked all Commissioners - and we will reiterate this request in an even more analytical manner - to define all the activities that can be abandoned. The Commission must determine its core activities, those on which it must concentrate, and hand over non-core activities to others so as to free up new resources and achieve a more correct relationship and greater cooperation with countries, regions and local communities. We will therefore free up other resources, but the time will come - I fear, and I want to say this here before you - when these resources that we are already freeing up will no longer prove sufficient to enable us to face our new responsibilities. I am thinking of enlargement, the new sector of justice and home affairs, health and environmental issues. When we have spent all our resources, I will not hesitate to come and ask you for more, but I am saying today that we will not accept new tasks if the financial means to carry them out do not follow because there would be no coherence between the missions to be accomplished and the resources available.

Another example: cocoa. The European Union wants to allow 5 percent alternative fats in chocolate in order to harmonize the internal market. This percentage could be zero, and the internal market would still be harmonized. But setting this quota at 5 percent - that seems to be the basic orientation - would almost certainly harm hundreds of thousands of farmers in developing countries who grow cocoa. And yet, it really seems that we want to go in that direction. I wonder if we really realize what we are doing. This is a typical example of a policy that makes our fellow citizens say: what are they doing there in Brussels? It seems that the interests of European companies are more important than our principles, our coherence and the interests of developing countries. Even with regard to countries subject to sanctions or embargoes, there are shocking cases to be cited. Why, for example, was a decision taken to boycott petroleum products against Haiti but not against Burma, where the elected President is under arrest, the Parliament has been removed from office and some of its members have been imprisoned or even murdered? Why was a boycott not imposed on petroleum products against Sudan, where even today there are clashes involving weapons - mind you - paid for with the money of the oil companies working in the regions where the refugees are located? The inconsistency of such a policy is truly scandalous. This morning Commissioner Nielson has once again shown us a positive example in relation to the Lomé Convention. If we apply the new Lomé Convention without first purging our policy of all its inconsistencies, the Union's policy will be built on sand, to use a biblical expression. The Council has never tired of repeating, time after time, the areas in which things were not going well: agriculture, trade, conflict prevention, peacekeeping operations, fisheries, migration, the environment. Commissioner Nielson, what we are waiting for is a comprehensive report on the inconsistencies between our policies and some concrete proposals to remedy these inconsistencies, because otherwise it will happen again that all your fine examples, all your splendid policies - and I say this also to the Secretary of State - will be built on sand and will therefore not be able to last for long. It is the citizens who are asking for it, and we ourselves have been demanding it since 1992: that is the real subject of today's debate. I hope that our message will be well received by you and I very much hope that you will return here shortly to submit a report and concrete measures. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I fully share the spirit of Mrs Maij-Weggen's speech and I believe that the representatives of the other institutions present here are all sincerely willing to delve into this issue in precisely that spirit. This is a subject of fundamental importance for the European Union. To begin with, I would like to clarify what we are discussing. Article 178, Title XX of the consolidated version of the Treaties on the Union states: "In implementing policies which are likely to have consequences for developing countries, the Community shall take into account the objectives set out in Article 177". And what are these objectives that any European Union policy must take into account?

Ireland supports the common position and many of the European Parliament's amendments. A period of 25 years for the implementation of legislation is hardly acceptable. We have no problem with the enforcement of the polluter pays principle to cover the costs of industrial, commercial, and agricultural water use. However, since water is life and access to clean drinking water is a basic human right, I firmly believe that this directive must provide for a basic free water supply to private households, that is, a certain quota per household for water for drinking, cooking, and sanitation purposes. Of course, we have to pay for waste and over-consumption, and cost recovery can be adjusted accordingly. In Ireland, where private households have not paid water charges since 1997 and therefore no longer have water meters, the introduction of water meters is viewed with great suspicion. Measuring water consumption could be a very important water management tool within the new river basin districts, helping to prevent water wastage and to systematically plan for future needs. The purpose of the directive is to promote the sustainable, environmentally sound use of water in the EU. Water is a scarce and valuable natural resource. I would ideally prefer it if Amendment 45 were not adopted tomorrow and the common position on Article 9 were to apply to water charges as well. This would ensure subsidiarity in setting water charges, and each Member State could set up its own system, provided the principles of this directive regarding incentives for sustainable, environmentally sound and efficient water use are fully respected. If Amendment 45 is not adopted tomorrow, I must table an oral amendment to ensure that Member States have the option of granting derogations from the provisions of this article, thus allowing a minimum quantity to be made available for household use before the cost-recovery requirement applies. All regulations must be enforceable and based on the general principle of political acceptance. I consider access to clean drinking water to be a fundamental human right in both developed and developing countries. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, at this stage of the debate, I would like to highlight a few aspects of this directive which, from an agronomic perspective and given my origins in a southern country, I consider to have extremely significant consequences. For example, the issues of costs and transfers. As for costs, I would like to know exactly what costs we are talking about. Are we talking about the distribution and origin of resources? Are we talking about the quality of distribution networks? Are we talking about the type of civil engineering works required to supply water? Or are we talking about large-scale hydraulic works and reservoirs? It would be barbaric to pass the entire cost on to the agricultural sector. As for transfers, these are defined as the transfer of surface water between different territorial areas.
