Is the Commissioner aware that our country has a transfer system that is one of the oldest in Europe? These transfers existed in very early times: they already existed in Roman times, but they were on a smaller scale.

In the meantime, we must give the Commission a vote of confidence. "Long-winded." I don't want to dwell on the length of this report here. I don't know if it breaks the record for all the resolutions tabled here, but in any case, and without a doubt, it does for this type of resolution. I don't think there has ever been a resolution in the past—and bear in mind that we draft complex resolutions in this Parliament—that contained paragraphs of more than 16 lines without a single point. Moreover, it is "unclear." I don't want to go back to what was said about the analysis of the issues that concern Parliament. That should be the subject of another report that we will have to draft, and it is necessary to reflect on it, but not in this report. And finally, frankly, Mr President, I don't want to cite examples, but there are many in which legal language is used with alarming imprecision. Therefore, and I will summarize, I await your report, Commissioner Kinnock—there are many of us waiting—so that we can comment on it, because that is precisely Parliament's task. Mr. President, the scope and the sheer volume of detail in the proposals for necessary reform steps indicate the importance of such a reform. However, given the events that triggered these efforts, the necessity is also obvious. Hopes and expectations were all the more aroused by the strong announcements made by Commissioners Prodi and Kinnock in plenary and in the Committee on Budgetary Control. The concept of transparency is particularly striking in the report. Ensuring this is a key concern. The importance of fully traceable work cannot be overemphasized. But this is not just about bureaucratic reform; it is much more about demonstrating goodwill towards the citizen. Their trust in EU policy must be regained. Citizens demand rapid and open access to the institution and legibility of the regulations. He draws his understanding from this, and he wants a policy of success, while simultaneously seeing this as a matter of course for the responsible citizen. The success of the reform depends crucially on the Commission's own initiative. However, it irritates me today to hear that the Commission now says it only wants to discuss the interim report informally with Parliament. Your presentation, Mr. Kinnock, in the Committee on Budgetary Control next Tuesday cannot be a one-way street; we as parliamentarians want and must help shape it. And it also goes against my political understanding if a press conference is held this week before we have thoroughly discussed the proposal in the relevant Committee on Budgetary Control. I believe, Mr. Kinnock, despite all my personal success, that the Commission still has a lot to do to meet our justified, high expectations. First, may I state for the record and as a statement for Ms. Langenhagen that the decision that I will not address the entire Parliament tomorrow and therefore will not be available for official questions about the report was made neither by me nor by the Commission – it was the decision of this Parliament!

I would first like to thank the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and its rapporteur, the chairman of the committee, Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf, for examining the Commission's proposal. The Commission's proposal is, as some of you have pointed out, quite technical. However, its objective is quite simple: the harmonisation of procedures governing the authorisation of additives in food. At present, there is a difference in the treatment of authorisations, depending on whether the applications were submitted before or after 1 January 1988. The objective of the Commission's proposal is to harmonise these procedures in order to ensure that such differences no longer exist. The scope of the proposed amendment is therefore very limited. Five amendments have been tabled by Parliament. I regret that the Commission is unable to adopt these amendments, despite the fact that I am well aware of the views and commitment of Parliament, the Committee on Agriculture and, in particular, the rapporteur, Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf, to these issues. I intend to deal with each of the amendments separately. The first amendment proposes to change the legal basis of the proposal by substituting Article 152 for Article 37. I simply wish to point out that the Commission's proposal makes no reference to health and consumer protection. The technical nature of the proposed amendment does not allow it to be interpreted as having the protection of public health as its primary objective. I note that the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market also considers Article 37 to be the appropriate legal basis. I would remind Parliament that the primary objective of Article 152 is the protection of health. I recommend that you read the arguments set out in the letter from the Legal Affairs Committee, which, in my view, describes the situation precisely, clearly and with commendable conciseness. Amendments Nos 2 and 3 go much further than the Commission's proposal, as they seek to introduce additional provisions on genetically modified additives. I am the first to acknowledge that GMOs are a very important problem. I also acknowledge and concede that a number of initiatives are necessary to update EU legislation in the field of GMOs. However, this technical amendment is not the appropriate instrument for introducing such initiatives. The Commission is of the opinion that it is premature, at this stage, to amend the provisions currently laid down by Directive 70/524 on genetically modified additives. On the other hand, it is appropriate to await developments in the common position on the amendment to Directive 90/220, which is currently in its second reading in Parliament. The Commission intends to go much further than what is currently proposed by Parliament in its amendments. I can also assure Parliament that I will ensure that the relevant provisions of Directive 90/220 are included in the proposal for a recast of Directive 70/524 which the Commission has put forward in the White Paper on food safety and which will be presented to Parliament before July 2001. I can also assure Parliament that all the remarks made today will receive our full attention. Amendments 4 and 5 are also unacceptable because they give unjustified preference to copies of products by giving them permission to be put on the market even before an application for authorization has been submitted.

Therefore, as you can see, this is a very important project that truly helps the Member States of the Union provide themselves with a more comprehensive and uniform instrument for legal assistance. In reality, within the Council, there are still some disagreements regarding the type of agreement and certain clauses contained therein. Some of these disagreements have already been resolved; others still persist. The spirit of the proposal, in any case, is to provide legal professionals—judges first and foremost, but also the citizens concerned—with an effective operational instrument for combating crime, while respecting fundamental procedural guarantees and the general principles of human rights. This is why, despite the numerous gaps in the text, the provisions contained therein can be accepted—they can be, Mr. President—but on condition that they are appropriately amended to ensure its functionality for other legal professionals and its acceptability by citizens. For this reason, the Commission has submitted several amendments aimed at systematically rethinking the Council's proposal, suggesting a series of technical adjustments to make the text more harmonious and coherent with respect to the proposed modifications. These amendments can be summarized as a greater emphasis on the fundamental rights of defense and various technical modifications necessary to make a series of obscure and contradictory passages more comprehensible, as well as to delete the section referring to remote wiretapping, which still lacks, on the one hand, technical knowledge and, on the other, acceptability by the governments of the various Member States of the Union. The proposal, as formulated by the Council and subsequently amended by the Commission, provides for a convention based on three titles: the first provides guidelines for standardizing the procedures and formalities to be followed in letters rogatory; the second lists a series of specific requests for mutual legal assistance and establishes the formalities and procedures to be followed in relation to these mutual legal assistance actions; The third, finally, provides for and establishes the methods by which wiretaps can and should be carried out on citizens who are in a State other than their country of origin. Undoubtedly, Mr. President, international cooperation is necessary to combat both cross-border crime and crime within the State whose evidence is located abroad. However, a new convention must be drawn up as soon as possible, taking into account other, even more delicate, issues: the whole issue of double criminality and the issue of specialization, as well as the issue of the credibility of a Union State vis-à-vis the judicial authority of other Union States. These are, therefore, extremely important issues that we hope the Council will return to as soon as possible in order to issue a new opinion. Mr. President, with regard to many other points of the matter, I refer to the content of my written report.

To achieve the highest possible degree of success in achieving the objectives of these policies, it is necessary to coordinate and organize them on the basis of well-developed, intelligently crafted guidelines, I would say. Let us not forget that these policies, when effective, are also visible to European citizens, who benefit from them and see the immediate improvement in their quality of life. Let us also not forget that special attention will have to be paid to the most remote and island regions of the European Union, since, due to their geographical location, they face fundamental obstacles to their economic and social development—unless, of course, the Commission intends to build underwater bridges and tunnels to connect them to the European trunk. Finally, I would like to emphasize that structural policies as a whole require greater flexibility, so that they can adapt to changing circumstances and thus respond to the new challenges and opportunities that arise with the arrival of the new millennium, for which we all wish the best. Mr. President, Mrs. Schroedter's report undoubtedly includes many important observations, and I congratulate her for this. I believe, however, that we should show more concern about the direction and results of the Community's regional policy. Broadly speaking, the enormous mass unemployment is not only not diminishing, but is actually worsening even further within the framework of structural policy. The agricultural economy and rural areas are irreparably affected by the regional policy being pursued, with dramatic consequences for rural employment and the living conditions of farmers, particularly in the South. Regional inequalities are increasing dramatically within the Member States. If we examine the data from the sixth report, we will see that enormous deviations from the average regional development have been recorded over the last decade. Minimal, if not nonexistent, attention is being paid to the enormous problems of the Union's island regions, whose deficiencies in infrastructure, transport, communications, and energy inevitably lead to depopulation. Both regional policy and the Union's more general economic and social policy are responsible for all of this. Broad sectors of the Union's people strongly condemn this policy as dangerous and unpopular. The new guidelines unfortunately move in the same direction, and nothing suggests that this can change with the implementation of these guidelines. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to say a few words here to underline two points that these reports remind us of and that are of essential strategic importance in our perspective of the Union. The first is the essential and fundamental importance we continue to attach to the principle of economic and social cohesion. And we express concern at the reports we are receiving that the importance of this objective is waning in the Commission's mind. We continue to consider economic and social cohesion to be a fundamental objective of the Union. Secondly, I agree with the words heard here from a Member on the issue of the islands, and I would also like to draw attention to the outermost regions. We would like to see more boldness in the future in addressing the issue of the outermost regions, such as, in the case of my country, the Azores and Madeira islands.

Mr President, excuse me, but there was a small translation error in the French booth, regarding what Mr Alyssandrakis just said, on the most sensitive word in the whole debate. I would not like there to be any misunderstanding. The translation, in French, made Mr Alyssandrakis say that the "confederal" solution is the best, whereas it is clear that he spoke of a "federal" solution. It is extremely important to clarify this, Mr President. Many thanks for the clarification, Mr Wurtz. Mr President, Malta and Cyprus are very different from the countries of continental Europe. The Maltese in particular have been very good at surviving in hostile geographical and geopolitical conditions. Their success has depended largely on their spirit of initiative, their dynamism and their flexibility. Malta has a very vibrant heavy and light industry, expanding financial services, good agriculture, thriving tourism and an incredible variety of job opportunities, all on an island with virtually no natural resources. I am therefore sure that an island like Malta, with a population of 340,000, cannot adapt to the rigid economic and legal structures of continental Europe, which has a population thousands of times greater. When I look at the proposed instrument, I therefore do not see a measure that can bring two peoples into the bosom of Mother Europe. The situation is more like a black hole in space, which sucks masses into itself with such force that not even light can escape. We must not induce these island peoples to collaborate in their own destruction by offering them money to convince them to accept laws that are as alien to their culture as a black hole is to Mother Earth. The European Union must leave Malta and Cyprus alone. It seems to me that the only people who want this in Malta are the political class, and I cross my fingers that once again the Maltese will be the winners. Mr President, this is one of the rare occasions when the positions adopted by all parts of the House reveal the greatest convergence of views on the Cyprus question and on the pre-accession procedure for Cyprus and Malta. This means that there is a certain common awareness in all of us about the so-called political problem of Cyprus. At the same time, it means that it is to the great advantage of the Council and the Commission to ensure that this potential, expressed by all the parties and peoples of Europe, becomes the cornerstone of their political approach to solving the problem. Ladies and gentlemen, Helsinki represents a historic turning point and a new point of reference. It would be a tragic mistake if we now, for whatever reason, regarded the balance achieved in Helsinki as a starting point for new negotiations or if we undermined that balance by our attitude. The time is ripe: what is required of the Commission and the Council is a firm determination to follow up, without subterfuge, on the pre-accession negotiations with Cyprus and Malta - ultimately the most ready candidate countries of all - so that their resolve may serve as a warning to any party that may have an idea different from the one we all share.

Following Oslo, a total of 17,400 hectares of land were expropriated by October 17, 1999, including 846.2 hectares under the new Barak government. Trees were uprooted, more houses were destroyed, and, especially in East Jerusalem, water access is restricted or denied, while settlement activity continues and the number of settlements continues to grow. However, the election of the new government undoubtedly marked positive steps; at least negotiations have resumed. However, there will be no stable and lasting peace in the Middle East if the Palestinians do not have their own state and cannot move freely within their territory. The international community must simply comply with UN Resolutions 332, 248, 245, and 194. We consider the suspension of relations with Syria worrying, as well as Prime Minister Barak's decision to postpone the Israeli troop withdrawal and the implementation of the Sharm el-Sheikh Agreement. We believe it is essential that the European Union plays a political role in the negotiations commensurate with the economic aid it provides. We cannot be content with a supporting role; we must act as major players, without thereby entering into a conflict of interest with the United States, as Minister Gama said today. Mr. President, I would like to thank Commissioner Patten for his remarks today, particularly for his report on the role of the European Union in the peace process and his assurance that this role is not limited to that of "financier" for the entire operation. I was very disappointed when it was announced this week that the peace talks between Israel and Syria had been suspended. I sincerely hope that a compromise can be found regarding the existing problems so that the peace talks can resume as soon as possible. Nevertheless, there have been positive political developments in the Middle East recently. The fact that the Syrian Foreign Minister and the Israeli Prime Minister recently sat at the same table for the first time in their respective histories during the talks in America shows that hatred and animosity, however ancient, can be overcome. The politicians in charge will need considerable courage to create a framework that can form the basis for a comprehensive peace settlement in the Middle East. I realize that even after an agreement between Syria and Israel is reached, the Israeli Prime Minister will face strong resistance to any further agreement with Syria in future referendums. The settlers in the Golan Heights will demand compensation and security guarantees. If Syria were willing to make concessions on the security issue, the prospects for a successful resolution of the problems between Israel and Syria would be good. Regarding the Palestinian issue, there are apparently still problems with the implementation of certain aspects of the Wye Agreement. Key issues at the moment include the difficulties surrounding troop withdrawal and the return of territory. The fact that few Palestinian prisoners have been released and the Israeli government's apparent reluctance to halt the implementation of previously granted construction permits and to refuse to issue new ones create further obstacles. These problems clearly hamper progress in the final status negotiations, although I don't believe they will delay these talks indefinitely.

There are therefore two possible solutions: the directive is not applicable in Denmark, or the directive requires Denmark to introduce universally applicable agreements. Can the Commission confirm that the Posting of Workers Directive is not applicable in Denmark with regard to "collective agreements declared universally applicable" (see Article 3(1)), since such universally applicable agreements do not exist under Danish law? If not, please explain how the directive applies to this point. The European Union Directive on the Posting of Workers stipulates that the mandatory rules regarding working and employment conditions in the host country must also apply to workers posted to that country. This leaves two possibilities open: either the legislation of the host country applies, or the collective agreements declared universally applicable for a specific sector. Because Denmark does not have a system of universally applicable collective agreements, the legislation implementing the directive must, in addition to the working conditions established by law, also provide that universally applicable collective agreements concluded by the most representative organizations also apply to posted workers. In short, Denmark has two options: either introduce appropriate legislation, or, again through legislation, select a collective agreement that will be activated through legal channels. Discussions are currently taking place between the European Commission and Denmark, and Denmark is expected to notify the transposition of this directive into national law. The deadline for replying to the Commission's questions expired on December 6, 1999. We have not received a reply. We are now awaiting the next steps. Thank you for the clear answer, which—if correctly interpreted—means that the directive on the posting of workers requires the Danish state to introduce a system of universally applicable agreements. While that is a clear answer, I would like to point out that this creates a very difficult political situation for Danish organizations, the Danish government, and the Danish parliament. As is well known, there are fundamental differences between the Danish system, which is largely based on collective bargaining, and the continental system, which is based on legislation. The disagreements and correspondence you refer to, Commissioner, primarily concern another directive, namely the Working Time Directive. A new letter of formal notice and a contractual procedure are therefore to be expected, since the Danish government does not intend to legislate and allow universally applicable collective agreements, or has expressly stated that it does not intend to do so. There is not the slightest intention of changing the system in force in Denmark or any other country. As I explained earlier, there are always difficulties in interpreting European Commission directives, both because they are framework-based and very general, and because the individual systems are designed very differently from country to country. The problem raised in your question does not only affect Denmark. There are still some unanswered questions, and not only there. Five countries have already implemented the legislation into national law, and the discussion process is ongoing in the others. Therefore, our goal—and this is why the consultations and discussions took place between the Commission and the Danish, as well as the other governments—is to find the best way to apply what has been agreed upon at the European level by all countries and constitutes a general framework to workers from other countries posted to Denmark.

This is the affirmation of a European cultural policy on which I expect us, Parliament, Commission and Council, to be in agreement. Cultural policy means, in particular, defending the role of creativity, recognizing authors and producing a demanding culture. Moreover, today, when Europe must adopt a new policy for copyright and related rights, it is urgent - this has just been emphasized several times - to define and redefine what an author is. We are still too vague in this regard and new technologies now require us to make this effort at clarification. Mr President, Commissioner, the advent of the WIPO Treaty has been a remarkable step towards a global information society. The legacy of decades-old copyright is crystallized in the treaties which represent a balanced and well-considered solution to the regulation of copyright and related rights. Beyond these recommendations, the entry into force of the treaty and its final form will, however, depend on the respective implementation of the parties. In the United States, the WIPO Treaty has already entered into force through the Digital Millennium Corporate Act, and this legislative measure has helped to safeguard the delicate balance of WIPO. The EU must also move forward with its legislative work in accordance with what was agreed at WIPO. It is therefore worrying that the positions taken by the previous Parliament do not support the balanced organization of WIPO. The first reading of the Copyright Directive was particularly aberrant, and, moreover, the balance is being shifted in the wrong direction from a European perspective. The proposed recommendations will not improve the position of culture in Europe—quite the contrary. The amendments proposed by Parliament would primarily improve the opportunities for media companies with a stable market position to transfer their former market shares of over 80 percent to a new environment with the help of rigid and excessive copyright regulations. I am therefore not speaking now of Mrs. Charlotte Cederschiöld's recommendation, which is an excellent document, but rather of the copyright-related topics that were addressed by the previous Parliament. As an isolated remark, I would therefore like to thank Mrs. Cederschiöld for clarifying, for example, the concept of so-called temporary copies in her opinion. The WIPO Treaty has not consciously taken a position on temporary copies. If these technical copies were to be included in the scope of protection, the transmission of data - as is quite rightly noted in the recommendation - would unnecessarily become expensive and complicated. It would be the same situation as if the postman had to pay royalties when he delivers a book to the customer who will read it. The real advantage of culture is the ability to transmit art and information, safely and effortlessly, directly from the artist to the user, to the consumer. Above all, the new framework for action represents an enormous opportunity to create and disseminate culture in new ways.

Furthermore, requests can be made directly between the competent authorities without having to go through central authorities. There are essentially two types of provisions: those that create an obligation to provide assistance, such as the provisions on telephone and videoconferencing, controlled deliveries, and the interception of telecommunications; and those that do not create such an obligation but simply provide a legal framework for Member States wishing to cooperate in the manner described, such as the provisions on joint investigation teams, covert investigations, and the transmission and handover of procedural documents. The Commission particularly welcomes the inclusion of provisions relating to new or modern investigative techniques. These are effective in combating the type of crime most likely to benefit from the opening of borders—organized crime. It is all too easy to be guided by the need to improve the efficiency of criminal investigations. However, one aspect must not be forgotten in all measures relating to criminal proceedings: the right to defense. I very much welcome the fact that Mr Di Pietro's report, to whom I pay the greatest respect for his excellent work, especially in such a short space of time, includes the right to a defence as a key point. At present, it is solely up to the Member States to ensure that these rights are respected under the scrutiny of the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. It remains to be seen whether this will change with the new European Charter of Fundamental Rights, on which work has just begun. We must admit that Article 18 is clearly a controversial decision. The article was carefully drafted in the Council through very lengthy discussions to ensure that intelligence activities remain effective and that criminal investigations are also covered. As far as criminal investigations, for which I am responsible, are concerned, I note the call from various Members of the European Parliament to the Commission and the Council to take this point into account and address it on a common legal basis, with reference to the relevance of telecommunications surveillance as potential evidence in court. The Commission is fully aware that the current draft is neither perfect nor ideal. But we must be realistic. The text is the result of a mixture of institutional structures envisaged for judicial cooperation in criminal matters under the Maastricht Treaty and the Amsterdam Treaty, respectively. This is what we have before us now, and only practice will show us in detail whether and where there are deficiencies and what further steps need to be taken in the future. It is quite clear to me that the further development of mutual trust and reliability between the legal systems of the Member States will facilitate progress along the road ahead. That said, the Tampere European Council indicated the direction the Commission should take. The necessary steps will include the implementation of the principle of mutual recognition of judicial decisions and the EuroJust project. The Commission sincerely hopes that its efforts to make progress in these important areas will have the support of the European Parliament.

It's a disgrace! This figure of 167 million euros for so many years is a disgrace for the European Union! We are literally forced to strip theater groups, young musicians, avant-garde activities in the arts and literature, we ridicule them and we accept a single project in the face of thirty other rejections, so that Europe is perceived as a foreign factor, contrary, and adversary to any attempt at cultural achievement. The European Union must be present in this area, because the path we have chosen is not only that of the euro, or of enlargement or of geostrategic objectives. We must ensure that European unification also flourishes on a political level. It is a very sad situation. And as long as we continue to maintain the system of unanimity, and as long as, as yesterday, the Dutch government can impose these 167 million in a completely arbitrary manner, and as tomorrow, Mr Haider's government will tell us what our cultural activities will be, we will never be able to make progress. For this reason, it is essential for the Intergovernmental Conference to take certain important decisions so that the European Parliament's effort is freed from the commitments of each government and can give a significant cultural boost to the European area. Madam President, I fully share the opinions expressed by the rapporteur and I also thank the chairman of the Culture Committee, Mr Gargani, for the commendable work carried out in a substantially difficult mediation process. The need to simplify and strengthen the previous programmes was certainly felt, but we all wanted the Culture programme to effectively contribute to highlighting, for example, the particularities of each cultural sector, even - and I would even say especially - the lesser-known sectors, or better, precisely those. We hope this will happen at least on the evaluation scale. We strongly believe in the validity of cultural actions, also in terms of their contribution to the social and economic growth of a people. And Europe can rightly compete with the rest of the world by fully rediscovering its roots, highlighting the common cultural heritage, and worthily promoting and recovering the cultural and linguistic islands that have been little known until now. In the case of the great educational mission relating to the cultural dimension, a mission that the European Union must assume, one of the most obvious limitations of the program lies in the quantification of funding—we have heard this repeatedly—which denounces an insufficient awareness—at least on the part of the Council, not the Commissioner—of the importance of the cultural operation. The document that prioritizes the economic factor over social integration also testifies to this. With regard to the overall growth of the European Union and the awareness of being European citizens, we believe that the "Culture 2000" programme, within the limits of its funding, can contribute to this great common objective. Madam President, I join this evening's unanimous movement and declare my support for the adoption of the Culture 2000 programme. Furthermore, I, too, thank the rapporteur, Mr Graça Moura, who has taken over from our former colleague, Nana Mouskouri.

However, an important merit of this summit, following Cardiff and Luxembourg, is that it demonstrates the political will to promote greater social cohesion, particularly for the 57 million people living in poverty in Europe, such as single mothers, large families, and children. To these will be added other socially excluded people in the future, namely those who will not have access to new areas of knowledge, which will lead to new social inequalities. A decisively forward-looking economic and social policy is therefore needed to prevent a gap between "info-rich" and "info-poor"—that is, as one of my colleagues said earlier, a digital divide. For this reason, I believe that new technologies will only have a strong integrative impact on our growth if they are learned from childhood, since by 2010, half of all jobs will be in sectors directly related to information technologies. To this end, I recommend that the Lisbon Summit make three decisions: first, a strategy for lifelong learning and the establishment of an agenda to eradicate both economic and intellectual poverty among children; second, shaping European society with a view to the European Research Area; and third, establishing an open coordination procedure linked to our social and economic policies, complemented by a coordinated approach to the evaluation of national action plans. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, there is one idea in the Portuguese Presidency's declaration that I particularly like. This idea is the notion that the strength of our European economy lies in the capacity, imagination, and creativity—quite simply in the knowledge of the people in the European economic process. But if we take this seriously, if it is to become a genuine political program, then a policy of social inclusion requires no further justification, because social participation as such would be the strongest productive force in our common economy. If that is the case, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, then we urgently need common goals. We need firm, measurable targets – both qualitatively and quantitatively – for increasing employment rates, as the Commission has now also proposed, for example. We need firm, consensually achievable targets for reducing the unemployment rate – as the Commission has now also proposed – to 4% in 2010. The logic that sees Ecofin ministers celebrating their consolidation successes at home while leaving responsibility for the issue of Europe's massive unemployment in the dark must end. I wish you strength, the support of Parliament, and the commitment to ensuring that this Parliament has more say in economic and employment policy in the future, as the citizens of Europe expect. Then you would have another ally for your policies. Mr. President, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, It is encouraging and promising when, as has been the case here, this plenary speaks of the new strategic objective for the coming decade: to make the European Union the most dynamic and competitive economic and social area in the world by building on new technologies, innovation and knowledge, so that we are able to raise the level of economic growth with more and better jobs and greater social cohesion.

The Presidency mentions the sensitive issue of corporate tax and points out that there is indeed a significant impasse on this issue in the Monti package. I would like to reiterate my call for an in-depth analysis of developments in the area of corporate tax, especially within the Commission. I would also like to suggest that the Member States consider starting a Luxembourg process in this area because, reading the report, I see examples of best practices that could be addressed. I therefore ask that attention be paid to this point as well. Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, much has already been said, and therefore, if we intervene at the end, there is a risk of repeating ourselves. However, I would like to thank the Portuguese Presidency for the document presented and the convincing speech delivered by the President of the Council. It is true—as President-in-Office Mr. Guterres has pointed out—that Lisbon does not plan to launch new initiatives, but rather to merge those of Luxembourg, Cardiff, and Cologne. This is the first time, however, in many years, that we have been proposed a strategic objective, and I believe this is extraordinarily important: to transform the Union into an economic area based on innovation and knowledge to increase economic growth and achieve full, quality employment and social cohesion. Last year, the Commission produced a study which concluded that, unless we significantly address qualifications and vocational training, by 2010, 80% of those currently employed will have outdated professional qualifications, which will exacerbate existing inequalities and produce new ones. Therefore, we need continuous training and massive investments in knowledge and expertise. Also with regard to research, another strategic sector, it is necessary to promote it in the Member States, in Europe; we need to make a qualitative leap, moving from framework programs to a European Research Area, to a common research policy. And innovation: not only structural and technological, but also in procedures and methods. As Mrs. Van Lancker said, the Social Affairs Council must have the same importance as the Ecofin Council. Therefore, social dialogue must be strengthened as a fundamental instrument of consensus for making the necessary changes. Lisbon must be remembered not only for the excellent preparatory document, but as a Summit that, with the new millennium, will mark a significant turning point for growth, employment, and social cohesion in Europe. Mr. President of the Council, I would like to congratulate you for having brought Europe together on the idea that economic modernization and social cohesion are compatible concepts. The preparations for the Lisbon Summit highlight that not enough work is being done in Europe, and that, if we want to be the most dynamic region in the world, we must not only work harder, but also have more information and the ability to use it.

At the same time, they call for the existence of an independent European body to coordinate and monitor the regularity of OLAF investigations, without prejudice to the administration of justice in each Member State and under the supervision of the Court of the European Communities. Finally, in line with what was agreed in Tampere, the report reaffirms the position of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which was opportunely brought to the fore by decision of Commissioner António Vitorino, and requests the IGC to include on its agenda the creation of this new position, which is now considered indispensable by all. By reaffirming the need to effectively regulate the legal life of the institutions, enclosing the Union's financial system with European substantive and procedural law appropriate to the credibility of the Community's economic life, this report deserves our approval. However, it raises some very simple questions. Will there currently be sufficient legal grounds to legally justify the creation of a new, specifically Community-based criminal law that, although it may be considered subsidiary, will always compete in practice and in certain sectors with the traditional and fragmented criminal law of the Member States? Wouldn't it be politically more correct, in case of doubt, to include the reform of the judicial system on the agenda of the IGC, incorporating these proposals into the more general reform of the Union's judicial system, similar to what is being called for the European Public Prosecutor's Office? Wouldn't these measures be of the utmost interest for a revision of the Treaties that contributes to the solidity of the Union's Area of Freedom, Security, and Justice? Mr. President, the EU is being subjected to rigorous scrutiny. Confidence in the Union is seriously damaged. Action is needed to remedy this situation. That is why we welcome the increase in resources for OLAF, which will allow for more effective investigation of all concerns. We also believe it is obvious that those who commit crimes against the EU should be held accountable. It is regrettable that the Convention on the protection of the Union's financial interests applies in so few Member States. For this reason, we believe it is logical to task the Union with submitting proposals that involve developing the existing judicial framework. However, I'm not convinced that this kind of improvement requires common European standards or centralized crime control. Currently, I'm skeptical about the idea of a European Public Prosecutor; it seems impractical within the framework of the current treaties. We believe more in EUROJUST, where national prosecutors collaborate. The big problem isn't the adoption of legal measures to combat crimes, but rather the fact that they are committed so frequently and are discovered so infrequently. The challenge for the Commission and for us, however, is to find the right balance. Fraud and irregularities must not chain us to a hierarchical bureaucracy that, through excessive controls, impedes the development of a modern administration.

This is the correction that must be imposed on the Commission's actions. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the fundamental democratic principle of respect for human rights and the freedom and sovereignty of peoples, against any new or old fascism, Nazism, or communism, and bearing in mind that all previous speakers have spoken of the sovereignty of the Austrian people, we see that today it is precisely this Parliament that denies that sovereignty. A reading of the Austrian Liberal Party's program reveals no elements that justify accusations of an attack on the principles of liberty, democracy, and respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms, and the rule of law, enshrined in Article 6 of the Treaty. However, I would like to draw the attention of the honorable Members to the fact that the President-in-Office of the Council, so critical of Austria, recently handed the inhabitants of Macau over to the sovereignty of the democratic People's Republic of China. But today, perhaps, to strengthen the Union's democracy, it is opportune to isolate Austria, criminalize a party democratically elected by the Austrian citizens, and allow the Turkey of the Grey Wolves into Europe. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are debating an extremely serious issue. Nothing more and nothing less than the presence in a Member State's government of a political force whose doctrine and principles are incompatible with the conceptual and moral foundations that inspire the Union and are enshrined in its founding Treaties. A simple reading of Article 1 of Chapter 4 of the Austrian Liberal Party's political program shocks any democratic conscience. The assumption of ethnicity as a defining factor of a nation and the assertion of the superiority of one ethnic group over others, as written here, resurrects old specters of a century we have just left behind and which some historians have defined as the century of horrors, horrors that the unacceptable philosophy of Mr. Haider's political program once again stirs before our astonished eyes. Of course, the Austrian people are sovereign, and of course we must respect the principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of a Member State. But that is not the problem. The problem is whether the Union can remain indifferent to the formation of a government in a Member State that includes a party with such characteristics. Our answer to this crucial question is no. Beyond strategic or tactical considerations, beyond possible excuses drawn from the behavior of others, beyond and above party interests or electoral circumstances, the Spanish delegation of the People's Party Group in this Parliament, in complete harmony with the Spanish People's Party and the Government of Spain, emphatically expresses its full agreement with the declaration of the Portuguese Presidency of the Council of January 31, with its content, its tone, and its scope. (Applause) Konrad Adenauer once said—and he knew what he was talking about—that the surest way to appease a tiger is to let it devour you. History is the compendium of those things that could have been avoided.

We will not fail to focus all our attention on this problem because the entire credibility of the authorities and structures representing Albanians on the ground also depends on their ability to prove that they are capable of implementing measures guaranteeing the multi-ethnic character of the territory. I would like to thank the President-in-Office. I am aware—as I think we all are—that Portugal, its former President, Mr. Soares, and his government maintained a circumspect and moderate attitude during the bombings in the Balkans. Today's political declaration on this issue is very positive, I emphasize and welcome it. Despite everything, there is concern, because while the intentions of the European Union are good and sincere, the results are very meager. Unfortunately, in recent times, we have witnessed the disappearance of all the minorities—Serbs, Roma, Turks, Croats—from Kosovo, and we wonder what will happen next. We note the failure of the UN mission and Mr. Kouchner in Kosovo. Because it is a failure that after an entire war waged to prevent ethnic cleansing, a cleansing by the other side should occur. That is why I repeat my question: does the Council intend to take more concrete initiatives to address these issues with Mr. Kouchner, who is largely responsible for the situation prevailing in Kosovo today? Mr. Alavanos, I cannot agree with what you have just said, with your last sentence concerning Mr. Kouchner's responsibilities, and I would like to make a very important distinction: the structure installed in Kosovo is a structure placed under the supervision of the United Nations. The European Union has given it all possible support, and the countries of the European Union, as such, have contributed in various ways. But it cannot be denied that Mr. Kouchner's efforts to normalize the internal situation in Kosovo are extremely positive. Regardless of the fact that you may believe, and we also believe, that some of the results of these efforts, for reasons beyond Mr Kouchner's control, may not have been as effective as we would all have hoped. A distinction must be made, on the one hand, between the question of the European Union's responsibility and, in particular in this case, the Council's possible action in this context, and, on the other hand, the responsibility of the international community as such, which has overall oversight of the situation in Kosovo. The European Union's responsibility is therefore part of a specific context. It is to the international community as such, in particular the United Nations, that we must turn with regard to responsibilities for implementing Resolution 12/99 and in particular with regard to the logic underlying this resolution and its compatibility with reality. These are questions that we must all ask ourselves, but it is within the framework of the United Nations that we must ask ourselves these questions.

The honourable Member referred to the issue of Ethiopia, which falls within the scope of national indicative programmes. However, as the Honourable Member knows, there are various Community-wide actions to combat AIDS, and in this regard, the Honourable Member is right: the United States is probably doing no better. Furthermore, in terms of development aid policy, I believe that Europe strictly has nothing to worry about, for the simple reason that our performance in this regard is in no way comparable with that of the United States. The honourable Member's question strayed into the broader political problem of armaments, which I do not believe falls within the scope of this question, but which the Council will naturally address in the future if it deems it appropriate and decides to raise it within a specific framework. Is the Council aware of the social problems caused by exporting food to developing countries at prices below EU production costs? Does the current President plan to intervene in this matter? Since its author is not present, Question 13 falls. I thank the President-in-Office of the Council, in whose person I personally welcome you to the Presidency of the Portuguese Government. Allow me to point out how eloquent he is and how well-versed in European issues he is. However, in my case, he has not given the answer that I would consider satisfactory. If the Council recognizes the great importance of culture as an economic asset, in my opinion, it should also demonstrate this in practice. And I fear that the justification that the cultural sector is conditioned by the principle of subsidiarity and is therefore the responsibility of national governments is an apparent justification. Because the question I had raised, and which has remained unanswered, was why, when the European Parliament requests an increase in funds allocated to finance European Union cultural programs, the Council, as well as the Commission, generally cut them, sometimes even cancel them. This, in practice, demonstrates its indifference to culture, despite the Council's promises about the great importance it is supposed to attach to it. I would therefore like to ask the Council whether it is prepared to support culture in the future with the same complacency with which it finances bananas, hops, cows, or Indian hemp. We do not, Your Honor, have an economic conception of our management of the Portuguese Presidency, and therefore, as you will understand, the cultural dimension is at the heart of our concerns. But these cultural dimensions almost always have an economic dimension, in turn, that is, the set of resources that can be mobilized precisely to support cultural activities. And this is a dimension that is difficult to overcome within the European Union and, in particular, within the Council. For our part, we will try to strengthen and consolidate the European position with regard to cultural goods and services and activities in this area, because we believe that this is one of the essential elements of the Union's image and its own specific identity.

You may be aware that this hospital is located in the northern part of the city and that, given the current tense situation, Kosovo Albanians cannot access the hospital under any circumstances. What is the Commission doing to ensure that Kosovo Albanians have access to the hospital? Regarding the first question, I will personally travel to Kosovo early next month for another visit and will certainly examine the allegations the Honourable Member has made about the ECHO food package. I had not heard anything about that suggestion before, but it is an important point, and I will certainly investigate it when I am there. Secondly, I fully understand what the Honourable Member is saying about Mitrovica. I was in Mitrovica a couple of months ago and saw for myself what the situation was like. I held discussions with municipal leaders from both communities, including the leader of the Albanian side, who had previously worked as a doctor and earned universal acclaim for his medical care during and after the hostilities. I am therefore aware of the serious problem that exists in that hospital and I can assure the honourable Member that we will spare no effort to ensure that everyone in Kosovo has access to adequate healthcare, regardless of their ethnic group. The specific difficulties that exist in Mitrovica—for example, it is not just a matter of Albanian patients having difficulty accessing the hospital, but Albanian staff have had difficulty working there—represent a particularly serious problem. We will try to find solutions, but it is not easy. Question No. 37 by (H-0029/00): Subject: The blockade maintained by Turkey against Armenia. Bearing in mind that the European Union is actively promoting social, economic, and political relations with Armenia under the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement signed on 12 October 1999, what measures does the Commission intend to take to persuade the Turkish Government of the need to lift the economic blockade it maintains against Armenia? The Commission supports all efforts aimed at finding a solution to the conflicts between Turkey and Armenia and regrets that normalization of relations between the two countries has not yet been achieved. In the current political circumstances, however, it is unrealistic to imagine that the border between Armenia and Turkey, as well as that between Armenia and Azerbaijan, could be opened without first reaching a solution to the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict. Mr. President, the Commission is also negotiating with an eye to the future, in view of Turkey's accession to the European Union. Is the Commission prepared to impose the prior lifting of the blockade as a condition for starting talks, given that, after all, we are all neighbors and also want to cultivate positive neighborly relations within the European Union? My question, therefore, is this: Does the Commission intend to impose this as one of the conditions for improving the outcome of future discussions? The fundamental issue is support for the efforts of the OSCE Minsk Group to find a solution to the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict, and we are ready to help in any way we can.

I want to address another fundamental democratic issue frankly. As a Member of the Assembly that has just begun work on the Charter of Fundamental Rights, I want to make it perfectly clear that, for my group and myself, a solemn proclamation of the Charter is not enough. What would citizens say if they were solemnly granted rights but could not assert them individually? No, I believe that would only further deepen the credibility crisis from which the Union is suffering. For all of us, the low turnout in the European elections should be a sufficient warning signal. What we need are rights that are perceptible to all; the Charter of Fundamental Rights must be legally binding on everyone living in the Union, on all citizens. In the interests of the latter, we should work together towards this goal, and I expect the Intergovernmental Conference to review the Cologne decision on this matter at the end of the year. Naturally, it is also a question of the effectiveness of decisions and the functioning of the institutions in a Union enlarged to 27 members and more. This will not be achieved by a mini-reform such as that envisaged by the Council, and that is why all the institutions must be put to the test. We must undertake courageous changes while paying the greatest attention to the balance between large and small Member States. I insist on this particularly as the representative of a large Member State. I thank the Commission for the proposals it has put forward and I am convinced that there will be, within this Parliament too, in-depth discussions with citizens on all the issues they have raised. I would like to address one last issue. Parliament's opinion expressly calls for amendments to the Treaty in the area of economic policy. Indeed, economic globalization and especially the introduction of the euro and the accompanying Stability Pact make it necessary to examine decision-making processes. But that is not all. Above all, we need the courage to critically examine the policies pursued so far by the Union. We need a Europe marked by social justice. A Europe marked by social justice remains more relevant than ever because it is, above all, a matter of placing the fight against mass unemployment and poverty at the heart of the Union's policy. To do this, we also need the courage, in my view, to amend Article 4 of the EC Treaty, which defines the Union, in the classic tradition of neoliberalism, as an open market economy with free competition, as well as Article 105 of the EC Treaty, because the European Central Bank must finally respect the mission assigned to it by the Treaty, which is to promote, through its monetary policy, sustainable growth and employment. Mr President, the Europe of Nations Group believes that the agenda of the next Intergovernmental Conference, as defined by the Helsinki Council, that is to say, focused strictly on issues of decision-making in an enlarged Europe, must be respected.

I would like to commend your thesis of greater synergy between the institutions, not only between the Commission and Parliament, but also between them and the Council, to underline the scale of the political challenge. We need a broader dialogue, not only between us, but also with civil society. We need to explain more about what Europe is, we need to be able to address fears and concerns, because in many cases, the greatest fear is fear itself. Perhaps by promoting dialogue and information we will be able to overcome part of this problem. My group is particularly attracted by the creative possibilities that you have raised in relation to the White Paper on new forms of government that will be presented in the spring. Faced with this Europe as an interconnection of different levels that you have described, it is very important that Europe concentrates on its core activities, that is, it is important to have the courage to suggest that there are areas in which Europe could perhaps step aside. Such an attitude could convince citizens that Europe, in its forms of government, is not directed exclusively by Brussels, which concentrates and swallows up more and more powers, decisions and authorities. This is the political essence of the challenge and I think you have illustrated it well to this House today. For my group, enlargement is the first priority against which all other possibilities for reform must be measured, whether they concern forms of government, the Intergovernmental Conference or the reform of the institutions. We see enlargement as a partnership process, not as a process that concerns only us and them; enlargement, for us, is an overall gain for both the Member States and the candidate countries. May I suggest that the Commission, which has an extraordinary amount of detailed information on enlargement, should present a document which explains the value of enlargement, not only in financial and budgetary terms, but in a broader sense: a document similar to the Cecchini report before the Single Act, which explains to citizens, so as to involve them in the debate, that this is the great historical challenge facing modern Europe. We must be able to prepare the ground very carefully. On south-eastern Europe, I agree with you that the value of political institutions is measured by the results they achieve. During the term of this Commission and of this Parliament, we must be able to achieve peace in south-eastern Europe, however difficult and complex that may be. We welcome the stabilisation and association agreements, but we would also like something more. We will make this material public and present it in the debate on the Swoboda report later this week. The strategic document emphasizes the global role of the European Union: our central objective must be to give the Union, on the global stage, a weight that is proportional to its weight in terms of aid, trade and financial flows. At the beginning of this decade we must foresee how our institutions will develop internationally before the end of these ten years, and in particular our role within international monetary bodies, within United Nations agencies and so on. This is a debate that we must launch. To conclude, this morning, the day after Valentine's Day, the newspapers write that our honeymoon is over.

I am referring to the very serious accusations levelled against people and parties like mine, with a long democratic tradition and a scrupulous respect and defence of human rights demonstrated for many years. Madam President, I am concerned that this all-out defence of human rights by Mr Knörr does not prevent his party - in government in that region - from counting on the parliamentary support of a political group that not only does not condemn, but actually encourages violence against citizens and property. I note that Mr Gorostiaga Atxalandabaso has asked to speak on the same subject. This is not the right time to open a debate. I will give the floor for all procedural motions at the end of the votes. Report (A5-0029/2000) by Mr Brok, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy, on the proposal for a Council regulation on the implementation of operations in the framework of a pre-accession strategy for Cyprus and Malta (COM(1999) 535 - C5-0308/1999 - 1999/0199(CNS)) On amendments 22 and 24 In other words, the rapporteur proposes an oral amendment to insert a recital which would read: "whereas Malta and Cyprus will participate..." . (Parliament agreed to the oral amendment) (Parliament adopted the legislative resolution) Report (A5-0013/2000) by Mr Knörr Borràs, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 3605/93 on the application of the Protocol on the excessive deficit procedure annexed to the Treaty establishing the European Community (COM(1999) 444 - C50174/1999 - 1999/0196(CNS)) (Parliament adopted the legislative resolution) Report (A5-0020/2000) by Mrs Cederschiöld, on behalf of the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs, on the draft Council framework decision on increasing protection by criminal sanctions against counterfeiting in connection with the introduction of the euro (5116/1999 - C50332/1999 - 1999/0821(CNS)) (Parliament adopted the legislative resolution) Report (A5-0019/2000) by Mrs Di Pietro, on behalf of the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs citizens, justice and home affairs, on the draft Council act establishing the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union (9636/1999 - C50091/1999 and SN 5060/1999 - C5-0331/1999 - 1999/0809(CNS)) Before the vote, Madam President, I would first like to denounce the absence of the Presidency-in-Office of the Council. When dealing with these third pillar issues and conventions that are so important for the construction of an area of freedom, security and justice, it is not a good thing for the Presidency-in-Office of the Council to be absent. Furthermore, Madam President, I have some comments to make on the problem of translations. I will give you just one example, because we do not have much time, but it is a case where translations are really important, since very specific legal concepts are involved. In Amendment No 83, in Italian, which is the original language, states that "the minor must be assisted by a person he trusts or by an external expert or lawyer".

So this is at least a step forward. The second criticism we have is that the system was too restrictive vis-à-vis the Commission. We adopt legislation in the European Union. We expect the Commission to implement it. And from that moment on, a system designed to hamper the Commission and make its work more difficult intervenes—in particular, this was the case with the so-called "counter-sirloin" system, through which the Council could block the Commission by means of a simple majority, even if the Council was unable to find an alternative to the implementing measure concerned. In this area, too, there is at least some progress. The Council will no longer be able to block implementing measures indefinitely beyond the three-month period unless a qualified majority has been reached to block the measure—in other words, unless there is substantial opposition among the Member States within the Council. This is a more reasonable system. This is also a step forward. However, with regard to the other two criticisms, we are less satisfied. The first criticism concerns the system by which the Commission is monitored, scrutinized, controlled, if you will, by a single committee appointed by the Member States or the Council and not by Parliament. The legislative authorities, namely the Council and Parliament, should be equal. We confer executive powers on the Commission, but only a body appointed by the Council or the Member States can put the kibosh on it, say no to the Commission, and put a stop to an implementing measure. Parliament does not have an equivalent power. It is true that we are now being granted the outline of such a power under this new system. We are supposed to receive all draft implementing measures sent to a committee at the same time as they are sent to that committee. We will have the opportunity to examine them, debate them, and ask questions. However, we will only have the right to challenge the Commission if we believe it is exceeding the powers we have conferred on it in the legislation. In other words, we can challenge the measure if it exceeds its powers, but not its content. And in a democracy, Parliament should be able to challenge the content. I'm not saying we do this every week. We don't seek to delve into implementing decisions, but the fact that we should have the opportunity to do so on the rare occasions when it is necessary constitutes a democratic safeguard. This is what is missing from this system, or at least what is present only in embryonic form. Finally, our fourth criticism is this: if an implementing measure is blocked through the comitology system, it is referred not to both branches of the legislative authority, but only to the Council, which has the right to take, if necessary, an alternative measure. This is not correct. Both branches—Council and Parliament—adopt the legislation that confers implementing powers on the Commission. If such implementing measures are referred, they should be to both branches, not just to one. Generally speaking, we have a system that has improved somewhat. The additional aspects arising from the interinstitutional agreement with the Commission are welcome, but this could not change the Council's basic decision.

The Commission must therefore assume its responsibilities in establishing the strategic framework for promoting employability and quality of work, in assessing results and in effectively disseminating best practices. Only in this way can the desired multiplier effect be achieved. Mr President, I would like to speak on the Commission's proposals for the budget line for information on the CAP. On 26 October 1999, the Commission adopted a proposal to secure the legal basis for the budget line for raising public awareness of the common agricultural policy. Under this proposal, the current budget line B2-5122 will be abolished in favour of a new budget line B1-382. Actions which promote understanding between young farmers and the European Union, and which also create stronger links with the candidate countries and the rest of the world, are important. I am therefore tabling amendments to Parliament to support this type of programme. Since it is necessary to encourage young farmers to remain in agriculture, it is essential that they are well informed about developments in the common agricultural policy: information and training of young farmers at European level is essential. I ask you to accept that part of the available budget should be earmarked for developing knowledge among young European farmers. In the area of information and training, in the past, the budget line was earmarked for information, communication and training. The Commission is now proposing to exclude training. I believe that training should be included where it involves relevant information on the CAP at European level. European training is an element that serves to ensure that young farmers have the necessary knowledge of the CAP to be able to take sound decisions about their future activities. I have therefore tabled three amendments which I ask the Parliament to approve. Mr President, I am taking the floor to express, on the basis of my experience in a municipal administration, the opportunity, but I would almost dare say the necessity, that the projects of the URBAN programme be oriented in a threefold direction: firstly, to promote the recovery of infrastructures and historic, old and perhaps degraded neighbourhoods. Secondly, to facilitate and stimulate economic activities and social life within these historic centres, within these corners of the "old city". What use are those streets, today perhaps tastefully lit, with redone sidewalks, even with tiled paving, splendid in their clarity, if we are then not capable of filling them with activities and therefore employment? And I would like to point out that here it is not a question of financing or assisting different social categories, but rather of knowing how to discern the employment vocation in the projects to be selected, or, but it is the same thing, of selecting projects that are able to incentivise the creation of jobs and initiatives in this area, to give them more impetus. Thirdly, but perhaps I should have said firstly, projects must be aimed primarily at the total recovery of people and families, because man does not exist to serve the law, but it is the law that exists to serve man.

The CFSP will never be anything more than a screen for national interests that have already taken over the system: How can we not see that it is a marriage between London and Berlin, supported when necessary by their respective accomplices and who do not conceive of their diplomacy in terms of autonomy from Washington, carving out for themselves the role of extras. On the other hand, Mr Solana, you are a living example of this so-called structural connivance: you have gone from NATO to the CFSP without discontinuity, as if it were the same thing, and in reality it is. It is always about serving the empire. I cannot deny a certain amusement in hearing you invoke this delightful and at the same time persuasive argument in the ridiculous competition that opposes you to Commissioner Patten. In any case, you declared to a German journalist: "The Americans call me". Mr Solana, you could have added: "It is to me that the orders are passed", because that is our observation. In the Balkans and elsewhere, the Americans ask us to destroy one day and then to rebuild the next. Mr Martinez was absolutely right to interrupt you, Mr Cohn-Bendit, it is still servility. You think I am being excessive! Not a day goes by without the reality of the facts providing us with additional proof of our subservience. ECHELON is one of many examples and it offers an image of Europe that is very different from the one we like to paint here. The experts talk about a cultural problem, I personally find them very amusing. On behalf of the coordination of the European right, I must tell you, Mr High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy, that we do not trust you. You say you are against war, but as Secretary General of NATO you have started one. It was an offensive war, in servile obedience to American policy in an area that does not fall within the North Atlantic Treaty, against a State that had never been a party to it, that did not pose any threat to international borders, a war provoked in violation of international law which establishes the principle of non-interference and the rules governing the declaration of war. Today even Mr Cohn-Bendit finds himself having to assess the results of the disastrous policy that he himself supported. We too have some questions to ask you that betray our concern, to put it mildly. Firstly, you claim that the common foreign and security policy aims to safeguard the security of the Member States of the Union. How can we believe that? Or do you perhaps recognise that these States have the right to intervene anywhere in the world? Secondly, in the latter hypothesis, to which rules of international law and political morality are you referring? I can already imagine your answer: humanitarian law. In Kosovo we systematically destroyed all Serbian civilian infrastructure in the name of humanitarian law. When the US caused the death of 2,000 people in Panama, it was certainly not to impose its policies, it was to fight drug trafficking.

Therefore, on behalf of my group, I am in favour of the Theato report; however, I believe that it is essentially a matter that should be included on the agenda of the IGC. Mr President, Mrs Theato's report on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union proposes, in particular and initially, to centralise criminal proceedings through a European Public Prosecutor's Office. This proposal is decidedly contrary to the spirit of the current system in which criminal law and criminal procedure, which are the cornerstone of national legal systems, must depend on the sovereignty of each people and are the exclusive competence of each State. The idea of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, on the other hand, aims, as regards this matter, to relegate the States to a subordinate role. Furthermore, this proposal would trigger a series of completely unforeseeable reforms. Indeed, according to Mrs Theato's report, the European Public Prosecutor's Office would be necessary, in particular, to frame the investigations of the Anti-Fraud Office, OLAF. But, at the same time, we discover that according to the Van Hulten report, the European Public Prosecutor's Office should in turn be supervised by a European Union court. This is how a small European reform can hide a medium-sized reform that can in turn hide a larger one. Without forgetting that a large reform can in turn hide a giant one because very soon we will be proposed a European criminal law and then, why not, subsequently, also a European Minister of Justice, controlled by the European Parliament, extending its powers. Therefore, I believe that we need to think carefully about the balance of powers that we risk upsetting by presenting this type of apparently specific reform. In conclusion, it seems to us that proposals such as that of a European Public Prosecutor's Office demonstrate the inability to imagine a Europe that is not only top-down, centralized and organized around a super-state. The "Union for a Europe of Nations" group instead wants a polycentric Europe that brings together nations as a network. A network that could be revealed, for example, with better coordination between national prosecutors, with the creation, possibly, of national bodies specialized in infringements against Community finances. Mr President, the legal framework already exists, it is based on a good principle and it only needs to be improved. Mr President, Mrs Theato is proposing an institutional revolution for two reasons. Public opinion, which would be indifferent to twenty million unemployed and thousands of mad cows, would instead be concerned about fraud that would endanger financial interests and these two reasons would justify a two-fold device: a European penal code that includes anti-Community crimes and a European Attorney General. Mrs Theato seems to have forgotten a European prison, however, since the FBI, the European police, already exists with OLAF. The whole thing would be enshrined in two regulations, one for the Prosecutor and one for the penal code, regulations based on Article 280 of the Treaty, that is, starting from secondary law because the characteristic of secondary law is to allow any deviation. In reality there would be two deviations.

We believe that, precisely because Turkey has embarked on a new path in its relationship with the European Union, and also because it now faces the need to respond to the European Union's positions on common foreign and security policy, we are going to test—there's no point in hiding this—its willingness to address the European Union's priorities in its foreign relations. And naturally, the relationship with Armenia, as evidenced by the agreement established last year, is an element of that foreign relationship. And we believe that, if Turkey wants to move forward in sharing the fundamental values of the European Union and the general framework for the European Union's relationship—and regardless of any bilateral differences it may have with another country—it must generally behave in accordance with the basic guidelines that the European Union reflects in its foreign relations. Furthermore, we are confident that this issue will be among the priorities of the bilateral relationship between the European Union and Turkey in the near future. Because these are similar issues, questions 5 and 6 will be answered together. Question No. 5 by (H-0031/00): Subject: Worsening situation in Kosovo The genocide of the Serbs and other ethnic minorities, except the Albanians, continues and is worsening in Kosovo. Even Mr. Kouchner himself recently declared that "the political and security situation in the area is absolutely unsatisfactory." It is also alleged that UN Resolution 1244 has not been respected, since, on the one hand, the UN provisions on granting guarantees to all inhabitants of Kosovo are being violated, and, on the other, extremist and separatist forces are gaining strength, to the point of appointing the former leader of the KLA, Hachim Thaçi, as "provisional prime minister" of Kosovo and proclaiming the latter "Kosovo Protection Corps." What actions does the Council intend to take, in view of the facts, to ensure the implementation of UN resolutions, especially Resolution 1244, and to prevent the secession of the province of Kosovo from Serbia? Question No. 6 by (H-0122/00): Subject: Ethnic cleansing of Serbs in Kosovo. Since the end of the NATO and EU bombing of Yugoslavia under the pretext of preventing the ethnic cleansing of Kosovo Albanians by Serbia, and since the entry of KFOR on 12 June 1999, 200,000 Serbs living in Kosovo have been expelled and 768 murdered, reproducing an ethnic cleansing of Serbs comparatively greater than the one that occurred in the opposite direction. In recent days, we have witnessed the murder of Serbs by Kosovo Albanian mafias, always with impunity. What decision does the Council intend to take to finally end this ethnic cleansing and guarantee respect for human rights for the entire population of Kosovo, regardless of race or belief? I would like to thank the Minister for his response, but also to point out that, statistically, there is more violence in Kosovo now than there was before the NATO bombing.

In this context, water is not a commercial commodity: it is an essential element for life, and people must have free access to a sufficient supply for their normal daily lives. We consider it positive that efforts are being made to reverse alarming trends in water degradation, which governments too often overlook. We all know that water is an essential good for humanity and that it is urgent to protect its quality. But it is equally essential to bear in mind that the components of water policy are inseparable, and action on this aspect determines all the others.
