However, in the debate and in the proposals, preference has been given to the topic of "physical, chemical, and ecological quality of water," and the adverse effects on the other dimensions have been taken into account only marginally. Thus, it is necessary to take into account the diversity of the realities of the Member States, the specific climates, the hydrological regimes and their variations throughout the year, and the social, economic, and ecological effects of the implementation of standards, or even their absence. Concerns about these issues are what have led us to disagree with some proposals from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, especially those relating to an overly restrictive timeline and the lack of attention to social and agricultural aspects, which are very important for a country like Portugal, where there are problems with water scarcity and, in addition, poor socioeconomic development. However, we also believe that in many cases the proposals from the Commission and the Council are too retrograde, and we therefore hope for a balanced vote within the constraints of the proposals presented. The Council's common position on this proposed framework directive has not disappointed. It is minimalist on several points, especially regarding the entry into force dates of a far too large number of provisions, as well as the number and conditions for applying the derogations. However, the main problem lies in the definition of the objective that the European Union wishes to achieve with this text. The objective is, of course, above all, to create a clear general framework that will finally simplify the applicable law in this area. However, in addition to this objective, the Union must have the ambition to improve the quality of both surface and groundwater. Public health and the supply of drinking water, biological quality and diversity, and the preservation of landscapes and species are at stake. From this perspective, the common position is weak. I wish our Parliament would defend a more ambitious position than that of the Council, but I also wish this position were credible. The requirement for "zero discharges" and "zero pollution," including substances naturally present in water, is unrealistic. I am not one of those Members who believe it is essential to adopt "extreme" amendments at second reading, the sole purpose of which is to create room for maneuver with the prospect of negotiations with the Council of Ministers.

The "Grappa War" is thus over. Peace reigns, and we look forward to cooperation with South Africa in accordance with the shared dreams and values that should have guided our relationship for a long time. I consider this a pleasant conclusion to the debate, which was overall quite positive, and I would like to thank the rapporteur and Parliament once again for the cooperation they have shown, particularly in this context, in their relations with developing world countries. Thank you, Commissioner. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12:00 noon. Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia The next item is the report (A5-0031/2000) by Mr Swoboda, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy, on the Commission recommendation for a Council Decision authorising the Commission to negotiate a Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (SEC(1999)1279 - C5-0166/1999 -1999/2121(COS)). Mr President, Commissioner Patten, ladies and gentlemen, today we are dealing with a country that has truly gone through difficult times, a country that has, however, developed very positively through its own strength, its own will and certainly also with the support of the international community. Therefore, when the European Union, Council, and Commission propose—and Parliament will endorse this proposal tomorrow, I assume—to conclude a Stabilization and Association Agreement, the first in Southeast Europe, in the Balkans—I dare say I use that term—then this is primarily a thank you or recognition for the fact that FYROM/Macedonia has carved out a good position for itself, economically, but of course, and above all politically, in light of the war in its neighborhood and also in relation to its own minority. Having a minority of 33 or even 35 percent in one's own country is no small feat, especially given the environment in which this country finds itself. The country and its politicians—to varying degrees here and there—have always done very good work, and this should be recognized. The Commission proposes that we conclude an agreement together with the Council. I would like to make a few comments, namely concerning those areas where views are perhaps somewhat more differentiated, although in this context I would also like to particularly emphasize and acknowledge Commissioner Patten's work and interest in FYROM/Macedonia and the entire region. First: the regional approach. I believe that the regional approach, if properly understood, is important and necessary. There must be a willingness to cooperate. If it is not understood as a constraint, but rather as a willingness, as an opportunity that every country should utilize, then this approach is correct. However, if we look at FYROM/Macedonia, we see that there are some countries in the neighborhood with which cooperation is very difficult, for example, economically, such as Kosovo and Albania, or politically, such as Yugoslavia. On the other hand, cooperation with Bulgaria, and especially with Greece, has developed positively; this too should be recognized.

In Spain—I want to remind you all—it's not that we are in an election period, it's that there are twenty-five days left until the elections. It is a consolation for the Commissioner that these elections will be held in twenty-five days, so he probably won't be asked these kinds of questions again. I do consider it important to say that Andalusia will receive 50% more within the Community framework and that Spain also holds a record in terms of the implementation of the Structural Funds, which means that the distribution is strictly based on the implementing regulations and is decentralized through regional development plans and the various Community support frameworks. Finally, I would like to ask the Commissioner a specific question: do you consider a change to the implementing regulations for the Structural Funds necessary, or do you consider the current distribution criteria acceptable? I find this debate fascinating. I fully understand that there is a dimension that is not exclusively Community-based. However, we must accept the fact that elections are constantly taking place in all countries of the Union. What pleases me is that, fundamentally, the Structural Funds are being debated in Greece and Spain. Earlier, we were talking here about citizen debates, public debates. The more we talk about Europe and what Europe does for everyday life, as long as we talk objectively, even when there are certain differences, the better. I am not going to express my opinion, Your Honor, on a possible change to the Structural Funds regulation. It was not long ago that it was approved—last year—in Berlin. I am putting it into practice for the next seven years. We will talk about it again during the debate on the cohesion report, which for me is an important event, here, with you, and before you, to take stock and at the same time to outline perspectives. At the beginning of next year, the time will come to talk about possible adjustments, possible modifications. For now, please allow me to apply the regulation that has not yet been applied, as it dates from the Berlin Council. This is what I can say today. Thank you very much, Mr. Barnier, for your answers. Questions 48 to 50 will be answered in writing. Question 51 by (H-0049/00): Subject: New OHIM premises. The Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market is currently operating in its same temporary premises, despite the new building having been inaugurated in June 1999. Given this unusual situation, the Commission asks: What are the reasons why OHIM has not yet moved to its new premises? The Honourable Member posed a question on this subject in November 1999, and I would like to refer to the answer given on that occasion. Furthermore, in connection with this new question, I have consulted the President of the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market—that is, the Alicante office—and on its behalf I can inform the Honourable Member of the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market as follows:

We will launch a broad and open consultation process to gather the views of all the different stakeholders. I consider the process to be almost as important as the content; we will devote all our resources to active participation and we invite all interested parties to participate. In parallel, we have also launched a process to improve coherence and to clarify, bring to the surface and make manifest the real or imagined problems we encounter in this area. It will be an ongoing process which I see as a kind of constant quality control and I invite Parliament to take part in it in order to improve the coherence of our actions. Mr President, I would first like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Amado, for what he said, as well as Commissioner Nielson. I am pleased that Mr Amado spoke about the European Development Fund. The resolution of the problem does not depend on this institution, on the European Parliament, or on the Commission; rather, it is up to the Council to take the initiative to give the EDF its own budget, and therefore it is to the Council that the sermon should be addressed. Mr President, I would also like to thank Commissioner Nielson, who spoke at length about the new Lomé Convention. However, that Convention is not exactly the subject we are discussing this morning. In fact, we intended to talk about coherence: that is the real issue today. Already at the beginning of the 1990s, the European Parliament, the European Commission and the European Council recognised that the degree of coherence of the Union's policies was not satisfactory, particularly in the area of development cooperation and in other aspects of European policy. Attention to this problem has been called for on several occasions: in 1992, 1995 and 1997. The resolution we are examining summarises more or less all the attempts made in this regard in the past. I myself already put questions on this issue years ago. In 1997, the obligation of coherence was even included in the Treaty of Amsterdam and then, in 1998, it was decided that the European Commission would draw up an annual report on the progress made. But what has happened since then? We have heard so many fine words, even this morning, but we have not yet seen any reports. It almost seems absurd to say so, but it is true: it is widely acknowledged that the Union's policy is contradictory, good intentions are constantly being made, but in practice nothing happens. It is therefore a good thing that this item is on our agenda today. I will use a few examples to explain the contradictions in the Union's policy. In some developing countries, sugar cane is grown to produce sugar. In the Union, sugar is produced from beetroot. To prevent cheap sugar from developing countries from competing with the more expensive sugar from the Union, a heavy tax has been imposed on sugar cane imports. As a result, imports of this product into the Union have fallen significantly. At the same time, we provide large amounts of development aid to those same countries that produce sugar cane. A minister from a Caribbean island where sugar cane is grown once said to me: If you allowed us to sell our sugar in the Union, we could easily do without your development aid.

How should one describe the rapes, looting, arson, and deportations declared as purges, which are reminiscent of the darkest Middle Ages in Europe? How should one describe the isolation of Russian and international journalists and the banishment of humanitarian organizations and every international commission of inquiry from the sites of the massacres? If this is realpolitik, if we truly have no means at our disposal, then I ask you, Mr. High Representative, Mr. Commissioner, let us at least use the means we do have: the aid programs for Russia. The Chechen war proves—if it were still necessary—that the duty to intervene, or the right to intervene, ends at the border of the major powers. Let us therefore ensure that in future every euro spent in the Russian Federation is used for nothing other than alleviating the suffering of the war-affected population. Mr. High Representative, you have spoken of the progress made so far in implementing the Helsinki resolutions. Some of us are firmly in favor of creating a purely European security organization to protect peace in the world. Of course, we recognize the importance of the Security Council for maintaining peace and international security—also enshrined in the Helsinki decisions. However, it should be noted that you have said nothing about the fact that this role of the Security Council, also reaffirmed in Helsinki, has been questioned in the recent past. The crucial point is: Is there political will to ensure that this mechanism, which will cover the entire spectrum of the Petersberg decisions, truly has autonomous powers of action? What about infrastructure? Is there any plan to guarantee these autonomous powers of action for the entire system? Secondly, what will become of the European defense industry, which is ultimately involved in all activities related to the system? Will the current programs continue? Finally, if a change to the Treaty is necessary, how do you envisage this being implemented, according to the report being presented in Feira, and how will it be integrated into the general process of reforming the institutional framework of the Treaty? How do you see this relating to the possible introduction of qualified majority voting? Are such considerations being considered? Is this issue being discussed? To what extent has the cooperation between you and the Commissioner responsible produced concrete results and a framework strategy on how, in your view, this system can be made truly effective? Mr President, from my studies of European history, I seem to recall that the Agreement of Sintra in 1809 was a controversial peace agreement that prolonged rather than shortened the Napoleonic Wars and almost cost the Duke of Wellington his job. I hope that is not an omen for this Sintra Agreement. Now, however, I would like to congratulate the High Representative on the progress achieved so far. It should be noted, however, that most of his remarks concerned progress on institutional matters, and the true test of the European defense identity will be its ability to generate capacity and effectiveness, rather than the creation of institutions with nicely worded names. And in this regard, I am not sure how advanced our heavy-lift transport capacity is to get those 60,000 troops to their operational locations, or what progress we have made towards an autonomous reconnaissance service, particularly in light of the American statements that they will not provide intelligence to the Europeans until they have mastered security.

It should be remembered that the European Union's overall competitiveness is currently 81% that of the United States of America, and that this figure will only improve if the competitiveness of our competitive units, the regions, improves. This, moreover, comes at a time when technological developments, economic globalization, and our problems, enlargement and the single currency, make it more demanding for regions, but also for businesses and individuals, to make a greater competitive effort. The sixth report of the European Commission offers very valuable conclusions. I will summarize two of them, as the rapporteur has already mentioned, one positive and one negative. The first is that significant progress has been made in territorial and social cohesion throughout the Union and that Community funds have been an important, though not decisive, factor in reducing regional inequalities. The negative is that this great effort was more effective in bringing the GDP and productivity of European regions closer together than in their employment levels. It is therefore necessary to link structural financing more closely to job creation. This, Commissioner, is the first commandment for the coming period. Therefore, Mr. President, I ask my distinguished colleagues to adopt this report and I ask the Commission, as other colleagues have done, to bear in mind the conclusions of its Sixth Periodic Report when planning for the 2000-2006 period. Mr. President, Commissioner, distinguished colleagues, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his good work and for having duly taken into account the amendments proposed during the process of drafting the report in the parliamentary committee. This Sixth Periodic Report establishes the basis for assessing the achievement of the objectives of the Union's regional policy. The report shows that, despite all the efforts made, growth is uneven. The regions of Central Europe continue to experience very rapid development. The most prosperous centers also continue to grow above the European average, while many regions in Southern and Northern Europe are developing much more slowly. We now need a thorough analysis of the reasons why regional policy is not achieving the desired results in all regions. Is this due to bureaucracy or because the differences between regions, such as long distances, extreme cold or heat, low population density, and poor soil fertility, have not been sufficiently taken into account? How can the Union address the challenges brought about by the globalization process so that the most backward regions can integrate? It is also important to determine the effects that the enlargement of the Union will have on the Structural Funds and the development of peripheral regions. Member States must also remember their responsibilities. Some Member States have ignored the compensation principle and reduced national subsidies to regions as the Structural Funds from the Union have increased. This has neutralized the results of regional policy. In the future, we will also need to consider developing indicators to be able to adopt appropriate measures and target them in the right places.

Mr President, Commissioner, this report by my colleague, Mr Berend, is in line with the strategy adopted by the European Commission, giving absolute priority to the aspect of increasing competitiveness. However, the broader objectives of the Structural Funds, such as increasing employment, improving equal opportunities, and making employment and development more sustainable, are only mentioned marginally. I believe that this approach is unjustified and I would ask that the above points be given greater consideration in the sixth periodic report. This does not mean that I do not see the need to strengthen competitiveness, especially as I myself am an entrepreneur in an Objective 1 region, namely Brandenburg, Germany, and I am well aware of the concerns and needs of small and medium-sized enterprises. In Objective 1 regions, it is absolutely necessary to introduce, in parallel, temporary measures to promote job creation, special programmes for young entrepreneurs and initiatives to support the setting up of their own businesses. These sectors are supported through appropriate measures under the EU Structural Funds. Support for the competitiveness of businesses alone cannot achieve the desired cohesion between economic and social development, as the Objective 1 regions lack the basis for an independent economic recovery. Economic development alone does not help to reduce unemployment, as is demonstrated by the fact that at least a 3% increase in gross national product is needed to create additional jobs. The desired results cannot be achieved by focusing exclusively on supply- and demand-oriented economic policy. And even if this were to be done, substantial investments in expansion would have to be made and fewer investments in rationalisation. This must absolutely be combined with a demand-oriented economic policy in order to have a chance of improving the situation in these regions. The situations in the various regions are quite different, which means that a series of accompanying measures would have to be implemented in order to be able to intervene in any way. For example, action is needed in the areas of vocational training, lifelong learning, the reintegration of workers who have been displaced from the production process, flexible working time organisation and types of working time, in order to be able to reconcile personal and social aspects much better and to be able to promote women's access to the labour market again. Mr President, I congratulate the rapporteur on his in-depth report. The main objective of the Structural Funds is to strengthen social and economic cohesion between the regions of the European Union. By stimulating the most diverse investments, the Union is trying to achieve an increase in GDP per inhabitant and to increase employment. From the sixth periodic report on the regions, it can be deduced, with some caution, that the aforementioned incentives do not always have the desired effect. Efforts to increase GDP per inhabitant in the Objective 1 regions do not always generate such an increase. This cannot be said to be a satisfactory result, given that the reference period, at least in recent years, has been characterised by an economic recovery. As the rapporteur points out, even structural measures aimed at boosting employment have not had any noteworthy effects.

We believe this would be desirable. I would like to make a few comments on the costs. Some say that the costs should be borne entirely by the producers, as this is fair and beneficial to consumers. This position seems highly questionable, as the producers would pass all the burden on to the consumers and create their own monopoly on state-controlled recycling. I would caution you against supporting this view. There are amendments which propose that the costs should be divided so that 50 percent are borne by the producers and 50 percent by the purchasers of new vehicles. With this pool, or however one imagines such a system, from 2006 onwards all vehicles in circulation can be taken back without any burden on the last holder, as my group expressly wishes. Our proposal on the distribution of costs has one important advantage, namely that we will not become liable to prosecution by the Court of Justice as soon as the directive has been adopted. Indeed, the retroactive effect that is causing so much concern and anxiety in the automotive industry is a serious problem that we must take into due consideration. For this reason, I propose that the costs be shared between the first holder and the manufacturer. A ban on certain materials: we need that! There are dangerous components in vehicles that must be banned in the long run. To do this, we need an instrument with which to exert the necessary pressure. The proposals put forward by the Commission are too rigid and we have developed some alternatives. A great many good amendments have been tabled. Parliament has gained more powers, let us make them count! We must have the courage to propose and develop a directive that shows the way forward in the future; a directive that was developed simply to do so would not be worthy of this House! I invite you to support my proposal. Mr President, I almost feel like breathing a sigh of relief: we are finally getting to the second reading of this directive that has given us a lot of work and, of course, a lot of work to its rapporteur, Mr Florenz. In my opinion, this directive is not at all satisfactory because it does not answer the real question: what will be done with vehicles that have already been abandoned and that can only be removed at the expense of the community and therefore of taxpayers? Therefore, the "polluter pays" principle does not apply. Vehicles that have already been abandoned are also abandoned by this Community legislation, since they are ignored both by the texts relating to landfills and by this text on VFU. The only merit of this directive is that it foresees the future. However, it has not been possible to solve the problem of vehicles currently in use, but already old, whose recycling will cost much more. On the other hand, we can be quite confident about the future, since we know what efforts car manufacturers are willing to make to find, on the one hand, materials that are easier to recycle, and on the other, to activate recycling procedures. I will also insist on the fact that it is essential to maintain a certain flexibility between recycling, reuse and incineration for new, particularly light materials that allow for a reduction in vehicle consumption and therefore emissions.

There have been several examples in Spain: Michelin, ABB-Alstom, and there are examples in Italy that my colleagues will give you. There is also another disguised method of dismissal, used, for example, in Spain by Ericsson under the name "outsourcing" (behind this beautiful word hides the word "dismissal"). The outsourcing of services, that is to say the subcontracting of services, amounts to transforming a stable and permanent job into a precarious one, without union or social rights. It is indeed a disguised method of dismissal. Commissioner, if the European institutions believe in what they say and talk about full employment, they will have to take clear measures: review the directives to ensure workers' participation in these negotiations, review the directive on collective redundancies, reduce working hours, make European subsidies conditional on a clear commitment to maintaining employment, and include social and labour clauses in the international agreements signed by the European Union. Mr President, this Parliament is once again discussing corporate restructuring in Europe, and I deplore this. Once again, workers are at risk of losing their jobs. Today, we are referring to the Goodyear workers in Cisterna di Latina. As has already been pointed out, this concerns some 600 people and as many families who could, within a month, find themselves deprived of their sole source of income. These workers - despite their willingness to help the company and their high level of professionalism, which has made the Cisterna plant one of the most productive in Europe - risk being excluded from the production chain. On the other hand, Goodyear, which has benefited from national and European subsidies for years, can calmly and freely close its doors. I believe this attitude is wrong: it is wrong towards the workers at the Cisterna plant, and it is wrong towards all the Italian and European citizens who have allowed Goodyear, even indirectly through the taxes they pay, to benefit from the state aid I mentioned earlier. The European Commission and the Council must assume all responsibilities related to this matter, both in terms of adopting a common position on the information and consultation of workers and in terms of Community and national aid, which must only be granted to companies that commit to signing long-term agreements to protect jobs. Today, we are asking the Commission to defend, above all, the Goodyear workers at Cisterna and to exert all possible pressure on the company to reach an agreement as quickly as possible to ensure that the Cisterna plant continues to exist and operate. Finally, I would like to remind you, Mr President and Commissioner, that the time available is truly limited. Therefore, any measures – including those already mentioned by the Commissioner in his introductory report – that we would like to adopt must be adopted immediately and in a timely manner. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in terms of restructuring, there is no doubt that European businesses must adapt to better face new challenges, or risk disappearing.

It is therefore time to examine all the elements of the chain involved in the production of feed for high-yielding animals. It is worth noting, in passing, that the problem is much less serious for the food we eat for our dogs, cats, and other pets. Is it because of the fierce, globalized competition among manufacturers in this sector that it has become a recycling channel for all the waste from the agri-food industry? Such a serious issue cannot be limited to a technical debate, even if the directive already limits the authorization of antibiotics and other growth promoters. The precautions we are about to take for animal feed must also be applied to the food we eat for farm animals, the very animals we will find on our plates. As this report forcefully emphasizes, labeling is an absolute necessity so that every farmer on their farm knows all the ingredients that go into the composition of the feed they feed their livestock. He also needs to know if GMOs have intruded into his bag of protein pellets. These components can potentially pose a risk to public health. In any case, the precautionary principle requires that we have clearly displayed traceability at all levels of marketing these products. But before labeling, clear rules must be put in place. We need to ask ourselves simple questions, such as the real purpose of using animal meal. If we look at all the problems they have caused us, from an ethical and health perspective, it is their very use that we need to question today. To this end, the chapter of the White Paper on Food Safety that deals with animal feed must serve as a working basis to go well beyond simple commercial issues. The Commission has repeatedly used this example: "from farm to fork." Our EPP colleague highlighted this earlier. This is a good formula, but it still needs to be given meaning. And to give it meaning, we need to address both animal-related issues and consumer health issues. This is why it is important to accept Amendment 2 to Recital 4, which avoids the risk of monopoly if the companies that were the first to place an additive on the market remained the only ones able to use it during the re-evaluation period. But above all, we must accept Amendments 4 and 5 to the new Article 2a, which will make it possible to clearly identify genetically modified additives in order to enable users to make a fully informed decision. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the presence of high-tech additives in the animal feed sector requires those involved – and everyone knows there are a great many of them – to provide detailed information on their use, in order to put an end to practices that are contrary to Community law. The directive in question, on additives in animal feed, is not enough. Other directives will follow, and I believe they are in good hands in the Committee on Agriculture. Animal feed and additives are structured, mixed, cut, sliced, and transported repeatedly until the meat, milk, bread, and other products are sold in stores.

Regarding the former, the Commission has sent us a series of proposals, contained in two directives and an action plan, designed to implement the following decision adopted by the Heads of Government in Tampere: "to ensure fair treatment of third-country nationals legally residing in the territory of their Member States. A more vigorous integration policy should aim to grant them rights and obligations comparable to those of EU citizens." This is precisely the opposite of what we have seen and observed in recent days in El Ejido: a world of irregularities, labor exploitation, and miserable living conditions, which have already been denounced. I hope for the swift implementation of the integration measures, and I also hope that the governments that used such fine words in Tampere—among them the Spanish government—will make a full commitment to their implementation. I have less hope for the development of an effective and fair European policy consistent with the Council's declarations on immigration. The only proposal received is the directive on family reunification, a key issue—we've seen many single men in the media in El Ejido these days—but we don't know if it has been adopted by governments yet. Outside of the Community sphere, some governments are making efforts to redesign their immigration policies. In my country, this is being done independently of the government; the governing party is the only one that dislikes the new Aliens Law. The objective of combating racism and xenophobia, enshrined in the Treaties, should be embraced by all institutions and all political leaders of the Union. European political parties signed the Charter of European Political Parties for a Society Without Racism on February 28, 1998. The People's Party also did so. This commits them to consistent action, but local leaders of this party are adding fuel to the fire by boycotting other institutions' attempts to extinguish it. The party to which the mayor of El Ejido belongs should act consistently, faithful to the commitments signed in this declaration. Only with great unity, as Mr. Hernández Mollar said, with responsibility and determination, can El Ejido, and with it all of Spain and Europe, overcome facts that today cause us deep shame. Mr. President, in the face of the scenes of veritable lynchings of Moroccan workers that unfolded in El Ejido, one can only feel disgust and indignation. We do not know to what extent the racist, far-right commandos are responsible, or the ordinary people who carelessly and thoughtlessly followed suit. We wish to express our unconditional solidarity with these Moroccan workers, who are not only exploited by unscrupulous employers but are also victims of such attacks. If the aggressors include members of the common people, we can only tell them that they are digging their own graves with their actions. By waging war against people just as poor as they are, they are only serving their own exploiters and preparing a future of oppression for themselves. However, those who engage in racist, xenophobic incitement bear even greater responsibility than the thugs armed with knives and iron bars, those who deliver demagogic, xenophobic speeches in Spain, Austria, France, or elsewhere, and even here in this very chamber. They are no better than those who take this reactionary, absurd demagogy at face value.

We have all the instruments, all the tools we need, but we need to combine them much more effectively than before, and that is the challenge that the High Representative and I will face up to in the next four to five years. Now I hope that we will receive support in meeting these challenges in the form of both adequate resources and brilliant rhetoric. We all know that there are a number of reasons for building a common foreign and security policy. I would like to mention three of them: Bosnia, Albania, and Kosovo. These are three reasons for a common foreign and security policy, and we will be judged on how successful the common foreign and security policy we have developed will be, and above all on how we deal with the events in the Balkans. We must not lose sight of the fact that quite a few of our critics, quite a few American politicians, and quite a few senators and congressmen are asking: "How can we take you seriously in your development of a Common Foreign and Security Policy if you can't even deal with the problems on your own doorstep?" So, the big test for us will be the Balkans. I hope that all those heads of government, all those prominent politicians in our member states who promised the moon for the Balkans, who pledged the Marshall Plans, and who made all those other promises to the Balkans, will be there when the budgetary authority makes its decision on how much we need to spend on the Balkans. My great hope would be that we all live on one planet whose inhabitants also include the European Council, the General Affairs Council, and the Economic and Financial Affairs Council. All living together on the same political planet, ensuring that there is a certain degree of consistency between what we have promised the world and what we can actually achieve. In the past few months of my work, I have heard assurances that we will become more involved in Latin America; I have heard promises that if an agreement is reached in the Middle East peace process, we will pay for it. I have also heard of our intention to establish a stability pact in the South Caucasus. And I have heard the commitment that we intend to safeguard democracy in Indonesia by providing greater support to that country. How do we resolve this issue? And this is not a reference to any of the political disputes of the recent past. I believe we should return to this question repeatedly in the coming weeks and months. One of the reasons I am so passionate about implementing effective reform of our external assistance programs is that I don't want to find myself in a situation again where someone asks a question like the one about the deep gap between rhetoric and reality, and the answer is, "Oh, we know you're not exactly working very effectively, we know you haven't fulfilled all your commitments, we know there's some money left in your pocket." I want us to be able to say, "It's not like that anymore.

Similarly, the Treaties do not define the concept of author. The Commission has also failed to respond to questions about what definition it intends to act on and whether it intends to resolve foreseeable conflicts by imposing its definition of the legal concept on others. One of the most delicate issues is the public interest: will the transposition and application of the WIPO Convention lead to the privatization of creation? And finally, the question of the relationship between the TRIPS and the WIPO Convention must be clarified. The Commission's silence in this regard also requires clarification. If an announced parliamentary debate contributes nothing to clarifying the issues or to adopting positions, then we should at least abstain! Report by Graefe zu Baringdorf (A5-0015/2000) Following the BSE and dioxin scandals, food safety issues are taking center stage. GMOs continue to present many uncertainties regarding their environmental impact on human and animal health. Therefore, where scientific certainty is lacking, the precautionary principle must prevail. A more in-depth study of the use of biotechnology is required, and it should no longer be "packaged" for sale in the name of profit for some multinationals in the sector. Furthermore, profit has been the driving force behind the current food safety crises. The rapporteur places himself within this framework, legally framing the issue of GMOs in animal feed, recalling that they "can only be authorized if they are harmless to human health and the environment." Furthermore, he believes that "genetically modified additives must be clearly indicated as such on all labels, administrative documents, or other accompanying documents." This will allow for greater control and traceability of these additives and guarantee consumer freedom of choice. Following the Montreal Agreement on genetically modified organisms (GMOs), I consider it positive that the rapporteur has included these issues in his report, and I therefore voted in favor of it. Stenzel report (A5-0034/2000) Mr. President, I would like to give a very brief explanation of vote, on behalf of the PPE Group, regarding the report on Equal. We followed a voting list that was exactly the same as the one previously agreed upon with the Socialist Group. That group changed its mind, which is why the report is now less clear than it would otherwise have been. This is why we abstain. We want the report on Equal, which is very important for refugees as well as for the elderly, the disabled, and women, to continue as normal. It is regrettable that the procedure has resulted in this report receiving such unfavorable attention in this plenary session. I am convinced that the rapporteur's nationality played a role, something that should not happen in this Parliament. It is truly contrary to European values, and certainly contrary to the values so often spoken about in this Parliament.

Given the position we took in Seattle, I am surprised by the EU's silence on the failure to implement the trade facilitation measures already agreed for developing countries in the GATT negotiations, including in the vital textile sector. Regarding the Common Agricultural Policy, the biggest culprit, no assessment of the development impact of the Agenda 2000 CAP reforms has been carried out. The scandal surrounding the export refund system is well known: 54,000 tons of surplus, subsidized beef were dumped to West African markets, resulting in a 50% drop in producer prices for local cattle farmers. Currently, 300,000 tons of beef are in storage. Who will be the next victim? I welcome Mr Amado's statement this morning, in which he highlighted the problems surrounding the failure to budget for the EDF, and called for a more active role for the Development Council and for development priorities to be taken into account as a central element of the new Common Foreign and Security Policy. I also welcome the Council's 1992 statement, its 1997 resolution, and the subsequent amendments to the Treaty on European Union. To date, the necessary measures have not been taken. For this reason, we are calling for annual reports, an interdepartmental working group to meet once a year, and an appeals procedure to ensure that the necessary measures are actually taken. I would like to ask Mr Nielson to address these points of the resolution directly in his summary. Mr President, I would just like to say something about the link between development cooperation and agriculture. In recent years, a significant proportion of funds have been channeled into agricultural and livestock development in developing countries, particularly in the Lomé countries. The results are certainly not what we expected. What could be the reason for this? I think the main cause is the lack of a consistent agricultural policy in certain developing countries, although this certainly does not apply to all. The Commission has an important role to play in developing such a policy. No farmer, anywhere in the world, will produce anything if prices are too low. Governments in developing countries are always faced with a difficult choice: whom should they support, the farmers or the people in the big cities who want to buy cheap food? This delicate balance must be struck jointly with the Commission, and not by the Commission alone. In most of the countries where the Commission is active, development aid is also provided by the Member States themselves. Member States' policies must not conflict with Commission policy. The Commission's delegations in developing countries must play a leading role in developing this political dialogue and ensure that all countries are on the same track. Particular attention must also be paid to the cost of inputs. Far too often, artificial fertilizers, veterinary medicines, and many other things are provided free of charge to farmers. Once the project has ended after five years, this policy of giving gifts also comes to an end. Therefore, the cost element should be addressed from the outset in the policy of all projects. As far as I know, this is far from always the case.

My second question concerns Africa, which, unlike all other continents, is also not mentioned in Shaping the New Europe. In Africa, we have the most refugees in the world, the greatest poverty, and a devastating AIDS epidemic. I know that Commissioner Nielson and others are doing good work in this area, but the Commission as a whole must pay more attention to this continent, including in its strategic objectives. Finally, let me underline that I welcome the Commission statement, which stresses for the first time that the EU is prepared to take unilateral measures to give developing countries greater access to our markets. My question is: when will this happen? Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, we have before us a document that is of crucial importance for the future and destiny of Europe. However, among all the points mentioned, two closely intertwined aspects pose an immediate challenge for us: peace and stability in Europe and outside Europe. These objectives must be pursued as a priority, as has long been our common aspiration, but we must also make it clear that they cannot be achieved without enlargement, even if it entails costs. Today, we are called upon to choose for the coming decades between a Europe that is less rich but a beacon of peace and civilization for the entire planet, and a perhaps richer Europe without a vision of the future. However, these objectives can only be achieved if, as a result of the Intergovernmental Conference ending in a year, a constitutional reform takes shape, conferring appropriate and genuine powers on the Commission, which must not merely execute the decisions of the Council or the co-decisions of Parliament, but must assume the role of a genuine European government. Parliament should be the leading advocate of this reform if it truly wishes to expand its role as the voice of the will of the Union's citizens and assume the central function required of a truly democratic and highly integrated Union. Furthermore, the Commission can only be held accountable for the commitments it has assumed within the limits of the powers actually conferred on it. Without these prospects, Europe would face a hopeless future. Madam President, Mr. President of the Commission, we can only welcome the ambitious goals announced, which are in line with the challenges facing Europe. I note that you consider the fall of the Berlin Wall to be the most important event of the end of this century. This event lays the foundation for enlargement. However, I would prefer to use the word "enlargement" rather than "reunification," because it seems to me to have a much stronger political significance. You are taking up the idea of focusing your work more closely on core tasks and making this an objective of your reforms. Essentially, it is about applying the principle of subsidiarity. The clear application of this principle can only reinforce the measures implemented and give citizens a clear understanding of each level of responsibility. But, Mr. Prodi, it is one thing to announce this, quite another to implement it!

As in Spain in April 1998, and as in Brittany and the Vendée since last December, an exceptional natural area is once again seriously threatened. In its resolutions, the European Parliament constantly draws attention to this type of danger, which threatens our environment, disrupts our ecosystem, and once again destabilizes populations. This new catastrophe raises the problem of integrating the EU environmental acquis for the candidate countries. The obstacles that the authorities of these states, still environmentally fragile, must overcome are numerous. First, prevention of this type of discharge must be improved by remediating the most critical industrial sites. Second, these countries should be able to have sufficient technical means to halt such pollution and reduce its scope. Finally, they should be able to implement recovery programs for the most affected and sensitive areas. Today, the banks and waters of more than four rivers crossing four countries are polluted. For this reason, the European Union must concentrate its efforts and exert pressure to ensure that all candidate countries adapt to EU environmental protection standards. But above all, what is at stake are the technologies and resources available to prevent and quickly and effectively address these types of disasters. I hope our future partners will demonstrate greater responsibility. The environment must be a priority within the framework of the reunification of the European continent. It must be at the heart of our partners' political will. The implementation of high environmental standards will not only allow for the development of important industrial and technological sectors, but will also simultaneously bring about favorable social and economic consequences and improve public health standards. The efforts already undertaken must be strengthened. The European continent must express its solidarity, and responsibilities must be clearly defined within the framework of the "polluter pays" principle. Mr. President, when the Doñana disaster occurred, the non-governmental organization World Wide Fund for Nature presented us with a report on the number of these types of ponds in Europe. We all know that there are an enormous number of these types of ponds, which are an ecological bomb and affect the supply of drinking water, the ecological wealth, and also the economic future of these areas. I was in Doñana after the spill and saw how agriculture, fishing, and the lives of the citizens of the surrounding area were greatly compromised. Therefore, I believe that the European Union must, first of all, analyze the situation of these ponds and rigorously record their number in Europe. It must proceed to include these ponds in Community law, in the directives related to waste, and use the principle of prevention to prevent this from happening again. Otherwise, we will be continually endangering the ecological wealth of our continent. Mr. President, this disaster at the Romanian mine encompasses a vast hydrogeological area with rivers and streams in Romania, Hungary, Serbia, and Bulgaria. The release of 100,000 cubic meters of water contaminated with cyanide and heavy metals into the ecosystem will have enormous consequences for the inhabitants of these regions, for the flora and fauna, for agriculture, for tourism, and for the entire ecosystem and biological diversity.

It should be remembered that at the Conference on Rural Development held in Cork from 7 to 9 November 1996, rural development was defined as one of the priorities of the European Union, insofar as it is essential to preserve the integrity of our agriculture and the entire rural fabric (infrastructure, public and private services, etc.). In this context, we deplored in committee the appropriations allocated to rural development and supported the amendments calling for an increase in the budget for this Community initiative, so that it would be in line with the previous Leader I and Leader II initiatives. Compared to the latter initiative, which had a limited duration of 6 years, the budget allocated to Leader +, for a duration of 7 years, is 50%. This is unacceptable in view of the importance of rural development and the consequences for farmers of the fall in prices and aid as provided for in the CAP reform following the Berlin agreements. Finally, among the priority parameters that will be introduced at European level to enable local registrations, particular attention must be paid to the quality and originality of projects that have already been carried out by LAGs under the Leader II initiative, but which have not been able to come to fruition due to the timetable and the complexity of the planned management arrangements. (The sitting was suspended at 1.40 p.m. and resumed at 3 p.m.) Additives in animal feedingstuffs The next item is the report (A5-0015/2000) by Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 70/524/EEC on additives in animal feedingstuffs (COM(1999) 388 - C5-0134/1999 - 1999/0168(CNS)). Mr President, Commissioner Byrne, Directive 70/524 currently provides for different treatment of high-tech additives when it comes to replacing existing authorisations. The Commission is now proposing to harmonise the authorisation procedures so that substances authorised before 1988 are placed on an equal footing with those authorised now. The Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development agrees on this point. However, the directive also covers the authorisation of antibiotics, other medicinal substances, growth promoters and genetically modified organisms. This is a matter of health and not simply a matter of harmonisation of legislation. The Committee on Agriculture is therefore of the opinion that the legal basis – Article 37 – is not admissible here and that the Commission should instead propose a legal basis based on Article 152, which provides for codecision by Parliament. We have asked the opinion of our Legal Affairs Committee, which has indicated that, regarding this harmonisation of legislation, Article 37 would be sufficient in this case. However, we, the Committee on Agriculture, have not limited ourselves to addressing this harmonisation of legislation; we have tabled another amendment, taking into account the fact that this proposal also concerns genetically modified organisms, and this amendment addresses the issue of content and therefore also the health of the population. We negotiated with the Commission for two years on the Seeds Directive and we have reached a compromise that regulates the release of genetically modified organisms in this directive. In doing so, we started from the text that serves as the basis for this Directive 70/524. Mr Byrne, we do not understand why the Commission is undertaking harmonisations and not also providing for the harmonisation of the text concerning genetically modified organisms.

Why not establish a kind of technological convergence criterion in Lisbon, according to which Member States should increase their research and development expenditure to at least 2.5% of their GDP within five years, which would still be below the current share of the USA? In this context, I would also like to welcome Commissioner Philippe Busquin's initiative to create a European Research Area. Better living conditions, employment, and the quality of employment will continue to depend heavily on our ability to stimulate European research. A genuine European patent, the development of venture capital, and support for start-up companies would also be crucial to this. President Prodi responded yesterday evening to my remarks about Europe's future deficit. However, I believe he misunderstood me, because I was not accusing the Portuguese Presidency or the Commission of lacking vision, but rather speaking of the fear of the future that grips many of our fellow citizens in a rapidly changing world. We are all aware that the development of the information society represents a paradigm shift. However, in a world where 1.5 billion people still live without electricity, the inclusion of all the world's people in the internet society is not achievable in the immediate future. The greatest challenge facing humanity is to avoid the division into "info-rich" and "info-poor" countries, to prevent the emergence of societies in which, as my friend Claude Desama aptly put it, digital divides are the new social divides. The annual legislative program is the most concrete expression of the key constitutional and political powers of the European Commission, which grant it the exclusive right of initiative. Such powers must always be legitimate and clearly justified. As in all previous years, this year's work program fails to provide a detailed justification for each of the numerous newly proposed measures. The 15-page general summary certainly does not do justice to the 500 initiatives listed in the appendix. The ELDR will therefore in future insist on a clear justification for all measures announced in the work programme, as well as a corresponding dedicated parliamentary debate. Above all, we are concerned with demonstrating that each new proposal has been thoroughly scrutinized to ensure it complies with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. We will also be seeking sector-specific debates in the European Parliament's special committees. In other words, it is high time that the somewhat antiquated procedure by which this crucial programme document is drafted and debated was given a complete overhaul. Mr President, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for speaking to us twice within 24 hours. Yesterday evening, he stated clearly that the outlook for the European economy over the next two to three years is very positive and that the unexpectedly above-average growth rates will make it easier for us to achieve the objectives of this annual legislative programme. In his intervention this morning, the President of the Commission raises three issues that concern me. The first concerns subsidiarity, which our group insists on very strongly, and the Liberals have already pointed out, that each individual proposal must be shown to be in Europe's interest.

I don't know if this information is correct, but we in the EPP-ED Group would certainly be grateful if this item were removed, because Parliament has already addressed this issue on several occasions. There are also resolutions against such a tax. That is why my group is requesting that this item be removed from the agenda. Thank you very much, Mr. Poettering. We now come to Mr. Wurtz, who is speaking against the motion. Madam President, I would first like to point out that what Mr. Poettering is saying is not entirely logical. Firstly, he is lecturing the Socialist Group because it is questioning a very clear and unambiguous decision of the Conference of Presidents. And now he is doing exactly the same thing. We discussed it, and we agreed, only the EPP Group and the Liberals did not. And I also pointed out, as the other Presidents will remember, that the issue is not whether we are for or against the Tobin tax, but whether we are prepared to listen to what the Commission and the Council think about it. That is not too much to ask. I therefore reiterate the suggestion that we maintain this oral question to the Commission and the Council in order to ascertain once and for all the opinion of these two institutions on this relatively modest proposal, which would send an important signal to the public, particularly after the furore following the failure of the Seattle Conference. We shall now vote on the PPE/DE Group's request to remove the oral question on the capital tax from the agenda. (Parliament rejected the request by 164 votes to 166, with seven abstentions.) Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Poettering for drumming up support for this debate. Thank you very much. Madam President! Has my vote been counted? I couldn't cast it electronically because I don't have the card. I voted "for." Indeed, if you add the two Members who spoke up, the result is... Madam President! The Presidency has announced the result of the vote. No changes are possible. Madam President, during the earlier vote on the Commission's strategic plan—don't worry, I will abide by your decision on this matter—I asked to be allowed to speak on behalf of my group before the vote. This did not happen. I would welcome the opportunity to give an explanation of vote on behalf of my group at the end of this item of business. This is an important matter. Perhaps it would be useful to record how what we have just done is received by each member in the light of their own political analysis. Madam President, I do not want to reopen the debate, but I also asked to comment on Mr Barón Crespo's request. You did not call on me either. I regret that, but the vote has been taken, the decision has been made, so let's leave things as they are. I am sorry, Mr Hänsch and Mr Cox. I had not seen that you had asked to speak. But the positions have become clear and will be recorded in the Minutes.

The honourable Member is therefore quite right to point out the strategic importance of these regions. We are involved in programmes in the region which also have an impact on the environment. There is a direct link between our food programmes and structural reforms in agriculture and poverty alleviation. These programmes themselves are intended to help put these countries' agriculture on a more solid footing and put an end to overexploitation. We should continue to give priority to this ecological aspect in the future. We also note carefully that the honourable Member who drafted the question applauded the Commissioner's answer. That is not usual. Furthermore, the Commissioner did not cite a bibliography in this case. Thank you very much, Mr Patten, for your contributions today. Question No 35 by (H-0778/99): Subject: Greek Action Plan for Employment According to the results of the evaluation of the action plans for employment, Greece and Italy are the countries most affected by the Commission's criticisms, both as regards the inconsistency of the plans and of the measures and policies to support employment. The report points out that in Greece and Italy the objectives for improving employability have not been achieved and it is uncertain whether the policies to be implemented satisfy the guidelines for preventing and combating long-term unemployment. With regard to Greece, it is also pointed out that there is no programme of medium- and long-term measures to reduce the tax burden and social security contributions in the employment sector and to ensure satisfactory use of ESF resources to support employment policy, and that, moreover, precise employment figures are not available. Can the Commission state whether the Greek government has made any concrete commitments, and which ones, regarding how it will tackle the problem of youth unemployment and long-term unemployment, and whether it has established and is implementing an appropriate system for locating, recording, and monitoring unemployment fluctuations, or whether most measures continue to be limited to enumerating unemployment? Regarding Mr. Papayannakis' question: As part of the 1999 employment package, the Commission made certain recommendations to Greece to make employment promotion measures more effective. These recommendations essentially suggest intensifying efforts to reform public services in problem areas, improving the statistical recording system, and implementing preventive policies in accordance with Guidelines 1 and 2 of the employment package. As part of its employment policy, the Greek government announced two concrete programs in 1999: "Yes to Working Life" and "Back to Work." Since the final results for these programs are not yet available, we cannot yet say whether the quantitative targets have been achieved. The Greek government now acknowledges the problem of its inability to measure unemployment fluctuations. It has therefore committed itself to, first, restructuring the public employment offices; second, creating efficient employment promotion centers—a program to this end has been initiated but is not yet completed; and third, introducing electronic employment cards and implementing appropriate computer systems to monitor the implementation of all these policies.

It's about strengthening banking supervision. It's about clarifying liability for transactions. It's about a regulatory framework at the international level. It's about reviewing national laws to determine whether they comply with the Basel Committee's rules and how these can be more widely disseminated. I have a major problem with one central point in this resolution, which we cannot accept in its current form. That is point 9. Having listened to the Commissioner, we know that the Commission's expertise will lead to a rejection of the Tobin tax. If the expertise, this debate, and the arguments are as we have presented them, and as I believe them to be correct, then keeping the Commission on the matter for another six months and thus causing uncertainty in the financial and capital markets is irresponsible. The capital market doesn't need uncertainty from us; it needs clarity from us. We therefore reject point 9 and call for a split vote. Madam President, the debate about taxing short-term financial transactions is not new. We've been debating the Tobin tax proposal for twenty years, and yet this question remains perennially relevant, because we need truly concrete and honest answers based on careful studies. We need to know how desirable and feasible a tax on short-term financial transactions actually is. This question truly takes on a different dimension today, when 1.5 trillion US dollars roam the world 24 hours a day in search of attractive investments, and at most 3% of this is connected to the real economy. We are concerned about the stability of the financial markets, not for the sake of the financial markets, but because it also affects our own growth, our own investments, and our own jobs in the European Union. Here, we must ask what instruments we can use to truly create a certain order here that has so far been lacking. We have contributed everything we can to the liberalization of financial transactions, but to this day we don't have a functioning set of rules, and we have had to experience this bitterly with the effects of the Asian and Latin American crises. It is therefore high time that we consider, on the one hand, supervisory rules and, on the other, transparency in the financial markets and their information. It is important that we know which players exist and what their creditworthiness is. We must also ask ourselves whether there is not a requirement for fiscal justice. At a time when the tax burden on labor is increasing across Europe and internationally, we must consider how we can achieve efficient taxation of capital gains, and we must also address the question of the taxation of short-term financial transactions. I truly believe it is necessary that we receive a thorough report and conclusion from the Commission so that we, as the European Parliament, can determine whether we need to ensure that the European Union, together with the USA and Japan, truly achieves international solidarity in order to make the economy and the financial markets more stable and secure.

Therefore, without a more active role for the Development Council in the overall coordination of political decisions that take place outside its decision-making centre and directly affect the European Union's development policy, it will certainly be difficult to develop a more coherent European Union policy in relation to development objectives. The European Parliament's input and reflection will certainly be timely and welcome here as well. Let me begin by saying a few words about the successfully concluded negotiations between the EU and the ACP countries. I would like to point out that participating in these negotiations was a very positive experience. I saw Member States working as a team, a great experience indeed. Both sides were deeply satisfied at the end of the negotiations, not only because they had come to an end, but also because we all knew that we had achieved something together, the EU and the 71 ACP countries. The world needs this, and the signal sent is very positive in the context of the general discussion on globalization. I will highlight some of the novelties contained in this new agreement. We are explicitly addressing the issue of corruption; we are establishing a framework for dealing with the immigration problem, for the very first time. We are encouraging participatory approaches, ensuring that civil society is consulted on the reforms and policies that the EU should support. We are refocusing development policies on poverty reduction strategies. We are basing the allocation of funds not only on an assessment of each country's needs, but also on an evaluation of their policy performance. We are creating an investment mechanism to support private sector development. We are streamlining instruments and introducing a new rotating programming system that allows the Community and beneficiary countries to regularly adjust their cooperation programs. We are decentralizing administrative, and sometimes financial, responsibilities to local levels with the aim of improving cooperation. We are improving the policy framework for trade and investment development. We are strengthening cooperation in all areas of trade importance, including new issues such as labor standards and the relationship between the environment and trade. After Seattle, I am sure you will appreciate the significance of these agreements. I now turn to some of the more important points. First, the agreement on political issues. The new agreement will involve a firm commitment on both sides to good government as a fundamental and positive element of the partnership, a subject for regular dialogue in a sector that enjoys the active support of the Community. Second, a new procedure has been devised for dealing with violations of human rights, democratic principles, and the rule of law. Compared with the current procedure, the new procedure places greater emphasis on the responsibility of the State concerned and allows for greater flexibility in the consultation process, with the aim of conducting a productive dialogue leading to measures to redress the situation. In cases of particular urgency, namely serious violations of one of these fundamental elements, measures will be taken immediately and notification will be made to the other party.

Of course, an effective competition policy is a prerequisite for the proper functioning of the internal market and of the Economic and Monetary Union. However, as the rapporteur points out, such aid is sometimes indispensable and can, in addition to the survival of certain businesses, contribute to sustainable development (Article 6 of the Treaty), services of general interest (Article 16) and economic and social cohesion (Article 158). However, it is clear that it must be monitored and this task falls to the European Commission. The aid that the Member States of the Union devote each year to the sectors in question reached, in the period 1995-1997, a total of EUR 95 billion, of which 40% was for the manufacturing sector. This aid has fallen significantly compared with the previous period, 1993-1995 (a decrease of 13% in the total amount and from 3.8% to 2.6% in the amount dedicated to aid for the manufacturing sector). This reduction in aid is mainly explained by the reduction in aid granted to the new German Länder. Like the rapporteur, I also regret that the data presented in the report do not include all state aid. The European Commission must remedy these shortcomings as quickly as possible. It must also work with the Member States to improve the quality of the data in good time, i.e. for the ninth census. It would be a good thing if the Commission were to publish a register showing the amounts of state aid by Member State. I also regret that the European Parliament is completely excluded from the Advisory Committee on State Aid. To remedy this situation, the European Commission must undertake to submit regular reports to us. I will conclude on one aspect of the use of state aid that I find particularly dangerous: aid that results in the transfer of a business from one Member State to another, with the risk of subsidy hunting without these contributing to the achievement of the EU's common objectives. For this reason, I hope that the next survey of state aid will include an assessment of the impact of such aid on employment and on the industrial and craft sectors in the beneficiary countries. Langen report (A5-0073/1999) This morning, in the context of the important debate on competition, I expressed my opinion on Mr Langen's text concerning the application in 1998 of the sixth steel aid code. As the Court of Justice recognised in its judgment of 3 May 1996, the steel sector is particularly sensitive to distortions of competition. It was therefore legitimate to introduce a system of state aid to this sector in order to guarantee the survival of viable firms, even though Article 4(c) of the ECSC Treaty prohibits all state aid to the steel industry. This is, in fact, the subject of the sixth steel aid code. At the same time, of course, it is essential to avoid any threat to the conditions of competition and any serious disturbance of the markets, hence the importance of regulating such aid. State aid should therefore continue to be granted only for research, development, environmental protection and aid granted in the event of plant closures.

Madam President, I would also like to applaud the Commission's initiative in presenting us with a report on its strategic objectives for the next five years, although I hope that it intends to correct, in subsequent documents, the excessive generalities and imprecision of the text we are analysing today. Having said that, Madam President, I would again denounce the absence of fisheries policy, even though I am hardly being listened to. It is truly surprising that the Commission does not include among its strategic objectives for the coming years the process of reviewing one of its common policies with a view to the reform that is due to take place in 2002. This review process is, without a shadow of a doubt, the most important event that will affect the fisheries sector for many years to come. But, at first glance, this is not the opinion of the Commission, which is responsible for presenting to the Council and Parliament, before the end of 2001, the report on the operation of the common fisheries policy over the last decade, on the basis of which the Council will have to take the appropriate decisions to amend it. In fact, the review process has already begun for many groups and institutions, such as the European Parliament, which, in 1998, already dictated and approved a report listing all the problems and defects currently present in the common fisheries policy. We have repeatedly asked for a minimum timetable for this review, but we have not received a response. Less than two years is not much, if we also remember that the fisheries policy is experiencing an anomalous situation with regard to internal market standards and that a solution to these anomalies should be found within the framework of the reform procedure. Therefore, Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, I ask that this point, which is of vital importance for such an important sector of the European Union, be taken into account in this strategy and in these strategic objectives for the next five years. Madam President, I would also like to congratulate Commissioner Prodi on his programme. I am particularly pleased that he has recognized this virtuous circle of sustained growth: the information society within an expanding European market with, in addition, a functioning single currency will give us the opportunity to truly develop prosperity, innovation, entrepreneurship and, yes – most importantly – sustainable jobs with very high added value for European citizens. I have one observation, not a criticism, to make regarding Commissioner Prodi's statement this morning, namely that it was a little weak on the actual content of economic policy. We must not take anything for granted as regards how to achieve the restructuring of the European economy. After all, what is social justice without full employment? Full employment is the best way to achieve social justice for our citizens. It is a fundamental priority for us, and one on which we must focus our efforts.

This is proof, if any were needed, that an immature diplomacy, which defends no interests, except perhaps particular ones, caught between the theology of free trade, pressure groups and more or less friendly NGOs, is not only effective, but dangerous. Finally, a word on the general inspiration of the Corrie report. Today, the Joint Assembly is considered, let us not hide it, as an obstacle to international free trade by theologians in Geneva and Washington. This was an opportunity to recall that our original and exemplary mode of cooperation with the countries of the South should be developed and strengthened. This opportunity was missed by the Corrie report and, regrettably, we must sanction the fact that it was lost to this extent. Mr. President, by way of conclusion and summary, I would like to highlight three essential aspects of this debate. First, the idea that emerges very strongly from all the interventions is that globalization accentuates regional imbalances and social inequalities, that it increases poverty. Something must therefore be done, otherwise tensions will be aggravated and mechanisms will emerge that trigger conflicts that jeopardize international peace and stability. Second, from this perspective, it would be important to give another dimension to development policies by promoting their role in correcting imbalances and mitigating inequalities. I think everyone agrees on the crucial importance of the European Union's role in development policies at the international level. Everyone recognizes, and this was the theme of today's debate, that for the European Union to assume a more active and leading role in development policies at the international level, it will necessarily have to strengthen the coherence of its various policies that contribute to development objectives. I believe that some of the interventions have also clearly emphasised the fact that this responsibility for the coherence of European Union policies does not fall exclusively on the Council, the Commission or Parliament; on the contrary, it will have to be the subject of concerted reflection and legislative and institutional preparation, both at Commission and Council level, as well as at the level of the European Parliament itself. Some Members have also put forward suggestions, such as the creation of an observatory or a working group to support the action of the various policies in the specific area of development. As this was one of the priorities of the Portuguese Presidency's programme, I would finally like to stress that it is also important to record the assertion that it is necessary to promote development policy in the context of European Union policies and particularly in the context of its external policy. We believe that this is absolutely essential; Without this, it will not be possible to develop a consistent action in terms of policy coherence, if we are not able to give a leading role to development policies as an instrument for affirming principles and values which shape Europe's affirmation in the international system.

We in the Community, in the European Union, have an important role to play here. SAVE is the only Community-wide program dedicated to promoting the rational use of energy. It is based on non-technical elements and contributes to the development of an energy efficiency infrastructure. The program's goal is to create an environment that encourages investment and energy efficiency. At this point, we must also realize that there is certainly market potential for energy conservation in industry. We have heard a lot about the competitive difficulties with renewable energy sources, but energy conservation can save companies, indeed everywhere, money, so that shouldn't be a problem. This is something we can all support. I must say that, much like with motherhood, we all support it, but sometimes do very little to provide concrete help to mothers or those committed to energy conservation.
