We could actually do more, given the major commitments we have made to reducing CO2 and greenhouse gases, and to reducing our dependence on imported energy. We are not taking the kind of action that citizens want to see. We are not making the necessary connection so that citizens can actually take action at home, in the office, or in their company to support measures to combat climate change. If we could get that message across, that would be a very exciting thing. I would like to thank everyone again who has taken part in this conciliation process. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Ahern again for her work as rapporteur on this draft, because she, with the cooperation of the other Members of Parliament, has helped to ensure that we end up with a very sensible result, which in some respects even improves on one or two of the Commission's own proposals and, of course, on what the Council had initially accepted from a budgetary point of view. As Mrs Ahern quite rightly pointed out, both the SAVE and ALTENER programme budgets are primarily symbolic, since the weight of the budget rests with the Länder, the Member States of the Union, the regions and, in some cases, even local authorities. But in any case, despite their relatively small size, the programmes have an important symbolic value, which shows that there is a will within the Community as a whole to support this type of measure, which will help us genuinely fulfil our Kyoto commitments and, at the same time, achieve greater diversification of our energy sources, greater security of supply and, in the case of SAVE, reduce consumption and achieve greater efficiency in energy use, thus helping us to achieve the objectives set. Furthermore, with the SAVE programme, greater efficiency and energy saving, and with the ALTENER programme, renewable energies, there is a technological challenge of the utmost importance which, from an economic point of view, can bring significant opportunities for industry and also for job creation in our countries and, consequently, throughout the Union.

To this end, we have submitted several amendments, and we hope Parliament will accept them: first, to offer the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia exemption from customs duties on its exports to the European Union and compensation for the progressive reduction in customs duties applied to Macedonia on European products, on condition that the principle of joint customs control at Macedonian borders is accepted; second, to encourage FYROM with appropriate financial support to integrate its currency into the euro, as a first step towards the Europeanization of its entire economy, with the ultimate aim of eliminating any possible corruption in the banking system; third, that the aid and assistance that the world must give to the region, and therefore also to Macedonia, must clearly be multilateral in nature, without the recipient country being conditioned by obligations to the donor country. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we hope that the agreement will achieve all its intended objectives, but we cannot delude ourselves that peace, stability, and prosperity in southeastern Europe will be achieved without a prior study of the issues that pose the major problems we are trying to eliminate. I am referring to the future constitutional state of Kosovo, the need to engage Serbia in the regional reconciliation process, and, why not, a new discussion about relations between the European Union, NATO, and the United Nations, within the framework of this new balance that must be found between humanitarian intervention and state sovereignty, which, in my opinion, must bring about a modification of the United Nations Charter itself. Mr. President, Commissioner, the war in Kosovo has made everything worse. That certainly applies, and above all, to the relationship between the European Union and the Western Balkans. Many hopes have been raised since then. That applies both there and here. There, because—whether we like it or not—in addition to the question of direct aid, the question is: what does Europe intend to do with us now? Is membership in the offing? This is something that is widely discussed in all these countries. But here in the European Union too, many hopes have been raised. If we do this well, it will be the first test of a genuine common foreign and security policy. Will the European Union succeed in acting jointly for the first time and developing a joint policy for such a complicated agreement? Likewise, the question is whether the European Union has learned its lessons from the poor experiences in Bosnia regarding aid and the somewhat better experiences in Kosovo. Can we improve it, based on the experiences in Macedonia and four other countries? Against this backdrop of very high hopes, I think I'm not exaggerating if I say that this first step, the stabilization and association agreement with Macedonia, is of crucial importance. It is not the Union's only contribution. Next comes the debate on the stability pact, the Cara program, and short-term financing. We are now discussing the Stability and Association Agreements, that is, the medium-term perspective.

The season risks going into a loss and giving rise to a very serious crisis at the end of the year. It was therefore fully justified for Parliament to draft a new resolution to which our group has made an extremely important contribution, a resolution that emphasizes a number of points that those working in the field consider absolutely essential. First of all, those who pollute must assume all their responsibilities. Our resolution therefore calls for the application of two principles: firstly, that of "the polluter cleans up", because it is unacceptable that the clean-up of coasts polluted by a load of hydrocarbons is not carried out at the expense of the owner of the load, but at the expense of public bodies, i.e. the taxpayers or, better said, the victims. Secondly, there is the principle of "the polluter pays". Their responsibility, our resolution specifies, must extend to the sectors and businesses in the fishing, marine culture and aquaculture sectors. This is essential and means that any polluter cannot claim to limit the amount of compensation to the victims based on the ceiling set by the IOPCF courtesy of the big oil companies. If the IOPCF ceiling is insufficient, if it is clearly underestimated, it must be increased. Well, our resolution demands this. If the increase is insufficient, the polluter will have to finance the rest. It would be particularly unfair to allow an oil company, whose profits this year are around ten billion francs, to deny full compensation to the victims, the vast majority of whom are small businesses and employees. The affected populations, Commissioner, expect concrete signs of solidarity at European level. Our resolution calls on the Commission to take the necessary measures to help repair the damage inflicted on the fishing sector, which has been hit by the consequences of the disaster. Blue Europe, the CFP, must now demonstrate that, beyond the constraints it imposes on fishermen, solidarity is not an unfamiliar sentiment and the European Union must also participate in the environmental recovery of affected wetlands and coastal zones, whose biological value is of interest to the Union as a whole. Commissioner Fischler has just said that he would welcome France's requests and I am pleased about that. In the crucial chapter of marine pollution, we must play a spurring role. Twenty years after the Amoco Cadiz disaster, laxity and irresponsibility continue to reign undisturbed in Europe in the field of maritime safety, with the resulting consequences of repeated oil spills. This time we must not let inertia get the better of us. We must quickly define a general framework for maritime safety in compliance with the principle of subsidiarity and we must finally put an end to this infernal spiral of generalised irresponsibility. Mr. President, the economy of the Western Atlantic is in shambles, contaminated by Erika diesel. Fishermen, oyster farmers, shellfish farmers, tourism operators, local and regional authorities are growing impatient waiting for help and treatment of the wreck which, we are told, continues to cause spills and is a real time bomb.

Mr President, the question posed by Mr Karamanou is an extremely serious one, it must be said. We are perfectly aware of the difficult and dramatic humanitarian situation in Kosovo, as well as the problem of displaced persons in the region, who come from Kosovo, with the repercussions this has on children's health and mortality rates. It is clear to me that the European Union has made a clear contribution to the humanitarian aid efforts of the international community. As you know, the European Community has provided a total of EUR 378 million to the province of Kosovo alone, to which must be added the national contributions of the various Member States. This contribution covers various projects in the fields of health and the health system, as well as water treatment. Furthermore, as you know, the European Union contributes EUR 66.3 million to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in 1999. I believe the honourable Member is aware that, given the necessary division of labour among international donors, the health sector in Kosovo falls under the responsibility of the World Health Organization. This organization is fully aware, based on the reports it has drawn up, of the alarming situation regarding children's health. It has focused its efforts on improving basic conditions in maternity wards and hospitals. However, we are aware that this situation is very far from being satisfactorily resolved; that it has a dynamic and a dimension that also affects other areas of health, especially children's health. This is a political situation, not just a technical one, but rather a solution to the political situation, because there are dimensions here, which must not be hidden, which have repercussions in terms of what is, until now, the inability of the international community to put into practice the functioning of a multi-ethnic society in Kosovo, which has had a detrimental effect on the improvement of the health system in this region. I thank you, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, for your reply, which complements what Commissioner Patten said yesterday on this subject. However, Mr President, the amount of EUR 378 million, which you say was allocated in 1999, has in fact proved to be completely insufficient for the creation of basic human conditions in Kosovo, particularly as regards the provision of health services. Do you not think, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, that the mere fact that infant mortality has increased is a stigma for the European continent, a shame that should mobilise us all to ensure that the aid we provide is more effective and generous? Certainly, the situation was not idyllic before the bombings, far from it, but it has deteriorated very significantly since NATO's intervention as far as the natural and human environment are concerned. In these circumstances, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, is it not a moral matter for us to strive to create humane conditions for the so-suffering inhabitants of Kosovo, and above all to keep all the promises we have made?

And if we let a group of high-level officials act as a hub for exchanging experiences in coordinating and evaluating social and labour market policy, we will learn from it. The Commission communication, which we are discussing today, and which was the starting point for the Council decision in November, provides a balanced presentation of how we can have a more qualified debate, how we can learn more about the challenges that Member States will face in the area of social policy in the coming years, years in which we will have ageing populations and we will feel the effects of enlargement. We already have major social problems and high social expenditure on public budgets, which is a problem for many Member States. If we do not start reforms, we risk eroding the economic basis of social policy, and a strong and competitive economy is certainly the safest basis for good social protection. It is therefore sensible to put these issues on the agenda. In the debate on the coordination of social policy within the European Union, we often use the expression "social convergence". We liberals can support the concept of social convergence when it comes to defining, within the European Union, broad common objectives that countries try to achieve through national social policy. It is therefore not a question of harmonisation, but of common objectives. It is a fact that the countries of the European Union have different ways of organising social policy. We have different traditions, there are cultural differences and, despite many common points, there are also major differences between one country and another in the nature of social problems and their extent. For this reason, it is important to underline that social policy is a matter of national competence. Naturally, national policy cannot escape a series of common references concerning the minimum social rights established in the Treaty, the guarantee of free movement of labour without loss of their social rights, respect for the need to coordinate economies and respect for economic cooperation. Coordination and cooperation are therefore necessary. Convergence, however, must be an end and not a means. I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Andersson, for his very constructive efforts to try to reconcile different positions and secure support for his report. I support the report. There are, however, some points with which I do not fully agree. I do not agree with the call for the Commission to take action against what is called unfair competition between social and tax systems, if this action is to be used to curb new ideas, the development and improvement of the efficiency of our social systems, or to prevent the reduction of excessively high tax burdens in many Member States of the European Union. I am sceptical about the detailed regulation that could be achieved if the Commission were to take a position on the scope and quality of childcare and care for the elderly, just as I am sceptical about the benefit of a common poverty line.

This is of no interest to the major groups in this Parliament, nor to most of the trade unions, which are theoretically committed to defending the European civil service but, in practice, are focused on the corporate protection of their own members, using the considerable powers granted to them in a questionable manner. Trade union representatives are on the Disciplinary Board and the Staff Regulations Committee, so that the disloyal civil servant risks nothing and so that the Staff Regulations are frozen. Trade union representatives are also, and this is incomprehensible, on the competition selection boards, and I would not be surprised if members of the union were already part of OLAF, which would seriously harm this institution which should, at least formally, offer the guarantee of being super partes. I therefore understand why we are meeting at this time, which is usually intended for other activities and not for debate, confrontation and information. Mr President, when it comes to internal reform, the European Commission is in a difficult position. After the affairs that led to the previous Commission's resignation, expectations are enormous. I sometimes have the impression that the proposals put forward in this House are all the more applauded because they are radical. On the other hand, circumstances cannot be changed overnight with the stroke of a pen. As soon as things have to be implemented, as soon as a few points of detail have to be discussed, difficulties very quickly arise. This is undoubtedly why the Committee on Budgetary Control has had to face more difficulties than expected on this point. However, we have no reason to be ashamed of the result as it appears before you today. On this occasion, I would like to thank Mr van Hulten for the work he has done on this report. If this report manages to avoid being watered down once again by the adoption of several amendments, it will enable us to give the Commission clear and straightforward instructions on several key points. Let us start with the most important instruction. We do not want financial control to be abolished. The financial controller must still be able to do his job before payments are made, not in all circumstances, but in cases where uncertainties and risks exist. The Commission is sending out the wrong signal by renaming the Directorate-General for Financial Control as the Directorate-General for Audit. The Commission's organisational structure can easily be changed, but the task becomes more difficult when it has to stick to the legal texts and, in this case, the Financial Regulation. I have not made an exhaustive list, but the Community's Financial Regulation and the implementing provisions relating to it refer in more than 100 different passages to the financial controller, his independence and the tasks assigned to him. This regulation cannot be ignored or circumvented, not even through so-called soft law, as a colleague mentioned during a committee meeting.

It is obvious that some Presidents ignore the show of hands and immediately turn to the electronic voting system. I wonder if this is the correct procedure. I know it takes longer, but shouldn't we always vote by a show of hands first? I assure you, Mr President, that I will be paying close attention to how many hands go up. I hope there will be many by the time the vote takes place. The environment is in a very, very serious state. Like the previous speakers, I would like to address the economic problem and the financing of projects that, in my opinion, should always be in the public interest. Regarding financing: EUR 613 million is not enough, Commissioner. Even EUR 850 million is not sufficient. At the end of August, I attended a meeting of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, where even EUR 2 million, or 4 trillion lire, was mentioned for eliminating or at least reducing the problem of nicotine addiction. However, the environment is a far more serious, far more important problem than nicotine addiction. I assure you, Commissioner, EUR 850 million—assuming this financial framework is actually approved—is not enough to advance any type of project in practice. Protected areas have been established in many places, and these are a particularly important component of the LIFE programme. But protected areas established with limited financial resources, i.e., without signage, are ineffective and pointless. I therefore call on Parliament and the Commission to pay close attention to this issue. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since the beginning of 1999, discussions have been taking place between the various institutions on the proposed regulation for a third phase of the financial instrument for the environment - LIFE. I would like to thank the Committee on the Environment and the rapporteur, Mrs Lienemann, once again for their good and constructive cooperation on this matter. As a result, I can announce that the Commission approves in principle nine of the fourteen amendments adopted by the Committee on the Environment. The Commission particularly welcomes Amendments 1, 2, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, and 13, on comitology. In this case, Parliament has responded to the Commission's objections to the common position. In principle, the Commission can also accept Amendment 4, which, however, should appear elsewhere in the text. With regard to Amendments Nos 5 and 6, I would like to stress that projects for the sustainable management of groundwater and surface water, as well as projects for the reduction of climate-relevant air pollutants, are largely included in LIFE. However, the Commission considers that listing them separately contradicts the original decision to concentrate the proposal on a few priority areas. There is also a risk of overlap with other Community action programmes, such as the Fifth Framework Programme for Research, Technological Development and Demonstration. The core measures of this programme – water quality, the city of the future, and innovative products and processes – partly address the same issues. On the budgetary issue, I am pleased with the confidence shown by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health, Energy, Water and Water Management. Amendment No 12 calls for a larger financial framework than proposed in the common position. I also believe in LIFE's great potential. This instrument should be able to finance good projects with a larger amount than the proposed financial framework. However, the amount indicated in Amendment 12 does not correspond to the budget established on the basis of Agenda 2000. Let me also mention that an expanded financial framework also places greater demands on the Environment Directorate, which will then have to manage a larger number of projects. Furthermore, other programmes decided upon under the codecision procedure must also be taken into account.

However, I would conclude by asking: what will come first? Can we really achieve full employment without unleashing this entrepreneurial talent? If we wait for this to happen, I fear that the major objectives you have outlined before us will not be achieved. Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, I believe that the Lisbon Summit, thanks to your efforts and those of the Commission, can finally become an ambitious and social summit, where the European social model is finally seen as a new engine for European integration and where full employment can become a concrete objective. But if Lisbon wants to become the Summit of these political ambitions, then Lisbon must also become the Summit of methodology. I would like to ask you to pay attention to three points that seem to me to be of essential importance to ensure that this Summit is a significant social summit. First, methodologically, the job creation strategy and the new social security coordination procedure cannot be subordinated to a macroeconomic policy that is focused solely on stability. For me, Mr. President of the Council, this clearly means that the Social Affairs Council should have the same weight as the ECOFIN Council and that political direction must remain in the hands of the European Council itself. Secondly, I would like to strongly support your commitment to setting clear objectives, both with regard to economic growth and job creation. But I would like to add that, if Lisbon is to be a truly social summit, we should be able to specify what we want to do to modernize and strengthen social security. In this area, too, we need "standards of excellence." We would like to have a Luxembourg process. Finally, I support the European Commission's ambition to formulate standards on poverty and drastically reduce poverty within ten years. I think it is important that you set objectives in this regard, Mr. President of the Council. In other words, we must encourage all Member States to combat the social exclusion of citizens, not only children but also their parents and the elderly. I wish the Council Presidency the best of luck in achieving its ambitions. Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President, the extraordinary Lisbon European Council on employment, economic reform, and social cohesion sets itself, as we have been told, an ambitious, very ambitious goal, at the risk of disappointing our fellow citizens, who are well aware that it is not enough to decree full employment and the eradication of poverty in Europe to achieve this. But ultimately, this summit has great merit: to forge, after Cardiff and Luxembourg, a political will for greater social cohesion, and in particular for the 57 million people living in poverty in our country, including single mothers, large families, and children, to whom, tomorrow, will be added other excluded groups, namely those who will not have access to new fields of knowledge, which will generate new social imbalances.

All of this is in line with the principles we have always defended. Thank you, Mr Segni, I am happy to do so. It is entirely in keeping with the position we have always taken as a Parliament. Madam President, I would like to draw your attention to a case that this Parliament has repeatedly addressed. That is the case of Alexander Nikitin. We are all pleased that the court acquitted him and made it clear that access to environmental information is a constitutional right in Russia too. But now he is to be charged again because the public prosecutor is appealing. We know, and we have stated this in many resolutions – especially during the last plenary session last year – that this is not just a legal case and that it is wrong to accuse Alexander Nikitin of criminality and treason because we, as those affected, benefit from his findings. These results form the basis for the European programs to protect the Barents Sea, and therefore I ask you to examine a draft letter outlining the most important facts and to clarify this position in line with the resolutions of the Russian Parliament. Ms. Schroedter, I would be happy to examine the relevant facts once I have received your letter. Madam President, first of all, thank you very much for keeping your word and for the enormous expansion of television channels in our offices during the first session of the new year. However, Madam President, my request has not been met. Although we can now receive two Finnish and one Portuguese channel, we still do not have a Dutch channel. However, I did ask you for a Dutch channel, because we Dutch people also want to follow the news when we are exiled here every month. Therefore, I would like to ask you again to ensure that a Dutch channel is also broadcast. Mrs Plooij-van Gorsel, I can inform you that this item is on the Quaestors' agenda for Wednesday. I hope that a decision will be taken there in your favor. Madam President, can you tell me why this Parliament does not abide by the occupational health and safety regulations it itself has adopted? Why has the air quality in this building not been checked even once since our election? Why has the Committee on Health and Safety at Work not met even once since 1998? Why has there been no fire drill in either the Brussels or Strasbourg Parliament buildings? Why are there no fire safety briefings? Why was nothing done to make the stairs safer after my accident? Why is the smoking ban not enforced in the non-smoking areas? It is a disgrace that we adopt rules that we then do not adhere to ourselves. Mrs Lynne, you are absolutely right, and I will check whether all this is indeed the case. I will also put the matter to the Quaestors. I am sure that they attach great importance to our own compliance with the legislation we adopt. Madam President, Mrs. Díez González and I have raised several questions about certain statements made by Vice-President de Palacio, which were published in a Spanish newspaper.

A5-0028/2000, by Mrs Decourrière, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, on the communication from the Commission (COM(99)0479 - C5-0243/99 - 1999/2178(COS)) to the Member States laying down guidelines for a Community initiative concerning trans-European cooperation to promote harmonious and balanced development of the European territory (INTERREG), A5-0024/2000, by Mr Procacci, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the draft communication from the Commission (COM(99)0475 - C5-0259/99 - 1999/2185(COS)) to the Member States laying down guidelines for the Community initiative for rural development (LEADER +), A5-0034/2000, by Mrs Stenzel on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the draft communication from the Commission (COM(99)0476 - C5-0260/99 - 1999/2186(COS)) to the Member States laying down guidelines for Community Initiative Programmes (CIPs) for which Member States are invited to submit proposals for contributions under the EQUAL initiative. Since Mrs McCarthy is slightly late due to the late arrival of her plane, I propose that we hear Mrs Decourrière first. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners and members of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, I have been instructed to draw up the European Parliament's report on the Community Initiative Programme INTERREG III. In committee we have examined over a hundred amendments and so far 17 have been re-tabled, some of which have already been tabled in committee. Before moving on to discuss the content of the resolution I am proposing to you, I would like to introduce you to the elements that I have taken into consideration and that have guided my work as rapporteur. First of all, I would like to remind you of the role of the INTERREG Community initiative, based on the principle of transnationality and innovation. This programme is a driver of development and of a European dimension. INTERREG is one of the four Community initiatives planned for the period 2000-2006 and will have the largest financial package, i.e. 4,875 billion euros compared to the current 3,604 billion. Created in 1990, the INTERREG initiative is based on the desire to prepare the European regions for a Europe without frontiers in the context of the creation of the large single market. With the reform of the Structural Funds in 1994 and 1996, the INTERREG PIC introduced new elements that contribute to the development of trans-European networks for the transport and distribution of energy. These programmes have encouraged cross-border, transnational and interregional cooperation in the European Union, giving priority to balanced development of the Community area. The INTERREG III programme, the guidelines for which the European Commission is submitting to us today, in accordance with the provisions of Regulation No 1260/1999 of the European Community concerning general provisions on the Structural Funds, pursues this objective. It is based on three elements: element A, which organises cross-border cooperation between local authorities in the internal and external border regions of the European Union on the basis of common development strategies, the implementation of which is the responsibility of the Member States and local and regional authorities; element B, which provides for transnational cooperation between national, regional and local authorities in several Member States or countries applying for accession to the European Union in the fields of spatial planning, transport networks and the environment; the implementation of this element is the responsibility of the Member States and national authorities; and element C aimed at organising interregional cooperation between different regions of the Member States or third countries for the networking of experiences on elements A and B as well as cooperation in the field of research and technological development, this aspect which will have to be defined with the European Commission responsible for its implementation.

Member States must act quickly and firmly. Our governments must pool financial resources to ensure effective controls and stop dragging out any initiative on maritime safety. The Erika tragedy did not cost lives, but it could have destroyed the lives of many, like the Sea Empress or the Braer. What is certain is that all three accidents caused an ecological disaster. My group stands in solidarity with the people of Brittany, whose region was devastated by the disaster, just as we have stood in solidarity with the people of West Wales and the Shetland Islands on other occasions. It is time to stop showing our solidarity and instead start issuing mandatory mandates to eliminate these ships of shame in favor of safe seas, otherwise, later this year, we will find ourselves once again debating a new motion for a resolution to sink yet another tanker flying a flag of convenience that is plaguing the sea with crude oil. The time for resolutions is over: now is the time to act. Unfortunately, I fear that the Council will remain inactive this time too and we will return to discussing another maritime and ecological disaster in the future. Mr President, every time a disaster like this occurs, people say that it must never happen again. In reality, we cannot prevent accidents at sea, but it is our duty to learn from every accident like this and to apply the lessons learned to reduce future risks. The Erika accident was especially serious for the people of Brittany who were most directly affected, but it had devastating effects on wildlife in much of Europe. According to some sources, it is the worst disaster ever to affect birds in this part of Europe; according to the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, at least 400,000 birds may have died, probably mostly guillemots. So much tragedy and so much anguish in the images of oil-blackened birds being dumped on beaches by veterinarians, which many of us have seen. We all want the best standards for ships, regardless of their flag. Regulations must be respected, as must the polluter pays principle, so that fines and incentives can be used to put pressure on shipping operators and oil companies to ensure that best practice is introduced. I agree with every word the Commissioner says, but the question is how long it will take for measures of the kind she has proposed to be introduced. As a politician, the Commissioner must remind her officials how difficult it would be to have to come back to this House in a year's time, on the occasion of a similar, equally devastating accident, if some of the measures proposed today were still just fine words, having not had the chance to put them into practice. The idea of another similar accident in the future should be the perfect catalyst for the Commissioner and her officials.

This House will face one of the most important imperatives that can result from the essential measures taken to ensure that the Commission's resources are equal to its tasks. Last month, as Romano Prodi just said, we launched a comprehensive assessment of the Commission's activities and resources, and we will report in detail on this in September. Our objective is to focus the Commission's work on key policymaking priorities and core activities, in line with our strategic policymaking objectives for the next five years. Inevitably, this will entail identifying activities that could and should be reduced or terminated. It entails a very close examination of how the use of external and internal resources can be most effectively balanced for the Union. It entails allocating staff to areas of major policymaking importance within departments and across the Commission. And, when this allocation has been completed, we will be able to determine whether the resources at our disposal are equal to the tasks entrusted to us. If it is proven that they are not, we will raise the issue of increased resources with the Budgetary Authority. If we do not receive a positive response, we will have to address the difficult matter of deciding which of our lower-priority activities should be suspended. This should not be done only by the Commission, but also by this Parliament and the Council. I am not making this observation because the Prodi Commission has the slightest desire to renounce activities or tasks. On the contrary, as many Members of this House understand, I am putting forward these considerations because we want to fulfill our tasks in the most effective and responsible manner. That means closing any significant gap between obligations and operational resources by reducing activities or increasing resources, or by a combination of both. In each of the three pillars of reform, the active support and cooperation of this House will be absolutely decisive. The new activity-based management system, which the President just mentioned, will for the first time link political priorities with the availability of resources and, consequently, with the budget. Thus, the role of the Budgetary Authority in the functioning of activity-based management will be decisive. It is clear that attempts to manage the Commission's activities on a small scale would not benefit anyone. A solid and practical interinstitutional agreement will therefore be a prerequisite for the efficient functioning of activity-based management. In human resources policy, Parliament's involvement will inevitably have to be that of an employer of civil servants and a democratic institution to which the Commission must be accountable. This will also be a very difficult imperative. And finally, in the crucial area of financial management, where the Court of Auditors, the Committee of Independent Experts, and other external and internal analyses have strongly recommended real changes, the support of this House for the implementation of the recommendations to make the most of the money without compromising security will be of paramount importance. In the limited time available to me for this statement, it is obviously impossible to set out our proposals in greater detail.

This is a great danger and we must ensure that all regions in Europe can participate in the knowledge society and that no one is excluded. Europe must be able to draw on the realities of its regions more than in the past in order to make the most of the strength of these regions for creativity and to arrive at a more realistic employment policy. We have had to note that despite all the resources allocated under the Structural Funds, there are still major differences in unemployment rates. I therefore call for networks to be established between the regions and for the idea of a Europe in which each Member State thinks for itself to be abandoned. Mr President, Mr Guterres, Mr Prodi, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome and approve of the fact that the Commission and the Portuguese Presidency have proclaimed full employment as the objective of European policy. I agree, but a sustainable model of full employment primarily includes skilled jobs with social protection. We need to change the world of the economy and work so that paid work becomes environmentally sustainable. They are primarily focusing on further reforms to deregulate the economy in the internal market, on the Internet revolution, on electronic trade and transactions as job-creating machines. With these policies they will not be able to deliver on the promise of full employment. Economic reforms such as the liberalisation of the internal energy market have led to fierce competition and numerous mergers, resulting in job losses, and this trend is still ongoing. Commissioner Bangemann promised enormous job growth through the information society back in the mid-1990s. The result we are facing is disappointing. Growth in sectors such as the media, mobile telephony and software has not been able to compensate for job losses in the telecommunications and electronics industries, nor for the effects of information technology-induced rationalisation in other sectors of the economy. And it does not increase my optimism to see many e-commerce companies registering a gigantic capitalization on the stock market, while at the operational level they continue to operate at a loss. It is clear that e-commerce and electronic transactions in general have a great future; but their contribution to employment growth is exaggerated by their protagonists in almost mystical terms. That is why I am convinced that for a new policy of full employment we need a different policy mix. Firstly, we need a less rigid monetary policy, a budgetary policy that strengthens investments for enlargement and the future, a wage policy linked to productivity that stimulates European internal demand and employment growth. Secondly, we need a strategy of drastically reducing working hours and redistributing work between women and men. Thirdly, we need to strengthen employment incentivized by public means in environmentally friendly economic sectors and a parallel innovation policy that looks to the future and aims in particular to consolidate small and medium-sized enterprises. Fourth, we need a policy of emancipation of the labor market, which clearly rejects strategies aimed at creating categories of underpaid work and compulsory work schemes for unskilled jobs, because only with a broad-based training offensive can we create a sufficient basis for a skilled workforce for the knowledge society, for environmentally friendly social and cultural services.

I also think it is right to recognise the efforts that High Representative Solana is making to have a more effective, more visible and more coherent common foreign and security policy with the European Union. In this sense, I agree with the interventions made by some colleagues who preceded me according to which it is necessary to have a global policy that integrates not only military aspects, but also civil, diplomatic, humanitarian and police elements, to which High Representative Solana referred. The Portuguese Presidency has made significant progress, in fact, by creating a series of bodies of a provisional or interim nature. In record time, it organised this informal Council of defence ministers and indicated a whole series of objectives to be achieved during the long journey towards this common foreign and security policy. One of these was the Sintra Council about which I have some questions to ask High Representative Solana. This Council was based on two documents: a British document on the headline goals, dedicated to priority objectives, and another document on the permanent military bodies of the European Union. Mr Solana, I would like to ask you whether, at the next Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy, you would be prepared to explain in detail to the members of that Committee B, together with Commissioner Patten, to whom I ask the same question, and with the President-in-Office of the Council, to whom I ask you, Mr Solana, to forward this request, the content of the documents that were discussed at the Summit. A second question, Mr Solana, would be to know to what extent you support the observations and statements made by the French Minister for Defence, according to whom it was necessary for the Member States to allocate 0.7% of their gross domestic product to defence spending. I would like to know your opinion, whether you share this view, whether you really believe that a more decisive contribution from the Member States in this area is necessary. Thirdly, what is your assessment of the recently concluded Crisex 2000@ exercises, in which, for the first time, the European Union shared a series of initiatives with NATO? Fourthly and finally, Mr Solana, I would like to know whether, if the Member States were to ask you, you would be prepared to chair the Political and Defence Committee, adding this post to all the experience you currently have as Secretary-General of the Council of Ministers, as High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy, as Secretary-General of the Western European Union and as a former Secretary-General of NATO. Mr High Representative, as rapporteur for the Committee on Foreign Affairs on security and defence issues, I will limit my speech to that area. Mr High Representative, you have heard the strong criticisms made by Members who cannot accept the terrible situation in Kosovo, in Chechnya and in other parts of the world. For my part, I do not mean to exasperate her and today, as far as she is concerned, I recognize the efforts she has made to build a European security and defense policy worthy of the name that did not exist before. It is true that we are still far from the desired objective, or at least from the objective that I hope for.

We too are affected by this democratic deficit. And that is why, the day after the inauguration of the Intergovernmental Conference, during which I will have the honour of representing the Commission alongside President Prodi and working, I repeat, in full agreement with your two representatives, Mr Brok and Mr Tsatsos, we have just decided within the College to launch the "Dialogue for Europe and on Europe", to contribute to this direct contact with citizens. All the Commissioners, whenever they have to go to a country and not just their country of origin, to a region - it happens to me three or four times a month - have committed to dedicating some of their time to a direct dialogue with citizens, not just with the elites or institutional leaders who meet regularly, to establish direct contact, in a university, a high school, a factory, to meet people, answer questions and listen. This will be the role that we will assume, as you will assume yours, with respect to this indispensable initiative, with respect to this pressing obligation aimed at reducing the democratic deficit, that is, the distance between what we do and the citizens. We wish to pursue this initiative in collaboration with the Member States and in liaison with the European Parliament. We will regularly present a summary, so as to take the pulse of public opinion and consequently make adjustments or impose new orientations. We also wish to pursue this initiative in consultation with national parliaments, local elected representatives, non-governmental organisations, socio-professional circles and the media. Opinion centres, political groups and parties, European and national parliamentarians, elected representatives, as I have just said, of local authorities or national parliaments, the Committee of the Regions, the Economic and Social Committee, civil society organisations and university circles will be involved. I would also like to point out - if there was any need - that on 1 February the European Parliament itself had already taken the initiative, for which I once again thank President Napolitano, to organise an initial working meeting with representatives of national parliaments, i.e. representatives of the citizens of each State. The Commission will propose to the Member States to join in this operation either in the context of specific cooperation or in the context of a more structured partnership. We will activate a plan for the media and close contacts with the Presidency of the Union and the European Parliament. I have already explained the ways in which the Commissioners will contribute during meetings and on-site visits. In practice, we want to organise civic debates. Allow me simply, without wishing to give lessons or advice, to point out that when I had the honour of being Minister for European Affairs in my country, I perceived this need to dialogue directly with citizens. By directly carrying out this dialogue every week in each region, I realised that there was an incredible need to give a face to the European Union. So, every week, I went to talk to them together with a Commissioner, not necessarily a French Commissioner, or ambassadors based in Paris or European parliamentarians.

Having made these general remarks, I would like to focus my remarks on Interreg on your main points. The first are related to the timetable and content of this initiative. You say that the adoption of these guidelines was too late, and the risk of interrupting previous programmes has been highlighted, particularly by your rapporteur. This is true, I acknowledge it, and you know the reasons for this, ladies and gentlemen, Members of the European Parliament. There was a delay in adopting the Interreg guidelines in March-April 2000. I acknowledge this, and I take note of it as you do. I note, however, that the Member States and the regions are already actively preparing the Interreg III programmes, and the draft guidelines were distributed more than three months ago. I also note that the eligibility of expenditure will be accepted from the date of presentation of the programmes, and I confirm the possibility of retroactivity to 1 January, if this programme is presented before 30 April. That's the first point. Second point: regarding the non-exhaustive list of measures eligible for strand B, I want to tell you and confirm that I have asked the Commission to agree to include other specific themes, particularly in support of small and medium-sized enterprises or cultural heritage, in the list of actions eligible for strand B and therefore to no longer consider this list as exhaustive. Third point: interregional cooperation, the importance of strand C. The Commission shares the observations made by your Assembly on the importance of this strand C, of interregional cooperation. As your rapporteur requests, I will send you detailed information on the system for implementing this strand. Fourth point: the observatory and the possible use of a technical assistance office. As you requested, I have decided to delete all reference to the use of a technical assistance office in the text, pending the outcome of the debate currently under way within the Commission on systems for outsourcing services. But, ladies and gentlemen, if we remove any reference and, later, any recourse to a BAT, this has a consequence, which must be the increase in certain civil service posts to do this work, because someone will have to do it and I will not be able to redeploy the same staff indefinitely, even though our tasks are increasing with ISPA and with the concern to better control, rigorously and transparently, the Community credits for which I am responsible, often in partnership or joint responsibility with the Member States. Now, regarding the implementation of Interreg, a subject that has been raised by many of you, and the possible eligibility for strand A, "Cross-border cooperation", of actions in the Adriatic, for Sicily or for the outermost regions, the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, understands your concerns and hears your request on these various points. I therefore intend to amend the guidelines to include a specific priority in transnational strand B: "Integrated cooperation of maritime and island regions", so as to cover, in what I consider to be an appropriate manner, the various possibilities for cooperation between these regions.

For now, it's clear that the first priority is rescue helicopters, and then food aid and other emergency assistance must follow. Three weeks after these floods began, the entire world has finally begun to wake up and realize the horrifying situation in Mozambique: thousands of people whose lives hang in the balance, and if we don't deploy means of transport, especially air transport, to get them out of this situation, they will quickly die. That is undoubtedly the most pressing issue right now: rescue transport and emergency humanitarian aid, including food aid. But I would like to emphasize that the European Union and the rest of the world cannot limit their aid to Mozambique to this emergency issue we are talking about. We must be aware of the devastation caused by the floods. Therefore, it is urgent to begin thinking now about finding financial support for the reconstruction of the infrastructure that has been destroyed, without which Mozambique would be unable to continue its path toward development, which it began so promisingly a few years ago. This issue of infrastructure reconstruction is fundamental; without it, there is no development, and it is also time for some of Mozambique's creditor countries to consider forgiving or reducing their debts. If nothing is done now, we will undo all the efforts made in the past to help Mozambique develop. Therefore, I hope that the visit to Mozambique made this week by Commissioner Nielson and the representatives of the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union will allow this extremely important issue to be properly raised. Mr. President, it has already been said that Mozambique, after a war that plunged the country into poverty, now finds itself facing a natural disaster of terrifying proportions. While it is not yet possible to calculate how many people have died, it is known that some 80,000 are in imminent danger of drowning and that 300,000 have lost their homes and fields. They urgently need aid for survival, food, water, and shelter. Then comes the need for medicines to prevent the epidemics, which appear to have already begun, and for the means for reconstruction. But immediate aid is difficult to reach, despite the efforts of NGOs, as roads, bridges, and railway lines are closed. Helicopters are needed. There are only five, it seems, to bring 80,000 people down from the trees. But the machinery used to mobilize aid is too heavy. The Socialist Group in this Parliament has promoted the prevention of natural disasters—it has even defended conflict prevention—as the best way to avoid situations like the one now suffered by the people of Mozambique. I would particularly like to recall the efforts of Member Michel Rocard, from the previous term. The European Commission responded by launching, as early as 1994, a disaster prevention program—DIPECHO—that sought to be proactive and, from a regional perspective, to prevent disasters or, at least, minimize their effects on populations.

The European Union's policy must regain the trust of citizens, who demand the right to access the institutions quickly and without preclusions and who demand that the rules on which their understanding depends be legible. They want a policy destined to succeed, which they see as a normal service rendered to responsible citizens. The success of the reform depends essentially on the initiative of the Commission. However, I am irritated by the statement made today by the Commission, according to which the discussion of the interim report with Parliament must be of an informal nature only. Commissioner Kinnock, your intervention next Tuesday in the Committee on Budgetary Control cannot, however, be one-sided, because Parliament wants and must contribute to the reforms. This week's press conference also offends my political sensibilities because it is held before a thorough discussion of the proposal in the Committee on Budgetary Control. Commissioner Kinnock, despite your personal successes, it seems to me that the Commission still has a long way to go before it can meet our strong but legitimate expectations. I would like to begin by putting on record and making it clear to Mrs Langenhagen that the decision that I will not be speaking at tomorrow's plenary session and therefore not be available to give formal answers on the report is not mine or the Commission's, but a decision of Parliament. So if she wants to lecture, she should do so here in the Chamber. She knows me well enough to know that at all stages of these five years, in which we have worked together in Parliament, there has not been a single occasion on which I have refused to give a full, formal and detailed account of my actions. Mr President, I would like to begin by paying tribute to the conscientious and, from what I understand, generous work of Mr Van Hulten in preparing this report. Although new to this Chamber, he is quite senior in some respects, certainly in terms of his familiarity with the institutions given that he is a former civil servant; I believe that he has demonstrated this quality in skilfully tackling a complex subject which is of the utmost importance to all our institutions, as several Members have pointed out. I thank him and wish him a long and successful career as a Member. Mr President, as you will know, Mr Van Hulten's report on the second report of the Committee of Independent Experts is necessarily long and, as I intend to respond in detail in particular on the issues of financial management and control, I ask you to be indulgent. I will of course not take up more of the House's time than is absolutely necessary. When this House considered the second report of the Committee of Independent Experts last September, I promised on behalf of the incoming Commission that the report would be considered as a key element in the Commission's reform proposals. Our efforts to keep that promise will be evident to Parliament when we consider the package of reforms that the Commission has adopted today, well within the deadline we set ourselves four months ago.

Negotiations in Austria for the formation of the government The next item is the debate on the negotiations in Austria for the formation of the government. I now give the floor to the President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, the Group of the Party of European Socialists wishes to send three messages to European public opinion today. Let me be clear: we are profoundly united on these three messages. First, we wish to make it clear that we fully support and identify with the statement by the Presidency-in-Office of the Council and the 14 Member States, because we believe it reflects the community of values that has been built by all of us, and not by a single political force. In any case, this is a community of values that is contrary to those defended by this party, which has ironically called itself the Party of Freedom. The Europe we are currently building is precisely the result of bitter experiences that we have all endured, and the Socialist Group condemns the insults addressed to the President of the French Republic and the Belgian government, but also to the Socialists, who are also European citizens, because, ladies and gentlemen, the Austrian Socialists are now accused of treason against their homeland. I will tell you one thing: for many years, I betrayed my homeland, at least that is what General Franco said. President Guterres also betrayed Salazar. I believe it is necessary for the EPP to affirm and defend this. Furthermore, I believe that the Commission, Mr President Prodi, has been the guardian of the Treaties. But I remind President Prodi that during the investiture debate, he spoke of the Commission as a European government. A government must have more nerve and courage. This is what I am asking of President Prodi for the time being. (Applause) With all due respect to a Commissioner as efficient as Mr. Fischler, according to certain rumors—it all depends on the language in which they are expressed—President Prodi has asked for Mr. Fischler's resignation. I would be grateful if you would clarify this point before Parliament. Secondly, Madam President, we wish to send a very clear message to the Austrian people. An appeal to the majority of the Austrian people who did not vote for Haider, who voted for clearly democratic parties, committed to the European project. I would like to point out that while Mr. Schüssel was Minister of Finance, Chancellor Vranitzky also played a role in Austria's integration process. In politics, one cannot be so partisan. It was together that we made Austria's entry into the Community possible. This is the work of all of us, not just one group. Therefore, Madam President, we believe it is our right and our duty to ask the Austrians to rethink their choice, as this type of plague, which we have already suffered in Europe, risks harming Austria, but also spreading, as history reminds us.

It is not enough to make proposals based on approximate data. What we need is a legally binding objective for OSPAR. Only in this way will we achieve legal clarity and, above all, the possibility of legal action. Anything else would be ineffective and would not help prevent ecological disasters like the one we are currently experiencing in Romania and Hungary from occurring here. I find it regrettable that national governments are not willing to commit to legally binding protection, despite having agreed on OSPAR at international level. But I believe that this is precisely what we must rectify here in Parliament, in order to show that we will not tolerate any damage to the credibility of our policy. It is also important to strengthen the polluter-pays principle, because prices must tell the ecological truth. We cannot bow to the interests of the agricultural and chemical industry lobbies; Rather, we must proclaim and express through our vote that we want the polluter pays principle and, in doing so, prices that cover costs. Water is our most important vital resource, and we must ensure, with our vote, that we encourage and push for genuine compliance with the OSPAR Convention. This is possible with closed production cycles; anything else would be a watering down of the directive. Let us seize this opportunity! Mr President, in the short time I have, I would like to welcome the report and recall three principles, to which must be added all the rest, which are clearly set out in the rapporteur's amendments: water is not a commodity but a heritage belonging to the peoples of the Union; the ultimate objective is to achieve the elimination of all pollutants from surface and groundwater; and the population must be informed so that they can participate in the recovery of water and do not consume it excessively when it is such a precious commodity. I know that this directive may encounter problems because we have discussed here the different realities of the different countries of the Union. What happens in the north is different from what happens in the south and from what happens in countries that have desertification problems. I know that. But some amendments attempt to help the southern countries, specifically Amendment 43, which, when it talks about cost recovery, also indicates that Member States will have to take into account the social and environmental conditions of the countries when making decisions. There are also difficulties in the area of transfers. In my country—I live in the north of Spain—there is a big difference between the north and the south, and these difficulties arise when it comes to transferring water from one place to another. But Mrs. Lienemann's report also says that the receiving river basins must save and look after their water.

This public intervention is feasible and the decentralisation of university education would certainly help to balance development policy. Another point we would like to highlight is linked to industrial policy. In planning the coordination of the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Funds, the Commission should have taken greater account of the importance of the tertiary sector, e-commerce and the spread of Internet use. In the past, poverty and wealth depended above all on the structure of the local economic fabric. Regions with a greater industrial presence were, in fact, considered rich. Today the situation is completely different, in fact we have reached the opposite, and these regions have become impoverished. It is therefore important to invest in new sectors, in so-called electronic production and in the tertiary sector, which represent the future. This, in my opinion, has been almost ignored by the competent committee that prepared this report. The Committee on Industry, External Trade, Research and Energy therefore calls on the Commission to devote greater attention to this issue. Finally, as the Committee on Energy, we would have liked to see more financial support for renewable energy sources through the use of the Structural Funds and the Regional Development Funds. This would have promoted greater use of renewable energy sources, compensating for the insufficient funding in the Energy Development Programme. . (EN) Mr President, my warmest thanks to Mrs Schroedter for her work. I would like to explain to my colleagues that I am speaking on behalf of Mrs Flautre, who followed this practice in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, but that unfortunately it is not good. I would like to draw your attention to Amendments Nos 1 and 2, which were adopted in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, but not in the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism. These amendments deal with the social economy and the need to provide social risk capital and financial support for local initiatives aimed at creating jobs and strengthening social cohesion. In the past, this Parliament has recognised the huge job-creating potential of the social economy. The above amendments therefore fit with Parliament's position that social exclusion is a serious problem that requires constructive action. We hope that those who are considering voting against these amendments have very good reasons to present to Parliament and to job-seekers. In her report, Mrs Flautre also highlights an area where there is a painful lack of coordination that is desperately needed. The Commission's proposals relate to the four pillars of the employment strategy and the five fields of action of the European Social Fund. The lack of specific guidelines here is particularly acute, given that the idea of linking Social Fund aid to the employment strategy will be implemented for the first time during the 2000-2006 programming period. This omission gives the impression that the Commission itself has no idea how to ensure maximum coordination between support from the European Social Fund, subject to review after three and a half years, and the annual national employment action plans of the Member States.

This event reinforces the need to strengthen European civil protection, following the guidelines suggested by President Prodi in his recent speech and as suggested today by one or two Members. But, for now, the priority is to overcome the crisis. As I have already said, my colleague, Commissioner Wallström, is on the scene today. She will report to Parliament in detail on the actions she will propose as a result of her visit. This has been a horrific tragedy for Europe, and Europe must respond and do everything it can to ensure that such terrible events do not continue to blight our future. The debate is closed. The vote will follow. VOTES. (FR) The only reason we voted in favor of the PSE-Verts/ALE-GUE/NGL compromise resolution is that only this resolution allowed us to "condemn the decision of the Goodyear-Dunlop management to close its factory in Italy." However, the measures proposed in this resolution are insignificant in halting the policies of large industrial groups, which are eliminating jobs and exacerbating unemployment. On the other hand, these are mere words, since socialist governments, which are the majority in Europe, are as incapable as right-wing governments of taking the necessary measures to prevent layoffs. The real problem is not finding legal procedures that make dismissal procedures more complex, but rather prohibiting layoffs. The only way to stop this infernal mechanism—which, on the one hand, generates financial surplus value and, on the other, unemployment—is to prohibit layoffs in all large, profit-making companies, under penalty of expropriation, and to publish the balance sheets of these large companies and subject them to scrutiny by their workers and the entire population. Society must have the means to impose its own priorities on large companies and their owners, and first and foremost, the eradication of unemployment. The sums necessary to create useful jobs in public services, as well as to finance the sharing of work among all, without lowering wages, must be obtained from the profits of large companies. This is infinitely more important, for the majority of society, than wasteful financial transactions or the scandalous enrichment of a minority of large shareholders. (SV) I cannot support this resolution, since Point 8 singles out a specific industry in Italy with the desire to maintain its facilities, while at the same time advising the company's current management to sell the factory to a European tire manufacturer. It is not the task of the European Parliament to declare which factories in the fifteen countries of the European Union must remain or close, increase or decrease their workforce, remain in one place or move, sell or not sell, and which ones must be sold, within or outside Europe.

Madam President, everyone has underlined: today is a very important day, the day of the first debate in the political life of Europe. And that is no coincidence. Today, however, the issue is not the relationship between Europe, our institutions, Austria, or Mr. Haider's party. I think today it is about Europe itself, its raison d'être, the reasons why we are sitting here in this Parliament today. This Parliament does not stand for money and goods. This Parliament and the European institutions stand for values, for a morality, and for a spirit. We have learned from the 20th century that democracies can be endangered, that these morals, these values, and this spirit can be fatally infected by viruses called fanatical nationalism, populism, and racism. One need only read the manifesto of Mr. Haider's party, the FPÖ. Fanatical nationalism, populism, and racism can be found in every chapter. I will just quote one sentence, to which my friend Vidal-Quadras referred earlier: "The concept of homeland is defined in spatial, ethnic, and cultural terms—in terms of space, culture, and race." And we cannot accept such declarations. If Europe is to have any meaning, and—forgive me for saying this to my political friends—if Christian democracy has any meaning, if the history of Christian democracy has any meaning, then it must clearly and unequivocally distance itself from the statements of this program and refuse, however many good reasons there may be, to enter into an agreement with an organization of this nature and ideology. That is why I believe that the European Parliament, which is more independent in its statements and actions than the Council or the Commission, must pay tribute to the states and European institutions that had the courage to say no; to say what you, Madam President, have declared on our behalf. A declaration that honors us and clearly and bluntly expresses our rejection and condemnation of what is unfolding in Austria. We should remember what a great French Christian Democrat said on the day of the Munich Agreement: "When it comes to saying no, it's best to say it immediately." (Applause) Madam President, we are worried. We, that is the Belgian Christian Democrats, and, happily, many other colleagues as well. The coalition being prepared in one of the Member States is certainly an Austrian matter, but it also undeniably has a European dimension. After all, what unites us in Europe are, first and foremost, the values and principles of freedom, democracy, and respect for human rights. The leader of the Freedom Party of Austria, Jörg Haider, has repeatedly expressed his disregard for these values. He also disregards elementary forms of diplomatic courtesy. He is a dangerous man. The Christian Democratic parties in my country made their decision long ago, and they're sticking to it: They acknowledge the protests of far-right voters, but they never negotiate with far-right leaders. Values must take precedence over power.

Mr. President, it is true that the suspension or indefinite postponement of talks between Syrians and Israelis, as well as the new bomb attack the day before yesterday, which injured 16 people, are not good news. It is clear that for once, the United States has not succeeded in breaking the deadlock so that these negotiations can resume. It is true that the obstacles are considerable: the Syrians aspire to regain sovereignty and jurisdiction over the Golan Heights and to recover the borders established prior to June 4, 1967, while the Israelis, believing that this is more appropriate for their situation, want the borders retained to be those established in 1923. The blockage of these talks between Syrians and Israelis is not the only delay in the Middle East peace process. The implementation of the framework agreement between the Palestinian Authority and Israel is currently suspended. Following the conversations that took place the day before yesterday between the Israeli Prime Minister and the head of the Palestinian Authority, the Israeli Prime Minister requested a two-month postponement from February 13, the deadline for implementing the framework agreement on the situation in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. What can the European Union do about this situation? Unfortunately, not much. It should logically support these negotiations, under the auspices of the United States, and should increase contacts. The presence of the European Union envoy, Ambassador Moratinos, who certainly fulfilled his mission with great diligence and efficiency in accordance with the powers available to the European Union, is positive. But all this does not prevent us from realizing that we are relatively powerless, because when the negotiators from both sides fly back to the United States this weekend, we will not be able to help thinking that for every hundred dollars spent on the peace process in the region, 60 dollars are paid by the European Union. And when we think that a Conference will soon be held in Moscow, the pathetic nature of the European Union's presence in this process is highlighted. I would like to emphasize to the Portuguese Presidency the need for us to play a more central role and that it is time to step up and assume a greater European Union presence. I hope that the upcoming visit of the President of the European Parliament to the region, as well as that of the chairs of the corresponding interparliamentary delegations, will mark the beginning of a period in which the European Union will take greater initiative and be more present in this difficult and complex peace process. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner Patten, I would like to thank you for your contributions, particularly Mr Patten, whose analysis I fully share. Therefore, I do not intend to repeat what he said. I would simply like to make three points which Commissioner Patten will no doubt consider to be similar to what he said, but which, for various reasons, can only be formulated so openly by a parliamentarian.

I cannot but fully share this wish. As soon as this opinion is approved here in Parliament, it will be resubmitted to the STAR Committee so that Member States can confirm their approval, which was provisionally issued on 14 November. I assume the Commission will be able to approve the final version of the guidelines in March/April. Once they are published in the Official Journal, there will only be a few months—specifically, six months—to submit LEADER+ programs. I think it's important to mention one thing: Expenditure incurred within the framework of LEADER+ is eligible from the moment the program is in the hands of the Commission. For programs submitted before 30 April of this year, there is also the possibility of retroactively setting 1 January as the start of eligibility. Finally, the draft resolution contains seven specific amendments to the guidelines under item 20. After careful analysis, I can tell you that the amendments contained in paragraphs 2, 4, 5, and 7 are acceptable to the Commission and will be adopted. The amendment to paragraph 6 is also partially accepted, as it insists that the deadline for authorizing programs under LEADER+ be a maximum of six months. The amendment to paragraph 1 is no longer relevant, in our view, because, as a result of discussions with the Member State representatives in the STAR Committee, this point was reworded in line with Parliament's position. Consequently, only the amendment to paragraph 3 remains. The Commission cannot but endorse this request for amendment, as it reflects exactly what the Commission itself originally formulated. However, I must add that, for the Member States, the cooperation of our action groups with similar groups in third countries has gone too far. Consequently, an amendment has been made in committee, but the Commission will now comply with Parliament's wishes in the revised version and thus present the guidelines. It will also continue to fight to make this acceptable to the Member States. I would like to briefly refer to the 13 amendments that have been tabled. Here, the Commission cannot accept three, specifically Amendments 3, 12, and 13. It can accept all the others in their entirety or in their meaning. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is an exceptional opportunity to speak today, in this legislative term, about the EQUAL initiative in the European Parliament. Recently, due to the political changes in Austria, there has been growing political unrest in Europe; there are political declarations and political dialogue. It is fair to point out that both Parliament and the Commission can put forward certain policies. Certain proposals not only on legislation but also on action plans related to the fight against discrimination, to building free and fair communities. I will therefore make a brief mention of discrimination and take this opportunity to request that the relevant committees responsible appoint their rapporteurs to advance this anti-discrimination package as quickly as possible.

We must also continue our support for economic reform and social development throughout Lebanon. A solution must be found to the problem of the Palestinian refugees; with almost five million people, they are the largest refugee population in the world, and this demonstrates the enormous challenges that will have to be met in the future. We must support initiatives to increase the availability of the region's extremely scarce water resources and improve their distribution and management. Finally, and perhaps most importantly, we must promote closer regional cooperation in various fields and try to bring all the countries concerned together to work together to solve their common problems. It is already clear that the Community's current financial resources for supporting this region will not be sufficient to meet the enormous needs that will arise after a lasting peace agreement. I wish to emphasize this emphatically. I would like to urge the Council, and if necessary Parliament, that we must not promise more than we can ultimately deliver. I repeat that a change in Middle East policy will require a fundamentally new approach to the support we have requested and expected. I hope I can assume that we will want to provide this support. As Mr Gama said at the beginning, progress has been made in recent months and weeks. Nevertheless, this difficult process will inevitably be accompanied by problems and disappointments. We will do everything we can to ensure that this process is brought to a successful conclusion and that we can meet the tasks and challenges that this agreement will entail. In conclusion, for those who have only arrived in the Chamber in the last few minutes, I would like to repeat what I said at the beginning: unfortunately, I cannot stay until the end of the debate because this debate was originally scheduled to take place in the morning, and I have therefore arranged a time for this evening to discuss the situation in the Balkans. I hope Members of the House will understand. Mr President, Commissioner Patten can count on our understanding. I would like to say to him that connections with Madrid have normally improved, and I therefore hope to see him there soon.
