The statements we have heard today on the Middle East peace process come at a very opportune time, given the pressed trip to the territory made by Minister Gama – I also regret his absence from this debate – accompanied by other Council representatives. The tone of the media reports on recent events in the territory might lead us to take a pessimistic view of the situation. I honestly believe that such an assessment would not do justice to the facts. In this respect, I share Commissioner Patten's positive perspective. My point is this: it is true that the Israeli Government has postponed the third handover of West Bank territory to the Palestinian authorities. But it is also true that since the signing of the Sharm el-Sheikh agreements, 39% of the territory of the West Bank and two-thirds of the Gaza Strip have been transferred to the Palestinian Authority, and, most importantly, this agreement has been meticulously implemented to date, especially since even its postponement is a prerogative of the Government of Israel, as provided for in Sharm el-Sheikh.

And we must also understand that at the European Union level, there will be contradictions between the various common policies, in this case, development. We must understand that these contradictions exist and we must reduce them to a minimum, a just and wise objective, which is the purpose of presenting this resolution. I believe that the idea of creating an observatory on the evolution of this coherence between Community policies and cooperation and development policies, whose scope of action should not be limited to Community policies but should also encompass the actions or policies of Member States, including the actions of economic groups, which I believe is important, is quite wise and pertinent. This observatory should prepare an annual report on the evolution and impact of these policies and their combination. I have left for last an issue that seems fundamental to me and that this Parliament should—it seems to me—take into account and approve. This new objective of minimizing contradictions between cooperation and development policy and other policies must be a valid goal not only within the European Union, but also globally, given the increasing globalization of the economy. If we want fair world trade, we must impose this same principle at the level of the next round of multilateral negotiations in the World Trade Organization, because it would be contradictory for the European Union to impose an iron, albeit fair, discipline on itself, only for the United States and other major powers to then come and do the opposite and take advantage of what we fail to do. Therefore, it is fair and fundamental that these principles be established in the next round of negotiations at the World Trade Organization. Mr. President, I would like to limit myself to the relationship between development cooperation and agriculture. A considerable portion of the funds have been allocated in recent years to the development of agriculture and livestock in developing countries, and especially in the Lomé countries. The results have not been what we expected. What could be the reason? I believe the root cause must be sought, first of all, in the lack of a clear agricultural policy in the various developing countries, with the corresponding exceptions. I believe the Commission must play an important role in developing that policy. No farmer, anywhere, will produce anything if prices are too low. The governments of developing countries always face a difficult choice: whom should we support, the farmers or the people in the big cities who want cheap food? This delicate balance must be achieved with the support of the Commission, and not only by this institution; the Member States themselves also provide aid in most of the countries where the Commission is active. Member States' policies cannot be allowed to contradict those of the Commission. The Commission's delegations in developing countries must play a leading role in conducting political dialogue and must ensure that all countries follow the same path.

Let us consider the fact that the Commission wants to dismantle or proposes to dismantle, considering itself not up to the task, for example the powers, which are conferred upon it by the Treaty, of implementing common policies. What do we ask in any way of a government? What do we ask of this, so to speak, ambiguous and particular structure that is the European Community? It is good that common resources have a supranational government and that they are not delegated to the Member States or to the BATs, as has happened in the past. It seems to me that you are proposing the same menu to us, but you are proposing it in an aggravated manner, limiting yourself, you say, to the tasks of designing a few White Papers, as you have proposed. The fear I have - even if you shake your head, Mr President - is that this will translate into what some countries have been thinking for years, that is, that the Commission should be a good secretariat of the Council of Ministers. If this is the role that the Commission intends to take on in the next five years, we, convinced federalists, are certain that this is not the right path to take and we will call it on this basis and judge what the Commission intends to do. The reform is important but, if it leads to a weakening, a reduction and a diminution of the supranational powers of the Commission, the structure of European integration is at stake, what the founding fathers had envisaged for the European Commission. As for the other points, Mr President, I take economic and social policy as an example: of course the European social model is in deep crisis, of course the problem of unemployment, not by chance, is the number one problem that none of our policies has managed to resolve, but it is not certain that it can be resolved by making a list of the problems we have spoken about in the past, without having a clear vision, a proposal, that there are economies in our Europe that are moving at some of the fastest paces and that, not by chance, are the economies that have been able to make the flexibility of the labour market and of business the number one objective. If we continue to get bogged down in proposals that have borne very little fruit up to now, I do not know what we will be able to do and what the Commission will be able to do. The same applies to enlargement as an end in itself, without it being linked to a much more effective reform of the European Union and its structures, to proposals that the Commission could also have made at the IGC. Mr President, I want to say one positive thing to you, perhaps contrary to the opinion of some colleagues, regarding the telegram that you sent to the Austrian Government. Your position has convinced us: you did well not to isolate that country further. In any case, we will see, in practice, what the concrete actions will be. I repeat, Mr President: it is a vision that is, in our opinion, a little short-sighted. Above all, there is a lack of impetus in the sectors that I have mentioned, for example with regard to the Balkans.

I must add, however, that the cooperation of our working groups with similar groups in third countries has gone too far in the eyes of the Member States. We have therefore reached an amendment in committee. The Commission will nevertheless once again take Parliament's expectations into account in the revised version and submit the amended guidelines. It will thus continue to strive to ensure that this objective becomes acceptable to the Member States. One last piece of information regarding the 13 amendments tabled. Of these 13 amendments, only three cannot be accepted by the Commission, namely Amendments 3, 12, and 13. All the others can be accepted, either completely or in spirit. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is an extraordinary coincidence that the EQUAL initiative is being discussed in the European Parliament during this period. Recently, and due to political developments in Austria, there has been growing political concern in Europe, but also political statements and dialogue. It must be emphasized that concrete policies must be presented to both Parliament and the Commission. Concrete proposals for both legislation and action plans that concern the fight against discrimination and the establishment of social rights and freedoms. Therefore, allow me to briefly refer to the package of measures against discrimination, by asking the responsible committees of Parliament to appoint rapporteurs in order to address the package of measures against discrimination as quickly as possible. I now come to the EQUAL initiative, which is of course based on Article 13. The EQUAL initiative concerns all forms of discrimination on the basis of Article 13, that is, the fight against discrimination based on sex, race, age, and disability. I would like, in particular, to congratulate Mrs Stenzel because her attempts to conclude the agreement on the EQUAL initiative are particularly difficult and complex, not only because the committees involved defended completely different points of view, but also because it was an extremely sensitive political issue. The first observation, which was also made by many other colleagues, refers to the question of whether there should be a separate mention for women. It is true that we have expressed our disagreement with one aspect of Article 13, but the Treaty at this moment is as it stands, and among the categories of discrimination we find discrimination on the basis of sex. Thus, in accordance with the Treaty as it stands today, the EQUAL initiative is structured in this way. I would like to point out, however, that there is a special focus in the employment strategy concerning women and that a special programme is being prepared, the fifth programme for equality between men and women. I have divided the issues that have attracted the attention of colleagues into four groups. Firstly, the broadening of thematic areas. There are four thematic areas, such as the employment strategy, employability, entrepreneurship, adaptability and equal opportunities, and we agree on the broadening of these thematic areas in accordance with the proposals tabled by the European Parliament. As for the concern about the possible danger of allocating all the funds for one of the categories suffering discrimination to a single country, I would say that the initiative stipulates, with the greatest possible clarity, that Member States will have to submit a thematic area for all the categories suffering discrimination.

Austria is a country open to the world where xenophobia and discrimination have no place. What is happening in Austria is a completely normal process of change of power following democratic elections, through which confidence in an old system has been withdrawn and a stable parliamentary majority has been sought and found to carry out the necessary economic and social reforms. There will be a functioning majority, as well as a functioning opposition. The European People's Party, which I represent in this Parliament, has been and is a party that has always consistently advocated for my country's integration into the EU and that feels deeply attached to the community of values of the European Union, as well as to its basic political lines regarding its deepening and enlargement. We respect and accept the debate and also understand the concern expressed in many of our member countries about future developments in Austria. We understand because we know that, due to our very recent history, we also bear a special political responsibility in the present. Our country was not only the first victim of Hitler's dictatorship, but many were also involved, although I reject any collective guilt. Austria found its way to the European Union not least thanks to the ÖVP. My country's place is not outside the European Union but within it... ...and with all the rights and obligations. A future government must be judged by the values and principles it defends in its government program and not by the prejudices held, in part, by political opponents and, in part, by the international media. The recognition of human rights, democracy, and the rule of law, a sincere review of Austria's role in the past, and a sharing of information about the greatest crime against humanity in the 20th century, the Holocaust, will also be reflected in the agreement in principle of a future coalition government between the ÖVP and the FPÖ. My party will guarantee that my country remains on the path of European policy and on the basis of the community of European values. (Applause) Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, representatives of the Commission: This is a dark day for Austria and for Europe. Mr. Sichrovsky's web of lies and Mrs. Stenzel's placating words can't change this fact. It's gotten to the point where two irresponsible politicians, consumed by a thirst for power, are selling out Austria's image, political role, and, in part, its economic interests. (Applause, exclamations) They're trading this for the position of head of government and participation in a government. They're accepting that Austria, once a respected country, will become a despised one, as well as the isolation of the country itself and, consequently, of some of its citizens.

We need considerably more openness and transparency on this issue than before. It is unacceptable that a measure like this is being imposed on the Member States without proper public debate. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Radical Members, I abstained from voting on this report in the Committee on Budgetary Control because I share the concerns so emphatically expressed by the representative of another, undoubtedly important legal culture, namely common law. We are undoubtedly exerting pressure with this report, as we believe certain aspects require resolution and fraud in the Community must be combated and curbed. However, the way in which our committee intends to conclude this report, under the impetuous pressure and dogged determination of Committee Chair Mrs Theato, cannot be accepted without criticism. Another important criticism of the report concerns secondary legislation. Article 280 of the Treaty empowers the Council to adopt appropriate measures to combat fraud. We are, however, somewhat dismayed that an institution which would represent a qualitative leap has been proposed without immediately anticipating the consequences which this would entail, that is to say, that the aspect of defence and, with it, the possibility of effective functioning of the prosecution and defence in such an important legal system have been neglected. My abstention in committee was intended to express this dismay. Mr President, I believe that this issue must be given serious thought in the European Parliament, both in plenary and in committee, although it cannot, of course, be discussed without taking into account the legal culture and the circles in which institutional issues are discussed. These are very serious incidents which seemed to be commonplace in the past. Certain changes have since taken place, at least in the mechanisms, particularly as regards control. But we are still not satisfied, especially when the relevant bodies are even talking about a European Prosecutor's Office for crimes committed at European level, fraud, embezzlement, and the disclosure of official secrets. We should undoubtedly protect the Community's interests and reputation, as well as its relationship with taxpayers, who are an indispensable and essential part of Community life. For this reason, it is right to raise the problem of general and universal protection of interests, better coordinated with the national justice systems. This raises the most difficult question: what role does a European Prosecutor's Office have in relations with the individual national communities and their respective judicial systems? I believe that this issue still requires further consideration from both a cultural and practical perspective. There is a danger today that a new body will overwhelm the multitude of different institutions existing in each country. Mr President, I would very much like to say two things very quickly. First, I don't want to refer to the philosophical questions of subsidiarity and the sovereignty of the member states, although I am very much in favor of having such a debate, because my regular viewing of British television channels reveals to me the threats to the domestic legal culture posed by national politicians from the continent. Sometimes this is almost worthy of cabaret and deserves a discussion. But that's not my point.

Already weak economies are being further weakened by the AIDS virus. Already overstretched resources are being further strained. In the countries with the highest AIDS rates, 50% or more of all hospital beds are currently occupied by AIDS patients. On a completely different note, I would like to support Cuba's membership as an ACP country in the new Lomé Convention, which will soon be agreed between the European Union and the countries of Africa, the Caribbean, and the Pacific. I know this is somewhat controversial, particularly because of the United States government's attitude towards the Castro regime. However, on this occasion, the European Union will call for the inclusion of political criteria in the Lomé Convention. Criteria of good government practice, broadly encompassing refugee issues, corruption, human rights, and democracy, will be part of the final agreement between the European Union and all the African, Caribbean, and Pacific Lomé signatories. The Lomé Convention, on which the entire fabric of relations between the European Union and the 71 states of Africa, the Caribbean, and the Pacific is based, remains the most effective and ambitious development instrument in the context of North-South relations. After years of "good and faithful service," it remains the most important symbol of the European Union's efforts to improve the lot of the poorest countries and promote their development. This is where the human face of Europe is revealed... John Corrie's report rightly highlights the importance of this unique, targeted instrument, as well as the work of the Joint Assembly that implements it. This is all the more true since the precarious structure of this ambitious framework was at risk. The negotiations on the path of the partnership between the European Union and the ACP countries into the new millennium were a very arduous process. I welcome today the fact that reason and generosity have triumphed over the difficulties, opening up new prospects for this partnership. More than 30 years after the launch of the unique North-South Partnership, it is essential to adapt a tried-and-tested but outdated instrument to meet new challenges. Therefore, the new agreement, to be signed in Fiji on 31 May this year for a period of 20 years, represents more than a mere extension of the agreements governing relations between Europe and the ACP states. It must also signify their overhaul. The new agreement clearly enshrines the political dimension of a partnership that provides the only forum for dialogue and political exchange in North-South relations. As the Joint Assembly increasingly opens itself to elected representatives from the parliaments of the ACP states, this dimension must not only be safeguarded but also promoted. The Joint Assembly thus represents a platform for defending the common interests of European and developing countries. Following the fiasco of the Seattle Conference, our task now is to coordinate our position regarding the further development of global trade rules aimed at combating poverty. The partnership can now be built on a long-term basis. The path to its modernization is clear:

Therefore, I ask you, Madam President, to ask the Commission to make its statement now and then proceed to the vote. (Applause from the PSE Group). Madam President, I want to make it very clear that, above all, the Commission has the utmost respect for the decisions of this Parliament, including the decision to establish its agenda. We therefore respect what Parliament may decide in this regard. But I also want to make it very clear that President Prodi committed to Parliament to include a new debate, as Mr. Barón recalled, in addition to the annual debate on the Commission's legislative program, on the main lines of action for the next five-year period, that is, for this legislative term. I would like to say, Madam President, that this debate was distinguished, in the agreement reached in September, from the annual presentation of the Commission's legislative program. And I would like to say, Madam President, that, on the Commission's part, we are prepared and willing to hold that debate whenever appropriate, that we were prepared to hold it this week, as had been agreed in principle, based on the fact that it was presented the day before in a speech to the parliamentary groups. Therefore, Madam President, I would like to reiterate that, for our part, we have debated the action programme for the next five years and that we are prepared, whenever Parliament so decides—this week if that is the decision—to present the programme for the next five years and, next month, the programme for the year 2000, which was what was fully agreed. I propose that we vote on the request by the Group of the Party of European Socialists to reinstate the Commission's declaration on its strategic objectives. (Parliament rejects the request.) President: On Wednesday's subject, I have another proposal concerning the oral question on the capital tax. The PPE-ED Group requests that this item be withdrawn from the agenda. Will any colleague speak on behalf of the group to justify this request? Madam President, I hear some laughter among the Socialists. I have been told that broad circles within the Socialist Group also welcome the deletion of this item from the agenda, since the vote taken at the Conference of Presidents lacked the vote of the competent working group of our colleagues from the Socialist Group. I do not know whether this information is correct, but we, as the PPE/DE Group, would in any case appreciate the deletion of this item, since Parliament has already addressed this issue numerous times. There are also agreements against such a tax. Therefore, my group requests that this item be deleted. Thank you, Mr. Poettering. Let us now listen to Mr. Wurtz, who will speak against the request. Madam President, first of all, I would like to underline the lack of logic on the part of Mr. Poettering, who has just lectured the Group of European Socialists about reconsidering a decision that was made absolutely clearly at the Conference of Presidents.

I can also agree with the part of Amendment 6 which proposes an amendment to Directive 93/53 on the basis of scientific and technical evidence. As I have already said, according to available scientific evidence, ISA does not pose a threat to health. I can therefore agree to Amendment 10, provided that the reference to the highest possible standard is replaced by a reference to safety. As regards the environmental impact, many people will be aware that a number of causes have been blamed for the decline in stocks over the past decades, including pollution, overfishing, climate change, and others. At present, it cannot be ruled out that ISA may also have an impact on wild salmon stocks. Fish have already escaped from aquaculture farms, and the virus has been detected in wild salmon. In this regard, there are a number of unresolved questions which can only be clarified through further scientific research. This is also why great caution must be exercised in the fight against ISA. Infected fish must not be allowed to remain on farms, and I am prepared to examine this matter further to prevent the virus from being released into the environment. To this end, I propose that we amend our original proposal to require Commission approval for rural programs drawn up by the competent authorities. This should avoid excessively lengthy fish removal periods. I also propose that fish showing clinical signs of the disease be removed immediately. Using the existing procedures under Community law for establishing additional control measures, removal programs will be established based on the health status of the fish in order to minimize impacts on the environment. On this basis, I can accept Amendments 7 and 8, with a minor modification to Amendment 8. I also have considerable sympathy for Amendment 9, but I believe it could be better worded to establish a link between environmental concerns and disease control and eradication strategies. I am unable to support Amendments 12 and 13. I have the feeling that this is intended to eliminate any risk. I believe it will be very difficult to achieve this without shutting down the affected fish farming sector. I look forward to Parliament's views on these amendments, and if you believe this approach is the best solution, I will take note of it carefully. I can accept Amendment 11 in part. Finally, I would like to underline that we remain committed to achieving a high level of health protection in accordance with our Treaty obligations. I believe that measures proportionate to this objective are the right way forward. We remain committed to eradicating the disease. This is an objective that will benefit both the environment and the salmon farming sector. I hope that the European Parliament will recognize our commitment by supporting our proposal. I would be very grateful. Thank you, Commissioner Byrne. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11:00 a.m. Protection of juveniles of marine organisms The next item is the report (A5-0035/2000) by Mr Gallagher, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the proposal for a Council regulation amending for the fourth time Regulation (EC) No 1626/94 laying down certain technical measures for the conservation of fishery resources in the Mediterranean and amending for the fourth time Regulation (EC) No 850/98 for the conservation of fishery resources through technical measures for the protection of juveniles of marine organisms (COM(1999) 552 - C5-0040/2000 - 1999/0222(CNS)).

It is clear that many in Wales see the Structural Funds programme as a way of addressing some of the great difficulties that we undoubtedly face. We have seen increasing poverty in Wales, a trend that has been increasing since 1997. We have seen the gap between rich and poor widening. We therefore expect the Structural Funds programme not only to look at industrial restructuring, but also to bring about broader improvements across the whole economic base of Wales. What is very damaging to us, however, is the perception that, in some way, the provision of Structural Funds has been a victory for the Government, when all they do is acknowledge that Wales does face very great difficulties. Therefore, I would like to highlight some points that I think the Commission should put at the forefront. We hope that the Commission will address the points relating to additionality. We regret that, in some ways, the British figures have obscured the Welsh figures. We also hope that the Commission will provide the projects with the appropriate funding. We hope that it will ensure, contrary to the British Government, the involvement of the private sector in the planning phase, as it is certain that the private sector must provide the main impetus for the expenditure of structural funds. Finally, we call on the Commission to ensure that structural funds are spent transparently. In this Parliament, transparency is too often lacking. In this area, the Commission can become a great friend of Wales. Mr President, our committee is addressing these issues from many different angles, and I will begin with the research angle. We consider it very positive that, in his conclusions, the rapporteur has taken account of our proposal that research infrastructures should be expanded in the cohesion countries by locating vocational schools and universities in such a way that they better serve the populations of the less developed regions and allow those trained to remain in their home regions. This is something that can be achieved by taking measures at the level of public authorities. Such decentralisation of higher education is undoubtedly a useful policy when it comes to ensuring development. The second point to which we wanted to draw attention, precisely from the perspective of industrial policy, is that we would have liked the Commission, when considering the coordination of the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund, to pay greater attention to the impact of the growth of services, e-commerce and the use of the Internet. In the past, poverty and wealth were more dependent on the structures of economic life. The rich regions were those where there were industrial jobs, whereas today these regions may very well have become a burden and are poor. It is therefore necessary to also invest in new sectors of activity, so-called "electronic" production and the production of electronic services, because these are sectors of the future.

The best prevention for the future is the certainty that charterers will have of being heavily fined, civilly, criminally and financially, if they are not extremely vigilant about the safety of the vessels they choose. Secondly, the double-hull requirement for oil tankers allowed to use Community waters must be imposed as quickly as possible and not postponed indefinitely. Thirdly, a strict age limit for vessels allowed to use Community waters must be set quickly. This could be a maximum of fifteen years. In the absence of a sufficiently clear, strict and rigorous Community regulatory framework, Member States that wish to establish one should be authorized to do so to protect their population and territory, in the same way that the United States learned the lessons of the Exxon Valdez disaster by requiring double hulls and banning all vessels over twenty years old from its waters. This is how the United States refused the Erika access to its waters. If the Community had done the same, a huge catastrophe would have been avoided. Let us ensure, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, that this time we truly learn the lesson, even when the media and parliamentary excitement have subsided. Mr. President, Torrey Canyon, Olympic Bravery, Haven, Amoco Cadiz, Gino, Tanio—these are all names of sinister memory. And now Erika. Whose turn is it? Twenty-one years after the Amoco Cadiz, this umpteenth oil spill, the seventh since 1967, proves the irresponsibility of our successive governments. The West Atlantic is once again paying a high price for their inability to react, for their capitulation to multinationals. It is difficult to understand why the French and Europeans allow what the Americans refuse, and why Europe, usually so quick to legislate on environmental matters, has ignored maritime safety. The result is clear. The Erika, a ship flying the Maltese flag, a walking wreck ranked among the most dangerous oil tankers, has polluted our coasts over a distance of more than 400 km, representing a pollution level far more serious than that caused by the Amoco Cadiz. As an elected representative for Loire-Atlantique, I can unfortunately attest to this. These repeated disasters are not natural, they owe nothing to fate. They are the consequence of human recklessness. This is truly an ecological catastrophe. Only those out of touch with the harsh realities on the ground could have doubted it. It is also an economic catastrophe for all those who make their living from the sea and tourism: fishermen, oyster farmers, shellfish farmers, salt workers, traders, etc. The Erika disaster must be the last in the series. First of all, we must shed full light on this shipwreck. Why not appoint a parliamentary commission of inquiry or involve parliamentarians in the mission announced earlier by the Commission? Then, we must urgently legislate, first, to ensure that the exact characteristics of the goods transported are known. Indeed, according to experts, the Erika's oil was expected to sink to the bottom and never reach the coast.

You said the precautionary principle should not be used as a disguised trade barrier. Is this aspect interpreted in the same way on both sides of the Atlantic? In my opinion, we will have particular problems with hormone-treated beef and genetically modified plants. Will the Americans take the same position on this issue as we do? Mr. President, I am pleased to announce that we have just signed a protocol on biosafety in Montreal. This allows us to reach agreement on the definition of the precautionary principle in an international forum. I consider the signing of this protocol a breakthrough on this issue. I believe it will form the basis for future discussions on the precautionary principle, as we will be able to use it as an example for interpreting this principle. Furthermore, this protocol is also recognized as an important and valuable tool. Mr. President, I have two questions and will try to be very brief. My first question concerns the application of the precautionary principle. If I understand correctly, there has been some confusion about this. Is it the case that a risk assessment, including a cost-benefit analysis, must first be carried out? If that were the case, it would be very worrying, since it was not actually intended to use a cost-benefit analysis as an instrument in deciding whether to apply the precautionary principle. Instead, the precautionary principle should take precedence. My second question concerns the burden of proof. I remember Ms. Wallström's presentation to the committee as the new Commissioner. At the time, she spoke of introducing a reversed burden of proof, meaning that the manufacturer of a product must prove its safety. I am now interested to know whether this also applies to the document now presented by the Commission. Thank you, Ms. Schörling. You have raised two important questions, and I am pleased to have the opportunity to comment on them. No, it does not have to start with a cost-benefit analysis. Instead, it should be based on an assessment of our current state of knowledge and scientific findings, and their evaluation in relation to the risks we see for the environment or human or animal health. However, if a particular measure has been decided upon, then the most cost-effective implementation should be chosen. This should prevent measures from being taken that are completely inappropriate in terms of their effectiveness. So it is not necessary to start with a cost-benefit analysis. The second question concerned the reverse burden of proof. It is quite right that we must apply this in certain cases. A good example of an area where this is necessary is the chemicals strategy. However, that concerns a single policy area, whereas this communication on the precautionary principle can be described as horizontal, meaning it affects all policy areas. For this reason, a reverse burden of proof or its implementation will not be discussed separately in this context; instead, the focus will be on political decision-making and the basis for it. However, it is absolutely true that we must adopt a reversed burden of proof, for example, with chemicals. Mr. President, in my opinion, the precautionary principle would have to be quite radical for it to work; otherwise, one would always get lost in the convoluted labyrinths of interpretation.

Finally, I come to the agreement on South Africa, which the rapporteur also mentioned. I am simply delighted—not to say happy—to be able to announce to you this evening, by way of concluding this timely debate, that the South African President has today accepted the solution unanimously proposed last Monday by the EU Council of Foreign Ministers regarding the outstanding problems with South Africa. The "grappa war" is therefore over. Peace has returned, and we can now look forward to cooperation with South Africa based on the common values and dreams that bring us together. This, I believe, is a good conclusion to this very interesting debate, and I reiterate my thanks to the rapporteur and to the House for the cooperation that has been established in the context of relations between third world countries and our work. Thank you, Commissioner. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at noon. Stabilisation and Association Agreement with FYROM The next item is the report (A5-0031/2000) by Mr Swoboda, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy, on the Commission's recommendation for a Council decision authorising the Commission to negotiate a stabilisation and association agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (SEC(1999)1279 - C5-0166/1999 -1999/2121(COS)). Mr President, Commissioner Patten, ladies and gentlemen, today we are talking about a country which has just overcome very difficult times, a country which is nevertheless on the way up, of its own strength, through its own will and with the support of the international community. If the European Union, the Council and the Commission - I assume that Parliament will support this decision tomorrow - propose for the first time in South-Eastern Europe to conclude a Stabilisation and Association Agreement in the Balkan region - I hope to be able to use this term throughout my speech - this constitutes first and foremost recognition of the work accomplished by FYROM/Macedonia on the economic level, but also on the political level, given the war that has raged in the surrounding area and the ethnic minority that lives there. Because having a minority of 33 to 35% on one's own territory is certainly no small feat considering the neighbouring country. This country and its politicians - who undoubtedly differ from one region to another - have always done remarkable work, and this must be recognised. The Commission is proposing that we conclude an agreement with the Council. I would like to make two or three comments specifically concerning the areas in which there may still be some differences of opinion. In this regard, I would like to highlight the quality of the work carried out by Commissioner Patten and I welcome his interest in FYROM and the region as a whole. Let us first talk about the regional approach. If it is understood correctly, I believe that this regional approach is important and necessary.

I also emphasized the need for prevention. The involvement of the social partners must also be emphasized. Flexibility is needed, and the administrative burden must be reduced; this is a priority. Flexibility is also needed for countries with small budgets. Although I think that some aspects of the report could be better handled in other ways, I believe overall that this report offers a flexible and sensible approach and that it must be supported. With this EQUAL Community initiative, the Commission wants to replace the Employment and ADAPT Community initiatives, as well as various sub-programmes in this sector – NOW (new opportunities for women), Horizon (for people with disabilities), Youthstart (integration of young people into the labour market), and Integra (for groups at risk of exclusion) – with the aggravating circumstance that the amounts allocated have been significantly reduced. Thus, it is through this initiative that we will implement what the Commission considers to be new methods for combating discrimination and inequalities of all kinds in the context of the labor market, based on the four pillars of the employment policy directives. This is a lot for so few resources. But to ensure that this new methodology has the potential to succeed, the Commission should have opted for a less complex, simpler and more direct proposal, with the participation of NGOs from the beginning of the process, so that partnerships develop in a balanced way. It did not do this. We hope that it will reconsider at least the points we have mentioned. Mr. President, some will remember the successful film "Cocoon," in which elderly people regain a second youth by drinking a particular type of water. It is therefore, in my opinion, extremely important to pay the greatest attention to the water we all drink and to monitor and approve the provisions relating to it. That is why I voted in favour of this common provision, but I would like to stress that I hope that, above all, we will ensure that the water is as pure as possible when it enters our homes. I noticed in the provision that was approved the lack - but I am sure that this will be remedied - of support for those who purify their water at home, in their own homes. Apart from Amendment 76, where I made a mistake, because my intention was to vote in favour, my votes could be explained by the following fiction: Supposed draft environmental directive: "Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the obligation to maintain a temperature of at least eighteen degrees centigrade in the streets, squares and gardens of European towns and cities during the winter." The broad outlines of the directive: a) each town must equip itself with sufficient energy and technological resources to achieve this objective by 2012; (b) the costs will be borne entirely by the inhabitants of each city, and will be added to the electricity bill. Opinion of a Member of Parliament from Northern Europe: "This directive would be unfair because, for example, the cost for a resident of Stockholm would be more than 200 times higher than the cost for a resident of Naples."

Work is ongoing in the Member States regarding BSE, a bovine disease, and work is underway to introduce random testing to determine infectivity in the Member States. I know that Ms. Roth-Behrendt has asked me this question before, and I promised a rapid solution at the time, but as far as I know, interdepartmental consultations are currently taking place within the Commission. In any case, work is underway. I hope that the next time you ask me this question, I can provide more detailed information. Ms. Jackson asked about the 24 new draft laws and 20 updates and whether this will not lead to even more overregulation. With these regulations, we want to close loopholes in existing laws. This is less about establishing new or additional regulatory systems, although that is part of it, but about identifying and closing weaknesses and gaps in the chain from farm to fork. The accession candidates were mentioned, and we have, of course, thought of that. Food safety and security in many other areas are crucial in connection with enlargement. I have brought this problem to Mr. Verheugen's attention. Commissioner, the ignorance of some member states has brought us to a major food crisis in Europe, and I am, alas, once again annoyed that today, as you present this interesting report, the Council is once again completely absent. I would very much like to know how you intend to ensure that such a new authority, whatever its exact name may be, also has influence over the Council, who has the final say within it, and who issues mandates. Of course, we must not dictate anything substantive, but I do insist that Parliament retain and even expand its powers after Maastricht and Amsterdam. I am very concerned that we will once again have an authority that flies anonymously around Europe like a satellite; I would love such an authority like the devil loves holy water. I hope that this will not happen! I, too, welcome the White Paper. But will the Food Safety Authority also have sufficient authority to prevent phenomena like the beef war and France's refusal to lift the ban? You mentioned that the Commission has the power to withhold grants and subsidies from countries behaving similarly to France. Could you also imagine the Commission, for example, providing interim payments similar to those currently being demanded by British farmers? Mr. President, Commissioner, last week at a briefing, you stated that you believe the future EU Food Safety Authority should not be located on the periphery, but you did not elaborate on what "periphery" means. The work of the EU agency relocated to Dublin has proven that geographical distance is no obstacle to efficiency and connections. The main tasks of the future Food Safety Authority were identified as the collection, publication, and coordination of data, the preparation of recommendations for the development of food safety, and—as you said—the collection of scientific information and its dissemination to consumers. All of these things can be achieved anywhere in the European Union using modern technology.

I would like to answer both questions as follows. Upon its accession to the European Union, Sweden was permitted to maintain its quantitative restrictions on the alcoholic beverages that travelers from other Member States are permitted to import into the country. This derogation from the principle of free movement of goods and persons expires on 30 June of this year. Sweden now wishes to extend this measure for a further five years, which it argues is necessary in the interest of public health. My position on this is clear. Since joining the Union, Sweden has had sufficient time to adapt its policy to a situation without such import restrictions. Therefore, I see no reason to propose a further extension of this measure. European citizens have the right to purchase goods for their personal use in any Member State, including tax, and to import them into another Member State without these goods being subject to controls or possibly being taxed again. Derogations from this fundamental principle of the internal market must remain temporary exceptions. We want to ensure that Swedish citizens, like other citizens of the European Union, can now enjoy the benefits of the internal market. This does not mean that I do not share Sweden's concern about possible health problems caused by alcohol abuse. However, a recent expert report by Professor Lindgren of Lund University proves that lifting the restrictions would not lead to an increase in alcohol consumption in Sweden. I have already had the opportunity to explain my position to Mr. Ringholm, the Swedish Minister of Finance, twice. Last week, I also discussed this matter with the Finance Committee of the Swedish Parliament. It is now up to the Swedish government to take appropriate steps. Thank you for this reply, Commissioner! First of all, I regret that an error crept into my question to the Commission. It states 2004 as the end date, but it should of course read 1 July 2000. I understand, to a certain extent, the Commission's position that derogations should only be temporary and that the rule should be the norm. Nevertheless, I would like to ask you two questions: Do you nevertheless intend to enter into further discussions with the Swedish government about extending the derogations, for example, as long as such regulations apply to Denmark and Finland? My second question relates to the common alcohol policy. This can be viewed as a matter of the internal market, but also as a matter of public health throughout the EU. What role do alcohol policy and public health aspects play in the Commission's work? Alcohol policy throughout Europe is not only about the internal market, but also about public health. If we had considered these aspects together, the discussions with Sweden might have been easier. I would like to thank Mr. Andersson for the supplementary question to his first question and give him the following answer. First, Finland and Denmark have derogations from the basic principle of the free movement of goods until 2003. These countries are currently preparing measures to ensure that they are prepared for the import of alcoholic beverages in 2003. In the case of Sweden, however, the situation is different. In 1995, an exemption was adopted there for a period of five years, which is now expiring.

You previously explained that we are heading for disaster and nothing is being done. We must provide for a rapid procedure! I would like to say first of all that I agree with the priorities regarding the identification of personal responsibilities invoked by the honorable Member. As for the judicial structure, we have had the opportunity to hear Mr. Kouchner describe on several occasions the major difficulties he is encountering in setting up an administrative machine and a judicial structure. We know that the first steps took place several months ago. We are aware of the difficulties, particularly financial ones, that Mr. Kouchner faced in setting up this administrative machine and in particular the difficulty in recruiting police forces for everyday public security. This is a responsibility, Mr. Deputy, that is always present within the framework of the European Union and I would like to tell you that this issue was highlighted, with regard to Kosovo, during the General Affairs Council on Monday. There have been statements and pressures put on the various Member States that have committed to providing police forces. Some Member States have taken refuge behind the fact that they have armed forces on the ground and cannot supplement, as quickly as would be desirable, the police forces they have committed to providing. We are perfectly aware that this circumstance decisively compromises Mr. Kouchner's work, the regularization and normalization of Kosovo's administrative structure, especially the judicial part and police coverage. This has clear and evident negative effects on the ability to regulate the articulation between ethnic groups, and we are aware that if measures are not taken in the short term, we could be heading towards situations of tension like those we experienced a few hours ago and towards a repetition of these situations of tension in other areas of Kosovo. This is an issue that is essentially situated in the NATO context, but on which the European Union has no difficulty in associating itself with NATO's interpretation of these issues. You are aware, Mr. Deputy, of the difficulty that exists in selecting targets during a military action, particularly when it takes place using air assets; you also know that a set of targets target infrastructure and are intended to hamper the functioning of the war machine. We are obviously entering a territory, a gray area, where you will tell me that these are civilian targets, such as bridges, road or rail infrastructure, while others will say that these are military targets, because they serve to support military structures in their aggressive actions, such as those carried out at the time by Mr. Milosevic's forces inside Kosovo. It is this difference in interpretation of military targets that separates us.

At the request of a French Member, Mr. Zimeray, a petition has been submitted. Many have signed it, including myself. However, in accordance with the position consistently expressed by the European Parliament and the entire European Community, I ask you to speak with the prestige of your office and that of the institution you represent before the President and the Governor of the State of Texas, Mr. Bush, who has the power to suspend the death sentence and pardon the condemned man. All of this in accordance with the principles we have always supported. Thank you, Mr. Segni, I will do so very willingly. It is, without a doubt, in line with the positions our Parliament has always adopted. Madam President, I would like to draw your attention to a case that this Parliament has repeatedly addressed. It is the case of Alexander Nikitin. We are all celebrating here that the court has declared him innocent and has shown that in Russia, too, access to information about the environment is a constitutional right. However, it so happens that he is going to be charged again, as the prosecutor will appeal. We know, and we have indeed stated in many resolutions—specifically at the last plenary session last year—that this is not merely a legal case and that it is wrong to accuse Alexander Nikitin of criminal conduct and treason because we, as those affected by its results, benefit from it. These results constitute the basis of the European Barents Sea programs, and I therefore ask you to study a draft letter outlining the most relevant facts and making clear to Russia this position, which is in line with Parliament's decisions. Yes, Mrs. Schroedter, I will gladly examine the facts related to this matter as soon as I receive your letter. Madam President, first of all, I would like to congratulate you on having kept your promise, since, in this first session of the new year, the number of channels in our offices has indeed been drastically expanded. However, Madam President, what I had requested has not been done. It is true that there are now two Finnish channels and one Portuguese channel, but there is still no Dutch channel, and I had asked you for a Dutch channel, because we Dutch people would also like to hear the news every month when we are sent into this exile. Therefore, I would like to ask you again to ensure that we can also watch a Dutch channel. Mrs. Plooij-van Gorsel, I can tell you that this issue is on the agenda for the Quaestors' meeting scheduled for Wednesday. I hope it will be discussed in a positive spirit. Madam President, could you tell me why this Parliament is not complying with the health and safety legislation it has actually passed? Why hasn't any air quality testing been carried out in this building since we were elected?

In these circumstances, could the Commission indicate when it intends to find, under Article 7.1, the existence of a serious and persistent violation by a Member State of the principles set out in Article 6(1) and urge the Council, acting by a qualified majority, to suspend certain rights arising from the application of this Treaty to Austria, in particular the voting rights of the Austrian representative in the Council? Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to begin my reply by recalling the position that the Commission had adopted with regard to the composition of the new Austrian government, reiterated this morning by President Romano Prodi with regard to the Austrian government, which includes ministers belonging to Mr Jörg Haider's Austrian Freedom Party. I refer, of course, to the Commission's statement of 1 February 2000, the broad outline of which I shall begin by recalling. The Commission has affirmed and reaffirms today that it shares the underlying concerns of the Portuguese Presidency's statement of 31 January. These concerns are legitimate and well-founded. There is no need to recall here the political career of Mr Jörg Haider and his numerous xenophobic and racist, and therefore anti-European, public statements. The fact that a clearly extremist, racist, and xenophobic party comes to power in a Member State of the European Union cannot fail to concern the other States participating in the European project, in the same way that it does not leave the European Commission indifferent. Secondly, the Commission has reiterated and reiterates its commitment to continue exercising its duty as guardian of the Treaties, in particular with regard to Articles 6 and 7 of the Treaty on European Union. One of the important innovations of the Treaty of Amsterdam is the introduction of an explicit reference to the fundamental principles that constitute the common heritage of the Member States and the creation of a mechanism for monitoring their compliance and for responding in the event of a violation of one of these principles. The Commission has thus demonstrated in practice its commitment to one of the fundamental principles: that of the rule of law. This principle obliges the Commission to act within the limits set by the Treaties, and it is in this context that its statement of 1 February is made. The Commission is not a State and cannot and should not act in such a capacity. But, to answer the honourable Member's question concretely, it should be recalled that the mechanism established by Article 7(1) of the Treaty on European Union requires, in order to be activated, that there be a finding of, I quote, a serious and persistent violation of the principles set out in Article 6. A serious and persistent violation, I repeat, constitutes the essential condition for the Commission to be able to propose to the Council the adoption of measures against a Member State. It seems to me clear that the conditions for the application of this mechanism to the situation in Austria are not met. Furthermore, I think I am right in saying that we all hope that these conditions of serious and persistent violation of human rights and democracy will never be met either for Austria or for any other Member State of the Union.

This system is financed through a special fund to which buyers of new vehicles contribute. Mrs Breyer, is this ecologically reprehensible? In my opinion, not. The Netherlands is an exemplary model for the disposal of vehicles as proposed by the directive. The question of whether the costs of this should fall on the buyer of a new vehicle or on the manufacturer in the case of a vehicle already in circulation has nothing to do with ecology, but is a purely competitive issue! The question is whether a European manufacturer should set aside EUR 250 million and a Korean manufacturer perhaps EUR 2 million. Taking into account the people employed in the automotive sector in Europe, I am in favour of not creating distortions of competition. In the interests of environmental protection, however, I want to ensure that the system is free for the last owner, which should be financed through a special fund, and I want to ensure that manufacturers are responsible for new vehicles, because then they will also have the responsibility to build vehicles that are easy to recycle! (Applause from the PSE Group benches) Mr President, there are many positive aspects to this proposal, particularly in terms of waste management, reuse, recovery and recycling of components and materials, etc. I think it is a very good proposal. The main point of discussion is: is it the manufacturer, the end-user or someone else who is responsible for taking back the end-of-life vehicle free of charge or not? I will give the example of my country in order to make it clear how the system works without any problems. We have an agreement with all the parties involved, namely the car manufacturers, the second-hand car dealers, the confederation of the automotive industry, the metal processing companies, the scrapping operators and the public authority. An agreement has been signed on a voluntary basis for environmental protection. The automotive industry, and Belgium is a country with a high production of vehicles, has not raised any problems. Our fellow citizens can hand over their end-of-life vehicles to the end-user free of charge. As a result, we have noticed - contrary to what is claimed here, namely that this would be to the detriment of employment - that a number of small businesses are doing a very good job of recycling materials. Some businesses have taken a leading role, as they are able to recycle certain materials, including some that have not yet been transposed into the directive. This means that we are developing a new sector, creating new jobs, and at the same time doing a great service to the environment. I am in favour of free take-back. In my country, we have succeeded in doing so; why shouldn't we succeed in doing so elsewhere? Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this interesting debate, full of important arguments. I ask you to bear with me for a few more minutes. Allow me to briefly outline some of the principles and starting points from which this directive was based. I would first like to begin with some comments and some responses to the most important remarks that have characterised this debate.

As acknowledged in the Swoboda report, its conditions do not call for peace, but for greater political and economic influence over the country, control of its natural wealth, exploitation of its workforce and use of the country as a base of operations against nations and peoples in the region who oppose the new order. All this is offered in exchange for the promise of the country's future membership of the Union. The report welcomes these orientations as well as the EU's more general policy towards South-Eastern Europe. It is significant that the report praises FYROM for its constructive attitude during the NATO aggression. It praises its peaceful role in accepting the deployment of NATO forces on its territory, but nothing is said about the indignation expressed by its people in the mass mobilisations against the continued NATO bombing. Finally, since we believe that the Stability Pact and the Stabilisation and Association Procedure applied by the Union to the countries of the region will cause new problems in those areas and new horrors for their inhabitants, further strengthening the hegemonic role of the American and European imperialists, we will vote against the report in order to express solidarity with the people of FYROM. Mr President, Commissioner, one of the fundamental objectives of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is the consolidation of stability and peace in the region, which of course presupposes the development and maintenance of good neighbourly relations between the countries concerned. I will not bore you with the details of the question of the name of FYROM which, as you are no doubt aware, is a source of conflict with Greece and has been the subject of negotiations between the two countries for more than four years, under the aegis of the UN Secretary-General in the context of the relevant Security Council resolutions, but also of an agreed commitment between the parties under Article 5 of the so-called Interlocutory Agreement of 1995. I believe it is appropriate to point out that, on the occasion of the forthcoming negotiations and the definition of the association agreement, the European side must make it clear to the Government in Skopje that it needs to demonstrate adequate and constructive political will in order to make a decisive contribution to the successful conclusion of the New York talks. I would like to hope that such a European request, bearing in mind the difficulties that a possible postponement would cause for the completion and implementation of the Association Agreement, will receive the attention it deserves and will be taken into due account by the Government of Skopje so as to respond adequately to the compromise position taken by Greece on this matter and to the real and generally declared intention of all EU Member States - Greece included - to facilitate and contribute to the path of FYROM towards a united Europe. In fact, Mr President, I do not believe that the smooth and harmonious development of relations, contacts and communications between FYROM and Greece, which should be ensured above all by the practical solutions of the Interlocutory Agreement, can sufficiently satisfy the criteria and conditions of good neighbourly relations, as is moreover required in view of the negotiations and conclusion of the Association Agreement.

. This is a sector where liberalization has shown its limits and serious shortcomings. I am not personally a narrow-minded activist for monopoly, whether public or private... but when I see the results of private companies in this area, I am comforted and strengthened in my position as a defender of public service! If liberalization continues, in this area too, there is a great risk of one day seeing entire regions not served by the post office. Who can indeed believe for a moment that private companies, whose only driving force is profit, would continue to serve high-cost areas unless they made already disadvantaged residents pay this cost, and who therefore would not be able to benefit from it. I would add that today, at a time when Europe is revealing itself and asserting itself as incapable of opposing the presence of fascists in a European Union government, it is no longer acceptable to see us impose an ultraliberalism that destroys public services, in the name of this same Europe. I am a European and even a federalist. To achieve this, I was ready, I am ready to make sacrifices... but not at any price! And above all, I am no longer ready to accept the construction of a single liberal market if Europe is not at the same time able to defend the values on which it was founded and which made me, since the 1960s, a convinced European! The President. Parliament has exhausted its agenda. The minutes of this sitting will be submitted to Parliament for adoption at the beginning of the next part-session.1 Adjournment of the session I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned. (The sitting adjourned at 11:10 a.m.) Resumption of the session I declare the session of the European Parliament, which was suspended on Friday, 18 February 2000, resumed. Statement by the President Dear colleagues, as you know, on 22 February, ETA struck again brutally in Spain with the assassination of Fernando Buesa Blanco, Secretary-General of the Socialist Party of Biscay and spokesperson for the Socialist Party in the Basque Parliament, and Jorge Díez Elorza, his bodyguard. On the same day, I expressed, on my own behalf and on behalf of our European Parliament, our deepest sympathy and sincere condolences to the victims' families. These men paid with their lives for their commitment to democracy. I strongly condemned this act of barbarity, unworthy of any civilised society. The rule of law and respect for fundamental rights and freedoms are the principles on which the European Union is founded. Terrorism, in whatever form it takes, is unacceptable. Hoping that these men will be the last victims of ETA, I call on the organization to put a definitive end to its use of violence and to use the democratic channels that exist in Spain. I invite you, dear colleagues, to observe a minute of silence in memory of Fernando Buesa Blanco and Jorge Díez Elorza.

Resolution on women in decision-making (B5-0180/2000) My group abstained on the resolution on women in decision-making, much to our regret. But it regrets even more that such resolutions are still necessary. In 1994, the Greens were the first group in this Parliament in which women formed a majority; they were the first to have a female Secretary-General, Dominique Voynet, now French Minister of the Environment; and the German Greens were the first political party to implement gender equality in order to correct the overall underrepresentation of women in political institutions. Since then, this initiative has been followed by certain parties, and it cannot be said that voters have risen up to condemn these parties for their actions. Nor have voters felt manipulated by such quotas. The resolution clearly states that the proportional system, which allows for the representation of women, is necessary and that political parties must act accordingly. We welcome this. We agree with those who argue that people should be selected on the basis of their merits; which is true. Our culture should allow for gender balance and people should be able to develop their talents whatever they may be, but at the moment, our culture and values do not reflect this belief. Prejudices, stereotypes, are widespread. It will come as no surprise that people from minorities, whether black, gay, disabled, etc., are subject to discrimination and unfair treatment if a majority group, women, must also suffer this discrimination. Our group therefore supports affirmative action; only when women are fairly represented in the decision-making process will men also be fairly represented. We should therefore also create a culture where your paid and unpaid work, your salary, your parental leave and your pension do not depend on your gender. As International Women's Day approaches, I wish to reaffirm my support for the action taken within the institutions and Member States to promote women's access to positions of responsibility, particularly in politics. This is why I will vote with conviction for the text of this resolution, which urges us to take more proactive measures to combat the discrimination that persists and prevents women from occupying their rightful place in our society! The promotion of women in the decision-making process has been one of the priority areas of the European Union's action programme on equal opportunities since 1995 and is part of the repeated commitments of both the Union's institutions and the Member States when they talk about gender equality. However, while progress has been made in recent years thanks to strategies such as mainstreaming and complementary measures such as positive action, it is too little to be satisfactory. The under-representation of women in politics, for example, continues to be a reality. However, we know the importance of seeing many women involved in politics.

This is terrible because the Windward Islands are one of the smallest and most vulnerable ACP countries and will be the ones that will have to pay the highest price for this new Lomé Convention. On the other hand, on the trade front, the WTO has pressured us to ensure that the new Lomé Convention is compatible with their interests, which has led to a huge push for so-called regional economic partnership agreements or free trade agreements. It is possible that the more developed ACP countries will be subject to great pressure to accept these agreements. However, it is very clear that, even after a period of adjustment, some countries will not be able to open their markets to the cold winds of free trade without their domestic economies collapsing. We therefore need to be especially careful to ensure that genuine options are being given to countries that are not yet ready for free trade agreements. We must ensure that strategies to promote regional integration within the ACP are genuinely being pursued. Finally, when any other trade summit is held, EU and ACP countries should jointly lobby for the reform of Article 24 of the GATT to explicitly provide for non-reciprocal regional trade agreements between groups of countries with structural and economic differences. The Lomé Convention is a unique partnership in the world; but for it to be truly effective, discussions within its context are not enough; we must also count on the collaboration of the WTO and participation in other international negotiation forums. Mr. President, in this debate, I would like to denounce the fate of those poor countries in Africa, the Caribbean, and the Pacific, which some dare to claim to be beneficiaries of the Lomé Convention. Even at the level of trade relations alone, the Lomé Convention has not in the least protected those countries whose already restricted share of trade with Europe has been halved. This reflects the growing inequalities between EU and ACP countries. The Lomé Convention primarily benefits a few large industrial or financial groups that continue to plunder these countries and perpetuate their economic dependence, particularly on the former colonial powers. As for the aid supposedly intended for development, it is obviously useless, as the underdevelopment of most of these countries deepens rather than diminishes, even if this aid does not constitute a disguised subsidy to European industrial exporters. This aid is above all a providential gift for the regimes in power, with no benefit to the poor majority of the population. Even if it were properly redirected, it would be insufficient to finance essential infrastructure for health, education, or drinking water supplies. For several years now, the major powers have been reducing the amount of this already paltry aid. The height of cynicism is that they sometimes do so under the pretext of disregard for human rights or corruption. But who protects these regimes that foster corruption, if not the governments of rich countries? In fact, we turn a blind eye to the main corruptors, those large oil, water supply or public works groups, against whom we could act with rigor since they have their headquarters here in Europe,

In three weeks, I will be in Paris and will continue, capital after capital, participating, from my position, in this dialogue. I consider it extraordinarily positive—and I wanted to thank you—that you have taken this initiative. Secondly, I would like to thank the Portuguese Presidency, and in particular Mr. Seixas da Costa, for your willingness. Furthermore, what you said earlier clearly expresses this willingness and interest: the Portuguese Presidency cannot be an intermediate Presidency. It is the one that will launch these negotiations. We know perfectly well that they cannot be concluded during these six months and that the baton will then be passed to the French Presidency, with the hope that they will be concluded before the end of 2000. And not just concluded, but also successful, which is not exactly the same thing. Concluding a negotiation is not the same as achieving success in it. The baton will be passed on, but the conditions under which you, Mr. President, and the Portuguese Presidency pass on that baton will be extraordinarily important, as will its nature. All the work that will be done together, particularly that promoted by you, during these months, is extraordinarily important. We have great confidence, great hopes, in the way the Portuguese Presidency, that of a small country—but one that will not cease to have, but must have, great ambitions—will successfully carry out this task. Having listened to Prime Minister Guterrez, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, and you, I have that confidence in the ambition of the Portuguese Presidency and in the very determined way it will guide these negotiations. In these months, you can count on the cooperation of the Commission. Finally, I repeat: we will have to make a great effort to popularize the issues of these negotiations. These are difficult issues. They are matters of politics and institutional mechanics that are not always easy to explain. All the more reason for MEPs, ministers, and Commissioners to devote a little time to explaining this to the public and to public debate. In this regard, the Commission will take initiatives, ladies and gentlemen, to launch and encourage this public debate. Provision of cross-border services The next item is the joint debate on the following reports: A5-0007/2000 by Mrs Berger, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council (COM(1999)3 - C4-0095/1999 - 1999/0012(COD)) on the conditions governing the posting of employees who are nationals of a third country in the framework of the cross-border provision of services. A5-0012/2000 by Mrs Berger, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, on the proposal for a Council directive (COM(1999)3 - C4-0096/1999 - 1999/0013(CNS)) extending the freedom to provide cross-border services to nationals of a third State established within the Community. Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I must apologize for my slightly strained voice, but as an Austrian Member, there has been a lot to say and say today.

The news of recent weeks about how modern technologies enable wiretapping makes us more careful: we do not want the dark scenarios described by Orwell to become an even more crude and worrying reality. Well, this is only the beginning of a great deal of work in the field of law, which must go hand in hand with the growth of the Europe we want. Mr President, for the benefit of Mr Schulz, I would like to point out that amendments by committees and political groups are admissible in Plenary, but not those by a single Member, in an individual capacity. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I fully understand the frustration of Mr Di Pietro, who had to carry out an enormous amount of work in a short space of time in order to present the report under consideration today. Crime in the European Union has increased so much that we cannot be satisfied with a gradual approach to the problem of mutual legal assistance in criminal matters. In this case, the European Parliament certainly cannot be blamed; Indeed, it is the governments of the Member States that have reduced the margin for manoeuvre to a minimum, thus forcing the European Parliament to face a kind of mission impossible. We must accept the idea that any means, however modest, must be used to improve the system of legal assistance. Paradoxically, I could say that it would be better to talk as little as possible about this report because, the more we make it clear that these are only small steps, the more criminals rub their hands and the more obvious the disproportion between their organisations and the serious shortcomings in cooperation between the judicial authorities become. I urge the Council of Ministers to face reality, taking into account in particular the imbalance between crime and the legislation in force. The aim is to provide the judicial authorities - especially the magistrates, but also the citizens concerned - with the tools to combat crime while respecting the fundamental guarantees of defence and the basic principles of human rights. Otherwise, our work would be completely useless. I also call for greater harmonisation of criminal law in the Member States. In my opinion, this is the only way to combat crime effectively and across borders. However, until such harmonisation has been achieved, the greatest possible coherence is needed to move forward with mutual legal assistance. To this end, I have tabled an amendment, according to which mutual legal assistance may only be granted if criminal proceedings are being carried out for acts which are punishable under the law in force in both the requesting party and the requested Member State. The content of the amendment which I tabled is also reiterated in Amendment No 43, which contains this cumulative requirement. This cumulative requirement is essential, since in my opinion the principle of legality "nulla poena sine lege" must be respected in criminal law. Consequently, any request for mutual legal assistance relating to an act which is supposedly not punishable in the requested Member State is contrary to this principle and therefore to the fundamental principles of the law of the requested Member State.

I hope that this time too Parliament's commitment will be as intense. Mr President, during the period of the last financial perspectives, 1994-1999, which included 13 Community initiatives, the cross-border programme INTERREG II proved to be an important initiative. The inclusion of the INTERREG initiative in the new round of the Structural Funds 2000-2006 is, in my view, a clear indication of how important this initiative is to the Member States of the European Union. INTERREG I, for the period 1989-1993, and INTERREG II, for the period 1994-1999, were a huge success in terms of bringing neighbouring Member States closer together in economic and social development.
