Indeed, one thing is clear: Europe has an incomparable potential for economic and social progress which, for reasons that are still partly beyond us, remains largely unexploited, hence the very interesting suggestions contained in the initial report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs to revive economic activity by setting ambitious targets (75% employment rate, resumption of growth, etc.) and by equipping itself with the means to achieve them! The initial proposals notably invited the Council to adopt measures aimed at ensuring full employment while remaining consistent with price stability and budgetary balance throughout the economic cycle. Indeed, this is not, as some would have us believe, a question of calling into question the stability policy adopted in recent years. Measures, particularly fiscal ones, encouraging private and public investment must be adopted. The trans-European networks programme as proposed in 1994 must be put back on track, and a vast research and development programme launched to give investments the necessary innovative content. How can it be considered that investment should not serve as an instrument for managing demand but be carried out on its own merits? We must promote better management of working time and the generalisation of good practice policies in the Member States in order to increase the degree of employability, particularly among the most disadvantaged sections of the working population. Certain measures such as requalification, in the form of lifelong training, are particularly relevant. They should be an integral part of the ongoing institutional transformation that must accompany the transition to a knowledge-based economy.

Secondly, there are Community directives, but they are not applied or are applied only to a limited extent because there are not enough national inspectors. This must be remedied urgently. A directive on maritime safety has been in preparation for many years, but progress is very slow. In this regard, there is unacceptable inflexibility and inaction on the part of the Commission. The deadline for presenting the Commission's communication on this crucial issue, which has been constantly postponed and is now set for July, must be brought forward. The basic provisions must be particularly clear and strict. Let me mention just three aspects that our group considers a priority. Firstly, the liability of cargo owners for oil cargoes must be clearly defined so that victims of pollution can invoke it unequivocally. The best precaution for the future is for charterers to be certain that they will face severe civil, criminal, and financial liability if they are not extremely vigilant with regard to the safety of the ships they choose to use. Secondly, the requirement that oil tankers authorized to operate in Community waters must have a double hull must be adopted as soon as possible and not postponed indefinitely. Thirdly, an age limit for ships authorized to operate in Community waters must be set immediately. This could be set at a maximum of 15 years. If it is not possible to adopt a sufficiently clear, strict, and consistent Community regulatory framework, Member States that wish to create their own framework of this kind should be entitled to do so in order to protect their populations and their territory, just as the United States learned the lessons of the Exxon Valdez disaster by requiring double hulls and barring all ships over 20 years old from entering its waters. This is why the United States banned the Erika from entering its waters. Had the Community done the same, a huge disaster would have been avoided. Let us truly learn the lessons this time, Mr. President, Commissioner, even if the emotions of the media and Parliament have subsided. Mr. President, Torrey Canyon, Olympic Bravery, Haven, Amoco Cadiz, Gino, Tanio—all these names evoke ominous memories. And now Erika. Which tanker is next? Twenty-one years after the Amoco Cadiz, this umpteenth oil spill, the seventh since 1967, demonstrates the irresponsibility of our respective governments. Once again, our west coast on the Atlantic is paying the high price for their inability to react, for their capitulation to the multinationals. It is difficult to understand why the French and Europeans allow what the Americans prohibit, and why Europe, which is usually so quick to act with environmental legislation, has ignored maritime safety. Now we have the result. The Erika, a Maltese-flagged ship, a floating wreck considered one of the most dangerous tankers, has contaminated more than 400 km of our coastline, a pollution far more severe than that caused by the Amoco Cadiz. As a member of parliament from the Loire-Atlantique region, I can unfortunately attest to this.

He has just lectured the Socialist Group because it is going back on a decision that was taken extremely clearly in the Conference of Presidents. However, he is doing the same thing. We discussed it, we were unanimous except for the EPP Group and the Liberal Group and I even pointed out, you will remember this, my dear fellow Presidents, that the question is not whether you are for or against the Tobin tax, but whether you dare to hear what the Commission and the Council think about it. That is not asking much. Therefore, I reiterate the proposal to maintain this oral question to the Commission and the Council to find out once and for all the position of these two bodies with regard to this relatively modest proposal, which would nevertheless send an important signal to public opinion, particularly after the emotion aroused by the failure of the Seattle conference. We are going to vote on the request of the EPP-ED Group to remove the oral question concerning the capital tax from the agenda. (Parliament rejects the request with 164 votes in favour, 166 against and 7 abstentions) Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Poettering for the publicity he has just given to this debate. Thank you. Madam President, has my vote been counted, as it could not be cast electronically because I do not have my card? I voted "for". Indeed, if we add the two colleagues who expressed their views, we get the following result: Madam President, the Chair has announced the result of the vote. There are no grounds for amendments. Madam President, during the last vote - and I defer to your decision on this matter - on the question of the Commission's strategic plan, I indicated that I was requesting the floor before the vote on behalf of my group. However, my request was not granted. I would be grateful, at the end of this agenda item, if you would allow me to provide an explanation of vote on behalf of my group. This is important. It would be useful to record in the Minutes of Parliament how people perceive what we have just done, in the light of their own political analysis. Madam President, I do not want to reopen the debate, but I had also asked for the floor to express my views on Mr Barón Crespo's request. You did not give me the floor either. I regret this, but the vote has been taken, the decision has been made, and we should therefore leave it at that. I am sorry, Mr Hänsch and Mr Cox, I did not see that you had asked for the floor. That being said, I believe the positions are quite clear and they will be recorded in the Minutes. When we adopt the minutes of today's meeting tomorrow, colleagues who feel that the positions have not been explained sufficiently well will be able to request amendments.

Mrs Palacio spoke at length on this issue, and I believe that, with a proposal for a directive on the maritime transport of dangerous goods, she has immediately initiated what is absolutely necessary today: the approach to European maritime law. In this regard, she will be able to see that France is prepared, during its Presidency, to work towards regulations that contribute to greater safety. But after the ecological shock, the economic shock, to which many Members have already referred, is becoming apparent. Shellfish farming, fishing, oyster farming, and fish farming are now seriously affected. In addition to the oil spill, storm damage has also been added to many areas. These industries have unfortunately suffered exceptional damage. They must, on the one hand, repair the damage and, on the other hand—perhaps even more difficult—regain customer confidence. Faced with this situation, the people of Brittany—in the Vendée and Charente departments—and forestry companies in other regions—are waiting for a sign from the European Union. We cannot simultaneously dedicate this legislative period to bringing people closer together and remain passive and lacking concrete responses in the face of disasters of this nature and magnitude. I listened with great attention to Commissioner Fischler's words, which are perhaps the most concrete we have heard to date. There have undoubtedly been numerous expressions of sympathy, solidarity, and announcements, but today it is time for the waiting to be followed by a concrete sign of European solidarity. The oil spill from the Erika shipwreck is just one in a long series of disasters in Community waters in recent years, including the oil spills from the Braer off Scotland and the Sea Empress off the Shetland Islands. These spills have not only caused irreparable ecological damage, they have also had devastating effects on local industries. The Erika wreck has caused serious damage to the local fishing and aquaculture sectors, and in addition to the damage visible today, the long-term consequences of oil pollution must not be ignored. There must be effective compensation. Community shipping safety rules must be tightened, controls must be tightened, and sailing under flags of convenience, which is also increasingly evident in the fishing sector, must be stopped. Shipowners and cargo owners bear responsibility and must be held accountable for their negligence. Existing compensation funds are inadequate, as was clearly demonstrated by the Braer accident, in which the Shetland fishing sector was not adequately compensated for its losses. We must learn from the past and ensure that the sectors damaged by the Erika oil spill can be rebuilt. Mr President, it is necessary that we revisit this disaster today, two and a half months after the Erika accident, because its dramatic consequences are far from over. Today, in conjunction with the organised victims, we must maintain the pressure to ensure that Total pays for all the damage caused by its unbridled pursuit of profit, while at the same time taking decisive action to prevent such disasters from happening again.

I am referring, for example, to the restructuring of the ABB-Alsthom Power company, where a large delegation of employees from all over Europe is in Strasbourg today. The management of ABB-Alsthom Power, which is the result of a merger carried out in June 1999, has already announced a restructuring with the prospect of job cuts in several countries. This disastrous employment situation raises numerous questions, particularly about the information provided to the European Works Council, which has existed since 1996. It calls for an update and strengthening of the Community directive on European Works Councils. It also calls for merger control that takes into account employment, the environment, and consumers. The report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs is insufficient from this perspective, which is why I abstained. By seeking to apply the principle of subsidiarity at the level of Community competition policy, the Commission delegates to national authorities and courts jurisdiction over decisions and abuses of dominant positions in relation to agreements between companies that create market distortions, although issues of corporate concentration and State aid remain under the notification regime. The position now adopted is aimed at creating more expeditious and less costly forms of competition policy enforcement, with Community law now being applied at the level of national courts rather than at the European Court of Justice, and there is even talk of the possibility of specialized courts. This partial renationalization of competition policy could entail greater costs for Member States. Furthermore, as the rapporteur points out, public monopolies have often been replaced by private monopolies in the name of competition policy, with the privatization of important public sectors and companies, as has occurred in Portugal, with negative consequences for the country and for its workers. (FR) The Commission's White Paper on the modernization of the rules implementing Articles 85 and 86 of the EC Treaty (new Articles 81 and 82) certainly does not propose a "renationalization" of competition policy, as some in the European Parliament fear. But it does, in any case, suggest some rather interesting possibilities for development for the European Union. Indeed, having noted the bottleneck in its services due to advance notifications of corporate agreements that could distort trade and fearing that their number will continue to grow with the arrival of new Member States, the Commission proposes the abolition of the prior authorization regime for these agreements and a more decentralized application of competition rules at the Member State level. The most remarkable thing, in my opinion, is the signal this proposal sends: the Commission anticipates the consequences of enlargement and understands that this necessarily and almost mechanically entails a reform of the centralized system. It is clear that, in this case, the reform consists of promoting flexibility, not dismantling it. On paper, the Commission is expected to retain central control and direction of the new system. Moreover, the von Wogau report, which the European Parliament has just approved, encourages it in this direction.

The European Union's water policy does not start from scratch. Numerous directives have been adopted, and the Commission is committed to making them more legible, more compatible with each other, and with clearer objectives. Thus, a desire for rationality has led to the formulation of this framework directive. But our Parliament, at first reading, insisted that the current directive not only be compatible with the commitments we have made—like OSPAR—but also allow us to reverse course. Despite these numerous directives, despite frequent declarations about the efforts that must be made to protect water, when we examine the state of the environment in Europe, we see that the objectives have not been achieved. In many cases, the situation has deteriorated, and therefore, we cannot be content with an effort to rationalize the texts. We must set objectives that match the imperatives we face, and we don't have much time. Because if we do so, as the Commission proposed, with excessively long deadlines, when the Commission and the Council have once again extended the deadlines, not only will we have a credibility problem with public opinion, but, in addition, efforts—as we know full well—will be left for tomorrow, and tomorrow they will be postponed again, and therefore the desired objectives will not be achieved. I insist on this point, because we shouldn't wait for the umpteenth time until catastrophes are reported every day in our newspapers to say: "Ah! Europe didn't act. Ah! Europe should have acted!" and then, in haste, pretend we are going to solve the problems we didn't want to tackle head-on in a timely manner. Today's example of the Danube, of the pollution occurring in Romania, shows very clearly that if we do not implement a new approach to economic development, clear requirements, controls, and precise measures regarding the state of our rivers, not only will these types of incidents be repeated—we know this—but they will also multiply over time. We also know that if we do nothing, the development of our agriculture will continue to be carried out with major imbalances. Already, the Breton rivers in my own country are in a state of eutrophication, which is damaging to tourism. I would simply like to conclude, Mr. President, by saying that the imperatives are clear at second reading. Do we want, yes or no, standards compatible with OSPAR, that is, approaching zero in the case of hazardous substances? Do we want to reduce the timeframes that the Council has proposed for this directive? Do we want a pricing policy that gives all public and private actors the ability to decontaminate, to act against pollution, and economize our water? Do we seriously want to respond to the aspirations of our people? Most of the amendments voted on by the Environment Committee respond to that objective; I hope they will gain the support of the House. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs. Lienemann has just forcefully explained the importance of water and air to us, especially as the simply essential foundation of human life.

In particular, as agreed in the Human Rights Council on 9 February 2000, the European Union intends to table motions for resolutions on the territories occupied by Israel, Iran, Iraq, Sudan, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Burma/Myanmar, a proposal for a Presidency statement on Colombia and, if possible, East Timor, as well as a proposal for a statement on the situation in the various countries. The European Union will continue the discussion on the preparation of the 56th session of the Commission on Human Rights at the next meeting of the Human Rights Working Party in March. In particular, the question of the possible presentation of a motion for a resolution on the death penalty will be discussed. The Working Party has so far failed to agree on the strategy to be used in addressing this issue and, in particular, on the wording of the commitment to be given as a last resort in response to any changes to the contrary, including Article 2(7) of the UN Charter, which refers to the question of sovereignty. An attempt was made to reach a preliminary consensus on a compromise text, given the difficulties that arose at the 1999 session of the Third Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, where the positions of the Member States diverged on an amendment introducing a reference to paragraph 7 of Article 2 in the draft resolution sponsored by the European Union on the death penalty. Last year, at the 55th session of the Commission on Human Rights, as is well known, the United States decided, at a very advanced stage, to table a draft resolution on China. This draft resolution was rejected on the basis of a Chinese motion for non-interference. The European Union voted against this motion. The position of the European Union on the attitude to be taken towards China in the Commission on Human Rights was reconfirmed by the General Affairs Council on 21 March 1999: no initiative by the European Union with regard to China, no support for a resolution on China, vote by the European Union against the motion of non-interference. It is not certain whether the cohesion of the European Union could have been maintained if the resolution had been put to the vote. The United States of America will present a motion for a resolution on China at the 56th session of the Commission on Human Rights and is pressuring the European Union to sign this motion. This has provoked strong reactions from China: the Chinese authorities are urging the countries and institutions of the European Union to refrain from supporting the initiative of the United States of America. The initiative is being discussed within the Union, but a decision is not expected in the near future. It is in the interest of the European Union to keep open, as far as possible and in any case until the end of the meeting to be held on 25 February 2000, all options in the dialogue between the European Union and China on human rights. In the light of the changes which have occurred in the composition of the Commission on Human Rights, it is expected that the outcome of the vote on the motion of non-interference will be very uncertain. It is therefore important that this year too the countries of the European Union reach a consensus on the position to be taken with regard to the possible vote on the resolution.

Perhaps Commissioner Kinnock could give us a preview this evening? Mr Van Hulten, my group of environmentalists and regionalists will shortly be supporting the attempts to further improve the report in the plenary session tomorrow afternoon. It makes no sense to repeat word for word the many valid recommendations of the Committee of Independent Experts. Therefore, if we vote against certain amendments or paragraphs tomorrow, it will certainly not be because we are against the content of the text. Our aim is to make your report easier to read. In any case, it must be clear that my group fully supports the recommendations of the Committee of Independent Experts. I am, however, looking forward to seeing the document adopted by the Commission today and the White Paper that will be published in February. However, I must tell you, Commissioner, that both the Wise Men's report and the Van Hulten report will become important points of reference for our group, enabling us to confirm or deny our confidence in the Prodi Commission. Allow me one final comment. We are calling for the new White Paper on the reform of the Commission to be given the same treatment as the one on food safety, which was published last week and made accessible to the public and which has set a concrete deadline. I believe this is a necessary step because public opinion is expecting a change. My group, in any case, is calling for real change to materialise by the end of 2002. Mr President, this report is certainly timely, but it is not enough on its own. Fraud, mismanagement and nepotism are not random phenomena. They are more likely to take hold where democratic control over finances is limited. A large part of the European budget is distributed through the Structural Funds. This only makes sense if it is based on solidarity, when rich countries help to create income and development in poorer countries. The funds thus distributed find their way back to the rich countries via Brussels. Municipalities and regional authorities consider these funds to be their property, but they can only regain possession of them by investing massive financial and human resources in lobbying and negotiation. With every misuse of European funds, and certainly after every fraud, the call for even stricter controls echoes. However, even the strictest controls cannot solve the problem. The only result would be an increase in bureaucracy and a reduced possibility for local democracies and citizens to influence and participate in the choices regarding the various projects and their implementation. It would be more appropriate for these funds to be transferred directly from national governments to local authorities without going through Brussels. In the coming years, we will have to think about the possibility of replacing the Structural Funds with an equalisation fund used exclusively to support the budgets of Member States or regions with low per capita income. This is perhaps the only way to contain fraud and administrative costs and to strengthen transparency and democracy.

A Europe that ensures social justice is a requirement that has lost none of its relevance, since achieving it means first and foremost placing the fight against mass unemployment and poverty at the centre of Union policy in a targeted manner. For these reasons, the realisation of this political vision also presupposes, in my opinion, the courage to amend Article 4 of the Treaty on European Union, which describes the European Union, according to a classical-neoliberal approach, as an open market economy with free competition. In this same political vision, an important role, in my opinion, belongs to Article 105 of the same Treaty, since the European Central Bank must finally receive the political mandate, provided for by the Treaty, to promote sustainable growth and employment through its monetary policy. Mr President, the Union for a Europe of the Nations Group believes that the agenda of the next Intergovernmental Conference must be respected as defined by the Helsinki Council, that is to say strictly focused on issues relating to the decision-making process of the enlarged Europe. This agenda must be respected precisely to ensure that, before enlargement, the work of the Conference is carried out effectively and rapidly. We cannot therefore associate ourselves with the opinion of the European Parliament, much less with that of the Commission, as they are aimed at excessively extending the agenda in a negative sense, that is to say in the sense of centralisation and the ever more tight closure of the European system. My group has therefore tabled a series of amendments which, put together piece by piece, form a genuine alternative resolution. We affirm that the next IGC must work towards a decision-making system that is more respectful of national sovereignty. We regret that the Commission, in its opinion of 26 January, persists in continuing in the usual direction towards a uniform Europe that extends to the East, a centralised superstate that functions by majority decisions. Federalists may believe that in this way unity can be created by force, but this idea is completely naive. On the contrary, in an enlarged Europe, Mr President, forced uniformity through the abusive use of majority decisions can only lead to explosion. Furthermore, the centralised European system, as it is developing and clearly taking shape, weakens the nations and thus undermines the national patriotism that is the vital centre of our will to defend ourselves. The Europe that emerges from this cannot be stronger, but only weaker, because it no longer recognises its own identity and the causes it defends. This is why we have always said that enlargement was only possible by clearly guaranteeing the diversity and freedom of the peoples that make up Europe, or by adopting a variable geometry based on respect for national sovereignty. We are pleased to see this idea progress in areas that fortunately still fall outside the competences of the European Parliament and the Commission. The Europe of variable geometry is the Europe that respects national democracies and is based on nations, on national patriotisms and does not persecute them. It is in this Europe that we will find the will to defend ourselves against external threats and not in the binding and overly complex decision-making procedures that the Commission intends to propose during the next Intergovernmental Conference.

And when one considers that a conference will soon be held in Moscow, the somewhat pathetic state of the European Union's presence in this process becomes evident. I would like to insist to the Portuguese Presidency that it must play a greater role, that it is time to take over and assume a greater presence of the European Union in this matter. I hope that the upcoming visit of the President of the European Parliament to the region, as well as that of the chairs of the corresponding interparliamentary delegations, will allow us to begin a phase of greater initiative and greater presence of the European Union in this complicated and difficult peace process. Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Commissioner Patten, I would like to express my congratulations on your presentations, especially to Commissioner Patten, whose analysis I fully share. Therefore, I will not repeat anything he has already said. I only want to make three observations that may be considered similarly by Commissioner Patten, but which, for various reasons, have not been able to be formulated as openly as some Members have done. First of all, I think we can welcome the agreements reached between Israel and the Palestinian National Authority. But we already have enough agreements: Oslo, Wye Plantation, Sharm el-Sheikh. Enough with the agreements; what we need to do now is fulfill them. I share my colleague Salafranca's skepticism when he says that this week there is bad news from Israel, since this latest agreement will not be fulfilled within the planned timeframe. The second point concerns the resumption of negotiations between Syria and Israel. I find this very encouraging news. But this week we learned that Mr. Barak will not be going to Washington, so the negotiations cannot continue. I want to state very clearly that if the Golan Heights are returned to Syria, the problem in that region will be resolved. Regarding the issue of the referendum, which several colleagues have mentioned, we must reconsider whether a referendum must always be held to fulfill the obligations arising from international law. In Germany, they would probably be very happy if it were announced that a referendum was going to be held on payments to the European Union and that those payments would depend on what the German people were willing to pay. It would be a similar situation. The third and final point: the role of the European Union. I would like to highlight the extraordinary role played by the special envoy to this region, Mr. Moratinos, as well as the funding we have provided there, Commissioner Patten. You know that you will always find support in this Parliament, also for your proposal. We will be present when funding is to be provided. But we must also play a political role, and this role cannot be played by Mr. Moratinos alone in this region. The Council Presidency must act here, and Mr. CFSP must travel to the region. And we, just as the Russians did, must invite the key players in the peace process. Then we will play the role that corresponds to our participation and contribution.

When it comes to safety, my group will always support initiatives that increase transport safety. As recent events have shown, we still have a lot to do on this issue. Madam President, I would like to make a few remarks. First, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his extraordinarily precise and technical work on this report, and second, I would like to thank the Commission for the proposal it has submitted. It concerns the harmonization of examination requirements, but we are actually talking about minimum requirements. This is a shame in a way. The importance of road, rail, and inland waterway transport safety is naturally very great, and given the international nature of transport, the training of safety advisers should be harmonized, as should, for example, the requirements for the future ADR. That is important, but so is monitoring, and there are, of course, several reasons why we must devote special attention to it. Look at the road accidents of recent years. For example, in Belgium, the Netherlands, and some other countries, trucks carrying dangerous goods continued en route due to fog when they should have stopped. Or ships from Eastern Europe docked next to other vessels, creating a highly dangerous situation. Furthermore, research conducted in ports in Belgium, Finland, and also Japan shows that 50% of containers with partially dangerous goods are not properly delivered. In other words, this is of great importance. When looking at the situation of safety advisors, we see that in some countries, companies have been required to have such advisors since January 1 of this year. This currently creates major control problems, especially for small companies, because they cannot afford it. They will either reject these goods or mix them with other goods, and this will cause certain problems. Therefore, an evaluation of these activities is being requested in the form of annual reports and company analyses, which could eventually be incorporated into ISO 9002 certifications. The rules are in place; now comes the control. Let me mention one last point. Regarding control, we must reach sound agreements with the Eastern European countries, because they will not participate in the treaties on this matter until 1 July 2001, or for a year and a half from now. This gives them a temporary competitive advantage. This is not serious in itself, but what we should especially do is prioritize safety aspects in the transport of goods by road, rail, and inland waterway and incorporate this part of the Community acquis as quickly as possible and present it to the candidate countries. Madam President, in this Parliament, attention is rightly regularly drawn to the importance of transport safety. The increasing quantities of goods passing through Europe entail risks of which we are aware, and sometimes unconscious, for personnel and for the social environment.

Mr. President, "The European Union's development cooperation is in a pitifully bad state." This was stated in a newspaper article published last week on the Union's development policy. This assessment is not new. Ever since we in Europe began engaging with development cooperation, its effectiveness and quality have been questioned. Hopes for improvement threaten to fade if the Commission continues to refuse to look in the mirror. Why was the critical report on the coherence of development policy not published? An important conclusion of this report concerned the inherent inconsistency of European policy. Especially in the areas of trade and agriculture, European policy is at odds with development policy. We are failing to make a serious contribution to the development of the least developed countries. This is due to the differing views on development cooperation in the individual countries of the Union. We must no longer view development and cooperation as an instrument of foreign relations; instead, they must be evaluated as an independent policy area. I advocate for a transparent, solidarity-based, and efficient development policy. As long as the European approach to development issues tends to be inefficient and wasteful, it is advisable to give the Member States a greater role. Finally, I would like to call on the Commission to forward the aforementioned document to the European Parliament as soon as possible so that we too can consider possible solutions constructively. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I consider this initiative to be appropriate and entirely sensible. As several colleagues have already pointed out, we repeatedly encounter situations in which there is a major contradiction between what we want to achieve with development and cooperation policies and what we undo with other sectoral policies that pursue opposing interests in the development of the same countries. We are not just talking about the concrete impact of our joint measures on tourism, the environment, agriculture, fisheries, and industry. We are talking more generally—and this is the worst of it—about the contradictions between our economic and trade policies and our defense policies. Ultimately, there are a whole series of contradictory situations. In my view, the contradictions are not quite as pronounced in the area of Community policies. However, they are more pronounced with regard to certain objectives and industries in some Member States. We must be aware of this. On the one hand, we often adopt resolutions on peace processes in other parts of the world, as recently happened in Indonesia, a blatant case. Then again, we find that some European countries have supplied them with weapons and military equipment. These, in my view, are the most serious contradictions in this entire area; they are more serious than those arising from a certain incompatibility between sectoral policies, which also exist. Of course, we know that even within a given country there are always contradictions between several policies. That is normal. At the level of the European Union, we must also be aware that there will be contradictions between individual Community policies, in this case in development policy. We must be aware that these contradictions exist and that we must reduce them as much as possible.

The European Union underlined its full support for the United Nations' efforts regarding the need for a tribunal to try former Khmer Rouge leaders. At the same time, we welcome the continued dialogue between the two parties. I am heartened by the optimism of Kofi Annan, Secretary-General of the United Nations, about the prospects for an agreement on the proposed tribunal. The Committee will continue to raise issues relating to the rule of law, democratic principles, and human rights with the Cambodian authorities through the EC-Cambodia Cooperation Agreement, which entered into force on November 1 of last year. It has been very useful to debate human rights twice in a couple of days. I hope we will have other opportunities, but I trust that in the coming years we will see fewer examples of their abuse. Thank you very much, Mr. Patten. The debate is closed. The vote will take place at 6:00 p.m. Environmental disaster in the waters of the Danube The next item is the joint debate on the following motions for resolutions: B5-0164/2000 by Mr Leinen, on behalf of the Group of the Party of European Socialists, B5-0167/2000 by Mr Maaten and Mr Thors, on behalf of the Liberal, Democrat and Reformist Group, B5-0168/2000 by Mr Oostlander and Mr Grossetête, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, B5-0173/2000 by Mr Papayannakis and Mr Sjöstedt, on behalf of the Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left, B5-0179/2000 by Mrs Schroedter and others, on behalf of the Greens/European Free Alliance Group, on the environmental catastrophe caused by the spill of cyanide from a Romanian gold mine into the waters of the Lapus, Somes, Tisza, and Danube rivers. Mr. President, this week we debated the Water Framework Directive. The catastrophe that has occurred in Romania demonstrates once again how seriously we need to take water protection. This catastrophe has brought to the fore several important issues that affect us as the European Union. We welcome the European Union's commitment to providing assistance in decontaminating rivers. It is equally important to raise environmental awareness, both in Romania and in Central and Eastern Europe in general. We are therefore pleased that Commissioner Wallström has rushed to visit the region, as her visit can contribute to raising that awareness. After all, this is a candidate country for accession, and this catastrophe adds to the existing concern about whether all candidate countries will be able to assimilate EU environmental regulations in time. Polluters must pay. I wonder if the European Union can pass this kind of cost on to the environmental "cowboys" demonstrating in the so-called "Wild East," benefiting from those countries' lax environmental legislation. I would be in favor of that option. Mr. President, Commissioner, not every day is the same, but ecological disasters, unfortunately, are all the same. There is reason to be troubled, once again, by this serious pollution that is currently affecting Europe's fourth-largest wetland. The Danube Delta is in danger.

Likewise, we must continue to provide our assistance for economic reforms and social development in Lebanon as a whole. A solution must be found to the problem of the Palestinian refugees. This is the largest refugee group in the world, numbering almost five million, a sign of the formidable challenges we face. We must promote initiatives that increase the availability and improve the distribution and management of the region's very scarce water resources. Finally, although this is perhaps a matter of fundamental importance, we are promoting closer regional cooperation in various areas, bringing together all the countries concerned in a common effort to address common problems. It has already become clear that the financial resources currently available for Community aid to this part of the world will not be sufficient to meet the amount of aid that will be required in the event of permanent peace. I wish to emphasize this point. I wish to remind the Council again, and, if necessary, Parliament, that we must not continue to allow a gap to develop between our rhetoric and what we are actually capable of doing. I repeat that a change in Middle East policy will require a change of pace in the support we are asked and expected to provide. I wish to add that we will want to provide it. In recent months and weeks, we have made progress, as Mr. Gama has pointed out earlier. But, inevitably, it will be a difficult process marked by difficulties and disappointments. We will do everything possible to contribute to bringing the process to a successful conclusion and to meet the obligations and challenges that will arise from such an outcome. Finally, I will repeat for those who have entered the room in the last few minutes what I said at the beginning of my speech: that I will not be able to remain here until the end of the debate, largely because I assumed the debate would take place this morning, as I have scheduled a meeting on the Balkans for this afternoon. I hope for Parliament's understanding. Mr. President, Commissioner Patten has our understanding. I would like to tell you that communications with Madrid are usually more fluid, and I therefore hope to see you there soon. The statements we have heard throughout the day on the Middle East peace process are very timely given the busy tour that the Minister, Mr. Gama—I also regret his absence from the debate—made in the region, accompanied by other Council representatives. The tone of the media reports on the latest developments in the region could lead us to form a pessimistic view of the situation. I honestly believe that such an assessment would not reflect the reality of the facts. In this regard, I share Commissioner Patten's positive outlook. Let me explain: it is true that the Israeli government has postponed the third transfer of the West Bank to the Palestinian Authority.

The Commission's communication recommends a greater exchange of experiences, as well as the establishment of a high-level group and benchmarking. Furthermore, the social protection report should be published annually and examined at the same time as the employment report. This is good, but it is not enough. We are proposing a procedure similar to the Luxembourg process. Clear guidelines and indicators are needed, while Member States must develop methods in national action plans. We are shaping a common model, but maintaining subsidiarity. This social convergence is a process that will continue for a long time. Therefore, Parliament must be involved in the work—not by joining the high-level group, but in such a way that Parliament's representative can monitor the work in this group and come up with proposals on how to continue the process. The Commission's proposal, like cooperation on employment, is based on four main objectives. These are: making the system job-friendly, making the pension system sustainable in the long term, promoting social integration, and ensuring sustainable and high-level health protection. All these points are important. In our report, we particularly emphasized the importance of combating poverty in the EU and of finding indicators as quickly as possible in order to make progress in this area. Equality between men and women does not have its own pillar. This is about mainstreaming. Aspects of equality between men and women must therefore be reflected in all four pillars. We have taken careful note of this. We are tabling a multitude of proposals to, for example, move towards individualized social protection systems, ensure that parental leave entitles people to social security benefits, improve opportunities for reconciling family and professional life, and ensure that basic old-age pensions ensure a decent standard of living. These proposals primarily benefit women. Alongside this European social convergence strategy, a concrete plan is needed for legislative work in the social field, as well as proposals for a framework agreement in the context of social dialogue with a concrete timetable. We expect Parliament to present this in its proposal for a social action programme. Social convergence is also necessary in view of enlargement, on the one hand to strengthen the social model and, on the other, to eliminate the risks of social dumping. The Commission must consider drawing up a specific action programme relating to social policy in the context of enlargement. We had a constructive discussion in committee. We had many amendments, but we managed to agree on a report. The number of amendments submitted to Parliament for a vote has now been reduced to fifteen. This is because we have significant convergence. Some of these amendments are returning from the reading to the committee, and I will reject them. I will also reject the amendments tabled by the TDI group, as I do not believe that they add anything to the report.

This is where the decisive point must be made. I am convinced, esteemed Presidency, that this will be shaped accordingly positively under your leadership. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, you will have gathered from the various statements that both in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and at the level of the group leaders in the European Parliament, the prevailing opinion, albeit not unanimous, was to trust the Portuguese Presidency and not to exacerbate the difficulties by postponing the start of the Intergovernmental Conference. I can assure you that last week in the committee I chair, it was not easy to reach this conclusion, but in the end we decided to bet on the Portuguese Presidency, and we do not want to lose our bet. You told us about the start of your tour of European capitals and the difficulties some governments are having in gaining support in their countries and, consequently, in their parliaments. I would like to draw your attention to what I consider a very interesting day of discussion and dialogue yesterday with representatives of the 15 national parliaments, who were present with knowledgeable and committed delegations. The aim was not to draw conclusions—which was not possible—but the debate was certainly very encouraging. I believe we must be vigilant and ensure that national governments seek to persuade their parliaments to ratify solutions that meet the needs of the Union's development, and not hide behind perceived parliamentary resistance in order to avoid signing the relevant decisions at the negotiating table of the Intergovernmental Conference. In any case, we will intensify our cooperation and dialogue with the governments of the Member States throughout the Intergovernmental Conference. Yesterday, we also discussed the Commission, represented by Commissioner Barnier, who explained its position. Their efforts were appreciated, although different views were expressed on the proposals, just as I believe you, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, expressed different points of view. It should be emphasized, however, that yesterday, too, many people were aware of the danger that enlargement could call into question the original concept of establishing a political union. This was also pointed out in an interview that, due to the authority of its author, Jacques Delors, will surely have escaped no one's notice. We must therefore ensure that, during the Intergovernmental Conference, there is genuine discussion about how to strengthen the democratic foundations of the Union, how – and this was also discussed yesterday in this House when the situation in Austria was discussed – the system of principles, values, and rights that underpins the Union, and the role of the Union's political institutions, including in the area of economic policy. We are relying on the Portuguese Presidency, we are relying on ourselves and on the Commission, so that all these issues can be debated constructively and coherently within the framework of the Intergovernmental Conference. Mr President, Only a strengthened Europe can manage enlargement. Only a strengthened Europe can counter political opportunists who exploit discontent. Therefore, fundamental reforms and, consequently, an expanded agenda for the Intergovernmental Conference are needed. The Finnish Presidency has listened only to minimalist governments and, unfortunately, has not shown itself in the least bit receptive to this Parliament.

We have all heard some of the stories coming from the Council of Ministers building in Brussels. I am also unclear about the extent to which we will achieve any form of convergence on defense spending, as some Member States spend considerably more than others. And, in fact, some Member States are not oriented toward mobility. They are very static in their military forces and unsuited for that kind of warfare. Perhaps I could turn to Mr. Patten as well and ask him, from the point of view of the conflict prevention work we will be doing, to what extent we will be able to examine long-term conflict-causing situations, such as environmental degradation and water scarcity, and include them in core EU policies, particularly in the area of development, because it is pointless to try to react quickly to something that has taken us years to prepare. And finally, let me also echo Mrs. Schroedter's remarks, to the effect that we need a parliamentary dimension to this defense development. We cannot simply leave it to governments. When Mr. Solana last spoke in this Parliament, I was extremely critical of the fact that he barely mentioned the idea of conflict prevention, and today there is much talk here about such prevention, but no proposal to seriously implement it. We talk a lot and with pride about how a contingent of 60,000 soldiers can be prepared in 60 days for a whole year, but we currently have crises in Europe and on its borders and elsewhere that this Union is failing to address, which is abject. What we need are 60,000 civilian police to try to address these situations. Mr. Solana has given us no information about the means that will be used in relation to Russia and Chechnya. Mr. Solana has told us nothing about whether he or the European Union is making any serious diplomatic intervention—serious diplomatic interventions—to stop the carnage in Chechnya. We have significant gaps in our fundamental defense of human rights. We mustered up our capacity to intervene in Kosovo, and now we are creating absolute chaos in that province by not sending adequate resources and personnel to address the situation, thereby demonstrating our inability to meaningfully address conflict prevention. Therefore, I would like Mr. Solana to explain to this House the European Union's position on Chechnya. What are we seriously going to do to put an end to this appalling situation? We have levers we could use with Russia, if we so chose, but we are determined not to. Mr. President, Mr. High Representative, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to ask you two questions, Mr. Solana. How can you, with any credibility, continue to deepen military and defense collaboration if the Member States are unwilling to fulfill their shared commitments?

However, it would be more appropriate for the Union to concentrate its financial expenditure on existing Community policies. Some are naturally taking the opportunity to outdo each other in demanding more financial resources, which is particularly inappropriate at a time when national budgets are being forced to undergo a drastic reduction due to the convergence criteria for EMU. Mrs. McCarthy, for example, proposes increasing the budget for URBAN and publicizing this Community initiative through an expensive public relations campaign extolling the benefits of a federal Europe. It should go without saying that the effectiveness of an expenditure does not depend on the amount of money allocated to a project. On the contrary, recipients of excessive and excessive subsidies will ultimately accept them as a given. The aim must not be to turn citizens into beneficiaries of aid, but to strengthen their autonomy. The report also makes a strong case for measures in favor of ethnic or sociological minorities. We can only reject a minority policy that is necessarily detrimental to social cohesion. On the one hand, it promotes the integration of immigrants, whereas their cultural assimilation in the host country is necessary to avoid the creation of ethnic ghettos that could become powder kegs. On the other hand, it tampers with the principle of positive discrimination, which, as the American precedent shows, is proving to be an equally harmful chimera. For all these reasons, the French delegation of the UEN Group could not vote in favour of Mrs McCarthy's report. Decourrière report (A5-0028/2000) Mr President, the INTERREG programme is particularly dear to our hearts. Like many other Members, I am delighted that the European Parliament has succeeded in preserving this INTERREG initiative. As I myself live in the Belgian part of the Sarre-Lor-Lux South region, I know that Europe is being built there, that we experience Europe every day, and that the process of European integration is truly being driven by the people. These projects must be genuinely considered and must already incorporate sustainable development. Why do I emphasize this point? For the simple reason that current projects, by their very nature, still all too often harm the environment. If, for example, one accepts new roads, then one accepts new emissions in the European Union, and this completely contradicts the policy we propose, for example, to combat greenhouse gas emissions. I also demand that the Commission, when selecting projects, ensure that the environmental pillar of EU policy is integrated into these projects, so that, for example, the objective of CO2 reduction is considered a specific added value in the proposed projects. I am thinking in particular of certain infrastructure projects currently being planned. As is well known, some Member States have not yet decided between rail and road for crossing vulnerable areas such as the Pyrenees, and in particular the Aspe Valley. I am also thinking of my region, where my Member State is still undecided between a railway line and a second motorway, the A32. I therefore call on the Commission to pay particular attention here too to ensuring genuine consistency between the various policies, and particularly within the selected INTERREG projects. Mr President, I voted in favor of the Decourrière report on the INTERREG Community Initiative, particularly because of Commissioner Barnier's response to some Members who called for greater consideration of maritime border regions in the programme.

I hope that all these problems can be addressed and dealt with within the framework of the discussion currently taking place on the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Externally, I believe that most of the points we have included in the resolution provide a fairly approximate view of reality and do not exactly inspire optimism, Mr. President, since aspects such as the abolition of the death penalty, the torture still practiced in many so-called democratic countries, or the situation of minorities in many parts of the world require a clear, visible, and effective response from the European Union. In my opinion, this resolution contains a series of essential points, but I would focus on one very specific one, which is the need for greater coordination between the European Union and the United Nations. Mr. President, in a world like today's, increasingly dominated by the phenomenon of globalization, and not only in the economic sphere, we must provide concerted and coordinated responses for these responses to be effective. To achieve this effectiveness in our action, it is necessary to implement a practical coordination that does not exist today. Therefore, this Parliament defends the principle of the need to participate in the Committee on Human Rights and other international forums where these matters are addressed, and, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, this Parliament would like to be able to participate in these types of meetings as soon as possible. Soon, in May, the European Commission plans to present a communication on the development of the role of human rights and democratization in the Union's external relations. I would like to take this opportunity to ask the Commission to take full account of this need for coordination I have just mentioned and to seek new ways to strengthen the role played by the European Union in the field of human rights, and in particular by this Parliament, especially from a perspective of coherence, recognizing the willingness of those third countries that agree to include the democracy clause. I believe that this should have an impact on all matters—and I am referring very specifically to the budgetary effect as well. Finally, I would like to acknowledge the important contributions that civil society can make in this field, as well as the often undervalued role of the many non-governmental organizations operating on the ground. The Union must strive to provide them with all the necessary support so that they can carry out their important work. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, when this House must discuss the issue of human rights, it runs a grave risk, which, if you will, is exacerbated by the climate in which we must debate this very important topic. The absence of the Council and of almost all the Members of Parliament shows us how wide the gap remains between noble, important, and useful declarations, from a formal point of view, and the concrete application of the issue of human rights in the realm of everyday politics. I believe that this Parliament, starting with the contribution that the European Union will make to the Geneva meeting, must fill this gap and contribute not only in terms of the enunciation of principles, but also in terms of truth and even loyalty.

All this was conditioned by the adoption of a budget which imposed limitations in various areas, and in particular by the need to allocate funds for the implementation of the special plan for the reconstruction of Kosovo. Parliament already approved a total of 34 amendments at first reading and the Council, in its common position, took up 18 of them in full or in part. Of the 16 remaining, some, such as amendments Nos 5 and 6 in particular, are now superfluous after the Interinstitutional Agreement on the budget for 2000. The discussion and negotiations which we held with the Council and the Commission centred on three issues: the budget, the timetable and comitology. Your rapporteur would particularly like to emphasise the commitment and flexibility shown by all to bring the budgetary positions closer together so that from an initial allocation of EUR 9 million for line B7-6201, which meant a total of EUR 73 million for the whole period, we have reached an agreement providing for EUR 249 million for the next seven years, starting from the EUR 30 million already foreseen in the budget for 2000. Following this budgetary agreement - which implicitly includes an agreement on the timing - the differences have coalesced around issues of comitology due to historical positions of Parliament and the Council which, with a view to the future - and without dwelling on the problems indicated by Mr Wijkman - should in my opinion be reviewed by an interinstitutional agreement to make the parliamentary legislative procedure more agile and fluid. I conclude by recommending that the House accept amendments Nos 1 and 2. 1, 7, 9, 10, 11 and 12 and the rejection of the others because, if they were to be accepted, they would cancel the agreement reached after the discussions with the Commission and the Council and would force us to start the whole negotiation procedure again, paralysing certain projects and actions to be carried out, and undoubtedly causing serious problems for the policy of conservation and restoration of tropical forests that we want to develop. Mr President, I think that the rapporteur, Mr Fernandez Martín, who spoke before me, is right on many points in his report. First of all, for all the budget lines it is very important to talk about their respective financial allocations. Just as for the report we have just discussed, I am not satisfied with the limited duration, but, in view of the very many projects at risk, this argument is excellent for aiming for an agreement with the Council as quickly as possible. As with the Wijkman report, I am in favour of the split comitology proposed by the rapporteur, i.e. dealing with the strategic lines using a management procedure and the measures concerning the implementation of the projects in an advisory committee. One point which I consider particularly important is the emphasis placed in several amendments - for example in Amendment No 2 and Amendment No 4 - on the active participation of forest-dependent people and local communities. This is, in my opinion, a very essential point, especially in the context of sustainable management of tropical forests and other forests in developing countries.

If this certificate and proof of insurance are not presented, the ship will be decommissioned and will not be allowed to leave the port, despite all port fees. We must agree on this in all ports of the European Union, from Marseille to Rotterdam, Wilhelmshaven, Cuxhaven, and wherever ships dock. Fourth, we need liability from the shipowner—not just a paltry $12 million, but at least $400 million, which the shipowner must prove with proof of insurance. Then we need liability from the country whose flag the ship flies. We need the assurance that the country under whose flag the ship sails will assume liability in case of doubt. This will be a wonderful control measure! I can guarantee you that the countries that issue the flag will then ensure that they are not held liable. Fifth, we need a guarantee that this will be required of all ships in the ports and waters of the European Union, including in the accession countries. This means that the requirements I have mentioned apply to all waters. Finally, we need the most important thing: we need a good memory, because we will be talking more often about legislation here in the near future. We will be talking more often about environmental standards. Then I don't want anyone to come along and say: These requirements will lead to job losses in the port. The unions will come, the industry will come. We need a good memory, colleagues. I'm looking at many of you who have not previously represented the leading edge of the environmental movement. Go home and say: We haven't bothered about the standards so far. We need a good memory when it comes to what is required in the ports. We need a good memory when we say: Let's agree on port fees and port requirements, and not play one off against the other in the European Union. If we can achieve that, we might be better off in a few years! Mr. President! Ms. Roth-Behrendt spoke from my heart. She provided us with a perfect compilation of the various measures. But how do we use the crisis awareness we have developed as a result of this environmental disaster? Let me cite as a comparison the introduction of the load line mark of a previous generation, a marking intended to prevent insurance fraud involving conditionally seaworthy ships. Where has the crisis awareness of the generations before us gone? I think we should introduce the certificate Ms. Roth-Behrendt mentioned, as well as the marking of tankers with green marks, as suggested by some ports in Europe. Furthermore, the classification societies must be critically examined, because we cannot accept their practices. We need an independent and transparent process. Finally, I would like to mention that some Commission departments consider it to be improper shipyard subsidies in my country when environmental subsidies are paid to shipowners who want to improve environmental quality. In other words, the right hand at the Commission doesn't know what the left hand is doing. It is unacceptable that measures that are in line with the Commission's environmental improvement guidelines should not be allowed to be implemented because they are considered to be inadmissible support for shipyards.

They alone are capable of inventing policies capable of changing structures that were developed by men for men. Because it is structural discrimination that women are most confronted with, whether in politics or on the job market. It is therefore up to European political parties to open up to women. Moreover, Article 191 of the Treaty (ex 138 A) underlines, and I quote, their "important role as a factor of integration within the Union." This article goes on to state that "they contribute to the formation of a European consciousness and identity, as well as to the expression of the political will of the citizens of the Union." While such a provision has no legal value, it is nonetheless highly symbolic. It gives political parties an important role in the construction of a democratic Europe. This can be achieved, for example, by implementing positive actions, by promoting parity within our political parties. Some parties presented gender-balanced lists for the 1999 European elections. This is a good practice that should be made more widespread. I don't know if there is a causal link, but the fact remains that the proportion of women MEPs in the European Parliament rose from 25.7% in 1994 to 29.9% in 1999. Furthermore, it has been chaired by a woman since the 1999 elections. I will conclude by repeating the conclusions drawn from the April 1999 conference organized by the Commission, entitled "Women and Men in Power." Equality between men and women is not an issue that concerns only women; it is an issue that affects our entire society! Progress has recently been made in increasing the number of women in the Union's decision-making bodies. In our own institution, 30% of elected representatives are now women, including the President of the European Parliament herself. Finland has also just elected a woman president. On average, almost a quarter of Member State governments and just over a fifth of their parliaments are composed of women. These rates are still far from satisfactory, especially given that the figures vary greatly between Member States: women in the Nordic countries are far more represented in positions of responsibility and decision-making processes. This situation is more a reflection of respect for the quality and competence of women's contribution to society than the result of fixed quotas. My group does not support the use of quotas in general because, in the long run, they risk being counterproductive or even undermining the cause they are intended to support. We nevertheless recognize that experiences vary from one Member State to another and that some recourse to such measures is sometimes justified, as a temporary remedy, with a view to rebalancing the representation of women where they are clearly underrepresented. We could support the resolution on women in decision-making, adopted to commemorate International Women's Day on 8 March, to which the Liberal Group tabled ten amendments and relaxed the reference to quotas in line with the approach put forward above.

The Balkan and Adriatic regions are particularly important, but in my opinion, cooperation with Russia should not be forgotten either. Our group wishes to raise the issue of monitoring the use of funds again and insists, in particular, on better coordination of the TACIS, ISPA, and PHARE programs. This coordination is lacking, and the Commission has still not presented any specific plans to improve it. Here in Parliament, we expect the European Commission to inform our committee in more detail as soon as possible. In practical implementation, the involvement of businesses, organizations, and other local stakeholders is of decisive importance. Cooperation projects, based on experience, require better planning, more precise monitoring, and more successful implementation. Projects have often been left halfway, and efficiency has been lost in administration and bureaucracy. We must also demand commitment from the partners to the projects and to fulfill their part. Our group is reintroducing several amendments that were rejected during the committee's examination. I will again refer to the Urban report, in whose explanatory memorandum the rapporteur commendably addressed the minimum of EUR 500 per capita, which refers to the Commission's guidelines. This will not work as a mechanical objective, but it must be possible to apply it depending on the circumstances prevailing in the region concerned. This is such an important aspect that it must be deferred from the explanatory memorandum to the conclusions. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Interreg is the initiative with the most European dimension of all the structural funds. Here, projects must not only be promoted at regional or national level, but also in border regions that involve two or more countries. Unfortunately, this only applies to part of the money, namely to the borders within the EU. But it is precisely the regions bordering third countries that require an effective instrument promoting cross-border cooperation. The regulation claims that this is the case. However, it is not. We are in a situation where the Commission has not amended the regulation for years, although Parliament has long demanded it. In concrete terms, this will mean a further deterioration in the situation for these regions in terms of support for border areas. Parliament has been demanding the creation of a common fund for cooperation with third countries since 1996 in order to eliminate these difficulties. Nothing has happened! These problems will once again drag on, at the expense of the regions concerned. Therefore, Parliament is once again demanding an improvement in this regard and the development of cross-border cooperation. We are also waiting for a common fund to be created and for the regulation to be amended again in collaboration with the other Commissioners. We want a Europe of citizens, not a Europe of bureaucrats! Mr President, a third of the European Union's resources go to funds for various development objectives.

In the case of Turkey, the situation is different: the plant does not yet exist and, as I have already said, Turkey has acceded to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and the Convention on Nuclear Safety. If, during the development of the nuclear plant, there are safety concerns, we will discuss them with Turkey. If we were to conclude that Turkey is planning a nuclear power plant that is incompatible with European safety standards, we would act as we did with Lithuania, Slovakia and Bulgaria. I believe that it is the right of a Member of Parliament to express his or her concerns or fears. I do not share these concerns. I believe that Turkey fully recognises the standards and criteria of the Convention on Nuclear Safety and the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, but there is no doubt that European public opinion has some concerns and I think it is only right to discuss them in this Parliament. Question No. 29, by the Honourable Member (H-0786/99): Subject: Weapons containing depleted uranium Has the Commission carried out any studies on the effects that cross-border pollution resulting from the use of weapons containing depleted uranium during the Kosovo conflict could have on EU Member States? If not, why not? Commissioner Wallström has the floor on behalf of the Commission. Thank you, Mr Bowe, for your question. The European Commission has been studying the effects of the conflict on the environment since the first NATO actions. Back in June, the Commission funded the first study carried out by the Regional Environmental Centre for Central and Eastern Europe and concluded that no large-scale ecological disaster had occurred. None of the evidence gathered since then or any subsequent analysis has contradicted that first assessment. The Commission was also closely involved in the preparation of the recent report published by the United Nations Environment Programme - Balkan Task Force. This is the most detailed and comprehensive report yet on the environmental consequences of the Kosovo conflict and I recommend it to anyone who has not read it. The use of depleted uranium weapons is one of several issues addressed and the report is also available online. The Balkan Task Force has been hampered by a lack or paucity of information about the actual use of such weapons during the conflict. The Balkan Task Force's fact-finding mission in Kosovo did not find any signs of contamination. However, this does not rule out the possibility that certain areas of Kosovo may have been contaminated with depleted uranium. Based on the theoretical assessment coupled with the on-site fact-finding mission the report concludes that any risks, if any, would be limited to the area surrounding the target. The Stability Pact for South Eastern Europe provides for further initiatives and a special regional environmental clean-up plan is being developed which will provide the framework for emergency assistance in the event of conflict damage, should such assistance become necessary. Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Commissioner for the very helpful answer she gave me.

We have not heard that, beyond the proclaimed and positive objective of eradicating child poverty, individual autonomy would be strengthened by establishing decent minimum incomes in each Member State, which would be part of a genuine strategy to combat exclusion. We have not heard that the objective of full employment would include support for local and regional initiatives, the hidden sector of the solidarity economy, the effective and coordinated reduction of working hours, and would be accompanied by strict requirements regarding the quality and durability of these jobs. We have not heard that the long-awaited growth would be based on choosing sustainable development. We do not find in the Portuguese Presidency document or in the Commission's 2000 Strategic Guidelines the slightest trace of the legislative project in the social area, to strengthen the protection of workers against dismissal or to combat social dumping. Of course, we cannot but express our solidarity with the concern of the Council and the Commission to finally provide the European Community, after the single market, after the euro, with a political project proposed to all its residents. However, the new governance you are using, abusively in my view, lacks the participatory democratic ambition to which the emerging European civil society aspires. Madam President, Mr. Prime Minister and President of the Council, the situation in the Union and in most of the Member States raises legitimate concerns, despite the current economic recovery. The unemployment rate remains at quite high levels, long-term unemployment is constantly worsening, and employment levels are extraordinarily low. These factors are also accompanied and aggravated by the increasing precariousness of employment and which, in reality, reflect a social situation that particularly affects women and young people and is dramatically marked by the nearly 50 million people who are excluded. On the eve of the Extraordinary Council meeting dedicated to these problems, the fundamental question that arises, therefore, is whether or not there is political will to change this situation. Or, on the contrary, if we are merely facing yet another inconsequential initiative, added to successive plans, strategies, and summits already dedicated to this issue in the past, from which no fundamental change has resulted. In our opinion, it is not only necessary to change this state of affairs, but it is also possible to do so. Necessary because employment, and quality employment with rights, constitutes a fundamental human right. Possible, if its true causes are addressed, which, in our opinion, are inseparable from the neoliberal drift that has characterized the fundamental orientations, particularly in the macroeconomic sphere, which has exponents in the priority given to the Stability Pact and the criteria of nominal convergence and, consequently, in the secondary nature of social cohesion, generally accompanied by the complete deregulation of labor, the incentive to privatization, mergers and company relocations, generally causing unemployment, but also by a deeply restrictive budgetary policy at the Community and national levels.

We want to see uniform rules for shipping at European Union level, covering all its technical, economic, social, and environmental aspects. The dangerous practices of flags of convenience must be banned without exception in the ports and waters of the 15 Member States and the 13 candidate countries. Furthermore, together with the Union for the Development of the Sea, we advocate the creation of coastguards and the deployment of maritime inspectors under the direct supervision of the shipping areas affected, to ensure strict compliance with European legislation. The resolution adopted points in this direction and has therefore received the full support of our group. I am pleased that the resolution on the impact of the Erika oil spill, to the drafting of which our group made a significant contribution, was adopted virtually unanimously. Unlike our previous resolution, it takes more account of the scale of the disaster, which is proving every day to be greater than initial impressions would suggest, and is therefore more ambitious, precise, and urgent. It is currently almost impossible to assess the overall damage caused to all sectors of fishing, seafood, and aquaculture. What is certain, however, is that it is considerable. The balance is exacerbated daily by new pollution incidents. The losses are reflected not only in reduced sales, but also in financial losses. The damage to the reputation of seafood cannot yet be expressed in figures. Added to this are the damage caused to upstream and downstream sectors (fish wholesalers, suppliers, tourism, etc.), as well as the costs incurred by local authorities in cleaning up the pollution and repositioning themselves in the tourism sector. Fishing and tourism, the two closely interrelated main sources of income for most regions of our Atlantic coast, are thus both severely affected. It is therefore necessary, as we did in our resolution, to emphatically emphasize the polluter pays principle, supplemented by the polluter's obligation to remedy the damage. It is the polluter's duty to pay for the clean-up of the areas polluted through their fault and for the restoration of the ecological balance disturbed by their fault. The victims are deeply concerned about the compensation process, as the initial payments made by FIPOL to victims are limited to 25%. This is scandalous. Every victim must, of course, be fully compensated. It would be absolutely unthinkable to burden victims with part of the damage caused solely by the polluter's negligence. Furthermore, our resolution welcomes the initiatives taken by some local authorities, such as the Vendée department, to record the precise state of the coast before the first oil slick hit. This process is exemplary because it allows for accelerated compensation for victims, whether individuals or local authorities.
