Finally, our resolution makes it clear that in the area of maritime safety, it is essential to put an end to the vicious circle of generalized irresponsibility, this absurd system of mutual paralysis in which states and the Union shift responsibility to the benefit of those who cause the damage. Each must fulfill its respective responsibilities. The Commission, whose American reflex failed to materialize this time, must urgently develop a general framework for maritime safety.

We know that this waste exists and how we must deal with it, and there is no excuse for inaction. This directive pursues three objectives. First, we want to limit the use of toxic heavy metals in the manufacture of new cars. Second, we want to establish the responsibility of manufacturers. We can no longer concern ourselves with products at the end of their life cycle; we must focus on waste prevention. As many of the various materials contained in the product as possible must be recovered. Third, we want to achieve the recycling targets specified in this directive. These are the three main intentions of the directive. Not recycling the material present in cars is a waste of resources. Above all, not addressing a car's life cycle is a wasteful use of the manufacturer's resources. Two very important questions have been raised here—there are others, of course, but I would like to mention the two most important ones. First, who should pay for this? The second question is: are we weakening the competitiveness of the European automotive industry with this proposal? The first question, therefore, is who should bear the costs. According to the directive, these costs should be borne primarily by the manufacturer, in accordance with the principles of producer responsibility and the polluter pays principle enshrined in the EU Treaty. However, it is clear that these costs are borne jointly by the manufacturer and the consumer. We have calculated that the cost of recycling a car amounts to no more than 1% of the price of a new vehicle. Can we fool ourselves into thinking that this money will disappear if the directive is not adopted? No, of course we will all have to bear the costs of environmental destruction, and this will be considerably more expensive. Moreover, these costs will only become apparent after a longer period of time. So the costs are not disappearing, but we are now making clear where responsibility lies and how the financial burden should be distributed. Are we talking about a crisis-ridden automotive industry here? Is the discussion about an economic sector with low profit margins that we need to support by not imposing even more burdens on it? Can the automotive industry simply not afford such a thing? Isn't our real intention to weaken the competitiveness of the European automotive industry? No, of course not! Do you think that consumer demand for environmentally friendly and fuel-efficient cars will fade away in the future? What do you think the demands our children and grandchildren, or the legislators of the future, will place on cars? Of course, that they must be environmentally friendly, recyclable, consume little fuel, and not pollute our environment! Only in this way can we give the automotive industry a future. We must create healthy incentives for the recycling of waste and the reuse of materials, so that we can compete with environmentally friendly and fuel-efficient vehicles. The fact that the European automotive industry has already made significant progress more than adequately compensates for the fact that even more cars are roaming around Europe, for which it must assume responsibility. This is not a matter of exorbitant sums of money or an insurmountable task.

Here, too, the water problem and the situation of Palestinian refugees in Lebanon are still unresolved issues. Finally, I would like to address the question of a future Palestinian state. This could be declared this year, with or without Israel's consent. The Barak government has indicated that it is prepared to conclude a peace agreement with a state as a contracting party. Even if negotiations are not concluded by September of this year, there are no contractual obstacles to the declaration of a Palestinian state after that date. For those of us who support this idea, it is of great importance in this context that this state is characterized by transparency and democracy, as Commissioner Patten put it. We all want to contribute to this. Mr President, first of all, I would like to refer to the joint motion for a resolution presented at the end of this debate, to which my group contributed and to which we naturally agree. In particular, however, I would like to express our joy that Israel and Syria are once again reaching out to each other after such a long period of stagnation to resolve their differences. The recent negotiations represent, for the time being, an important step toward lasting peace in the Middle East. It is therefore regrettable that the peace talks have been temporarily suspended. Both sides will indeed have to make significant efforts. A stable peace in the region is only possible on the basis of an agreement that guarantees the security of Israel's borders and Syria's territorial integrity. This will also require the establishment of normal diplomatic relations and a permanent dialogue. Hopefully, in addition to the bilateral meetings with Syria, Israel will soon begin negotiations with Lebanon, and that a multilateral approach will prove possible within the framework of economic and regional cooperation. Unfortunately, the European Union, as one of the main donors, is still unable to play a significant political role in the peace process. This Middle East peace process is one of the priorities of the European Union's Common Foreign and Security Policy. Mr Solana, Secretary-General of the Council and High Representative for the CFSP, has a special task in this regard. The Commission and the Member States must also be encouraged to support projects that help establish mutual understanding and partnership between the various peoples of the region. The importance of the Barcelona Process, which must have a positive impact on regional cooperation, should also be emphasized here. We support Syria's participation in this process, provided it recognizes human rights, does not provide aid to terrorists, and fully supports the peace process. Naturally, numerous problems remain unresolved and many questions remain unanswered, including in relations with the Palestinians. While the peace process is, as we know, lengthy and complicated, with the necessary trust, the indispensable political will, and the required perseverance, we are convinced that we will achieve our common goal of a peaceful and prosperous Middle East. Mr President, The fact that peace negotiations between Israel and Palestine, as well as between Israel and Syria, are underway despite certain delays and problems, is cause for celebration. The moment of truth is near. Is Israel prepared to comply with UN resolutions and return the Arab territories conquered in 1967 in exchange for peace and security?

Experience to date has clearly demonstrated that linear regulations on staff reductions and incentives for voluntary departure often have undesirable effects. I recall that the Belgian telephone company had to recall retired employees so that the company did not lose too much know-how and experience. Staff reductions will undoubtedly be a topic of discussion in the liberalization of postal services. It should not be forgotten that offers of voluntary departure are primarily accepted by those employees who are already working under pressure or who can easily find new employment; in other words, these are often workers whom the company itself needs. It would, in my view, demonstrate prudent human resources management if the Commission took some of these concerns to heart, so that the liberalization of such a sensitive sector as the postal service is as socially acceptable as possible. Mr President, postal services and post offices seem to be a very topical issue in Parliament at the moment, and rightly so, given their importance. Just last week, the newly elected MP from our European Free Alliance partners, Plaid Cymru, the Welsh party, delivered his maiden speech on this issue in the UK Parliament at Westminster. There was also a recent debate in the Scottish Parliament, which highlighted the role of post offices, particularly in rural areas, in providing services and supporting the survival of rural communities. Liberalisation is not the only potential threat to post office services. Post offices in Scotland, as we have heard, do far more than just deliver the mail. Governments and some local authorities have traditionally used them as a place to pay pensions and other benefits, as well as rents, council tax, and so on. But as the modernisation of public finance systems increasingly moves towards electronic payments through direct debit and transfer, the viability of rural post offices is under threat. The closure of a rural post office, which usually includes the only local shop, can pose a major threat to the viability of the community and social cohesion. Rather than allowing post offices to be undermined by liberalization or the modernization of systems, governments, and indeed the Commission, should encourage and support a widespread network of post offices and view them as an asset to be built upon by providing public information and services from a location convenient for local residents. Mr. President, it is the responsibility of the Post Office to ensure that mail is delivered everywhere, in town and country, every day, at the same rate for everyone. For 150 years, the post office has been a public service and, like public transport and electricity supply, a core function of national governments. Such obvious and useful core functions give people a reason to vote. They will show considerably less interest in a government that does not concern themselves with such matters.

We are losing market share. I think we must do something to make ourselves more competitive. I hope you will help us. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are today discussing a very important sector that directly employs more than 10 million people in the European Union and that is helping more or less disadvantaged, remote, and island regions get back on their feet. Tourism also creates additional jobs, thus stimulating employment, particularly among the most vulnerable social groups, namely women and young people. However, I believe this is in blatant contradiction to the fact that there is no European tourism policy. Due to the lack of a legal basis, no measures can be taken in this area. The repeated invocation of Article 308 (formerly Article 235), which requires unanimity for a legal act, has not even made it possible to adopt a program worth ECU 8 million for five years and fifteen Member States. The measures occasionally taken to date have been fragmented and therefore ineffective; the regulations have been subject to the dictates of parallel policies, such as consumer protection, the environment, transport, taxation, etc., which have often not only failed to promote tourism but, in fact, hindered it, as their implementation usually entailed costs for the tourism industry without any examination of whether it could actually bear these costs or what incentives existed to bear them. I note with regret that, as part of the restructuring of the Commission's services, tourism is now not even a directorate, but merely a department within the Directorate-General for Enterprise. Yet we should support our tourism sector! In our opinion, key pillars that could lay the foundation for this are the inclusion of a substantive chapter on tourism in the reform, which would also constitute the legal basis for the sector; the development of an EU-wide tourism policy that promotes the sector without compromising the functioning of the tourism market; the coordination of tourism policy with other Community policies that directly or indirectly affect the sector; its study; and medium- and long-term measures to promote the competitiveness of tourism products. Since we are talking about employment, I would like to point out another very serious problem: the bankruptcies of tour operators and their impact, especially on hotels that are small and medium-sized enterprises and therefore lack the necessary equipment and access to information to verify whether their contractual partners are solvent. Clearly, it is not enough to act solely at the national level. Rather, EU-wide measures to improve relations between hoteliers and tour operators, such as a charter, could be considered. It would also be conceivable to establish a special fund for bankruptcy cases in cooperation with representatives of both sectors. The Commission has already requested quantitative data on the losses suffered by companies as a result of such bankruptcies in order to gain an understanding. It has also called on the European associations of both the hotel and catering industry and travel agencies, HOTREC and ECTAA, to draft a regulation regulating their mutual relations. Since then, however, no progress has been made.

However, despite the good results they achieve in their studies, women are underrepresented in individual scientific disciplines. This underrepresentation of women can no longer be tolerated. I therefore note the European Commission's proposals with great satisfaction. The objective of the Commission's document is to focus on the measures to be taken at Community level, and in particular within the Fifth Framework Programme for Research and Technological Development. I naturally agree with this. In the coming years, the aim is to achieve a 40% participation of women in Marie Curie fellowships and in the advisory and evaluation bodies for the entire Fifth RTD Framework Programme. To achieve this, it is necessary to improve debate and the exchange of experience between the individual Member States and to establish a "Women and Science" data collection group within the Fifth RTD Framework Programme, whose task will be, in particular, to collect and disseminate statistical data on women's participation in the research activities of the Fifth RTD Framework Programme. Furthermore, I share the rapporteur's opinion that studies must be conducted into the reasons for the discrepancy between the number of women with degrees in scientific subjects and the number actually working in these fields. Based on a better analysis of the obstacles women face, a strategy to eliminate them can then be developed. We must mobilize the numerous existing networks of women scientists and obtain their support in developing a common research policy. The European Parliament will continue to closely monitor the implementation of the Fifth Framework Programme for Research and Development (RTD) with a view to promoting women and will develop ideas for the direction of the next programme. In the field of science and research, as in all other European Union policies, the gender dimension must be integrated in order to put an end once and for all to the structural discrimination that prevents women from competing on an equal footing in the labor market. (FR) In its communication "Women and Science," the Commission announces its good intention of mobilizing women to enrich European research. That's very good, and we're pleased about it. Indeed, there are too few women involved in research in the European Union. We know that we can only change this underrepresentation of women in science through a school guidance policy that systematically promotes the diversification of girls' career aspirations, and, after they have graduated, through positive action at the professional level. That said, some Members are obviously uneasy because the report of the Committee on Women's Rights, which we have adopted, contains a point that is open to misunderstanding and which some interpret as a quota requiring a 40% share of women in European research. This, of course, is not the case; such a quota would be unrealistic. Moreover, the report does not specify a deadline by which such a quota should be achieved. In order to calm people's minds and allay my colleagues' concerns, I have tabled an amendment to the resolution simply to note that the Commission, in its communication, undertakes to make a significant effort to increase the participation of women in Community research programmes, which is certainly commendable.

Use of the precautionary principle The agenda is the Commission communication on the use of the precautionary principle. I will begin by saying that I am pleased to present this communication on the use of the precautionary principle which I have drafted together with Commissioners David Byrne and Erkki Liikanen. The precautionary principle is not a new concept. The Community has had frequent recourse to it for some time now in various policy areas: the health of the environment, human health, animals and plants. Moreover, in addition to appearing in various international texts such as the Rio Declaration and the more recent Protocol on Biosafety, it has been explicitly mentioned in the environmental provisions of the EC Treaty, starting with Maastricht. The substance of the precautionary principle is clear: it involves taking certain measures in a given policy area where science is not certain, but there are reasons to fear that the potential risks are such that such measures are urgently needed. In recent years, however, recourse to the precautionary principle has increasingly come to the fore. Incidents such as the BSE or dioxin crisis have given rise to a lively public debate on the circumstances justifying and making precautionary measures necessary. In the light of this growing interest, the Commission has deemed it useful to present a Communication to set out its position on the precautionary principle. The main objective of this Communication is twofold. First, to clearly and logically explain how the Commission applies (and intends to apply) the precautionary principle to its risk management and, secondly, to set out application guidelines based on considered and logical principles. We also hope that the Communication will contribute to a better understanding of risk management and to dispel the fear that the precautionary principle may be used arbitrarily as a disguised form of trade protectionism. The Commission's starting point in applying the precautionary principle is the need to ensure a high level of protection in the areas of environmental, human, animal and plant health. Of course, this objective cannot be used to justify arbitrary or irrational measures, but it is possible to act even when science is not certain. Consequently, the precautionary principle does not lead to the politicization of science, as some have claimed, but leads us to choose between science and politics. The initial decision to apply the precautionary principle depends essentially on the level of protection desired and the level of risk that decision-makers are willing to accept for society. This decision is therefore, by its very nature, political. However, the measures that can subsequently be adopted must obviously comply with the general principles applicable to risk management and the guidelines for applying the precautionary principle are therefore the essential element of the document. The measures adopted must be proportional to the level of protection chosen - and therefore you don't need a sledgehammer to crack a peanut. There must be no discrimination in the application process, that is, the measures must not make distinctions on the basis of geographical origin.

These contradictions cannot be overcome with hypocrisy and fine words such as convergence, benchmarking, modernisation, concertation. Either the European Union becomes a true federal state with a true redistributive budget, true labour mobility, and then, only at this point, with common rules on work and welfare, or it will be better not to delude ourselves and delude ourselves about impossible paths of convergence, which sound good but which in reality harm especially the weakest. And we should all be aware of this. Mr President, departing from what some colleagues have said during today's debate, I am inclined to approve the Andersson report, also because I see significant differences in it compared to the Commission's communication. It seems to me, in particular, that the report, for which I would like to congratulate the author, supports the solidarity-based approach of the European social model. It defines the broad objectives of social policy, taking unequivocal positions that I am pleased to underline: against social dumping and in favour of the right to social security, for the objective of social convergence and above all, very concretely, in favour of equal opportunities for women. I also see some shortcomings in the insufficiently in-depth examination of the European Union's macroeconomic policy which contrasts the renewal of the European welfare state model in a solidarity-based way. Overall, however, I consider the report to be positive. Mr President, I take the floor to reiterate that we need to modernise social protection, a valid instrument, much more than just a step forward towards the construction of Europe. This is underlined in the report - in my opinion, excellent - by Mr Andersson. Europe, the European Union, although very strong in the economic and political sphere, would be unstable, weak and limited if we were not able to strengthen its social sphere, increasing the opportunities for finding a job for anyone who requests one and working concretely in favour of the most socially disadvantaged. Considering that every person has the right to social protection and a guaranteed minimum social income, I believe that we must not forget the situation of those who were not born in the European Union. Let us not forget that, during 1999, no less than 717,000 people came to compensate for our low birth rate. For this reason, in the social sphere, we need an immigration policy that is socially aware, as President Gutierres recently declared in Spain. We must also take into account the situation of those who, faced with economic changes, mergers, takeovers and new technologies, etc., see their employment opportunities threatened or reduced. We therefore need a training policy that enables and prepares people for new jobs to maintain their position or to have a second chance. Sometimes, in fact, as the title of the film confirms, the postman rings twice. I believe, in all modesty, that it is up to European, national and regional governments to ensure that the postman rings on more than one occasion. It seems to me, Commissioner, that the responsibility for promoting and coordinating these possibilities falls on the Commission. Mr President, in addition to congratulating Mr Andersson on his excellent work which justifies this general consensus, I would also like to thank the honourable Members for their contribution and move on to some comments on what has been said.

We must continue to keep inflation low, push ahead with liberalization, increasingly ensure competition, encourage the spread of information technology and all new technologies; stimulate science, the frontiers of science, have the pleasure of being at the frontiers of science. The upcoming Lisbon Summit, which will address these issues—the spread of technology, employment—is a decisive summit. It has taken four years to hold a summit of this kind. It is finally within our grasp: we cannot miss this opportunity. The final commitment is to a better quality of life. We began this chapter with the White Paper on food safety: now we must take major steps in the area of the environment. The case of the Erika ship and the poisoning of the Danube call for urgent intervention at European level to protect the environment. The time has come to think, and therefore to create, a European civil protection emergency structure. In too many cases, this is perceived as an afterthought. I believe it is opportune to start thinking about these things before disasters occur. These are the challenges before us: before the Commission and before all the European institutions. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, how will we measure the five years of our activity? How will we measure the results of those five years? I do not know, but certainly one unit of measurement could be the challenge we face together. We take a very simple parameter: turnout in the next European elections. If it is higher than the previous one, it will mean that we have met our challenge. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have all these major political challenges before us; however, thanks to the recent recovery, we also have great opportunities. This, ladies and gentlemen, can be the decade of Europe. And I say: this must be the decade of Europe. Madam President, Mr. President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)/European Democrats welcomes this debate and is pleased that the Commission has presented a document for its preparation. We also welcome the conclusions contained in that document, as well as the general content of the declaration just presented by the President of the Commission, Mr. Prodi. The conclusions of the document indicate that the five years of the Prodi Commission's mandate will be a period of major transformation. Europe will advance along the path of integration, and the Union will simultaneously embark on a phase of enlargement that aims to ultimately achieve the reunification of our continent. This is a demanding and ambitious approach, which we might even call prophetic. Mr. President of the Commission, we wish you the best of luck in making it a reality. However, we also wish to remind you that the present is the foundation on which the future rests, and we can only build the future if we pay attention to the present. I say this with all seriousness and also with concern.

As Commissioner for the Budget, my corresponding responsibilities already include relations with the Court of Auditors. This Board for the Development of Internal Audit Control will ensure effective and rigorous monitoring of internal auditing. I would like to emphasize that changing our control systems will in no way mean relaxing them. The proposed change will make them more effective both in terms of inputs and in terms of measurable and verifiable outputs. I can also specifically assure the House that we are not seeking what is sometimes called a "big bang approach." Financial control based on ex ante authorization for each spending department will only be abandoned when and as long as a department's internal control system proves fully adequate. I am somewhat surprised that paragraph 10 does not appear to address the fundamental criticisms made by both reports of the Committee of Independent Experts on the functioning of the current centralized system of financial control. That Committee was very clear about the need to abolish the centralized system of ex ante authorization. It was also very clear about the need to separate internal audit from financial control. Furthermore, I do not believe that paragraph 10 fully reflects the Court of Auditors' opinion regarding 1997. Naturally, the Court of Auditors will be able to give its esteemed opinion on the proposed changes to the Financial Regulation, but it is useful to recall the comments made to this House last month by Mr. Karlsson. "The Commission's internal control," he said, "is not sufficiently vigorous to prevent malfunctioning. For example, the Financial Controller granted ex ante authorization in most of the newly discovered cases of mismanagement or irregularity. At the same time, the internal audit function is carried out in an uncoordinated manner by several bodies, especially by the Financial Controller himself, the Inspectorate-General, and certain units in Directorates-General." The system of ex ante authorization was, no doubt, originally designed to ensure caution, but over the years it has had the perverse effect of reducing the extent to which managers feel responsible for their decisions. I do not believe there is any real disagreement among us on this. From paragraph 10, I infer that the underlying concern of your honourable Members is that there must be a carefully managed transition. That will almost certainly be the tenor of the change, as you will see when you read the reform strategy document. Our objective, the objective of the committee, the objective of the Court of Auditors, is not to abolish financial control, but to rid ourselves of centralized financial control and improve upon it. Before leaving this subject, I would like to add that we agree with the rapporteur that the existing internal audit function must be retained pending the establishment of the new independent internal audit system, which will take place in a matter of months. Turning quickly to the part of the resolution devoted to combating fraud, corruption, mismanagement, and nepotism: the most important new proposal in the report concerns public officials reporting perceived malpractice. As I made clear during the debates last September and on other occasions, we all believe it is positive to define the mechanisms for this as clearly as possible, although, of course, we hope that they will rarely be necessary.

I would point out that our Parliament is requesting appropriations of 850 million ECU, which is not a huge amount in the Community budget, and that the current proposals are for 613 million ECU. It seems to me, in any case, that at least for the end of the implementation of LIFE, there would be a way for the Union to make a significant budgetary gesture in favour of the environment. Allow me to conclude on the question of the way our institutions operate. The speech I hear today is: "We absolutely must now reach a rapid conclusion. In short, you, Parliament, lower your expectations, especially your budgetary expectations! Because, if we do not quickly manage, within the framework of codecision, to establish the framework for the LIFE regulation, we will fall behind in its implementation for the year 2000, and it is true that the NGOs, the operators on the ground, are waiting for our funds. I would like to point out, however, that the Council has a very long time to form an opinion, that it submits its proposals to us a few months before the fateful deadline. We are constrained by the texts: four months maximum. We meet our deadlines and, afterwards, we are told: "Wait! If you want to be reasonable, you have to accept our position because, in codecision, we don't have the time." I believe that our Parliament often protests against this method, which does not specifically call anyone into question within the Council, and I certainly would not want the Portuguese Presidency to feel responsible for this state of affairs, since in reality it is a bit of a tradition, which the Council has maintained over time. But I would like to stress that, on this environmental issue, the budgetary question is central and that Parliament cannot give in to blackmail that would force it to be the only reasonable one in this matter. I therefore hope, firstly, that, in conciliation, our colleagues will support us - but the votes have always been very convergent in this area - but also that the Council and the Commission will listen to us and that we will each take a step towards each other. Mr President, Members of Parliament, it is true that we openly disapprove of some of the options taken by the Council and the Commission. And I will have the opportunity to elaborate on this later. However, it must be acknowledged, to begin with, that this regulation is better than the LIFE I and LIFE II regulations. Firstly, because the basic proposal has made LIFE more rigorous, more transparent and more rational. Secondly, because the common position incorporates certain essential aspects defended by the European Parliament at first reading, in particular the fact of retaining the promotion of employment as a criterion for selecting projects and the reduction of the overall impact of products from their production to their recycling and disposal, as the objective of LIFE "environment".

Are there any objections to the minutes? (Parliament approved the minutes.) Madam President, I am usually present at the opening of the sitting at 5 o'clock on Monday afternoons. Yesterday, like many Members of the European Parliament, I was unable to attend because the Air France flight, which normally brings us here at 2:15, was cancelled by the airline without any explanation. This meant that we were very late. If Air France were to maintain this policy of boycotting the European Parliament, Parliament would have to take measures to prevent it from happening again. Thank you very much, Mr Medina Ortega. I regret this as much as you do. Would you be so kind as to put this in writing so that I can give the details to the relevant departments at Air France and also to the French Government? I really believe that this is no longer acceptable, and we must protest in the strongest possible terms. Madam President, the same thing happened to me yesterday as did Mr Medina Ortega. I believe that the French authorities – who have the honor of hosting the European Parliament in Strasbourg – should be aware of their responsibility to ensure adequate connections with all the capitals of the Union. In any case, Mr Napolitano, thank you. Madam President, I am not concerned about plane delays, but I would like to apologize for the absence yesterday of my colleague Caroline Lucas from the Green Group, a British MEP. She could not be here because she was arrested yesterday morning at an anti-nuclear demonstration in Glasgow. Her identity was established, and although it was clearly established that she was an MEP, she was detained all day. I consider this completely intolerable. I would therefore ask you – and I have already sent you a letter to this effect, together with my colleague, Mrs Hautala – to urge the British authorities to ensure that such incidents do not happen again and to apologize to Mrs Lucas. Thank you, Mr Lannoye. I have received your letter and have already spoken to the British representation. Madam President, with regard to today's vote, I would like to make a request that I already raised yesterday during the oral debate on the EQUAL report. I would like to ask for the vote on the EQUAL Community Initiative to be postponed because we simply need a little more time to negotiate an important point. I am optimistic and truly look forward to the vote with composure and confidence; we will find the broadest possible support for this position on EQUAL. We just need a little more time to work out the details relating to the asylum issue, and I therefore ask that the vote be held instead of this morning. Madam President, I would like to say something in response to what Mr Lannoye mentioned: Mrs Lucas was arrested on the outskirts of Glasgow for protesting against the Trident base in Faslane. I have sympathy for this protest. However, I cannot express solidarity with Ms. Lucas, who is trying to hide behind her parliamentary immunity. I was also arrested for protesting in Faslane. I did not hide behind any immunity.

We know what happened recently in the UN General Assembly. We had to freeze our resolution on the death penalty or we risked seeing a resolution approved that included absolutely unacceptable arguments asserting that human rights are not universally valid and applicable. The scene in New York is different from that in Geneva. Last year's debate on sovereignty and humanitarian aid, held in New York, dealt with such a sensitive topic that it influenced all other issues. It certainly influenced the debate on the moratorium on capital punishment. The Geneva debate, however, focuses more on human rights. It may, therefore, be that we have a better chance of making progress there. Second, Cuba. I want to address this point directly because we Europeans are the subject of unjustified criticism; we are accused of not taking human rights seriously enough. We are deeply concerned about certain actions by the Cuban government last year that have further restricted citizens' freedoms, actions such as changes to the penal code and the scope of the death penalty. We are also concerned about the recent increase in the number of political detentions. We monitor the human rights situation through reports provided by NGOs and the activities of our human rights working groups based in the EU embassies in Havana. We have regularly expressed our criticism to the Cuban authorities, and Parliament has done the same. But I do not believe that attempting to isolate Cuba is the right approach. We want a just and open society in Cuba, a country that respects market principles, the sanctity of contracts, and the rule of law. We want to encourage a process of transition towards democracy and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. My view is absolutely identical on the third issue I would like to address, namely, China. It's very simple: I want us to have relations with China. It would be too easy and self-defeating to want anything else, and it would be an insult to more than one-fifth of humanity. I also want to see China transformed through peaceful change into a free, pluralistic society that does not throw democracy activists or religious adherents into prison. So what are we to do? Of course, we must have enthusiastic trade relations with China and hope to be able to welcome that country into the WTO on reasonable terms. It is really inappropriate to talk about a World Trade Organization that does not include China—or even Russia, for that matter. But I do not think today, and I have never thought so, that our nascent economic relations with China—manifested, for example, by China's €25 billion surplus with the European Union—should silence us when it comes to the human rights situation in China. For me, the question is not whether we should address the issue of human rights in China—we have a duty and a legitimate interest in this matter—but rather how best to do so.

We are also working in this direction to develop a deep and positive relationship with the Commission. Honourable Members, I do not have much to add on these subjects. In recent weeks, many events have occurred that I would like to refer to: Kosovo, the Middle East, Chechnya; many things that I would like to comment on with you. I would prefer, Madam President B, if you will allow me, to stop here in order to have sufficient time available to answer the questions that will be put to me. However, before doing so, allow me to report on a telephone conversation on Chechnya that I had a few hours ago with the Commissioner of the Council of Europe Gil-Robles who, having returned this morning from Chechnya, where he visited Grozny, contacted me by telephone to tell me his first impressions which, as you can imagine, are not good. The situation in the refugee camps in Ingushetia is precarious and constantly worsening; in most cases there is no more hot food during the day: the Russian authorities are no longer distributing food, so it is the non-governmental organisations that are providing it. In Grozny at the moment there are about 20,000 people in desperate situations, who have to walk for kilometres and kilometres to find a place to eat something. However, there is something positive that is moving and I would like to report to Parliament. The Commissioner of the Council of Europe told me that last night, speaking with the President and the Minister of Foreign Affairs, the Russian authorities had agreed that representatives of the Council of Europe should join the humanitarian mission already present in Grozny, under the direction of the Russian authorities; negotiations are also underway with the Chairmanship-in-Office of the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) to involve, if possible, representatives of that organisation. These are the only positive things that I can communicate at the moment; I hope that in the next few hours we will be able to have more information from Mr Gil-Robles and, above all, better news from the point of view of the authorities of the Russian Federation. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I will stop here. I would just like to go back to what I said at the beginning. It is a great satisfaction to be able to participate in the work of this Parliament, to share with the honourable Members the work that is being done jointly by all the countries and by the Commission, with a clear objective, the objective that our European Union can participate, exercising the greatest possible weight at international level, in peacekeeping operations. Europe does not want to wage war anywhere, but rather to work together to ensure that there is peace and stability throughout the world. I would like to thank the High Representative, Mr Solana, very warmly. Mr Poettering now has the floor on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party and European Democrats. Thank you, Mr Poettering. Mr Poettering, it is clear that Commissioner Patten should speak in this debate. He will certainly be given the floor when he feels it is appropriate to speak.

Coordination is the key word here. The water problem is increasingly topical. Climate change and small increases in temperature have a direct impact on precipitation. Some regions are becoming drier, while many others are becoming wetter. It is time to act. In March, the Second World Water Forum will take place in The Hague. This forum advocates a global vision. This vision must lead to regional action plans for sustainable water management. For the European Parliament, the time for action is now. We must opt for a sustainable water policy and, at the same time, we must be realistic. But we cannot set the bar too low either. The common position is not ambitious enough. That is why it is essential to resort to previous international conventions or the OSPAR objectives. We must aim for the phasing out of hazardous products by 2020. This is understood for the marine environment. It is clear that this agreement must also apply to other waters. The OSPAR objectives are currently being drawn up. A list of 400 products that pose clear environmental hazards has been drawn up. Both technically and economically, it is possible to approach zero emissions of these substances, and that is the choice we must make. Naturally, the directive must also be binding. Downstream countries must be able to rely on upstream countries meeting the quality objectives. Quality has a price, but pollution may prove to have a much higher price in the future. Mr. President, Commissioner! I would like to express my deep admiration for the remarkable work Mrs. Lienemann has done on this water directive. Allow me to point out that the most serious environmental problems we face today - the transformation of climates, the devastation of virgin forests, the depletion of fishing resources - always affect resources that we share and that are absolutely indispensable to us, but which, in a certain sense, are also ownerless. Let us also recognize that the freshwaters of the European continent can be said to fall into a grey area, between what belongs to everyone and what belongs to no one. This is why establishing responsibilities in this area is of strategic importance. It is also essential that the individual watercourses be considered holistically, treated as the whole that they do indeed constitute, regardless of the country to which any particular part of their common course belongs. Dear colleagues, as has already been said several times, the proposal for a directive does indeed represent a historic opportunity to simplify and improve the plethora and veritable mosaic of EU regulations and directives and thus achieve a high level of environmental protection in Europe. However, I have the impression that the policy of the Water Framework Directive is marked by deregulation and renationalization. I also hope that the vote will not be a complete waste of time, and two points are absolutely essential for me in this regard. First of all, OSPAR. We know that the Commission's proposal does not go far enough; unfortunately, the same is true of the proposal from the Committee on the Environment.

Fifth and finally, the aggregate to which the public deficit will refer will be the gross domestic product at current market prices, estimated according to the definitions of the 1995 European System of Accounts. In short, this Commission proposal is, in my opinion, a correct and concrete adaptation of the criteria established in the European System of Accounts 1995, which I therefore fully approve, as expressed by the Commission. Mr. President, it is positive that statistical data are not only reliable but also comparable. This is especially important for integration and the completion of the internal market. Hence, this report also has political significance, for which we sincerely congratulate the rapporteur. It also gives rise to a couple of political observations. The Stability Pact is a fact in Europe. All countries participating in the euro have committed themselves, through this Stability Pact, to achieving a balanced budget in the medium term or to running a small surplus. That, of course, doesn't mean that when the economic climate is adverse, there can't be some imbalance, but in the long and medium term, we speak of equilibrium or surplus. The stronger the position of the participating countries, the more stable the euro will be. Therefore, exceeding the 3% rule should happen rarely, not even in unfavorable economic circumstances—at least that's what logic dictates. We have always believed that these criteria must be strictly adhered to. It is very important for the EMU to be successful in the future. Strict adherence to the Stability Pact can contribute to creating a culture of stability in all Member States. Several Member States have adopted exclusive provisions to enable them to meet the criteria. We believe that Member States' budgetary policies must be strictly monitored so that the measures adopted to meet the established criteria continue to be applied. Any relaxation of these criteria cannot be permitted. Moreover, we believe that further spending cuts and reducing public debt must be among the priorities. After all, the expense is still being passed on to future generations. Mr. President, first of all, thank you very much to the rapporteur for the excellent work he has done. It was a subject that required a high degree of technicality, and I believe Mr. Knörr handled it with great precision and professionalism. I would not dare to summarize the content of our proposal better than he did; I would only make a brief additional comment, saying that, in addition to the ESA 95 adaptation, there are two minor technical modifications that Mr. Knörr is very familiar with, concerning interest and the valuation of foreign currency debt. I only mention this as a comment to give a complete overview of the process. Secondly, I would like to thank Mr. Knörr for his promptness. He has done a truly excellent job in a very short period of time.

First of all, it is essential to encourage private investment. The Union must help stimulate entrepreneurship and create jobs in this way, but we must not forget public investment. This has been the major victim of recent years, and an improvement in public finances must clearly allow us to improve public investment, while respecting our commitments on fiscal consolidation. Our major bet for the future must be research and development, but also human capital. These are two of the major challenges we will have to face in Lisbon. We believe it is essential to make progress on these challenges with quantified targets and specific definitions that will ultimately allow us to achieve what we all aspire to: net improvements in productivity that make possible increased growth in our society, as well as an increase in employment that allows us to regain some of the ground lost in recent years. This is the policy that the Commission has defended and that we will continue to defend in Lisbon. Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) The agenda calls for joint debate on the following reports: A5-0038/2000 by Mrs Attwooll, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the proposal for a Council Regulation establishing a Community framework for the collection and management of fisheries data essential to the implementation of the Common Fisheries Policy (COM(1999) 0541 - C5-0302/1999 - 1999/0218(CNS)); A5-0037/2000 by Mrs Attwooll, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the proposal for a Council decision on a financial contribution from the Community to the expenditure incurred by Member States in collecting data and in financing studies and pilot projects in support of the common fisheries policy (COM(1999) 0551 - C5-0303/1999 - 1999/0224(CNS)). The proposals for a Council regulation on the collection and management of fisheries data and for a Council decision on a financial contribution in this area are both to be welcomed. Hence this joint debate, since each can only be fully understood in the light of the other. I understand that they took about five years to prepare. It is important that rapid progress is now being made, in view of the 2002 review of the Common Fisheries Policy. Consider first the proposed Council Regulation. This requires Member States to collect a wider range of fisheries data than was required under previous regulations. Both biological and economic information are included. The proposal also requires Member States to produce such data in aggregated form. An implementing regulation will specify exactly what new data must be collected and which of these must be aggregated with existing data. The implementing regulation will establish a minimum Community program and an extended Community program. It appears that these programs will not cover the entire spectrum of potential data but will be selective, for example, according to fish stocks. The proposed Council Decision allows for the establishment of a financial contribution granted by the Community to Member States engaged in data collection and management.

We will receive all draft implementing measures referred to a committee at the same time as that committee. We will have the opportunity to examine the drafts, discuss them, and ask questions. However, we will only be able to intervene officially with the Commission if we believe that the Commission has exceeded the implementing powers conferred on it. In other words, we can take action against an implementing measure that exceeds the Commission's powers, but we have no influence on the content of that measure. In a democracy, however, Parliament should also have the opportunity to question its content. We do not intend to do so all the time. We do not want to interfere in implementing decisions, but it is a democratic safeguard that we have this opportunity in the few cases where it seems absolutely necessary. This opportunity is missing in the new system, or at least exists only in a rudimentary form. Our fourth point of criticism is that an implementing measure blocked in the comitology procedure is not referred back to both legislative bodies, but only to the Council, which has the right to draft an alternative measure. This is incorrect. Both institutions—the Council and Parliament—adopt the legislation that confers implementing powers on the Commission. When implementing measures are referred back, this should be done not just to one institution, but to both. Overall, this system has achieved some improvements. The additional aspects resulting from the interinstitutional agreement with the Commission are welcome, but they do not change the Council's basic decision. Even here, we voluntarily—this did not happen automatically—waived the Plumb/Delors agreement as part of the overall compromise. We were prepared to waive these provisions. We will have to monitor very closely what was previously covered by that agreement but is not fully covered by the new decision. We must be very vigilant. So, it is a step forward. My group reluctantly accepts this as a step forward. We are not as enthusiastic about compromise as Mrs. Frassoni. We recognize the limitations and are certain that this issue will be back on the agenda in a few years. If we want a democratic Union with the greatest possible transparency, we will have to address this issue again. Mr. President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs. Frassoni, for the work she has done. Dealing with comitology issues is never easy. Mrs. Schleicher has touched on a kind of 'committee magic' we have always spoken about. Certainly, the process has always been very complicated as a result of previous decisions that ultimately need to be streamlined. In my view, the agreement we have reached between the Commission and Parliament represents a clear streamlining of the process. In our view, it satisfies Parliament's fundamental interests. Mr. Corbett has expressed his concerns. He says that some of them have been resolved, and some of them have not. I would say that those that the Commission was able to resolve have been resolved. What Mr. Corbett is referring to are other conditions that are not covered by the Council's decision, but which, unfortunately, we cannot go beyond.

That was the opening statement by Commission President Prodi when presenting the European Commission's strategic objectives for the next five years. We look forward to the White Paper on the governance of the European Union, which will address the issue of the balance between the governments of the Member States and the institutions of the European Union and will be published this summer. On this specific point, I believe it is important that we address the reform of the Commission's internal decision-making procedures. Along with the proposals the Commission has submitted to the next Intergovernmental Conference, it has indicated its preference for smaller Member States to lose their automatic right to appoint a member of the European Commission. This is assuming the European Union has more than 25 Member States. I do not want to see a two-tier European Union built. I believe that would run counter to the spirit and purpose of the Treaty of Rome and all subsequent Treaties. There must be equality in terms of national representation in the Commission, just as in the other European institutions. I would like to remind those who seek to eliminate the right of smaller Member States to appoint a European Commissioner that the United States of America grants smaller states the same recognition in the Senate as larger states. Virtually every one of the 50 states is entitled to two seats in the United States Senate, regardless of its population. Any future reform of the European Union Treaties requires a referendum in my country. It is very difficult for those who advocate a "yes" vote on a future treaty of this nature to gain the support of the Irish people if we lose our right to appoint a member of the European Commission. There is no doubt that this White Paper on the governance of the European Union, which will be published this summer, will also include reform of the European Council. Once again, there are special areas at the political level that should remain within the national competence of the Member States. I don't believe there is broad support in Europe for the introduction of qualified majority voting in areas such as taxation, justice, home affairs, and foreign affairs at the European Union level. Currently, under Article 99 of the Treaty of Rome, decisions at the EU level regarding changes to the tax system must be taken unanimously. I believe this proposal should be maintained, as a common European tax code would hinder rather than benefit the functioning of the European Union. I am in favor of the enlargement of the European Union. I am in favor of institutional changes that ensure that the enlargement of the Union occurs in a streamlined and structured manner. However, we must remember that public opinion among the 370 million people in the European Union is a decisive factor in changing the EU Treaties. Changes should not be made hastily and cannot be too radical, otherwise, public opinion will make the ratification of any future Treaty on European Union very difficult.

It is therefore absurd and often impossible to transfer LIFE projects directly to another instrument. If alternative funding proposals were to be sought for each project, this would also require greater resources than are currently available. Now that the Commission must assess precisely what resources are needed for each action, this is an example of a non-core action requiring considerable resources that we must avoid. The Commission also cannot accept Amendment 14, which is at odds with the Commission's right of initiative. Regarding the discussion on the deadline, I would like to say that the deadline for the entry into force of LIFE, set at 31 March 2000 in the common position, must now be brought forward. This deadline will be set as soon as this regulation is adopted. In conclusion, I would like to reiterate my conviction that LIFE will become an effective instrument in the context of supporting development and establishing a common environmental policy. Parliament has made a significant contribution to improving this instrument. I am sure that you share my desire to see the regulation adopted as quickly as possible, particularly given the high expectations of the Member States and other countries, especially the candidate countries, which now have the opportunity to participate in LIFE. Thank you, Mrs Wallström. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11.30 a.m. Modernisation of social protection The next item is the report (A5-0033/2000) by Mr Andersson, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the Commission communication on a concerted strategy for modernising social protection (COM (1999) 347 - C5 - 0253/1999 - 1999/2182 (COS)). Mr President, the issue of the social protection system is of prime importance. It is a natural consequence of cooperation within the EU. It is based on monetary cooperation, which has since been followed by macroeconomic cooperation and cooperation on employment policy. The logical next step is now to develop the social protection system. These areas are interdependent. Economic stability provides a basis for progress and leads to a high employment rate. It also offers the opportunity to develop well-being. However, the reverse is also true: a well-developed social protection policy can contribute to increased employment and growth. Social protection is, in other words, a productive factor. There are differences within the EU in the social protection system. Many of these stem from history. However, we now have a number of common challenges to address. This is particularly the case with demographic change, which not only concerns the increasing number of elderly people, but also the decreasing number of births. The labor market is also changing. Women are finding themselves in large numbers on the labor market. Technological developments pose another challenge. We must face these challenges together.

For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the Langen report and now expect the Commission to respond to our expectations and demands. (The sitting adjourned at 1:05 p.m. and resumed at 3:00 p.m.) Oil spill in France The next item on the agenda is the Commission statement on the oil spill in France. Mrs de Palacio will speak on behalf of the Commission to open the debate. Mr President, I am speaking on behalf of the PPE-DE Group, but also as a Breton Member who is directly affected and shocked by these events. Together with Françoise Grossetête and the PPE, we have tabled a draft resolution. Today, we are pleased to have a compromise proposal before us. The Erika tanker disaster is indeed a European matter, firstly because it has affected and polluted some of Europe's most beautiful beaches, with serious consequences for tourism, maritime professionals, and environmentalists, and secondly because it calls into question legislation and controls, which of course have European dimensions. It is safe to say that such a disaster would not have been possible off the American coast. Why? Because the Americans learned the lessons of the Exxon Valdez disaster and, in 1990, passed the Oil Pollution Act, which, on the one hand, contains stricter liability provisions, since it can also hold the charterer liable, and, on the other hand, is more binding and, thanks to various regulations, in particular the existence of the American Coast Guard, is better monitored. If we had such regulations, let me repeat, the disaster would undoubtedly have been avoidable. We therefore believe that the relevant provisions must be revised, particularly the 1992 Protocol, which exempted charterers, in this case the owners of oil tankers, from all liability. If charterers are exempted from liability, they are naturally less interested in the controls that fall to the oil companies. The provisions therefore need to be revised, and I thank you, Commissioner, for pointing out all the shortcomings currently existing in European regulations. Above all, as you said, we need to strengthen controls, both with regard to the flag state and with regard to ship classification societies. According to you, RINA is an Italian ship classification register recognized by the Commission. Under what conditions is this recognition granted? What are the reliability criteria? You will be sending a mission. We await the results with great interest. We also need to strengthen controls by maritime authorities and controls in European ports. As is well known, there is a Paris Memorandum that provides for a minimum level of control, according to which a quarter of the ships calling at European ports must be inspected by the maritime authorities of the country concerned. However, this obligation is not being met, not in France and not in numerous other European countries either. Why? What conclusions has the Commission drawn from this, or does it intend to draw from it? It also seems to me necessary to strengthen the control incumbent upon the charterer, in this case the oil company. When it comes to their financial responsibility, the control will undoubtedly be somewhat more thorough.

The Commission will fulfil the commitment made in Tampere to present proposals for the adoption of common definitions, incriminations and sanctions in the field of trafficking in human beings, the economic exploitation of migrants, the sexual exploitation of women and children, with particular emphasis on combating the use of new media and, in particular, the Internet for the dissemination of child pornography. We have also prepared a communication and opened the debate on the tools to ensure greater security in the information and knowledge society and to combat cybercrime. The year 2000 also marks the beginning of the implementation of the European Drug Strategy 2000-2004. In this context, the Commission, in cooperation with the Portuguese Presidency and the European Parliament, will give its full support to the Interinstitutional Conference on the Drug Problem to be held in February. As regards Schengen - and more specifically the integration of the Schengen acquis into the Community framework -, without entering into the Council's sphere of competence at this stage, I would like to point out, in relation to the topical issue of the reintroduction of border controls, that the Commission reiterates its willingness to examine in greater depth the ways in which better control of the application of Article 2(2) of the Schengen Convention can be ensured, in the sense of making it more imperative. The recent reintroduction of certain internal border controls leads me to conclude that it is necessary to proceed with a detailed analysis of the conditions for adopting a legislative instrument based on Article 62 of the Treaty. As was underlined in Tampere, in view of the preparation of the Feira European Council in June 2000, we will have to summarise the external implications of the new dimension of home affairs and justice with a view to adopting inter-pillar political strategies which will strengthen the coordination of internal and external policy in this area and which will contribute to the affirmation of the Union in the world. I would therefore like to stress that all these actions will obviously have to take into account the principles agreed at the Helsinki European Council in relation to the candidate countries, so that they can cooperate and participate, as soon as possible, in this project of creating an area of freedom, security and justice. It is important to remember, among other things, that JHA negotiations will begin in 2000 with the first group of candidate countries and I therefore hope that we will be able to proceed with the preparation of the negotiating dossiers on the second group admitted to accession at Helsinki. Finally, I would like to reiterate that the Commission intends to take the pole position in presenting proposals to help implement the Treaty of Amsterdam. I hope that the Commission and the Council will reach an agreement on the division of responsibilities in exercising the right of initiative and in conducting the legislative process itself. As I have already said, the task before us is enormous and ambitious, so the Commission needs to be provided with the necessary human resources to meet this challenge and hopes to be able to count on the support of Parliament and - why not say it? -, of the Council to ensure these resources and objectives, so that the creation of an area of freedom, security and justice in the Union becomes a reality within the shortest possible time and so that everyone can contribute, in a spirit of interinstitutional cooperation, to the realisation of this project, which undoubtedly represents the "pearl" of the Treaty of Amsterdam.

Madam President, the reform process has certainly been assessed very positively, which must be acknowledged, although perhaps a little benevolently. My question: Reform will be necessary, among other reasons, because of the accession of new states and, with it, the enlargement of the Union. How can we—the Commission, Parliament, and the national parliaments of the acceding states—effectively address this challenge, taking into account the ideas and approaches of the states applying for membership? The delegations are actively working on it—I am doing so in my delegation to the Czech Republic—but it must be noted that we often maintain a very know-it-all attitude toward one another. What can reform contribute to more efficiently shaping relations and collaboration, the joint action of the European Parliament, the national parliaments, and the Commission? I thank the Honorable Member for emphasizing that, apart from its own inherent merits, reform will be necessary because of accession, enlargement, and, in particular, the kind of enlargement our Union will soon undertake. It is essential that we achieve this reform for the good of the current Union and, of course, to facilitate accessions. Over the next few years, I will continue the method I have begun to apply, together with several of my colleagues in the Commission, of course, with very in-depth discussions with the administrations of the next new Member States. We do this to try to explain as fully as possible the system they will enter. I would also like to see the enrichment of the training work undertaken by current Member States and by the Union in general to ensure that, as new officials arrive at the Commission and Member State officials and administrators have to deal with the realities, the complex realities, of accession to the Union and the Single Market, it is difficult to see the seams. That is the level of refinement and performance I would like. All I can do now is promise that I will strive to achieve it. Let me begin by wishing the Commissioner a happy St. David's Day. Thank you for his presentation. It is important that the Commission never lose sight of the fact that if the reform process does not reconnect with the European public, it will be an utter and pointless waste of time. That must truly be the focus at all times. It has to provide a service to them, and of course, the recommendations on reducing payment delays will be very welcome—I am sure—but the other major complaint we receive from the citizens we represent concerns paperwork. Excessive paperwork. Is there any reference to reducing paperwork and bureaucracy for applicants for European funding while still ensuring financial control? That is the clear complaint we receive, and it must be addressed. The other question I would like to ask concerns the Audit Committee. It is certainly welcome, but it is essential that there be a reference to the oversight of recommendations from the European Parliament in our discharge procedure.

Soon, in May, the European Commission plans to present a communication on developing the role of human rights and democratisation in the Union's external relations. I would like to take this opportunity to ask the Commission to take account of this need for coordination and to seek new formulas that will strengthen the role played by the European Union and especially by Parliament in the field of human rights, especially in terms of coherence, recognising the goodwill of third countries that agree to include the democracy clause. This commitment should be translated into all respects, and I am referring in particular to the budget. Lastly, I would like to highlight the important contributions that civil society can make in this area and also the role, often underestimated, of the many non-governmental organisations working in the field. The Union must commit itself to providing them with all the support they need to carry out their important mission. Mr President, Members of the Commission, when this House is called upon to discuss the issue of human rights, it runs a serious risk which, if you like, is also underlined by the climate in which we are called upon to discuss this very important issue. The absence of the Council and of almost all of Parliament's colleagues makes us understand how much space there is still between noble, lofty and useful declarations on a formal level and the concrete application of the issue of human rights in the field of everyday politics. I believe that this Parliament, starting with the contribution that the European Union will give to the Geneva meeting, is called to fill this space and to make a contribution, not only on the level of the enunciation of principles but also on that of truth and even loyalty. Human rights must escape an interpretation that is only linked to the moment of denunciation or the moment of punishment. We are called, as a Parliament, to address the issue of human rights above all on the level of prevention. In this sense, we must be able to export a culture of legality, a culture of law, a convenience of law. I believe that a long period in which treaties and signatures were added to treaties has definitively ended. Today we have many, perhaps too many, treaties that intervene on the issue of human rights: if these treaties remain mere enunciation, they are only useless places of thought. Today we must move on to a subsequent and necessary phase, which is that of the daily and binding application of what is written in our treaties, even if we must not forget that some fundamental treaties still need to be implemented: I am referring to the Rome Conference and the fact that 14 out of 15 countries of the Union have not yet ratified the treaty on the International Criminal Court. I believe that we must verify and modify some political instruments by which we measure the quality of human rights on the planet. We have often used instruments that, on a formal level, may be comfortable but which, on the level of political outcome, are absolutely useless: I am referring to the use, and often the abuse, that has been made of the embargo over the years and to the overly cautious application of the suspension clause of agreements between the European Union and third countries, in the event that human rights are violated in these countries.

I can tell you that, in the context of the negotiations currently underway on the third Community Support Framework, I have asked for the provisions relating to the partnership principle to be fully respected, including for regional and local authorities and also for everything that concerns non-governmental organisations and associations. This principle must therefore be translated, in the context of the third CSF, in particular by the participation of all these partners in the follow-up committee. That, honourable Member, is the answer I can give you. I thank the Commissioner; I do not dispute his intentions and his actions in any way, which have moved in the right direction. However, things are very different. A centralising hand hovers over the Community Support Framework, so much so that in this era, on the question of European Union funding, we are witnessing a form of State, government and party delirium. I cannot show you certain television programmes here, but I can read you the Greek newspapers a few weeks before the elections. It was in the Sunday papers all over Greece: The Ministry of Public Works and Structural Funds: the work of the Minister; Ministry of Agriculture: the work carried out by the Minister of Agriculture - a few weeks before the elections -; Ministry of Telecommunications: the work carried out by the Minister of Telecommunications; Ministry of Education: the work carried out by the Ministry of Education, complete with a photograph of the Minister; Ministry of Employment: the work of the Ministry of Employment, complete with a photograph of the Minister, a photograph of the Deputy Minister and, behind all this, the symbol of the Community Support Framework. The elections are only a few weeks away. Parties and candidates are advertising themselves with funds from the European Union, from the Community Support Framework. I ask the Commissioner: what do we want to do? Will the Commission remain silent? Does it intend to discuss it? Will it raise the issue with the Greek Government or will we once again fall into the pathological situations of the previous Commission? Mr Alavanos, I saw that you were throwing all the documents you mentioned to your left. I would like you to give them to me so that I can read them - once translated - to see how much of them correspond to information, to communication, which I can only be happy about as Commissioner responsible for regional policy, and how much to propaganda. And then, if it is really necessary, I will make some observations or recommendations to the Greek Government. So I would be very happy, Mr President, if you would give me the documents, otherwise I will go and look for them on the floor of your group's benches. Having said that, I thought your question was more about partnership. Apart from the issues related to the pre-election period that you mentioned, I repeat that I am keen for local and regional authorities to participate together with non-governmental organisations. But I cannot even write something different from the text of the general regulation on the Structural Funds, which provides that the Commission will work with the governments of the Member States and that I will have the Greek Government as a partner, as my first partner. After that I will have to make sure that the partnership is widespread, decentralised, and I will make sure of that. I can do nothing but work with the Greek Government.

I will only mention here the wine and other goods produced in the Golan Heights and the occupied territories. Peace reigns in Palestine and Israel. Credibility and respect for the legality of treaties and agreements are essential if the European Union and Parliament intend to play an active political role. Israel is certain that Europe supports the security and stability of its state, but cannot ask us to be complicit in such serious violations. The Palestinians know that the European Union supports the affirmation of their state and their rights, but they need confirmation of this. Peace is not built on the violation of rights. Some Israelis, like the soldier Igal Moshe, who refused four days ago to leave for Lebanon and is now in prison, and some Palestinians, like those who have been refugees for 50 years and who, despite the demolition of their homes and their lives, want peace, are of the same opinion. It is above all respect for ourselves and for the democratic rules we have set for ourselves that demands this of us. Allow me to say, more prosaically, that this also concerns the loss of income for European citizens resulting from this violation of human and economic rights. Mr President, Members of the European Parliament, Mrs Morgantini, the questions that the Commission has formulated concern possible illegal exports to the European Community of products from Israeli settlements or occupied territories that benefit from preferential treatment and, consequently, call into question the correct application of the rules of preferential origin. The Commission has already given a written answer to a question from Mrs Morgantini on this subject in January 2000. However, Mrs Morgantini would like to obtain additional information. I will therefore endeavour to provide it to her. Firstly, when you refer to the lack of clarity in the agreement, I can tell you that the interim agreement on trade and related matters between the European Community and Israel specifies that it applies to the territory of the Member States of the European Community and, I quote, "to the territory of Israel". And that, therefore, from the perspective of the European Union, it is quite clear, in view of the clarifications set out in the written reply of Commissioner Christopher Patten, which I will read to you in the original language: "... as already explained in the communication, the Community cannot consider Israeli settlements or the occupied territories as part of Israeli territory for the purpose of implementing the EC-Israel agreement. This is a very sensitive issue because it relates to the wider question of borders, to Israelis and to Palestinians." We have repeatedly made this position known to the Israeli authorities during all official meetings between the Commission and the Israeli Minister, the most recent being on 21 January, when Prime Minister Shimon Peres met with Commission President Romano Prodi and Commissioner Christopher Patten. And as the Member has just pointed out, it is well known that Israel's interpretation of the territorial scope of the agreement does not coincide with the European Union's interpretation, but, from the Commission's point of view, our interpretation is unambiguous.
