In other words, experts are increasingly convinced that climate change and, in general, human activities are linked to the increase in natural disasters in recent years. In fact, temperatures have risen more in the last decade than in the rest of the entire century. That is why Europe must make a clear commitment to the Kyoto Protocol and promote concrete proposals. Secondly, I was rapporteur on the issue of civil protection in Europe, and I completely agree with the Commissioner when he proposes to create a European civil protection corps. Furthermore, given that this is an extraordinary disaster situation, an extraordinary budget line must be used. First of all, we would like to express our solidarity with the families who have lost loved ones in this terrible tragedy and with their communities. It is precisely the loss of human life that makes this disaster so extraordinary for Europe. It is regrettable that we do not have an instrument to provide assistance in such circumstances. I thank the Commissioner for his comprehensive statement on this matter and for suggesting that we should organise ourselves at European level to provide assistance to Member States and regions affected by such tragedies: that is important. Another thing we must bear in mind is that in the past we had a budget line, limited indeed, which was certainly not enough to do much, but which on several occasions was exploited by Members of this Parliament to propose interventions even in cases of minor disasters. Officials and ministers from the Member States would go to Brussels, have a private chat with the Commission, get a handful of euros and boast about the political achievement of being able to stand in their constituencies with the aid they had received. That is to say that the budget line in question was not very popular when it was abolished. I believe that this budget line should be reinstated. During the earthquake in Greece, a major disaster, the Community had no instrument to show its solidarity and sympathy for the Greek people in the same way as it did during the floods in France and this latest disaster. These are major disasters, we should have some kind of instrument, but we do not, so we should reinstate it and adopt strict rules so that it can only be used in the event of a major disaster. The funds saved could be carried forward from year to year so that we have an instrument of intervention in the event of a particularly serious event. This time Ireland has not been badly affected, despite several strong windstorms in the Atlantic. We have also had floods in Ireland and I would like to express my solidarity with the Irish people who have been affected. Ladies and gentlemen, we should not have short memories. It is true that the Council and Parliament have jointly decided to abolish the budget line for emergency aid. It is also true that there is a lot of European money, as Commissioner Barnier has indicated: for oyster farming and agriculture, Article 30 of the Regulation on rural development would be used, for forestry, Article 33; for businesses, the derogations provided for in competition law in Article 87(2) of the Treaty; for public structures, the Structural Funds.

I oppose Amendments 7 to 13, which were resolutely rejected by the Committee on Fisheries. Their content, for the most part, is unnecessary or is already mentioned in my text. In particular, I drew attention to the need to study the extent and effects of the interaction between farmed and wild salmon, the need to study the source of ISA, and the need to carry out more widespread testing of the virus in wild fish stocks. These amendments tabled by the Green component of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance seek to provide a justification for Amendment 13. This amendment is completely unacceptable and inappropriate, given that it not only seeks to maintain the obligation for the mandatory and immediate slaughter of all fish, but also seeks to prevent any fish from an infected farm, whether diseased or not, from being sold, and I must emphasize that, in accordance with current policy, no diseased fish are sold. No proposals are being made to change this situation, and under the proposed new regime, there is no question of selling diseased fish. Amendments 7 to 13 simply fail to take into account the reality demonstrated by the starkly contrasting statistics provided by Scotland and Norway. In Scotland, we have endured a draconian regime that has failed to achieve its objectives. In Norway, thanks to their longer experience, compulsory culling was abandoned some years ago, and a series of measures have led to the situation improving dramatically. It is in all our interests that in Scotland, we too can contain ISA and prevent its further spread. Last week, in Scotland, a joint ISA working group, made up of government and industry representatives, published a report. This comprehensive document considers a wide range of potential risks and recommends actions to address them in areas such as site-to-site transmission, safety measures to reduce leakage, waste and effluent treatment, detection and diagnostic methods, farrowing and rotation, disinfection of equipment, and many other measures. Some measures can and will be immediately implemented by local authorities using existing powers, and others will be included in codes of practice. All will be beneficial, not only in relation to ISA but also in driving higher standards in aquaculture generally, where this is needed. Colleagues, your vote in favour of my report as a whole and as adopted by the Fisheries Committee will be an important part of a wider package of measures concerning the control of ISA, based on the reality of the situation in Scotland and the lessons learned from the successes achieved by other countries. I congratulate Mr. Hudghton, I fully support his report, and I urge honourable Members of Parliament to do the same. As he mentioned, fish farming provides a crucial source of employment in the most remote parts of rural Scotland, and at a time when rural Scotland is suffering the worst recession in over a century, the aquaculture industry provides a vital boost to the rural economy on which many thousands of jobs depend, directly or indirectly. As he mentioned, over 85,000 tonnes of salmon are produced by Scottish farms in a sector that generates over €800 million each year.

Will the European Union be able to take a united position for the first time and develop a common policy in the face of such a complex problem? We also wonder whether the European Union has learned the lessons from the negative experience in Bosnia and the slightly more positive experience in Kosovo in terms of aid. Will we be able to achieve better results in the light of what has been learned in Macedonia and in four other countries? Given the particularly ambitious expectations, I do not think it is too much to say that this first step, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, is of crucial importance. This is not the only contribution of the European Union. There will soon be a debate on the Stability Pact, the CARA programme and short-term financing. The issue now under discussion is the Stabilisation and Association Agreements, which are a medium-term perspective. That is why I think this first agreement with Macedonia is so important, because it is a model. I am convinced that the other four countries are wondering what will happen. What will the European Union do with Macedonia? And will the same fate be reserved for the other four countries? That is why I believe that this first step, this model, is of crucial importance. Macedonia is a model for another reason too. The rapporteur has already mentioned this very clearly. It concerns inter-ethnic relations. In this respect we must not construct an overly idealised version of the situation. It became clear during the presidential elections that difficulties remain, but, compared to the rest of the region, Macedonia could still be considered a model. There are many advantages to be gained if we succeed, together with the Macedonians, in exporting this model to the rest of the Western Balkans. The same model also applies to regional cooperation. I fully agree with the rapporteur when he says that a balance must be found between promoting regional cooperation on the one hand, and maintaining openness to Bulgaria and Greece on the other, avoiding any closure. Mr President, Commissioner, if we succeed in taking this first step correctly, there will be many advantages to be gained. If we waste this opportunity, the damage will be even greater. Mr President, first of all, let me say that I have no difficulty in endorsing this well-reasoned report in principle. I would simply like to point out one point which I believe is missing from the report and which constitutes a serious problem for Macedonia and for the effectiveness of financial and other support from the Union. I am referring to the sanctions against Yugoslavia. In order to avoid any misunderstanding, I too believe that vigorous opposition to the Milosevic regime is necessary. But firstly, the sanctions also have a serious and negative impact on many neighbouring countries, including Macedonia, which are already in an extremely critical economic situation. Secondly, in violation of the humanitarian perspective and with counterproductive political effects, the entire Yugoslav population is being held responsible for the misdeeds of Milosevic and his henchmen.

I think it was important that everyone attached particular importance to the role of the European Union in development policy on an international scale. Everyone recognizes, and this was the subject of today's debate, that the European Union must necessarily strengthen the coherence of its various policies which contribute to development objectives in order to assume a more active and leading role in development policy internationally. I think that some of those who have spoken have also made it very clear that this responsibility for the coherence of European Union policies does not lie solely with the Council, the Commission, or even with Parliament. Rather, it must be the subject of concerted effort, reflection, and legislative and institutional preparation, both at Commission and Council level, and in the European Parliament itself. Moreover, some Members have put forward proposals in this regard, such as the creation of an observatory or working group to monitor the actions of the various policy areas in the specific field of development. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of recalling, as this was a key element of the Portuguese Presidency's programme, the statement on the need to give greater prominence to development policy in conjunction with the European Union's other policies, and particularly within its external policy. We consider this absolutely essential, because we will not be able to develop consistent measures in the area of policy coherence if we are unable to give development policy the importance it deserves as an instrument for affirming the principles and values that shape Europe's image in the international system. To do this, it may be necessary, as I have already said, to undertake a paradigm shift, to move beyond the post-colonial paradigm and to give development policy a wider European dimension. In this respect, I believe (and this has also been expressed in some of the comments made here) that the adoption of the new agreement, which will replace the Lomé Conventions, provides an important tool for renewing and giving new impetus to the concept of partnership with such a significant group of countries in the South, at a time when there is considerable and tangible instability in the negotiating processes at international level, such as the first round in Seattle. I detect a certain frustration in many of the contributions to this debate. On behalf of the Commission, I have presented you with a statement which I believe provides useful background information for this discussion. We will be submitting more detailed information in due course, dealing specifically with all the issues of coherence. This discussion is not new. We are currently working on it in the Commission, and when this work is completed, we will report on it, as many have asked for the report on coherence. I have no doubt that the increasing political attention being given to these problems, as has also been made clear in today's debate, will make it easier for the Commission and DG Development to give coherence the highest priority in the agenda of the tasks ahead.

This element of inflationary resurgence can be especially significant if it ends up generating cost-push inflation, which is why we always speak of the need for a wage policy compatible with the definitions of inflation we wish to propose. Parliament, in its analyses, has highlighted another issue: the evolution of stock market risk. From the Commission's point of view, this is significant, although we do not believe it is the substantial problem. In any case, I would like to emphasize that we currently have excellent opportunities to do more. I think we all agree that, after a decade of very weak growth and intolerable unemployment, there are some things to be done. There is a lack of public and private investment. Our research and development levels are too low compared to our competitors, and we have a low employment rate that reflects, among other factors, the imbalances in our labor market. Our objective must therefore be to make this economic recovery a lasting period of strong growth and job creation. Job creation remains the Commission's fundamental objective, as we reflected in the Prodi document, which was sent for debate at the Lisbon Summit, insofar as we are committed to full employment in the medium term. What policy should we implement to achieve these objectives? In our opinion, the Union is experiencing a period of economic recovery, but there is still unused production capacity. Not only the use of physical capital but also, above all, new sources of employment. The policy mix we implement should precisely allow for the full absorption of this capacity. We must define a macroeconomic policy that supports growth. It is true that this is not an expansionist policy in the sense of growth for growth's sake; it is simply a budgetary policy that can be consistent with price stability, but that also allows us to implement an appropriate monetary policy that facilitates growth. And this policy mix will undoubtedly be good for investment and will facilitate growth. The Union's growth potential, in our opinion, must pay special attention to certain factors. I believe that on most of them we agree with the analysis carried out by Parliament. First, it is essential to facilitate private investment. The Union must contribute to fostering entrepreneurship and generating employment through this means, but public investment must not be forgotten. Public investment has been the great sinker of recent years, and an improvement in public finances must clearly allow us to improve public investment, which must be done, however, while respecting our commitments to fiscal consolidation. Our major commitment for the future must be to research and development and human capital. These are two of the major challenges we face for Lisbon. We believe it is essential to advance these challenges with quantified objectives, with specific definitions that will ultimately allow us to achieve what we all aim for: clear improvements in productivity that make possible greater growth in our society, with job growth that closes some of the gap we have lost in recent years. This is the policy that, as a Commission, we have defended and will continue to defend in Lisbon. Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) The following reports are now under joint debate:

Fourth and final aspect I would like to submit to your consideration, necessarily regarding this aspect of development policies: the role of the Development Council. The role that the Development Council can play within the framework of Union policies has been examined, particularly in recent months. It is well known that the difference in status between development and other policies at the Union level is glaring—one need only look at the difficult conditions under which the budgeting or non-budgetization of the EDF has been raised—and it is difficult to accept that we can instill greater coherence in European Union policies without a more active role and greater involvement of the Development Council in advising on political decisions that are eminently related to the sphere of development and that are adopted in other Councils, in other decision-making centers, ranging from the Agriculture and Fisheries Councils to the Environment Councils, but in relation to which the Development Council has so far had no opportunity to be heard or to intervene. Therefore, without a more active role for the Development Council in the overall coordination of political decisions which, while directly affecting the European Union's development policy, are adopted outside its decision-making centre, it will undoubtedly be difficult to implement a policy of greater European Union coherence in relation to development objectives. In this regard, too, the words and reflections of the European Parliament will be timely and will be welcomed as such. To begin with, I would like to say something about the negotiations between the EU and the ACP countries, which have concluded successfully. I must say that participating in those negotiations was an extremely positive experience. I was able to see the Member States working as a team, which is a truly rewarding experience. Both parties were deeply satisfied when the negotiations were over, not only because they were over, but because we all knew that we had achieved something in common, the EU and the 71 ACP countries. This is something the world needs and represents a very positive signal in the context of the debates on globalization. I would like to highlight some of the main innovations of the new agreement. We explicitly addressed corruption; we established a framework for addressing the immigration problem for the first time. We promoted participatory approaches and established civil society consultations on reforms and policies the EU will support. We refocused development policies on poverty reduction strategies. We based the allocation of funds not only on an assessment of each country's needs but also on the results of its policies. We created an investment facility to support private sector development. We streamlined instruments and introduced a new rolling programming system, allowing the Community and the beneficiary country to regularly adjust their cooperation programs. We decentralized administrative, and in some cases, financial, responsibilities to the local level to make cooperation more effective. We improved the regulatory framework for trade and investment development. We promoted cooperation in all areas of relevance to trade, including emerging issues such as labor standards and the links between the environment and trade.

In this case, Mr President, we certainly have a decalogue. A whole series of problems have been cited but, with all due respect, it seems that the Commission, in a way, does not dare to say "we should act like this" for any of them. It seems to me that you have only insisted - and even too much in my opinion - on one point, namely the fact that little by little the objective that you consider a priority is to dismantle "superfluous" activities. However, we are attentive, Mr President, because we have experienced a crisis of confidence in the Commission and we have counted on this Commission - at least the majority of this Parliament - precisely so that, above all, the reform of the Commission would be accompanied by a strengthening, a new identity, a feeling of being once again led by a watchful hand. Let us take the fact that the Commission wants to dismantle or proposes to dismantle, not considering itself up to the task, for example, of the powers conferred on it by the Treaty to implement common policies. What are we asking, in a certain sense, of a government? What are we asking of this, so to speak, ambiguous and particular structure that is the European Community? It is good that common resources have a supranational government and that they are not delegated to the Member States or the TAOs, as has happened in the past. I find that you are submitting the same menu to us, but in a more serious way, by limiting yourself, as you say, to the duties of designing some White Paper, as you have proposed to us. I fear - even if you are shaking your head, Mr President - that this will translate into what some countries have been thinking for years, that is to say, that the Commission must be a good secretariat for the Council of Ministers. If this is the role the Commission intends to assume over the next five years, we, as committed federalists, are certain that it is not the right path to follow. We will challenge you and judge what the Commission intends to do. The reform is important, but if it leads to a degradation, a reduction, and a diminution of the Commission's supranational powers, the future of European integration, the future that the founding fathers envisioned for the European Commission, will be at stake. As for the other points, Mr. President, I would raise, for example, that of economic and social policy. Certainly, the European social model is experiencing a serious crisis; certainly, unemployment is, and this is no coincidence, a problem that none of our policies has managed to resolve. But it is not certain that we will be able to resolve unemployment by drawing up the list of problems we have spoken about in the past, without having a clear vision, without a proposal, the one that means that there are economies in Europe that are moving at one of the fastest paces and which are, and this is no coincidence, those that have been able to make flexibility in the labour market and in business their number one objective.

I can only reiterate this. It is absolutely important to involve the public with adequate information and a consultation procedure. This is also reiterated in recital 14. I would like to say to Mr Bowe that he, just like my Scottish colleague, will be able to continue enjoying a glass of Scotch whisky from time to time with a clear conscience. The Commission has not found it necessary to regulate the very limited water consumption required for whisky production. I would now like to comment in a little more detail on some of the issues under consideration. Limiting the release of hazardous substances into water must be one of the most important objectives. I am pleased to see that the amendments tabled by Parliament focus on this aspect. The Commission fully supports the proposal to include the commitments of the OSPAR Convention in the text. However, their exact content and scope must be adhered to. As I have already said, the objective and the timetable of the OSPAR Convention are above all a political commitment. The introduction of a legally binding timetable would not be in line with this commitment. However, it must be ensured that the Member States and the Community are obliged to take action to achieve those targets and to stick to the timetable. I therefore welcome Amendments Nos 6, 10, 14, 24, 58, 60 and 88. The Commission cannot accept Amendment No 19, which defines dangerous substances differently from the OSPAR Convention. The Commission proposal introduces a clear procedure for the selection of substances, which makes a definition unnecessary. Although I myself agree with the content of Amendments Nos 79 and 106, these amendments go beyond the commitments under the OSPAR Convention. I cannot therefore accept them. The Commission can also accept in principle Amendment No 60, which requires a timetable for the Commission proposal on the restriction of priority substances. Amendment No 59 introduces the requirement for a constant review of the list of priority substances. However, this would lead to legal uncertainty as to the status of the list and therefore the amendment cannot be accepted. The request, in Amendments 60 and 93, for a guide list and a list of substances for which sufficient data are not available cannot be accepted. Such lists would have an uncertain legal status and would not fit in with the procedures for the adoption of the priority list. In this respect, I would like to underline that the OSPAR Convention does not in any way amend existing Community legislation on nitrates from agricultural activities. The Nitrates Directive will therefore not be affected by this Framework Directive. I appreciate the fact that Parliament has shown flexibility on the very sensitive and difficult issue of water pricing. I fully support the request for the price of water to be set at a level that provides an incentive to use water resources sustainably. I also support the request for an adequate contribution from each sector to cover its costs. I can therefore accept in part and in principle Amendments Nos 43-46 and Amendment No.

I would like to draw your attention to one thing: it is dangerous to re-design the entire governance of the European Union from here. I would clearly advocate subsidiarity. If we are able to define the scope of our governance, that would be very positive, in my view. Moreover, I believe that subsidiarity also deserves consideration. It cannot be just the Commission; it must be our states, our parliaments, and our civil society that also reflect on it. Finally, I would like to briefly address the last objective, which we consider absolutely fundamental: the stabilization of the continent and the strengthening of Europe's role in the world. Here, I would say that there is agreement and support regarding the priority of South-Eastern Europe, regarding enlargement and—as I have already mentioned—the integration process and the strengthening of the Euro-Mediterranean program, as well as our capacity for conflict prevention, and regarding an issue that is very little discussed: the North-South challenge. We must not forget Africa, the continent completely abandoned not only by God but also by Europe, nor our important contribution to development cooperation. Finally, an issue in which we, as the world's most important economic and trading power, bear increasing responsibility: the European Union's voice in the world. This does not only mean a proactive stance with regard to the Millennium Round. It means reforming the United Nations and the international financial institutions, in which Europe bears enormous responsibility. And above all, and I conclude with this, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we must be able to express this in understandable and clear language, by changing, to some extent, the jargon we use. We cannot expect Europeans, who are living through times of profound change, to join us and share our enthusiasm if we continue to use a very difficult-to-understand language and turn our backs on them. This is the most important means of increasing and strengthening trust, which, in any case, I hope, will be measured in the next European elections. Mr President of the Commission, first of all, on behalf of my group, I would like to assure you that we share your starting point and support the core of the analysis and strategy you have presented in this House today, namely that Europe is facing major and clearly political challenges. Political because we are in a process of further development. Even if the economic building blocks are still being worked on, we are leaving the purely functional entity of Europe behind and turning to a political perspective marked by greater challenges. Enlargement is a challenge of a political nature. The task of creating an area of cooperation in the fields of justice and home affairs and tackling the problems of asylum, immigration, and crime is also deeply political. This also applies to the implementation of a common security and defense policy. It is precisely the political nature of these tasks that makes them complex to solve. This political nature means that questions of sovereignty are involved, which in turn makes citizens and voters more sensitive.

Sixth and last: we proclaim that ETA's terrorism and violence must disappear and that it must stop hijacking the will of the Basque citizens, who, freely and without violent coercion, must be able to decide on their future. Just three months ago, I spoke in this House, like many other Members, to congratulate the Irish and British on their success in reaching the Northern Ireland agreement. In Northern Ireland, too many people have been killed and injured in the last thirty years... too many families torn apart. Until now, and unfortunately, precisely the opposite has happened in Spain and France with regard to the ongoing conflict in the Basque Country. We, the Basque Country, are convinced that a definitive solution to the current struggle can only be found through an open process of dialogue and negotiation without a limited agenda. Before January 20, for nineteen months, the only violent death we witnessed in the Kingdom of Spain was that of José Luis Geresta, a member of ETA, in March 1999. Despite this and the arrests made by the Spanish and French police, including those of ETA negotiators with the agreement of the Spanish Government, ETA respected the unilateral ceasefire. Then, last November, before the ceasefire ended, the Spanish Government spokesperson, Mr. Piqué, declared that his Government had done and would do in the future everything possible to hinder current initiatives aimed at achieving a political solution in the Basque Country. We, the Basque Country, have on many occasions lamented the loss of human life. We share with all Basque citizens the suffering of our people. We are committed to dialogue and ready to collaborate with all those eager to find a democratic solution for the Basque Country. Twenty years have passed since the question of Northern Ireland was first raised in this Parliament. Allow me to ask: Quosque tandem - Noiz arte? Madam President, thank you very much for giving me the floor. I swear I'm having trouble speaking now, after the speech I just heard. When my colleague Mr. Alonso Puerta mentioned some of ETA's victims, he did not name—and I believe he did so out of respect for me—a person whom ETA killed 16 years ago. A Socialist senator, also a Basque parliamentarian, whose name was Enrique Casas. (Loud applause) Madam President, Senator Enrique Casas was my husband. I was widowed with four children, the youngest of whom was eight months old. The only fault my husband had—he was Andalusian by birth, a Basque senator, sent by the Basque Government to defend the Basque Country in Madrid—was that he was a socialist, but above all a democrat, nothing more than a democrat. I myself, Madam President, have never spoken about this in this Assembly. Only on the day ETA declared the truce did I welcome it as a hope for the entire Basque people, for all of Spain and Europe.

the Council statement on the European Union's position on developments in the Cyprus question; the report (A4-0029/2000) by Mr Brok, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy, on the proposal for a Council regulation on the implementation of measures in the framework of the pre-accession strategy for Cyprus and Malta (COM(1999)0535 - C5-0308/1999 - 1999/0199(CNS)). Mr Seixas da Costa will speak on behalf of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, I would like to provide some information regarding the resumption of the inter-Cypriot negotiations and the latest developments on this issue. I think it is obvious to everyone that what happened in Helsinki at the end of last year, as well as the new climate, particularly noticeable in relations between the European Union and Turkey, reflects a background at Community level from which the very framework of relations between the two communities in Cyprus itself cannot remain unaffected. I would like to stress that, at the beginning of December last year, the first new round of negotiations between the Cypriot communities of the north and south of the island took place in New York after several years of interruption. These rounds of negotiations were indirect discussions mediated by the United Nations Special Representative, Álvaro de Souto. A second round of talks followed in January of this year, opening on 31 January, and a third round is scheduled to begin on 23 May in New York. There is a possibility, although this has not yet been definitively confirmed, that these talks could take place directly and continuously, with work continuing until September of this year. Four main issues were addressed during this discussion: questions of security, government structure, territorial adjustment, and the refugee and compensation issues resulting from the situation following the island's division. However, since it was agreed that it would be possible to include further issues, Rauf Denktash, the representative of the northern part of the island, proposed three new topics: the question of sovereignty, the question of confidence-building measures, and the question of lifting the embargo on products from the north of the island. Two main developments have emerged in the discussions so far: The possibility of establishing a direct information channel between the European Union and the northern part of the island is emerging, without this necessarily implying recognition of this part of the island as an entity with its own legal personality at the international level. The goal is to facilitate the adoption of the acquis communautaire in the event of a possible accession of the entire island, should the global problem of the island's division be resolved in the meantime. The second development that we consider important is the statement by the Secretary-General of the United Nations at the end of the first day of talks, in which he assured that a comprehensive settlement of the situation would entail recognition of the specific characteristics of the northern part of the island. This position expressed by the Secretary-General of the United Nations is a factor that must naturally be taken into account in our future analysis.

This is an important step towards a European natural judge (which is one of our aspirations), based on mutual trust between Member States and between their respective judicial systems, on the trust of European citizens towards any European judge, but also on scrupulous respect for fundamental freedoms and rights and, in particular, procedural guarantees. It is on this point that Parliament has rightly changed - in my opinion - the balance proposed by the Council, with a clear and resolute strengthening of these procedural guarantees in all its amendments. Mr President, as the rapporteur has pointed out, Parliament has paid particular attention to one issue, that of telephone interceptions, which it has decided to delete. On behalf of the European People's Party, I have tabled an amendment to the resolution calling on the Council to propose a text on the matter as soon as possible, since the absence of regulation is harmful. The regulation submitted to us was incomplete, and therefore inadequate. However, the absence of rules could also lead - and in fact has often led - to abuses in the telecommunications sector. Another point on which I would like to dwell, also widely discussed, concerns the use of videoconferences in the case of persons under investigation, accused, indicted or on trial. On this issue too, I have asked, on behalf of the European People's Party, that the Council draw up a convention as soon as possible to clarify and complete the legislation, which is clearly insufficient. Mr President, we members of the European People's Party, with a few exceptions, will vote in favour of the amendments approved in committee and, obviously, in favour of the amendments that we ourselves have presented. Mr President, part of the construction of Europe passes, in our opinion, through the construction of a common legal system that includes administrative law, civil law, substantive and procedural, and criminal law, substantive and procedural, of the Europe that we want to build. The Convention on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters, which we are examining today, is only one piece of this great European corpus juris, which finds its natural foundation in fundamental human rights and freedoms. Therefore, judicial and criminal cooperation must also take place in the strictest respect for fundamental rights, principles that are the basis of our culture and our civilization: I am thinking of due process, in particular the rights of defense, the impartiality and third-party nature of the judge, the length of judicial procedures for which my country, Italy, unfortunately holds a negative record with regard to the number of convictions, of cases pending before the European Court of Human Rights. The limitations of fundamental rights, which are justified because they are linked to a real or presumed violation of the criminal law, cannot and must not find application in the fields of law. The report that the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights has largely modified with respect to the original approach, accepting many amendments presented by us, still raises some doubts, linked to the way in which it intends to regulate telephone interceptions and videoconferences.

However, the Court of Justice has not explicitly addressed the issue of visas and residence permits; consequently, the Member States have not been able to clarify these issues either. Moreover, the Member States have not complied with the Court's provisions on the abolition of work permits, and to this day they are placing unacceptable obstacles to the provision of cross-border services, which are often insurmountable, especially for small businesses. As regards self-employed workers, the current Community legal acquis does not provide for third-country nationals to provide services across the border. Legislative action is therefore necessary. Both draft directives aim to facilitate the freedom to provide services by EU businesses. They do not concern the original rights of third-country nationals that can be traced back to freedom of movement. All regulations, entry into the Community and questions of residence must be considered in relation to the freedom to provide services. Like the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market of the European Parliament, I am therefore of the opinion that the legal basis chosen by the Commission is the right one, while I do not find the opinion expressed in the expert report of the Council's legal service valid. Therefore, in my opinion, there are no well-founded legal arguments that could prevent these two draft directives from proceeding expeditiously through the Council. I also believe that the amendments proposed by Parliament to the Commission's proposal should help the Council to approve the directives. Many of our amendments are linked to concerns that have also emerged in the Council; and we are therefore trying to reconcile these concerns with the mandate that we derive from the legislation currently in force and from economic considerations. I can only appeal to the Commission to adopt, if possible in their entirety, the amendments accepted by Parliament, even where they differ considerably from the Commission's original proposals. I am deeply convinced that on this basis we will be able to find an agreement more easily in the Council. And now let's move on to the most important amendments proposed by us. One of the substantial differences is this: the current proposal refers to a system that provides for the issuing of a service provision card and requires the indication of each individual task performed. Well, we propose to abolish the obligation to declare each individual task to the host State as it appears difficult to implement in practice. As a counterpart, of course, any potential difficulty must be resolved before the aforementioned card is issued. We therefore propose to make the requirements for its issuing more stringent. Evidence of regular employment, legal residence and insurance coverage must not only be provided at the time of issuing the card but also during its entire validity and for the three months thereafter. In this way, the host State is assured that the employed or self-employed worker, once the task has been completed, will actually return to the State of origin and that in the event of illness or injury they will have insurance coverage.

Furthermore, there are problems of a different nature within the regions. It is clear that it is primarily the local and regional authorities - and, consequently, to a lesser extent the national authorities - that are best placed to assess the situation and formulate an appropriate policy. I cannot therefore support the idea of delegating competences to the European level in this respect. Nor should we forget employment policy in general. Here too, the structure of the economy differs in the various Member States and the same applies to the ways in which the current level of employment has been achieved. It is not appropriate to apply a single type of policy, perhaps with many derogations and adjustments. This would mean that the European Union is unfairly taking competences away from the Member States and that the Brussels bureaucracy is needlessly interposing between the two sides. It is better for the Member States themselves to take measures to promote employment. They know the situation better than the Commission. For this reason, I am reluctant to formulate Community measures to promote employment, including in the tourism sector. It is totally unacceptable for us that Parliament should seek to achieve this objective indirectly by extending its powers. Mr President, you will understand that we cannot vote in favour of the resolution in its current form. First of all, I would like to congratulate Mr Viceconte on the work he has done on the report, a very thorough document which we support, just as we supported the original report on which the document is based, that of the High Level Group set up by the European Commission. I hope that the Commission will not forget the Group it has set up and that it will make use of it and not leave it lying idle in a corner. The tourism sector is essentially a small business and is therefore a fertile area for job creation. As has already been said in the debate, three million potential jobs within the next ten years is a goal worth pursuing. Europe can no longer refuse to give the fastest growing sector of its economy the recognition it deserves because of its economic and social position, and it must do so both politically and through appropriate measures. We need a more dynamic vision, based on the contribution of tourism to job creation. We need to recognise that the sector is predominantly a cross-border business and therefore deserves a European policy with a stimulating, innovative and proactive approach aimed at sustainable business development. I know that the Commissioner is a computer enthusiast, and I must say that he has rubbed off on me too. Well, tourism and computer science are two sectors that go very well together. There are therefore many reasons why the tourism industry can be considered as an ideal testing ground for integrating job creation strategies. Let us look at these reasons in detail. The importance of tourism for the economy and its growth potential is clear. Various sections of the population work in the tourism sector, in particular the most vulnerable groups such as young people, women and unskilled workers.

Each chairperson has as many votes as the group has members. There was a vote on this point. As I recall, the outcome of this vote was as follows: 422 to 180, with a few abstentions. That means that all groups, with the exception of the non-attached members—but they are not a group—agreed; only your group was of the opinion that we should proceed as you proposed here. All the others disagreed. That was the decision. Now I would like to say something about the matter itself. We have confidence in the Commission, in Romano Prodi, and the vast majority of our group, as everyone knows, expressed its confidence in Romano Prodi and the Commission after a difficult process. But we also believe that we must conduct a debate on this Commission strategy in an orderly manner, not just on the basis of an oral statement here in the European Parliament, but also on the basis of a document adopted by the Commission and describing this program for five years. There is no such document! The Commission will present the programme for 2000 in February. We said, OK, if the Commission doesn't want to draw up the 2000 programme in January, then we'll do it in February. We agreed to this. We don't really want to argue with the Commission; rather, we believe that, if at all possible, the Commission and Parliament should go down a common path. But we as Parliament are also the Commission's controller. And not everything that comes out of the Commission has to be our opinion. I want us to be able to prepare properly for a debate on the five-year programme in the parliamentary groups. You can't prepare when you hear a statement here and have no idea what such a statement contains. That is why we recommend – and I have the impression that the Commission is also open to this idea – that we hold the debate in February on the Commission's long-term programme up to 2005 – I hope the Commission will have agreed on a programme to propose to us by then – and that we also hold the debate in February on the Commission's legislative programme for the year 2000. It is therefore also a sensible factual connection that advises us to hold the debate on both programmes together. That is why my group categorically rejects the Socialist Group's proposal! (Applause from the PPE-DE Group) I propose that we vote on the Socialist Group's request to put the Commission's statement on its strategic objectives back on the agenda. (Parliament rejected the request.) President. I have another request before me for Wednesday, concerning the oral question on the capital tax. The PPE-DE Group requests that this item be removed from the agenda. Would anyone like to explain the motion on behalf of the group? Madam President, since I hear a bit of laughter from the Socialists, I've been told that large sections of the Socialist Group would also like to see this item removed from the agenda because the vote of the working group of the relevant colleagues from the Socialist Group was not available during the vote in the Conference of Presidents.

I believe that the idea of creating an observatory for the development of this coherence between Community policies and cooperation and development policy is sufficiently wise and relevant; its scope should not be limited to Community policies, but should also cover the actions or policies of the Member States, including the actions of economic groups, which seems important to me. Each year, this observatory will have to produce a report on the development and impacts of these policies and their combination. I have left until the end a question that seems fundamental to me and which must be recorded and approved by this Parliament. This new objective of minimizing contradictions between cooperation and development policy and other policies must be a valid objective not only within the European Union, but also at global level, given the increasing globalization of the economy. If we want fair world trade, we must impose this same principle at the next round of multilateral negotiations of the World Trade Organization, because it would be contradictory for the European Union to impose on itself an iron, but fair, discipline, while the United States and other major powers then do the opposite and approve of what we are not doing. That is why it is right and fundamental that these principles be established at the next round of the World Trade Organization. Mr. President, the Director-General of the DG for Development has stated that producing a report on the coherence of EU policies with development policies, before the presentation, next spring, of the development policy document itself, is tantamount to putting the cart before the horse. It does not matter that the Commission, subject to the requirement to produce an annual report, clearly set out in the Council resolution, has produced only one "non-document." The real problem is that when it comes to tackling global poverty, these oxen are climbing a hill, and the wagon of other EU policies is so heavy that development policy is actually being gently pulled back. Time and again, development policy is forgotten or given an afterthought when the European Union's major policies have already been reviewed. Take the new chocolate directive, which states that EU countries spend more on chocolate each year than on development aid. This directive has not undergone any proper development assessment, and producing countries, 90% of which are our ACP partners, estimate that it could reduce cocoa farmers' incomes by at least 15%. Take the fisheries agreements, in which we acknowledge the unsustainability of current fishing practices in EU waters. At the same time, we are negotiating joint ventures that will allow greater access for European large-scale fishing vessels to the waters of developing countries at the expense of 190 million small-scale fishermen from those countries around the world. Take trade agreements. As Mr. Nielson said this morning about Lomé, preferential access only applies to essentially all products from developing countries. In other words, when EU trade interests are at stake, poverty considerations evaporate.

Ladies and gentlemen, this is what we are doing and what we are committed to. I believe that we have worked well in these months, in these weeks and I believe that we will be able to work in the coming months of 2000 during the Portuguese Presidency B which is truly doing a magnificent and extraordinary job B and continue during the French Presidency which, without a doubt, will continue to work with the same promptness and ability shown on other occasions. I wanted to say that in the meantime at least four European Councils will take place, the one in Lisbon, the one in Feria and two European Councils during the French Presidency. On these four occasions, the Heads of Government are also prepared to continue to analyse these aspects, so as not to miss the train and to be able to proceed, by 2003, to the deployment of what has been agreed, should this prove necessary. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, I believe that in this regard we are working with determination, with energy and with the great support of all the governments and all the Heads of Government. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say two more things on this matter. The European Union has the obligation to carry out this operation in contact with the third countries to which I have referred, countries which, although geographically part of Europe, are not yet part of the European Union. They are countries with which we must work, which we must integrate, because in the event of a crisis B which we obviously avoid B all forces and all countries will be more than welcome. Secondly, we must be able to establish a fluid and transparent relationship with the Atlantic Alliance. The operations that we will have to carry out in the future will be of three types. The first type will be the operations that will involve European forces within the framework of the Atlantic Alliance. The second type of operations will involve European forces and will be directed by them themselves, but will use the means and infrastructure of the Atlantic Alliance. The third type of operations involves the Europeans acting alone. In the first and the second, we will need the cooperation of the Atlantic Alliance and, therefore, to establish a transparent, positive and trust-based framework of relations between us and the Atlantic Alliance, as it should be, to the mutual advantage of both the Atlantic Alliance and ourselves. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have spoken of the capabilities that we are prepared to deploy, of the timetable that we intend to apply and of what has been done in recent months. I would also like to add that we must not forget that we will have to deal with crisis operations in the civilian sphere too. Humanitarian crises, crises involving the forces of law and order, as unfortunately are currently occurring in Kosovo, in the Balkans: we are also providing or trying to provide solutions to all of these in proportion to our capabilities. Together with the Commission, together with Commissioner Patten, we are working in this direction. On Saturday morning I will meet with all the Interior Ministers of the fifteen Member States of the European Union to try to make them see the need we all have to mobilise the police, too, because there are times when a crisis that begins with a military necessity develops in such a way that a few months later, more than the military, the police force is needed, and more than the police, in the final phase of the crisis, perhaps judges or institutions that can create the democratic institutions that the country needs are needed.

Commitments that are poorly omitted internally are clearly highlighted externally. The way in which the Commission fails to address cohesion seems serious to me. It puts in second place a principle of the Treaties - that of economic and social cohesion - which must inform all policies and measures of the European institutions, it seems to ignore that serious delays persist in the European regions and forgets that enlargement justifies caution in regional policy. Without real convergence, the cohesion of the European Union is put at risk. Let us remember the sixth periodic report on the situation of the regions of the European Union, drawn up by the Commission. In that document it is confirmed that, for an average level of development to which a grade of 100 is attributed, the ten regions defined as "strongest" reach an average of 158 and the ten defined as "weakest" stand at 50. Draw your conclusions. 50 is exactly the level of development of the region I come from, the Azores, a region defined as ultraperipheral in the Treaties. I await the report that the Council has asked the Commission to draw up by December 1999. I conclude by reaffirming my conviction that without economic and social cohesion there will be no cohesion at all, only disintegration. Madam President, Mr President, we need - or rather European public opinion needs - a strong Commission because, in the form desired by the Treaties, as desired by the will of the people, the Commission is the driving force of European construction, this sort of Sisyphean boulder that together, after each enlargement, we must begin to push towards the top again. A strong Commission, therefore, but one that relies on a Parliament, a Parliament that is therefore your ally, although a little inconvenient, whose messages we must grasp and, taking advantage of this brief intervention, I would like to launch a couple of them. First of all, Mr President, I believe that if your two predecessors were essentially dedicated to building an internal market and introducing the single currency, it is up to you to develop all the civic value at the heart of the European construction. You must not allow yourself to be absorbed by the sole problem of enlargement, regardless of its importance. We must go further, towards reconciliation between citizens and Europe and, in particular, between citizens who are victims of economic, social and, in the future, certainly also technological fractures. The market and competition will not guarantee the promotion of scientific development, of new technologies and access to them, nor the availability and social effectiveness of major collective services, such as health, education, transport, communications, water and so on. Your action programme, your objectives are reserved, if not silent, precisely on the necessary relaunch of public investment. They are also discreet, if not silent, on the consolidation and financing of major public services and services of general interest. This is an absolute priority, Mr President, if you want to reconcile Europe and its citizens and make them choose Europe instead of Jörg Haider. Madam President, the Commission has rightly made food safety one of its priorities.

That was the case this time too, but I think it is a little excessive to dwell so much on these 100 amendments. I would also like to point out that our coordinator in the Committee on Budgetary Control is Mr Pomés Ruiz, who comes from Spain, and who has made an important contribution to the debate on the Spanish side. Mr President, one of the most important elements mentioned is the rapporteur's proposal to set up a permanent committee to deal with the parameters applicable to public administration. This is a very important proposal. I am only surprised that the Socialist Group is attacking it by countering it with a proposal from Mrs Morgan which aims to delete it completely. I am not clear about the situation. On the one hand, there is a lot of praise for the rapporteur, on the other, Mrs Morgan, on this point as on others, is following a scorched earth strategy aimed essentially at deleting the entire content of the report. I do not know whether the intention of this strategy is to accommodate Commissioner Kinnock. However, I know Commissioner Kinnock; I know that he wants to listen to our demands and is prepared to distance himself from them if he deems it necessary. I do not think that such a scorched earth strategy is indispensable. Finally, I would like to refer to the issue of civil servants. I completely disagree with Mr Haarder. I do agree that the text on civil servants is not at all sufficient. First of all, the emphasis is placed on the importance of public service in general, and secondly, a series of proposals are listed, the question being raised as to whether they are reasonable or whether they will actually lead to improvements. For example, we have dealt with the BATs, which is important, but at the same time we want to eliminate the temporary staff of the Commission. These two proposals are contradictory and I cannot understand how they could have been tabled. Mr President, since Plato's Republic, the Western world has been systematically tempted to replace the government of the people with the government of the wise. Already on the first occasion, our Parliament asked for the assistance of the wise men to evaluate the performance of the European Commission, and they seized the opportunity to decide its fate. In this second report, the wise men go even further, criticizing the political groups in this Parliament that would have hesitated to accept the resignation of the European Commission because of the common political affiliation of some of its members and arguing that the problem can be solved by requiring the Commissioners to renounce all political affiliations. Again according to the wise men, the Parliament should renounce the prerogatives of control of the European Commission and should be replaced in this task by a committee to guarantee good morals in public life, a permanent and non-elective body, presumably made up of another group of wise men. In their second report, the wise men teach us that Italy is financed by the Cohesion Fund, that two-thirds of the Structural Funds are allocated to the ERDF and the Social Fund, that in the Structural Funds the principle of additionality and the principle of complementarity are equivalent, that the agricultural lobby imposes the financing of rural development through the Guarantee Section of the EAGGF and that the partnership principle applies only to the Commission and the Member States.

I would like to point out that the first, URBAN, aims to improve the quality of life of citizens living in different European cities, while the second, INTERREG, aims to promote cohesion and recognise the diversity and potential of the European Union's regions, at a time when the outermost regions are about to be included in Chapters B and C. Like the rapporteur, we regret the exclusion of Chapter IIIA. With regard to INTERREG, we consider the reference to the creation of a European observatory for the effects of cooperation very appropriate. We thank the rapporteurs, particularly Mr Decourrière, for their sensitivity to regional policy and for taking our amendments into account. I hope that the Commissioner will accept our proposal. Mr President, in the context of the various initiatives we are debating this afternoon, I would like to restrict myself strictly to a discussion of one programme, URBAN. One thing is certain: it is only because the European Parliament stubbornly insisted on continuing this initiative that we are debating this program today. The Commission's intention was to phase out this and other initiatives. But thanks to Parliament's proposal and the Commission's timely insight, URBAN is being continued. I think we can congratulate ourselves on this. But what arguments did the Commission, in this specific case Commissioner Monika Wulf-Mathies and the Director-General, Mr. Eneko Landaburu, put forward for phasing out URBAN? They had a convincing argument. Urban issues are too important to be limited to a program with very little funding. Today we have the program, I think we have achieved something important: URBAN has become a symbol of identity in the European Union. But addressing Commissioner Barnier, I would like to say that I share the arguments put forward by the Commissioner and the Director-General, because they were right, very right. The urban dimension must be given much greater consideration in all structural funds. Given the budgetary resources our cities require—80% of Europe's population lives there, and that's where the good and bad examples of what Europe has to offer can be found—I believe that this European dimension must be taken into account, and that this URBAN program cannot be used as an excuse for not analyzing the problems comprehensively, not setting priorities, and thus not allocating disproportionately higher budgets to urban-related programs within all European funds. Therefore, I believe it is unnecessary to examine the multitude of factors that justify this investment in urban areas. The factors are known, and I would like to tell the Commissioner that we count on his understanding in this regard. The cross-sectoral approach enshrined in the new EQUAL initiative is to be welcomed. At the same time, however, it is crucial that the programme addresses the blatant discrimination that particularly affects disabled people: physical barriers in the workplace faced by people with reduced mobility, visual information systems that cannot be used by blind workers, and working methods that do not allow people with learning disabilities or mental illnesses to participate.

The implementation of this component is the responsibility of the Member States and national authorities; and component C, which organizes interregional cooperation between different regions of the Member States or third countries by networking experiences concerning components A and B as well as cooperation in the field of research and technological development, a subject to be defined with the European Commission, which is responsible for its implementation. The new Interreg program, as it was sent to us, takes into account the needs generated by the enlargement to the CEECs and to the island and outermost regions. The Commission proposes that we distribute the Interreg allocation as follows: from 50 to 80% for component A, 6% for component C, the difference for component B, that is to say from 14 to 44% maximum. The European Commission draws up the list of regions eligible for components A and B. It relied essentially on the map of regions eligible during the previous programming period. The outermost regions may receive support under strand B. The Commission draws up a list of priority areas and eligible measures which are not exhaustive for strand A, but exhaustive for strand B. It reserves the right to subsequently propose themes which it considers important for the exchange of experience and enhanced cooperation between regions, for strand C. The procedure for adopting the programmes is laid down in the general regulation on the structural funds. The proposals are drawn up by the Member States and submitted for approval to the European Commission, which checks their compliance with the general guidelines adopted. These proposals must include a number of elements: an overview of cross-border or transnational strategies and priorities, a description of the measures necessary for their implementation and an indicative financing plan. I am one of the large majority of parliamentarians who voted to maintain the Interreg Community initiative programme. I regret that Parliament was not informed of the evaluation of the previous programme - which would have allowed for optimal effectiveness of the new measures implemented, but I know how difficult this operation is - I also regret an extremely short work schedule, since the text was examined in parliamentary committee on 24 November and 26 January, and I also regret that neither the regions nor the representative regional organisations were involved in the preparation of the programme. By promoting cross-border, transnational and interregional cooperation, this cross-cutting instrument is the very embodiment of a regional policy with a European dimension that promotes harmonious and balanced development of the Community territory. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, the Conference on Rural Development, held in Cork from 7 to 9 November 1996, defined rural development as one of the priorities of the European Union, since it is essential for agriculture, to support its existence and continued development, to provide farmers with an environment equipped with the necessary infrastructure and services, essential also for greater respect for the environment and a better quality of life, and finally essential for diversification and the creation of jobs.

That said, one can positively assess the different organization of the guidelines which, leaving aside geographical objectives, are intended for sectoral policies. If, in theory, this can satisfy the requirements of concentration and therefore effectiveness of interventions, a question arises of itself, the question of whether the current situation of the Objective 1 regions in practice allows for a policy of integrated interventions, which requires an operational instrument for coordinating the amounts allocated. We could then, in principle, even respond positively to the Commission's request to create a management centre for structural promotion in the Member States, responsible for coordinating the application and management of structural interventions on the spot, provided that this centre does not become a centralising instrument at supranational level and ensures that effective attention is paid to those regions which - I repeat once again - due to a whole series of converging negative factors, have not yet reached the correct levels in terms of the use of structural funds, so that replacing the geographical objective with sectoral policies could lead to a negative intervention in fact. The guidelines, as approved by the Commission, are very limited because, instead of fulfilling the objective of indicating orientations, they provide a catalogue of possible provisions, a catalogue which, in the absence of a progressive definition of priorities, could actually put the Member States on the wrong track by directing them towards a range of proposals contrary to the desired concentration. It could be said that, as things stand, the opportunity to effectively strengthen sustainable urban development by containing the growing phenomenon of urbanization and the associated degradation of the landscape has been missed. The importance of the global grant instrument has not been properly assessed, as it could prove very useful in rebalancing urban and rural areas, while also conferring the necessary dignity on local bodies which, through their autonomy, could define conditions for territorial development including shorter timescales, thus contributing to the efforts to reform the structural funds and the objectives of efficiency, concentration and administrative flexibility. Rural areas must truly be considered as a resource in which increasing investment is required, encouraging young people to remain in rural areas to avoid their economic and social destruction. It is now clear that to achieve this goal, jobs in rural areas will have to be created not in agriculture as traditionally understood - which is nevertheless an essential instrument for safeguarding the environment and biodiversity - but in sectors such as rural tourism, sport, culture, the environment, small and medium-sized enterprises and services. There is a real gap in the guidelines due to the lack of concrete guidelines for ensuring coordination between the ESF and employment strategies, a coordination which, since it is being applied for the first time for the 2000-2006 programming period, presupposes that the Member States need "guidelines".

I therefore plead in favour of maintaining the plan: debate on Friday, vote later. Madam President, I do indeed owe Mr Wurtz an explanation, and I will provide it to the whole of Parliament. We reached this agreement in principle at the Conference of Presidents. At that time, I did not know that Commissioner Bolkestein would be raising the issue next week at his hearing before the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism. Furthermore, we have debated the issue within my group, and we believe, given the current situation in the entire process of market integration and deregulation on such a sensitive subject, that it is appropriate that Parliament, whatever it does in the future, first pronounce itself so that Commissioner Bolkestein can take due note and guide the debate next week. Madam President, I would simply like to invite my colleague, Mr Wurtz, to reread and check what it is about. This is not a substantive discussion, but simply the following question: when will the Commission finally be able to present the directive, given that it has already had a year and a half to do so? With this resolution, we simply want to ensure that the deadlines agreed to by the Commission are finally met. It is therefore important that we act as quickly as possible. That is why I would like to support the Social Democrats' proposal to hold the vote this Friday. (Parliament agrees) Madam President, since the Cederschiöld report is no longer on the agenda for Thursday's sitting, we should have a little more time on that day. Given the number of issues that will have to be debated in an hour and a half, the urgent business session is likely to be very tight. Could the plenary proceedings department therefore check whether it is possible to grant us an extra half hour for the urgent business session, so that we have sufficient speaking time? Last week, the organization of the session seems to me to have been very chaotic. We had a very tight schedule in terms of speaking time, then suddenly, last Thursday, we found ourselves with a gap on the agenda for an hour, or even an hour and a half. We had to wait until the vote. This Friday, only one item is on the agenda. This is completely absurd. I would urge us to examine the organization of the session. This is something that is entirely possible: let us see if we can extend the urgent business session by half an hour, taking into account the withdrawal of Mrs Cederschiöld's report. That is what this is about and that alone. Madam President, I wanted to speak about Wednesday's agenda, which you did not announce.

This is the correct procedure. Mr President, I request that the matter be referred back to committee pursuant to Rule 69(2). The reason for this is that this concerns the approximation of a legal provision proposed by the Commission. We have accepted this, but have proposed further approximation of the legal provisions relating to this directive, in particular the adoption of a text – which has been approved in its entirety by the Commission – on the use and labelling of genetically modified organisms. We believe that this belongs in this approximation at this stage, but the Commission is not accepting it. I think that, pursuant to Rule 69(2), we must try to enter into dialogue with the Commission, and I therefore ask my colleagues to agree to the referral back. (Parliament adopted the request for referral back to committee.) Report (A5-0034/2000) by Mrs Stenzel, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the communication from the Commission to the Member States laying down guidelines for Community initiative programmes (CIPs) for which Member States may submit proposals for support under the EQUAL initiative (COM(1999) 476 - C5-0260/1999 - 1999/2186/COS)) Before the vote: Mr President, let me say publicly to Mrs Stenzel, as a member of the ÖVP executive committee, that many Members are appalled that you have entered into a coalition with Haider, and that we wish to condemn this here! (Applause from the left, heckling from the right) Mr Cohn-Bendit, Members of the House, I do not think that the European Parliament is the place to intervene in a country's internal politics on such a massive scale as you are doing. I can speak for my party, which was a pioneer in Austria's accession to the European Union and has since joined. As a political force, we are the guarantee that Austria will remain committed to European values. I refuse to allow myself to be pigeonholed into a right-wing corner for domestic and party-political reasons! This does not reflect the facts; it is pure polemic! I categorically reject this! (Lively, prolonged applause from the center and the right, protest from the left) Welcome I would like to take this opportunity to welcome to the distinguished visitors' gallery a delegation of four members of the Moroccan Parliament, led by Mr. Brahim Rachidi, Vice-President of the House of Representatives. We are delighted at the visit of this delegation so shortly before the entry into force of the Association Agreement between Morocco and the European Union on 1 March 2000. On the occasion of this historic step, we welcome the developments in our relations and the prospect of intensified contacts between our two parliaments. To this end, a delegation for relations with the Maghreb countries and the Arab Maghreb Union will travel to Morocco from 20 to 22 March. I wish the delegation a successful stay in Strasbourg. (Loud applause) Mr President, since you are welcoming a delegation, I would like to take this opportunity to inform you that we also have the pleasure of welcoming to our House today the principal officers of the Austrian anti-racism associations, who do Parliament the honor of their visit.

In the new programme presented for the period 2000-2006, financed by the European Social Fund, the resources used and the policies implemented must be aimed, with the support of the Commission, at achieving the objectives I have mentioned. The Commission will monitor the work of the Greek Government closely in order to honour the commitments it has made. I thank the Commissioner for his reply. However, Mrs Diamantopoulou, the situation we find ourselves in is the following. We have the second highest unemployment rate in Europe, namely 11.3% - in the past it was not that high -, we have the highest rate of increase in the number of unemployed, we are the country that spends the least on the unemployed, namely less than 1% of GDP while the other countries spend between 3 and 4% (such as France, Belgium and Germany), and it is not at all clear how the Social Fund appropriations, which were allocated, among other things, to the fight against unemployment, have been used. You tell me that the Commission has made certain recommendations. I take note of this and I am pleased: let's hope that the recommendations will be respected! However, I have been asking myself for some time: what about the policies adopted previously? Have some people found work? And if so, how many? At least last year and two years ago, if you cannot provide us with the figures for this year. And what about training? Do the famous training centres serve to provide work for trainers or for trainees? Do we have figures available? In short, do we have the possibility of monitoring at least in part the progress of this policy of the Greek Government? Mr Papayannakis, I can tell you that the Greek Government will really have to step up its efforts at this point in the computerised management of statistical data and in the creation of structures that allow the programmes implemented to translate into quantitative results, as you say, and that allow for real monitoring on the basis of which policies can then be oriented. Greece has seen an increase in the unemployment rate and, from what I see from these figures, an increase in productivity. What the Commission can do concerns the guidelines in question. As you know, there are 22 guidelines on which each country is judged, and they concern, among other things, access to training, its numerical distribution between men and women, and specific measures for the long-term unemployed. The Commission will endeavour to quantify the data and to have precise figures for all these guidelines, and this will depend on the implementation of the new Community framework for 2000-2006. Question No 36 by the Honourable Member (H-0782/99): Subject: The Danish early retirement programme Can the Commission say whether the Danish early retirement programme has been fully approved or whether there are still differences between Denmark and the Commission in relation to other social sectors? The Danish pension system, Efterløn, only allows the retirement of those who are resident in Denmark and have completed the required periods of work in this country. Some workers have lodged a complaint with the European Commission, alleging that their pension rights are being denied.

In the Swedish case, excise duties are indeed used to reduce alcohol consumption. Although this leads to a disparity in excise duties between Sweden and other EU Member States—and as such increases cross-border smuggling of alcoholic products—it is a legitimate instrument to reduce alcohol consumption. Of course, there is the elasticity of demand; in this case, the price elasticity of demand. I am not entirely sure of its value, but it is not zero, and therefore it must have an effect. My question would have been almost identical to the one raised by Mr. Purvis, but I would like to take the argument further.
