Even if you accept, as you have said, that excise duties are a prerogative of the Member States, the fact remains that the use of that prerogative in a way that discriminates and is unfair to producers in one part of the Community as against other producers may conflict with the principle of the single market. For example, if we look at what Mr Purvis and I are thinking of - the whisky-producing Highland regions, which are particularly peripheral parts of Europe, under great pressure, where farming and distilling communities are entirely dependent on that production - the general practice of taxing the alcohol in Scotch whisky, Dutch genever or Danish aquavit more heavily than the alcohol in beer or wine seems to me to be discriminatory and to be a discriminatory use of a practice that is commonly recognised as being within the prerogative of the Member States. Let me confirm to Mr MacCormick and other Members of this Parliament that the current situation, in which excise duties differ between Member States, is indeed not conducive to the proper functioning of the internal market. We must not limit ourselves to alcoholic products. If we look at petrol, for example, we see that excise duties levied in Germany are different from those levied in the Netherlands: the result is that Dutch drivers cross the border and fill up in Germany. This is indeed a distortion of the internal market. If it were up to me, I would use a magic wand to harmonize excise duties across Europe. This would put an end to all smuggling, unless products are inherently more expensive in certain Member States. But I do not have a magic wand and it is not up to me alone. This is an area that requires unanimity, as Mr MacCormick knows, and unless all Member States agree on the harmonization of excise duties, it will not take place. Once again, the Commission will submit a report towards the end of the year on the state of play regarding excise duties, and I am naturally open to any discussion with Parliament on that report. Thank you very much, Commissioner. Today we will deal with you and offer you a glass—or two, perhaps—of Alsace wine, the taxation of which we do not know, although I assume that it will also be heavily taxed. As the time for Question Time has expired, Questions 55 to 114 will receive written answers.

A third-country national who has legal status in one Member State must also be admitted to other Member States. This does not prevent those States from taking public policy measures within the framework of the proposed prior notification obligation. The Commission also finds unacceptable the proposal to maintain legal status in force for three months after the expiry of the card. It is unacceptable that the national concerned can remain in the host country after the end of their provision of services. This is why the Commission supports, in both respects, Amendment 22 by Mrs Palacio. As regards the second proposal, the Commission understands the desire for a clear definition of the concept of self-employed and therefore intends to address this in its amended proposal. These are some preliminary remarks on the most important amendments. I hope you will give me another opportunity, at the end of the debate and after all speakers have spoken, to expand on the individual amendments. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in tomorrow's vote, the EPP Group will support the Legal Affairs Committee's proposed amendments and the editorial changes by a large majority. I will limit my intervention to two areas. The first area is the question of what this directive should have the effect of – in the literal sense of the word. On the one hand, there are the interests of the economy and the individual. Let me say straight away that my explanations are based on the assumption that this is an honest individual and a conscientious worker. On the other hand, there are the interests of the Member States, which should perhaps assume the worst for the individuals concerned. If we consider one of the extremes, the interests of the Member States, there are certainly good reasons for providing fairly high hurdles for issuing this card. Then there are good reasons to justify the rapid introduction, despite this card, of notification obligations. If I consider the other extreme, namely the fewest possible obstacles, I run the risk that this procedure will deprive me of any legislation because the Member States will not approve the directive. In the end, either I will have a directive on the service card that no one will actually have because the obstacles placed on the economic sector will be too great, or I will not even have a directive. Neither outcome can satisfy us. Perhaps this is also why we are told that negotiations are also stalled on this subject in the Council. We have tried to find a balance, as light a solution as possible, between the interest of public policy and the other interest. We want to have a solution that dismantles certain obstacles placed on the economic sector but which allows, once these obstacles have been overcome, to achieve as light an application as possible. This is why we want a service card to be requested for one or more Member States. If a French company declares that one of its employees must work permanently in Denmark and only in Denmark, the service provision card should be able to be requested for that country only.

This observatory will have to produce an annual report on the evolution and impact of these policies and their coordination. I have left for last a question that I think is fundamental and that I think should be put on record and approved by the Assembly. Our objective of reducing to a minimum the contradictions between cooperation and development policy and other policies must be valid not only within the European Union, but also at global level, given the increasing globalisation of the economy. If we want fair world trade, we must affirm this principle in the next round of multilateral negotiations within the World Trade Organisation, because it would be contradictory for the European Union to impose on itself an iron discipline, albeit fair, and to let the United States and the other major powers do the opposite, taking advantage of our reserve. It is therefore right and essential that these principles be enshrined in the next round of negotiations at the World Trade Organisation. Mr President, the Director-General of DG Development has said that producing a report on the coherence of EU policies with development policy, before the paper on development policy itself due in the spring, is like putting the cart before the horse. Leaving aside the fact that the request for an annual report, clearly addressed to the Commission in the Council resolution, has produced only a 'non-document', the real problem is that when it comes to alleviating world poverty those horses are going uphill and the cart of other EU policies is so heavy that it is slowly dragging development policy backwards. When you look at the main policies of the European Union, development policy is often forgotten or is simply an afterthought. Take the new chocolate directive, which shows that EU countries spend more on chocolate each year than on development aid. No accurate assessment has been made of the development impact of this directive which, according to producing countries, 90 percent of which are our ACP partners, could reduce cocoa farmers' incomes by at least 15 percent. Take the fisheries agreement, where we recognise the unsustainability of current fishing methods in EU waters. At the same time, we are concluding joint venture agreements to give large European fishing vessels greater access to developing country waters, to the detriment of 190 million small-scale fishermen in those countries. Take trade agreements. As Commissioner Nielson said this morning in relation to Lomé, preferential access is granted for essentially all products from the least developed countries. In other words, when the EU's trade interests are at stake, considerations of poverty go out the window. Given our position in Seattle, why this silence on the EU's failure to implement the trade concessions for developing countries already agreed under GATT, including those for the crucial textile industry? As regards the common agricultural policy, which bears the greatest blame, no assessment has been made of the development impact of the CAP reforms envisaged by Agenda 2000. Everyone is now aware of the scandal of the export refund scheme, which dumped a surplus of 54 000 tonnes of subsidised beef on the markets of West Africa, reducing by half the prices paid to local farmers.

We ask the Commission to reconsider these proposals. Finally, we would urge Members, in particular, to vote against Amendment 41 on capital requirements, as we believe it would be very bad for the industry. I would also like to point out that I am the first Member to stay within my time limit. Mr President, pecunia non olet, as the Latins used to say. What matters is that money multiplies. This is the only point at which we reconcile the interests of economists with the interests of all those who want to earn money and who only have dollars on their minds, like Scrooge McDuck, who is portrayed with a dollar sign for eyes, only in this case it is the euro sign. Here we reconcile the interests of these citizens and the interests of pensioners who want to live a carefree life. For example, my brother-in-law, who lives in Rome, retired a year ago, and since then, every day from 7:00 a.m. when he gets up until midnight, he has been watching on television the performance of the pension funds and securities in which he has invested. Pensioners will in the future—as they do now—have enormous sums of money at their disposal. While the young are poor, the elderly have accumulated money, and because they want to increase it, they have a great interest in this directive. If national governments—as the European Union does with this directive—were concerned about increasing the amount of money earned over the course of a working life, the burning problem of the pension explosion would already be solved. You, Commissioner Bolkestein, by virtue of your office also bear a very great responsibility for the future of older people and pensioners, a future that I hope will be better once we have adopted this directive as soon as possible, in accordance with the proposal by Mrs Villiers and Mrs Kauppi. Mr President, first of all, on behalf of the Commission, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur, Mr Olle Schmidt, and the members of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, which is responsible for the report. I would also like to thank Mr Brian Crowley, draftsman, and the members of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market for their commendable and intensive efforts in developing and expanding the proposals. Since the adoption of Directive 85/611, the capital and securities markets have evolved continuously, so the current provisions now need to be adapted accordingly. The new proposals aim to maintain a uniform minimum level of investor protection, which, following the introduction of the euro, is an essential prerequisite for market integration. Since the average European family invests its savings in investment funds, the proposals contain provisions for prudent management—I would like to emphasize this very much—for prudent management in terms of investment policy and risk diversification. The two proposals form a coherent whole. The first proposal expands the instruments in which an "undertaking for collective investment in transferable securities" (UCITS) can invest. UCITS, as has already been stated in this Chamber, are among the most important players in modern financial markets.

This is why we must focus our attention on policies - Mr. Karas also mentioned this - that lead to the overvaluation of a particular currency in relation to its actual potential. However, this would require control measures for the import and export of capital, otherwise we cannot focus on these policies. The Tobin tax therefore seems like a sensible idea, but it is not without problems, even if we could manage to implement it, which, I repeat, I doubt. We must remember that as things stand, money is above all information, and that in the future the global economy will increasingly revolve around the power of knowledge and intellectual capital. This is why the uninterrupted flow of colossal masses of fortune between the world's financial centers is not purely a speculative activity entirely disconnected from the real economy. If this feedback mechanism, which therefore gives users the opportunity to make choices, is hampered by measures such as the Tobin tax, this may result in erroneous choices whose economic cost will be far greater than the tax would ever generate. This is why, as Mr Kalas has already explained so well, our group is absolutely opposed to the adoption of the Tobin tax. Madam President, I am speaking in favour of taxing capital movements for speculative purposes across monetary boundaries. It seems to me absolutely clear that action is necessary. Over the past 30 years, the volume of monetary transactions has increased 83-fold, with the following results: firstly, the total of central bank reserves worldwide is barely equal to the daily volume of transactions on the foreign exchange markets; Second, the annual volume of real world trade in goods and services is equivalent to exactly three and a half days out of 350 of speculation in the foreign exchange markets, which means that trade in goods and services accounts for 1 percent of capital movements, compared to 99 percent for speculation. The size, unpredictability, and irrationality of global foreign exchange markets make it increasingly difficult to manage national and regional economies. Computer trading programs have transformed a marginal phenomenon into a tidal wave, sweeping away jobs, lives, and industries all over the planet. The only argument against taxing speculative capital movements is that it would undermine the efficiency of foreign exchange markets: a rather bizarre argument considering the frenzy that has gripped the markets, destroying jobs all over the world, from East Asia to Europe and Latin America. Mr. Chirac has called those participating in this frenzy the AIDS virus of the global economy. What is needed is to put a spanner in the works of currency speculators, stockbrokers, and options sellers. This is, of course, not feasible on a national scale, or even on a eurozone scale, but it could be done on a global level, with good international cooperation. Europe, Japan, and the United States, the euro, the yen, and the dollar, would, in my opinion, constitute a sufficient bloc. The EPP Group disappoints me.

During the negotiations, the Commission must make every effort to admit every candidate country into the Union as quickly as possible. At the same time, care must be taken to ensure that the successes achieved in integration to date and the objectives set for it are not diluted. To prevent this, the Liberal Group has expressed the hope that the Intergovernmental Conference will discuss models for differentiated integration and create a concentric Union with a federal state at the core, around which a less integrated outer circle is grouped. It is foreseeable that the Union's internal differentiation will be addressed at the Intergovernmental Conference. This issue must be addressed impartially. A technical improvement of the flexibility system is not enough; rather, the development of separate institutions for the vanguard countries must be sought, as Jacques Delors already proposed. This would create a decision-making system with greater efficiency, clarity, transparency, and democracy. I hope that the Commission will put forward its own proposal on how the institutional and other differentiation of the enlarging Union should be implemented. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, Commissioners, I was seduced by your inspiring speech, Mr Prodi. It raises expectations, but it can also disappoint. This is due to the discrepancy between words and deeds, to which Mr van Velzen just pointed out. The enlargement of the Union is driven by our desire for peace, security, and stability. You want to reassure the candidate countries and the European public. However, we can see with our own eyes how the exact opposite is happening today. Fear and unrest are spreading even in regions that are prosperous and virtually free of unemployment. As Mr Swoboda says, and I agree with him in this respect, we must make our citizens feel at home. Here we are united by the same values, and everyone knows their roles and responsibilities. This is probably due to the standards mentioned by Mr van Dam. That is subsidiarity: clearly defined powers at all decision-making levels, partnership instead of competition in politics. Exercising power as closely as possible to the citizen, where transparency is maintained and the citizens themselves have the opportunity to exercise control. This requires a new political culture, not only in theory but also in practice, one that is geared to the reality in the Member States and regions. Regions which, due to their cultural and economic importance, are sometimes quite equal to some Member States. The new Europe must not only develop in breadth; its progress must also go deeper, with us truly living our values and driving forward the democratic construction of a genuine community. The Commission will have to be judged by this. Madam President, the Commission is presenting its strategic objectives for the years 2000-2005 today in an extremely general document in which all sticking points are glossed over so as not to scare off either side too much. Thus, in the first section on the new European decision-making structures, one will naturally not find the words federalism or superstate anywhere. But these concepts inevitably emerge when we talk of strong European institutions which only decentralise their day-to-day executive activities and which develop their collective vision in a confused structure in which governments and national parliaments are mixed with regional and even local authorities and civil society, all of which are described, without any hierarchy, as - and I quote - 'an integral part of European decision-making structures'.

Therefore, the European Union must take a clear position on the current situation in Austria. (SV) We voted for the joint resolution to express our solidarity with all those exposed to xenophobia and racism, and also in protest against the despicable policies represented by Jörg Haider. However, we reject the methods used by the 14 Member States on this issue. The resolution lacks a clear reference to respect for national identity and legal traditions, as required by Article 6 of the Treaty. We also miss a point on the EU's shared responsibility for social and political development in Europe and Austria, which was one of the prerequisites for Haider's electoral success. Right-wing extremism is—today, as in Europe's earlier history—the result of precarious social and economic living conditions. The austerity policies implemented in the course of EMU adjustment have fostered the successes of right-wing extremism. A radical policy of security and justice in every country is the best guarantee for democratic development in Europe. I make this statement on behalf of the CSU group. It is intolerable that the EU should interfere in the formation of a member state's government. This is not the EU's right. Instead of prejudging the FPÖ and the Austrian government currently being formed, we must first critically examine and evaluate the government declaration, the party program, and the coalition's policies. Only after such a critical examination of the future policies of the parties in coalition talks can we decide whether this government contradicts the democratic spirit of Europe. This does not mean that we sympathize with Haider. The CSU MEPs have no sympathy whatsoever for FPÖ leader Haider. As politicians, we must rather ask ourselves why 27% of the Austrian population voted for a party like the FPÖ in the October 1999 elections. We must examine the reasons for this and try to eliminate the factors that lead to such results. Only an examination of the FPÖ's arguments and policies can prevent a radicalization of politics in Austria. The European Parliament's resolution, however, does not question the reasons for the Austrian election result and does not suggest a possible solution. For these reasons, the CSU European Parliamentary Group opposes this resolution. "For he knew what was unknown to this cheerful crowd and what can be read in books: that the plague bacillus never dies or disappears, but can slumber for decades in furniture and linen, that it waits patiently in rooms, cellars, suitcases, handkerchiefs, and old papers, and that perhaps the day will come when, to the misfortune and instruction of humanity, the plague will awaken its rats and send them out again to die in a happy city." With these words, shortly after the Second World War, at the end of a long allegorical narrative about the difficult struggle of the inhabitants of Oran against the plague, Albert Camus reminds us that there is no final victory in the fight against Nazism, the "brown plague"—as it was called at the time. That racial hatred, xenophobic violence, fear of the Other and rejection of the Other, which have their roots in the lowest traits of human nature, can resurface at any time in any group of people and gain dominance.

This means that all the political groups, except the non-attached groups - which do not constitute a political group - were in agreement and that only one group was of the opinion that we should proceed as my colleague proposed here. All the others were of a different opinion and so it was decided. I would now like to go into the substance of the matter briefly. We have confidence in the Commission, in Romano Prodi and the large majority of our political group, as everyone knows, voted confidence in Romano Prodi and the Commission after a difficult process. However, we are also of the opinion that the Commission's strategy should be discussed in the course of a regular procedure, not only on the basis of an oral statement in this Parliament but also on the basis of a document adopted by the Commission setting out this programme for the next five years. But such a document does not yet exist! The Commission will present the programme for 2000 in February. We have agreed: if the Commission does not want to discuss the 2000 programme in January, we will do so in February. We certainly do not want to enter into conflict with the Commission. On the contrary, we believe that the Commission and Parliament should go down the same road as far as possible. However, Parliament also has a supervisory role over the Commission and not everything that the Commission proposes necessarily has to be agreed with us. I would like us in the political groups to be able to prepare ourselves adequately for the debate on the five-year programme. This cannot be done by listening to a statement whose content we do not know exactly. We therefore recommend - and I have the impression that the Commission is also prepared to accept this idea - that in February we discuss the Commission's long-term programme up to 2005 - in the hope that by then the Commission will have agreed on a programme which it will submit to us - and, again in February, the Commission's legislative programme for the year 2000. It is therefore on the basis of an objective link that we propose to discuss the two programmes at the same time and for this reason my political group emphatically rejects the Socialist Group's proposal! (Applause from the PPE-DE Group benches) Madam President, I would like to state clearly that, first of all, the Commission has the utmost respect for Parliament's decisions, including that of drawing up its own agenda. We therefore respect any decisions Parliament may make on this matter. But I would also like to say clearly that President Prodi has committed himself to Parliament to include a new debate, as Mr Barón has said, in addition to the annual debate on the Commission's legislative programme, on the broad lines of action for the next five years, that is to say, for the present parliamentary term. I would like to stress, Madam President, that, according to the agreement reached last September, this debate was separate from the presentation of the Commission's legislative programme. And I would like to make it known that, as far as the Commission is concerned, we are ready and willing to hold this debate whenever it is deemed appropriate; we were already ready to do so this week, in accordance with the initial agreement, on the basis of the understanding that the speech would be presented to the parliamentary groups the day before.

In my opinion, it is regrettable that the Commission has not given the same assessment of Leader II, assessing the quality of the projects, the number of loans used, and, above all, the demobilization of some local stakeholders in the face of the administrative and financial obstacles encountered. However, I welcome the fact that, within the framework of Leader+, new resources have been committed to helping rural areas develop their potential and implement the objectives of local and sustainable development. I believe it is important to place particular emphasis on experimenting with new ways of enhancing natural and cultural heritage, as well as strengthening economic environments to foster employment. I believe it is appropriate to consider that the sharing of these positive development experiences can also be part of the framework of transnational cooperation. It is worth emphasizing that all rural areas will be eligible for Leader II. However, although Member States are still able to define zones within this initiative, the Commission must ensure a certain concentration of resources and the prioritization of projects in less prosperous areas. Of course, transparency prevails over the selection criteria for projects and local action groups. Likewise, I believe that we must ensure above all that the financial mechanisms of states or local authorities do not again generate payment delays, which have been able to lead some local action groups to financial bankruptcy within the framework of Leader II. Mr. President, as a Member from an outermost region, I must point out that this is a very special afternoon in terms of regional policy, and I say this because of the debate on two Community initiatives: URBAN and INTERREG. I would like to point out that these initiatives are aimed, the first, URBAN, at improving the quality of life of citizens living in the neighborhoods of the various European cities, and INTERREG at facilitating cohesion and recognizing the diversity and potential of the regions of the European Union, particularly when it comes to including the outermost regions in Chapters B and C. We deplore, as does the rapporteur, its exclusion from Chapter IIIA. We believe that the reference to the creation of a European observatory for cooperation in INTERREG is very appropriate. I thank the rapporteurs, particularly Mr. Decourrière, for their regional sensitivity and for accepting our amendments. I hope that the Commissioner will accept our proposal. Mr. President, with regard to the various initiatives we are analyzing this afternoon, I would like to focus strictly on a reflection on one of them, specifically the URBAN program. It is true that we are debating this program today because the European Parliament was adamant that this initiative should be maintained. The Commission's proposal was to eliminate it, along with other initiatives, but Parliament's proposal and the Commission's own sensitivity at the time led to the URBAN initiative being retained.

Thank you very much, Mr Barnier. You have answered the questions specifically and opened the dialogue on Europe that you initiated. You have set a very good example today of respecting speaking time. The debate is closed. Question Time (Commission) The next item is Question Time (B5-0009/2000). We will be dealing with questions to the Commission. Part I Question No 36 by (H-0025/00): Subject: Infant mortality in Kosovo According to the most recent figures sent to the United Nations by the World Health Organization, Kosovo has the highest infant mortality rate in Europe; almost 50% of premature babies die, while the war has led to a sharp rise in miscarriages, and those babies who are carried to term are not as well developed physically. In light of the European Union's humanitarian aid and the efforts of Special Representative Bernard Kouchner, can the Commission indicate what measures have been taken in Kosovo to protect women's right to maternity, as well as the health of pregnant women, new mothers, and infants? Mr President, the Commission is fully aware of the very difficult situation regarding health and medical facilities in Kosovo, not only for pregnant women but more generally. This situation is the result both of the recent conflict and the years of neglect that preceded it. The figures mentioned regarding infant mortality are eloquent and unacceptable. But the situation is hardly better for other sections of the population. The Commission has taken the following measures: First, the health sector is receiving extensive support from ECHO. The focus is on the provision of medical supplies and emergency medical assistance, support for health facilities, and vaccination. However, we are increasingly focusing on the creation of a self-sustaining health care system in the province. This process is being significantly supported by UNMIK. Secondly, the reconstruction programme has begun to carry out urgent initial measures at Mitrovica Hospital, using EUR 1 million from the rehabilitation programme. Due to the strained relations between the ethnic groups in this divided city, work is progressing slowly. However, thanks to the support of UNMIK, the Commission can continue its assistance through this project. We hope that this project will one day become a symbol of ethnic reconciliation. Based on the Community's assessment of the damage, the cost of rebuilding health facilities and equipping pharmacies and clinics is estimated at EUR 4 million. The Commission is now turning to programming the funds for the year 2000. We expect that a substantial amount will be allocated, among other things, for the reconstruction of the health sector. The focus will be on long-term reforms addressing health care financing, training, and procurement. The extent to which the Commission can participate in these measures is currently being examined with UNMIK. Commissioner, This morning, Commission President Prodi emphasized, among other things, that our ability to act effectively is being put to the test in the Balkans, that the very credibility of the European Union is at stake, and that the gap between words and deeds must finally be bridged. Do you not think, Commissioner, that the available data on the high infant and child mortality rate in Kosovo—the highest in all of Europe—and the general picture of human misery and destruction in Kosovo, are already seriously undermining our credibility and calling into question our ability to turn promises into action?

After the failed talks between the SPÖ and the ÖVP, the Socialists attempted to form a minority government, asking the FPÖ to support them. We were offered three ministerial posts – you only have to read the newspapers to know this – posts offered to the very party that is accused of being fascist here! After we suddenly refused such an offer, a frenzied campaign of incitement and propaganda began that we still cannot understand. The FPÖ is a party that has a well-established position in the political landscape of Austria: one of its members is the Prime Minister of one of the nine states of the Republic of Austria, while the party participates in the governments of all the others. Therefore, many Austrians today are wondering why their democratic choice is suddenly interpreted as an expression of a fascist mentality and why the incitement campaign began only after the FPÖ withdrew its support for a minority government. A climate of prejudice is spreading which, without looking at our program, reduces the cruelest period in European history to a political spectacle. It truly disgusts me that some of our opponents exploit, for low-grade propaganda purposes, the millions of people who died in the gas chambers of concentration camps. This was done, for example, by the Honourable Bertinotti, who yesterday, on Italian television, accused Haider of denying the Holocaust. Shame on you, colleague! Even if you have exhausted all political arguments, you still have no right to exploit the memory of those killed for your petty propaganda. You will not gain a reputation as an anti-fascist by denouncing a democratically elected colleague as a Nazi! On the contrary, you do nothing but mock the real victims of National Socialism and minimize fascist dictatorships. You act on the basis of your prejudices, renouncing any political debate. In doing so, you behave precisely in the style you claim to want to fight. The attacks on the new Austrian Government, the attempt to exert political influence in a Member State are an insult to the Austrian people. We are therefore particularly grateful to the Commission for the position it has taken. In future negotiations within the coalition, we will discuss democratic reform, the rights of the opposition, the commitment to compensate forced labourers... (The President interrupted the speaker) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin my speech by making it very clear that there is no danger of a resurgence in Austria of either a one-party political system or a right-wing totalitarian system. Austria is a stable democracy, in which human rights and fundamental freedoms are guaranteed by the Constitution and protected by an independent judiciary. Austria is an open country, in which there is no room for xenophobia and discrimination. What is happening in Austria is nothing more than a normal process of transfer of power following democratic elections in which a "no" was said to the old system and a stable parliamentary majority was sought and found that could implement the necessary economic and social reforms.

Now, Intergovernmental Conferences are like an event and can also be like a Christmas tree. Therefore, the possibility cannot be ruled out that these issues, which are recurrent and have been passed down from one conference to another, may be raised. The problem that arises is whether there is currently a consensus within the European Union to include this issue, bearing in mind in particular that, if an issue of this kind is included, other similar issues will likely be added to the Conference's agenda. Mr. Dimitrakopoulos has the floor for a point of order. I would ask you to be brief. Mr. President, I understand that I have to do it very quickly. I very much liked what Mr. Seixas da Costa said about Santa Claus. In Spain, they say "Letter to the Three Wise Men." I simply want to remind you that the European Parliament has already sent the letter to the Three Wise Men with its reports. Now it is up to the Presidency, and the Council, to bring the gifts we requested in our letter to the Three Wise Men. As I suspected, it wasn't exactly a point of order, but rather a closing of the debate. We thank Mr. Seixas da Costa, but he can also write his letter to the Three Wise Men. I would just like to say that this Christmas-related issue raised by the Honorable Member is of the utmost importance. However, in this case, Santa Claus can only give gifts when authorized by others. It will not be up to the Portuguese Presidency to provide the gifts everyone wants, particularly those requested by the European Parliament. After this interesting exchange of views, and in accordance with the Rules of Procedure, I inform you that Questions 17 to 27 will be answered in writing. Question time to the Council is now closed. Capital tax The next item is the joint debate on: the oral question (B5-0004/2000) by Mr Désir and others to the Council, on the Council's position on the idea of a capital tax. the oral question (B5-0005/2000) by Mr Désir and others to the Commission, on the Commission's position on the idea of a capital tax. Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, everyone was able to appreciate, during the Asian crisis in 1997, as well as after the crisis that hit Mexico in 1995, or the EMS in 1993, the damage to the economies of entire countries that financial speculation, particularly speculation on currencies, can cause. Between 1,500 and 2,000 billion euros are exchanged daily on financial markets, or in four days, the equivalent of the entire global annual production, of global GDP, which is approximately 6,000 billion euros. In other words, these financial transactions are, for the most part, purely speculative, with no link to the exchange of goods or investments. But the erratic movement of such considerable amounts of capital can cause the collapse of a currency, of a country's economy, and plunge the entire population into recession within a matter of hours.

Isn't it time for the Turkish government to lift the economic blockade against Armenia? Mr. President, I would like to thank the representative of the Council Presidency for his response. However, I am somewhat saddened that, although this is initially viewed as a bilateral issue, it ultimately involves a major triangular relationship. We provide partnership funds and have cooperation agreements to help Armenia, and yet the aid cannot be effective because Turkey is imposing an economic blockade, preventing many things from progressing for the Armenians. Negotiations are underway with Turkey regarding possible accession, and it is in all of our interests that every state that wishes to become a member maintains friendly relations with its neighbors, including those along its border. Can't you exert greater influence on Turkey to facilitate peaceful development here, to enable the Armenians to develop in a way that is necessary for further cooperation? Madam Member, you are quite right when you say that we must use our relations with Turkey to ensure that the country in question can play a constructive role in this situation and, above all, is part of the solution and no longer part of the problem. Precisely because Turkey has embarked on a new path in its relations with the European Union, and because Turkey is now also confronted with the need to respond to the European Union's positions in the area of the common foreign and security policy, we will – there is no need to conceal this – examine Turkey's intentions with regard to the European Union's priorities in its external relations. Naturally, relations with Armenia, as evidenced by the agreement concluded last year, also fall within these external relations. We believe that if Turkey wishes to share the fundamental values of the European Union and the general framework of European Union relations – and regardless of the specific bilateral relations it may have with other countries – it should generally conduct itself in accordance with the basic standards that the European Union applies in its external relations. We also expect that this issue will be a key focus in bilateral relations between the European Union and Turkey in the near future. Since they cover similar topics, Questions 5 and 6 will be answered together. Question 5 (H-0031/00): Subject: Worsening situation in Kosovo. The genocide of the Serbs and other ethnic groups in Kosovo, apart from the Albanians, continues and is becoming even more serious. Even Mr. Kouchner recently stated that the political and security situation in Kosovo is anything but good. It is also pointed out that UN Resolution 1244 is not being applied and, in particular, that its provisions, which contain guarantees for all inhabitants of Kosovo, are being violated. Instead, the extremist, separatist forces are being encouraged, culminating in the appointment of the former KLA leader, H. Thaqi, as 'provisional Prime Minister' of Kosovo and the KLA being declared 'the protection force for Kosovo'. In view of this situation, what does the Council intend to do to ensure that UN resolutions, and in particular Resolution 1244, are implemented and prevent the separation of the province of Kosovo from Serbia?

I myself have mentioned various possible responses to this challenge, which consists for all of us in recalling, in demonstrating again what we have been doing together since 1957: Economic Community of course, but first of all Community of Values and Charter of Fundamental Rights which will protect individual citizens more and more clearly; Article 13 of the Treaty, relating to discrimination, which we proposed, in our opinion of 26 January, even before the Austrian crisis, should be governed, after the IGC, by qualified majority and no longer by unanimity; the possible hypothesis, I repeat possible - I say this in a personal capacity - of supplementing Article 7 with a new paragraph which would provide the democratic monitoring or alert procedure with a legal basis and then, finally, public debate. The only way to push back bad ideas is to express others. So I come back to the subject of our discussion just now, I deeply believe in the value and democratic power of debate, particularly in combating demagogy. Commissioner Barnier, you strongly insisted in your statement on the importance of dialogue with the citizens of Europe. As for the IGC, you know that under the Helsinki decisions, the Portuguese Presidency was granted the specific right to broaden the agenda of the IGC during this Conference. It is clear that Parliament will have its own representatives, Mr Brok and Mr Tsatsos. However, Commissioner, would you also be able to undertake, if the agenda is broadened by the Council, to refer the matter to Parliament so that we can debate it within ourselves but also with you, in order to continue this dialogue with the citizens on which you have so insisted? Mr Beazley, my answer is clearly yes, but it is not really new. President Napolitano and many members of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, and even more Members here in plenary session, know that I will be available to say, on behalf of the Commission, throughout these negotiations, in a spirit of transparency and in real time, how things are going. I may say it differently from Professor Tsatsos and Elmar Brok, who are your direct representatives. It is likely, moreover, that in many circumstances, we will say it together. I believe it is very important that these negotiations not be clandestine, either with regard to the European Parliament or with regard to the national parliaments, which, I remind you, will ultimately have their opinion to give and their positions to take in the ratification process. This is why I paid tribute to Mr Napolitano's initiative for joint, regular consultation between the national parliaments of the fifteen countries and the European Parliament. That said, the duty of transparency and debate begins here, with regard to the reform of the institutions. So, I will be available whenever you wish to report to you on our positions and the progress of these negotiations throughout the coming year. Mr President, I would first like to compliment the Commission on its approach. I think it is really very good to begin dialogue with citizens as soon as possible because, frankly, this did not happen in the wake of the Treaty of Amsterdam and the Treaty of Maastricht and it only led to great mistrust.

This objective of minimizing contradictions is a just and reasonable one, and one that the proposed resolution is directed toward. I believe the idea of establishing an observatory to develop this coherence between Community policies and cooperation and development policies is entirely logical and appropriate. Its scope of action must not be limited to Community policies, but must also encompass the measures or policies of the Member States, including those of economic groups, which I consider important. This observatory should produce an annual report on the development and impact of these policies and their interrelationships. I have reserved for last a question which, in my view, is of fundamental importance and which must be examined and confirmed by this Parliament. Our objective of minimizing contradictions between cooperation and development policies and other policies must be valid not only within the European Union but, given the increasing globalization of the economy, also on a global scale. If we want to achieve fair world trade, we must enforce the same principle in the next round of multilateral negotiations at the World Trade Organization, because it would be contradictory for the European Union to impose an iron, albeit fair, discipline on itself, only for the United States and other major powers to then do the opposite and exploit what we fail to do. Therefore, it is right and necessary that these principles be established at the next round of negotiations at the World Trade Organization. Mr. President, the Director-General of the Directorate-General for Development said that preparing a report on the coherence of the various Union policies with development policy before the development policy document due in the spring has been presented would be putting the cart before the horse. It is irrelevant that the requirement for the Commission to submit an annual report, clearly defined in the Council resolution, was met only with a "non-paper." The real problem is that, at a time when global poverty is increasing, this horse is climbing the mountain and the cart onto which other EU policies are loaded is so heavy that development policy is slowly slipping behind. Development policy is constantly forgotten or treated as an afterthought when the European Union's most important political decisions are made. Take, for example, the new chocolate directive, which shows that EU countries spend more each year on chocolate than on development aid. There has been no proper assessment of the development impact of this directive, which, according to estimates by producing countries, 90% of which are our ACP partners, could result in income losses for cocoa producers of at least 15%. Take the fisheries agreements, which show how unsustainable current fishing practices in EU waters are. At the same time, we are negotiating joint ventures that will give large European fishing vessels expanded access to the waters of developing countries, which will put 190 million small-scale fishermen in those countries out of work worldwide. Consider the trade agreements. As Mr. Nielson said this morning with reference to the Lomé Convention, the preferential treatment applies only to "essentially all products of the least developed countries." In other words, poverty reduction becomes meaningless when the EU's commercial interests are at stake.

In this perspective, the strategy of separating the objective of preventing the deterioration of the state of surface and groundwater from the objectives of protecting, improving and restoring their quality should not be pursued, constituting a superfluous scale of priorities to the detriment of an organic nature of interventions and specific measures aimed at the combined approach and the use of the best available techniques. With regard to the elimination of pollution produced by dangerous substances in the aquatic environment, the optimization of the approach should include regulation, both at national and community level, to allow better identification of the different types of water bodies polluted as a consequence of human production activities. Finally, it is necessary to establish a system that prepares an objective list of potentially dangerous substances, through the greatest number of information about their chemical, physical and biological properties, in order to create an integrated model of intervention at different strategic levels, with the protection of the good water, which is fundamental for all of us. Mr President, the aim of the directive must be to ensure that Member States provide combined protection for surface water, groundwater and drinking water, and that the level of protection is compatible with existing Community environmental legislation. Let me point out that the decisions already adopted on the Nitrates Directive have not yet been implemented in several Member States, despite the fact that it is a Union decision. The proposal before us contains a series of more stringent provisions on the protection of the aquatic environment which go beyond the environmental objectives currently in force. The directive proposes that the ultimate objective for the marine environment must be achieved of concentrations close to the environmental concentration value for substances existing in nature and close to zero for synthetic substances attributable to human activity. Not only is this impossible, it is also against nature. The adoption of this report will have serious consequences for European agriculture, insofar as concentrations of, for example, phosphorus and nitrogen cannot exceed the environmental concentration of these substances in the aquatic environment and insofar as we want to set a zero limit value for pesticides in the aquatic environment. European agriculture will therefore not be able to devote itself to the cultivation of bread-making cereals with a protein content high enough to allow the use of these cereals for bread-making. The result will be that agricultural production will shift to other countries outside the Union, with all the socio-economic and employment consequences that this entails. I will not be able to vote in favour of the provisions of the Water Framework Directive which deal with the aspects mentioned. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, water is a precious resource. Millions of people do not even have clean water, an essential prerequisite for survival. It is therefore not surprising that water is the underlying cause of certain wars. The capitalist world also places its pawns in order to exercise maximum control over water reserves. It rarely shows solidarity or thinks about the general interest. Europe therefore has a difficult task ahead of it: to integrate the EU water policy, fragmented in terms of both objectives and means, by creating a more cohesive framework regulation.

The importance of safety in road, rail and inland waterway transport is unquestionable and given the international nature of this type of transport, training courses for safety consultants must also be harmonized, such as for the upcoming new ADR. All this is important, but equally essential is the implementation of the existing regulations. There are several reasons to pay attention to this aspect, just look at how many accidents have occurred in recent years in fog in Belgium, or in the Netherlands or in other countries. There are many accidents involving trucks carrying dangerous goods that should not have been traveling in such weather conditions instead of being calmly on the roads. Or think of ships from Eastern European countries that sail in clearly dangerous conditions. Surveys conducted in Belgian, Finnish and even Japanese ports have also shown that 50 percent of containers containing partly dangerous goods are not delivered in compliance with the current regulations. In short, the importance of the topic is enormous. As regards the situation of safety consultants, in some Member States companies are required to have an internal one from 1 January this year. Currently, this regulation creates many problems, especially for smaller companies, which do not have sufficient financial resources. As a result, these companies are forced to give up their load or to mix it with another load, with the serious problems that this generates. For this reason, companies are required to integrate these activities in their financial statements, or in their business analyses, which may be included in ISO 9002 certifications. The regulatory framework is ready, now we have to deal with its implementation. Allow me to make one last point, still concerning the application of the regulations. Satisfactory agreements must be made with the Eastern European countries, since they will only join the relevant treaties from 1 July 2001, i.e. in just a year and a half. These countries currently enjoy a slight competitive advantage, which is not serious. However, I believe that priority should be given to the safety aspects of road, rail and inland waterway transport and that this part of the acquis communautaire should be presented to the candidate countries in good time. Madam President, in this Parliament, the importance of transport safety is regularly highlighted, and rightly so. The ever-increasing volumes of goods crossing Europe involve, consciously or not, all kinds of risks for personnel, the environment and society. Those who have to manage these risks must therefore meet very stringent requirements. The rules laid down in another directive, Directive 95/35/EC, appear to be adequate enough to provide responsible advice on the organisation of the transport of dangerous goods. I am pleased that an agreement has been reached with the Council on minimum requirements for examinations of safety advisers, although I would have preferred to have drawn up uniform standards and programmes to ensure the equality of qualifications at international level.

Furthermore, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to dwell for a moment on the role and structure of the guidelines, before moving on to the main observations and criticisms made by the rapporteur or the honourable Members. On the role and structure of the guidelines, the Chairman of the competent committee, Mr Hatzidakis, the rapporteur and Mrs McCarthy have pointed out that they are intended to assist national and regional authorities in preparing the programming strategy for Objectives 1, 2, 3 of the Structural Funds and their links with the Cohesion Fund. The Commission's priorities are presented on the basis of the experience gained in implementing the programmes and of current Community policies related to structural interventions. The aim is to ensure that these priorities contribute to better use, optimal and effective use of Community interventions, as many of you have hoped, including by making use at the appropriate time, Mr Bradbourn, of the performance reserve specifically designed to promote optimal and effective use of European public money. When I speak of optimal use, I mean both at national and regional level, and therefore, Mr Seppänen, when I speak of the national level, I am also referring to the link with the Cohesion Fund. This is in relation to the objective of the guidelines. In relation to the content, however, as the honourable Members know, the guidelines are structured around three strategic priorities which the rapporteur has recalled with great clarity and also with great passion, as I was able to see in her speech. The first priority is to improve the competitiveness of regional economies in order to create, in all sectors, but particularly in the private sector, as Mr Berend said, the maximum number of serious, solid and lasting jobs. Competitiveness of regional economies, of all regional economies, therefore, and in particular of Wales, Mr Evans, but not only of Wales. I would also like to add, since many of you felt that this was an omission, the regional economies of the European regions disadvantaged by their geographical remoteness, whether peripheral regions, island regions or of course the outermost regions, which are the most remote. In this regard, I could perhaps reply to Mr Ribeiro i Castro who asked me, as I wrote to the presidents of the outermost regions, that the Commission has asked for a few weeks' extension for the publication of its report. We received the memoranda from the governments of the outermost regions very late, but this is certainly not intended to be an alibi, but rather an explanation. Extremely serious work needs to be done on these memoranda. I personally attended a meeting of the outermost regions on 23 November and the College felt that a few more weeks were needed to draft a report that was up to the extremely serious and grave problems and expectations of these outermost regions and I thank you for your understanding. That is the first priority, namely the competitiveness of regional economies. The second priority, on which many of you have insisted, in particular the Honourable Member Puerta and others - far be it from me to want to establish a hierarchical order between them - is the strengthening of social cohesion and employment, especially by valorising human resources, better than in the past.

Mr. President, this has been a very useful debate. One or two speakers have referred to specific issues that we have been strongly advised to think about carefully. For example, Mrs. Maij-Weggen spoke about both Indonesia and Burma, and she made some important points about those countries and the human rights situation there. I would like to focus very briefly on one or two topics that have been raised regularly throughout the debate. One of the very first speakers, Mr. Wuori, referred to the remarks made today by Mr. Havel. That was a remarkable speech, and I hope that Mr. Gollnisch, who is no longer able to be with us, was also able to hear it. I also hope, if there is life in space, as Mr. Newton Dunn has speculated, that she too was able to hear Mr. Havel's speech. The latter reminded us that our Union is not just about markets, about GDP growth, that it is a union of values, which is reflected in the Treaties and in our obligations in terms of external aid as a whole, which is reflected quite specifically in what we are mandated to do. How do we implement what the Treaties say about development aid programs? One or two honorable Members, Mr. Feber and Mr. Cushnahan, talked about the gulf between rhetoric and reality. Mr. Cashman said, and he is right in a sense, that words are no substitute for real action. Of course, words can make a small difference, as Mrs. Malmström pointed out. She said that she had received a letter from the Chinese Ambassador, a very kind and very intelligent representative and servant of his country, telling her that she was wrong and that the European Parliament was taking the wrong attitude towards human rights in China. I think that after her speech, she will receive a mountain of letters from the Chinese authorities. She will be able to fill a filing cabinet with letters concerning what is claimed to be the real situation in China. I think she reflected the views of many non-governmental organizations, many people who admire Chinese civilization but who are concerned about what is happening in China today. Obviously, it is absolutely true that we must consider action, and the very first speech, given by Mr. Salafranca, mentioned two separate issues from Geneva, which concerned action. One of them, of course, is made possible by the generosity of the European Parliament on behalf of European taxpayers—namely, the budget that we are able to spend on human rights activities—about €100 million that is spent through programs, for which I am responsible, and which go mainly to non-governmental organizations to promote human rights and democratization. We will need to share with Parliament, as the vicars say, our views on how best to focus and target this spending programme to support human rights in the years ahead.

That is the level of sophistication and provision I would like. All I can do at this point is promise that I will strive to achieve it. Let me first wish the Commissioner a Happy St. David's Day. Thank you for that introduction. It is important that the Commission never loses sight of the fact that the reform process will be a real waste of time unless contact is re-established with the citizens of Europe. That is what we must be fully focused on at all times. It must provide them with a service, and the recommendations to reduce payment times will, I am sure, be welcomed, but the other complaint we regularly hear from the citizens we represent is about red tape, excessive red tape. Is there any reference to reducing red tape and bureaucracy for applicants for European funding with the guarantee of financial control? That is a specific complaint we are hearing. We must address it. The other question I would like to ask concerns the Audit Progress Committee. This committee is, of course, welcome, but I think it is essential that it includes a reference to the scrutiny of the European Parliament's recommendations in our discharge procedure. Will you add this to the work of your Audit Progress Committee? Finally, the Socialist Group agrees with activity-based budgeting and accountability, and you will be judged, as Mr Prodi says, on your actions, not your words. The task of reconnecting the Commission with the citizens of Europe is critical, as Mrs Morgan said. It can only be achieved through actions, not words. I say this with some deference within the European Parliament because there are many experts in words, but we will try to lead by example. On the issue of excessive red tape, Mrs Morgan explained the dilemma well. We hate excessive paperwork, but given the requirements for control, additional control, and re-verification to ensure effective financial control, sometimes the demands of administration, which some call "bureaucracy," are unavoidable. However, with a view to reducing these obligations as much as possible, we are not just talking about it; we will appoint, in the not too distant future, a Deputy Secretary-General, an additional Deputy Secretary-General, whose specific mandate and task will be to identify best practices and disseminate them within the Commission; he will also have to ensure a radical reduction in the procedures that cause so much paperwork, so much bureaucracy, and, I would also say, so much frustration, not only among citizens and businesses in the Union, but also among all the people who work for the Commission. Certainly, we will strive to achieve this, and I believe that the effects will begin to be felt in the coming years. One of our difficulties will always be, of course, that the more effective we are at reform, the less people will know about it. So we will be counting on our friends and partners in the European Parliament to explain, with their usual generosity, all the efforts that the Commission is making to properly serve the citizens of Europe.

They live in areas that should benefit from these projects. If we achieve this from the perspective of this triple focus, I believe that these families, these individuals, these European citizens will believe more in Europe, and this seems very important to me because, ultimately, cities will increasingly be the protagonists of European life. (FR) Mr. President, before my colleagues and friends, Mr. Franz Fischler and Mrs. Anna Diamantopoulou, speak in turn—given that the three of us in charge of these four Community initiatives have been fortunate enough to follow this debate with the same attention—I would like to reiterate the evocation of URBAN and Interreg, which many of you have recalled and on which you have spoken. I would like to express my gratitude at the outset to the rapporteurs from the committees, from all of them, and also to the speakers from the groups and to each and every one of you for the excellent quality and the great interest that your interventions reveal in relation to these two initiatives. In particular, what Ms. Arlene McCarthy said about Urban is very true. I would like to thank her not only for the work and the report she has presented, but also, why not say it myself, for everything we owe her, what you owe her in relation to this initiative, which we also owe, more generally, to your Parliament. Indeed, I have not forgotten that it was the European Parliament that politically decided and desired the continuation of this initiative to promote the regeneration of urban areas in crisis, to promote sustainable urban development, while generating this integrated approach, which we so appreciate, to jointly address economic, social, and environmental aspects. Other points of agreement underlined by Ms. Arlene McCarthy's report are: the effectiveness of this instrument through financial concentration and a critical mass for interventions; the horizontal mechanism—which, in our view, is more conducive to disseminating results and multiplying exchanges of experiences and effective practices; and, finally, the growing role of local authorities in the design and management of programs, based on a genuine partnership. Having recalled the fundamental points of agreement between the Commission's proposals and your Parliament, and having emphasized my great interest in listening to the various contributions, I would like to respond to some criticisms and suggestions that have been made, apologizing in advance for not being able to personally quote each of those who spoke. I believe, however, that everyone will be able to identify with my remarks. First, the Urban program, and the maximum limit of fifty cities, which some of you have described as arbitrary. I understand this concern. I have therefore asked my services to be prepared to consider a reasonable increase in the number of cities that will be eligible for the Urban programme, subject to certain guarantees, relating firstly to concentration - I am thinking specifically of intervention zones, which must have a minimum of 20,000 inhabitants and, exceptionally, 10,000 - and secondly, to critical financial mass: we should stick to the figure of 500 euros per inhabitant so that the European Union's intervention is both effective and legible, and so that it does not appear to be some kind of superficial cosmetic that would offer no meaning either to citizens or to local authorities.

It is very helpful and I consider it a very good contribution from Mr Swoboda and his colleagues. We are very grateful for the way in which he has been able to conduct the work on this issue and for the contribution of some of his colleagues, some of whom are here this evening - Mr Pack, Mr Lagendijk and others. I am pleased that overall our relations with FYROM are so good, and perhaps Mr Dupuis, and his interpreter, will forgive me if I use this expression in a spirit of entente cordiale. This has been achieved thanks to the excellent representative of the European Union in the country, who is a great friend of Parliament and a great servant of the Commission. The imminent start of negotiations on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement is the most significant example of our good relations. The same can be said of FYROM's cooperation in the reconstruction of Kosovo. I am grateful to the authorities of Macedonia for the assistance they have provided in recent weeks in helping to address the considerable difficulties encountered in the supply of electricity in Kosovo. Like the honourable Members, I recognise the stabilising role played by this country during the tragedy in the Balkans, in particular with regard to the integration of the Albanian minority into the political and social life of the country. I saw the newly elected President Georgievski a few weeks ago and was extremely impressed, like others, by his commitment to multi-ethnicity and pluralism. If I may, I would like to explain how things stand with regard to the negotiations which - as Mr Lagendijk said - other countries in the region are looking at with great interest. On 24 January this year, the Council adopted negotiating directives for a Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which represents the most important step forward in the stabilisation and association process in the Western Balkans launched by the Commission in May 1999. Let me clarify the main elements of these draft directives, which provide for the inclusion in the agreement of provisions for establishing a political dialogue with FYROM, including provisions for improved regional cooperation, including the prospect of creating free trade areas between the countries of the region, although I must make it clear that any attempt to recreate the State of Yugoslavia is out of the question. They also cover the prospect of creating a free trade area between the European Union and the countries of the region within ten years of the entry into force of the agreement, provisions on the free movement of workers, the right of establishment, the provision of services, payments and capital movements, a commitment by FYROM to approximate its legislation to that of the European Union, in particular in key areas of the internal market, and provisions on cooperation with FYROM in a wide variety of fields, including justice and home affairs. The Commission is now making all the necessary preparations to ensure that negotiations can start in March. I will be visiting FYROM in the second week of March. I hope to be able to start the process then, although formal negotiations will start soon after.

What is the Commission's position on these considerations? Yugoslavia is also a weak link in stability and therefore poses a threat to the stability of Macedonia. We must await further developments in the situation. The climate in Belgrade is becoming more and more uncertain. However, we support the Council's decision to change the tone of the sanctions. This decision is at least a serious attempt to support the opposition, which is preparing for a new round of demonstrations. What does the European Union intend to do in this regard, if the opposition's demand for early elections is accepted? What can we still do to support the opposition? Mr President, Kosovo was hopefully the last case in which international law was interpreted as the right of a dictatorial leadership to persecute minorities in the most appalling way, with the argument that 'these are internal matters'. By the time the United States and NATO, and finally the European Union, decided to act, it was too late. If, for example, the Union had acted earlier and more clearly, much suffering would have been avoided. The European Union therefore now has a special responsibility in terms of aid, assistance and reconstruction in the Balkans. Our ultimate goal must remain to create the conditions that will allow all the countries of south-eastern Europe to integrate with the rest of the Union, economically, commercially and politically. Trade and economic integration are the best way to create fertile ground for democracy in a corner of Europe so devastated by war. We liberals are prepared to do a lot and to do it quickly, just as Paolo Costa has illustrated. We therefore welcome with great satisfaction the proposal for a Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Macedonia, and we thank Mr Swoboda for his excellent report. Macedonia deserves our help, also in recognition of the sacrifices and the generous work done by the people of Macedonia and their leaders during the war in Kosovo. Now that Macedonia is freeing itself from the destructive grip of communism and nationalism, we are clearly obliged to act and provide our assistance. Just as we will have to do for the other Balkan states. This is a duty for the Union. Mr President, in this context I would like to remind Members - not least in the light of a debate already held in the course of the evening - that the man who bears the main responsibility for the war, for the humiliation of human beings, for the massacres, and for the expulsion of innocent people from their homes still governs the rest of Yugoslavia, Serbia. The man who is accused of genocide and who should be tried by the war crimes tribunal in The Hague is still at large. I am talking about Milosevic. As long as Milosevic remains in power and Serbia does not take the path of democracy, Serbia will represent a constant threat to peace in the entire Balkan area and also to Macedonia. Mr President, this agreement will be the first step towards the implementation of the Stability Pact in South-Eastern Europe.

We must take into account the views of fishermen. We must take into account the concerns of fishermen and we must work closely with them. I hope that you, as the Commissioner responsible for fisheries, will be aware of this gap and will try to work as closely as possible to bring all parties together and to ensure that their views are taken into account. Thank you, Commissioner Fischler. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11 a.m. Insolvency proceedings The next item is the report (A5-0039/2000) by Mr Lechner, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, on the proposal for a Council regulation on insolvency proceedings (9178/1999 - C5-0069/1999 - 1999/0806(CNS)). Mr President, I believe that we all agree on the creation of a European judicial area. We also all agree that there should be harmonization in an area marked by extreme disparity in our legal systems, and even more so in concepts. The very word insolvency, the legal concept of insolvency, does not cover the same accounting notion in each of the Member States of the Union. So we agree on the observation, and the draft regulation and the report are going in the right direction. If I may, I will make a few observations, however, on the method. When we acknowledge - and we could not do otherwise - the disparity of legal systems and concepts, and we want to move towards better coordination, I believe there are three ways of proceeding. The first is to make equivalences by saying: ultimately, insolvency in France is the same thing as insolvency in England or in Germany. The second way to proceed is to recreate a law ex nihilo, that is to say to harmonize the systems, to completely overhaul all the concepts and legal systems in each of the States. This is not the path that has been taken. The third path that has been taken is ultimately to superimpose, on top of the existing systems, which are not touched, a veritable embryo of Community law on collective procedures and companies in difficulty. This is a good thing, moreover, and the result has probably exceeded the ambition of the authors. But at this stage I would like to make an observation, which is not technical, but more philosophical and inspired by practice. It is that insolvency is experienced in the European Union, in most States, as an absolutely definitive event for the person who experiences it. And I think it is our responsibility, in an economy that is moving faster and faster, where everyone must have a chance and a real chance, to give people the chance to try a business venture, and a second, a third chance if necessary.

At the request of a French MP, Mr. Zimeray, a petition has already been submitted; it has collected many signatures, including mine. However, I ask you, in accordance with the direction now constantly expressed by the European Parliament and the entire European Community, to intervene with the President and Governor of Texas, Mr. Bush, by using the prestige of your mandate and of the Institution you represent, because it is Mr. Bush who has the power to suspend the death sentence and pardon the condemned man. And all this while respecting the principles we have always upheld. Thank you, Mr. Segni; I will do so with pleasure. This is indeed entirely in line with the positions our Parliament has always adopted. Madam President, I would like to draw your attention to a case that has regularly been dealt with by Parliament. It is the case of Alexander Nikitin. We are all pleased in this House that the court ordered his release and clearly established that, in Russia too, access to environmental information is a constitutional right. However, it appears that he is being indicted again, as the public prosecutor has appealed. We know, and have established this in numerous resolutions – including during the last part-session last year – that this case is not only of a legal nature and that it is wrong to accuse Alexander Nikitin of criminal activity and treason because we are concerned with its results and we benefit from them. These results form the basis of the European programs for the protection of the Barents Sea, and that is why I ask you to consider a draft letter outlining the essential facts of this case and to inform Russia of the position that follows from Parliament's decisions. Yes, Mrs Schroedter, I will be happy to examine the facts relating to this matter when I receive your letter. Madam President, I would first like to congratulate you on keeping your word because, indeed, during this first part-session, in this new year, the number of television channels has been significantly increased in our premises. However, Madam President, what I requested has not been achieved. There are two Finnish channels and one Portuguese channel, but there is still no Dutch channel. Yet I asked you for a Dutch channel, because the Dutch also want to be able to follow the news every month when they are sent to this land of exile. I therefore ask you once again to take the necessary steps to ensure that we have a Dutch channel. Mrs Plooij-van Gorsel, I can tell you that this issue is on the agenda for the Quaestors' meeting on Wednesday. It will, I hope, be examined in a positive spirit. Madam President, how is it that Parliament does not comply with the health and safety regulations it votes on? How come no air quality tests have been conducted in this building since we were elected?

In this context, the most delicate problem arises: how does a European Public Prosecutor fit into relations with the various national communities and with the justice system, as it is structured? I believe this issue still needs to be addressed from both a cultural and a practical perspective. Today, we run the risk of superimposing a new institution on top of the multiple and diverse institutions that already exist in each of the States. Mr. President, I will briefly address two issues. First, I do not wish to comment on the philosophical aspects of subsidiarity and the sovereignty of the Member States, although I strongly support their debate. As a regular viewer of British television, I am aware of the complaints of British national politicians about what they consider a threat from the continent to their national legal culture. Sometimes they border on the theatrical, and I believe this merits a debate. However, this is not the topic I wish to address. The topic that interests me is Mrs. Theato's report. I believe that, given the legal difficulties this issue raises—and it is clear that the European Union only has a very narrow path to ensuring that these crimes are prosecuted as European crimes—the legal path has been lost. I am referring to recommendations 1 and 2. They no longer refer to a European prosecutor but, for legal reasons, have now become an independent European authority, a body Ms. Theato previously called for.
