In this regard, it is clear that we have difficulties with the legal basis. We also have difficulties with the crimes. This point has not been changed. It continues to include crimes that to some extent go beyond, or at least could go beyond, the scope of European crimes, such as money laundering and receiving stolen goods, and criminal association. In this context, it seems to me that some legally confusing points remain, which should be clarified. Even so, it is essential—and this is why we will vote in favor of point 1, excluding this recommendation—that Parliament sends a clear signal to the Commission and the Council of our desire to put an end, through a clear legislative act, to the situations that have taken root. Mr. President, Parliament has, for years, called for specific and uniform criminal protection of the Union's financial interests. The truth is that frustration increases when one realizes the fragility of the Convention (and the protocols relating to such protection), which, five years after its signature, has still not been ratified or entered into force. Moreover, more voluntaristic attempts, such as the current OLAF, fail to overcome legitimate concerns about the system of guarantees for individual rights. The proposals in Mrs. Theato's report, which call on the Commission to submit a substantive legislative act on the criminal protection of financial interests, defining the offences, particularly fraud against the Community budget, are, in our view, a serious attempt to establish a new and increasingly necessary uniform Community criminal law.

Thank you very much, Honourable Member. Allow me to congratulate you on what is known in German parliamentary circles—unjustifiably in your case—as the "debut speech" (Jungfernrede). Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking on behalf of my colleague Robert Goebbels, who had to be absent for a political commitment. Within the Economic and Monetary Committee, the Jonckheer report has sparked bitter controversies regarding the functioning of the market. A narrow right-wing majority has succeeded in eliminating any reference to the market's shortcomings. Even if our Parliament were to pursue this ultra-liberal concept of a supposedly perfect market, the world would not change. Economic relations in the real world amply demonstrate that the elimination of all government intervention in the market by no means produces perfect competition or an optimal distribution of resources. Although the market has been the privileged place of exchange between human beings since the dawn of time, it has never been perfect. The market prioritizes the short term and immediate profits. In the market, the balance of power between supply and demand generally works to the disadvantage of the weakest, consumers and workers. The market requires rules to function. The necessary and precious spirit of initiative must have as its corollary a sense of responsibility to society. We, European socialists, are in favor of a market economy with social goals. The market is not an end in itself; it must serve the improvement of the human condition. The European Union, the states, must not replace economic agents; rather, public authorities must define the rules and objectives that allow for sustainable economic development. Finally, aid makes it possible to carry out restructuring, offer training, save jobs, and, ultimately, act wisely. The Union's competition policy cannot have as its primary objective a reduction in the overall level of aid. This aid must be directed toward the Union's objectives, in particular, economic and social cohesion, sustainable development, and research. The Commission must pursue illegal aid and aid that actually hinders the internal market. Eliminating all public aid would be a grave mistake. The Internet is not a product of the market, but the result of research funded by the US military. The World Wide Web, which has made possible the meteoric rise of the information society, was the work of CERN in Geneva, financed, once again, with public aid. The German government's bailout of the Holzmann group has been criticized as an unjustifiable hindrance to the market economy. President Duisenberg has even tried to attribute the euro's relative weakness against the dollar to this state intervention. I have not heard Mr. Duisenberg criticize the bailout of the LTCM Hedge Fund by the US monetary authorities. Wanting to save 60,000 jobs is apparently a sin against the market, but the bailout of capital does not seem to pose any problems for defenders of the free market.

I therefore ask you, Madam President, to ask the Commission to speak now and then proceed to the vote. (Applause from the PSE Group) Madam President, first of all, I would like to make it perfectly clear that the Commission has the greatest respect for the decisions of this Parliament, and in particular for the one concerning the setting of the agenda. We therefore respect any decisions that Parliament may take in this regard. But I would also like to make it perfectly clear that President Prodi has undertaken with Parliament to establish a new debate, as Mr Barón pointed out, in addition to the annual debate on the Commission's legislative programme, on the broad lines of action for the next five-year period, that is, for this legislature. I would like to say, Madam President, that, in the agreement reached in September, this debate differs from the annual presentation of the Commission's legislative programme. I would add, Madam President, that, on the Commission side, we are ready and willing to organize this debate whenever it suits you, that we were ready to develop it this week, as was originally decided, based on the fact that it was presented the day before in a speech to the parliamentary groups. I would therefore like to repeat, Madam President, that, for our part, we have discussed the action programme for the next five years and that we are ready to come and present the programme for the next five years whenever Parliament decides, including this week, if that is its decision, and the programme for the year 2000 next month, on which we were in complete agreement. I propose that we vote on the Socialist Group's request to reinstate the Commission's statement on its strategic objectives. (Parliament rejects the request) The President. Still on the subject of Wednesday, I have another proposal concerning the oral question on capital gains tax. The PPEDE Group requests that this item be removed from the agenda. Is there a colleague who would like to speak on behalf of the group and justify this request? Madam President, in response to the laughter I hear among the Socialists, I have been told that large sections of the Socialist Group would also like to remove this item from the agenda because, during the vote in the Conference of Presidents, the responsible colleagues of the Socialist Group did not have the vote of the working group. I do not know if this information is correct, but in any case, the PPE-DE Group would be grateful if you would remove this item from the agenda because Parliament has indeed addressed this issue many times. There are decisions opposing such a tax. That is why my group requests that this item be removed from the agenda. Thank you, Mr Poettering. We now hear Mr Wurtz, who speaks against this request. Madam President, I would first like to point out Mr Poettering's lack of logic.

I have received 7 motions for resolutions, pursuant to Rule 37(2) of the Rules of Procedure, to close this statement. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday. Cyprus and Malta The next item is the joint debate on: the Council declaration on the position of the European Union on developments in the Cyprus question; the report (A4-0029/2000) by Mr. Brok, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy, on the proposal for a Council regulation on the implementation of measures within the framework of the pre-accession strategy for Cyprus and Malta [COM(1999)0535 - C5-0308/1999 - 1999/0199(CNS)]. Mr. Seixas da Costa has the floor on behalf of the Council. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, I would like to provide some information on the resumption of intra-Cypriot negotiations and recent developments on this issue. I believe that what happened in Helsinki at the end of last year and the new atmosphere prevailing, particularly within the framework of the relationship between the European Union and Turkey, reflect—as is evident to all—a backdrop at the Community level to which the very framework of relations between the two communities, within the context of Cyprus, cannot fail to be sensitive. I would like to emphasize that at the beginning of December last year, the first round of negotiations—which had been interrupted for several years—between the northern and southern Cypriot communities of the island was held in New York. These were indirect talks mediated by the United Nations Special Representative, Álvaro de Souto. In January of this year—starting on January 31—another round was held, and a third round is scheduled to begin in New York on May 23. There is a possibility, not yet fully confirmed, that these talks will be direct and ongoing, extending their work until September of this year. The substantive aspects of this debate are essentially four: security, governmental structure, territorial adjustments, and refugees and compensation resulting from the situation created after the division of the island. However, it had been agreed that other issues could be included, so the representative of the northern part of the island, Rauf Denktash, proposed three new topics: sovereignty, confidence-building measures, and the lifting of the embargo on products from the north of the island. The talks held so far have yielded two essential results: the possibility of structuring a direct channel of information between the European Union and the northern part of the island—without necessarily implying its recognition as an entity with legal personality at the international level—is emerging, in order to facilitate the adoption of a Community acquis for the possible accession of the entire island, should a resolution to the overall problem of the island's division be achieved in the meantime. The second result, which we consider important, is the statement made by the Secretary-General of the United Nations at the end of the first day of talks, stating that, if a comprehensive agreement on the situation were reached, it would entail recognition of the specific characteristics of the north of the island.

This is the only way for Cambodians to forgive those who were merely followers and for a lasting peace. Mr President, this week it became known that two major Cambodian opposition newspapers were threatened with closure because they had insulted the King and the Prime Minister. These are newspapers that actively support opposition leader Sam Rengie, who is currently being stripped of his parliamentary immunity so that he can be tried for treason. In his millennium speech, Sam Rengie dared to say that the succession procedure for King Sihanouk must be clarified - if he ever dies. In March last year, a member of Sam Rengie's party was killed by a group of people in military uniform in Kandal province. In September, two party members were arrested for their involvement in a rocket attack on the Prime Minister. It is worth noting that this is the only party in Cambodia that does not have an armed wing. In October, a member of parliament from the same party was kidnapped by men in uniform and released after a ransom was paid. The campaign of intimidation is evident. In Cambodia, much more is happening: torture of prisoners, involvement of the army and police in trafficking of minors and women, and excessive use of pre-trial detention. All this is the order of the day. Even more serious is the government's refusal to have the leaders of the Khmer Rouge tried by an international tribunal. It is true that the civil war in Cambodia is over and political tensions are less accentuated. The way in which the political opposition is treated is a source of serious concern and, if the situation does not change, this will also have repercussions on relations between the European Union and Cambodia. Mr President, a new doctrine is increasingly imposing itself in international law, according to which no state can afford to treat its own citizens and residents as it wishes. Despite the presence of a democratically elected government, even the principle of national sovereignty is no longer sufficient to prevent third countries from intervening in cases of clear violations of human rights. Clear examples of this are the Pinochet-Ugarte case, the crisis in Kosovo and, in a more moderate form, the debate within the European Union about the new Austrian government. In Cambodia, however, this trend risks coming to nothing if those responsible for the former revolutionary government are not brought to justice. At the same time, the fight against impunity is also being jeopardised. This should remind us that ratification of the treaty establishing an international criminal court has been shamefully slow. Mr President, yesterday's debate on human rights was extremely useful; I am pleased with this further opportunity to look at the situation in some regions of the world - Kosovo, Angola, Chechnya and Cambodia - where the protection of human rights has proved to be a very difficult task.

The regulation might mislead one into thinking that this is the case, but in reality this is not the case. The Commission has not made any changes to the regulation for years, despite Parliament having long called for this. In practice, this means that in the short term these regions are once again reduced to receiving only the funds for peripheral regions. Parliament has been calling since 1996 for a common fund for cooperation with third countries to be set up to overcome the difficulties in this area, but nothing has been done! The problems continue to drag on, to the detriment of the regions concerned. Parliament once again calls for improved and extended cross-border cooperation, for a common fund to be set up and for further changes to the regulation in cooperation with the other Commissioners. We want a Europe that responds to the needs of citizens, not a Europe of bureaucrats! Mr President, a third of the Union budget goes into development funding, which my group finds excellent, provided that this eliminates the development gap in regions, cities and groups of people, or improves the health and environmental situation. It is a question of solidarity and progress. But the distribution of ever-larger sums of money is no guarantee that the way in which these funds are spent will improve. The municipalities and regions that benefit from these funds have gained some experience in the meantime and find that it is incredibly difficult to invest the money in the areas that need it most. Projects related to economic growth and infrastructure usually produce quite satisfactory results, while projects in the social and environmental fields are not always guaranteed to be approved. Given the great uncertainty surrounding the interpretation of the rules, the regions and municipalities seek the assistance of expensive consultancy firms. These experts are tasked with estimating the extent to which European Commission officials are prepared to approve the plans submitted. In some cases, I have the impression that it is not a question of solidarity or of solving the most urgent problems, but rather that it is aimed at maintaining vested interests and propaganda for the blessings that come from the European Union. It seems to me that the possibility of displaying a billboard saying that such and such a project is co-financed by the European Union has become the main aim. Too much money is spent on propaganda and consultancy firms, on consultations and controls, and much of the money ultimately goes back to the coffers of the Member State that originally paid it. After the expected accession of new Member States, whose standard of living is one to two thirds of the average of the current Member States of the European Union, such a waste of resources will generate even more opposition. In the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, the Confederal Group of the European United Left agreed with the rapporteur for the opinion on the LEADER programme, Mr Nogueira Román, who rightly stated that it is not wise to disperse resources across all rural areas.

It would therefore be extremely important to incorporate this cumulative requirement. Finally, I would like to reiterate that, in my opinion, Mr Di Pietro has done an excellent job in presenting a report which, in the context of the limited opportunities available, offers all possible guarantees for the protection of individual rights and fundamental freedoms. However, if we want to give European citizens a greater sense of security, we must strengthen legal assistance. Mr President, my group welcomes the fact that a convention is being launched to frame the daily practice of legal assistance in criminal matters in a specific regulation. The proposal under consideration is complex, because it analyses the agreements in force between the Member States, but it has profound consequences for the relationship between the State and its citizens. The Council's proposal highlights enormous shortcomings precisely in the field of legal protection. According to the rapporteur, Mr Di Pietro, the proposal actually contains colossal gaps. The convention makes possible a whole chain of requests for legal assistance, involving the authorities and judicial systems of other Member States in a cascade. The way in which this practice is regulated means that the abovementioned chain cannot be kept under control in its entirety by any magistrate. Supplementary measures must therefore be adopted, such as the obligation for investigators to testify, when requested, in any criminal proceedings in which the material they have collected is used. My group also takes a disfavored view of the fact that the Council proposal tramples on the principle of proportionality. There are no limitations on the scope of application, so the convention does not only concern the fight against the most serious crimes and organised crime. Nowhere is it written that it concerns only criminal law, so it is not unthinkable that the European Union will soon use heavy weapons to fight petty crime and that citizens' rights will disappear, suffocated by the smoke of gunpowder. Mr President, the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters, which we are examining today, contains the bare minimum for effective and rapid cooperation between the various judicial or investigative bodies. It concerns notifications, the exchange of information, the temporary transfer of prisoners, the restitution of assets, testimonies by videoconference, investigative and so-called undercover activities, telephone interceptions, and more. It is the least that can be agreed upon, and it must be said straight away that, if some amendments were to pass, such as for example no. 32 or no. 81, the revised no. 70 or the revised no. 71, the whole convention would be reduced to the exchange of notifications or information and would really have to be thrown in the bin, and we would vote against it. I hope that the good sense of my colleagues in the various groups will lead them to reject these amendments. The fact that this has not become a framework agreement but has remained at the level of conventions is also a defeat for Parliament. As Commissioner Vitorino will have noted from all the various interventions, the need to develop a framework of common rules emerges, that is, to no longer go on like this, with this scattered order, with these small conventions that concern various sectors such as investigations or others.

In the system in use in the northern Member States, however, the financial component is applied differently. Everyone has to pay, regardless of whether they dump their waste at sea or deliver it. There is also a kind of economic incentive built into this system that encourages ships to deliver their waste to port. It is a well-tested system that has been researched and proven to be effective. That is one of the reasons why Parliament and the committee whose work I am called upon to defend insist on the need to maintain a percentage of indirect costs and integrate it into anchorage charges. I will now explain in detail the essence of our proposal. The percentage applied must be 90 percent, first point. We could also decide on 75 percent, but in any case we need to ensure a solid and consistent basis, otherwise we will once again find ourselves with a plethora of different systems before we have, so to speak, learned the lesson that we actually already know. I would therefore like to convince everyone that for the reasons I have given, it is reasonable to opt for a system that integrates indirect costs in one way or another into anchor charges. The Commission proposal in its current form leaves the Member State free to reduce indirect costs to 0.01 percent if it so wishes. And I fear that in practice everyone will do exactly that. This will be the most important aspect on which we will have to focus our exchanges in the future. There are many other elements in the proposal, and we have reached agreement on many of them. I am convinced that we will be able to find a solution, but what I have explained to you is the crux of the whole issue, to which I wanted to draw everyone's full attention. Mr President, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to stress that we have had an excellent discussion in the two readings. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Bouwman, very much for taking up the dossier and for explaining it so well. We agree with the Council on three points. Firstly, all European ports that do not yet have them must build adequate collection facilities for ship waste. The presence of these facilities is therefore mandatory. Secondly, all ships, regardless of their flag, must dispose of the waste they generate. Thirdly, the costs must be charged to the ship in question. We agree on these points. In practice, we want to set up a system together to prevent economic incentives to throw waste into the sea. Firstly, we want to protect flora and fauna, and secondly, there are many coasts where not only do many tourists arrive, but where jobs need to be created. In short, we want an effective system. How does our position differ from that of the Council, apart from a few small details, such as the exemption from bureaucratic provisions that we are asking for museum ships and the somewhat stricter provisions that we want for large fishing vessels and pleasure boats?

That's why, as discussed in committee, I have now proposed an amendment to Amendment 2, which includes the abandonment of the term "harmonization." This is done in the knowledge that the Council is meeting us halfway, and that we can then meet the Council halfway in return, because I believe this directive is a sensible step forward. Nevertheless, and the Council must know this, it is of course sensible for the Member States in the Council to coordinate such controls and threatened sanctions sooner or later. It would be absurd if, for example, in Finland, violations were punishable by almost a prison sentence, while in a southern country, only a small fine was imposed, or vice versa. That makes no sense. That's not European either. Therefore, I would like to reiterate the procedure: Amendment 3 replaces Amendment 2, which was voted on by the committee. It would therefore have to be voted on first tomorrow. I would be very grateful if this could be communicated to the Bureau, which will preside over the vote tomorrow. Then we wouldn't have a procedural problem. So first, let's vote on Amendment 3. That would then replace Amendment 2. That's how it was discussed in committee, and then we could have this regulation very quickly and avoid having to resort to a complex conciliation procedure for a solution that, in principle, makes sense. Mr President, everything has been said. Please allow me to build a bridge for the Vice-President so that she might support Amendment 3, which replaces Amendment 2. There are sometimes Members in this Chamber who say: It does make sense to standardize traffic controls in terms of their severity and intensity. But when the term "harmonization of sanctions" is mentioned, some in this Chamber flinch—left and right, top and bottom of this House. That's why I think Amendment 3, which Mr Piecyk, as rapporteur, has drafted, is wonderful. He avoided the word "harmonization" altogether. But he did say what it was about. He said that it cannot be that the use of a commercial vehicle, a bus with passengers, without observing safety regulations – which endangers people's lives and limbs – is considered a minor offense in one country and severely punished in another. However, this would be necessary given the danger to passengers and other road users. Therefore, the question here is not: are we for subsidiarity or centrality? The point is that it is not acceptable for us to have the common goal of road safety, but some governments say: well, in terms of penalties, we treat road safety violations like violations of the ban on entering certain green spaces, and the others give it the right weight. First principle, Madam Vice-President: equal consideration of the need to improve road safety. The second argument is that there must be no distortion of competition within the Community. There are certainly examples where, in one country, the trucks of another Member State are subjected to particularly strict controls and severe sanctions, detention, etc., while in another country it makes no difference at all. This is the core of the difference between Parliament and the common position: We do believe that, in relation to sanctions, which remain within their national competence, Member States should try to coordinate their efforts from the perspective of: How do I assess the threat to traffic and how do I ensure equal competition within the Community in a single market?

I would like to address a very important point regarding the impact on businesses, raised by Mrs Thyssen, Mrs Peijs, and Mrs Palacio Vallelersundi: this concerns SMEs. Many speakers have emphasized this. The Commission pays particular attention to legal certainty for SMEs. We are proposing a system that significantly improves legal certainty for SMEs. Why? Is this simply a political gesture? No. In this system, we propose to reform our important rules in such a way that most SMEs are covered by block exemption regulations, as in the area of vertical restraints. Most SMEs have less than a 30% market share. We have a de minimis opinion containing the following statement: since SMEs are not involved in market dominance, they are not normally subject to the strict prohibition contained in Article 81(1). We are currently developing additional block exemptions and guidelines, all of which will take into account the special situation of SMEs. Furthermore, our White Paper on Modernisation will also improve the situation of SMEs, firstly by eliminating the bureaucracy resulting from the current notification system and secondly, by making Article 81(3) directly applicable, which will benefit SMEs in particular. (IT) Fourthly, legal certainty. Certainly, Mr Evans, legal certainty is – I am the first to acknowledge this – essential for businesses and not only for the legal professions, which nevertheless play a very important role in promoting European integration. Legal certainty is essential for businesses; it is one of the issues whose importance was also highlighted in her last speech by the Chair of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, Mrs Palacio Vallelersundi – whom I thank for her way of following the issues relating to the single market in the broad sense and therefore, in this case, competition as well. I am convinced that this proposal will increase legal certainty for businesses for three reasons: it will allow, without prior decision, under the direct effect of Article 81(3), all agreements restricting competition that meet the conditions for exemption; it will allow businesses to be assisted in cases of doubt regarding interpretation through the publication of reasoned opinions; and it will be accompanied by exemption regulations and guidelines aimed at clarifying the rules and ensuring certainty. Mrs Thyssen also referred to the issue of legal privilege for company lawyers. Let me just point out that the Court of Justice ruled on this issue, as you know better than I, in 1982. This case law remains valid and there is no reason to call it into question. The White Paper requires a re-examination of the issue in only one respect: the exchange of confidential information. The guarantees that must be given to businesses are currently under discussion. (IT) I now come, Mr President, briefly to the report by Mr Rapkay, whom I thank warmly for the quality of his work and for the overall support given to the Commission's 28th annual report on competition policy.

However, accurately understanding and assessing all situations and expectations is a task that is virtually impossible. I belong to a country whose southern half faces the Mediterranean, and where water availability historically responds to the whims of a volatile climate and a difficult terrain. The Mediterranean region has had to fight for its development, trying to overcome this adversity century after century, year after year, day after day, right up to the present day. Therefore, we believe that the practical application of the directive's obligation contained in Article 164 of the Treaty, which requires Community legislation to take into account the diversity of its regions, is essential. Precisely in application of this principle, the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will oppose Amendments 4 (Recital 21), 13, and 49 (Article 11(d)), as they represent a serious limitation for an area of exclusive management by the Member States, such as the regulation of their water resources. It would be very difficult for the Community to determine the conditions for its regulation in the different regions, given the different internal balances that are always at stake and which in any case require an in-depth knowledge of the different areas and interests involved. We also reject the amendments that seek to incorporate the full cost of water for 2010. Undoubtedly, we must set water prices that incentivize its efficient use but, at the same time, maintain the competitiveness of the productive sectors in the most disadvantaged regions and do not impede their legitimate development. Finally, I would like to refer to the amendments relating to hazardous substances, which establish that a zero or near-zero pollution level must be achieved. Zero pollution has not yet been achieved for any human activity. Ladies and gentlemen, we would be doing a disservice to the objectives of this important directive if we are unable to provide it with the necessary flexibility and adaptability to ensure compliance. I hope that, once again, this Parliament will vote with a sense of reality and respect for the principle of subsidiarity, seeking an appropriate balance between environmental objectives and economic and social considerations, the three essential elements for achieving the sustainable development we all so desire. Mr. President, Commissioner, this is a very important directive. Its objective is to improve water quality and the safety of distribution systems. Citizens must have the right to clean water. This is important for both the environment and public health. I am not speaking so much on my own behalf, as I happen to be one of the small group of privileged Europeans who can drink water directly from the nearest lake in the neighborhood. We must strive to ensure that improvements in water quality are implemented quickly. Let us start working now. We cannot afford delays. It is important that the timetable be ambitious. In my opinion, it's not too ambitious, considering the goal is to stop discharging impurities into water by 2020 and aim to reduce the rate of discharge of impurities and harmful materials to zero by that date.

As is well known, the European Commission should have presented new proposals by the end of 1998 to amend Directive 97/67 on postal services, while maintaining universal service and ensuring its economic viability, by providing for the gradual liberalization of the postal services market and taking into account the consequences for all those affected, including employees and customers. To this end, the Commission commissioned studies on the costs of universal service, the impact of liberalization on cross-border mail and direct mail, the consequences of reducing weight and price limits in the exclusive sector, and the impact of the subsequent phases of liberalization of postal services other than delivery. An overall evaluation of the results of the studies was also to be carried out. We are asking ourselves, and of course the Commissioner too – Mr Bolkestein is not here, but Mr Monti, with his broad expertise, can certainly comment on this: shouldn't these studies also examine the economic and social impact of the various liberalisation scenarios on each, I repeat, each, Member State of the European Union? Postal services are very different in Greece from those in Great Britain, and very different in the Netherlands from those in Belgium. After liberalisation, how will the universal postal service be adequately financed and organised in a country such as my own, Greece, which has the particular geographical feature of having many small but inhabited islands? How will an operator in my country, which is obliged to provide a universal service, survive if approximately 25% of cross-border postal services are liberalised, when in other countries this figure is less than 5%? What is the response to the relocation of the national postal service abroad? You heard what Mr McCartin just said about this. Since this is highly likely due to technological developments that make this shift easier and thus more profitable, further gradual and controlled liberalization must be decided upon, with simultaneous definition of weight and price categories. But what should these look like? Will we be so naive as to allow the companies, who then act like "free shooters," to pick out the most lucrative items and circumvent the weight limits without any problem, since the contents of the mail cannot be verified anyway? In any case, we call on the Commission to lay bare its cards and present its proposals, while examining the planned overall development of this matter from all sides and for all Member States. Of course, liberalization is not an end in itself, but merely a means to improve services. Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues! The envisaged liberalization of traditional national postal services inevitably raises the question of what the postal services will consider their core business in the future—in other words, what the postal services will still do themselves, what they will do together within the international network, and what they will no longer do. This question must be answered against the background of the fact that the sole monopoly has already been de facto eroded by various courier services and technological developments such as fax and email. On the other hand, employment is the central focus of postal services' liberalization.

By granting de facto preference to products from settlements in occupied territories during the validity of these trade agreements, the EU is violating two fundamental principles of international law: the rules on the unilateral integration of occupied territories, and the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949. Since respect by the EU and the world for these two international principles is the basis of the peace process that has been initiated, such violations have the effect of undermining the foundations of the peace process itself. The EU must now choose between basing its relations with Israel and Palestine on the norms of international law, and thus strengthening the peace process, or ignoring international law altogether. The choice should be simple. International law prescribes that we establish trade relations only with countries and regions that it recognizes, and not with territories whose membership is disputed. EU Member States and Israel must respect the rules contained in the trade agreement on strict control of the origin of products, and customs duties must be returned. It is up to the Commission to ensure this. Commissioner Vitorino's intervention gives us some hope in this regard. The Middle East peace process must be given a chance. And this chance can only be based on international law. The EU has a responsibility to contribute to this. Mr President, Members of the European Parliament, I would first like to thank all the Members who have made a rich and valuable contribution to this debate at a time when a highly politically sensitive issue has been addressed. If the Commission can draw a lesson from this debate, I would say that we could conclude that, broadly speaking, Parliament is sticking to a cautious but clear strategy, which the Commission will also adopt to address this issue. The Commission is aware of the political sensitivity of this issue and has no doubt at any time that progress in finding concrete solutions for the practical implementation of this trade agreement is closely linked to developments in the Middle East peace process. In fact, the political importance attached to the peace process by the European Union is echoed in Parliament and the Commission, as several Members have pointed out, and this interest stems from the recent visit to this region by President Nicole Fontaine and President Romano Prodi last week. We are therefore well aware that we are living through a particularly delicate moment in the peace process, which must not be disrupted by positions resulting from a blind application of legal rules, since the application of the law requires an attempt to find a solution acceptable to all parties. And in truth, the Commission has adopted a position in this area aimed at securing the support and convergence of all parties involved in this peace process.

I would like to emphasize to Mr Schulz that we do not table amendments as individuals or out of personal considerations, but always within the framework of a general political interest. If we wanted to draw up a list of those under investigation, or to search for such individuals, we could also find them among the rapporteurs, including the author of the report on this convention. I therefore believe Mr Schulz could have spared himself his offensive remarks. As I have already said, numerous amendments have been incorporated concerning the right of defense—I am thinking here of the obligation for the investigating judge to submit a request—and the fact that joint investigation teams may not include officials who are also judges. In principle, Parliament wanted the convention to apply exclusively to criminal law; the curtailment of fundamental rights and freedoms provided for in the convention must therefore necessarily be limited to criminal law. We need firm rules. It is, of course, true that the Council did not act consistently, that it changed its mind during the procedure, and that it is not present today. On the other hand, I would like to thank Commissioner Vitorino for being present in this Chamber during the debate. We therefore need secure rules to ensure that fair trials are conducted in the Union – without being overwhelmed by surveillance measures, without the unlawful use of videoconferencing; so that there will never again be trials in the Union in which judges play politics instead of dispensing justice; so that the truly guilty parties are punished, not innocent people who are inconvenient to anyone. Mr President, the draft Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union is about to be adopted by the Council. Most people say it is about time. Following the Action Plan to Combat Organized Crime, adopted by the Council in April 1997, work on the draft MLA Convention should be completed before the end of 1997. However, it will be some time before it actually enters into force, given that ratification by the Member States is required. Even under the new rules of the Amsterdam Treaty, which stipulate that the Convention will enter into force only after at least half of the Member States have accepted it, I would nevertheless urge the Member States to do everything in their power to ratify it as soon as possible. Unfortunately, past experience with the ratification of European Union conventions in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters has been disappointing. This Convention does not seek to create a new or different system of mutual legal assistance. Rather, it aims to build on tried and tested mechanisms that have existed for a very long time, such as those provided for by the 1959 European Mutual Assistance Convention and the Benelux Treaty. The draft prepared by the Council contains provisions on a wide range of matters that have been discussed by various Members. It is a notable achievement of the Convention that requested Member States must, wherever possible, adhere to the formalities and procedures referred to by the requesting Member State. This is particularly important with regard to the possibility of using judicial evidence.

We cannot continue to allow all our political possibilities to be destroyed. Income from non-economic activities cannot continue to increase ever more rapidly. Since Tobin developed his idea, it has emerged that in Germany, income from financial capital has increased from 7.6% of all income to almost double that figure today. We cannot continue to see the poorest countries on this planet being the hardest hit by speculation affecting short-term currency fluctuations. Nor do I think it is unfeasible. Why should it not be possible to reach an agreement between the G7 states, the other EU states, China, Singapore, and Switzerland on the introduction of the Tobin tax? There must be a common economic interest. Why could we not manage - the distinction can be made - to subject to this tax transactions aimed at the immediate exchange of currencies, all so-called spot transactions, forward and option transactions on currencies? Why could we not set the amount of this tax in such a way as not to threaten economically indispensable long-term investments, but to ultimately make short-term and speculative investments unattractive? Many difficult questions will undoubtedly arise, but the only major problem I perceive is political will and this Sankt Florian principle, also applicable today, which consists of shifting responsibility from one place to another. Madam President, as Mr. Karas said a few minutes ago, we are not asking for more bureaucracy. We are looking for solutions. There is no doubt that more clarity is needed on the capital markets: that is the idea. The Tobin tax will bring some transparency to this very obscure issue. The more we move towards trade liberalization, the more rules we need. This is what Commissioner Lamy said at the opening of the Millennium Round in Seattle. He acknowledged that the combined effect of the single market and the single currency that characterize the process of building the European Union is closely linked to an enormous volume of new regulations. Now that capital can immediately cross national borders without any difficulty, it is clear that the same approach will be strictly necessary, especially since the amounts engaged daily in speculative transactions are enormous. We, citizens of the world, cannot accept the current level of speculation. To continue would be economic suicide. My dear colleagues, Commissioner, we often hear that Europe has succeeded in ensuring financial stability, which is true if we limit ourselves to the public sector. But if we include the private sector, we see that this famous financial stability has not only not been achieved, but that we are likely sitting on a volcano ready to erupt at any moment. Private sector over-indebtedness and the corresponding excessive surge in share prices – the two major indicators of financial market stability – have long been in the red, as the Commission's own report on the economic situation in Europe demonstrates in a way that is beyond dispute.

We believe that one factor that will influence the Commission's role in the near future is a certain revival of European political initiative on the part of the Member States' governments, following the failure of the Santer Commission. We consider this a very positive aspect, as it will enable the national parliaments, on which governments depend, to continue to insist on the indispensability of their democratic mandate in the construction of Europe. It is a fact that the European Parliament still fails to win the trust or even the interest of national public opinion, which stubbornly refuses to think in European terms, as demonstrated by the high abstention rate recorded in the recent elections. The aim, therefore, is to strengthen the mechanisms used for cooperation between the governments of the Member States by making them more coherent, transparent, and democratic. We welcome Romano Prodi's efforts to improve the Commission's public image and the need for it to reach an understanding with the European Parliament and the Council. However, we believe that the priority should be to reform the mechanisms of intergovernmental cooperation, particularly by creating a Council of Ministers for Europe, whose members would assume responsibility, among themselves and in consultation with the other European institutions, for ensuring that the political decisions of the European Councils are translated into concrete action. Corrie Report (A5-0032/2000) Madam President, the work of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly in 1999 was marked by growing concern about the continued existence of the cooperation model emerging from the Lomé Conventions. As early as 1994, in an initial resolution, to which our colleague Dominique Souchet played a key role, the Joint Assembly expressed concern about the foreseeable consequences of the Uruguay Round, which had rejected the fundamental principle of Community preference, essential to such cooperation. These fears have been confirmed over the last two years. The most striking example is the banana dispute. Despite their unstable economies, developing countries are expected to adapt to trade liberalization. While Mr Corrie's report criticizes this situation and reaffirms the Joint Assembly's commitment to the Lomé model, it fails to sufficiently highlight a second problem, which is also fundamentally rooted in the misguided free trade policy: the incoherence of the regional trade agreements concluded by the European Union. The best example is the cooperation agreement with South Africa. The Council approved this agreement, negotiated by the Commission, even though the nevertheless important agricultural chapter had not yet been finally settled. As our colleague Paul-Marie Coûteaux aptly noted in his remarks yesterday and in his amendments, one must ask what political logic such a blank cheque might represent. We are very concerned about this, all the more so as a similar agreement with Mexico appears to be on the horizon. The rapporteur's call for the European Development Fund to be incorporated into the Community budget is also unacceptable. We want to preserve the clear commitment and responsibility of each Member State, as the intergovernmental nature allows. Unfortunately, we have seen too many examples of joint aid being diverted from its intended purpose, for which no one feels responsible, and we want to avoid such a disastrous system in the EDF.

(Parliament adopted the motion for a resolution) Report (A5-0078/1999) by Mr Rapkay, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the 28th Commission report on competition policy 1998 (SEC(1999)0743 - C5-0121/1999 - 1999/2124(COS)) (Parliament adopted the motion for a resolution.) Report (A5-0087/1999) by Mr Jonckheer, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Seventh Report from the Commission on State aid in the manufacturing and certain other sectors in the European Union (COM(1999)148 - C5-0107/1999 - 1999/2110(COS)) (Parliament adopted the motion for a resolution.) Report (A5-0073/1999) by Mr Langen, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Commission report on the application of its Decision No 2496/96/ECSC of 18 December 1996 introducing Community rules on Aid to the iron and steel industry (Steel Aid Code) in 1998 (COM(1999)94 - C5-0104/1999 - 1999/2107(COS)) (Parliament adopted the motion for a resolution.) Explanations of vote - Own resources system . (FR) The European Union is, as we know, financed from four sources of revenue. The European budget is fed by value added tax (VAT) and the share of GDP, particularly since the abolition of Community preference and the proliferation of free-trade areas led to the abolition of customs duties and the Community agricultural levy, which had already been curtailed by the GSP. Since then, the collection and fairness of Community own resources have been seriously compromised by VAT fraud and distortions in the calculation of GDP as the basis for taxing the fourth resource. Therefore, Europe, with its federal pretensions, is financing itself more than ever like a banal intergovernmental organization—which, indeed, it is, but does not want to be. This is quite clear from the regulation before us. Concerns are expressed about the "accounting of own resources," their "provision," and the "control" of the amounts made available to the Commission. Moreover, the newly created advisory committee consists of representatives of the contributing Member States. This is a far cry from the excesses already existing with "Community criminal law," the "Community Public Prosecutor General," or the Community police force with OLAF. There is still no European federal tax. However, the Europe of 25 will demand a European income tax, unless it prefers a profit tax, or the 2025 budget is financed from CO2 taxation. Koch Report (A5-0105/1999). (FR) I am very pleased with this report on improved harmonisation of the training of safety advisers for the transport of dangerous goods. Over recent years, the national and international transport of dangerous goods has increased considerably, with the associated risk of accidents rising sharply. In many cases, these accidents were due to insufficient knowledge of the risks associated with such transport. It therefore became necessary, as part of the creation of the internal market, to adopt measures to improve risk prevention. Directive 96/35/EC responded to this need. Undertakings whose activities include the transport of dangerous goods or the loading or unloading associated with such transport were rightly required to be subject to risk prevention rules applicable to transport by road, rail or inland waterway. To facilitate the implementation of this objective, Directive 96/35/EC provided for the appointment of appropriately trained safety advisers for the transport of dangerous goods.

An appeal to the majority of the Austrian people who did not vote for Haider, who voted for clearly democratic options, committed to Europe—and I must point out that if Mr. Schüssel was Finance Minister, Chancellor Vranitzky also lent a hand in Austria's integration process. One cannot be so politically sectarian. We achieved Austria's entry into the Community together. It was the work of everyone, not just one group. Therefore, Madam President, I believe we have the right and our obligation to ask the Austrians to reconsider and reconsider, because the kind of plague we have already suffered in Europe can not only harm Austria but can, if necessary, spread, and I speak with the memory of history. Therefore, I would like to know if the EPP, apart from its defense of Mr. Schüssel, who will guarantee us everything, as Chamberlain and Daladier did in Munich in 1938, plans to take action against the Austrian People's Party if it goes ahead with this delusional project. Thirdly, if we do not rise up against this unnatural alliance, I can tell you, ladies and gentlemen, that the main objective of the European Union, which is enlargement, can be considered over because, if you were Czechs or Slovenians or Hungarians, what would you say if you had a neighbor who treated you on a racial basis and did not want you to join? Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, I believe this is a great day for the beginning of political Europe. We support the Council and believe that we are within our rights and under our obligation to address the Austrian people so that they seriously reconsider this absolutely delusional option. (Applause from the PSE Group) Madam President, my group welcomes this debate because we find ourselves at a decisive moment. This is the first time in the history of the modern European project that we are on the verge of witnessing the integration of a far-right party. This is deeply disturbing. The FPÖ argues that if we read its documentation and its programme, we will find many things we could share. That may be so, but today I want to record in the Minutes the long and difficult experience we Liberal Democrats had with the Austrian FPÖ in our Liberal International family. As early as 1986, we had reason to believe that Mr. Jörg Haider was not a man whose principles or attitudes were consistent with decency and modern liberalism. In November 1991, after a long internal debate within the Liberal International and numerous visits to Vienna to discuss the issues, we suspended the FPÖ's membership, and in July 1993, we expelled it. We expelled him then and continue to oppose what Mr. Haider stands for. Let me share with you what we learned from that long experience. Many within our ranks said, "Read the text," but many more within our ranks said, "Read between the lines."

Madam President, in my dual capacity as a member of the Greens/European Free Alliance Group and as a Basque Nationalist Party MEP, I would first like to express our firm condemnation of the cowardly attack that claimed the lives of two people: Ertzaina Jorge Díez Elorza and the Basque MP and former vice-president Fernando Buesa. Second, we extend our heartfelt condolences, solidarity, and compassion to their families, their socialist comrades, the Basque Parliament, and the Basque Autonomous Police for this loss. Third, we denounce the gravity of an attack that not only ignores respect for dignity and human rights, but also disregards the will of the people by targeting an elected representative. Fourth, we express our disgust at the direct aim of this double murder to undermine the process of political normalization aimed at achieving peace in the Basque Country. Fifth, we appeal to the Spanish and French governments and political leaders, urging them once again to show the same sense of proportion shown in the United Kingdom and Ireland in order to find a solution to the current Basque political conflict through measures other than police measures, which in themselves will not bring about the pacification we all desire. Sixth and finally, we declare that ETA's terrorism and violence must end and that it must cease stifling the will of Basque citizens, who must be able to decide their future freely and without coercion. Just three months ago, I, like many of my colleagues, congratulated the Irish and British people in this Chamber on their success in finding a solution to the Northern Ireland conflict. Over the past 30 years, too many people have been injured and murdered in Northern Ireland—too many families have been destroyed. As for the current conflict in the Basque Country, unfortunately, the exact opposite has happened in Spain and France. We at Euskal Herritarrok firmly believe that the current struggle can only be definitively ended through open dialogue and transparent negotiations without a rigid agenda. In the nineteen months prior to January 20th, there was only one murder in the Kingdom of Spain: the assassination of ETA member Luis Geresta, who died in March 1999. Despite this attack and the arrests by the Spanish and French police, including of ETA members who were negotiating with the Spanish government, ETA maintained its unilateral ceasefire. Then, in November of last year, before the ceasefire ended, Spanish government spokesperson Piqué declared that his government had done everything possible to date and would continue to do everything possible to thwart the current efforts to find a political solution for the Basque Country. We at Euskal Herritarrok have often had to mourn the loss of human life. Together with the Basque people, we share the suffering of our people. We are in favor of dialogue, and we are ready to cooperate with all those seeking a democratic solution for the Basque Country. Twenty years have passed since the Northern Ireland question was first raised in this Parliament.

With these comprehensive documents, aren't we reinventing the Gosplan, Mr. President? One might ask, especially when reading the French contribution, which goes too far in its dirigisme by proposing that a whole series of national policies be coordinated in Brussels, for example in the areas of employment, social protection, or SMEs, and by accompanying them with a vast array of coded indicators whose monitoring would have to be organized. Such centralized control would result in new violations of subsidiarity, new detailed standardizations, new compulsory coordination imposed on countries in different situations—in short, new elements of rigidity added to the rigidity of the single currency. The Lisbon Council should, in our view, set itself the goal of eliminating this rigidity, promoting flexibility and adaptation, and exchanging positive national experiences to stimulate the creativity that will only flourish thanks to the freedom of choice of people. Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, distinguished colleagues, in the speeches we have heard, a sublime goal has been mentioned, specifically, the goal of making us, as Europeans, competitive with the United States, becoming equal partners with the United States. This should actually be possible if we consider our gross domestic product. However, if, on the other hand, we consider, for example, in the area of people—when it comes to finding a new IMF President—how Europeans behave in this regard vis-à-vis Americans, then we are undoubtedly still very far from this equal partnership. Now, we must ask ourselves why this is so. There are certainly sectors in the economic sphere—even in the media—where we hold leading positions. I am referring, for example, to mobile phones. Here in the Plenary Hall, we have quite rightly banned them, for they are instruments of torture. But at the same time, in some areas they also constitute a substantial aid in life, as they create jobs. In this area, we Europeans are ahead of the curve. Why? We are ahead because we managed to arrive early at a common European regulation in this field, a common European standard that has now become a global standard. This means that if we Europeans make the effort in time, we will also be competitive in this area of new technologies. Where do Europe's deficits really lie? I believe, Mr. President of the Council, that we cannot eliminate the deficits by establishing more observatories, as is currently planned. I believe these observatories generate a few jobs for civil servants, but they do not create jobs in small and medium-sized enterprises. In Europe, we have a deficit in the area of training. This indicates that in the area of new media, we have to import from countries outside Europe. Europe lacks, as has already been said, entrepreneurship, an entrepreneurial spirit.

UCITS have been a great success in the European Union: they are a safe product and traded across borders. But it is time to update the legislation that regulates them and that is where Mr Schmidt has done an excellent job. I have to say, however, that I am not enthusiastic about the considerable changes that have been made to the Schmidt report in Parliament. I urge the House to take a balanced and sensible approach to the issue at hand. The radical measure taken by this report is to allow UCITS to use OTC derivatives. I ask everyone here to consider the products that UCITS will use; we are not talking about using derivatives for speculative purposes, but about using them to reduce risks and increase returns on the savings of ordinary European citizens. We must congratulate Mr Schmidt on getting Parliament's support for OTC derivatives. We must not be afraid to move forward and react to changes in the market. We must continue our efforts so that UCITS offer consumers a balanced and protected product; The report protects consumers very adequately. However, some of the amendments excessively restrict the use of OTC derivatives. I believe that this type of derivatives will be a supplement to the portfolio of investment funds, and this can only benefit individual European citizens who will obtain high returns on their savings. I pay tribute to Mr Schmidt. Many thanks, Mr Kuckelkorn. Ladies and gentlemen, I can now give you some news on the issue of the screen and the window. If we remove this screen, we will find behind it a temporary wall that cannot be removed now. We will therefore have to postpone this experiment until the next plenary session. However, I will ensure that a trial is carried out at that time to see what effect it has. Mr President, since it came into force on 1 October 1989, the UCITS Directive has been a huge success, mainly because of the high level of investor protection it guarantees. The investment fund sector has used the Directive and the positive image of UCITS among investors to increase its activities in the European Union fivefold. Cross-border marketing of investments within the European Union has grown significantly and the Directive itself has become a model piece of legislation worldwide. However, ten years on, given the development of markets and the offer of new and increasingly sophisticated financial products, it is clear that it is now a little out of date. The Commission proposals being discussed in this Chamber provide the facelift it needs. I share some of the concerns expressed - particularly by Mr García-Margallo - but this facelift would be even more appropriate if funds that simply replicate a stock market index - and are therefore passively managed or, better still, not managed at all - and those that use an index as a benchmark for an actively managed fund were managed in the same way, if only to allow medium-sized companies that are listed on the stock exchange, even if they are not included in the stock market index, to gain better access to the capital market.

It would also be the first time that the European Parliament has watered down a Council position, whereas we generally - I believe - act the other way around. Taking back end-of-life vehicles free of charge, for example, and increasing the proportion of recycling would expand the relevant economic activities and thus create new jobs. In the interests of consumers, the environment, and the new jobs created in the recycling industry, the Council's common position, which is entirely acceptable in its current form, must therefore not be amended under any circumstances. Mr President, like many of those present, I consider this a good measure. It is a sensible measure that we all need. The technical problems have essentially been resolved. A few individual issues still need to be definitively clarified, but the majority of the technical problems have been resolved. We have come to the final question. In the debate at first reading, this question was raised only by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, and I, as the draftsman of that committee's opinion, put it to Parliament. It is quite simply: who pays? The Council proposed a sensible compromise in its common position, which states that manufacturers should bear a significant part of the costs, but not all of them, as Mr. Bowis erroneously stated. In fact, as the lawyers tell us, perhaps no more than 20% or one-fifth of the costs. Surely that is not too much. If you look at the British consumer, for example, who buys a Rover cited by Mr. Lange, or indeed any other car brand in the United Kingdom, and who has been paying inflated prices for these cars for years, far higher than comparable prices elsewhere in Europe, why should they pay? They have already paid. Why should these same people, as taxpayers or future car buyers, pay for the disposal of vehicles from which the manufacturer has made money? I cannot accept that. We have some amendments before us today that propose exactly that. I cannot accept that, and I will not vote for them. The responsibility for these vehicles lies with the manufacturer. The manufacturer must provide the appropriate infrastructure and bear a reasonable share of the disposal costs. The common position does not rule out the possibility of state involvement. The common position is a reasonable compromise. Some of the amendments tabled today are completely unreasonable in that they relieve car manufacturers of their responsibility for bearing even the smallest part of the costs of vehicle disposal. I cannot accept that, and I am therefore voting against these amendments on behalf of European taxpayers and consumers. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, there is agreement that we must think about how we in Europe properly deal with old cars, but in this case the Council has not set an example of sensible European environmental policy. The way the German Council Presidency handled this issue was disgraceful. First, Mr. Trittin, the Environment Minister, did not coordinate sufficiently with his colleagues in the Cabinet, and then Chancellor Schröder, like a bull in a china shop, interfered in this process without any expertise.

If it exists, we have fostered it in this House over the past year. I have been here for 20 years and have found absolute trust between the Council, the Commission, and Parliament. We have had our problems and seen difficulties, but there has never been a situation in which the citizens of the European Union distrusted, doubted, or feared this bureaucratic Commission because it was mismanaging our affairs. This is a vast exaggeration of the existing difficulties. This Commission must not live forever in the shadow of the mistakes that caused the resignation of the previous Commission. While there were problems—and we must resolve them in anticipation of enlargement, for example—on some occasions we took the negative aspects too far. Mr. President, Commissioners, first of all, I cannot help thinking that this debate, as far as the speakers are concerned, is Dutch-English-Scandinavian. Perhaps that is a little unsettling. I hope, like many others, that the state of emergency in relations between the Commission and Parliament is disappearing. It's not right for us to continue running around trying to put out fires. On the contrary, as Blak said, we must create a system with clear functions. First, we need a system of solid, enforceable rules. Codes of conduct and ethics committees aren't enough. There must be consistent rules that, among other things, specify what can be decentralized, what can be delegated to others, and what is independent. I find it a little alarming that in this debate we talk about independence without defining it and without specifying the right to decide. Therefore, the EU needs a basic system of administrative rules for its institutions and for its relations with member states. This doesn't exist. We have pointed out the need for a Community Prosecutor's Office and Community criminal law, but we also need Community administrative law. We would make significant progress if the Commission approved the delegate's proposal for a code of conduct for good administrative practices as a mandatory rule. The Van Hulten report is a step in the right direction, but it is not enough. Secondly, we must clarify our own role in reviews. The Court of Auditors examines whether something complies with the rules, but it does not monitor its usefulness. It is the European Parliament that is responsible for making political assessments. We do not pursue criminals; that is OLAF's job. Tell me, for example, to which national parliament the documents in a case are sent. I would like to say, with the stubbornness of a drunk, that the regulation on the disclosure of documents will have to be much better than the draft that has been circulating on the internet; otherwise, we will get nowhere in this fight. Mr. President, I would like to sincerely thank the rapporteur for his report. I am happy to be able to address him now in Dutch, after Mr. Van den Berg did so. Otherwise, I might have felt a little guilty.

It would be very beneficial, not only for Tibet and for all those who believe in peace and stability in Asia, but also for the reputation of the Government of the People's Republic of China, if they would respond to these attempts to establish dialogue. Question No. 31 by (H-0795/99): Subject: Regulation on good administration in the EU rejected by the Commission. According to press reports, the Commission has rejected the proposal by Mr. Jacob Söderman, the European Ombudsman, on the right of citizens to good administration in the EU. The Commission itself has accepted the idea of a regulation on this subject, but has not yet accepted the specific proposal made, limiting itself to issuing a series of additional instructions on improving the service. Is this information true? What is the reason for the Commission's actions, and how does it intend to explain the gap its actions create between words and deeds regarding the reform of EU administration? Does the Commission consider that what has happened is in line with the five-year program agreed in September by the European Parliament and the Commission? Is the Commission prepared to present a detailed proposal on the regulations relating to good administration so that Parliament can also comment on it? Mr. Patten, on behalf of the Commission, gives the floor. The press reports to which the Honourable Member refers are, in my opinion, misleading and inaccurate. In November 1999, the Commission adopted a code of good administrative behaviour at first reading for incorporation into its Rules of Procedure. The Commission is currently consulting its staff representatives on the document, a process that will be completed in the coming weeks. The Commission will then adopt the code at second reading. It should be noted that the new Commission immediately followed up on the European Ombudsman's decision of 28 July 1999 with its own-initiative consultation on the Code. The Commission would like to emphasize in particular that, in drafting the Code, it has taken into consideration all of the European Ombudsman's draft recommendations. The Code will be a document dealing exclusively with the relations of the Commission's administration with citizens. It will be adopted by a legally binding Commission decision to be published in the Official Journal of the European Communities. The document has been drawn up taking full account of the provisions contained in the draft prepared by the European Ombudsman's Office. In accordance with the relevant provisions of the Treaties, the legislator responsible for establishing the Commission's Regulation is the Commission itself. However, it goes without saying that the Commission adheres to the principle of maintaining regular political dialogue with the European Parliament on all aspects of administrative reform. Mr. President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and ask him when these instructions are expected to finally come into force, given that they have been in place since 1997. The information appearing in the press was misleading.

Perhaps you will eventually understand that the European Union's cultural activities pose no danger, but rather an opportunity! Cultural collaboration—this is another point we have emphasized—truly creates an identity, much more so than any transport directive, however important it may be. Everyone agrees that culture must be promoted, which cannot be said of all political decisions. That being the case, I ask the Council what it is afraid of. Madam President, who, like me, has the honor of chairing the Committee on Culture, can only share what my various colleagues have said and can only congratulate the rapporteur and Commissioner Reding, as well as, as everyone has said, those who have worked and those who, even during conciliation, have had moments of difficulty and have fought against the Council. I have seen that the principle of a culture that is necessary at the organizational level has been strongly affirmed, but with little ability to meet all the requests that the European States will make. I would like to emphasize that I am not satisfied that, in the end, a review clause was not approved. There is, however, the availability and foresight of Mrs. Reding, who has personally committed to addressing the issue again and conducting a comprehensive assessment in a few years and, consequently, determining a new situation. The cultural programs—KALEIDOSCOPE, ARIADNA, RAFAEL—that were established in recent years are being replaced by a single program, Culture 2000, in which—I must emphasize this emphatically—the rapporteur stigmatizes a position that should make the European Parliament reflect—as someone said this afternoon—but which always emphasizes the great importance of being part of a broad community where the interpretation of culture is a factor of democracy. I believe that these are not rhetorical words, but a new element of a modern liberalism that unites European states and constitutes the turning point of the European Parliament and the Commission. We are in line with this line of thinking, and the result we are presenting this afternoon, despite the meager funding, I believe serves to significantly relaunch this strategy and this opportunity for Europe, which ultimately determines an economic factor and a development factor, and therefore culture, the institutional and organizational element of a large community as a prerequisite for economic development, and not the opposite, as perhaps Europe, following a cultural custom, was accustomed to believing years ago. There is a prevalence of the human being, a prevalence of culture, and this culture can determine economic development. We must consider this result, congratulate ourselves on it, and demonstrate a clear openness to a useful strategy. Madam President, allow me first of all to express my gratitude to Mr. Graça Moura for having been able to weave this way into the somewhat complicated fabric that has constituted this tapestry of conciliation. I consider it very appropriate that at the beginning of the conciliation procedure for Culture 2000, we have been able to count on a poet to guide us in our work. Once again, because these reconciliations are not entirely easy, we must thank Vice President Imbeni for his exemplary negotiating skills in the intricate task of ensuring that cultural funds are allocated to our Community and that they are used appropriately.

We can discuss this a little later. But I see that the reality corresponds exactly to what I am saying, namely that prices have fallen in areas where competition prevails, while they have risen where the postal service remained a monopoly. This almost always happens. That is why I am asking today that the Commission take the necessary initiatives and ensure that competition really does take place in the postal sector. Mr Markov, you will have a few minutes in five or six minutes. I would be grateful if you would not interrupt your colleagues. Mr President, there is a mystery. What happened to the postal services directive that was adopted on 15 December 1997? Between then and today, the silence from the Commission has been deafening. I am sorry that it is Commissioner Monti who is here today. I appreciate him very much. He is one of the most diligent and hard-working Commissioners. I regret that I cannot say the same for some of his colleagues. During that period, the Postal Services Directive has shown no real progress. Commissioner Monti said that this was partly due to the organization and the new allocation of tasks. All of this has only happened recently. For over a year, the old Commission could have worked on this. We really made very little progress. However, since Commissioner Monti is here, I would like to ask him to tell Commissioner Bolkestein what the Postal Services Directive was about. It was about progressive liberalization, about a guaranteed universal service at a reasonable price, about keeping direct mail and cross-border mail in the reserved sector. These issues were fundamental to the report concerned and they should be fundamental to any future directive. The postal service is not just for the Christmas period. It is useful for life. In the part of Scotland where I come from, it is much more than just a postal service. It serves to maintain the link between communities. The postal service is also the bus service. The postal service is also the social service. The postal service is also the doctor. If we allow the complete privatization of postal services, we will lose all of that, and many of our local communities will lose their tourism—we voted on that earlier. We will cut them off from the world. Postal services are important. That message must be conveyed from this House today. The Commission must listen to it. Mr. President, we support the liberalization of postal services in the European Union. This liberalization must, first and foremost, mean that customers will be better served. That is the direction, that must be the ultimate objective. Liberalization began because there were doubts about the structure of postal services, about the value of a monopoly. Is a monopoly flexible enough in a market where customer demand can change very quickly and where the market situation can also change very quickly, because, for example, electronic information media are used much more extensively?

The EU/ACP agreements make a mockery of democratic principles and the fight against corruption, sparing those responsible: when will there be sanctions and a control of Total-Elf, which fuels the supporters of the civil war in Congo? When will there be a control of Shell?
