Although the market is presented as the only rule that should govern EU/ACP relations, the European Union also provides for police management of immigration, as implied by Article 13, which justifies the policy of European states against undocumented immigrants. We do not accept this agreement because it deprives people of the means to create companies that are independent of European multinationals and banks. Mr President, I would like to commend the sincere commitment of MEPs - including some of my Labour colleagues - in the ACP-EU Joint Assembly, and to commend their efforts to secure a new Lomé agreement, which will benefit some of the poorest countries in the world. Few people in my constituency are probably aware that the EU is the world's biggest donor of international aid. Others may have bigger missiles, but the EU can draw on bigger funds. That is something the EU can be proud of, and perhaps something we should highlight more often. The successes of the Labour government in Britain are also not insignificant. Clare Short, a member of the current British Parliament, holds one of the world's few international development ministers, and in that capacity she can make her voice heard in government. Meanwhile, Gordon Brown MP has led international efforts to relieve the huge debt burden of the Third World and ensured that Labour's campaign to reduce poverty does not stop at the Channel. Labour's aim to reduce poverty remains the same wherever it is pursued, whether it is guaranteeing a living wage in Manchester or fighting for debt relief in Durban. Of course, much remains to be done. The new great challenge we face is to relaunch the new round of world trade negotiations that failed in Seattle last December. It must be a "development round", in which developing countries, excluded from previous rounds, can participate fully. In fact, the best way to reduce poverty in the world is to promote the autonomy of developing countries; more than aid, they need trade; they want a hand, but not our alms. The best way to help them is to open world markets to allow them to sell their products; in this way, the power of globalization can be used for good, to the benefit of the poor and not just the rich, to the benefit of the many and not just the few. With the New Deal in Newcastle or fair trade in Freetown, the goal of the Labour Party remains unchanged: opportunity for all. Swoboda report (A5-0031/2000) The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and FYROM, in the form of a mixed agreement pursuant to Article 310 of the EU Treaty, can contribute to restoring stability and development in this Balkan republic and therefore financial support granted through the PHARE programme could be decisive.

The common will to overcome this terrible and still-relevant history of the 20th century, when all humanistic ideals were destroyed in the heart of Europe, is the true significance of the European Union. And if somewhere in Europe a government enters into a coalition with neo-fascists, it is not merely a question of national sovereignty. For our Union is not a loose association of nation states that come to terms with one another to improve their position. It is a community of shared destiny in which, when fundamental issues are at stake, when fundamental values are threatened, all democrats must seek solutions together to prevent the mistakes of the past from being repeated. We should learn the lessons of the past. In the 1930s, when Adolf Hitler was democratically elected, admittedly by a minority, many believed that this wasn't so bad after all. And, Mr. Poettering, in my country, some people from the right-wing camp, but certainly representatives of other currents as well, thought: "Better Hitler than the Popular Front." You prioritized petty party squabbling instead of focusing on the essentials—and it led to disaster. We must react quickly, decisively, and jointly. I would have liked to have seen you speak with the Austrian President, Mr. Poettering, who is known to be deeply embarrassed by this dirty coalition government. So we must react quickly and decisively. Of course, the treaty offers protection if the situation becomes unbearable; I almost said "irreparable." History has taught us that fascists use the hot-and-cold tactic: first, they heat up—populist and xenophobic rhetoric—then they cool down—they become presentable, are represented in institutions that they gradually infiltrate and undermine, and then one day they strike. And then it's too late. Now, our treaty provides safeguards for when it's too late. But we're not there yet: today, we must prevent it from getting that far. So we need a political solution. I therefore support the Council's proposals and, at the same time, regret the somewhat cautious and timid behavior of the Commission, which should really be constantly resolute and vigilant, because the fascists are counting on the weaknesses of democracy, they are gambling on time to wear us down, hoping to ultimately prevail. We must therefore react quickly. If we do not resolutely support the Council today, history will judge us and speak of a "political Munich." Madam President, I am pleased that the will of the overwhelming majority of the population is being respected in Austria and that, in my view, democracy has achieved a very significant victory with this government formation. One thing must be made quite clear: to a Europe that develops into a kind of Big Brother, monitoring the left-wing political correctness of the member states in a Stalinist manner and using Stalinist methods, to such a Europe we say: no, thank you. European democracy and Austrian democracy need not be lectured by anyone, especially not by the Belgian government, which includes corrupt parties financed by arms dealers and which has appointed the leader of such a corrupt party, convicted by a court, as a member of the European Commission.

Essentially - through a legal change - the Commission will systematically move away from the current centralised system of prior approval of every financial transaction by the Financial Controller and instead strengthen the internal control systems of departmental expenditure so that Directorates-General are better equipped to take responsibility for decisions that may affect the EU budget. Furthermore, to have more guarantees than the current system provides, the new decentralised control system will have to be accompanied by an internal audit service - the second key, as Mr Bösch called it - in line with the recommendations of the Committee of Experts. This service will start operating on 1 May this year, will be led by a highly qualified auditor, and its independence must and will be guaranteed through new provisions to be added to the Financial Regulation. The new service will be accountable to me, and will be supported by an audit committee chaired by my colleague, Mrs Schreyer, whom I am delighted to see in the Chamber this evening. As Commissioner for Budgets, she is already responsible for relations with the Court of Auditors. This audit committee will ensure that internal audits are then followed up effectively and rigorously. I want to emphasise strongly that changing our control systems in no way means making them less stringent. The proposed changes will make the systems more effective both in terms of the information they receive and in terms of the thoughtful and accountable results they provide. I can also give the House explicit assurance that we will not adopt what is sometimes called a 'big bang approach'. The financial controls that have been in place so far over each body's spending will only be abandoned once the new system of internal control over each department's spending has proven to be fully adequate. I am a little surprised that paragraph 10 of the draft resolution does not appear to make any fundamental criticism of the current centralised character of financial control, contrary to both reports of the Committee of Independent Experts. The Committee of Independent Experts has made it very clear that the current centralised system needs to be abolished, and has also been explicit about the need to separate internal audits from financial control. I also do not believe that paragraph 10 of the draft resolution fully reflects the opinion expressed by the Court of Auditors in 1997. Of course, the Court may, after careful consideration, express its opinion on the proposed changes to the Financial Regulation, but it is useful to recall the comments made in the Chamber last month by President Karlsson. He said that the Commission's internal control is not sufficiently effective to prevent incorrect functioning. For example, the Financial Controller had given prior approval to most of the cases of mismanagement and irregularities recently discovered. Furthermore, the internal audit function is carried out, without adequate coordination, by various bodies, such as the Financial Controller himself, the General Inspectorate and some units of the Directorates-General. Originally, the centralized system of prior approval was certainly adequate to ensure adequate control, but over the years it has instead ended up reducing the degree of responsibility of officials for decisions.

We look forward with interest and confidence to a concerted strategy for the modernization of social security systems in Europe, which, however, must not be separated from a parallel process of convergence: this means modernization, but also cohesion, as the rapporteur, with whom we agree, has emphasized in his report. In many policy areas, this latter path has been initiated, albeit with difficulty, but in many others it still needs to be followed before Europe, even if the principle of subsidiarity is respected, can truly become a common home not only for the citizens of the Member States but also for the people of the candidate countries. European social security systems have, moreover, always played a positive role in the social and democratic development of every people; and since these systems must continue to act as a pillar of development today, in the face of economic developments, the world of work, and the needs of society, they must naturally be modernized. Nevertheless, we would like to emphasize three main aspects: First, there must be a close and directly proportional link between economic policy, employment policy, and social security policy. Second, there is the issue of the management of social security systems and their providers. In fact, increasingly comprehensive and effective measures are being taken in the area of additional and supplementary social security. However, we believe that this must not under any circumstances lead to a weakening of the role of the public authorities, both because of the universality and the desirable quality of basic social security benefits. This is fundamentally a principle of justice that applies to health care, pension systems, and also to social assistance, where the public authorities cannot escape strategic coordination, albeit in a new form. The third aspect concerns the principle of subsidiarity, on which the Union is founded. To date, there is no common strategy for social protection and social security, and the current systems are essentially based on action and solidarity within the Member States. When modernizing these systems, the differences between individual states—whether member states or accession states—in the areas of the economy, employment, and social protection must not be ignored. Modernization, which is closely linked to a process of convergence, albeit one based on different preconditions, must therefore be able to strive for and promote developments that increase, rather than reduce, the level of social protection. This is, moreover, a matter of culture, progress, and the common dignity of the current and future enlarged European Union. The common values of the Member States of the European Union are based on democracy, human rights and freedom, as well as a social market economy. This spirit must be expressed in solidarity with the vulnerable groups in our society and the outside world. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, Member States design their own social security systems. However, all citizens of the European Union should be able to enjoy a minimum level of social security, regardless of their country of residence. The report calls for "effective and ambitious fiscal coordination" without further defining what this means. In our view, such a statement would constitute too great an intervention in national tax policy and therefore cannot receive our support.

Madam Member, according to the Rules of Procedure, this is not possible. You must speak outside the Chamber. Questions to Commissioner Barnier I am announcing Question No 44, from the Honourable Member (H-0020/00): Subject: Partnership and the Third CSF for Greece The new Regulation 1260/1999/EC on the Structural Funds places emphasis, in contrast to the previous regulation, on strengthening partnership and provides for the participation of regional and local authorities and other competent public authorities, the economic and social partners and any body competent in this field, both in the preparation and financing, monitoring and evaluation of interventions. However, with regard to the new Greek CSF, representatives of the local authorities have repeatedly complained that the procedures have remained similar to the previous ones and are not at all essential as regards the role of the "partners". Has the Greek State changed the procedures in order to broaden the composition of the social relationship, essentially with regard to local authorities and other representative bodies? What is the increased role of local authorities in the preparation and management of the third CSF, and what measures does the Commission intend to take to ensure that the "partners" are more closely involved in all the procedures of the new CSF? Allow me to extend by one sentence the reply that Margot Wallström has just given to President David Martin, to tell him that, as it is a joint letter from two of our predecessors, as the successor to Mrs Wulf-Mathies, I believe that this letter retains its validity and that I undertake, in common agreement with Margot Wallström, to verify the compatibility of the projects financed by the Structural Funds with the Union's environmental directives and policies. It is also a former Minister for the Environment who is answering you, Mr Martin. I would now like to turn briefly to Mr Alavanos, who I hope will forgive this incursion into another subject, to tell him, in response to his question, that the Commission has monitored and will monitor, in the context of the preparation of the new programming period, the application of the principle of partnership. The association of regional and local authorities with Community action is, I would remind you, although you know it, an essential element of the new Structural Funds regulation after Berlin. More specifically, with regard to the application of this partnership principle in the context of the next Community support framework for Greece, the Commission has been able to ascertain that the public authorities have contributed significantly to the preparation of the Greek regional development plan for the period 2000-2006. Mr Alavanos knows this, I have been there twice in rather tragic circumstances, after the tragedy of the earthquake; during these visits I was able to discuss with the Greek government authorities and recall the need to give adequate consideration to the objective and the need for partnership. As regards, Mr Alavanos, the subsequent stages, namely the preparation of national and regional programmes, it is not enough to incorporate the objective at national and theoretical level, it must be done in practice in the programmes implementing the CSFs at national, regional and local level. As regards the monitoring and management of the programmes, I have not yet received the national provisions proposed by the Greek Government pursuant to Article 8 of the new Regulation.

Since approximately 80% of the European population lives in urban areas, cities are at the heart of Europe's economic, social, and cultural development. At the same time, the social and economic problems of European society are much more evident in cities. Many European cities are confronted with an internal territorial divide, which manifests itself in the fact that, within the same city, districts characterized by high-added economic activities and high-income residents exist alongside others characterized by low incomes, high unemployment, mediocre and overcrowded housing, and heavy dependence on social assistance. The concentration of social and economic problems in certain urban areas requires targeted intervention that does justice to the complexity of the problems. Therefore, the European Parliament successfully called for the continuation of the URBAN Community Initiative (CI) as part of the reform of the Structural Funds. The success of URBAN in the 1994/1999 programming period is undeniable. Concrete successes have been achieved in the form of improvements in the quality of life in the eligible areas. This GI promoted the development of good practices in the economic, social, and environmental fields. One of its successes was the strengthening of the role of local authorities, non-governmental organizations, and regional authorities, as well as the promotion of new forms of partnership in urban regeneration. The new initiative will pursue these objectives in a more focused manner, with particular emphasis on promoting equal opportunities for men and women and the integration of socially excluded and disadvantaged groups. Its adoption is therefore to be welcomed. However, it should be noted that from a financial point of view, we have no cause for celebration, as the allocated resources fall far short of the challenges to be met. They have shrunk from €900 million for the period 1994/1999 to €700 million for 2000/2006, a reduction of 30%! This reduction has led to a reduction in the number of programs under the new URBAN initiative. The chosen ceiling of 50 programs is undoubtedly too low. It must be increased to take regional and local specificities into account without reducing the financial allocations to Member States. Given this concentration on a limited number of projects, the publication and dissemination of the results of the new URBAN Community Initiative may play a decisive role in achieving a multiplier effect. The McCarthy report on the URBAN Community Initiative provides an opportunity to reflect on the appropriateness of Community intervention in the urban sphere. The situation in certain urban areas is alarming, as social deprivation manifests itself there in the form of unemployment, poverty, and crime. Drug trafficking, in particular, leads to insecurity and acquisitive crime. In the face of such social problems, the effectiveness of the Structural Funds remains questionable. Based on subsidiarity, we should actually say that the state, in the exercise of its sovereign powers, and local authorities are better placed to intervene appropriately in this regard: the state to ensure security, and local authorities to assist the needy. The intention to create a system for the exchange of best practices is to be welcomed, but the specific problems of individual urban areas are not always comparable. The URBAN Community Initiative is linked to the European Union's intention to communitize urban policy.

This is all the more serious because it fails to take into account the new situation created by the enlargement process to include regions such as Malta. We therefore propose extending the eligible regions to at least the NUTS III borders of Sicily – in relation to Malta – and to all the Adriatic regions – in relation to the Balkans. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my satisfaction that the outermost regions, including the French overseas departments, have received some attention under the INTERREG III initiative. This has opened up new opportunities for cooperation with the countries in their geographical area. However, it must be said that we could have expected better results, particularly in terms of access to the various strands. For a long time, and this is undoubtedly due to the persistence of colonial ways of thinking, our regions looked towards their European capital and ignored, even despised, their nearest neighbors. That phase is now clearly over. Our regions have become aware of their belonging to an environment to which they are bound not only for geographical reasons, but also for cultural reasons and by the history of their peoples. Hence the unequivocally expressed desire to become more firmly anchored in this environment. This new self-image concerns more than just identity. It is also based on a better understanding of our assets. The island of Réunion, for example, is located on an axis of exchange between the states of southern Africa and Southeast Asia. It cannot afford to distance itself from the regional groupings active in this area, as otherwise it would miss a historic opportunity. This is also true of our Caribbean region. Ultimately, we are convinced that our young people can find a way out of the discouraging and dramatic unemployment if we can export the know-how they have acquired with the help of European Structural Funds to neighboring countries. By using INTERREG funds, our regions can become true bridgeheads of the European Union in their respective geographical areas, thus giving it a global dimension. I am counting on the Commission, and especially on you, Commissioner, to provide these regions with the resources they need to take effective action. Mr President, Members of the Commission, while I wholeheartedly support the possibilities for increased trans-European cooperation within the framework of INTERREG, I must express my concern that the proposal contains fewer opportunities of this kind for coastal regions than for other regions. I understand the Commission's concern that great distances can be detrimental to effective cooperation. Nevertheless, there are many coastal regions between which contacts have already been established. The numerous municipalities along the North Sea coast are an excellent example of this. INTERREG would certainly make it possible to strengthen this cooperation. For this reason, I would like to make some minor adjustments to the guidelines, thereby introducing a little more flexibility and taking into account the interests of maritime areas that are often caught between strands A and B. For example, the possibilities for cooperation between coastal regions and the creation of space for the increased development of practical and visible projects, particularly in the area of infrastructure, should be analysed.

There are also divergences between national legal systems and lengthy rogatory procedures, which sometimes even remain unanswered. Not even the Convention on the protection of the European Communities' financial interests, signed by the European Council in 1995, and the two associated protocols have changed this state of affairs: to enter into force, the Convention must be ratified by all 15 Member States, while to date - and five years have already passed - only four have done so. Such inaction risks undermining the credibility of the Union and has led Parliament to propose the establishment of European Prosecutor's Offices. The aim is in no way to create a transnational criminal and judicial system, but rather to provide the Union with the tools necessary to protect its financial interests, in full compliance with the subsidiarity principle. The report we are debating takes up this idea and calls on the European Commission to present legislative proposals to achieve this objective, taking on board the concerns expressed in the opinions of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market and the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs. Drawing the consequences of the establishment of OLAF, the two recommendations we have formulated aim to ensure its efficiency and operational and legal transparency as well as the protection of individual rights. To this end, a legislative act is needed - the subject of the first recommendation - which covers the types of crimes damaging the financial interests of the Union and also sets out some guidelines of principle. In this regard, I support the amendment which sets 30 September as the deadline by which the Commission must present its proposal. The second recommendation concerns criminal procedure. The Commission - and here too I propose an amendment by 31 May 2000 - should present a legal act on the establishment of an independent body, institutionally linked to the Commission, which would exercise powers of coordination and control over the regularity of OLAF's investigative activity. The Supervisory Committee already in place can only control the independence of the Director of the Office. The proposed act should provide for an independent status for this new body and define its functions, limiting them to OLAF's internal investigations and the prosecution of those who damage the financial interests of the European Communities, as well as to relations with national authorities. Any influence on the administration of justice in the Member States is excluded. Supervision of the regularity of acts should be entrusted to the Court of Justice. We also hope that the forthcoming Intergovernmental Conference will launch a debate on the creation of a European authority that can exercise criminal prosecution to protect the financial interests of the Union, possibly on the basis of the study known as Corpus Juris, carried out by renowned scholars and now widely recognised, as well as the feasibility studies published in the meantime. This project is also advocated in the second report of the so-called Committee of Wise Men. The Commission, Commissioners Barnier and Vitorino, and some Member States are also inclined to take up this idea. I therefore ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to vote in favour of this report, approved by a large majority in the Committee on Budgetary Control.

But in this regard, Mr President, the Commission and Parliament will need the Council to ensure that the creation of this European research area has the necessary financial resources. The framework programme will no longer be sufficient; it will need to be altered, by modifying its basic guidelines. This is a huge task, but we are counting on you. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, the President-in-Office spoke of a political deficit. I believe that the proposals you will put forward in Lisbon, which should allow a synthesis of the famous broad economic policy guidelines, of the "Employment" guidelines, so as to derive guidelines for European growth and employment policy, are heading in the right direction. It is a tool for the decision-making process. Yet those proposals imply a number of institutional decisions whose weight can only be assessed in the medium term. It is proposed to strengthen the role of the European Council in the decision-making process. Our work in this regard is not without impact, and this impact must be weighed up in all the decisions we take in the debate on the reform of the General Affairs Council. Furthermore, behind this decision-making process at European level lies another battle to be fought: the one that each of us will have to wage in our own Member States, because there is no point in launching beautiful guidelines at political level if the budget debate in our countries does not take those guidelines into account. Each of us has the task of working on it. In the context of the strategy that you are proposing to us, with a ten-year objective, how can we not welcome the ambitious goal that you are setting out, namely to stop considering full employment in the European Union as a taboo and to equip ourselves with the necessary means for this purpose, with a growth objective set at 3%? And yet, beyond that, with regard to the objective of a knowledge economy, Claude Desama before me mentioned the role of public services in achieving this objective; For my part, I would like to emphasize a lifelong learning strategy. This requires concrete objectives, and we know that we will not achieve them without basing each proposal on a real social dialogue: something on which more needs to be done. Finally, a few words on social cohesion. I welcome the insistence with which you spoke about it, because we do not know what to do with a society that trades the progress of innovation for the abandonment of social cohesion. And we do not think that the fight against exclusion can be fragmented: it is a global project and the idea of target categories may perhaps constitute an intermediate stage, but certainly not the solution to our difficulties in terms of poverty and social exclusion. We know that we must commit ourselves to this battle, and we know that we can count on your determination. In Lisbon, we will give you our support in implementing new guidelines for the Union's economic policy. Mr President, like my colleagues, I welcome the very clear document presented today by the Portuguese Presidency.

As a specific comment, I would like to thank Mrs. Cederschiöld for clarifying in her document, among other things, the concept of so-called provisional copies. The WIPO Treaty has deliberately adopted no position on provisional copies. If these technical copies were included in the scope of protection, the exchange of information would become very expensive and unnecessarily complicated—as this recommendation rightly notes. It would be as if the postman had to pay royalties when delivering a book to its recipient. What would truly benefit culture would be if art and information could be transmitted conveniently and securely, directly from the artist to the user, the consumer. This new framework offers, above all, enormous possibilities for creating and transmitting culture in a way never before seen. It is essential that the interests of all parties involved be taken into account. This is precisely what this Parliament has sought to take into account in its recommendation. (NL) Mr. President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on the work she has done. The Commission has the impression that it has worked quickly and concisely. That is important. It is now up to the Commission to express its thanks to the rapporteur. I will immediately inform you of the Commission's conclusion: we agree with the conclusions of the draft recommendation. This therefore means that the Commission agrees with Parliament's ratification. I would like to emphasize the importance of both Treaties. The WIPO Copyright Treaty and the WIPO Performances and Phonograms Treaty both constitute progress in the international protection of copyright and related rights and will therefore substantially improve the Berne and Rome Treaties. Both Treaties will contribute to a high level of protection for works and other things, but they also offer the public access to content through electronic networks. Both Treaties explicitly allow the Community to become a contracting party and to play an important role in managing this area. Therefore, the adoption of the Treaties is of great importance, as it is evident that the Community attaches great importance to intellectual property rights. Adoption also leads to greater international recognition of the European Union's role in the field of copyright. Internationally, there is strong support for a speedier entry into force of the Treaties. They have now been ratified by thirteen and twelve WIPO Member States, respectively, including the United States. This entry into force depends largely on the European Union, because thirty instruments of ratification are required for the entry into force of the Treaties, and these instruments, which must be signed by the European Union and the Member States, plus the associated countries, are of great importance in achieving this number. Furthermore, many developing countries hope that the European Union will ratify them quickly, as this would send a positive signal to the entire world.

Finally, the report insists on measures to support ethnic or social minorities. We can only express our disapproval of a minority policy which would ultimately prove dangerous for social cohesion. On the one hand, it encourages the integration of immigrants when instead their assimilation into the culture of the host country should be encouraged in order to avoid the appearance of ethnic ghettos which would create so many urban powder kegs. On the other hand, it makes use of the principle of positive discrimination, a politically correct and harmful chimera, as the American precedent has shown. For all these reasons, the French delegation of the UEN Group was unable to approve Mrs McCarthy's report. Decourrière report (A5-0028/2000) Mr President, the INTERREG programme is particularly close to our hearts. Like many of my colleagues, I am delighted that the European Parliament has succeeded in maintaining the INTERREG initiative. I, who live in the Belgian region of Sarre-Lor-Lux Sud, know that it is there that Europe is created, that Europe is experienced on a daily basis and that, in fact, the citizen participates fully in the construction of Europe. These projects should be taken into consideration and must already be part of sustainable development. Why do I insist on this point? Simply because the projects currently presented are too often still destructive of the environment, precisely because of the way in which they are presented. For example, accepting the construction of new roads is equivalent to accepting new forms of pollution within the European Union and this is completely contrary to the policies that we propose in terms of combating greenhouse gas emissions, for example. I also ask that, in the context of the projects presented, the Commission ensure the presence of the environmental pillar of European Union policy, so that the objective of reducing, for example, CO2 can tomorrow become a pilot added value of the proposed projects. I am thinking in particular of certain infrastructures currently being built. It is known that some Member States still have to choose between rail and road, for example, when crossing vulnerable areas such as the Pyrenees, and I am thinking in particular of the Aspe Valley; but I am also thinking of my own region, where the State has not yet decided whether to allow the railway to pass, while instead it is proposing a second motorway, the A32. Here too, I would ask the Commission to pay particular attention to cohesion between the various policies, in particular between the INTERREG programmes presented. Mr President, I voted in favour of the Decourrière report on the INTERREG Community initiative, above all because of the response that Commissioner Barnier gave to some Members who spoke and asked that more attention be paid, in this programme, to border regions whose borders are marked by the sea, and this not only because I was born in a seaside town, Genoa, but above all because those of the regions bordered by the sea are also borders. These borders take us to the states of Africa and the Middle East: we must take into greater consideration the fact that it is also important to develop the coastal regions of any part of Europe. . (FR) As a Member of the European Parliament from a border region, I welcome this third INTERREG initiative with great interest.

It is high time that the polluters started paying because, until now, it is the victims and the taxpayers who have been paying. And not only are they paying, but they are also cleaning up the affected areas. I therefore welcome Mr Fischler's response, especially when he acknowledges the need to apply retroactive measures and respond quickly to requests that arise. On behalf of my group, the Socialist Group, I want to send a message of solidarity to the victims, to the fishermen, the fish and oyster farmers and the industrialists who ensure that seafood arrives on time at the market; to the mayors and politicians, and to the volunteers who cleaned up. We express our full solidarity with them. I would like to ask the Commissioner two questions. Parliament adopted a resolution on the application of the polluter pays principle to this type of case and on the liability of shipowners and cargo owners. My question to the Commissioner is whether these principles can actually be applied and whether we will receive compensation from these people. The second point concerns the future and the publication of the Commission's White Paper on Environmental Liability, the purpose of which is to ensure the future application of the polluter-pays principle and to improve our ability to enforce European environmental legislation. This White Paper recognizes that liability is only effective if the polluter is identifiable, if the damage can be quantified, and if a clear cause-and-effect relationship can be established between the two. The sinking of the Erika could not better illustrate this point because it sums up exactly what the White Paper aims to tackle. This question would therefore seem to be the best measure for dealing with such problems in the future. The proposed directive provides for strict liability for damage caused by dangerous activities regulated at Community level, and I wonder—and perhaps the Commissioner can answer this question—whether the White Paper on Environmental Liability will be able to address problems such as the Erika, whether it will actually be able to address this concern, or whether, in practice, when it comes to maritime accidents involving ships on the high seas, polluters will once again escape the obligation to pay compensation for the damage they have caused. Mr President, our sympathies and expressions of solidarity go out to the people and regions affected by the disaster. But good intentions are not enough; the damage must be compensated and the losses made good, both in terms of environmental restoration and shellfish farming facilities and fishing equipment. We are pleased to hear the Commissioner express the need to act and provide compensation quickly and retroactively. We also denounce excessively lax control of ships and we are in favour of the creation of a European coastguard corps, and in particular the requirement for more restrictive regulations and the requirement to have double-hulled boats.

This must no longer be just an option for us, but an imperative. The citizens of Europe will not settle for anything less than a quality of life that is worthy of human beings. We do not want to follow the American model, a model that has not created the jobs that are absolutely necessary to ensure an acceptable quality of life. In the United States, the number of poor people in employment has increased incredibly, and that is not what we want in Europe. We have a tradition of solidarity in Europe and we know a better way of doing things. But for this, we need to have the right tools, and so I am calling not only for the high-level group proposed by the Commission to be set up, but also for us to go further and launch a process similar to that of Luxembourg so that we can take an integrated approach to the issue of social protection. Mr President, Commissioner, this is one of the social issues that the European Union must pay much greater attention to. Macroeconomic policies, the Stability Pact and the nominal convergence criteria have, in fact, hindered a modernisation of social protection that would enable it to contribute to improving the quality of life of the population, in particular by significantly increasing pensions and retirement benefits - especially their minimum levels - and by combating social exclusion. The situation is particularly serious in countries such as Portugal, where minimum pensions and retirement benefits are just over half the national minimum wage, which is the lowest in the European Union. We will therefore have very serious doubts about the Commission's true position until it takes on the need to review macroeconomic policies in order to create high-quality jobs that guarantee all workers' rights. These are in fact the fundamental prerequisite for maintaining and modernising a truly solid public social protection system. Although the Andersson report has incorporated positive proposals, some of which bear our signature, some of the principles we criticised in the Commission's communication remain unchanged. We therefore remain concerned about the strategy for modernising social protection. Mr President, I have previously managed two manufacturing companies, one in the UK and one in the Netherlands. As the UK company grew, we invested in staff; as the Dutch company grew, we invested in machinery. This was because social security costs in the Netherlands are higher than in the UK. I am in favour of social protection and of the original Commission document, but I do not want jobs to become too expensive because social protection costs are indiscriminately rising. That is why I proposed in committee that we should apply some form of economic impact assessment of the business directive that takes into account the costs and risks in terms of employment. The PPE-DE Group supported this amendment. However, I must note that other groups, led by the PSE Group and my compatriot, Stephen Hughes, rejected this amendment. I am sure that the rapporteur, Mr Andersson, had the best intentions and I respect him for the work he has done, but I believe that the way in which the report defines and promotes social convergence would lead to an increase in social security costs throughout the European Union which would put at risk a large number of jobs and also the credibility of this House, demonstrating how far we are from the real world.

I believe that, as far as the specific case of the Erika is concerned, measures are being taken and actions are being organized with the French authorities. But what concerns us in this case is that we must debate this issue again, because the key to the issue is preventive measures. The Commissioner for Fisheries has indicated - and I would like to emphasize this - that the Commission will meet and adopt a package of technical and legal measures. I believe that this is the way forward. I would simply like to say that these measures are welcome and that the members of the Committee on Fisheries will monitor these measures very closely so that we no longer have to meet in this Parliament to deplore events such as this. I have received, in accordance with Rule 42(2) of the Rules of Procedure, five motions for resolutions. The debate is closed. The vote will take place at 11 a.m. EC/Israel Trade Agreement The next item is the oral question (B5-0012/2000) by Mrs Morgantini and others to the Commission, on irregularities in the application of the EC/Israel trade agreement. In reality, we have to debate today a simple matter: respect for, application of, and monitoring of the agreements to which the European Union subscribes, respect for the treaties and international standards to which the European Union adheres. It is a simple matter, but in this world, it is often the simplest things that cause the most problems. The colleagues who signed the question to the Commission with me want the correct application of the Israel-EC trade agreement, which – not only do we have reason to believe, but we, like several Member States, have concrete evidence – is openly violated by Israel. We also have reason to believe that the Commission is not sticking to what should be its basic mission: to be the guardian of the Community treaties. We are talking about Article 38 of the territorial clause, which limits the scope of application to the territory of the State of Israel and therefore does not authorise the granting of customs facilities to products originating from the territories militarily occupied since June 1967, in which, in defiance of all international law, starting with the Fourth Geneva Convention, successive Israeli governments have established settlements by confiscating the Palestinians' land and rivers and installing new inhabitants there. This is not the first time that the Commission and Parliament have addressed these issues. I will only recall the Commission's report to the Council and Parliament presented in May 1998, which criticized Israel's refusal to apply the protocol on laws of origin as referred to in Article 38. Despite this, the Commission has not succeeded in forcing Israel to respect these agreements and has given vague answers to the various questions from parliamentarians, constantly referring to the difficulty of obtaining reliable proof of the origin of products, even though it has always reminded Israel of the legal obligations of the agreement. In order to facilitate the task of the Commission and the Member States, an Israeli peace movement published a list of companies established in the settlements and a Palestinian NGO has gathered and presented to the customs authorities of the various Member States irrefutable evidence on the origin of several products from the occupied territories and marketed in the Community.

This is of course a positive thing, but it would be essential for it to refer to the monitoring of the European Parliament's recommendations in our discharge procedure. Will you add this to your committee's work on the progress of the audit? Finally, the Socialist Group agrees with an activity-based budget and the need for accountability because, as President Prodi said, you will be judged on your actions and not your words. As Mrs Morgan said, a crucial factor will be to reconnect with the European public, and this will require actions and not words. I say this with all due respect to the European Parliament, which has some real masters of eloquence; we will try to set a good example. As far as excessive bureaucracy is concerned, Mrs Morgan has clearly defined our dilemma. We too hate mountains of paper, but because of the requirements that we have to check, re-check and re-check to ensure effective financial control, administrative requirements that some call bureaucracy are unavoidable. However, to minimise these requirements, we are not just discussing them; in the near future we will appoint a Deputy Secretary-General, an additional Deputy Secretary-General specifically responsible for identifying best practices and disseminating them in the Commission, and also ensuring a radical reduction in those procedures that produce paper and bureaucracy. They generate a great deal of frustration, not only among citizens and businesses in the Union, but also among those who work for the Commission. We will certainly fight to achieve this, and I believe that the effects will be felt in the coming years. One of our difficulties, of course, will be that the more effective the reform process, the less information there will be in circulation about it; We will therefore have to count on our friends and partners in the European Parliament to explain, with their usual generosity, the efforts made by the Commission to properly serve the people of Europe. I know that I can count on all of you. The debate on this point is over. I thank President Prodi and Commissioner Kinnock. Statement by the High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy The next item on the agenda is the statement by the High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy. I would like to extend a warm welcome to the High Representative, Javier Solana, who has the floor. B (ES) Madam President, as you can imagine, it gives me great pleasure to be back before the European Parliament once again. Ladies and gentlemen, since the last time I came to speak about foreign and security policy issues on our continent, a lot has happened. Sometimes you might think that too much has happened. Today I would like to share with you some ideas, mainly about the common foreign and security policy. It is true, as I have said, that the world has undergone many changes in recent months and that many events have occurred; however, if you agree, I will answer questions during the time allotted for this purpose.

In this context, I would like to underline the adoption in May 1999 of a new rural development support scheme, which constitutes the Community framework of reference for sustainable rural development. This has been, as you know, one of the developments that has taken place in the negotiations for Agenda 2000 and in the very evolution of the treatment of agricultural issues at the Community level. Through the European Agricultural Guidance and Guarantee Fund (EAGGF), this Community support framework is intended to help reverse the trend toward desertification of rural areas, to which the Honourable Member rightly refers in his question. Furthermore, the European Fund for Rural Development (ERDF) also contributes, within the scope of its mission, to promoting economic and social cohesion by correcting the main regional imbalances and by participating in the development and conversion of rural areas. In this regard, it is important to bear in mind that the ERDF also contributes to promoting sustainable rural development and the sustainable creation of jobs in rural areas. These Community instruments are what allow us to work with a rural development policy that is today, moreover, one of the developments and lines of evolution of the Common Agricultural Policy, in one of its dimensions, and of regional policy, on the other hand. We believe that within the concept of multifunctionality currently linked to the evolution of the Common Agricultural Policy, this is one of the fundamental issues, and the EAGGF Guarantee Fund naturally has a fundamental role to play in this regard. Question No. 9 by (H-0798/99): Subject: Agriculture and the Portuguese Presidency Can the Council outline the Portuguese Presidency's priorities for the next six months with regard to the common agricultural policy, and also indicate the steps it considers necessary to increase consumer confidence in both the agricultural sector and products that have been adversely affected by the alarm caused by the recent health crises? The question that the Honourable Member raises regarding the common agricultural policy is one that affects us closely and is worth constantly considering in the debates of this House, because we will probably have a lot to say on this issue in the future. During the Portuguese Presidency, we will continue the process of reviewing the CAP by adapting some of the common market organizations with a view to the harmonious development of the Union's rural areas and ensuring a positive trend in farmers' incomes, paying particular attention to measures that may have an impact on small family farms. Furthermore, the Portuguese Presidency will naturally, if and when the new round of negotiations for the World Trade Organization begins during its Presidency, which is by no means certain, ensure the consolidation of the presence of Community production on international markets and a greater balance between exported Community agricultural products and the preservation of a multifunctional European agriculture, as I have just mentioned. The Portuguese Presidency will also emphasize the intensification of food security policy, and I believe that the Portuguese Minister of Foreign Affairs and President of the Council of the European Union has already referred to this aspect here this morning. We believe that the role of food security, particularly in all aspects related to public health, is a fundamental element of our Presidency; moreover, it constitutes one of the priorities of our program.

I do not agree with the paragraphs concerning Parliament. This report concerns the Commission. Parliament is a separate subject. There is no justification for introducing Parliament into the discussion on the Commission. There is also the issue of duty-free shopping. This was an argument against the Commission put forward by the lobbies opposed to the abolition of duty-free sales at airports. This subject also has no place in the report. The report mainly concerns financial control. This is reasonable, because it comes from the Committee on Budgetary Control. But we should not give the impression that vast amounts of European resources are at risk due to the negligence of the European Commission. After all, this represents only 1% of GDP compared to national expenditure. We have already discussed this, but some in Parliament are young and do not seem to understand how limited the European Union's financial resources are and that 80% of these resources are spent by the Member States. The Commission's negligence in its spending will therefore not threaten vast amounts of money. We should take that into account. It is an important element to bear in mind. The European Commission's action is very limited when it comes to spending. Its role is very limited. Its responsibility is much greater. Responsibility for environmental management, food safety, foreign trade, the internal market, and many other responsibilities that we have entrusted to the Commission without providing it with the necessary resources to fulfill them. I am not one of those who thinks there is a serious lack of trust. If there is, it was we in Parliament who created it last year. I have been here for 20 years, and I have always seen absolute trust between the Council, the Commission, and Parliament. We have had problems, we have identified difficulties, but the citizens of the European Union have never lacked confidence in this bureaucratic Commission, they have never doubted it or feared it because it mismanaged our affairs. This is a great exaggeration of what the difficulties were. This Commission should not be forced to live forever in the shadow of the mistakes that caused the Commission's resignation and that preceded it. When there are problems that we have to solve with a view to enlargement, for example, we sometimes overemphasize their negative side. Mr President, allow me to thank the rapporteur for the quality of his report. I hope that the Commission will draw inspiration from it in its reform work. The reform process has been underway for some time, and there seems to be a kind of state of emergency within the Commission. It is clear that the way in which the Commission administers affairs is not particularly good. There are obviously capable and competent officials within the Commission; they even represent the majority, but we need radical reforms. There is too little action and too much bureaucracy.

It is better to heed calls for amendments and improvements to current legislation than to rush into new proposals. Within this framework, I support calls to strengthen port state control to ensure full and effective inspections. I support calls for classification societies to effectively monitor the structural conditions of vessels and to be held accountable for their actions. Calls for improvements in hull design, particularly for vessels to have double hulls, are sound, but their implementation across the entire fleet takes time. They cannot replace regular and rigorous inspections. Mr. President, I would like to thank my Socialist colleagues, primarily those on the Committees on Transport and the Environment, for not forgetting that this disaster also affects the fishing sector. Because, in addition to the irreparable damage to the environment, the damage to the ecosystem, and the losses to the tourism sector, the oil spill is a blow to fishing and to the conservation of marine resources, and it will take many years to recover the damaged coastline. It is no coincidence, Commissioner, that the affected areas are always those European regions lagging behind in development, those that barely survive on the tourism-fishing trade and, in most cases, lack other resources. These are the same regions, Commissioner, that already endure, year-round, the reckless practices of certain shipowners who clean the bottoms of their vessels off their coasts, beyond any control. I come from a region, Galicia, that has suffered similar accidents in the past. Brittany and Galicia, the two European Finisterres, are permanent victims of the irresponsibility of those who prefer to flout safety regulations and transport crude oil in vessels that are themselves potential oil spills. That is why I believe it is necessary to act in two directions. On the one hand, by asking the Commission, within the aid planned for the fishing sector, to implement special measures to mitigate the effects of this disaster on the productive sector in the affected areas, and also by asking it, both from international organizations and itself, to strictly monitor vessels flying flags of convenience. In this regard, the current negotiation process for Malta's accession to the European Union should serve to require this country to strictly monitor oil tankers flying its flag. On the other hand, prevention is necessary. Portugal is a country that has amply demonstrated its sensitivity to issues related to the sea. I would ask the Portuguese Presidency to study the possibility of launching a comprehensive maritime accident prevention strategy at the European level, concentrating all the resources we already have at our disposal—technological, structural, and socioeconomic—to prevent a catastrophe like this from happening again in the future. Finally, Mr. President, I would like to highlight the work done by the volunteers and local authorities, which reminded me of old times when I—then mayor—experienced similar situations.

This is a transparent and strong way of proceeding, to involve all the European institutions and the European population. This White Paper is a response to the challenges that enlargement imposes on us, an enlargement that forces us to rethink the functioning of all our institutions, to rethink our own policies - all our policies - to rethink above all what we must continue to do at the level of the Union when the member countries will be twenty-five or thirty, what will be better to do at the level of individual states, at the level of the regions and at the level of local administrations. But it is not only enlargement that pushes us to this rethinking: as said earlier, it is also the globalization of the economy and politics itself. We must govern Europe in such a way as to be more efficient, closer to the citizens, promoting the participation of all, starting first of all with the great problem of female participation. One of the great differences in the comparison made in this period between Europe and the United States is not so much the mobility of labor or the problem of risk capital, but rather the participation of women in economic life, a participation that in the United States has a much greater importance than in Europe. This is a field in which Europe has always been at the forefront: we must therefore reflect on this deeply, with openness, and all the institutions - Commission, Parliament, Council - will have to think about their own role, their own policies. We will therefore immediately return to work on this White Paper, even if we will have to wait for the results of the Intergovernmental Conference to complete it, and therefore it cannot be presented before spring 2001. It will not be a book of philosophy, but a concrete book, full of precise proposals. We - the Commission - are the first to know that we must rethink this completely, and for this reason we will do two things: we will commit ourselves and are committing ourselves fully to internal reform, and we will rethink our policies in depth. I have asked all the Commissioners - and we will ask them even more analytically - to identify all the activities that can be abandoned. The Commission must define what its core activities are, those on which it must concentrate, and give up non-essential activities, so as to free up new resources and to have a more correct and more cooperative relationship with individual countries, regions and local communities. We will therefore free up new resources, but the time will also come - I fear, and I want to say this here in front of Parliament - when even these new resources that we are already freeing up will not be sufficient to allow us to deal with our new tasks: I am thinking of enlargement, the new sector of justice and home affairs, health problems, environmental problems. On that day, when we will have used all our resources to the fullest, I will not hesitate to come before you to ask for new resources, but I say from now that, if we do not have the necessary resources, we will have to refuse to take on any new task because there is no consistency between the new tasks we are taking on and the resources we have at our disposal.

I find it serious that the Commission is not addressing cohesion. It is postponing a principle of the Treaties—that of economic and social cohesion—which should inspire all policies and measures of the European institutions. It seems unaware that profound backwardness persists in several European regions, and it forgets that enlargement justifies adjustments in regional policy. Without real convergence, the cohesion of the European Union will be at risk. Consider the sixth periodic report on the situation of the regions of the European Union, a commission from the Commission. It confirms that, for an average level of development attributed to 100, the ten regions designated as "strongest" reach an average of 158, and the ten so-called "weakest" are around 50. Draw your own conclusions about this. 50: that is exactly the level of development of the region where I live—the Azores—one of those designated as outermost in the Treaties. I await the Commission's report on the outermost regions, which the Council determined would be prepared by December 1999. I conclude by reaffirming my conviction: without economic and social cohesion, there will be no cohesion whatsoever, only disintegration. Madam President, Mr. President, we need, European public opinion needs, a strong Commission, because, as the Treaties intended, as the will of the people also intended, the Commission is the driving force of European construction, that rock of Sisyphus that we must push to the summit after each enlargement. Therefore, a strong Commission, but one that relies on a Parliament, and Parliament is therefore its ally, but an awkward ally, whose messages we must hear, and I would like to give one or two in this brief speech. First of all, Mr. President, I believe that, if your two predecessors were essentially dedicated to developing an internal market and establishing a single currency, it is primarily your responsibility to develop all this civic value that is at the heart of European construction. Indeed, we must not allow ourselves to be distracted, whatever its importance, solely by the issue of enlargement. We must go further, towards the reconciliation of citizens with Europe and, above all, those citizens who are victims of economic, social, and, undoubtedly, in the future, technological fractures. The promotion of scientific development, the promotion of new technologies, and access for all to these technologies will not be guaranteed by the market and competition, any more than the market and competition will ensure the social proximity and effectiveness of major public services: health, education, transport, communications, water, and who knows how much more. Your action program and your objectives are discreet, even silent, specifically regarding the necessary revival of public investment. They are also discreet, even silent, regarding the consolidation and financing of major public services and services of general interest. In that case, Mr. President, if you wish to reconcile Europe with citizens, there is an absolute priority to act in such a way that they choose Europe rather than Jörg Haider.

Firstly, the Committee on Development and Cooperation wants nothing more than to see the EDF communitarised, and in doing so, it has clearly chosen the wrong path. We believe that cooperation is an intergovernmental task and that is how it must remain. As Europe prepares for enlargement, communitarising the EDF would allow some to simply hide their lack of commitment behind the protective shield of the Community budget, quite apart from abandoning a fruitful and promising method by which we can involve our partner countries in the South in our cooperation policy. Finally, the Commission has recently demonstrated – as Mrs Maes very rightly pointed out earlier – the difficulties it has in managing the funds it has made available for its development and humanitarian aid programmes in a completely transparent manner. The question arises as to why we should now add further programmes. Secondly, we find it extremely regrettable that Mr Corrie's report mentions the Trade and Development Agreement with South Africa, because ultimately this agreement is an example of the unprofessional diplomacy that the European Commission is increasingly engaging in. We are, in fact, utterly astonished to discover that the Union has negotiated an agreement for its Member States in which a significant part has simply been omitted. Incidentally, it is even more incredible that the Council allowed this to happen. We now find ourselves in the absurd situation of having to negotiate from a position of weakness on such vital aspects as wine and agricultural production, within the framework of an agreement that we have already signed. The part of this agreement that is blocking negotiations could mean that the Union will have to compensate producers to stop producing sherry and port. These are a whole range of products that are, quite simply, counterfeit under international trade law, and the potential cost of such a precedent can be imagined. This is proof, if it were still possible to prove it, that an immature diplomacy that represents no interests whatsoever—except particular interests caught between the doctrine of free trade, lobbies, and more or less friendly NGOs—is not only ineffective but even dangerous. Finally, a word about the general thrust of the Corrie report. Today, the Joint Assembly—we will not hide this fact—is viewed by the "theologians" in Geneva and Washington as an obstacle to international free trade. This could have been an opportunity for us to recall that our form of independent and exemplary cooperation with the countries of the South should be further developed and strengthened. The Corrie report missed this opportunity, and we regret that it was squandered in this way. Mr. President, as a conclusion and summary, I would like to highlight three essential aspects of this debate. First, and more generally, the views expressed clearly demonstrate that globalization is deepening regional disproportions and social inequalities and increasing poverty. This suggests that action must be taken, otherwise tensions will intensify and conflicts will emerge, threatening international peace and stability. Second, from this perspective, it is essential to give development policy a new dimension by enhancing its role in correcting disproportions and reducing inequalities.

The fact that, as you know, the President of the Republic in Finland is not only a representative office but also the supreme commander of the army, adds to the historic significance of this event. During the Finnish Presidency, a report was drawn up which described the entire decision-making process in great detail; I hope that it will serve as a reference when the Commission proposes legally binding measures to improve the role of women in the decision-making process. I would invite all of you, Members of the Right, to listen carefully to Mrs Lulling's speech on the need for fixed quotas, as she has more political experience in this area than anyone else. Finally, I would like to stress that this issue should also be addressed at the next Intergovernmental Conference. I would therefore ask you, ladies and gentlemen, not to vote in favour of the proposal amending point 4, thus allowing the issue of gender democracy not to be addressed at the Intergovernmental Conference. Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, despite the progress made in legislation and the complaints we regularly express about gender inequalities and discrimination, the proposals developed to resolve the problem do not eliminate the underlying causes; this means that in order to ensure equal participation of women in the decision-making process, it is necessary to reform policies in various areas. We know that this is the area that presents the greatest difficulties, both because women continue to bear the main responsibilities related to family life and because prejudices and interests persist that hinder the effective participation of women in the areas of greatest responsibility. The truth is that the low participation of women in political representation centres and decision-making bodies implies a democratic deficit that is incompatible with effective democracy. It is therefore essential to implement the directives on equal opportunities and for the Council, the Commission and each Member State to firmly respect the commitments made, in particular in the context of the Beijing Conference. Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, I am a right-wing Member of Parliament, but I am fighting the same battles as my colleagues to support and help women citizens to gain access to power and decision-making bodies - something that must be done not only in the political sphere but also, of course, in all sectors of society. In short, I would point out that there are many ways to gain access to it and, if I am particularly opposed to the phenomenon of quotas, because I find it particularly contemptuous of women, I come from a country where equality has only just been established. It is perfectly logical, it is coherent! All this should have been there a long time ago because women represent more than half of society and it seems completely normal to me that they are present, at least 50 percent, if not more, in decision-making bodies and in politics. I am therefore against discriminatory measures to impose women. Women impose themselves because they are pragmatic and have common sense. When I realize that we ask for training for women in politics, I am tempted to say: absolutely not.

These neighbourhoods of our cities are often home to single-parent families, elderly people who are living on pensions and who no longer carry out any productive activity, families in difficulty, if not in disintegration and disarray. They live in areas that should be able to benefit from these projects. If we succeed in implementing this three-pronged approach, I believe that these families, these people, these European citizens will be able to be more creative throughout Europe, which I think is very important because, after all, cities will increasingly play a leading role on the European stage. Mr President, I would like to speak on the URBAN and INTERREG programmes, which many speakers have mentioned. After me, my colleagues Franz Fischler and Anna Diamantopoulou will speak, since all three of us are responsible for these Community initiatives and have had the opportunity to follow this debate with great attention. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs of the parliamentary committees, of all the committees, as well as the spokespersons of the groups and all the Members for the high quality and the deep interest shown in their speeches on these two initiatives. This is particularly true of what Mrs McCarthy said on URBAN, and I would like to thank her not only for her work and for the report she has presented but also, why not say it, for what we and you owe her for this initiative and for what we owe more generally to your Parliament. Indeed, I do not forget that it was actually the European Parliament that took the political decision to maintain this initiative in favour of the revitalisation of urban areas in crisis and sustainable urban development, also promoting an integrated approach, which is very important to us, to address economic, social and environmental aspects at the same time. Mrs McCarthy's report highlights other points on which we agree, which are: the effectiveness of this instrument thanks to financial concentration and a critical mass for interventions; the horizontal mechanism, which in our opinion is more conducive to the dissemination of results and the multiplication of exchanges of experiences and good practices; the growing role of local authorities in the design and management of programmes based on a genuine partnership. Having recalled the fundamental points of agreement between the Commission's proposals and Parliament and having stressed the great interest I felt in listening to the various speeches, I would like to respond to some criticisms and some suggestions, apologising in advance for not being able to quote each speaker personally. I believe, however, that everyone will recognise themselves. First of all, with regard to the URBAN programme, I understand that a maximum of 50 cities, which some of you have described as arbitrary, is a cause for concern. I have therefore asked my services to be prepared to assess a reasonable increase in the number of cities eligible for the URBAN programme with certain guarantees, first of all on population density - I am thinking in particular of intervention areas that must have a minimum of 20,000 inhabitants and exceptionally 10,000 inhabitants - as well as on financial critical mass: we should stick to 500 euros per inhabitant so that the European Union's intervention is effective and at the same time visible and does not get lost in a random distribution that would make it incomprehensible for citizens and municipalities.

First, the classic ideological deviation, Eurofederalist, a single market, a single VAT, a single diplomacy, a single army and now a single criminal law and a single prosecutor. All this to fight against fraud of less than one billion euros while tens of billions are being let go for GSPs, for free trade zones, for customs gifts to Chiquita and for the billions lost on the fourth resource, GDP, due to the austerity pact on the budget. Then there is the puritanical deviation: Northern German Europe, Lutheran, Calvinist, Quaker Europe wants to impose its moral order on us. After all, the more we let ourselves go with customs, the more we tighten the purse strings. - (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today more than ever, effective criminal protection of the financial interests of the European Union is essential. The scandals of the past related to fraud and corruption have seriously shaken the confidence of European citizens. The credibility of the European Parliament's commitment to ensuring the correct use of financial resources is closely linked to our commitment to investigations into the past and future prevention. The changes needed are not only administrative but also structural; in other words, we must create the tools to ensure criminal protection that is currently non-existent. The 2000 Intergovernmental Conference seems to me to be the most appropriate forum for this debate. Obviously, there are also those who maintain that criminal law and criminal procedure are matters that fall exclusively within the competence of the Member States and that the principle of subsidiarity excludes any other consideration in this regard. There is no doubt that I personally count myself among the advocates of this latter principle, being opposed to any further extension of Europe's supranational competences. Precisely in the light of the requests addressed to the Intergovernmental Conference, the emphasis must be placed on a clear separation of competences. However, I do not see any contradiction in this with the call for the creation of criminal and criminal procedure instruments, which are the subject of recommendations 1 and 2 of the report, since these are interests that indisputably concern the whole of the European Union and as such do not harm the legal interests of the Member States, but rather promote them at least indirectly. Experts have confirmed their compatibility with the various national legal systems, which shows that Europe also has much in common in the area of criminal law, for example with regard to the types of crime involved. In the light of these considerations, I consider the creation of such a framework as proposed to be appropriate, and I even consider it necessary for the coherent development of OLAF. Mr President, will a European Public Prosecutor be able to eliminate fraud involving Community funds? I do not think so. On the other hand, we can achieve substantial results with the existing instruments. An alternative to the European Public Prosecutor could be EUROJUST, as proposed at the last European Summit. EUROJUST, in its architecture, should be under the control of EUROPOL and provide support for investigations in the case of criminal offences. Practical cooperation of this nature is what we need.

This is a distant goal, but it can be achieved in stages. The most important will be the harmonisation of State rights, but for today let us be content with this small step because it goes in the right direction. Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent explanatory memorandum, which points out some of the serious shortcomings of this proposal. The lack of clarity of expression will inevitably give rise to legal uncertainty, whereas legal certainty is essential in such vital matters. Due to poor wording, the Convention can be interpreted in very different ways and ignores the strict conditions to which interception should be subject according to the European Convention on Human Rights. Article 18 allows interceptions to be carried out in another Member State without informing it. Not only should this Article be deleted, but the entire title should be removed. The user requirements that form the basis of the current legislation were drafted at the initiative of the FBI. The Council proposal that includes these requirements, ENFOPOL 98, was approved by Parliament last May with the Schmid report. We are now being asked to provide the legal basis for such interception, and it would be appropriate to consider combining these two documents. The requirements propose to allow authorities to access all service providers' equipment (telephones, mobile phones, Internet), and given the current very poor wording, the proposal is open to abuse. I would like to ask a question: given that the user requirements specify that the police can access all service providers without exception, does this include Parliament's internal services? Are we passing legislation that will allow the police, on very flimsy grounds, to access our systems? Furthermore, this proposal does not include any definition of a serious crime, thus encouraging all kinds of abuse.
