Furthermore, as regards the reversal of the burden of proof, something recognised in fundamental international law, the presumption of innocence is essential, but is not guaranteed here. Neither the preamble nor the main body of the text take due account of the rights of the defence, an essential principle of fundamental international rights. This is a very serious issue; We are very concerned about the direction we are about to take without the issue being debated publicly in national parliaments or elsewhere, and without involving civil rights movements across Europe. They too are anxious about recent developments. Mr President, I am not a member of the Legal Affairs Committee nor am I a lawyer, but, like almost all my fellow Members, I understand how important it is for the European Economic Area to be accompanied by a single area of justice, freedom and security. In this sense, issues relating to judicial cooperation in criminal law are particularly relevant. Reading the texts in question, I have come to the conclusion that it is risky to rely on the provisions issued by the Council, while maintaining the contradictions, the conflicting opinions on what Europe is and the different judicial systems that cause not only confusion and ineffectiveness, but also dangerous situations. I am referring, for example, to Article 18, mentioned by some speakers, according to which any country - or rather, any large country - having the technical capacity could intercept the communications of another State even without the latter's authorisation.

Mr. Provan said that I often speak about tourism and information technology. I am personally convinced that information and communications technology will play a key innovative role in European tourism. The travel and tourism sector is at the forefront of the use of information and communications technology tools. This will profoundly change the way it operates. Marketing, booking, and transportation are expected to be the areas that will undergo the greatest changes and improvements. The use of these technologies opens up a completely new dimension in the field of travel and tourism. Direct contact between the consumer and the company will complement, and sometimes even reduce, the current and almost exclusive business-to-business relationship. The offerings for tourists will be broader and better, and new, higher-quality products will be created. To achieve this, the Commission believes, action in the tourism sector must be closely linked to measures to promote the adoption of information and communications technology by the tourism industry, in particular through the Technology Programme for Innovation and the Technology Programme for an Innovative Society, both of which fall within my remit. The new strategy set out in the Commission Communication on Tourism and Employment, approved by the Council, places emphasis on the collection and dissemination of information on tourism and on good practice. Implementation of the Statistics Directive aims to improve knowledge of the structures and trends of the European tourism market and the sector concerned. The Commission's decisions have advanced the methodological approach. The report on the experience gained in the work carried out under this Directive is part of our work programme for the current year. Additional work on the social and economic impact of tourism is currently being carried out in collaboration with international organisations such as the World Tourism Organisation. The primary role of the European Community is to provide a framework that enables and encourages stakeholders and authorities at all levels to optimize and realize the tourism sector's growth and employment potential. Such a European strategy will be achieved by building on the commitment of the Member States and the Commission to cooperate in a number of priority areas: exchange and dissemination of information, including through new technologies; training to improve skills; quality of tourism products; and sustainable development in the tourism sector. In the autumn, the Commission will report on progress made in this regard. In about two years, a report on the work to be undertaken jointly with the Member States and the tourism sector should be available. Depending on the results of this work, a broader debate could then take place, which could well be the starting point for even more comprehensive policy initiatives. Mr. Medina Ortega asked me some very specific questions. Regarding the role of tourism policy in the communities concerned, we must understand that many policy sectors have a huge impact on the structure of tourism. It is not only specific, targeted tourism actions that are important; there are also other horizontal actions in the transport sector. Currently, air and road congestion is the fundamental problem. In the environmental field, we are examining methods of cooperation with Ms. Wallström; in the field of regional policy, Mr. Barnier is paying great attention to this sector.

Mr. President, I have heard Commissioner Vitorino's response and I must say that I am satisfied. It seems to me that his intervention attempts to answer the questions contained in the question. I also believe that we must emphasize the importance, for the European Union and, consequently and from an executive perspective, for the Commission, of promoting tripartite activities, particularly with regard to the levels of economic, financial, and scientific cooperation, in order to ensure that our quantitative presence, in terms of money, can increasingly become a more significant political presence in the Middle East. I believe this is the lesson we must draw from a situation that has been going on for a long time. Regarding the case at hand, I just heard Mr. Galeote refer to our President's visit, and Mr. Menéndez del Valle to President Prodi's visit to Israel and other Middle Eastern countries. I believe that both Presidents were right not to include this issue on their agenda: everything must have its place, and each level, obviously, must have its priorities. I believe it was a good idea for the two highest representatives of Parliament and the Commission to address the most sensitive issues of the peace process, which, as we know, continues to encounter difficulties. We must fully support this peace process, and the attention we pay to these events denounced in Ms. Morgantini's question is not a prejudicial or detrimental attention to one of the parties involved: it is the strictness of friends, it is strictness with the friendly government of Israel so that these illegalities and irregularities are not repeated, as they harm everyone. From this point of view, this initiative must also be understood positively, as an initiative that seeks to foster the peace process in the Middle East. Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the current trade agreement between Israel and the EC is indeed confusing. Furthermore, it is very difficult to determine the origin of the products in question. I therefore maintain that it is desirable to clarify this as soon as possible. However, there are other important factors that we must take into account. After all, we are all in complete agreement that the relaunch of peace negotiations should be encouraged, not hindered. For the time being, Israel and the Palestinians have negotiated their future borders in depth. Any effort by anyone trying to define, let alone impose, the territorial scope of application, even when it involves a third party, seems premature at this point. It seems better to me to await the results regarding the rules of origin of the tripartite working group, which will be set up jointly at the initiative of Israel, the European Commission, and also the Palestinians. I am pleased that the Commissioner also shares my opinion. I hope that this working group will find an interim solution to the problem within the current legal framework, without jeopardizing the peace process.

Today, in many states, this is not possible. One of the reasons for the difference in competitiveness between the European Area and, for example, the United States, is precisely this ability to bounce back that exists on the other side of the ocean and which we do not know about. I believe that, since we have gone this far and will continue on this path, which is the path of creating a collective procedure for settling this type of dispute uniformly in the European Union, we must think about ensuring that this does not become the allegorical figure of the guillotine. Mr President, my dear friends, Commissioner, I believe that if we have so far avoided a number of disasters that could have occurred in the absence of the rules that the previous speaker has just mentioned, we owe it more to luck than to our skill. When we deal with the internal market, we must be concerned not only with the most positive side of the project, that is, the construction of the internal market itself, but also with its downside, namely bankruptcies. I believe that we are living in a historic moment. I congratulate the rapporteur for having pushed this work forward with such diligence. Furthermore, I am proud that my home country was involved in drafting this provision, which we hope will be adopted quickly by the Council. I believe that we are about to take an important step here, even if its impact on national systems is not very noticeable. I must unfortunately inform the rapporteur that our group will not be able to support Amendment No 3. We believe that it would have a negative effect on the legal position and protection of citizens. As for Amendment No 6, we presented a similar proposal during the committee debates, and I am rather surprised that the members of the PES Group did not support it. We intend to vote in favour of this proposed Amendment 6, but I repeat, I wonder why you did not approve the text that we presented in committee. I also hope that we will achieve transparency in this context, as well as a comparison that will enable us to determine which procedures will be the best and quickest for our different countries. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, firstly, the Commission would like to point out that the proposal for a regulation under consideration this evening constitutes only and above all a new formulation of the 1995 Convention on Insolvency Procedure. Everyone knows that the Convention in question was the result of many years of debate, often difficult, often laborious, and that, as a result, it represents a compromise between the principles of unity and territoriality, that is to say, between the structuring principles of different legal systems of bankruptcy in each of our Member States. The fact that we are aware that developments in the global economic situation and, above all, in the internal market, may require more frequent recourse to bankruptcy procedures, which are often in the nature of cross-border procedures, fully justifies the Union, as such, equipping itself with the necessary binding legal instruments to ensure that insolvency proceedings are carried out according to a set of common structuring principles and with guarantees of rapid execution.

These two countries are also eligible for financial support under the MEDA programme (B7-4012). During its first and second readings of the 2000 budget, the European Parliament stressed that the new heading "pre-accession" (B7-0) proposed by the Commission in the preliminary draft budget should not be limited to the associated countries of Central and Eastern Europe, but should also be extended to Malta and Cyprus. However, due to the Council's refusal to negotiate the necessary revision of the ceiling set under heading 7 (pre-accession) of the financial perspective, the European Parliament agreed, exceptionally, and I would like to stress this fact, to finance this expenditure under heading 4 (external actions) of the financial perspective for the year 2000. At the same time, the European Parliament created a new chapter on the "pre-accession strategy for the Mediterranean countries" (B7-04). Within this chapter, two new articles concerning the pre-accession strategy for Malta and Cyprus have been created, pending the presentation by the Commission - following the Helsinki European Council - of the necessary legal bases, as well as the revision of the ceiling for heading 7 of the financial perspective. This proposal for a regulation should constitute one of these legal bases! I welcome Mr Brok's report which supports, with some amendments, the Commission's proposals to prepare for the accession of Cyprus and Malta to the EU. The package will provide a total of approximately EUR 15 million for the two countries during this year. However, it is regrettable that the Commission has favoured an annual allocation of funds over multiannual financing. This decision risks having repercussions on the ability of Malta and Cyprus to plan their expenditure. The financing will ensure the technical and financial support to enable the two islands to meet the requirements of the acquis communautaire. Given their lead over the other candidates, these countries should not encounter any technical or administrative difficulties in gaining accession at the end of the five-year programme. Cederschiöld report (A5-0020/2000). As a member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs during the previous legislature, I welcome the adoption of this framework decision aimed at strengthening the protection of our single currency. The Union must implement all the means at its disposal to guarantee its protection against counterfeiting. Indeed, consumers and traders are not really familiar with the euro. Counterfeit money could therefore be put into circulation quite easily in supermarkets, bureaux de change and banks, without anyone noticing it immediately. As for coins, the fact that they may have a national side will make them even more difficult to identify. The European Information Centres, which already play a vital role in raising public awareness of the single currency, will need to strengthen campaigns to draw public attention to counterfeiting. At a different level, cooperation between Community and national institutions will need to be ensured and an information system will need to be set up to enable the collection and exchange of data on counterfeiting. Criminal law measures are also needed to ensure the protection of the euro from the outset. It is in this context that the European Parliament has presented the draft framework decision aimed at strengthening the criminal law framework for protection against counterfeiting.

However, these values only assume their full significance if they are incorporated into the Treaty in comprehensible detail and ultimately constitute legal rights for individual citizens. Articles 6 and 7 of the Treaty are not enough in this case. In this sense, the Commission must insist—and I would like to confirm and reinforce this here—that the newly drafted Charter of Fundamental Rights becomes part of the Treaty and creates binding and enforceable rights. In this sense, the Commission must insist on the continuous expansion of the common area of freedom, security, and justice, and in this sense, I disagree with my two previous speakers. Only sensible, feasible, and humane principles of immigration and asylum law can counter the irrational, seductive, and demagogic claims of the far right. But, and I would like to emphasize this, this policy must also be accompanied by a coherent and convincing policy on employment and against social exclusion, because unemployment, marginalization, and growing inequality are an ideal breeding ground for anti-European, nationalist sentiment and action. In this context, Mr. President of the Commission, I would also like to consider the globalization you have problematized and how it is perceived by large sections of the population. The feeling of being at the mercy of others, of lacking influence, and of lacking state protection leads, at best, to a turning away from politics and abstention, as in the European elections, and, at worst, to extremist voting behavior. Here, the Union, like all others, has not yet understood how to offer our citizens in the EU the EU as a means, indeed as protection, against the negative effects of globalization. We are in the process of building a house, but too few of our own citizens truly feel at home in this house. Therefore, this is not just about reforming the World Trade Organization and the economic architecture—and the Commission President has tellingly forgotten to mention reforming the financial institutions of the international financial architecture—but also about confidence-building measures for our citizens, who can rightly expect help and support from the EU and within the EU in the unavoidable but painful processes of adapting to the new global situation. In this context, what the Commission says about Europe's strengthening voice is important. You yourself, Mr. President, spoke today of a model about which I unfortunately find too little in the document; you said that we must offer our citizens, both internally and externally, a model of economic, social, cultural, and ecological development that is clearly different from other models, including the US model. In this sense, the US is not only our partner, but also our competitor—not opponents, but competitors—and we must fight to see who offers the best model for our citizens. I hope that what we have said today with such clear vehemence will also be reflected more strongly in the Commission's documents. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, the greatest legacy your Commission could leave to the European Union would be an active contribution to the redesign and redistribution of the increasingly convoluted and confusing powers and competences of the Commission, and possibly of the Union itself.

Experience in other sectors where observatories have been set up also shows that, in addition to creating jobs of dubious value, these jobs are of no particular use. I therefore urge the Commission to exercise its control functions directly and personally and to work to ensure the positive progress of the LEADER+ programmes. This also involves, among other things, the evaluation and dissemination of the results, as has already been done so far. Mr President, most of the borders that have divided Europe for centuries were drawn artificially, dividing single geographical areas and inducing strong disparities in terms of balanced development and cohesion. Our internal borders, or what remains of them, are no longer a cause of war today but continue to produce economic backwardness, social barriers and cultural incommunicability between the peoples of Europe. The Community institutions have a duty to ensure that these scars left by the borders become a memory, since they are in contradiction with the spirit of European unity. The economic and social cohesion that we defend manifests itself, within the framework of the INTERREG initiative, in the form of territorial cohesion and integration of the border areas and peripheral areas of our continent. From the outset, INTERREG has been the seed of a genuine Community policy on spatial planning, as well as a truly polycentric conception of European space. While Parliament supports this initiative, it only regrets that we are being asked to adopt a resolution on the subject before we have even been able to examine the evaluation carried out on INTERREG II; on the other hand, we are aware that it is not right to further delay the implementation of this third edition of the programme, which would jeopardise the outcome of numerous projects, or the continuity of those already underway, since the success of INTERREG is undeniable, as recognised by the local, regional and national authorities that have participated in co-financed projects. Learning together, innovating, sharing projects and good practices, understanding and being tolerant of each other: these are some of the lessons that this initiative has to offer to those who participate. A series of interesting issues revolve around the initiative: the observatory, the principle of concentration, etc. For my part, I would like to focus on the issue of management bodies. I believe it is necessary to identify common, interregional and transnational management bodies, in which all local and regional authorities, as well as economic and social actors, actively participate. Cases of parallel projects on both sides of a border must no longer be repeated. A cross-border culture must be created, but this requires the ability to innovate in administrative cooperation, the ability to imagine how to overcome existing barriers and the difficulties represented by the different levels of competences foreseen in each Member State, in each region and in each municipality. It is not acceptable that a given project cannot be implemented solely because of communication difficulties. During the discussion in committee, we also noted the difficulty of coordinating INTERREG with other annual or biennial financial instruments, such as MEDA, TACIS or PHARE. The motion for a resolution of this Parliament paid great attention to these difficulties, offering the European Commission useful ideas for overcoming them and establishing reasonable deadlines for implementing the necessary changes.

I thank the President, Ms. Fontaine, for expressing her position yesterday, denying the involvement of this Assembly. In that statement, Mr. President, in addition to discrediting the Basque Nationalist Party (PNV), Eusko Alkartasuna, and the democratic government of the Basque Country by calling them Nazis, which have an attitude that in another case, Ireland, even deserved the Nobel Prize, they insult representatives of European citizens—as is my case: I represent a segment of Galician society, saying that we are more dangerous than Nazism—and they insult unequivocally democratic organizations with decades of history, in an unacceptable madness that I take the liberty of condemning at this moment. I request, in any case, that our words be heard, because the European Parliament cannot be so implicated in a madness that I clearly describe as unacceptable. Thank you, Mr. Nogueira, for your clarification. I remind you that questions about the Minutes should be referred to the Minutes. In any case, for those colleagues who are unaware of the President's position, I will read the official statement, and it will also be recorded in today's Minutes: "On 17 February, Ms. Nicole Fontaine, President of the European Parliament, received, at their request, representatives of the Ermua Forum. The Spanish Vice-Presidents of the European Parliament were represented. At the end of this meeting, the representatives of the Forum sent her a document entitled the "Strasbourg Declaration," the terms of which the President can in no way endorse. Strasbourg, 17 February." Therefore, I believe that the matter is completely settled. Mr. President, I request a correction in the Minutes regarding the vote on Amendment 5 to the Swoboda Report. Please note that Mr. Michel Raymond, Mr. Jean Saint-Josse, and I voted against this amendment. It is noted and will be recorded in the Minutes. Mr. President, not for the record, but for a communication we have before us today, namely, that the Conference of Presidents scheduled for February 23 has been canceled. We must reflect on whether this type of event should continue to be held in this manner. I have the feeling that it is nothing more than a mechanical part of the performance of our duties. What we hear there we could easily read about in the newspapers the next day. And when something else comes up, I don't think it's right that the agendas of the various committees, already excessively busy, should always be shortened because of the show we put on. Therefore, let us consider whether we should not do away with these conferences altogether. Mr. Bösch, I take note of your observation, but, obviously, the holding of this type of Conference of Presidents open to all Members stems from a request from Members, in order to be able to participate in some of them. We should certainly be more selective. In any case, the Bureau will consider your suggestion. (The Minutes are approved.) VOTES Mr. President, we request that the last sentence of Amendment 2, which reads: "Also invites Member States to promote tourism for older adults," be moved forward and included in paragraph 25, specifically aimed at social tourism, at the end of the sentence "tourism for organized social groups."

The fundamental point of discussion with the Council will obviously be the allocation that LIFE III must be provided with. The common position provides for a financial envelope of 613 million euros for the period 2000-2004, which is insufficient. The Liberal Group is in favour of increasing this amount to 850 million euros. We therefore support Mrs Lienemann's amendment, which notes that the LIFE allocation was not increased during the last enlargement of the Union, let alone the next wave of new arrivals. The sums we are requesting do not constitute a Himalaya of useless expenditure. On the contrary, they are still very modest compared to the needs to be covered. A drop in the ocean, I would say, compared to Europe's structural policies. The environment remains a very poor relation of the European budget, even though it constitutes, above all, an investment. Investment in natural resources, of course, but also in employment, since it has been shown that an active environmental policy creates new jobs, as evidenced in particular by the very great success of LIFE: success with NGOs, businesses, local authorities, third countries. Nearly a third of the 8,500 applications received met the required conditions and approximately 1,300 projects were able to be co-financed between 1992 and 1998. A success that Parliament wants to see, intends to see perpetuated, which is why we also support Amendment 14 outlining the fourth stage of the LIFE project. When it comes to the environment, investment and ambition are, and must be, long-term. The future of future generations depends on this. Mr President, Commissioner, I will no doubt repeat what my colleagues have been saying, but I believe that, for the Council, it is a matter of repeating again and again what we think of LIFE. Therefore, I will also say – as the rapporteur has already done very well – that LIFE is the only specific financial instrument for the establishment and implementation of the European Union's environmental policy. This mechanism is absolutely essential because it stimulates truly innovative actions in favour of nature and the environment in Europe, which are taken up and amplified by the Member States. This financial instrument is, moreover, deliberately democratic in being accessible to both governmental organisations and NGOs. That is why, dear colleagues, I will ask you not to vote for the amendments which have completely failed to understand the spirit of LIFE. Indeed, through associations, LIFE can be used directly by European citizens, and for the benefit of actions of general interest. Several million - I did say millions - of NGO members recognise in LIFE the Union's desire to build an ambitious policy in favour of natural heritage. LIFE is, moreover, the fundamental instrument of the Natura 2000 network in Europe, to which the Member States have committed themselves, in accordance with the Community directives on the habitats of rare and threatened fauna and flora and on migratory birds, and which allows the establishment of protection for sites of high biological value in our States.

We must ensure that what we do is meaningful. We must not create confusion or jurisdictional conflicts over rights, which would be highly detrimental to freedom, justice, and security. In short, we must establish and observe the highest possible common standards and find ways to safeguard them. But we must also always bear subsidiarity in mind. Like everyone in this House, I aspire to this area of freedom, justice, and security, but I do not want it to lead to excessive centralization, chaos, and confusion. Madam President, Honourable Members, several questions have been asked about the Portuguese Presidency in previous speeches. The President of Parliament made us feel that we do not have much time, which is why my colleague from the Ministry of Justice and I propose to answer objectively all the questions that have been asked here. We will do so at the parliamentary committee meeting we will be attending next week. (Prolonged applause) Thank you very much, Minister. The debate is closed. Mr President, I welcome the Council's oral and written response. Its effectiveness has truly been remarkable. I will spare a few seconds because I would like to propose that the Council continue the debate at the next meeting of the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs. There we will have the opportunity to comment on these proposals and to express our concerns to the Commission. I personally welcome some of the responses received, for example, those concerning such sensitive subjects as Schengen or the Europol Convention, which we hope will be reviewed, and I welcome what the Minister of Justice said, namely that we will try to submit to the jurisdiction of the judiciary. I hope the same will be true regarding parliamentary scrutiny. Representatives of the Council, we will be submitting a motion for a resolution to this House in a month's time. I am sure that, with the good humour you have shown today, the first thing you will do, in this new climate of mutual understanding, will be to consider the motion for a resolution that we will submit to you. Question Time (Council) The next item is Question Time to the Council (B5-0003/2000). Question No. 1 of (H-0780/99): Subject: Construction of a nuclear power plant in a region of Turkey with high seismic activity The two recent earthquakes in Turkey, measuring over 7 on the Richter scale, have given rise to grave concern at Turkey's stated intention to build expensive nuclear reactors at Akuyu, at a time when excess energy from the Ataturk dams is being exported to third countries and the EU is using its own resources to help repair the damage caused by the earthquakes. This suggests that Turkey's nuclear programme, which ignores the dangers to the inhabitants and ecosystems of the country and the region as a whole, is a front for a strategy adopted by the Turkish politico-military authorities to acquire nuclear technology that will enable them to develop nuclear weapons, since they are seeking to acquire the same reactors, of Canadian origin, that India and Pakistan possess.

Madam President, today the Commission presents its strategic objectives for the five-year period 2000-2005 in the form of an extremely generic document from which all the sensitive points have been removed to avoid offending certain sensibilities too much. And so in the first part on the new forms of European government one obviously never reads the words federalism or superstate, while this is precisely what is looming on the horizon when one speaks of a strong European institution, which decentralises only ordinary executive activities and which carries forward a collective vision in a not better clarified whole, in which national governments and parliaments are put in a cauldron with regional and even local administrations, as well as with civil society, all defined, without a minimum hierarchical structure, and I quote "participants in European policies". These ambiguities hide numerous misunderstandings, first of all about our values. In fact, to be democratic it is not enough to appeal to democracy. In concrete terms, it is above all necessary to accept that citizens are free to decide at the level that can best guarantee objective conditions for a close, fair and transparent democratic debate, that is, mainly at the national level. Instead, the entire communication from the Commission is built precisely on the opposite postulate, according to which, under the pretext of better defending peoples, their margin for autonomous choice should be increasingly limited through new regulations, new integrated policies and new binding legal structures, such as the draft Charter, wrongly defined as the Charter of fundamental rights. And I stress "wrongly" because in reality it will end up reducing these rights. We in the Union for a Europe of Nations group cultivate completely different principles: we intend to defend European countries, but also to respect the choice of peoples. This is not at all about squaring the circle: we must free ourselves from the obsolete federalist schemes of those who continue to draw inspiration from the memoirs of Jean Monnet for any idea on the European theme. On the contrary, we must open the European institutions to the modern world, inventing a dynamic of variable geometry that respects nations. This is the great idea about the new government that we would have liked to have seen in your communication, Mr President. Unfortunately, however, it was not there. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, you claim to be building a new Europe, but unfortunately you lack an essential requirement: trust. In fact, you cannot win the trust of millions of Europeans by not being worthy of it. And how could you be worthy of it after the mad cow scandal, after the resignation of the Santer Commission for corruption? You are responsible for the millions of unemployed, the millions of poor, for the precariousness and growing poverty caused by your free-trade and liberal policies to the bitter end, for the forced march towards the single currency. You wanted and organised the elimination of internal borders, thus leaving Europe at the mercy of the explosion of crime and insecurity, as well as the spread of uncontrolled immigration. Today you propose to give all decision-making power to a handful of officials, making the States, local administrations and non-governmental organizations, all of which are accumulated in the subjection to Brussels, mere executors of decisions imposed from above.

The new Commission now recognises the need for such independence for ex post checks, so isn't it logical that it should also apply to preliminary checks? I believe that tomorrow's vote should decisively reiterate this need, already expressed by my colleague Theato, which I fully share. Mr President, a few years ago the previous Commission tried to come to terms with the old, rigid structures. This led to strikes and smear campaigns by narrow-minded unions, after which the proposals were abandoned and replaced by a "soft" compromise. This was the stupidity of the old Commission and Parliament was of no help at the time. Reading the chapter on personnel policy in the Van Hulten report, I fear that Parliament will once again fail to live up to expectations on the key points, making only weak speeches devoid of any substance. There are too many rights, too many rules and too little room for management. The backbone and teeth are missing. Where is the beef? And I say it to you too, Commissioner: Please, deliver the beef even if it is British. President Prodi promised a revolution and you too have spoken strongly and positively, but now be careful not to give in on the fundamental points, the most delicate ones! Bring order to the jungle of staff funding! Hold firm on the need for mobility, not as a right, as the report says, but as a management tool! Make sure that training also becomes a management tool! Do not accept the report's request that temporary agents should be appointed to permanent posts! It is the posts that should eventually be made permanent, and not necessarily the current temporary agents who should become permanent officials. Finally, Mr President, as a member of the Bureau until six months ago, I would like to invite you to deal with this issue in the Bureau, so that here in Parliament, in our administration, we at least meet the requirements that we impose on others. We have not done so so far, and you must help to change things. Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Van Hulten for his report, which I voted in favour of. However, I would like to highlight the points on which I disagree. I do not agree with the paragraphs relating to Parliament. This report is about the Commission, and Parliament is a separate issue. There is therefore no need to also talk about Parliament in the debate on the Commission. There is also the issue of tax-free goods. This was an argument used against the Commission by the duty-free lobby, which was upset that the Commission had abolished duty-free at airports. This is also an issue that should not be included in the report. A large part of the report deals with financial control, and that is understandable given that it comes from the Committee on Budgetary Control. However, we must not give the impression that a large part of Community resources is being put at risk by mismanagement by the European Commission.

I am pleased with the draft compromise resolution, which we have agreed on together with the GUE, Green, Liberal, and PSE groups, calling on the Commission to submit a report to Parliament within six months on the feasibility of this tax and also to examine financial coercive measures and sanctions against countries that encourage tax evasion or operate tax havens. It is often argued that such a tax would be circumvented, but this is true of any tax, and if this argument were accepted, there would be no taxes at all today. Furthermore, the draft resolution calls for a position paper to be drawn up by the Commission and the Council before the next annual meeting of the IMF. I believe that the European Union must take the initiative here; furthermore, it must propose this initiative to the G7 countries, as the draft resolution calls for, since this is primarily a political issue. If the Union were to take the initiative, it would have a certain impetus, because this debate is taking place everywhere, including in the United States and Japan, and because there is a growing trend throughout the world for the world to be run not by stockbrokers, but by citizens, their parliaments, their governments, and their democratic institutions. I believe that Europe must assume its responsibilities within the framework of this new international arrangement, and I am extremely pleased that this issue is on the agenda for European construction today, in this debate and through this draft resolution. Madam President, I do not have much to say in advance on this subject. The Council has not yet considered Professor Tobin's proposal for a tax on capital movements. This is an innovative initiative which, as we know, has met with support in various sectors throughout the world and among several European political groupings, but so far the Commission has put forward no proposal or initiative on the matter. Since the Commission is responsible for any initiative, the Council can only then take a position on this matter. (NL) Madam President, the Tobin tax is intended to be levied on revenue from very short-term foreign exchange transactions. Such transactions, it is argued, have little connection with real economic data. This was also emphasized by Mr Désir just now. Proponents such as Mr Désir therefore believe that an internationally introduced Tobin tax would, in principle, help curb speculative currency transactions and thus also exchange rate fluctuations, which would lead to higher economic wealth. Given the considerable scale of short-term capital movements, even a very low nominal Tobin tax would generate considerable tax revenue. The growing interest in the Tobin tax and other international sources of finance in the mid-1990s was in fact based on non-economic motives: the revenue that the tax would generate to finance international public programs at a time when demand for such finance was growing rapidly and capital was becoming increasingly difficult to obtain. The Commission has recently noted renewed interest in a global tax such as the Tobin tax, which is intended to achieve what could be called a socially acceptable globalisation.

However, there is one point of contention. Given the scope of the directive, it may be a minor issue, but it is the focus of the discussion. It concerns the issue of recycling costs. We maintain a fundamentally different position from that expressed in the Council debates last year. There, the issues of free recycling for the last owner and financing were mixed up, and the free nature of recycling for the last owner was questioned. In this Parliament, we unequivocally agreed in February last year—and we Social Democrats support it—that free recycling for the last owner is beyond question! But who pays for the vehicles that must be disposed of? It is clear to us that, with regard to new vehicles, it must be the manufacturer, as this incentivizes the manufacturer to design and build vehicles suitable for recycling. But what about vehicles already on the road? An example: in Great Britain, if Rover were responsible for all end-of-life vehicles, it would be responsible for 5.8 million vehicles in the European Union and would have to immediately set aside €250 million in reserves to cover recycling costs, while a Korean manufacturer that builds similar vehicles has to set aside, as a Deutsche Bank representative said, a paltry amount. These are distortions of competition that have nothing to do with environmental protection, but only affect the investment capacity and jobs of those who build cars in Europe. We therefore propose setting up a fund to cover the costs of recycling end-of-life vehicles, thus ensuring compliance with the cost-free principle. I understand that colleagues from other countries where car manufacturers are not built say that manufacturers should pay all the costs, and the problem of distortions of competition with funds is of no interest to us! But I ask these colleagues to show solidarity with the more than two million people who build vehicles in Europe and earn their living from it, so that these jobs can be guaranteed in the future. I am in favor of imposing strict environmental requirements, as you know from the vehicle oil program and the debate on maximum exhaust emission values. But, in my opinion, these requirements must be the same for everyone! Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in my opinion, we need this directive. First, because it clearly sets out the environmental objectives. Second, because it can encourage recycling, and that is important. Third, because it constitutes a clear procedure for tackling heavy metal pollution. This is also an important aspect. The directive provides a European framework, also for countries that already have a system in place and that wish to continue working with it. Therefore, we must maintain recycling rates first and foremost, because this naturally encourages technological innovation, in order to find a solution for recycling materials that we still don't quite know what to do with.

First, Parliament must have unhindered access to all Commission documents. On the other hand, we must quickly find an internal arrangement to guarantee the confidentiality of sensitive documents. In connection with the gathering of information, I would like to draw the Commission's attention to the fact that we are concerned about the draft plans for public access to documents. If the concept is correct, it represents a huge step backwards compared to today. It must no longer be the case that financially powerful organizations can obtain information through their representatives in Brussels, while ordinary citizens cannot. It is also unacceptable for a public institution to own copyright on public documents. Furthermore, the duties of all European civil servants must be defined in principle so that officials who feel guilty about their actions can more easily defend themselves against assignments that violate ethical principles or legal provisions. If the Court of Auditors signals that a problem occurs not one but two years in a row, management must be held accountable, and this must also be reflected in their career planning. Finally, there is, of course, a need for better cooperation between the European Court of Auditors and its national counterparts. Parliament is demanding that the Commission outline its plans for reforming its external aid programmes on 31 March of this year. It is no longer acceptable that Europe, while an economic power, cannot exert political influence because, when it comes down to it, we are unable to provide effective support to areas in urgent need. We cannot accept that the Commission completed a hospital in 1996 which, to this day, does not have a single patient. Since 1996, discharge has gained political significance. It is one of the most powerful instruments of power at Parliament's disposal and must therefore be used judiciously. In all likelihood, therefore, we will grant discharge tomorrow. However, we will not relinquish this weapon without laying a time bomb. Discharge for 1999 will not be granted until the financial irregularities identified by the Court of Auditors have been resolved. This discharge report is, of course, addressed to the Commission. But the European Parliament must also put its internal affairs in order. As long as we do not have a statute, we will lack credibility as a driving force behind the Union's reform package. The reform of the EU institutions is a fundamental prerequisite for the further construction of Europe. Only an open and democratic Europe can be effective and fair. All institutions must now work together to create this Europe. Mr President, the Committee on Industry, External Trade, Research and Energy has decided to take the first step and draw up a report on the discharge for the 1997 financial year, even though we had no specific mandate to do so. We did this because we believed that we should begin in this Parliament in the same way that we intend to proceed in the future: by ensuring that European taxpayers' money is in good hands. During the preparation of this report, it became clear that there are serious problems in the areas of expenditure that fall within our budget.

It therefore seemed essential to fill this gap in order to achieve a high and uniform level of training for safety advisers, but also to avoid disparities in training costs and, consequently, an impact on competition between companies in the Member States. The Commission's proposal aims to ensure uniform training for safety advisers. It defines the minimum content of examinations and defines the tasks of the competent authority as well as the requirements to be met by the examining bodies. Our Parliament supported this text. However, it tabled several amendments, most of which were included in the Council's common position, particularly with regard to the need to draw up a questionnaire and declarations concerning the authorization of certain documents within the framework of "the specifications of the examination arrangements proposed by the examining body". I also support postponing the date of application of these provisions to three months after the entry into force of the directive for the sake of realism. I will conclude by stressing that harmonising the professional qualifications of these advisers will help to improve the quality of service in the interest of users, and to minimise the risk of accidents that could lead to environmental damage and serious damage that could affect the physical well-being of anyone who might come into contact with dangerous goods. Koch report (A5-0104/1999) Last October, I spoke about the Hatzidakis report on the transport of dangerous goods by rail. The comments I will make today are not far removed from those I made at the time. They can be summed up as follows: I regret that, in an area as crucial as the transport of dangerous goods, we are always putting off adopting harmonised standards to the detriment of human safety and the environment. I would point out that a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States concerning the transport of dangerous goods by road entered into force on 1 January 1997. This directive included a number of transitional provisions valid until 1 January 1999. It was from that date that we should have taken a position on a proposal from the European Commission aimed at ending these derogations. According to the current procedure, it is the European Committee for Standardization (CEN) that proposes standards in this area, which are then included in the European Agreement concerning the International Carriage of Dangerous Goods by Road signed in Geneva in 1957 (better known by its acronym ADR), which applies throughout Europe and whose provisions serve as the basis for the legislation applicable in the EU. CEN was unable to complete its work within the allotted time. Therefore, the Commission proposal we are discussing today is intended to amend the directive to address these problems in the short term, not to end the transitional arrangements, as should have been the case! This is exactly what happened with the transport of these goods by rail, with one difference: a deadline had been set.

In this case, the Commission proposes obtaining specific information from the Irish authorities on the current status of compensatory measures and on potential problems associated with the mechanical removal of sable grass. We do not consider it appropriate at this stage to propose a suspension of funding under the Structural Funds. Mr President, the case raised by Mrs McKenna is unfortunately not an isolated incident. There are other examples of EU funds being used in a way that has a negative impact on protected areas established for scientific reasons. Can the Commission imagine instructing all Member States that, where they find a breach of European environmental directives or improper environmental assessments, not only should current funding be suspended but any funding already granted should be withdrawn or, in other words, the funds should be reclaimed from the Member States. This is the only way to prevent similar actions in the future. (SV) This is an extremely important question. As you, as Members of the European Parliament, will no doubt be aware, a joint letter was written last year by our predecessors in the Commission, Ritt Bjerregaard and Monika Wulf-Mathies, addressing the relationship between Structural Funds, funding from the Structural Funds, and protection under the FloraFaunaHabitat Directive. The message of this joint letter remains valid. We cannot distribute funds with one hand and, with the other, take countries to court, where they may be fined, so that it is important that there is agreement on this. Of course, difficult judgment calls can arise. However, in my opinion, the most important effect is that countries think more carefully and, above all, submit their lists of Natura 2000 sites, so that we have the opportunity for proper monitoring and control. Ireland, as well as other Member States, still has shortcomings in this regard, but we hope that this pressure will soon produce results. Let me reiterate that the content of the above-mentioned letter is still valid. According to the Rules of Procedure, this is not possible. You must speak outside the Chamber, Madam. Questions to Mr Barnier: Question No. 44 by (H-0020/00): Subject: Partnership and the third CSF for Greece. Compared with the previous regulation, the new Regulation 1260/1999 on the Structural Funds places particular emphasis on strengthening partnership and provides for the participation of autonomous self-governing bodies at regional and local level, as well as the other competent public authorities, the social partners, and any other relevant competent body, not only in the preparation but also in the financing, monitoring, and evaluation of assistance. However, according to repeated complaints from local government bodies, the procedures for the new CSF for Greece have remained unchanged and do nothing to enhance the role of "partners." Has the Greek State made any changes to the procedures to expand the partnership, particularly with regard to local authorities and other representative bodies? What is the enhanced role of local authorities in the preparation and management of the third CSF, and what measures has the Commission taken to ensure greater involvement of the partners in all procedures under the new CSF?

However, before the debates begin or during breaks in the sitting, could it not be opened so that we can enjoy, free of charge, that magnificent spectacle that appears to be behind you? I fully understand that it should be the richness of our debates that illuminates our Chamber; but we would benefit if sunlight could occasionally enter to illuminate our "bubble" of democracy. I think it would be very positive if the possibility of opening this curtain were examined. Thank you very much, Mr. Onesta. I welcome any suggestions that would give a more human dimension to our sitting chamber. I would like to make the following proposal. For the time being, we can continue the sitting by leaving the room as it is. In the meantime, I will send for information on whether the change poses any technical problems. If not, we will conduct a half-hour test to see what happens when the President sits against the light. UCITS. (SV) Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my hope is that today Parliament is ready to take the decision to expand and strengthen the financial market in Europe. As a new Member of the European Parliament, I have found it very interesting and instructive to be responsible for this important issue. I would especially like to thank my colleagues for their willingness to reach agreements, the President and the Chamber for their sensitivity to the complexity of this matter, the Commission—especially the Commissioner—and the Council for our good relations, and also the Committee Secretariat for its generous work. There was great unanimity in the Committee, except on one point, on which I hope we will also agree. The issue of UCITS seems complicated, fraught with political and technical risks. I believe there are those who do not even know what UCITS means. However, let me state that this issue truly concerns European citizens, that is, how their savings are managed, the choices available to them, how competition between countries works in the area of savings, investors' demands for security, and their ability to save wisely for old age. The aim is to balance the demands for liberalization to improve the market and achieve greater benefits with investor protection and security. During the 1980s, most European markets underwent considerable liberalization. This was a consequence of the rapid development of national securities markets, especially, for several years. Mutual funds then became an alternative to bank savings. In my own country, more than 60 percent of Swedes invest in various funds. Saving in funds provides security, which is based on the broad base of their investments. The capital and securities markets have continued to develop. The current UCITS directive has become outdated. New types of funds have been introduced in some member countries, which cannot be offered in others.

Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe it cannot be repeated often enough and intensely enough that what the Council has agreed as the agenda for the next Intergovernmental Conference is politically absolutely unacceptable, and I would add, shameful. We find ourselves in a historic situation in which we are negotiating with 12 Member States or are about to begin negotiations, and in a situation in which the joint growth of Europe can become a reality in the foreseeable future. But how can the Union be enlarged if things are not done properly now, that is, before enlargement? That is why our political group is in favor of the Intergovernmental Conference. We consider it essential and urgent, and we hope that it will truly produce results that will make an early enlargement of the European Union possible. Mr. President of the Council, my political group has noted with satisfaction that the Council Presidency is not satisfied with the current situation. Therefore, rest assured that the Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left will work to ensure that the Union finally fulfills its mission. This is nothing less than the future of Europe, and above all, a Europe that citizens understand as their own, because they can participate in its formation, and because the concerns, problems, and issues that truly move them are taken seriously by politics. Politics behind closed doors, deliberations in silent cliques—all this must end once and for all. Therefore, transparency is absolutely necessary. I believe that, as Presidency of the Council, you should ensure that the train does not continue to roll as it has until now and that people are not left behind on the platforms as if they were illiterate in Treaty matters. We believe it is essential not only to ensure that everything is done to thoroughly inform citizens about the progress and results of the Intergovernmental Conference, but also that they must be included much more intensively in the entire reform process. We also believe that the politicians who make the decisions must finally do something and, once the Intergovernmental Conference is over, ask the citizens through referendums how their Europe should develop further. This would truly give us a Europe of citizens and a completely new quality in the democratic legitimacy of the Union. I will address another central democratic issue. As a member of the Assembly that has just begun its work with the Charter of Fundamental Rights, I want to state clearly that a solemn declaration of the Charter is not enough for me and my political group. What will citizens say if they are solemnly announced certain rights but cannot claim them individually through the courts? No, I believe this would further deepen the Union's credibility crisis.

Madam Deputy, I ask you all - please do not take this as a warning - to only address strictly Community issues. I know that these are very important issues in Spain and there are several points of view... I say to the Commissioner that Aznar is the President of the Spanish Government. You can answer the question. Madam Deputy, as I heard that you were vocal, I hope that your voice was strong enough to be heard in Madrid, but I understood that what you were saying was not addressed directly to me. I have given you my answer. I am concerned that the structural funds, and in particular those under Objective 1, are allocated where they are needed. We have criteria that apply and we know here, as a guide, what each of the regions of Europe should or could receive. The fact remains - I am not hiding, but I am obliged to always refer to the general regulation - that I must discuss with the national authorities of each country and with the government of each country. It is their responsibility to make the distribution as objectively and fairly as possible. I need to know anyway, which is why I told you that I could not reply today. As I do not have the answer, I wrote to the Minister of Economy and Finance on 14 December. Now, the time is coming when I will become impatient at not having received a reply and I will pass it on to you when I have received it. I regret that the Commissioner has embarked, once again, on an imaginative, and this time fascinating, intervention. In Spain - I would like to remind you all - the problem is not that we are in an election period, it is that there are only 25 days left before the elections. The Commissioner will be pleased to know that these elections will take place in 25 days because, after that, he will probably no longer be asked these types of questions. Yes, I think it is important to say that Andalusia will receive 50% more under the Community framework and that Spain also has a record in the implementation of structural funds, which means that distribution is carried out in strict compliance with the implementing regulations and is decentralized through regional development plans and the various Community support frameworks. Finally, I would like to ask the Commissioner a specific question: do you think the implementing regulations for the structural funds should be changed, or do you find the current distribution criteria acceptable? I find this debate fascinating. I understand that it has a dimension that is not exclusively Community-based. That said, we must accept the fact that there are permanent elections in all the countries of the Union. What pleases me is that, fundamentally, the structural funds are the subject of discussions in Greece and Spain. Earlier, here, we were talking about citizen debates, public debates.

Unfortunately, more than a year after the proposal was presented, the other body of legislative power, the Council, has not yet started to deal with it. I hope that this debate will serve to remind the Member States of the importance and urgency of this initiative. We have recently learned from the Portuguese Presidency that a serious discussion on this proposal is about to begin. The French Presidency, which is about to replace the Portuguese Presidency, also seems willing to give this dossier the priority it deserves. The Commission sincerely hopes that Parliament and the Council will rapidly complete this important dossier, which in our view is the most effective response to the concerns raised by cases such as those discussed here today. As regards transnational worker participation, there is some evidence that in at least one case companies have breached the transnational information and consultation agreements they had concluded with their workforce at European level, or at least it is possible that they have exploited some ambiguities in the current legal and contractual framework. The Commission will contact the relevant national authorities to follow up on this. However, I would like to reassure those who fear that their rights in this area have been infringed that the appropriate enforcement and redress tools are available to them, in particular through the competent national courts. The Commission is aware of your request for an immediate review of the European Works Councils Directive. As stated in the report that we will adopt in the coming weeks, we recognise that the Directive does have some loopholes. However, my colleague, Commissioner Diamantopoulou, has already stressed on other occasions that other considerations will have to be taken into account when deciding on a possible immediate review of the Directive. Firstly, any review of the Directive would have little immediate effect on existing agreements, unless we wish to suspend the application of the fundamental principle of respect for the autonomy of the parties involved in negotiations. Secondly, an immediate revision would significantly complicate the situation for the other open dossiers in this field, such as the European company statutes and the proposal for consultation and information at national level. The successful conclusion of these dossiers could greatly facilitate the subsequent revision of the European Works Councils Directive and even provide, to some extent, a solution to the problems identified. That is why, in this context, we feel it is more appropriate to proceed with the revision of the European Works Councils Directive only after these two dossiers have been concluded, and after having more carefully assessed the application of the Directive. Our action is not limited to the legislative field. In order to encourage and support dialogue as a key element in successfully adapting to change, the Commission is also developing the recommendations of the Lillehammer report, by preparing a European observatory on industrial change. We are also working on another idea offered by that group of experts, namely the report on managing change. Finally, I would like to address some of the other concerns expressed in the draft resolution presented to Parliament.

I would like to see some changes in the Assembly, especially after the conclusion of the new Convention in May. There must be greater equality between the ACP partners and the European members and I want to get rid of the "them and us" syndrome. First, I would like to see a Joint Parliamentary Assembly of elected members from the ACP countries and not of ambassadors or government ministers present as delegates. I think that is the new Convention. Second, the new Convention provides for regional meetings in the six areas concerned, which would allow us to be more specific in our work. The regional assemblies should send reports to the Joint Assembly. We had a regional discussion in Nassau in the Caribbean and it was a very productive experience. We will also have another in Abuja in West Africa. I want the Assembly to stop being just a forum for discussions and become a laboratory for improving the conditions of all people in developing countries. I want civil society to be given a greater voice. But to do so, we need to put an end to the problem of corruption, and we need to tackle it with the utmost determination. We need to reward those nations that strive to uphold the standards of good governance. We need to be equally firm with those that are corrupt or whose constitutions do not allow for the pluralistic governments we demand. I am very pleased with the outcome in Zimbabwe. European taxpayers will no longer accept their taxes being used for fraudulent purposes. A new wind of change must blow across Africa and new standards must be set and respected. The Joint Assembly must play a leading role in monitoring compliance with the principles of good governance, human rights and democracy in cooperation with the Commission. I believe that as equal partners the ACP and EU elected delegates are up to the task and I ask you to approve the report. Mr President, I would first like to congratulate Mrs Corrie on an excellent and comprehensive report. Respect for human rights and the fight against poverty must be the basis of any development policy considerations. The reduction in resources in the area of development aid in many Member States and in the European Union is in stark contrast to the intention to fight poverty. As regards the crucial issue of funding, with a view to the future, the Joint Assembly must be provided with additional resources to be used to send electoral observers at the request of the ACP countries. In future, the European Union, when defining development projects, must, on the one hand, focus on several fronts and, on the other, better coordinate its position with the individual States, in order to work more efficiently and use funds more effectively. We can cite as an example the area of education, which deserves and needs special promotion in the future in the ACP countries. The rapid development of the potential of education and technology on the Internet has revealed the existence of entirely new tools for bringing developing countries, with their still modest means, closer to globality, but not to globalization.

The European Parliament certainly cannot be blamed for this failure. It is the governments of the Member States that have so severely restricted the scope for action. This presents the European Parliament with an almost insurmountable task. We should accept the idea that every available opportunity must be seized to achieve better legal assistance. Paradoxically, I could say: It would be best if we spoke as little as possible about this report. The more we make it clear that these are only very small steps, the more organized crime rubs its hands together, and the more clearly the blatant disproportion between organized crime and the acute lack of judicial cooperation becomes apparent. I urgently appeal to the Council of Ministers to finally acknowledge reality. Above all, it should recognize that crime is inversely proportional to codification. The goal is to provide judicial authorities – namely judges and prosecutors, but also the citizens concerned – with tools to combat crime without undermining fundamental rights of defense and general principles of human rights. Otherwise, we will only be combating the symptoms, not the causes. I therefore primarily advocate for the further harmonization of criminal law in the Member States of the European Union. In my opinion, this is the only way to combat crime in a cross-border and targeted manner. However, as long as this harmonization is still pending, we must be consistent in enabling legal assistance. To this end, I submitted an amendment stating that legal assistance may only be provided if the authorities initiate criminal prosecution for acts that are punishable under the domestic law of the requesting party and that of the requested Member State. Incidentally, the content of my amendment is reflected in Amendment 43, which also sets this cumulative condition. This condition is essential because, in my opinion, the principle of legality in criminal law, "nulla poena sine lege," must be respected. Consequently, any request for mutual legal assistance concerning an act that is hypothetically not punishable in the requested Member State is contrary to this principle of legality and, consequently, also to the fundamental principles of law in the requested Member State. It is therefore extremely important that this cumulative condition be adopted. In conclusion, I would like to reiterate that, in my opinion, Mr Di Pietro has done an excellent job. He has presented a report that, given the limited options available, offers every conceivable guarantee for the protection of individual human rights and fundamental freedoms. If we want to give European citizens a greater sense of security, we must make greater efforts towards judicial cooperation. Mr President, my group welcomes the drafting of a convention to regulate the daily practice of mutual legal assistance in criminal matters. The regulation is intended to establish the rights and obligations of states or citizens among themselves, or in the relationship between citizens and the state. The current draft is complex: It deals with agreements between member states, but also has far-reaching consequences for the relationship between citizens and state authorities.

This is the position adopted by the Secretary-General of the United Nations, and it is an element that must naturally be included in our future analysis. There is some hope for the third round of negotiations, given the proposed plans being prepared, involving representatives of the United States and the United Kingdom, particularly in the areas of security and constitutional structure. These plans are expected to be presented at that round through the representative of the Secretary-General of the United Nations. This will take place in a context already following the elections in the north of the island, scheduled for April 18. Furthermore, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union, following the example of previous Presidencies, has decided to appoint a representative to liaise with the various stakeholders on this matter. The representative has already contacted them and, in close collaboration with the representative of the Secretary-General of the United Nations, has followed the work of several rounds. In particular, we intend for the European Union to maintain a permanently active stance in this regard, all the more so given that Cyprus is, obviously, a candidate for European Union accession with a fairly advanced negotiation process, which naturally raises some hopes and determines that the European Union will play a significant role in this context. The approach we have been following in this debate and our participation in it has essentially consisted of taking advantage of a certain climate of easing tensions created by the conviction, commonly shared, it seems to us, that further negotiations are necessary and that the continuation of the negotiations and their continued pace are also, in themselves, elements of hope for the conclusion of a final solution. There is, moreover, another important element, already mentioned at the beginning of my statement, related to Turkey's commitment to contribute to the preparation of the north of the island for accession. We believe that we should not only read the conclusions of the Helsinki European Council with some care and attention, but we should also monitor the Turkish authorities' willingness to contribute to resolving this issue. I myself was in Ankara, where I had the opportunity to speak with Prime Minister Bülent Ecevit on this matter, and, although we are aware of the difficulties, the specific sensitivity, and the very idiosyncrasies of the Turkish approach to this issue, I believe that a window of opportunity is opening that cannot be missed. To achieve this, several factors must be combined, one of which—and it is worth noting—has to do with the very dynamics of the relationship between Turkey and the European Union. This is an essential element for the future of this issue. On the other hand, we believe it is important—also in relation to the way the European Union addresses the core of this issue—to encourage the exchange of information between the Commission and the Cypriots in the north of the island, without this implying—it should be made clear—any kind of official recognition.

When the United States landed in Somalia, from which it had to shamefully leave, it was certainly not to secure control of the oil routes, but to restore hope. "Restore Hope", do you remember? In short, do you not see that it is in the name of humanitarian law that the greatest atrocities are being committed today? Finally, you spoke to us about using the great means of crisis management, not to wage war of course, but to safeguard peace. But this has always been the argument of the architects of preventive wars. Can you guarantee that there will be no preventive war against other states, especially those whose elections do not support the policy decided by the other states of the Union? Mr High Representative, these are the issues on which our concerns are centered. You say you are against war, but you are certainly not the first warmonger to swear it. May God spare us the disastrous consequences of the grandiloquent principles that you have just set out to us. Mr President, the development of a European identity in defence and security obviously does not leave the three new members who joined NATO last year, namely Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary, indifferent. As candidate countries for accession to the European Union, they wish to be fully involved in this important initiative from the very beginning, from now on. However, the Council, meeting at the Helsinki Summit at the end of last year, chose not to take this wish into account. Only vague promises of consultation and cooperation were made in the Finnish capital. I would therefore like to ask the High Representative, Mr Solana, to what extent Prague, Warsaw and Budapest are or will be involved in the definition of European military crisis management plans. The question is all the more pressing in the light of the critical attitude taken by the Polish side. In short, the Polish reservation is as follows: avoid American isolationism and European separatism. Polish Foreign Minister Bronislav Geremek logically formulated this position in a more diplomatic way, stating that the construction of a European defence identity cannot be at the expense of NATO unity. On the contrary, the European defence identity must strengthen NATO. This is a position we fully share! Minister Geremek is certainly not the only authority among the new NATO members from Central and Eastern Europe to disagree with the crucial process underway. His position was supported by the Czech Defence Minister who, in the autumn of last year, stated: "The security of Europe is not divisible. Security cannot be limited to a small group of countries, while others are forced to passively watch or carry out decisions." The positions expressed bring back my question to Mr Solana. Poland's demand is simple: to be involved in decisions that concern it. What is the response of the current EU Member States to this legitimate demand of the candidate countries? B (ES) Mr President, I too would like to welcome the presence of the High Representative and his willingness to answer Members' questions during this second appearance, since during his visit in November - certainly not for reasons attributable to High Representative Solana - this was not possible, although it is right to recognise that he had taken note of the questions and that he had undertaken to answer the questions put by Members as quickly as possible.

It would be of great benefit to Tibet, and to all those who believe in peace and stability in Asia, and the Government of the People's Republic of China would also gain a great deal of credit if it responded to these attempts to initiate a dialogue. Question No. 31 of (H-0795/99): Subject: Commission's rejection of the Code of Good Administrative Behaviour in the EU According to press reports, the Commission has rejected the proposal by the European Ombudsman, Mr. Jacob Söderman, to grant citizens a guarantee of good administrative behaviour in the European Union (EU). The Commission itself approved the idea of a Code of Good Administrative Behaviour, but did not accept the detailed proposal made. Instead, it put forward a set of additional guidelines for better service. Is this information correct? Why is the Commission acting in this way, and how does it explain the resulting discrepancy between talk and action regarding reform of the EU administration? Does she consider this event compatible with the five-point programme agreed in September with the European Parliament, and is she prepared to present a detailed proposal for a code of good administrative conduct on which Parliament can also express its opinion? I call Mr Patten, on behalf of the Commission. It seems to me that the press reports to which the honourable Member referred are misleading and imprecise. The Commission approved at first reading in November 1999 a code of good administrative conduct for inclusion in its rules of procedure. The Commission is currently consulting its staff representatives on the document, a process that will be finalised in the coming weeks. The Commission will then adopt the code at second reading. It should be noted that the new Commission followed up immediately on the European Ombudsman's decision of 28 July 1999 in its own-initiative inquiry into the code of administrative conduct. The Commission would like to emphasise, in particular, that it took into account all the European Ombudsman's draft recommendations in drafting the code. The code will deal exclusively with relations between the Commission's administration and the public. It will be adopted by means of a legally binding Commission decision to be published in the Official Journal of the European Communities.
