The document has been drafted with full consideration of the provisions contained in the draft prepared by the Office of the European Ombudsman. In accordance with the provisions contained in the Treaties, the Commission itself is responsible for drawing up its own rules. However, it goes without saying that the Commission adheres to the principle of regular political dialogue with the European Parliament on all aspects of administrative reform. Mr. President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and ask when these directives will finally enter into force. I would point out that they date back to 1997. The information reported by the press was misleading. I do not think there is any difference between us and the Ombudsman.

This is why I want to highlight some issues that I believe the Commission should have at the forefront of its attention. We count on the Commission to take into account the points related to additionality. We are unhappy that these figures appear to have been somewhat hidden within the overall figures for the United Kingdom. We count on the Commission to also ensure that funds are matched to projects. We count on this to challenge the UK Government, to ensure that the private sector, which is surely the largest target of Structural Funds spending, is involved in planning. Finally, we ask the Commission to ensure that Structural Funds money is spent transparently. There are too many things in this Parliament that are not transparent. This is an issue that will foster friendship between the Commission and Wales. Mr. President, our committee deals with these issues from very different perspectives, and, first of all, I will speak from the perspective of research. We consider it very positive that the rapporteur has incorporated into his own conclusions our committee's proposal on the need for research infrastructure in the countries covered by cohesion, by locating higher education institutions and other training centers in such a way that they provide better service to the inhabitants of less developed areas and facilitate the permanence of qualified individuals in their areas of origin. This is possible through measures adopted by public authorities, and this method of territorial distribution in the location of higher education is undoubtedly an efficient policy for smoothing development. Another issue we wished to draw attention to, particularly from the perspective of industrial policy, is that we would have liked the Commission to have taken more account of the effects of the growth of services, e-commerce, and internet use when planning the coordination of the Cohesion Fund and the Structural Funds. In the past, poverty and wealth depended on the structure of economic activities. Wealthy regions used to have the greatest number of jobs in the industrial sector, but today these areas can become burdensome or even poor. In such cases, new investments must be made in the so-called IT and service sectors, as these are the sectors of the future. This aspect has not been sufficiently taken into account by the committee responsible for preparing the report, so, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, I draw the Commission's attention to this matter. Finally, as the Committee on Energy, we would have liked to see more emphasis placed on the need to subsidize renewable energy sources from the Cohesion Fund and the Structural Funds. This would have allowed us to increase the use of renewable energy sources by coordinating the two Funds. This would have offset the lack of financial resources for the energy program through the granting of these considerable financial aid funds. Mr. President, I would like to express my deep gratitude to Mr. Schroedter for his contribution to this issue and for explaining to colleagues that I am speaking on behalf of my colleague, Mr. Flautre, who succeeded him on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs but who is unfortunately ill.

Paragraph 3: Mr. President, I believe there is a translation error in the Swedish text; it would have been amusing if the European left had expressed its concern about a possible increase in taxes on capital gains. We voted as we intended, but there was a translation error in the Swedish text, and I want to put that on record. We know that the Commission will soon reform the Common Fisheries Policy. This proposal for a Council regulation is the first in a series that will make this reform a reality. The collection and management of fisheries data is essential for the sound management of the Common Fisheries Policy. This data must be reliable, independently produced, and accepted by all stakeholders in the sector, politicians, and those responsible for implementing the CFP. The text of the proposed regulation has been amended relatively substantially in the Committee on Fisheries. All the Members of our group voted in favor of these amendments, both in committee and in plenary. Amendment 1 clarifies the text significantly. Indeed, the data collected should not be used solely for scientific purposes. Scientists must process this data and transmit it to the relevant political authorities responsible for decision-making. However, it is essential that the collection method be carried out in a scientifically justified manner. Amendment 2, for its part, modifies the Commission's initial proposal. The Commission's proposal, in fact, requires the preparation of very detailed studies, vessel by vessel and company by company. In addition to the extraordinarily high cost of this proposal, the heavy management burden could lead some administrations to use this complexity as an excuse for not providing information in a timely manner, and could provoke feelings of distrust among professionals in the sector if such heavy additional bureaucratic burdens are imposed on them. Regarding the second part of the amendment, it is important to better account for and characterize job losses in the sector. The management of a common fisheries policy, let us not forget, must include a social dimension in terms of statistical analysis. Amendment 3 allows for the addition of an important dimension: the collection of environmental data. The particularly serious effects of not taking this type of data into account can be measured, for example, by the decision banning driftnets, which is completely unjustified from an environmental point of view, as it affects one of the most selective fishing gears available. If this environmental dimension were not integrated into data management, the Commission could unilaterally prohibit the use of this or that fishing gear at will. Amendment 4 clarifies the obligation imposed on scientists to process and transmit all data to the competent authorities, including national and regional authorities, so that they can contribute to the decision-making process.

If Parliament wants to monitor effectively, the evidence must be available, and I would like to know what the Commission intends to do to remedy this. One more word on ex post control, the DAS. The Van Hulten report also says this in part: I think it would be good if we gave numerical marks by category and by sector for the way in which the budget is implemented. The general impression at the moment is that everything is bad in the European budget. However, we have clearly observed in recent years a trend towards improvement in the agricultural sector and a deterioration in structural expenditure. Is this possible? I suggest that the Commission set a deadline for the implementation of the reforms. If we welcome new Member States, it is intolerable that there is no order in our own institution. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, thank you to my colleague, Mr Van Hulten. This is his first report to the House. This deserves congratulations, although I regret that he did not present his report in his mother tongue. Ladies and gentlemen, this report was difficult to prepare and perhaps comes too late. This is due, in my opinion, to the bickering between the two large groups sitting in the Committee on Budgetary Control. Let us be honest. The second report of the Committee of Independent Experts arrived in September. We are now four months later. In the meantime, Mr Van Hulten has been inundated with amendments, more than 100 in the first round. He went back to work and rewrote his report, taking into account a large number of suggestions, only to receive almost 100 more amendments in the second round. This explains the late presentation, I fear, of this excessively detailed and voluminous report. Furthermore, according to my information, the Commission has just approved a report on the reform of the Commission, which will be sent for consultation in the various institutions and therefore also to Parliament, I hope. Perhaps Mr Kinnock can shed some light on this this evening? Dear Mr Van Hulten, the Greens and Regionalists Group of the European Free Alliance will support the amendments in plenary tomorrow that seek to further improve this report. It makes no sense to repeat word for word in your report the many very valid recommendations of the Committee of Independent Experts. If we vote against certain amendments or paragraphs tomorrow, it will certainly not be because of their content, but only to make your report a more readable summary. In any case, it must be made perfectly clear that my group fully supports the recommendations of the Committee of Independent Experts. In any case, I am eagerly awaiting the document approved today by the Commission. In any case, I am eagerly awaiting the White Paper, which is due to be published in February.

Mr President, we are faced with a proposal that seeks to incorporate into Community legislation an ICCAT recommendation - as has been said, from 1998 - which should be binding from June 1999 and which only reached Parliament at the end of last year. The Commission's legislative laziness on certain issues should not surprise us if it were not for the fact that we are faced with a recommendation issued by one of the major international fisheries organisations and which concerns the protection of a resource that is now seriously threatened, tuna. The Mediterranean - in particular some of its areas - is a very important breeding ground for bluefin tuna, of enormous commercial value. For this reason, ICCAT has recommended that the Adriatic be considered a closed area to fishing and has made the conditions governing the capture of age-zero specimens more stringent. As the rapporteur says, both measures are fully and extensively justified and therefore all that remains is to ask for their approval. However, I agree with Mr Gallagher who feels he has to express his frustration at the delay with which the Commission is putting its mechanisms in motion and converting recommendations into Community legislation. We are still waiting, for example, for the proposal for a regulation on the ban on imports of bluefin tuna from Honduras and Belize, a recommendation which dates back to 1996. From what I understand, it seems that last January the Directorate-General for Fisheries sent a note to the Directorate-General for Trade and that the latter has already started the preparatory work. However, four years to implement the ban on imports from countries which are known to favour flags of convenience is a completely unacceptable time limit, Commissioner. We have listened to the explanations given by the Commission to illustrate the long internal process required to transpose a recommendation and the image we have received is that of exasperating bureaucracy. As regards the only proposal that has been put forward to streamline the procedures for the legislation under discussion, which would exclude the Council and Parliament, I wish to express reservations. It is clear, however, that we must find a solution to this problem already in the context of the Commission's report on regional fisheries organisations and, in any case, as soon as possible. I do not think that anyone in this House would object to the principle of the protection of juvenile fish. In fact, it is often said that one of the general objectives of the common fisheries policy must be to protect and conserve the living resources of the marine environment. That is all very well. And there is no doubt that bluefin tuna is of enormous environmental and financial importance. As an amateur fisherman, I too would like to go back to the 1930s, when fishermen in the port of Scarborough in Yorkshire were catching tuna weighing up to 830 pounds - I do not know what the metric equivalent is. I therefore support the ICCAT conclusions and the principle of intergovernmental cooperation on environmental issues. However, I would not like us to sit here debating and twiddling our thumbs while Rome burns. The common fisheries policy does not work. What has been said about conservation is certainly inspired by noble principles, but in reality the quota system is leading us directly to environmental catastrophe.

The Helsinki European Council had the courage to take some decisions and I believe that, from various points of view, they have already taken into account what I defined as a glimmer of possibility at the beginning of my initial speech. It is not by exploiting tensions that we will obtain concrete results in this negotiating phase, which is a delicate phase. It is, on the contrary, with a view to discreet work, work in support of the mission of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General of the United Nations in this area, that we must continue to move. The European Union has had an unequivocal position on this matter, honourable Members, and it seems pointless to me to want to give a different interpretation to any sentences that may appear in the Council's speeches or in any other position taken. In this Chamber we are not fighting for what is politically correct, we are fighting for the right choices at international level and to support the concrete and coherent positions taken by the Council over time and which the European Commission has also followed with great attention and in a pragmatic way. When, in this period, we hear about the need to involve the community of the Northern Cyprus area in some exchange of information, especially in the perspective of a future accession of the Republic of Cyprus to the European Union, we must realize that we are trying to find practical formulas that will allow us to overcome the obstacles that we encounter on the road to a political solution. This is not a matter of subterfuge, nor are we in any way trying to create, through practical solutions, a model that constitutes a recognition of a political nature. I believe that in this regard the Council of the European Union has provided clear evidence over time that this is not its position. Decisions have been taken with a great sense of responsibility on the part of the Council. The Helsinki conclusions are, in our opinion, very clear in this regard. The way in which we have dealt with the Republic of Cyprus within its process of accession to the European Union is something that the Cypriot authorities themselves recognize as extremely positive. It is useless to give or try to give a different interpretation to our intentions. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to express my warm thanks for this debate, in which I have felt encouraged and confident and which shows that the European Parliament largely shares the policy of the Member States and the Commission. I am happy to provide some clarifications requested. Firstly, on headings 4 and 7, the issue is very simple: in Berlin, as part of the broad Agenda 2000 package, a special heading was established for the candidate countries of Central and Eastern Europe which have begun a process of transformation, and for them alone, namely the infamous heading 7. Malta, Cyprus and Turkey were not covered by it. Mrs Schroedter described this as inconsistent. Perhaps she should turn to the then President of the Council, who is not far from her, and ask him why this alleged lack of consistency.

As for the Commission, I hope that it will be able to join in the compromise reached in Parliament and aimed above all at ensuring this balance. To underline this aspect once again - given the difficulty of the situation - Parliament has decided for now, for ease and safety, to enter the funds for the EQUAL programme in reserve, so that at a later stage it can be convinced of how the resources are being spent. I believe that this was the right choice. Parliament's position throughout this procedure is unclear and not even the regulation helps to clarify it. Precisely for this reason I believe that entering the funds in reserve was the right choice. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is an incontrovertible fact that the INTERREG initiative contributes to the commitment to economic and social cohesion of the Union. However, I would like to underline the particular importance that INTERREG has in the Balkan area, where the political upheavals and war events of recent years have had a significant economic impact on the surrounding countries, and in particular on my own, Greece, the only Member State of the Union located in that tormented peninsula. For Greece, for the other countries bordering the region, Italy and Austria, but also for Europe as a whole, a social and economic restructuring of the Balkans that will bring political stability to this area is of primary importance. To date, some Balkan states have received funding under the PHARE and OBNOVA programmes, while others have not. In the new programming period, in view of enlargement and taking into account the funding provided by new regulations and financial instruments, such as ISPA and SAPARD, it appears absolutely essential to adequately coordinate the funding of the three INTERREG areas with other funding intended for third countries. We therefore welcome the relevant references included in Chapter 7 of the European Commission text on the definition of the general guidelines of INTERREG. The commitment to coordination, and therefore also to efficiency in programming, must equally concern all the various programmes, and if I make this observation it is because, in the previous period, the MEDA programme highlighted some difficulties that must now be overcome, in order to guarantee equal treatment for all third countries participating in the programme. Finally, Mr President, I would not like to fail to point out that the new definition of the cooperation zones between States did not take into account the particular geographical situation of the Mediterranean, which would have instead justified the creation of a specific zone for coastal and island areas. We therefore ask the Commission to pay particular attention to the issue of maritime and island cooperation in a forthcoming review of the definition of the zones. I conclude, Mr President, by pointing out that the Union must persist in this type of initiative aimed at eliminating disparities between regions and ensuring their harmonious development. And, since today is Valentine's Day, as a former mayor of a provincial town, I propose that we all declare our love for the regions of Europe, for those that are in such great need of our love. Mr President, Commissioner Fischler, the development of rural areas can and must take into account three issues: maintaining jobs, protecting the territory and, last but not least, preserving local culture, which is of the utmost importance!

Under these circumstances, even the best resolutions will remain demands of principle that will not prevent the big trusts from doing harm. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am in favour of tightening up the rules on port State control and classification societies. However, we must also stick to the facts. The Erika was inspected four times in the last two years. It is therefore not the number of checks but their intensity that must be ensured. In the debates of recent weeks, I have heard it said: the Member States do not have enough money for checks! I cannot accept this argument. If the Member States decide in agreement with us that 25 per cent of ships must be inspected under port State control, then they must also provide the necessary personnel! In the event of an inspection, it is not enough for the inspector to simply go on board to see if a fire extinguisher is missing; tests must also be carried out on the materials, because it is clear that the ship in question broke down due to excessive strain on the materials. Such phenomena can only be detected with very thorough checks. We must ensure that port State checks do not only cover external aspects, but also include tests on materials. Secondly, I agree with what the Commissioner has said, and I encourage her to continue along this path. If it is found that one or more classification societies have issued fake appraisals, these societies must be removed from the list of authorised societies; only with this deterrent can we prevent others from behaving in the same way. Dear Mrs Roth-Behrendt, the TÜV for vessels already exists, and it is the classification societies! There are also series of them, and you know several of them, as do our French colleagues; but we must take a good look at which societies do not meet the pre-established criteria, and these must be removed from the list. One last point: we should make it clear to Malta that, if it wants to join this Community, when it joins it will have to apply a standard in the registration and control of the flag State that truly meets the criteria we have established, because the environment is common to all, it cannot be divided! Mr President, Commissioner, the Erika sank right near me and is still there, with 20,000 tonnes of fuel that we don't know what will happen to them. It could also have sunk elsewhere. It sank there by chance, and Brittany, where I come from, certainly does not have to apologise for being a peninsula because of its geography, given that it is Brittany that often suffers shipwrecks. First of all, I think of the 26 Indian sailors who are not mentioned and who were rescued. There could have been victims in this catastrophe and maritime safety concerns above all the lives of men. They have now left but it is a miracle that they were saved. We start again like 20 years ago with Amoco, one accident on the north coast, one on the south, one on the west.

On the other hand, at European level, various measures could be studied to improve relations between hotels and tour operators, such as a regulation governing their relations, the promotion of a special bankruptcy fund, etc., in cooperation with representatives of both sectors. In the past, the Commission requested quantitative data on the damage suffered by businesses due to bankruptcies, in order to form an opinion from the European hotel and restaurant confederations and travel agencies, Hotrec and ECTAA, and to draw up and draft a regulation governing their relations. Since then, however, no progress has been made. It is therefore necessary, Mr President, Commissioner, to establish measures that would improve the quality and competitiveness of European tourism, but also ensure, as far as possible, the functioning of businesses. They must also aim at the rational use of natural and cultural resources, as well as tourist infrastructure, thus contributing to the sustainable and balanced development of tourism. In conclusion, I would like to congratulate Mr Viceconte and, as a Cretan living in a tourist region, I ask you to consider tourism not only as a pleasant holiday but also as a job creator for a Europe that needs them. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the recent change of attitude adopted by the Commission towards tourism has attracted the attention of those who, like me, have followed this important economic activity and its introduction into the Community world in recent years. Everyone is aware that this is fundamentally due to the close cause-and-effect relationship between tourism and employment and to the recognition by the European Union, following the conference held on this subject in 1997, of the enormous potential that tourism represents for employment. This is why the Commission communication we are debating today is timely, as is, of course, Mr Viceconte's report, which contains 34 conclusions, including 15 requests to the Commission, for which I congratulate him. In these 15 requests, the Commission is invited to adopt concrete measures and actions without neglecting the environmental aspect and cultural protection, particularly in the outermost and island regions. Four requests are addressed to the Member States, in particular the need to coordinate actions with regional authorities and to establish measures favourable to tourism SMEs, particularly in terms of taxation and access to financial instruments in order to encourage job creation in sectors that use a lot of labour, such as tourism. Finally, we must recognise that once the lack of a legal basis, to which many of us aspire in order to have a common tourism policy, has been overcome, we must be realistic and develop a strategy in this area, as the Commission, with the help of this Parliament, has emphasised regarding its relationship with employment, in which young people and women, training and quality, and the new information society must receive particular attention. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank Mr Viceconte for his report, which helps to draw attention to a sector that is too often overlooked.

It is insufficient, and I am glad that Mr. Barnier has mentioned here an idea that I very much like and that, moreover, I expressed to the press in Bordeaux, namely, the establishment of a strengthened European civil security policy. If we want the European citizenship we desire to exist, if we want this mandate, which our President, Mrs. Fontaine, has attributed as its hallmark the rapprochement of the Union and the citizens of Europe, to be effective, I believe that the urgency must be palpable for our fellow citizens. Therefore, I believe that a Eurocorps Civil Security, the establishment of genuine Blue Helmets for civil relief, present in places of difficulty, within the Union, since we currently do not have an emergency procedure, but also outside, if the need arises, in Venezuela or elsewhere, would be something we should advocate for. I therefore wish to tell Commissioner Barnier that in me he will find an active ally of this idea, which I consider generous and European. Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in Europe we are relatively safe from hurricanes, compared to the frequency with which they occur in other regions of the world. Even so, the storms of the last week of December demonstrated what their consequences can be and that they can still cause us major problems. Those who traveled to Strasbourg by car or train will have seen how violent the storm was, even in Alsace. I would therefore like to express my condolences to all the citizens and regions so severely affected by the storm, and at the same time, in this House, emphasize the importance of supporting these regions and their inhabitants. We all know that other regions of Europe may be similarly affected in the future. Now it is necessary to remove all the felled firewood as quickly as possible. We all know, indeed, that even more serious disasters can occur if firewood remains abandoned in the forest for too long. It is also worth remembering, for example, that the bark beetle finds fallen trees an optimal environment for propagation and laying their larvae, which can have further consequences that are still impossible to assess. It is therefore essential to remove damaged wood before the warm season arrives. The true extent of the damage suffered in the forestry sector will only be appreciated in several decades. We all know, indeed, how long it takes a tree to grow. It is a process of decades, not years. I would also like to point out, furthermore, that forestry is not, of course, associated solely with timber production, but in some regions is above all an essential factor in maintaining forest reserves. I am therefore very proud to announce that Austrian foresters have also volunteered... (The President interrupted the speaker) Mr. President, I express my deepest sympathy to all those affected by the storms.

We are also developing another proposal made by this expert group relating to the "Managing Change" report. I will conclude my speech with the other concerns raised in the draft resolution submitted to this House. As regards strengthening the link between competition policy and social policy, allow me to remind you that the merger regulations contain a provision allowing workers' representatives to be heard by the Commission in the relevant procedure. From a general point of view, the Commission recognises that the various bodies must properly take into account all aspects of this type of operation, including their effects on employment. Thus, for example, the public authorities, and in particular the Commission, have already taken measures through guidelines on national regional aid which came into force on 1 January 2000 and are designed to ensure that public funding remains linked to the beneficiaries of regional aid and, consequently, to jobs linked to the investment. To this end, the granting of any regional aid is conditional on the maintenance of the investment concerned for a minimum period of five years. The same provision has been added to the Structural Funds Regulation. This means that it applies to all investments co-financed by the Structural Funds. Social cohesion and the interaction of actions carried out at Community level is at the heart of the next summit, which will be held in Lisbon. I know that we will return to these issues in the future, as we must consider how best to adapt our actions and reform them to respond to economic and social progress in Europe. Thank you very much, Commissioner. Mr Gorostiaga Atxalandabaso, I understand that you have a point of order. If this is a personal statement, would you be willing to wait until the end of the debate? At that point, I will be happy to give you the floor. Mr President, this is a matter of public honour for this Parliament, not a personal statement. This morning, the President of Parliament, Ms. Nicole Fontaine, repeatedly refused to give me the floor when I wanted to speak on a point of order. This is unfortunately not the first time that Madam President has displayed this unacceptable behavior towards me. In doing so, she violated Rule 142 of the Rules of Procedure, which stipulates that requests to speak on a point of order have priority over any other request to speak. She also violated Rule 122 of the Rules of Procedure, which gives all Members the right to speak on a personal matter. In my case, these were observations that refuted remarks made by another Member, Mr. Vidal-Quadras. This partisan behavior by our President should be condemned in the strongest possible terms. I will gladly accept her apologies at any time. Thank you for your statement. We will certainly ensure that we inform the President. I can assure you that, as far as I know, the President does not like to interrupt votes and start a debate. So the Assembly probably wanted to continue voting. But I thank you for your comments.

It will be composed of qualified auditors, and its independence must be and will be guaranteed by a new provision that will be added to the Financial Regulation. The new service will be accountable to me and will be supported by an Audit Monitoring Group chaired by my colleague, Mrs. Schreyer, whom I am pleased to see in this chamber this evening. As Commissioner for Budgets, my responsibilities already include relations with the Court of Auditors. This Audit Monitoring Group will ensure rigorous and effective monitoring of internal audits. I would like to emphasize strongly that the modification of our control systems will in no way mean a relaxation. The proposed modification aims to improve the effectiveness of the systems, both in terms of inputs and in terms of measured and accountable results. I can also assure Parliament that we are not moving towards what is sometimes called a "big bang" approach. The prior approval of financial control for each spending department will only be abandoned if a department's internal control system proves to be entirely adequate. I am somewhat surprised that paragraph 10 of the draft resolution does not appear to echo the fundamental criticisms of the current centralized financial control function expressed in the two reports of the Committee of Experts. That Committee clearly stated the need to abolish centralized prior approval. It was also clear on the need to separate internal audit from financial control. Furthermore, I do not believe that paragraph 10 fully reflects the opinion of the Court of Auditors issued in 1997. The Court will, of course, be able to give its opinion on the proposed changes to the Financial Regulation, but it is worth recalling what Mr. Karlsson said in this Chamber last month: "The Commission's internal control," he said, "is not sufficiently vigorous to prevent incorrect transactions." Thus, the Financial Controller has issued a positive prior approval in most of the cases of mismanagement or irregularity that have been discovered recently. At the same time, the internal audit function is not carried out in a coordinated manner by certain bodies, notably by the financial controller himself, by the financial inspectorate, and by certain units managing directorates-general. Originally, the centralized prior approval system was undoubtedly intended to ensure vigilance, but over the years, it has had the perverse effect of reducing the extent to which managers feel responsible for their decisions. I do not think there is any real disagreement between us on this point. I gather from paragraph 10 that the underlying concern of Members is that there should be a carefully managed transition. This will most certainly be what characterizes the change, as Members will be able to read in the reform strategy document. Our objective, that of the committee, that of the Court of Auditors, is not to abolish financial control, but to get rid of centralized financial control and do better. Before moving on to another area, I would add that we agree with the rapporteur that the existing internal audit function must be maintained until the new independent internal audit service is established in a few months.

It took the Council and the Commission two years to present this proposal. Therefore, it is absolutely necessary to reach a decision now in March. Delaying the matter or even risking damage to the euro would be irresponsible and also a betrayal of the citizens who will be using the new, unfamiliar banknotes. Counterfeiters are expected to operate primarily in countries outside the euro zone, where awareness of the new currency is less widespread. Therefore, the protective measures also cover these countries, whose views have been given great weight. For this reason, the proposal can be described as solidarity-based and reciprocal in its consideration of the various interests, which is also mandatory. Now the Council must meet in March and make a decision. I thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for listening to me. Thanks also to those who contributed to the swift treatment of this issue. I am thinking in particular of the PSE Group. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Charlotte Cederschiöld, on this report, which is an excellent starting point for strengthening criminal protection against counterfeiting in view of the introduction of the euro. The euro will enter circulation on 1 January 2002 and will then become one of the world's most important currencies. Due to its global importance, the euro will be particularly exposed to the risk of counterfeiting. This draft framework decision therefore lays down a series of minimum rules and attempts to harmonize criminal law in this area and make its implementation by each Member State simpler and more effective. Furthermore, it provides for criminal protection of the euro even before it is put into circulation, thus closing a legal gap in some Member States. I would like to expressly support the rapporteur's view that it is necessary to extend this criminal protection to national currencies, which can continue to be exchanged even after they have been withdrawn from circulation. Each Member State must ensure the introduction of effective, appropriate, and dissuasive criminal penalties for the acts criminalized by the draft framework decision. As for the proposal to set a maximum prison sentence of eight years, I do not think there will be any problems with my country, which, although our penal code currently provides for a maximum sentence of five years for counterfeiting, has already indicated its willingness to make such an amendment. Secondly, I would like to appeal here, as our rapporteur has already done for the reasons she has indicated, to the few Member States that still have some reserves of money to dispose of them so that a decision can be taken on the matter as soon as possible. Mr President, this draft framework decision represents the first joint proposal for a criminal law regime applicable simultaneously in all 15 Member States. In doing so, we are taking further steps towards the goal of developing and shaping the European Union as an area of freedom, security and justice, as envisaged in Tampere.

It is clear that the incidence of scrapie in sheep has been a contributing factor to the overall problem. I welcome the legal basis that has been established and the comprehensive approach of the new provisions, which I hope will correct this situation. We must ensure that nothing enters the food chain or compound feed that could lead to situations like those we have already experienced in the future. No one wants a repeat of the situation faced by farmers due to BSE. We must introduce the strictest possible provisions, and we must ensure that they work. It is of the utmost importance for producers, as well as for consumers, that we restore confidence, and the only way to do this is to rigorously tackle and resolve the problem. BSE has not disappeared. We can find it in some countries. I do not want to point the finger at any particular country, but many countries are currently facing problems similar to those we had in the United Kingdom. The problem will remain for some time. We must ensure that the entire system of identifying the origin and tracing the animal from birth to slaughter and throughout the entire food chain is part of this confidence-building mechanism. If we fail to achieve this, we will face enormous problems in the future. Finally, I have long believed, because I come from a farming background, that if we had fed animals properly and if the feed had been made from the right compounds, BSE would never have occurred. It was never the farmer who was responsible; it was the feed producers who caused this problem, and we have an obligation to ensure that it never happens again. Mr President, I am pleased to have been given this opportunity to address an issue on which there is good cooperation between Parliament and the Commission, namely the fight against TSEs. I would also like to thank Mr. Böge for the work he has done on this matter. Considerable progress has been made on our proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council, pursuant to Article 152 of the Treaty, on the prevention and control of scrapie. This proposal addresses all the dangers of TSE in all animals and at all stages of the production chain. I am here today to hear your views on the first step in this process aimed at establishing a truly comprehensive Community system for the control of these diseases. In the proposal before us, I propose removing all the Community provisions currently in force relating to scrapie in sheep and goats and transferring them to the framework of the proposed directive. Detailed provisions would then be introduced into that framework. I have learned that Parliament welcomes this initiative to formulate a single text, as evidenced by your interventions this afternoon. I look forward to discussing any further improvements that Parliament may wish to suggest within the framework of the proposed legislation, especially following Mrs. Roth-Behrendt's reference to her own report and opinion on the matter.

As a result of this unusual procedure, Parliament is refraining from attributing responsibility for the 1997 provisions where it lies, namely with the former Commission. It was the 1996 accounts that brought down the former Commission, and the 1997 accounts are just as damning. There is therefore no reason to grant discharge. As regards the decision to close the accounts, we will abstain from voting, and finally, as regards the motion for a resolution, we would like to stress the many recommendations that have rightly been made, and we will vote in favour. Mr President, the discharge decision for the 1997 financial year was postponed because the previous Commission had already resigned by the date set for that decision and was now only dealing with current business. Now, Mrs van der Laan, to whom we should pay tribute for all the work she has done, calls on us in her report to grant the Commission a discharge for 1997. One might wonder why the current Commission should receive a discharge for the implementation of the general budget of the previous Commission - Mr Camre also mentioned this - especially since the discharge for 1996 was refused. But that is how it is. Since taking office, the new Commission has had to assume responsibility for past actions, but also for past failings. Since the system of collegiate responsibility that prevails within the Commission allows us to take a total of three decisions on discharge, namely to grant, postpone or refuse, the fact that four Commissioners who were members of the previous Commission are now back in this body has no further impact. This question should have been raised when the new Commission was sworn in. If Parliament approves the proposal made by the Committee on Budgetary Control this week and grants discharge, the Commission would be wrong to regard this decision as a blank cheque. I believe that the third part of Mrs van der Laan's report, the motion for a resolution, is the most important. The obligations it contains, set out under eight different headings, are an integral part of the discharge. Our decision depends on its implementation. During the discharge for the following financial year - 1998 is already under consideration - Parliament will have to check very carefully whether it has not congratulated the Commission a little too prematurely. We will have the touchstones when the Commission presents its reform programme. The discharge for the financial year 1998 will allow us to see whether efficiency, transparency, accountability and an open attitude towards the discharge authorities prevail. Mr President, we all know that Parliament has decided to postpone the discharge for the 1997 financial year pending the internal reform commitments that the new Commission would adopt.

Three-quarters of these are children under the age of five. This is not due to food shortages, but rather to what we have spoken about several times today, namely increasing poverty. Food safety and the protection of biodiversity must come before commercial interests. In my view, patents on living organisms serve the sole purpose of controlling the world's food supply, especially for commercial reasons, and nothing else. In the report which I hope the Commission will prepare, I would also like to see something on the subject of women. In every context, not least in development cooperation, women seem to be completely absent, which is not at all the case. Mr President, today's debate underlines the strong need to discuss development policy in much broader terms than simply recording aid flows. The level of aid is certainly an important aspect and all rich countries, as a whole, should increase it. This should serve, not least, the purpose of combating poverty, with particular attention to development potential. On the other hand, the level of aid is only one of many instruments that can have a huge impact on the development of poor countries. A number of colleagues have highlighted today some important areas, in addition to aid, where conflicts and contradictions between different fields of action are of great concern. This concerns, for example, trade policy, agricultural policy and fisheries policy. Other important areas are of course the flow of private investment, cooperation in research and technology and the way in which the global community manages and finances certain global issues that affect us all. These global issues include climate change, biodiversity, health problems and so on. This is further confirmed by globalisation, that is, by the new economy that is emerging. In this new economy, the links between different fields of action are becoming stronger and stronger. What we are discussing today is partly, in my view, the Union's contribution to the debate on the potential and risks of globalisation, on the rules of the game that must exist to ensure adequate opportunities for poor countries. The report, the snapshot of the interconnections and contradictions between the various sectors of intervention that Mrs Maij-Weggen has requested is of course of vital importance. I wonder why the Commission has not done more. The Commission is new, it must be given time, but the absence of this snapshot indicates that there are strong tensions within it. I can only hope that Commissioner Nielson will be able to gain consensus in future discussions within the Commission. Beyond this type of report, I would also like a more positive analysis, which should be a continuous analysis. This analysis should not be limited to checking the flows of aid, but should instead focus on all the different types of aid and transfers that have an impact on poor countries. I am referring to technologies, trade aspects, cooperation in the field of research, etc.

However, AIDS is such a major problem in Africa today that more people die from the disease than are killed in conflicts. I hope the Minister will take the time to address this particular point. The US already has medicines, but it is unwilling to sell them at a price that the people of Africa can afford. I would like to ask the Minister what he will do about the emerging situation in Ethiopia. The country is suffering from drought and crop failure, and in six months' time, it will face exactly the same problems as a few years ago, when thousands of people died in famine. At the same time, the war between Eritrea and Ethiopia continues unabated; the European arms industry supplies plenty of weapons, and then we come and supply the food. Mr. Member, you must understand that, firstly, I disagree with your interpretation of my colleague's statement at the meeting of the Committee on Development. There is no contradiction between these positions; quite the opposite. In a presidency's program, we cannot, except in a fit of megalomania, undertake something like an exhaustive inventory of all possible and imaginable situations relating to all major problems, particularly in the context of external relations. It would be easy to do so, as you will surely understand. One need only take a development glossary and copy out all the questions one by one. We are responsible enough to recognize that we can only include those issues that we can deal with within the framework of our presidency and within the capabilities of the governments at Council level—and we must always be aware of this. We must understand that there are limits to the possibilities for implementation here, particularly with regard to the national indicative programs. The honourable Member referred to the problem of Ethiopia, which is included in the framework of the national indicative programs, but as you know, there are various measures at Community level to combat AIDS, and in this respect you are right, Mr. Moreover, I believe that Europe has nothing to worry about when it comes to development aid policy, for the simple reason that our conduct in this area bears any comparison with the United States. The honourable Member's question then moved on to the problem of the negative effects of armaments. This is a problem of wider political importance, which probably goes beyond the scope of the original question, but which the Council will of course discuss in the future if it so wishes and decides to address it in a specific context. Is the Council aware of the social problems caused in developing countries by EU food exports at prices below producer prices? Does the Presidency intend to take any action on this matter? Since the author of the question is not present, Question No 13 lapses. I should like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council and, on behalf of the Presidency of the Portuguese Government, extend a personal greeting. Please allow me to express my appreciation for his eloquence and his in-depth knowledge of European affairs.

This situation is caused by both regional policy and the Union's economic and social policy in general. Broad sections of the Union's population strongly denounce this policy as dangerous and anti-grassroots. Unfortunately, the new guidelines point in the same direction, and there is no indication that their implementation will change this. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to say a few brief words here to underline two points which these reports remind us of and which play a key strategic role in our vision of the Union. The first is the crucial and central importance we continue to attach to the principle of economic and social cohesion. We express our concern at reports which indicate that the importance of this objective is increasingly diminishing in the Commission's views. We continue to believe that economic and social cohesion is a central objective of the Union. Secondly, I agree with what I have already heard from a colleague here on the subject of islands, and I would also like to draw attention to the outermost regions. In the future, we would welcome more courage in addressing the issue of outermost regions, as is the case with my home country's archipelagos of the Azores and Madeira. I take this opportunity to ask whether the Commission can explain the reasons why the Commission's report on the outermost regions, which Parliament has been awaiting for some time, has been delayed. Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, and also for her willingness to include our suggestions in the report. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the aim of guidelines is to offer Member States guidance on how to achieve the reform objectives within the framework of programming. However, contrary to their claim to provide guidance, the Commission's specifications in this regard represent more of a catalogue of possible measures within the policy areas. Providing direction and setting priorities, however, is their real purpose. I agree with the rapporteur that the Commission document unfortunately contains too few recommendations to the Member States on administrative simplification, and I underline calls for negotiations to focus on promoting a favourable environment for labour-intensive small and medium-sized enterprises, on setting clear objectives for alternative sources of finance, including arrangements for venture capital and private finance, on start-up aid, including new information technologies, and on investment in innovative sectors. I particularly support my group's amendment to paragraph 10, which is intended to ensure appropriate involvement of the private sector in project planning and implementation. I would be delighted, Mrs Schroedter, if you would include this amendment in your positive considerations, particularly from the perspective of subsidiarity. Mr President, Commissioner, in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs we unanimously took the view that supporting Structural and Cohesion Fund interventions to improve employment opportunities for the unemployed and to promote equality between men and women is of strategic importance and a priority. Unfortunately, the excellent Schroedter report did not take this idea into account, even though there is ample evidence - as we shall see later in the Berend report - of how these funds are doing a really great job of helping less developed regions to bridge the gap between them and the most developed regions in Europe.

To underline this—the situation is a bit complicated, of course—Parliament has, for the time being, placed the Equal program in reserve, for convenience and security reasons, so that Parliament must be convinced later on how the expenditure will be carried out. I think that's a good thing. Parliament's position throughout this procedure has remained somewhat unclear. The position in the Rules of Procedure is also not very clear, and that is why this reservation is very positive. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, it is indisputable that the INTERREG initiative fosters the effort for economic and social cohesion in the European Union. But I would like to underline the special importance of the INTERREG program for the Balkan region, where political changes and military activity in recent years have had serious economic consequences for neighboring countries, and especially for my country, Greece, which is the only member country on this troubled peninsula. For Greece, for neighboring countries Italy and Austria, and for all of Europe, the economic and social reconstruction of the Balkans, which will bring them political stability, is a matter of vital importance. To date, the Phare and Obnova programs have funded some Balkan countries and not others. Under the new program period, with a view to enlargement, and taking into account the provision for funding from new resources and financial regulations, such as ISPA and SAPARD, it is absolutely essential to coordinate the funding of the three aspects of INTERREG with other funding to third countries. We therefore welcome the references to Chapter 7 of the European Commission's text on the adoption of INTERREG guidelines. Efforts to coordinate and, consequently, to achieve greater planning efficiency, must concern all programs equally. I say this because in the MEDA program, during the previous legislative term, there were some problems that will need to be overcome in order to treat all countries participating in this program equally. I would like to conclude, Mr. President, by noting that the new planning of transnational collaboration zones has not taken into account the unique characteristics of the Mediterranean, which would justify the creation of a special zone for maritime and island regions. We therefore ask the Commission to give special consideration to the issue of maritime and island collaboration in a forthcoming review of the planning of these zones. I conclude, Mr. President, by emphasizing the need for the European Union to insist on such initiatives that aim to eliminate the inequalities between our peripheries and their harmonious development. And, since today is Valentine's Day, as a former mayor of a peripheral city, I propose that today we all declare our love for the European peripheries, which need it so much. Mr. President, dear Commissioner Fischler, development in rural areas can and must respond to three approaches: specifically, the preservation of jobs, the care of the landscape, and, last but not least, the care of local culture, for this is indeed important.

I will therefore judge on the actions. In the meantime, I approve and encourage this desire clearly expressed in your communication. However, two points are essential: the simplification and application of Community law. In 1998, there were 123 referrals to the Court of Justice for non-application or non-transposition, and 25% of environmental directives are not applied or transposed. The events of recent days show us how essential this is. Community law must not remain unapplied because it is too complex or too fussy. The Union must not fall into this trap, and here again, I regret that your communication does not go into more detail. You are realistic about the fact that the welfare state will no longer be able to provide the right answers to the problems we face, including unemployment. I regret, however, that a clear option was not put forward. The emphasis should have been placed on rejecting any welfare policy and, on the contrary, on promoting initiative and responsibility. You do not emphasize the aging of our population, an aging that will have fundamental impacts on the structure of our society, not only from an economic point of view but also in terms of public health. It is, in fact, a silent revolution, and from this point of view, I expected more from your communication. Finally, you emphasize European research as being at the heart of our future. However, you do not tell us what resources you wish to implement. Ethical principles are also at the heart of this research. Your communication says nothing about this. Mr. President, you want to better inform the citizen. Start by strengthening ties with Parliament: we are the representatives of these citizens. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we cannot but agree with the general thrust of the five-year programme and the programme for the year 2000, illustrated this morning with such passion by President Prodi. In both documents, the emphasis was placed on the need to define new forms of European government and to implement, to this end, a new Commission agenda, defining the most immediate priorities in pursuit of the objective of full employment, through more effective coordination of the economic and social policies of the States and - I would like to stress this - above all of the nations participating in the Monetary Union, which must be helped to constitute the first example of enhanced cooperation. To this end, I will limit myself to stressing the importance of three priority choices, among others, which should inspire, in addition to the Commission's agenda, the work of the European Union in the coming months, also in the formulation of the action programmes of the governments of the countries of the Union. Firstly, the promotion and participation in the definition of joint projects for the creation of an integrated network of services in the transport and energy sectors, with the support of the European Investment Bank. Secondly, the adoption, as binding parameters in the formulation of action programmes on employment, of investments to be made in the various countries and through Community projects in the priority sectors of research, innovation and the qualification of the human factor.

The Commission pointed out in committee that it intends to present a novel food directive in the future. However, this should not prevent us from harmonizing the directives now, so as to avoid legal uncertainty arising from different directives. We therefore assume that you will also accept our amendment concerning genetically modified organisms. The fact that Directive 70/524 still contains the old text is due to the fact that the Seed Directive was presented to Parliament in 1986, and we negotiated with the Commission until 1988, while the report on this directive was dealt with in 1994. Clearly, Parliament did not attach the same importance to genetically modified organisms at that time as we did later, when I was rapporteur. Therefore, Commissioner Byrne, we believe that you will accept the amendments we have tabled, including those concerning the legal basis. If that is not the case, we must reserve the right to refer this report back to committee in order to then negotiate with you on this sensitive issue, similar to what we did with the Seeds Directive. I would like to point out once again that the text we have now drafted is valid as a compromise for both your Legal Services and ours. We therefore do not need to renegotiate the text; we simply need to incorporate it into this directive. I am eager to hear your comments on our proposals, Commissioner Byrne! Mr President! Commissioner! Is the regulation of additives in feedingstuffs a matter of competition or consumer policy? For the Commission and the Legal Affairs Committee, it is a matter of competition. We must certainly take account of the competitiveness of the feed industry by harmonizing the regulations for substances authorized before and after 1988. A rise in feed prices must be prevented, and therefore Amendments Nos 4 and 5 by Mr Doyle should be supported. First and foremost, however, as Mr. Graefe zu Baringdorf put it in his report, this is a consumer policy issue. Food safety must have absolute priority in all discussions about animal nutrition. When we talk about transparency in the food chain, this applies from the pitchfork to the dinner fork, and so consumer protection logically begins with animal feed. Antibiotics, growth promoters, and genetically modified organisms added to animal feed ultimately find their way into the human food chain. As a consequence of the dioxin scandal, it was clear to all of us that we must finally step out of this dirty corner. Regulating additives in animal feed is a step in the right direction. According to Article 152 of the EC Treaty, we are obliged to eliminate the causes of danger to human health. The emphasis is clearly on causes. Consequently, we must turn off the tap on the original sources of pollutants – harmful additives in animal feed. Otherwise, I believe we're just treating the symptoms but not addressing the causes. The public is particularly critical of the use of GMOs. We must address the public's growing awareness of GMOs and regulate their use in feed accordingly. First, if an additive consists of or contains genetically modified organisms, it may only be approved if it is safe for human health and the environment.

Mr President, this initiative is gaining in importance as the economic and social problems in Europe's cities worsen and their citizens increasingly feel that the administration of their city or district is moving further and further away from them. Added to this are the profound social changes resulting from the enlargement of the European Union. We must therefore make timely efforts to promote the economic revitalisation and social cohesion of our cities. Tackling these problems is also a matter of urgency, given the significant influence cities have on the surrounding region and their historical and cultural role. However, the success of this project requires the commitment and participation of all citizens, as well as the mobilisation of less active social groups and those particularly affected by the economic and social crisis. We would like to stress the importance of the balanced participation of women and their organisations in the planning and implementation of programmes under the URBAN initiative. As the Committee on Women's Rights and Equal Opportunities, we would also like to point out that funding must be provided for infrastructure measures that facilitate women's professional activities, particularly with regard to reconciling professional and family responsibilities, and more generally for facilities that promote intergenerational solidarity and social solidarity. The effective implementation of this initiative could have a multiplier effect, perhaps inspiring similar projects at regional and local level. This would make it possible to further enhance its political significance, because women must finally feel the practical impact of European policy in their daily lives. Mr President, in our committee we welcomed the Commission's proposal to improve the integration of local communities and ethnic minorities, as well as increasing security and crime prevention, as priorities for the URBAN programme. In committee, we considered it necessary that the economic and social revitalization of urban areas must go hand in hand with the creation of an atmosphere of tolerance towards minorities, so that measures designed to reduce racism and xenophobia must be an integral part of the programs to be financed under URBAN. We considered increasing citizens' sense of security, and thus combating everyday urban crime, to be a key task in the revitalization of urban areas. Our committee has established that innovative and effective crime prevention and control at the municipal level requires differentiated measures; these include the integration of crime prevention into urban planning, measures to prevent juvenile delinquency, the reintegration of offenders, and models for effective cooperation between various actors at the local level, such as the police, the judiciary, or social services. As a committee, we adopted our recommendation unanimously because it was very important to us to continue URBAN—which has been successfully implemented in the past—because we believe that only with such programs will we succeed in achieving long-term, peaceful coexistence among all residents of the European Union. For this reason, we warmly welcome such programs. Regarding the largest of the four Community initiatives, INTERREG III, I would like to draw attention to the concerns of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.

Why did the Council not inform us? Why did the Commission not inform us of this formal request from Macedonia? Mr President, Commissioner, from a political point of view, the Balkans are not simply a dark cave. One only has to look at the considerable positive developments that have taken place in the Republic of Macedonia in recent – difficult – years. The appalling spiral of ethnic violence in neighbouring Kosovo has not spilled over into Macedonian territory. Paradoxically, although it is true, the war in the Kosovo Polje camp has had precisely the opposite effect: a clear reduction of the dangerous gap in trust between the Macedonian majority and the Albanian minority. In the eyes of the Macedonian majority, the Albanians have behaved with great loyalty towards the common state during the international outbreak of the conflict in Kosovo. In the eyes of the Albanian minority, the Macedonians and the Macedonian state have generously fulfilled their obligations as neighbours towards the tortured Albanian population of Kosovo. This unusual outcome of the conflict in Kosovo can therefore rightly be called the second internal political birth of the Republic of Macedonia. The balanced and commendable report by Mr Swoboda is very concretely linked to this surprising and happy outcome. In other words, the European Union knows what position to take towards Macedonia. It must help this region, which has recently become a place of refuge for a great many refugees, to properly play its role as a promoter of the Stability Pact in the Balkans. Mr President, I have been dealing with Macedonia for eight years, and I take the liberty of contradicting Mr Dupuis. What we are doing is not hypocrisy: we have come at the right time, and I believe that the Macedonians are happy about it. I ask you not to be so hostile and to moderate your statements: I think we should approach the issue in a more positive light. Macedonia was not at war, but it has suffered from the conflict in neighbouring countries and from sanctions and is still suffering from the consequences of sanctions rightly imposed on neighbouring countries. It was greatly affected by the influx of refugees during the Kosovo war. It should therefore also be said that Macedonia has shown surprising continuity in its democratic developments: it is a country that has to deal with difficult problems of inter-ethnic relations within its borders and is solving them with ever better results. I would like to explicitly emphasize that we can congratulate Macedonia on its exemplary legislation on minorities and the way it has dealt with the problem, and that the involvement of 30 percent of the Albanian population in government life and politics and at the social level is a prerequisite for peaceful coexistence in the country. I am pleased that the demand formulated in Mr Swoboda's report is being followed up at the beginning of March, namely that a European delegation should finally be established in this country too, that we should finally be considered as the European Union. I believe that the start of these negotiations on the stabilisation and association process is the logical consequence of fruitful and positive development in the country.

I think Mr. Swoboda's report is excellent, and I fully endorse it. Mr. President, I too would like to congratulate Mr. Swoboda on his report. It is welcome that so many people here support the approach he has chosen. It is about tackling stability in the region structurally, and that is also the content of the agreement with the Republic of Macedonia that we are discussing today. While the actual implementation of the Stability Pact has yet to get underway, the Commission has worked quickly in developing the new instrument, the Stabilization and Association Agreement. This will begin the contractual stabilization of the countries of the former Yugoslavia. It concerns the countries that are not yet eligible for a pre-accession agreement. The current agreement is actually a kind of "pre-pre-agreement," but with the prospect of future membership. This integration of countries through active treaties is a very good instrument, provided the agreements stipulated therein are vigorously implemented, so that the hoped-for stabilization actually occurs. Macedonia remains a potential powder keg and, as such, has a history. However, it has the ambition to shed this image. This requires internal stability. The new government will be approached about this, and the agreement can provide an agenda for reforms, including the direct participation and equal rights of the Albanian minority. The country now needs, above all, calm to establish internal order and find the path to greater prosperity. We, the Social Democrats, appeal to the opposition to act in accordance with this view. It must support the much-praised Macedonia model. But the country also, and above all, needs external stability. What use is internal stability if the environment is unstable? This stability is necessary in relations with Yugoslavia, Kosovo, Albania, and Bulgaria. The region must acknowledge that Macedonia exists and will continue to exist. External stability means open borders and regional cooperation. Minorities and majorities must be given space for human and cultural exchange. Macedonia's stability is closely linked to developments in neighboring countries. The Kosovo problem is well known; the international community has a massive presence there. The Albanian factor appears to be underestimated. In the Union's view, the time is not yet ripe for a Stabilization and Association Agreement with that country. But when? The very arguments for concluding an agreement with Macedonia but not yet with Albania fill us with so much concern that a wait-and-see attitude towards Albania by the Union is truly unacceptable. What is the Commission's position on this issue? Yugoslavia is also a weak point in stability and thus a threat to a stable Macedonia. We must wait and see what happens there. The mood in Belgrade is becoming more difficult to assess by the day. However, we support the Council's decision to shift the focus of sanctions. This at least represents a serious attempt to finally support the opposition, which is preparing for a new round of demonstrations. What further steps will the Union take in this direction if the opposition's demand for early elections is granted?

Secondly, it is clear that the reform will require some new investment in training and technology; thirdly, it is clear that much preparation will have to be made for enlargement, and these initiatives already have an impact on the availability of resources. On the other hand, as we take on new tasks - which the Council and Parliament will certainly ask us to do - we will have to identify the so-called 'negative priorities' and eliminate them in order to create new spaces. A key feature of the reform will therefore be the introduction of a more rigorous procedure to link the setting of priorities to the allocation of resources on the basis of an activity-based management system. I would like to stress, however, that while internal discipline on setting of priorities will certainly be introduced by the Commission, it can only be truly effective if Parliament and the Council support it and take an equally rigorous approach to the requests made to the Commission. The Commission therefore welcomes paragraph 15 of the Van Hulten report. I conclude, Mr President, by thanking the House for its attention to this necessarily long speech, and by extending my heartfelt thanks once again to the rapporteur, the Committee on Budgetary Control and the other committees which have expressed their opinions. We hope that we can soon begin working side by side with Parliament to finalise the strategic package of reforms and, most importantly of all, to be able to collaborate with Parliament in finalising the implementing measures which will be necessary over the years for such a complex reform. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon. (The sitting closed at 11.15 p.m.) Middle East peace process (continuation) The agenda is the continuation of the statements by the Council and the Commission on the Middle East peace process. I am very grateful to the President of the Council for the statement on the Middle East which he made this morning at the start of the debate and for having been able to listen to some of the analyses carried out by Minister Gama, who has just returned from the region. My only regret is that my commitment to open the European Agency for Reconstruction on Monday meant that I could not take part in the trip to the Middle East, although, as I said before - but that is another story - circumstances meant that I stopped at Munich airport and could not get to Thessaloniki. That is life. I hope that Members will forgive me if I cannot stay until the end of the debate, as I would do in normal circumstances. The debate was scheduled for this morning and on that basis I had decided to meet the visiting delegation from the Balkans this evening. I therefore hope that I can count on the House's understanding on this occasion. I assure you that I do not intend to make this a habit. Like Parliament, I welcome the efforts made by the United States in relaunching negotiations between Syria and Israel, despite Syria's decision to say that it needed more time before resuming the talks, which were due to start today. There is reasonable hope that the foundations for a peace agreement can be laid in the near future.

Mr President, Commissioner, I have brought you a little present. Here is a piece of naphtha sent by an inhabitant of the island of Noirmoutier who wrote to me: "At every tide, the beach is covered with crude oil leaked from the Erika. At every tide, volunteers, soldiers and firefighters remove huge masses of this black, viscous and dense tar. When will we have a clean beach again and when will this devastating accident end?" Yes, this Erika accident, like that of the Russian ship in Turkey, is unacceptable and intolerable in an age when high technology is skyrocketing. It is even more unacceptable because it occurred twenty years after the Amoco Cadiz disaster, when we had said and repeated many times that it would never happen again. It is undoubtedly the responsibility of politicians, and therefore ours, to guarantee the safety of maritime transport. We must really guarantee citizens that a disaster like this will never happen again. Listening to you, Commissioner, one feels a little frustrated because those who have already dealt with these issues know that the Commission and Parliament had prepared, in 1992 I believe, a very interesting text which already contained all the proposals contained in the resolution drawn up today by the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism. Because it is true that it must be said and repeated: the Erika is one catastrophe too many. For this reason, it is urgent that the European Union undertakes a drastic revision of its directives on maritime transport, to make them more restrictive and to establish a clear and precise regime of the responsibilities of cargo owners. For example, Shell and British Petroleum refused to have their oil transported by the Erika. Why is the responsibility of the charterer, Total, not recognised in this case? Your proposals also need to include the obligation of double hulls and the ban on degassing at sea. A European body of inspectors must be set up so that they can effectively and efficiently check the condition of ships. It is also urgent that the European Union commit to reforming the IMO. After all, what is the point of drawing up restrictive directives if most ships do what they want when they sail the oceans? Finally, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to address a heartfelt thought to all the volunteers, friends of nature and birds who spontaneously and generously respond and rush to the aid of birds soaked in diesel fuel, organising their rescue with the means available. I am a first-hand witness to this exceptional work. You are certainly aware that around 200,000 birds will die because of the oil spill, which is an ecological disaster of enormous proportions and virtually without precedent. You are also certainly aware of how difficult it is these days to conserve species and how difficult it is to conserve habitats. In this regard, Commissioner, you have said nothing about how the Commission intends to contribute to the restoration of nature and ecosystems. Once again, there will be no clearly identified responsible parties. In the meantime, it is always nature that gets the worst of it.

We are at the beginning of an era of creating a new law, in which the right to exploit intellectual property will clash with the public interest in its dissemination and exploitation by the general public. Mr. President, I thank the rapporteur for this excellent report, which nevertheless concludes that our adherence, as a Community, to these two WIPO treaties must not be limited to a simple institutional evolution, however important that may be: the possibility for the European Community and the WIPO Assembly to work together. This ratification is also necessary with regard to the enlargement of Europe. But behind this Community adherence lies an objective that, in my opinion, is still too virtual and yet too offensive to some Member States. It is the affirmation of a European cultural policy on which I hope we, Parliament, the Commission, and the Council, can agree. Those who refer to cultural policy are referring, among other things, to the defense of the role of creation, the recognition of authors, and the production of a demanding culture.
