And even more so today, when Europe must adopt a new policy on copyright and related rights, it is urgent—as has been emphasized on several occasions—to define and redefine what an author is. We remain too vague on this matter, and from now on, new technologies force us to make this effort at clarification. Mr. President, Commissioner, the signing of the WIPO Treaties represented a considerable positive step in the global development of the information society. These Treaties crystallize a decades-long copyright tradition and constitute a balanced and well-thought-out solution for regulating copyright and related rights. However, the entry into force of the Treaties and their final form will depend both on this recommendation and on its implementation by the interested parties. The WIPO Treaty has already entered into force in the United States with the help of the Digital Millennium Corporate Act, a legislative measure that has helped preserve the delicate balance of the WIPO Treaty. The European Union, too, must make progress in adapting its laws to the provisions of the WIPO Treaty. It is also worrying that the positions adopted by the previous Parliament do not support the balanced system of the WIPO Treaty. The opinion adopted at first reading on the Copyright Directive was severely distorted, and the balance is shifting in a direction detrimental to Europe. The recommendations proposed do not improve the position of culture in Europe; quite the contrary. The amendments proposed by Parliament would be limited to improving the possibilities for established media companies to transfer their former shares of over 80 percent to a new framework through rigid and scaled copyright laws. I am not referring here to Ms. Charlotte Cederschiöld's recommendation, which in itself is a wonderful proposal, but to copyright as addressed by the previous Parliament.

(IT) On behalf of the Italian communists, I wish to express my deep dissatisfaction with the contents of the document that, according to expectations, was supposed to formulate the strategic objectives for Europe up to the year 2005. Employment: For years, the link between economic growth and increased employment has not corresponded to reality, yet it is once again being proposed as a recipe—one that has proven useless—for solving the extremely serious problem of unemployment. And yet the President is a seasoned economist. Pensions: The document states: "The responsibility for modernizing social protection systems will continue to fall to the Member States." Yet, in the case of Italy, the Commission intervened repeatedly, repeatedly calling for a rapid modification of the pension system, aimed at reducing rights and benefits. And yet, President Prodi, due to the important guidance he gave the Italian Government in those years, knows how many and what sacrifices our fellow citizens have been asked to make and made in order to join the euro, and he is aware of the important role Italy plays in European development. For this reason, we cannot accept calls for further pension cuts. There is an agreement on this issue that provides for its review in 2001. It should not be revised one day earlier or one day later. Moreover, the cost dynamics in this regard are completely under control. Therefore, the Commission must refrain from this unacceptable ideological approach and from these statements that create instability and uncertainty among citizens. I mentioned the case of Italy not only because the President is very familiar with it, but also because, based on EU data (Eurostat), it is clear that for Italy, welfare spending—currently at 25.9%—has not only been lower since 1990 than the EU average (28.2%), but is also far lower than the average of countries considered exemplary, such as Germany (29.9%) and France (30.8%). Europe's role: first, we must reaffirm that Europe rejects war as an instrument for resolving international conflicts; then we can talk about the Union's "military" role. Agriculture and health: our view of the issue differs from that of the Commission: for us, there are no consumers, there are citizens who want to eat healthy food, with products whose purpose is not competitiveness, but rather healthiness, quality, and respect for the environment, elements that, moreover, create jobs. (FR) The proposed measures and the program presented by Mr. Prodi are extremely vague, and social issues are, once again, absent. Furthermore, the word "social" seems to be banished from the Commission's vocabulary, while liberal and North American references abound. Renano Prodi embraces the highly controversial concept of "good governance"; controversial because it favors dirigisme over the proper functioning of democracy, and because it refers to the notion defined by the IMF, whose ideological content is totally dominated by liberalism and monetarism.

Coherence and action are needed. The next Lomé Convention must specify investment in education and encourage regional cooperation and the participation of local authorities. The participation of local authorities is of the utmost importance. And, in a much broader framework, I consider the conversion of the debt of poor countries into poverty eradication and sustainable development programs, as well as the control of fraud and corruption, to be priorities. We must move forward with concrete and coherent actions. The populations of poor countries are beginning to despair. I ask the Commission to take steps towards East Timor's urgent accession to the Lomé Convention, as a way of promoting, among other measures, the eradication of poverty and accelerating its economic, cultural, and social development, in order to strengthen its internal democratization. Finally, I congratulate the Council Presidency on the upcoming Europe-Africa Summit and call on all participants to make contributions to the implementation of practical actions to promote peace, democracy, and the eradication of poverty in underdeveloped African countries. Thank you, Commissioner. The debate is now closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12:00. Stabilization and Association Agreement with FYROM The next item is the report (A5-0031/2000) by Mr. Swoboda, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy, on the recommendation for a Council decision authorizing the Commission to negotiate a Stabilization and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (SEC(1999)1279 - C5-0166/1999 - 1999/2121(COS)). Mr. President, dear Commissioner Patten, ladies and gentlemen, today we are debating a country that has gone through truly difficult times, a country that, thanks to its own efforts, its will, and undoubtedly the support of the international community, has experienced very positive progress. If, consequently, the European Union, the Council, and the Commission propose—I dare say this term without a doubt—to conclude a stabilization and association agreement for the first time in southeastern Europe, in the Balkans. Parliament will, I suppose, join this proposal tomorrow. This will be thanks to, or in recognition of, the fact that FYROM/Macedonia has worked hard to enjoy a good position economically, but also, and above all, politically, with regard to the war in neighboring countries and in relation to its own ethnic minority. Having an ethnic minority of 33 or even 35% in one's own country is no small feat considering the environment in which this country finds itself. The country and its politicians, although certainly different, have always done very good work, and this deserves our recognition. The Commission is proposing that we conclude an agreement with the Council. I would like to make a few observations regarding areas where there may be differences of opinion, although I would also like to particularly highlight and acknowledge in this context the work and interest shown by Commissioner Patten for FYROM/Macedonia and the entire region. First: the regional approach. In my opinion, the regional approach is, if I understand it correctly, important and necessary.

Articles 6 and 7 of the Treaty would indeed prove insufficient in the worst-case scenario. In this regard, it is necessary—and I would like to confirm and reaffirm this here now—for the Commission to persevere in its efforts to ensure that the new Charter of Fundamental Rights to be drafted is incorporated into the Treaty and establishes binding rights that are enforceable before the courts. In this regard, the Commission must also persevere in the ongoing consolidation of the common area of freedom, security, and justice. Consequently, in this regard, I maintain a position opposite to that of the two speakers who preceded me. The only way to respond to the irrational, misleading, and demagogic statements of the right, the far right, is by contrasting them with the principles of immigration and the right to asylum. However, I wish to emphasize this, this policy must also be accompanied by a coherent and convincing policy on employment and combating social exclusion, since unemployment, marginalization, and growing inequalities constitute an optimal breeding ground for anti-European nationalist sentiments and actions. Mr. President of the Commission, I would also like to review in this context the problems you have raised regarding globalization and the perception of it held by large sections of the population. The feeling of powerlessness, lack of influence, and lack of support from the State lead, at best, to distancing themselves from politics and abstaining from elections, as occurred in the European elections, and at worst, to extremist electoral behavior. In this context, the Union—something that not everyone understands—must offer our EU citizens the EU itself as a means, as a protection against the negative effects of globalization. We are building a home, but too few of our own citizens truly feel at home there. Therefore, not only is a reform of the World Trade Organization and the economic architecture necessary—and it is significant that the President of the Commission forgot to mention the reform of financial institutions, of the international financial architecture—but it is also necessary to adopt confidence-building measures for our citizens, who are entitled to expect help and support from the EU, and within the EU, in the face of the inevitable but painful processes of adaptation to new global circumstances. In this context, what the Commission can say about strengthening Europe's voice is important. Mr. President, you yourself spoke today of a model to which, unfortunately, I find too few references in the document. You said that we must offer our citizens a model of economic, social, cultural, and ecological development, within and outside the Union, that is clearly distinguished from other models, including the American one. The United States, besides being our partners, is also our competitor in this regard—not adversaries, but competitors, and we must compete to determine who can offer the best model to our citizens. I hope that the statements we are making so forcefully today will also find greater relevance in the Commission's documents. Madam President, Mr. President of the Commission, your Commission's greatest legacy to the European Union could be your contribution to restoring and redistributing the Commission's powers and responsibilities, which are becoming increasingly intertwined and confusing, and which could perhaps even be extended to the Union.

The authors of this question are not proposing any solution, but are calling for a new tax, for more bureaucracy, for a measure that goes against market mechanisms, and are bringing an inter-group concept before the plenary session, bypassing the relevant parliamentary committee, in contradiction with several of Parliament's decisions. In my view, and I say this clearly, this question is ideologically motivated and not solution-oriented. I repeat that I consider this to be the wrong path. Why do we reject the Tobin tax and consider it so questionable? Firstly, as the Commissioner also confirmed, because it represents a very heavy burden on the capital markets. A reduced tax would also have serious repercussions for the capital markets, because such a tax on speculation would significantly reduce the profitability of investments. Furthermore, such a measure would also seriously hamper the development of the financial markets. This would run counter to the principle of the free movement of capital, which is at the heart of the internal market. Secondly, speculative capital is difficult to identify. Third, tax measures can easily be circumvented if they are not introduced simultaneously in all countries, as there are then many safe havens. Fourth, this measure is hardly technically feasible, creates a significant bureaucratic and administrative burden, and is difficult to monitor. The measure we should take concerns part of the resolution before us. This concerns strengthening banking supervision. It concerns clarifying liability for transactions. It concerns a regulatory framework at international level. It concerns examining national laws to determine whether they correspond to the Basel Committee's rules and whether these can be further disseminated. I have a major problem with a crucial point in this resolution, which we also cannot accept as it stands. This is point 9. If we have followed the Commissioner correctly, we know that the Commission's knowledge of this matter will lead it to say no to the Tobin tax. If the knowledge, the debate, and the arguments are as we present them and as they seem justified to me, I believe it is irresponsible to mobilize the Commission for six more months and thereby create uncertainty on the financial and capital markets. The capital market does not expect us to create uncertainty; it needs clarity. That is why we reject point 9 and request a separate vote. Madam President, the debate on the taxation of short-term financial transactions is not new. We have been discussing the Tobin tax proposal for 20 years, and yet this issue is still relevant because we really need concrete and sincere answers based on scrupulous research. We need to know to what extent a taxation of short-term financial transactions is actually desirable and feasible. Today, this question has indeed taken on a new dimension, since every day, USD 1,500 billion travels around the world 24 hours a day, in search of attractive investments, and at most 3% of this sum is linked to the real economy.

The recent dioxin scare in Belgium and before that the BSE crisis in Great Britain, as well as the ongoing controversy over the safety of genetically modified foods, have contributed to undermining consumer confidence in food. If the Commission succeeds in rebuilding confidence in the food production chain, it will simultaneously rebuild confidence in the European institutions themselves and demonstrate that they are capable of protecting the rights of European citizens. I am therefore pleased that the issue of food safety, public health and consumer confidence have a prominent place in the Commission's work programme for 2000. However, I have been disappointed by the nature of the proposal for the creation of a European Food Authority in the recent White Paper. At present the proposal is more of an advisory agency to the Executive, rather than an independent body with legislative and decision-making powers more similar to those of the US Food and Drug Administration, which has already established its credibility in this field. In addition, future legislation will have to address the modus operandi of the relationship between the European Food Authority and national authorities, for example the Irish Food Safety Authority. This body, together with the recently established cross-border food safety body in Ireland, is already doing good work. It would be a tragedy if these efforts were undermined by shortcomings in EU legislation. My fear is that such shortcomings in EU legislation could lead to jurisdictional wars between national and EU bodies which should be working together and not against each other. That is something we must guard against. Madam President, today's presentation by President Prodi was necessarily just a brush stroke. We expect the details year by year, for example with regard to the social action programme which is to be presented this year. We will also look at it from the perspective of social and employment policy and subject it to a series of tests. We will see to what extent it is possible to create an equilateral policy triangle, combining economic policy, employment policy and social policy. At the moment, social policy is lagging behind economic and employment policy. In the context of the employment strategy, we will look at deepening and broadening the strategy following the review carried out under the Portuguese Presidency and in the context it has proposed. On the social dimension, we will look at whether a deepening of the internal market with a social component is proposed. The explosion of mergers, disposals and takeovers that we are seeing as the market strengthens means that we need to update the matrix of directives on information and consultation of workers adopted in the past, but we also need to complement them with a new general framework of information and consultation provisions and an update of the directive on European works councils. We also need a code of conduct for companies to ensure that they actually work in partnership with employees to manage change.

On average, the Commission has 2.9 staff to manage USD 10 million of aid, compared to 4.3 in the World Bank and between 4 and 9 in the largest Member States. This is a serious problem: there are too many financial instruments, each with its own characteristics and, in particular, a number of different budget headings. It is difficult to reconcile this with the requirements of an effective management system. To address and resolve these problems, the Community must engage in real dialogue with the Member States and the Parliament. It is absolutely essential to address the issue of coherence in a realistic and pragmatic way, which means engaging in discussions in the appropriate institutional context, i.e. with the Council and the Parliament. The lack of concerted action between the 15 Member States and between them and the Community also needs to be addressed. By focusing the Community's development policy on internationally agreed strategies and objectives, we will pave the way for better complementarity with the Member States. This is pretty much the line outlined earlier by Mr Amado, President-in-Office of the Council. Nowadays, when we talk about policies, we are engaged in a process of convergence. This is part of the solution. We are engaged in formulating new policy orientations and we need to identify priority areas for Community intervention. Everything has become increasingly complex, and this is also true for development cooperation. No donor can address the entire spectrum of issues alone, ranging from macroeconomic issues to the regulatory framework or from sectoral policies to a variety of new cross-cutting issues, such as gender, environment, good governance and institutional reforms. It is important to find flexible mechanisms that allow for a division of labour according to the skills and capacities of different donors in each developing country. This should be done at Member State level and should lead to the formulation of sectoral policies for Community intervention. This is what we aim to achieve. In order to identify priority areas for Community support, the specific characteristics of the Community in relation to Member States and international institutions need to be taken into account. I will mention just a few: our ability to combine development policy with trade policy and to ensure synergies between aid and economic cooperation; our neutrality and the protection of the general interests of the Community; the fact that we represent a critical mass and that we are able to undertake interventions of a relatively large scale compared to what individual Member States can normally do. And then there is our concrete presence: basically, I think our greatest asset is precisely the fact that, as a successful attempt at regional cooperation ourselves, we are seen as a neutral and welcome partner in this global experiment, a role that no one else can claim. It is vital to make Community policy more effective and to develop a more operational strategic framework. The Commission must take up this dual challenge by presenting a proposal for a general political declaration in the coming months.

The situation has now escalated to the point where the Pentagon has banned American forces from returning to northern Mitrovica. They have since been replaced by robust Danish, Finnish, and Swedish troops. It is easy to despair in the face of violence and hatred, but it is vital for Kosovo, the Balkans, and Europe that we do not fail here. The Stability Pact imposes major obligations on us. This issue therefore becomes a test of the credibility of the Union's Common Foreign and Security Policy. Currently, Kosovo suffers from a severe shortage of suitable personnel. Last autumn, Bernard Kouchner called for a civilian police force. I am therefore pleased to hear that Mr. Javier Solana will be bringing together interior ministers this weekend to discuss the police issue. I hope these talks will focus primarily on Kosovo, so that the desperate situation there can be ended. As far as the Balkans and Kosovo are concerned, I also hope that the Council will support Parliament's and, as I understand, the Commission's call for a multiannual budget for operations in Kosovo. Mr. Solana, the situation in Kosovo has taught us many things, such as the creation of military capacities for crisis management, which has already been put into practice. Another, at least equally important, experience, however, is that preventing a crisis is more important than later firefighting operations. For this reason, the EU also needs independent and credible means of conflict prevention. As far as the Commission is concerned, Commissioner Patten has already undertaken several commendable initiatives in this direction. I am thinking here of the proposal to set up a rapid reaction facility and a rapid reaction force for non-military operations, as well as the creation of headline goals for non-military operations and a Commission crisis center. My final question to Mr. Javier Solana is: What concrete steps are planned for conflict prevention? How is this organized in Mr. Solana's office and coordinated with the work of the Commission? Mr. President, Mr. Solana, you enjoy the full support and confidence of the Liberal Group, but we would like to remind you of the enormous responsibility that now rests on your shoulders. I am thinking, firstly, of the important humanitarian, peacekeeping, and peacemaking tasks that lie ahead. But I am also thinking of your responsibility to ensure that the new European cooperation in the field of defense does not drive a wedge between NATO and the EU, or between the USA and Europe. Such a division would only benefit those tyrannical and despotic states that threaten freedom and human rights. I believe you have noted the concerns expressed by some members of the American Congress here in Parliament last week. You must allay these concerns, Mr. Solana. You yourself said that we can achieve something if we work together across the Atlantic. Disunity weakens us and thereby prolongs the suffering of the oppressed. Therefore, dear Mr. Solana, maintain as close contact as possible with our American allies and also consider Norway, Turkey, and Canada.

Respect for and the inviolability of human values, the rights of minorities and the rights of all citizens living in the European Union are the foundations of the principle of the rule of law in the EU. This is why the Convention on Fundamental Rights should also be legally binding and not relegated to the role of a mere declaration. Equally important is our support for the democratic forces in Austria; none of us has the intention of isolating this country. We know perfectly well that a large part of the Austrians respect these values, as they have demonstrated, also publicly, through their protest, which did not take place outside the borders of Austria. There are certainly also many voters who wanted to give voice to their strong desire to see a radical change of direction in Austrian politics. In my opinion, Parliament should support these democratic forces. I also call on the Austrian President to make every effort to try to form a government based on these democratic forces. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would simply like to underline the value of an attitude such as that which the chairman of our group, Francis Wurtz, mentioned a moment ago. I appreciate the statements of the Presidency of the Council and the position of the 14 countries which have refused official contacts with the Austrian Government if Jörg Haider's party were to be included. This emphasis of ours is all the more important because, as is well known, we substantially disagree with the policies pursued by this Europe: with its economic and social policies, with its democratic deficit, with the involvement of these same countries in the dramatic war in the Balkans. This disagreement underlines even more today's appreciation: an exceptional element, because the danger of a rebirth, in Europe, of an irrational and neo-Nazi component is exceptional. This danger does not concern Austria, it concerns Europe. We are talking about ourselves, not Austria. We know the social causes which, with unemployment and uncertainty, contribute to fuelling tendencies in that direction; we know the cultural causes - xenophobic, racist - but we cannot fail to point out in the inability and unwillingness of these far-right forces to come to terms with Nazism, the possibility of building an explosive mixture in Europe. He speaks of the Alpine arc, he speaks of all our countries: conditions are being created in which a danger to democracy and European civilisation can be reborn. The position taken by the Presidency has shown itself to be aware of this civilisational drama. Europe shows that it has not forgotten Auschwitz; Europe encounters a soul. Now, however, it should be consistent in its actions, and the first to be consistent should be the Commission which, instead, has demonstrated here an opacity and a lability that make the value of the position of the Presidency even more evident. This is the correction that must be imposed on the Commission's action. Madam President, colleagues, in the fundamental democratic principle of respect for human rights and the freedom and sovereignty of peoples, against any new or old fascism, Nazism or communism, and given that all the previous speakers have spoken of the sovereignty of the Austrian people, we see, today, this sovereignty denied by this very Parliament.

It is true that the problem of the timber sector is terribly complex. You have indeed spoken of releasing funds for timber storage because it must not depreciate. On the other hand, the municipalities that were not affected by the storms will also suffer losses, since the National Forestry Office has decided to freeze logging for four years. So these municipalities that have not suffered losses will still see their revenues decrease. All this to tell you that the problem is eminently complex and I thank the Commission again for pushing the analysis of this situation as far as possible. I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that there is, of course, an economic disaster, but that the real ecological disasters are still to come. You said it yourself, Commissioner, these disasters, these storms are not always natural and we believe that they are the first signs of climate change. Therefore, we must review our policies to take this fact into account. Mr. President, anyone who arrived here by car, train, or plane will have seen the extent of the damage caused, particularly in France, by the unprecedentedly violent hurricanes that struck Europe at the end of last month. Faced with a disaster of such magnitude, what can the elected members of the European Parliament do? First of all, I would like to pay tribute to all my fellow mayors and local elected officials who, on a daily basis, have had to reassure the population, organize solidarity, and cooperate with public services. They have earned the trust of their fellow citizens. I would also like to thank the emergency services and armed forces of the EU Member States who, as part of exemplary intergovernmental cooperation, have come to support the efforts of their French colleagues. I would also like to reflect on the paradoxical situation in which we find ourselves with regard to emergency aid. If this disaster had occurred in Guatemala or Turkey, we could have immediately used the Community budget to help the victims, but in our countries, nothing of the sort is possible due to the lack of an adequate credit line. We must also ask the Commission not to prevent local authorities and states from helping businesses affected by the disaster, in the name of an overly narrow application of Community competition rules. I am thinking in particular of the fishing and shellfish farming businesses that have been particularly hard hit. As you said, Commissioner, it must be possible to compensate for forced shutdowns and for investments that have to be completely redone to be able to call on the FIFG. Beyond that, I believe that the mechanical application of the POPs is no longer appropriate in the devastated coastal regions. I therefore ask the Commission to abandon this and, on the contrary, to help maritime professionals make the new investments that are urgently needed. Mr. President, dear colleagues, the storms that ravaged France on the night of December 26 and 27 caused, as has been said, 90 deaths and 75 billion francs, or 11 billion euros, in damage.

The Council's draft contains serious deficiencies, particularly with regard to legal protection. According to rapporteur Di Pietro, the draft contains even significant deficiencies. The Convention allows for a chain of requests for mutual legal assistance, with authorities and criminal justice systems from other Member States being assigned to each link. This chain is structured in such a way that no single judge can monitor it as a whole. Accompanying measures are needed, such as the obligation for investigating officers to appear as witnesses upon request in every criminal case in which their documents are used. My group also finds it problematic that the Council's draft disregards the principle of proportionality. In any case, the scope of application is not limited. Thus, this Convention is not only applicable to combating serious crime and organized crime. Nowhere does it even state that it refers only to criminal law. It is therefore entirely conceivable that the European Union will soon use a sledgehammer to crack a nut, and citizens' rights will vanish into thin air. Mr President, the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters, which we are discussing today, contains minimum rules that are essential for effective and rapid cooperation between the various judicial and investigative bodies. It concerns service of document, the exchange of information, the temporary transfer of detainees, the return of property, the examination of witnesses by videoconference, investigations, including so-called covert investigations, telephone tapping, and much more. That is the minimum that could be agreed upon, although it must be said straight away that if certain amendments, such as Nos 32 or 81, or Nos 70 or 71 in their revised form, were to be adopted, the Convention as a whole would amount to a mere exchange of communications or information and could really be thrown in the wastepaper basket, which is why we would vote against it. I hope that colleagues from the various political groups will use their common sense and reject these amendments. The fact that it resulted in only a convention, not a framework agreement, is also a defeat for the European Parliament. Commissioner Vitorino will surely have gathered from all the various contributions how necessary it is to create a framework of common rules, rather than continuing with this disjointed regulation, these small agreements for individual areas such as investigations and the like. Rather, it is absolutely essential to create a minimum of secure, Community-wide rules, while, of course, increasing the guarantees as much as possible—also in view of enlargement. I can only imagine what would become of this Community, of these agreements, or of legal relations if, for example, a fascist country like Turkey were to join the European Union: I would be truly perplexed. We need, as everyone has emphasized, a corpus juris and, particularly in procedural law, common rules that guarantee a common rule of law throughout the Community. It is clear that this is a matter that must primarily be addressed by the Intergovernmental Conference, and that Parliament can only make a limited contribution to this objective, since everything depends on the Council and the Commission. I believe that this first six months, with the Commissioner responsible being Portuguese and Portugal holding the Council Presidency, offer an excellent opportunity to give initial impetus to this common objective.

However, I have noted your comments and will consider them further. Mrs Roth-Behrendt asked me a question about the establishment of a positive list. This is one of the issues we are addressing in the annex to the legislation, and we intend to establish a positive list for substances intended for animal feed. At the moment, the list is, I would say, negative and is being completed as required. The establishment of a positive list is one of the issues raised in the annex and given a date, namely 2002. We have identified the rapid alert system for animal feed as a gap in the legislation. The rapid alert exists for food, not for animal feed. This is unfortunate and incorrect, and we believe it is important to highlight this, to establish legislation to close this gap, and this will be done. Work in relation to BSE within Member States and the establishment of random tests to assess infectivity levels in Member States is ongoing. I know that Mrs Roth-Behrendt has already asked me this question, and I replied that I thought it was progressing rapidly. However, I understand that the matter is at the stage of consultation between services within the Commission, and that work is currently underway. I hope that the next time you ask me, I will be able to provide you with more detailed information. Mrs Jackson highlighted the fact that there are 24 new pieces of legislation and 20 amending pieces of legislation. She also asked whether this adds to the overregulation. I would say that the pieces of legislation we have identified are intended to fill gaps in the current legislation. This is less about establishing new regimes or additional regulations, although that is part of it, than about identifying where the gaps and weak points are in the chain from stable to fork and filling them. Reference was made to the candidate countries, something we bear in mind. Food safety standards and, of course, other safety areas are obviously of crucial importance with regard to enlargement, and this is an issue to which I drew Mr Verheugen's attention. Commissioner, the ignorance of some Member States has plunged Europe into a major food crisis, and I am once again irritated, unfortunately, by the complete and repeated absence of the Council as you present this interesting report. I would really like you to tell me how you intend to ensure that this new authority, whatever its detailed name, will have influence over the Council, which will have its say within this authority, which will give the orders. It goes without saying that we cannot impose anything in terms of content, but I nevertheless insist on the fact that after Maastricht and Amsterdam, Parliament retains its right, and even develops it.

In today's debate, many words have been used that correspond to essential concepts of our time: globalization, the knowledge society, the relationship between the old economy and the new economy. All these words and the concepts underlying them can simultaneously correspond to opportunities and problems. And the imperative before us is to transform problems into opportunities and, above all, to avoid at all costs transforming opportunities into problems. Clearly, to achieve this, there are two essential issues in all spheres. First, a very strong investment in people and a crucial concept mentioned here today by so many of you: lifelong training and education are an investment in people, a crucial issue for all these issues to be transformed into opportunities for all. But, in addition to investment in people, there is also a need for regulatory capacity on the part of public authorities, whether national states, the European Union, or global authorities, to make indispensable entrepreneurial and personal initiative compatible with the conditions of social justice and equity. This is true in the sphere of globalization. Globalization is something that allows for greater increases in wealth, international trade, and productivity. But deregulated globalization, as it exists today, or globalization in which large sectors of the world's population lack a strong investment in people, is also a factor of exclusion, of division, of widening the gap between rich and poor. This is true in the knowledge society, which can provide new equality of opportunity, but it can also be a factor of increasingly clear separation between those who have access to it and those who do not, as occurs in the relationship between the old and the new economy. Furthermore, this is not the first time that a technological transition has changed the paradigm of society and the organization of the economy. And what has always happened in these moments of profound transition is that the problems of the old economy, particularly those of employment, are always resolved by resorting to the new economy and its instruments. I'll give you an example: in Europe, we have a textile industry, and we must continue to have it, but we will only have it if we can apply the technologies of the information society and the knowledge society. It is extraordinary that, at this moment, in the sectors of the so-called "new economy," there is a shortage of almost 80,000 people suitable for existing jobs, just as there are millions of unemployed. This means that we have not yet been able to use the instruments of the new economy to solve the problems of the old economy, which will never be solved with the logic of that same old economy. Finally, I would like to answer a question that has been asked of me: whether I speak here on behalf of fifteen or fourteen countries. The answer is simple: I speak on behalf of fifteen countries. And one of the things that the Portuguese Presidency has guaranteed is Austria's full participation in the functioning of all the institutions of the Union.

Mr Andersson will certainly be familiar with the phenomenon known as prohibition and also with the consequences it had for the activities of the American mafia. So much so that in the end it was decided to abolish prohibition. It is obvious that we must protect the health of the public, but not by prohibiting alcoholic beverages, because that obviously serves no purpose. Mr President, what is really at issue here is the revenue from the Swedish state monopoly on alcohol. When the Swedish Government says that it needs it to cover its health costs, it shows that we are dealing with a distortion of competition, since other countries have to finance their own health costs without having a monopoly on alcohol. My question is: are you also aware of studies which state that moderate consumption of high-quality alcoholic products such as French wine or Bavarian beer can even be healthy and that it could therefore even relieve the Swedish budget. I understand that Mr Posselt was referring to the fiscal aspects of the matter. And if I am not mistaken, the high excise duty on alcohol in Sweden dates back to 1638 and since then a large part of the state's tax revenue has come from the sale of alcohol. It is also known that there is currently a state monopoly in Sweden, which in itself is a violation of Union law. So, as far as the healing power of alcohol is concerned, that is what Mr Posselt was referring to if I understood correctly - I agree with him one hundred percent. In my opinion, a good bottle of wine can be very good for your health and in terms of social contacts it can be extremely pleasant. Perhaps Mr Posselt, Mr Andersson and I could meet up at the Parliament bar one of these days and have a glass of aquavit together. Mr President, I have followed the Commission's response with interest regarding the need to implement the Single Market legislation. I wonder if the Commissioner can tell me whether he considers his answer compatible with the fact that the Commission has not taken the French Government to the Court of Justice because of the application of the French "Loi et Vin" law which effectively prevents the application of single market legislation to the sale of alcohol in France. Can we expect the European Commission to bring an action against France before the Court of Justice? I would like to answer the Honourable Member's question very briefly, as the matter is currently before the Commission. The Commission must decide whether the matter is closed or whether it should be brought to the attention of the Court of Justice. My answer may not be satisfactory at the moment, but I would like to reassure the Honourable Member that the Commission will take a decision within a few weeks. I ask for the Honourable Member's understanding for this small delay in the Commission's decision. Commissioner, are there public health reasons which justify different tax rates, for example for Scotch whiskey rather than French Bordeaux wine or for my colleague's Bavarian beer?

The truly substantial difference concerns the charging of waste disposal costs. My colleague Bouwman has already touched on this aspect. There are two experiences in this area. The Baltic Sea experience, which is therefore not only a national experience but an experience of the entire Baltic basin, according to which, by largely including the costs of disposal in general port charges, the disposal of ships' waste at sea is no longer encouraged. Once paid, it is better to provide for waste disposal in the port. The second system is based on the pure "polluter pays" principle: ships that unload waste are required to pay an additional amount. This second system has proven ineffective, otherwise why would the Mediterranean be so dirty? Why is the North Sea so dirty? Because the "polluter pays" principle, without adequate controls, does not work! This is why a large majority in the committee - not a large majority and now the representatives of the minority opinion will speak - reiterated the thesis approved at first reading by Parliament without any conflict, namely that the best system is the no special fee system, since, in a certain sense, it offers ships an economic incentive not to throw waste into the sea and to deposit it in the appropriate port collection facilities. This is the crucial point. We are willing to reach an agreement with the Council, but up to now the Council has refused any serious agreement with us. I therefore appeal to this House to recommend the adoption of our amendment in which we ask for up to 90 percent of the costs to be covered by port charges. In this way we would have the possibility of reaching an agreement with the Council in conciliation, either on 75 percent or on another percentage. I also appeal to the Commission: Madam Vice-President, be careful which side you intend to take! I believe that, in the interests of environmental protection and of a sustainable and thriving tourism industry in many countries of the Community, an effective system is better. Please support our no special fee system, perhaps then we can reach a reasonable compromise with the Council in conciliation. Mr President, I am pleased that you are chairing this debate, because I know that, as a Bavarian, you always pay a lot of attention to issues relating to ports and the sea. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Theo Bouwman, for his work and his cooperation in preparing for tomorrow's vote. Tomorrow we will have to decide on a couple of points. Firstly, we know that the transport of people and goods by ship is the most environmentally friendly mode of transport compared to other modes of transport. At the same time, however, we also know that ships contribute significantly to marine pollution, through waste, cargo residues and sludge. Ship fuel is heavy oil and we know that 1-3 percent of this heavy oil remains in the form of sludge, which is usually discharged into the sea.

I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council, who has spent several hours in this Chamber working with the Members of the European Parliament, whether he has gained any idea of their worth in terms of remuneration. Honourable Member, as this debate on the European Parliament's fees is not exclusive to your country and even extends to my country, I have a precise idea of how much the fees of Members of the European Parliament amount to. I am therefore perfectly aware of this problem. Mr. President, I appreciate the answer. I would like to ask a complementary question that bears some similarity to Mr. Sjöstedt's. We are both Swedish. In our country, the largest tax is the municipal tax, since services are local and plentiful. There are problems related to trust in politicians, and, to a no lesser extent, in European politicians in Parliament. How do you think trust in us politicians would be affected if we were granted the right to use services in the places where we live—schools, welfare, etc.—but, at the same time, we didn't pay taxes, didn't contribute? How do you think a system of this nature would influence trust in us? This is a question, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, that I don't know if you are obliged to answer because it is truly philosophical. But if you want to delve into the realm of philosophy, go ahead! No, Mr. President, I am not tempted to enter the realm of philosophy. These are fundamental issues related to the very foundation of the status of Members and their role within the framework of political society. I do not wish to enter into that kind of debate because it seems to me that it could—to use a French expression—prejudice the interpretation that the Portuguese Presidency makes within the framework of the negotiations, in which it is immersed, on the status of Members. I would like to ask that you allow me not to make any comments in advance. As the time allocated for Question Time to the Council has expired, Questions 11 to 35 will be answered in writing. Question Time to the Council is now closed. (The sitting, adjourned at 7:05 p.m., resumes at 9:00 p.m.) Address by Mr. Vaclav Havel, President of the Czech Republic. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the European Parliament, I have the great honor of extending a warm welcome to Mr. Václav Havel, President of the Czech Republic. I would also like to extend a welcome to Mrs. Havel, who has taken a place in the gallery. Madam, you are welcome. (Applause) This is not the first time we have welcomed you to our Parliament, Mr. President. You already spoke before the House in Strasbourg in March 1994, almost six years ago, and many of us have very vivid memories of it, namely those of our colleagues who were already members at that time. Indeed, just after the Maastricht Treaty came into force, you spoke out in favor of strengthening European values, creating a European ethical dimension, and opening the Union to the countries of Central and Eastern Europe.

I am not saying that we should not increase the level of specialisation of workers in the sector - of course we should - but first we must allow jobs to be created. The availability of unskilled, temporary and seasonal work is very important in some economic sectors of the Community. Tourism contributes to regional development in rural areas that are trying to diversify and to that of urban areas that are trying to highlight the importance of their cultural heritage. Taking all these aspects together we can really do something in Europe and perhaps we can extend the tourist season by staggering holidays on our continent. We must not forget that with enlargement we will have the opportunity to increase the number of tourists coming to Europe to visit those monuments of our cultural heritage that for many years - about forty - have not been open to the public. We are losing market share, and I think something must be done to make us more competitive. So I hope you will help us. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today we are dealing with a very important sector, which directly employs more than 10 million people in the EU and which helps the more or less disadvantaged regions, as well as the most remote and island areas, to get by. Tourism creates an additional number of jobs, helping to consolidate employment, especially for the most vulnerable sections of society, namely women and young people. In the light of these data, I think that the lack of a European policy for tourism constitutes a serious contradiction. The absence of a legal basis makes it impossible to adopt measures in this sector. The occasional use of Article 308 (ex 235), which requires unanimity, has prevented the approval of a five-year programme worth ECU 8 million for all fifteen Member States. : The measures adopted sporadically in the past have been fragmented and ineffective, and their provisions have been dictated by parallel policies in the areas of, for example, consumer protection, the environment, transport, taxes, etc.; these were policies that not only did not help tourism but actually hindered it, since their application often implied a cost for the tourism sector, without any detailed consideration of how to help or encourage it. I must stress with regret that today, in the context of the restructuring of the Commission's services, tourism is only a sector - and not a directorate - within the Directorate-General for Enterprise. In my opinion, our tourism should instead be supported and the pillars for such support could be the following: adding a chapter dedicated to tourism in the revision that will give a legal basis to the sector; developing a common tourism policy that will support the sector without disrupting the functioning of the relevant market; coordination between tourism policy and other parallel common policies that directly or indirectly influence it; study of the sector and adoption of medium and long-term measures to help the competitiveness of the tourism product.

The history of the Joint Assembly clearly demonstrates a positive development in this regard. While ACP countries were previously represented at meetings by members of government, senior officials, or ambassadors, today more than three-quarters of our interlocutors are elected parliamentarians. We must celebrate when we soon reach 100% representation, as the new agreement seeks. Progress in democratization processes, which, unlike the various outbreaks of crises, occur discreetly, unfortunately goes too unnoticed. A specific element of ACP multilateral collaboration is regional cooperation and integration. This will fulfill one of the Parliament's long wish lists. The Joint Assembly will soon hold meetings at the regional level. We have already heard this. Strengthening regional cooperation can help prevent the outbreak of conflicts for ethnic, economic, social, or religious reasons; in other words, it can have a preventive effect. For the same reason, the European Parliament has promoted civil society participation in decision-making processes and the management of cooperation from the outset and has highlighted the significance of decentralized collaboration. The intensification of contacts between the Joint Assembly and the social partners, provided for in the new agreement, represents a further step in the right direction. Only a trace of sadness remains that the European Development Assistance Fund is not yet integrated into the EU budget. I hope we will not have to wait another 25 years until we achieve our goal in this regard. Mr. President, allow me to congratulate Mr. Corrie on his report. The Lomé Convention has attested to a genuine partnership between the EU and the ACP countries for more than 25 years, and the fact that it has continued despite the overwhelming pressure against it from many organizations, including the WTO, represents a true triumph. However, it is obvious that the new Convention should not be evaluated by its mere existence, but by how it can contribute to the EU's commitment to eradicating poverty and achieving international development goals. If we apply this criterion, we will realize that the new agreements have several shortcomings: for example, the agreement is quite disappointing for ACP countries that suffer short-term fluctuations in their export earnings. In December, during a marathon round of negotiations, an agreement was reached to provide aid to island, landlocked, and least-developed countries when they suffer losses of at least 2% in their export earnings, while the 10% threshold would continue to apply to other ACP countries. However, at the end of the negotiations, the EU claimed that it had never given its approval to include island and landlocked countries among the candidates deserving of aid based on the 2% threshold. This change has had devastating consequences, especially for the Windward Islands, which is possibly the only ACP country that will actually lose out under the new arrangements.

And all this must be done with the European citizen in mind. It must be done with the men and women who work and live their daily lives in our countries in mind. The extraordinary summit in Lisbon must fundamentally reconfirm in the European citizen the idea that the European Union remains faithful to a society aimed at promoting integration and social cohesion. Mr President, the Portuguese Presidency has the merit of focusing the debate on issues which, while not new, are set in a new way with courageous objectives, starting with the urgency of addressing the issue of competitive capacity based on innovation and permanent technological democratisation, given that the technological development of the United States is the result of a very dynamic private initiative but also of the military sector and a certain protectionism. It is also necessary to evaluate the case of Japan, from which Europe could draw lessons on the organisation of work, on the responsibility of the State and companies - and also of the worker himself - with regard to business objectives. We must draw inspiration from these two models for useful aspects such as entrepreneurial capacity and work organisation, maintaining the best of Europe, its social model suited to a post-industrial economy. The fact is that Europe needs 32 million jobs to reach the levels of the United States, we need an increase in female employment, the integration of marginalised groups, the strengthening of social cohesion (a problem that the Structural Funds have not yet resolved), the inclusion of five million long-term unemployed, largely due to industrial reconversions, we need new specialisations because access to technology is not a tacit guarantee of quality of employment and entrepreneurial initiative. We need greater participation and responsibility from the social partners, new actors, as stated in the Pintassilgo report, to create pacts for employment and business competitiveness. We need to resolve the problems of poverty and we need a social model suited to the new conditions. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, your proposal is courageous, although it does not depend directly on you but on the Fifteen. As regards the question of Austria, I would very much like this country to be part of the group of States that will make this proposal of yours a reality. However, if it did so, Austria would be deceiving and lying to the voters of part of its government. I hope it will do so, however! Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, the statement that we live in a globalised world is a statement that our fellow citizens, regardless of their level of education or their ideology, have heard many times. However, more rarely do we hear what the role of Europe should be in this context of the information society, globalisation and technology. I happen to think, Mr President, that this is probably because perhaps we Europeans have a perception of Europe that is sometimes a little distant from our closest concerns and interests. The first concern of European citizens, after health, is probably work.

I hope that what we have said so forcefully today will also find greater support in the Commission's documents. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, the greatest legacy the Commission could leave to the European Union would be to reorganise and redistribute the increasingly chaotic and confusing powers and competences of the Executive and perhaps of the Union itself. You have taken a courageous first step by stressing, rightly, the need to focus on so-called "core activities". As you yourself said today, this means identifying the tasks, policies and programmes that are marginal or irrelevant to the Commission's primary vocation. Many current European Union policies and programmes have probably already passed their use-by date, or have proven difficult to manage or ineffective at European level. The challenge today is to find the courage to delegate as many non-core activities as possible to a lower level of government, be it national, regional or local. If we are to convince the sceptical European public of the merits of further European integration, we must be able to demonstrate that we are as committed to the downward delegation of unjustified European competences as we are to the granting of new powers to the European Union. We must not allow the critics of European integration to argue, as they do now with some justification - we have heard this from Mr Bonde - that the proliferation of Community responsibilities is a one-way street. We must demonstrate that it is a two-way process, in which Union policies and programmes that are not fully justified on the basis of subsidiarity and proportionality are being delegated and abandoned. If we can match these aspirations with concrete action in the coming years, we will make an unprecedented contribution to the future of the European Union as a whole, and, as we have heard today, you will benefit from a broad consensus in this Parliament. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, I fully support the logic of the proposals by my colleague Heidi Hautala regarding the strategic objectives of the Commission for the next five years. For my part, I will speak on a subject that has not been addressed, although it was foreseen, namely the Commission's work programme for the year 2000. I am aware of the limitations of the operation: working within the framework of the Treaty in force, we must abide by its rules. I am thinking in particular of an important subject, namely the fiscal issue, but I do not want to talk about fiscal aspects. Instead, I will begin by welcoming some of the proposals in the programme for the year 2000. I am thinking of all the ambitious and important proposals on food safety and also on shipping safety, following the two oil spills that hit the coasts of Brittany and Turkey. It is good that the Commission is reacting quickly on this. On the other hand, in other areas I believe that we could be more ambitious and move forward more quickly. I would like to put forward a series of positive proposals regarding, for example, social issues, the environment and the follow-up to Seattle.

Among the most vulnerable, it is important that I speak on this point, are migrants and refugees. Thus, the almost systematic conditions of detention and the criminalization of asylum seekers are no longer acceptable. Every asylum seeker must have the right to a fair hearing and an appeal with suspensive effect. Last week, somewhat by chance, I witnessed at Roissy-en-France airport a scene of unusual violence in which two young women, undoubtedly clandestine, were returned to Conakry. They were treated like the worst criminals. They were naked, dragged along the ground by their hair, and escorted by a horde of CRS (Refugee Refugees). The Portuguese Presidency must put an end to this kind of barbaric acts. Our role, on the contrary, is to accompany, reassure, and assist those fleeing dictatorships. The Commission proposed the creation of a European refugee fund. Parliament was very much in favor of it. Instead of vacillating over the budget allocated to this fund, I believe you can decide to implement it. The Presidency and the Council can implement what was incomprehensibly rejected in Tampere, even though Tampere constituted an important base. Similarly, we cannot be content with observing the rise of xenophobic currents in Europe, the trivialization of discrimination, without adopting significant measures. Harmonization of anti-racism legislation is essential. What meaning do you intend to give to Article 13 of the Treaty? What do you intend to do to promote equal treatment in pay between men and women? How do you hope to work towards the eradication of homophobia, racism, and sexism? We must take the best of what is already being done in each of the countries of the Union. When six European countries grant the right to vote, their president can afford to extend that right to vote and eligibility in municipal and European elections to all non-EU citizens who have resided in European territory for more than five years. Thus, the regularization of undocumented immigrants in some countries, including yours, must become an example for others, since these undocumented immigrants currently constitute a mass of people weakened by the merchants of dreams and a workforce subject to personal services and economic exploitation that turns them into modern-day slaves. More generally, this Presidency must initiate a change in the behavior and relationships of our fellow citizens with minorities and immigrants. Immigration is too often synonymous with insecurity and violence, and the responses are purely repressive. How do you intend to make our fellow citizens understand that today, as always, immigration is a source of social and cultural wealth, whose role is and will continue to be indispensable in the demographic context we know today? What action is necessary to take to enhance the place of immigrants in our society and guarantee genuine protection for asylum seekers? Mr. President, there is a great lack of transparency in the areas of security, freedom, and justice. The European Union is an economic marvel, but we are in no position to pontificate when it comes to the treatment of refugees. The level of racism in our society is terrifying.

We would, however, like to stress the essential need to adopt the strategy for the new millennium as soon as possible, which will give new impetus and continuity to the work carried out under the previous action plan. Furthermore, in the area of judicial cooperation, important progress has been made on the euro's criminal law protection, and a framework decision of fundamental and strategic importance is currently being discussed in the European Parliament. We believe that, in order to be credible, the euro's criminal law protection requires that we avoid a proliferation of instruments and, therefore, make a joint effort to be able to adopt a single instrument in March covering all the issues to be addressed, both those consisting of initiatives already presented by France and those whose adoption the Commission itself has expressly identified as necessary. In this area, it is important that measures for the mutual recognition of judicial decisions be implemented, and we believe that, thanks to the work already done, steps towards the mutual recognition of decisions will soon be taken, at least in the area of the seizure of goods. Finally, with regard to Europol, which only began its effective work in 1999 and prompted the Council to adopt a series of instruments, known to Parliament, to enable it to operate, a fundamental question still remains, relating to the democratic and judicial control of Europol. These issues are, of course, given a new dimension by the political option adopted at Tampere to broaden Europol's remit and, above all, to give it an operational dimension. The French Presidency has submitted to us an important working document setting out various scenarios for discussing and resolving the issues of democratic and judicial control of Europol. The Portuguese Presidency will take the initiative to present a working document on the Eurojust network shortly. Although it is clearly not necessary for judicial oversight of Europol to be carried out through Eurojust, it cannot currently be ruled out that this may become an alternative course of action in the future. Therefore, it is now particularly important that the Council debate on the development of Europol and Eurojust take place simultaneously, so that the appropriate conclusions can be reached simultaneously. I believe that in this area, and in the dialogue that the Council and Parliament must inevitably have on the development of Europol and Eurojust, we have the opportunity to find an institutionally acceptable solution for relations between the Council and Parliament in relation to Europol. We know Parliament's positions and we know that Parliament knows the positions of the Council's legal services. By resolving the issue of democratic oversight of Europol, I believe that this problem will find a definitive solution, and also a solution that mobilizes and strengthens interinstitutional cooperation between all. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, members of the Council, I must first say that, without wishing to compete emotionally with the Ministers, I am not moved but confused by having, for the first time, two personal friends in the Presidency, and I sincerely hope that this does not undermine the separation of powers, which is essential to the functioning of our Union.

The road has been very long, especially due to the legal problem that arose regarding the extent to which the Community could be considered to have full jurisdiction over intellectual property issues. This problem has been overcome. Today, we must essentially give our assent to two treaties: the Intellectual Property Treaty and the Treaty on Performances and Phonograms. Regarding the former, it appears to effectively resolve the claims of authors of artistic and literary works, while creating the framework for protection in matters of distribution, rental, and presentation of their works to the public. Regarding the latter treaty on performances and phonograms, we must emphasize that for the first time, the exclusive rights of performers and artists for production, distribution, and rental to the public, as well as the right to fair remuneration for broadcasting, are recognized by an international treaty, also signed by the Community. Within this framework, it is worth noting the great progress that the treaty represents in the area of the right of reproduction. Although, as the Commission points out, the treaty texts do not contain special provisions regulating all the additional issues that arise with technological development, it can nevertheless be stated that within this legislative framework being created, performers enjoy broader protection than that derived from the Treaty of Rome or even from Community directives. An interpretation of Article 7 of the Treaty leads us to the conclusion that the application of protection against reproduction does not only mean protection against the reproduction of the performances themselves or of the performances incorporated into phonograms, but also protection against copying, whether partial or total, permanent or ephemeral, as well as protection of all types of production. However, it would be useful to address some points that should be the focus of future work at WIPO or other diplomatic conferences. First, this concerns the right of distribution, as referred to in Article 8, paragraph 1. The possibility given to States, from the next section of the same article, to regulate the exercise of the aforementioned right is dangerous and constitutes one of the most negative aspects of the Treaty, since there is nothing to prevent Member States from approving special conditions for exercising this right, something that will have negative consequences for artists. Regarding the right of rental, the interpretation of Article 9 leads us to the conclusion that only artists or performers enjoy the exclusive right of rental, as long as it is provided for in national legislation, and I believe there is a difference here compared to Article 13. Finally, I would like to say that the ratification of these treaties opens horizons for the right of property. For the 21st century, the century of knowledge and the intangible economy, intellectual property will be a fundamental form of property and, in many cases, more important than traditional property.

Mr. President, the place of women in politics is an important issue that deserves better than the politically correct overtaking we are witnessing. Undoubtedly, not many women participate in politics. It is not true that the predominance of men in party apparatuses is the only reason that should be invoked. In France, 95% of those elected are city councilors. Most of them are not affiliated with any party. In departmental bodies, the first party in France is that of those elected without a label, those who represent various parties of the left or right. To be elected as a local councilor, it is enough to want to be elected, and the possibility of assuming national responsibilities often depends on the establishment offered by these mandates. Our Group wishes to promote fair representation of men and women in the bodies of the European Union. That is why we reject the policy of quotas and positive discrimination, whether expressed in favor of women or even so-called social minorities. Minority politics, by downplaying the profound unity of the human family in favor of establishing superficial divisions, dangerously threatens the cohesion of society and the balance of our democratic model. On the one hand, if we establish quotas for women, why wouldn't we also establish quotas based on age or ethnicity—quotas for Catholics, workers, or people who wear glasses? Applying social quotas for the most modest categories would be no more absurd than creating quotas for women. With this philosophy, it would no longer be necessary to organize elections or administrative competitions. It would be enough to determine the composition of ministries and chambers through statistical calculations. Quota politics can only increase voters' lack of interest in politics and give them the impression that everything happens behind their backs. On the other hand, this policy demonstrates a profound contempt for women. It is not through the mechanical game of a certain quota that women should access political or administrative functions, but through the recognition of their own merit and skills. Ladies, would you have so little pride as to be willing to hold a ministerial portfolio or a parliamentary sash for the mathematical contingency of a quota? Women are worth much more than a quota. It is by restoring the principle of "meritocracy" that we will improve the quantity and quality of women's presence in the decision-making process. I would like to thank the Minister and the Commissioner for their interventions and the important statements they made before the European Parliament on such a crucial issue as the one we are debating today. The presence of women in decision-making positions is above all a matter of democracy. All citizens, men and women, need to recognize themselves and feel truly represented by their elected officials and their leaders.

For this reason, we warmly welcome these programs. I would like to refer to the positions of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs regarding the largest of the Community initiatives, namely INTERREG III. It is essential that a considerable number of social measures also be promoted within the framework of INTERREG III. Given the fact that 50% of unemployment in the Union is structurally determined, and given the particularly sensitive situation in border territories—I wish to refer only to possible unwanted migratory movements—this is not only reasonable but also imperative. However, the measures that can be promoted and are mentioned in Annex II of Guideline A seem to hold much promise in this regard. However, the Commission communication completely lacks instructions to the Member States containing these integrated approaches to aspects of social and employment policy. For this reason, I would like to pay special attention to the gradual adoption of vocational training measures, especially in areas affected by high levels of long-term and youth unemployment. Guideline B should also be open to employment policy promotion measures, especially in connection with the introductory strategy for the candidates for accession. With regard to employment policy measures, I believe it is generally necessary to establish the Joint Cooperation Committee at the regional level, because only at the regional level are there the experience and familiarity that are precisely necessary for these measures, so that they do not fade into something abstract. We can always criticize the fact that INTERREG—as I also believe—still remains excessive in terms of administrative burden, but we must always criticize it, although this seems almost inevitable to me in the case of the Commission's promotion programs. However, I would like to point out that this is fatal precisely here. For employment policy, we should strive for the simplest possible measures so that the social dimension in this EU regains its rightful importance. Mr. President, the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism considered, among other things, the report on LEADER+ and, in this regard, agreed to support the decentralization process in the management of actions, considering that such a process can be effective if two conditions are met: that local action groups are representative of the general interests of the local community and that the Commission's oversight mechanisms are used to prevent territorial and local political authorities from using LEADER+ resources to maintain civil organizations and groups linked to those powers. It is requested that equal representation of three components be guaranteed in the decision-making bodies of the projects: political representatives and public administrations, businesses and economic operators, and social actors, including trade unions and non-governmental organizations. It is especially emphasized that, in all these bodies, there must be a balanced representation of men and women.

It is for this reason that the Commission presented a proposal for a directive on the information and consultation of workers in November 1998. We thank Parliament for its support for this proposal since then. Unfortunately, more than a year after the proposal was presented, the other branch of the legislative branch, the Council, has still not started work on this proposal. I hope that this debate will help to remind Member States of the importance and urgency of this initiative. We recently heard the Portuguese Presidency state that a serious debate would soon be launched on this proposal. The next Presidency, which will be held by France, also seems willing to give this dossier the priority it deserves. The Commission sincerely hopes that Parliament and the Council will quickly finalize this important dossier, which, in its view, constitutes the most effective response to the concerns raised by cases such as the one that brings us here today. As regards the involvement of employees at transnational level, there are some indications of at least one case of infringement of transnational consultation and information agreements between companies and the European workforce. It may be that the companies concerned have taken advantage of certain ambiguities in the existing legal and contractual framework. The Commission will contact the relevant national authorities to determine the outcome. In any case, I would like to inform anyone who believes their rights have been violated that they have adequate means of enforcement and redress, including through the relevant national courts. The Commission has heard Parliament's call for an immediate review of the European Works Councils Directive. As indicated in the report it will adopt in the coming weeks, the Commission accepts that the directive has certain shortcomings. However, as my colleague, Commissioner Diamantopoulou, has already pointed out on various other occasions, the decision whether or not to revise a directive immediately is not an easy one. It depends on several considerations. First, a revision of the Directive would have little immediate effect on existing agreements, unless the fundamental principle of respecting party autonomy ceased to apply. Second, an immediate revision would risk delaying progress on other pending dossiers in this area, such as the European public limited company and the proposal on national information and consultation. The success of these other dossiers could greatly facilitate the subsequent revision of the EWC Directive and even provide some possible solutions to the problems identified above. Therefore, the Commission believes that it would be better, in this context, to proceed with the revision of the European Works Council Directive after these two other dossiers have been completed and after a more thorough assessment of the application of the Directive. The review does not stop at legislation alone. To encourage and support dialogue as a cornerstone of successful change, the Commission is putting into practice the recommendations of the Lillehammer report by preparing the creation of a European observatory of industrial change.

The neighborhoods where these people live should benefit from these projects. If we succeed in doing this by defining three priorities, then I believe that these families, these people, these European citizens will believe more in Europe, and that is ultimately crucial, because cities are playing an increasingly large role in European life.
