Mr President, before my colleagues Franz Fischler and Anna Diamantopoulou have their say—after all, all three of us responsible for these four Community initiatives have had the opportunity to follow the debate with equal attention—I would like to turn to URBAN and INTERREG. Many of you have raised this issue and expressed your views on it. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs of the committees, all the committees, but also the speakers from the political groups and each and every one of you for the quality of their contributions and the interest they express in these two initiatives. This applies in particular to Mrs Arlene McCarthy's comments on URBAN, and I would like to thank her not only for her work and the report she has presented, but also - and why not mention this too - for what we owe her, what you owe her with regard to this initiative, as well as for what we owe your Parliament in general. I shall not forget that the European Parliament voted and wished to maintain this initiative to regenerate urban areas in crisis and to promote sustainable urban development, which also includes the integrated approach to tackling economic, social and environmental problems that we favour. There is also agreement, as Mrs Arlene McCarthy set out in her report, on the effectiveness of this instrument, resulting from the financial concentration and critical mass of interventions; on the horizontal mechanism, which we believe is particularly suitable for disseminating results and intensifying the exchange of experience and good practice; and, finally, on the growing role of local authorities in the preparation and implementation of programmes on the basis of a solid partnership. After reminding you of the similarities between the Commission's proposals and those of your Parliament and expressing the interest with which I have followed the contributions, I would like to respond to some of the criticisms and suggestions that have been made, apologising in advance for not being able to mention every speaker personally. However, I am sure that everyone will recognise what I have said. I should first like to refer to the URBAN programme and its ceiling of 50 towns, which some of you have described as arbitrary. I understand your concerns. I have therefore instructed my departments to prepare for a reasonable increase in the number of cities eligible for URBAN funding. This requires certain guarantees regarding concentration – I am thinking here in particular of intervention areas with at least 20,000 inhabitants, and in exceptional cases, more than 10,000 – and critical financial mass. We must maintain the level of €500 per inhabitant so that the European Union's intervention is both effective and visible, and not perceived as a scattergun approach that citizens and municipalities can no longer understand.

To ask for greater appropriations for this element in these conditions, as paragraph 20 does, contributes to the irresponsible and ideological budgetary excesses to which this House is accustomed. Finally, we note the desire expressed both in the Commission document and in the report by Mrs Decourrière to use INTERREG for peace and reconstruction in the Balkans: I do not believe that the Structural Funds should be used to repair the damage inflicted by the Americans on Serbia during the criminal and ineffective bombing. It should be up to Washington, and not us, to assume responsibility for a conflict unleashed to serve its own interests alone. For these reasons, the French delegation in our group was unable to support the Decourrière report, choosing to abstain at the time of the final vote. Procacci report (A5-0025/2000) Mr President, I voted in favour of the Procacci report on rural development, not only because I agree with the LEADER programme in its most important aspects but also because it is the other side of the URBAN programme, which we spoke about earlier. Just as older people in cities are very lonely, older people in rural areas are becoming the only population, because young people are going to the city: they are fascinated by the lights, by the pubs too, and the countryside and rural areas remain empty. I therefore believe it is very important that this European Union project should find universal support and be further strengthened. The LEADER + Community initiative, while giving continuity to the previous ones, has some special features. Firstly, the reduction of around half of the funds available, although the period is longer. In the meantime, new objectives have been included, notably the financing of the Natura 2000 network and all rural regions become eligible. Although this Community initiative is aimed at rural development, it is unacceptable that it does not address agriculture and agricultural production in a coherent manner. Without agriculture, the rural world does not exist and consequently any rural development strategy must be based on the endogenous potential of agriculture while increasing other activities, upstream and downstream, to avoid the desertification of the rural world. For this reason, we considered it essential to improve the relationship with the proposals we have presented to expressly include agricultural activity and farmers in the rural development strategy, to request an increase in funding in order not to jeopardise the continuation of the programme in the rural regions previously covered and to argue that the new programme must continue to give priority to the most disadvantaged regions. Our position on LEADER is the result of our general assessment of the overall agricultural policy conducted by the Union. Both LEADER 1 and LEADER 2, applied in the 1990s, were an essential component of the new CAP resulting from the 1992 reform and, together with other individual measures, constituted the so-called second pillar of the rural development policy implemented by the Union. Their real objective was to alleviate and conceal the disastrous consequences of the new CAP, as well as to disorientate small and medium-sized farmers, and certainly not to develop rural areas and maintain the agricultural population there, as was instead hypocritically proclaimed among the objectives of these programmes.

However, I would like to warn you against the illusion that the inconsistency is the product of some kind of mechanical deficiency in the system. It may be, but that inconsistency is only a small part of what we are discussing now. Most of these inconsistencies have to do with known and well-established differences in interests between men and women, etc., and therein lies the problem. Mr. Mulder has said that no farmer will start producing anything whose price is too low. That is true for our part of the world, but our partners and beneficiaries in Africa have a slightly different perspective. In those countries, farming is not just for earning a living, but for living, and that is the difference. Subsistence farming is not based on any price calculations; it is based on the hope that it will rain during the next season. That does not apply to all agriculture in developing countries but to an agriculture aimed at reducing poverty, in which we must intervene more and better than we have done so far. From that perspective, what I'm saying is very pertinent. Other issues have been mentioned: livestock in Namibia, tomatoes, and powdered milk in the Caribbean. Let's not be excessively masochistic. There's a limit to the usefulness of everything. All the cases mentioned are characterized by the fact that we have addressed them. Intervention prices have been regulated, and the problems we had with cattle in West Africa and Namibia were resolved by reducing support for intervention. These were real problems, but we have resolved them all. As for the issue of cocoa, or chocolate, I repeat that 5% of it has to do with creating a livelihood in neighboring countries. What we're talking about are local cocoa nuts, which are as important to the people who harvest them to earn a living in Burkina Faso as coconuts are to farmers in Ghana. This isn't a clear case of inconsistency; it's more a case of competition between suppliers. What has been said about sugar in the Caribbean is more complicated. Within the framework of overseas countries and territories, the accumulation of some of these trade aspects represents a complicated problem, but it may well be that what we are mentioning here has more to do with promoting the interests of some European companies than with generating income in the Caribbean. Be that as it may, this is an issue we are addressing. I have undertaken to try to create the right balance in all these issues, and I will allow myself to mention the achievement of the trade cooperation and development agreement with South Africa. I will say, in all modesty, that this example is something that indicates that the Commission is prepared to make an additional effort to achieve coherence between the perspective of development cooperation and the perspective of commercial interests. There is no doubt that we have done everything necessary to resolve this problem, and I sincerely hope that we will now have a period of tranquility and peaceful implementation of that agreement in the coming years.

And this requires generating a growth dynamic that guarantees, for the European Union as a whole, a sustained average annual growth rate of at least 3%. I therefore believe it is necessary to stimulate a culture of dynamism and entrepreneurial initiative and a culture of strengthening social cohesion. All of this is absolutely necessary: technological change and institutional reforms. If it is necessary to learn more quickly from good practices, it is also necessary to create new, appropriate practices and innovate in terms of political methodology. And Europe, of course, today has the organized institutional processes to develop these policies, to achieve an economy and, above all, a society based on innovation and knowledge, through the design of a European policy for the information and knowledge society, the construction of a European-wide educational society, and the development of a European science and technology area open to the world. In conclusion, Mr. President, we must guarantee a combination of policies that boost growth and employment, ensure macroeconomic stability, and the consolidation of the euro. that foster growth and the transition towards a society and economy of innovation and knowledge. Through the role of structural policies and reforms, serving citizens, we will have a closer Europe and, of course, a stronger Europe. Mr. President, I would like to join in all the congratulations on the ambitions of the Portuguese Presidency at this extraordinary Summit. I particularly welcome the intention to achieve real coordination of socioeconomic policy in all its scope. However, I would like to ask for attention to three specific points. The first point is the issue of corporate governance. The Portuguese Presidency has explicitly put the social dimension of innovation on the agenda, but it seems to me that this dimension is too far removed from the intentions regarding the promotion of new businesses. In my opinion, this social dimension must be integrated into this new European business, whether it is a large multinational or one of these small ICT start-ups. Therefore, I would like to reopen the debate on corporate governance, focusing on the broader concept of the company as a "stakeholder society," including the role of the social partners and all those involved. On the last page of the Presidency document, I find the proposal to launch an "observatory for industrial change." I predict a significant role for such an observatory and would like to see this pursued vigorously. I would like to ask UNICE, the European employers' organization, to show a little more commitment and enthusiasm in this regard. I was annoyed that in their documents for this Summit, they mainly presented lists of demands on the administrations but failed to highlight their own commitment and their role in the entire process. I think we need to give it a try: they should collaborate with these activities. Another point I would like to mention briefly is fiscal coordination, because I don't think I have time to address all three.

However, before the opening of debates or when the session is suspended, there is nothing to stop you from drawing back the curtain to admire for a moment, free of charge, the magnificent spectacle that apparently lies behind it. I am pleased that the House is illuminated by the richness of the debates, but in my opinion it would be even better if, from time to time, the sun could shine directly on the Chamber. It would therefore be appreciated if you could check with the ushers whether it is possible to open the curtain from time to time. Thank you, Mr President. I am grateful for any suggestions aimed at making our meeting room more liveable. I would like to make the following proposal: for the time being, let us continue the work in the room as it is. In the meantime, we will check whether this is technically feasible. If so, we will do a half-hour test to see what effect it has on the President against the light. OICVM Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I trust that Parliament is ready to take a decision today that will strengthen the European financial market. As a new Member of the European Parliament, I found it extremely interesting and instructive to take on the responsibility of such an important issue. I would particularly like to thank my colleagues on the committee for their willingness to compromise, for the attention shown by the Chair and the Bureau to the complexity of the matter, for the good contacts established with the Commission, not least with the Commissioner, and with the Council, and for the dedicated work carried out by the secretariat of the parliamentary committee. The degree of agreement in the committee was remarkable, except on one point for which I am confident that a solution can be found. The issue of UCITS can be considered technically complex and politically risky. I think that some people do not even know the meaning of this acronym. But let me make it clear that this is an issue that really concerns the European citizen, because it concerns the way in which their savings are managed, the options available, the ways in which countries compete for different forms of savings, the needs of savers in terms of security and the opportunities for European citizens to save wisely in preparation for old age. These are all issues that require a careful balance between the need for liberalisation for a better market and higher returns on the one hand, and the need for investor protection and security on the other. During the 1980s, most European markets underwent a drastic process of deregulation. This resulted in the rapid development of national money and bond markets over a period of several years. Collective investment funds have become an alternative to bank savings. In my country, over 60 percent of Swedes have placed their savings in funds of one kind or another. Managed savings provide a certain level of security precisely because of the size of the investments made by the funds. The capital and investment securities market has continued to expand and the UCITS Directive currently in force has become outdated and no longer up to date.

In my view, this assessment should be contrasted with a picture of economic stagnation and low growth - equal, for the 1990s, to only 1.9 percent per year, despite some peaks that we have not been able to consolidate. Consequently, if we do not want to relive the failures of the past, we must take advantage of the current situation to improve economic performance and promote a new policy of transition towards higher levels of growth for our economy. This is the challenge that awaits us. In this respect, the Commission has essentially suggested that we stick to our past positions in relation to economic policy, limiting ourselves to establishing the fundamental fiscal and monetary principles for our economy, looking with confidence to the markets and hoping for a miracle from them without foreseeing further intervention by conscious social actors. In Europe, according to the rapporteur, this is precisely the attitude that has made us fail in the past - and not just once, but repeatedly - and entails the risks of downsizing that the ECOFIN Council is currently discussing. These risks include the correction of the US economy and the future path of oil prices and long-term interest rates in the Union. If one of these risks materializes, how will we respond? With more liberalism or better preparedness than when the last downturn occurred? My proposal asked Parliament to suggest an active economic policy in two ways. On the one hand, it recommended taking the Commission's excellent econometric analysis and asking the Council to turn it into an action plan with some quantifiable and interconnected targets for employment and economic growth, targets that would transform our commitment into an operational and credible full employment policy. One of the cornerstones of this plan was to increase the level of investment in capital creation from 19 percent - the level reached over the last decade - to at least 23-24 percent of GDP, both in the public and private sectors. In order to allow the public sector to take the lead in investment policy, the Council would have to sacrifice some of its most sacred cows. It should have revised its negative attitude towards the large trans-European network infrastructure programmes that have been gathering dust in drawers for too long, allowed these programmes to be adequately financed through EU bonds, and accepted an interpretation of the concept of budget deficit that would allow governments to borrow for investment without falling victim to the restrictions of the Stability Pact. This was the first key aspect of my proposal. The second aspect was to embrace a large number of proposals for structural reform, privatisation and deregulation and to facilitate the transition to a knowledge-based economy which, as we know, is the cornerstone of the Presidency's proposals for the Lisbon Summit. Experts have repeatedly said that the structural reform plan in conjunction with an expansion programme of investment and growth could awaken the European economy from its state of inertia, while unilateral policies are doomed to fail.

There are also very concrete issues at stake, such as transport capacities. These things must be coordinated more quickly within the European Union. Another example: the large-scale cattle slaughter in Mongolia. We know that funds are available in the European Union through the TACIS and ECHO programs. But why aren't we helping? Because there are too many bureaucratic obstacles. The European Union's external representation must better reflect our need for a stronger future European foreign policy. In short, operational implementation is paramount. Relations with Russia are of utmost importance. We must not let the criticism of Russia's Chechnya policy expressed in the Council of Europe be overlooked. To our extreme regret, we must note that press freedom is not yet guaranteed in Russia. We invited the journalist Babitsky to visit us next Thursday, but the Russian authorities are not allowing him to leave. I hope the European Commission will lodge a vigorous protest with the Russian authorities about this. Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, when a parliament debates priorities in the legislative process, everything becomes a priority. For me, the most important priorities are employment and thus economic growth, as well as quality of life and thus environmental protection, food safety, and consumer rights. I would now like to make a few comments on the economic and social sphere. One of the Commission's high-priority initiatives is the e-Europe initiative. Yesterday, we debated the Lisbon Summit on the economic and social renewal of Europe. I emphatically called for common growth targets so that we can achieve full employment. Full employment does not mean the complete end of all forms of unemployment; there will always be cyclical unemployment, workers looking to change jobs, and young people looking for their first job. However, full employment will be achieved when there are no longer any long-term unemployed, when every young person is offered at least one training opportunity six months after entering the labor market. This is possible if we invest more in what Mr. Guterres yesterday called "human capital," that is, in basic education and, above all, in lifelong learning. In this context, the e-Europe initiative comes at just the right time. In the future, jobs will increasingly have an IT component. But we, as in the United States, lack specialists in this field. Therefore, the US Senate has approved the issuance of a total of 500,000 visas for highly qualified foreign workers over a four-year period. We must train our own specialists and ensure that they stay in Europe. A Commission document found that half of the young graduates who complete postgraduate studies in the United States end up staying there. To retain our specialists here, to attract the best specialists, and to train more, we must invest massively in research and development. The only two countries that invest a larger share of their GDP in research and development than the US, Finland and Sweden, are also the only two European countries that can compete with the Americans in communications technologies. That would be an example for other European countries to follow!

How can we explain to workers who are victims of the rationalizations of global Monopoly that they must be prepared to change jobs several times in their working lives, when the great business leaders, having lost the windfall of a takeover, leave with a €30 million severance package? For years, we have been told that it is necessary to liberalize the economy. In liberalized sectors, we are witnessing an avalanche of mergers and acquisitions that inevitably leads to monopolistic situations. All these stock market battles are built on nothing more than anticipated profit growth of 15%, 20%, 25%—in other words, levels that are unrealistic in their longevity. The uncontrolled increase in financial and real estate assets means that risks are also on the rise. The main risk facing us in the medium term is not inflation, but deflation caused by a collapse of speculative bubbles in the international financial markets. I conclude, Madam President, by saying that the next five years will be crucial. New rules for globalization are needed; investments in the real economy, in humanity, are needed; the visible hand of the States, the visible hand of the Commission, must guarantee the social dimension of the market economy. Madam President, Mr. President of the Commission, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, the strategic program presents, in my view, two obvious weaknesses. It is pointless to draft a new economic and social program without having exhausted the old one. Specifically, I am referring to transport policy or regional policy. In both areas, you have excellent Commissioners in the persons of Mrs. Palacio and Mr. Barnier, yet you still give them too little importance in your strategic document. Why do I say this? In the case of transport policy, it is crucial that it be defined at the level of the European Union with a rational approach from an economic and environmental policy perspective, and this must be done before the accession of new states. If the President of the Commission would listen to me, I would be very grateful, but I can see that I will have to resign myself. I will give you three examples. First, we need reasonable liberalization of the railway sector, since we want to shift freight transport from road to rail. This makes sense from an economic and environmental policy perspective. Without liberalization, it will not be possible to make progress in developing a reasonable transport policy. The same can be said in relation to the area of air safety in Europe. Citizens cannot understand why we liberalize air transport, but instead keep airspace divided into 15 different sectors, controlled at the national level, with the resulting economic disadvantages for airlines and environmental pollution. In this regard, you still have work to do. Commissioner, regional policy is too little mentioned in your document. The social and economic cohesion of the EU is a crucial task for the Community. If we fail to fulfill it, citizens in disadvantaged regions will fear enlargement. We must make it clear to them that over the next five years we will promote their outreach to the wealthier regions, allocating reasonable resources to support disadvantaged regions.

There remains the fixed point. The fixed point is the means. Well, you are standing here before a Parliament some of whose members still remember what I would call the White Paper syndrome—that is, that magnificent initiative by Jacques Delors that was thwarted by the accountants of the Ecofin Council. We don't want the same misfortune to befall you today, because the project you are proposing is so promising that it can provide impetus and offer Europe the future perspective demanded by our colleague Goebbels. However, you need the necessary means to do this, which I fear you are somewhat lacking today. Your task, therefore, is to raise the necessary resources, which, however, will not be possible within the narrow framework of Agenda 2000. Your colleagues will therefore have to be persuaded to provide funding for the proposals you will put forward. One example among many—and this is one of the important measures you have proposed—concerns the information and knowledge society. Without a doubt—and you've explained this clearly—the social divide is a fundamental problem we must combat. This must not be compounded by what I would call the digital divide. Who do you intend to offer this information and knowledge society to? An increasingly older or aging population, a population that remains poor despite everything, and, unfortunately, a population that is increasingly less well-educated? Therefore, we must start at the grassroots level if this knowledge society is not to be limited to the profit-seeking of a few successful start-ups, which are certainly necessary. But that is probably not your goal. Unfortunately, one area is missing from your program: public services. Public services have played a fundamental role in the history of our European social model. While we no longer live in the era of monopolies, the Commission has initiated a process of liberalizing several public sectors, opening them up to competition in order to modernize and make them more efficient. However, we cannot stop there. What is now needed is a more precise definition of the future, in this context of competition and the information society, of the most important public service tasks to be performed by both public and private companies in this sector. In this regard, more sustainable measures are needed, which are not yet included in the Commission's work programme, but which you could initiate. I believe this would send an extremely important signal. This knowledge-based society is ultimately based on research and development, and I would like to take this opportunity to welcome the Commission's initiative to create a European Research Area. However, the Commission and Parliament need the Council to provide this European Research Area with the necessary resources. The Framework Programme is not sufficient; it must be further resourced and its main objectives modified. This is certainly a major task, but we are counting on you. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President-in-Office of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, you have spoken of a political deficit.

The restructuring of companies is part of the principle of free determination of investments, and must therefore be defended. However, events that are clearly in contrast with these principles are increasingly occurring. Among these today is a case that, at first glance, may seem sectoral and insignificant in scope but which, if allowed to pass without any authoritative intervention by the European Union, will become an unwritten rule that will cause difficulties for many Member States and the Union as a whole. An American company - Goodyear - with production sites in Italy, Germany, England, is, from its point of view legitimately, reviewing its production and relocation. It is doing so, however, perhaps, not respecting the Community rules on the matter: certainly, not giving reasonable notice and not taking care of the obligation to account for the use of public funding, both Italian and European. In Italy, Commissioner Liikanen, Goodyear is not proceeding with restructuring, but with closing a plant that, with its production, covers 14 percent of the market and that Goodyear itself has defined as "with the highest qualification of its workers", a plant that was opened by investing European money for a total of 85 million euros. Closure without warning, therefore, and without any desire to discuss the fate of the plant and its workers, despite the fact that with the public funds used in that plant there is little that is private and much that is public. It would be serious if every non-European company learned, in fact, to use Europe like a bus, where you don't pay for the ticket, you don't pay for the collaboration, you cash in for having used the vehicle and you leave without having to answer to anyone. Europe must guarantee freedom in all its forms, including that of using one's own money for one's own purposes of freedom, not to have it used by others at will, others who claim to cash in and refuse to discuss, at the time of divorce, even on the terms of divorce, while keeping in mind that this is a unilaterally declared divorce. Commissioner Liikanen spoke earlier of restructuring that must not be done in an ignorant manner. In this case, unfortunately, those who undergo it are unaware and those who implement it appear to be unaware. I would like to point out to Commissioner Liikanen that it is not easy to go to national courts. Of course, it is always possible to do so, but when jobs have been lost, when industries have been closed, going to court, with a slow justice system like the Italian one, leads to a result that is certainly not comforting. Commissioner Liikanen, we expect an authoritative intervention. Of course, as a Parliament, we expect to be able to collaborate on the resolution you mentioned - we are very ready - but we expect an authoritative intervention on this issue, which certainly cannot be concluded and passed as it has almost passed. Mr President, honourable colleagues, for the second time in four months we are discussing the restructuring of companies in Europe. Today, as then, the starting point for the debate is offered by the reorganisation of large companies, combined with the loss of jobs.

To this end, important Community initiatives—which our committee has always supported—are emerging from Bergen, aimed at rebuilding the biomass of spawning stocks, reducing and adapting fishing efforts to resources, protecting juveniles, species, and their habitats, and adopting technical measures aimed at selective and responsible fishing. These aspects are key to the future of fisheries, along with effective control systems. But we must not allow ourselves to be carried away by maximalism in this area, as Mr. Katiforis initially suggested in his draft report. I am referring to this now because I will not have time to speak later. I would like to point out in this regard that the numerous amendments tabled and adopted in our committee and the flexibility shown by Mr. Katiforis enabled the adoption of his report in our committee. As fate would have it, my report and Mr. Katiforis's report on fisheries and the environment coincide in this very plenary session, and at the same time, our committee's oral question—which we will examine tomorrow—on the extremely serious consequences for fisheries of the oil tanker accident, the Erika. Maritime transport and industrial and urban pollution, as well as waste, have a negative impact on fisheries. Their problems do not stem solely from overfishing. Thank you very much, Commissioner Fischler. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11:00. Fisheries management and nature conservation in the marine environment The next item is the debate on the report (A5-0017/2000) by Mr Katiforis, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the communication from the Commission to the Council and the European Parliament "Fisheries management and nature conservation in the marine environment" (COM(1999)363 - C5-0176/1999 - 1999/2155(COS)). . (EN) This House has in the past debated the problems of resource management and environmental protection in the fisheries sector. This particular communication from the Commission is part of the Commission's overall strategy to improve the integration of environmental considerations into other Community policies. The Commission's overall strategy is to direct fishing activities toward economically and environmentally sustainable levels through the management of scarce resources, thereby preventing depletion caused by overexploitation and/or environmental degradation. The alternative for successful management lies in downsizing the fishing industry as resources dwindle and the demand for fishery products is increasingly met by imports. I am aware that a Spanish newspaper has described me as an enemy of the fishing industry because I have said such things. Of course, I am only an enemy of the fishing industry to the extent that someone would be an enemy of the fishing industry who recommends not cutting down the branch on which they are sitting. This is an inadvisable policy. In particular, the communication calls for controlling fishing pressure to benefit commercial stocks and marine systems, improving nature conservation measures in the marine environment, gradual coastal zone management, better training, transparent information, and a greater contribution of scientific research to fisheries management. All these priorities will be pursued at Community level and in various international forums in which the Community participates.

We need joint, interregional, and transnational bodies in which all local and regional authorities, as well as all economic and social stakeholders, are actively involved. Parallel projects developed on both sides of the border must no longer be allowed to exist. We must create a cross-border culture, and this requires innovative approaches to administrative cooperation that can overcome existing borders and the difficulties arising from the different systems of responsibilities in the individual Member States, regions, and municipalities. It must not happen that a project cannot be implemented due to communication problems. During the committee discussion, we also noted that there are problems coordinating INTERREG with other funding instruments such as MEDA, TACIS, or PHARE, which run for one or two years. In its draft resolution, Parliament attaches great importance to resolving these problems; it submits proposals to the Commission for solutions and sets reasonable deadlines for implementing the necessary changes. Mr President, the reason I have spoken in this debate is that the URBAN initiative has been quite successful, particularly in Ireland. I am therefore very keen for the European Union to continue its contribution in this area. It is a sad fact that hundreds, if not thousands, of communities in the European Union have to suffer from extreme poverty and disadvantage. Even in very wealthy Member States and large cities, large numbers of people live in ghettos with inadequate housing, low levels of education, underdeveloped physical infrastructure, and rampant drug addiction and all that goes with that. I believe that the European Union must stand by the Member States to demonstrate that it can be of help in supporting European citizens and also that the Union is doing something for these citizens and their families. The programme has been hugely successful in Ireland, and I am, of course, aware of its success in other countries. In the beginning, progress was slow, and this slowness was due to the need to let the local population develop these programs themselves. It is crucial that they contribute their own initiative and their own expertise about local conditions to the development of these initiatives. It would be very easy to have these programs developed quickly and on time by external experts, but this approach would undermine the entire purpose of the URBAN program. Before I conclude, I would like to raise one more point: We should insist that wherever the funds are being channeled and wherever this program is being developed, everything is done within the framework of a serious URBAN development policy. Unfortunately, this is not the case in Ireland. I welcome the innovative approach of the EQUAL program and its goal of integrating discriminated groups into the labor market. I consider the development partnerships to be a very clever concept, even if they are experimental in nature. However, I have two important concerns about the development partnerships. They should also be made accessible to smaller groups so that they can develop, implement, and monitor the programs. We need a high degree of flexibility for this program. In the past, I have repeatedly emphasized the need to use simple language instead of technical jargon to ensure comprehensibility for everyone.

The Brok report is an excellent instrument in this regard; indeed, it is regrettable that, as it is a public debate, it is influenced by the political position taken by the Council and the Commission and that no more can be said about this excellent report. In any case, future developments depend not only on you, but also on us to the extent that we provide you with decisions and opportunities. Returning to the Brok report, Cyprus and Malta are the last islands in the Mediterranean and, if I am not mistaken, in the whole of Europe that have not yet joined the Union. This has a symbolic value because the Mediterranean and its islands - I am an islander myself - are the region where those who live there and those who come there in the summer from northern Europe to spend their holidays meet. From this point of view, the island of Aphrodite, as Cyprus is called, and the island of pirates, as we kindly call Malta, are two pearls that should be integrated into the Union soon. They have high incomes and excellent trade relations and, ultimately, they will be the test of the political will of the Union. In conclusion, I have no reason to go into further detail given the unanimity that reigns in the Chamber, but I would just like to make a point to the President-in-Office of the Council. I believe that his speech was not impeccable, but I hope it was a translation error and I await his reply so that I can have an answer. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened very carefully to your speeches and in particular to some rather emphatic statements on the Cyprus question, in defence of what is now the law in Cyprus and which the European Union obviously recognises, given that it recognises the resolutions of the United Nations Security Council on the matter. In this regard, Mr Wurtz, there is no ambiguous silence on the part of the Council: it takes full responsibility for the interpretation it gives to the situation existing in Cyprus. It was, moreover, this situation and this interpretation that prompted him to adopt the decision we know about in Luxembourg at the end of 1997, and to take the first steps in the process of accession of the Republic of Cyprus to the European Union. Regardless of more or less emotional positions on this kind of question, I would like you to realise that the routine of international negotiations usually forces governments - and when I say governments I mean all governments - to give a somewhat more flexible interpretation. It is true that we need more emotional positions to project the questions we are dealing with onto the human level, but we must also realise that it is thanks to the rationality of political positions and flexibility in negotiations that we can find solutions that allow us to overcome the great controversies that have given rise to the tragedies of the past. Leaving aside the guilty - we are not here to make an inventory of the guilty, the United Nations resolutions are clear on this - I believe we should exploit, without emotion and with greater rationality, the opportunities that the new situation offers us.

The sixth report from the European Commission draws some very valuable conclusions. I will summarize two of them, which have already been recalled by the rapporteur, one positive, the other negative. The first is that significant progress has been made in territorial and social cohesion throughout the Union and that Community funds have played an important, although not decisive, role in reducing regional inequalities. The negative is that the considerable effort that has been made has proven more effective in bringing the GDP and productivity of European regions closer together than in bringing their employment levels closer together. It is therefore necessary to better coordinate structural financing and job creation. This, Commissioner, is the first mandate for the next period. I therefore ask, Mr President, my distinguished colleagues to approve this report and I ask the Commission, as have other colleagues, not to lose sight of the conclusions of its sixth periodic report with regard to programming for the period 2000-2006. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first of all like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and also for the way in which the proposed amendments were taken into consideration during the committee's examination. The sixth periodic report provides a basis on which to assess the achievement of the objectives of the European Union's regional policy. The report shows that, despite all efforts, growth is uneven. Extremely rapid growth continues in central Europe. Similarly, the most dynamic centres continue to grow faster than the European average, while many regions in the north and south of Europe are experiencing significantly slower growth. A thorough analysis of the reasons why regional policy does not deliver the desired results in all regions is now necessary. Is the reason bureaucracy? Or have regional disparities—distance, climate that is too hot or too cold, dispersed settlements, harsh conditions—not been sufficiently taken into account? How can the European Union meet the challenges of global change in such a way that less developed regions can keep pace? It would also be important to analyze the effects of enlargement on the Structural Funds and on the development of the most remote regions. Member States also have their share of responsibility in this area and they must not forget this. Some Member States have contravened the principle of subsidiarity and reduced regional resources at national level, while regional aid provided through the European Union has been increasing. This has had a detrimental effect on the results of regional policy. In the future, we must also consider establishing indicators that will enable us to target measures at the right time and in the right place. For example, uncontrolled migration has not been sufficiently taken into account. Here too, we must stress the crucial role of SMEs as providers of employment and drivers of regional development. It is particularly important to make new technologies and know-how available to businesses in developing regions. Our group supports the adoption of this report. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Community's territorial policy has not yet been able to meaningfully reflect differences in residents' incomes.

So, Madam President, I repeat that we have discussed the action programme for the next five years and that we are ready to present it whenever Parliament wants - even this week, if it so decides - while next month it will be the turn of the programme for 2000, exactly as it was agreed. Madam President, I hear some laughter among the Socialists. I have been told that a large part of the Socialist Group would also like to see this item removed from the agenda, as the vote in the Conference of Presidents did not include the vote of the working group of the competent colleagues in the Socialist Group. I do not know whether this information is correct, but we in the PPE-DE would nevertheless be grateful if this item were removed, as Parliament has already dealt with this issue on several occasions. There are also some decisions against this tax. For this reason, the PPE-DE Group requests that this item be removed from the agenda. Thank you, Mr Poettering. Mr Wurtz has the floor and speaks against the request. Madam President, I would first like to point out the lack of logic on the part of Mr Poettering, who has just lectured the Socialist Group for going back on a decision that the Conference of Presidents had approved by a clear majority. Well, he did the same thing. It was discussed and everyone agreed, except the PPE-DE Group and the ELDR Group. On that occasion - my fellow Presidents will remember - I also stressed that the point was not so much whether we were for or against the Tobin tax, but whether we had the courage to listen to what the Commission and the Council thought about it. That is not asking a lot. I therefore reiterate my proposal to keep the oral question to the Council and the Commission on the agenda, in order to learn, once and for all, the position of the two institutions on a relatively modest proposal, but one which would send an important signal to public opinion, especially in the wake of the emotion aroused by the failure of the Seattle Conference. I now put to the vote the request by the PPE-DE Group to withdraw the oral question on the wealth tax from the agenda. (Parliament rejected the request by 164 votes to 166, with 7 abstentions) Madam President, I thank Mr Poettering for the unexpected publicity he has just given to this debate. Thank you! Madam President, has my vote, which was not cast electronically because I do not have the ballot paper, been counted? My vote was in favour. In fact, if we add the votes of the two Members who spoke, the result... Madam President, the Presidency has already announced the outcome of the vote. No changes are permitted. Madam President, I will respect your decision, but during the previous vote on the question of the Commission's strategic plan, I had expressed my intention to speak on behalf of my group before the vote, but I did not have the opportunity. I would be very grateful if you would allow me to make a declaration of vote on behalf of my group before closing this item on the agenda.

Mr. President, I am no friend of Milosevic and his government. Nevertheless, I have serious doubts about the legitimacy of NATO's intervention against Yugoslavia in the Kosovo conflict, firstly because of the lack of a UN Security Council resolution, and secondly because I believe this intervention could have been avoided if unrealistic demands regarding Serbia's sovereignty had not been made at Rambouillet. The current situation in Kosovo, where the ethnic cleansing of Serbs and Roma has now been completed, speaks for itself. Shouldn't NATO at least admit its mistake and accept responsibility for the deliberate bombing of the Belgrade television station building and the deaths of over 20 civilian journalists, as this remains a grave moral stain on the way this war was fought and will now potentially lead to shameful accusations of war crimes against our Western leaders? Mr. Member of Parliament, As far as the European Union's positions are concerned, there is no selective assessment, interpretation, or analysis of military objectives, especially measures against a specific type of infrastructure that served as a support for Mr. Milosevic's political and propaganda system. Therefore, I cannot tell you whether we agreed or disagreed with a specific NATO action. They are part of an overall plan with which we agree. Some of these actions may be questionable, and some have even been described as regrettable by NATO itself. Others, however, can be justified on tactical grounds, namely, to prevent Mr. Milosevic from continuing his domestic propaganda campaign. In any case, on behalf of the Council, I do not wish to make a value judgment on any particular NATO action in the military field. Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, as I am well-versed in the history of the Balkans, I would like to remind you that the peoples of Yugoslavia lived together peacefully for decades. The destabilization began approximately ten years ago with the dissolution of Yugoslavia, in which the European Union played a decisive role. Yugoslavia's crime was to be the only Balkan country not to want to join NATO or the European Union. What remained after the airstrikes is now being destroyed by the supposedly disarmed KLA, under the watchful eye of KFOR, which is increasingly revealing itself as an occupying power. Every day, new crimes against non-Kosovo Albanians, as well as against Kosovo's cultural heritage and hundreds of violations of UN Resolution 1244, come to light. In my view, the best course of action would be for the Council to end the occupation of this part of Yugoslavia and seek a solution acceptable to all sides, one that respects the ethnic characteristics of the region and, above all, the principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of an independent country. I respect the honourable Member's opinion and knowledge of the Balkan region, although, frankly, I find it difficult to understand how respecting the region's specific features in terms of political stability can be a solution to the problem. Indeed, considering the region's democratic stability, one could argue that the cause of the current situation can be found in the disintegration of Yugoslavia. However, we do not wish to enter into an assessment of an international development here.

Thus, a small European reform can conceal a medium-sized one, and a medium-sized one can conceal a large one. Not to mention that the large one can, in turn, conceal another gigantic one, because we will soon see the proposal for European criminal law and, why not, a European Minister of Justice, controlled by an extension of the powers of the European Parliament. I therefore believe that we must reflect carefully on the balance of power, which risks being upset by the presentation of this type of seemingly ad hoc reform. Finally, it seems to us that proposals such as that of the European Public Prosecutor demonstrate an inability to imagine Europe in any other way than as a pyramidal and centralized system, organized around a super-state. The Union for a Europe of Nations Group, on the contrary, wants a Europe with multiple centers around which nations unite. And the network could translate, for example, into better coordination between national judicial authorities, with the possible creation of national training bodies specializing in offenses against Community finances. The legal framework, Mr. President, already exists. Its principle is sound. It just needs to be refined. Mr. President, Mrs. Theato proposes an institutional revolution for two reasons. Public opinion, which remained indifferent to the 20 million unemployed and thousands of cases of mad cow disease, is apparently concerned about fraud that could endanger financial interests, and these two reasons would justify a dual system: a European Criminal Code that covers anti-EU crimes and a European Prosecutor General. Mrs. Theato has probably forgotten a European prison, given that the FBI, the European police force, already exists following the creation of OLAF. All of this would be instituted through two regulations, one for the Prosecutor General and one for the Criminal Code, regulations that would be based on Article 280 of the Treaty, that is, based on secondary law, since the nature of secondary law is to allow all kinds of deviations. Indeed, there is a double deviation. First, the classic Eurofederalist ideological drift: a single market, a single VAT, a single diplomacy, a single army, and now a single criminal law system and a single prosecutor. All this to fight fraud worth less than a billion euros, while allowing the loss of tens of billions of euros due to the GSP, free trade zones, customs gifts to Chiquita, and the billions lost in the fourth resource, GDP, resulting from the budget rationing pact. Then comes the Puritan drift: Northern German Europe, Lutheran, Calvinist, and Quaker Europe, wants to impose its moral order on us. Ultimately, the more morals are relaxed, the more we cling to our wallets. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, at this time, effective criminal protection of the European Union's financial interests is more essential than ever.

Mr. President, we will vote for the GUE/NGL Group's resolution because it denounces Total-Fina's responsibility for this ecological disaster, and I support the proposal to ban flags of convenience and the use of outdated ships, as well as to require double-hulled tankers. Let me add that, at the very least, Total should be required to fully compensate for the direct and indirect damage caused by the oil spill. How can we prevent similar disasters from occurring in the future without imposing draconian measures on the major oil companies, and indeed on others who, for the sake of additional profits, risk making our planet uninhabitable? How can we not be outraged when a bank, citing banking secrecy, refuses to reveal the names of the Erika's owners, without governments reacting? Fundamentally, the problem lies in the fact that all governments, as well as all European institutions, grant large corporations like Total-Fina and their ilk the right to maximize their profits at the expense of their workers and the environment. They grant companies and banks business secrecy, even when doing so conceals genuinely criminal activities. Under these circumstances, even the best resolutions remain mere petitions of principle, incapable of preventing large corporations from causing damage. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, I am in favor of tightening the rules on port state control and the rules on classification societies. But we must also stick to the facts. The ship Erika has been inspected four times in the last two years. The number of inspections cannot be the problem; what matters is ensuring the intensity of the inspections. I have heard in the discussions of the past few weeks that the Member States do not have enough money to carry out the inspections! I cannot accept that. If the Member States decide with us that 25% of ships will be inspected on the basis of port state control, then they must also provide the personnel! Then the inspections must be carried out in such a way that the inspector doesn't just go on board and check whether a fire extinguisher is missing, but also conducts material inspections, because this ship obviously broke apart due to material fatigue. This can only be determined if the inspections are carried out with great intensity. Our aim should be to ensure that port state controls are not superficial, but that they include the material. Secondly, I also share the Commissioner's suggestions and would like to encourage her to continue down this path. If it turns out that one or more classification societies have issued biased reports, then they should be removed from the list of permitted classification societies! That is the only deterrent to prevent other classification societies from also issuing biased reports. Dear Mrs Roth-Behrendt, we have the TÜV for ships. The classification societies are the TÜV for ships! There are also good societies. You know some good societies, our French colleagues know some good societies, but we have to look closely to see which societies don't meet the requirements, and those must be removed from the list.

The discretionary powers of the State, which you refer to in point (e) of your Amendment 10, do not seem to me to be consistent with the entire text of your otherwise excellent report. I therefore ask colleagues to consider my amendment with an open mind and hope that we can reach a conclusion tomorrow. On the surface, these two proposals appear to introduce certain procedural changes in order to promote free movement within Europe and to implement the recent judgments referred to by Mrs Berger in her introductory remarks. However, in the case of the United Kingdom, we believe that they go beyond this and are therefore unacceptable. This applies partly to their content, but also partly to their legal basis relating to the United Kingdom's special status. Under the arrangements contained in the Treaty, the United Kingdom maintains its border controls. The system proposed in these legal texts provides that third-country nationals wishing to come to the United Kingdom in accordance with the procedures described must present the service provision card issued by another Member State, thereby circumventing United Kingdom border controls. If there are to be changes to the United Kingdom's current border control regulations, then these changes should be brought about by the United Kingdom Government and Parliament, not en passant through the European legislative process. For this reason, we will vote against these two proposals. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to sincerely thank the rapporteur and Mr Wieland for their efforts in bringing together the various amendments and the various interests so homogeneously in this report. These two proposals make a significant contribution to the implementation of one of the four core principles of the internal market, the freedom to provide services. The new regulation for cross-border services will undoubtedly improve both the functioning of the internal market and the competitiveness and flexibility of companies. The strict framework for issuing the EU service provision card—and here I agree with Mr Wieland—is essential, as it serves to prevent abuses such as illegal immigration and bogus contracts. Why do I consider the directive so necessary? Three reasons: because of the economic importance of third-country national workers in the EU, because of the competitiveness of companies, and because of the smooth functioning of the internal market. Therefore, on the one hand, I welcome the strict framework, and on the other, I appeal for the appropriate controls carried out by the Member States to be as effective and simple as possible. My final question, because I am repeatedly asked about it, is directed at the Commission: Will the directive prejudice the accession negotiations? How do you see Article 1 being interpreted and explained, given that this plays a particularly important role for our country, which borders many new countries and is particularly relevant in the accession negotiations? Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, until now, businesspeople have had to realize that two important freedoms, namely freedom of movement and the freedom to provide services, did not apply to them. In fact, they still had to endure endless bureaucratic immigration procedures from Member States in which a service was to be provided. Approximately 13 million third-country nationals live in Europe. The number of business people among them is not exactly known, but it is certainly not small.

I cite as proof an excellent report that our colleague Mario Soares prepared in international bodies on the state of the seas and oceans. Rightly, when we talked about climate change, we referred to the greenhouse effect and the state of the atmosphere. But we also know that the deterioration of the oceans will considerably destabilize entire parts of our planet. It is therefore appropriate that Europe, both because it must promote a certain development model and because it is itself facing serious problems of pollution and deterioration of its waters, whether groundwater, surface water, or seas, must be, in a certain way, exemplary in its practices. Moreover, our Europe has signed international conventions. I am thinking in particular of the OSPAR Convention, where it has made commitments. She said: "In a few years, we must have stopped the discharge of pollution, we must have stopped the increase in pollution, and we must even get close to a level almost zero, when it comes to toxic substances or dangerous substances." So Europe signs international agreements, and then the directive arrives, along with concrete policies on the ground, and then it announces that it will not be able to achieve the objectives set or it postpones them to dates such that the very credibility of signing these international conventions is called into question. This is why, when initiating the debate on the Water Framework Directive, from the first reading, the European Parliament sought to demand consistency between the framework directive and international objectives, and in particular, regarding compliance with OSPAR, convergence that is effective, concrete, and that commits us to action. The European Union's water policy is not starting from scratch. Many directives have been adopted, and it is the Commission's desire to make them more readable, more compatible with each other, with clearer objectives. It is therefore a concern for rationality that led to the creation of this framework directive. But our Parliament, at first reading, insisted that the current directive not only be compatible with the commitments we have made - OSPAR type - but also allow us to reverse the course of things. Because despite these numerous directives, despite frequent declarations on the effort that must be made in terms of water protection, when we look at the state of the environment in Europe, we see that the objectives have not been achieved. In many cases the situation has deteriorated and therefore, we cannot be satisfied with an effort to rationalize the texts. We must set ourselves objectives that match the challenges that lie ahead, and we do not have much time, because if we do it, as the Commission proposed, with excessively long deadlines, when it and the Council have extended the deadlines even further, we will not only have a credibility problem with the public, but we know very well that efforts will be postponed until tomorrow, and tomorrow they will be postponed again, and so we know that we will not achieve the objectives set. I insist on this point, because we should not wait for the umpteenth time for disasters to be reported every day in our newspapers to say to ourselves: "ah! Europe did not do it, ah! Europe should have done it," and then, in haste, act as if we were going to resolve the problems that we did not want to tackle head-on in good time.

We are, in principle, opposed to this type of program, as well as to structural funds, but since the vote only concerns how these resources will be used - and not their volume - we voted for the report. We believe, in fact, that it is important to guarantee equal opportunities for the groups mentioned in the report. We did not vote against this report because it announces some fair general principles: for example, the need to combat racism in the workplace and to reduce gender inequalities in the labor market. But we did not vote for it either because all of this remains extremely vague, if not wishful thinking. On the other hand, in the chapter on aid and training projects for refugees, the report represents a step backwards compared to the original text, since it insists that it no longer concerns refugees as such, but "only refugees within the meaning of the Geneva Convention." This restriction is unacceptable when, throughout Europe, many refugees find themselves in a dramatic situation, without protection, forced to work illegally and in hiding, while the governments and police forces of so-called democratic states hunt them down. The first step in this area is to give these undocumented migrants the legal means to lead a decent life and to be able to work without being relegated to the status of pariahs, victims of unscrupulous employers and multiple administrative and police harassments, the main one being having to live in constant fear of deportation. I voted in favour of Mrs Stenzel's report on the EQUAL initiative because I believe it is essential to continue the work that was started with the previous NOW, Horizon, Youthstart and Integra components of the ADAPT and Employment initiatives. We must build on the lessons we have learned from these actions. EQUAL stands for "equality". It must produce results. I welcome the proposed focus on promoting new ways of combating discrimination and all other forms of inequality in the employment market. I also support the desire to move away from an outdated format and bring partners together to find innovative ways to stem unemployment. Flexibility is needed. I deeply regret that only limited funds are available for this initiative. In the last programming period, 9% of the structural funds were allocated to Community initiatives. This figure is now 5.3%. This means that the funds must be used to achieve maximum effect, and information about partnerships must be widely and quickly disseminated. The Committee on Employment and Social Affairs adopted several of the amendments I had tabled, concerning, for example, the emphasis on access to seed capital, how to exploit new business opportunities in towns and rural areas, and the criticism that business participation was insufficient in previous initiatives. This has often resulted in good projects not leading to real employment opportunities. The positive experience of innovative actions by small developers has been weakened by their distance from the decision-making process.

Only women can invent policies capable of changing structures created by men and for men. Because it is structural discrimination that women face most, whether in politics or in the labor market. It is therefore up to European political parties to open up to women. Furthermore, Article 191 of the Treaty (formerly Article 138 A) states that they—I quote—"constitute an important factor in integration within the Union." The article goes on to say that "these parties contribute to shaping European consciousness and expressing the political will of the citizens of the Union." While this provision has no legal value, it is nonetheless highly symbolic. It grants political parties an important role in building a democratic Europe. This can be done, for example, by introducing positive discrimination measures and promoting parity within our political parties. Some of them presented joint lists for the 1999 European elections. This is a good practice that needs to be generalized. I don't know if there is a cause-effect relationship, but the fact is that the proportion of female Members of the European Parliament rose from 25.7% in 1994 to 29.9% in 1999. Furthermore, a woman has held the presidency since the 1999 elections. I will conclude by repeating the conclusions drawn from the April 1999 conference organized by the Commission, entitled "Women and Men in Power." Equality between men and women is not an issue that concerns only women; it is a challenge that affects our entire society! Some progress has been made recently with the increase in the number of women present in the Union's decision-making bodies. In our own institution, 30% of elected representatives are currently women, including the President of the European Parliament. Finland has also just elected a woman as President. On average, a quarter of Member State governments and just over a fifth of their parliaments are composed of women. This situation is still far from fully satisfactory, especially since the figures vary enormously between Member States, with the Nordic countries having a much higher representation of women in positions of responsibility and decision-making. This situation has more to do with attitude and respect for the quality and capacity of women's contribution to society than with fixed quotas. My group does not support quotas in general because, in the long term, they can be counterproductive and even undermine the cause for which they were created. However, we recognize that the experience in all Member States is not the same, and some recourse to this type of measure may even be justified as a temporary remedy to rebalance women's representation where they are grossly underrepresented. We support the resolution on women in decision-making, adopted in view of commemorating International Women's Day on March 8, which incorporated ten amendments from the Liberal Group and softened the reference to quotas in line with the approach outlined above.

There have been large public investments at the federal level, at the state level and at the local level. They have been enormous, and they have been investments in modern infrastructure. Pay attention, here our direct commitment - I repeat, direct - at the public level and at the various levels is to build the telematic highways, that is, the roads on which these new vehicles run. The market, private individuals, businesses will build the vehicles to run, but we are the ones who have the obligation to build the new highways. So, what Minister Guterres said about the computer in every school, about the network that must reach all peripheral areas, this is not an obligation that can be left exclusively to the market because, simply, the market does not do this, and moreover without this we will not reach those new objectives of productivity development that are necessary. Our problem therefore is to avoid the crisis of peripheral economies, which does not mean centralization, does not mean centralized planning, but it means giving peripheral economies the same opportunities that we give centralized economies. This is why the program must be addressed to schools, this is why we must take an entire age group and insist on it, ensuring that in that age group there is no one left out of the new literacy. Lisbon therefore has a very specific strategy. In Lisbon the real problem, in my opinion, is to inject new courage for employment, for growth, knowing that we can do it, and therefore we must move towards this model that is based on certain balances. To summarise today's debate I would like to take an expression that was used by one of you parliamentarians, if I remember correctly the Honourable Goebbels, who said: "We have a deficit of future in Europe". It is simply this. We have been crying over ourselves for a long time, while the seeds of what we had planted with so much sacrifice at the roots of Europe were maturing. Now, please, let us also try to close the deficit of future and give meaning to the new generations, thinking that we are working together modestly but seriously for something that lasts. It is clear then that it becomes essential to put the three processes together. Unfortunately our terminology is horrible, but we really put together the problems of macroeconomics, work and structural problems now, and then we have the capacity and the possibility to obtain the results we wanted, with very simple actions, even specific ones. Let's remember the European society: we have not yet found unanimity for the European society, but there are hundreds of thousands of companies that ask us for it. At all costs this must be done, because simply the idea of operating in fifteen countries - which are now becoming one - with different rules in the elementary principles of business is an unsustainable idea: we cannot sell it, because it makes no sense. The same goes for the European patent: we cannot sell this either; and the rules on procurement, the capital market; even the seeds of social security coordination, because it is useless for us to think of great opportunities for mobility, to create very successful programs like ERASMUS, SOCRATES to make people more mobile, if then we have social security rules that do not help us in this mobility.

It is right that the Lisbon Summit, which will take place at the end of this month, should focus on analysing the situation. Despite their complexity, these processes all have one thing in common: improving the quality of life of the citizens of the European Union. To achieve this, we do not need new formulas, new working groups or new forums for discussion. We know very well what tools we have at our disposal. Often, citizens' opinions and, at times, ideological opposition mean that these tools are not used. It is now extremely important to quickly remove all the obstacles that are preventing the creation of a real European internal market; only in this way will it be possible to avoid having to continue to move in fifteen different national markets, as is still the case in many sectors. When, in the 1980s, the idea of the internal market began to be put forward, it was possible to maintain a pace similar, to use a metaphor, to that of an accelerated steam train. Today - with the rapid development of e-commerce and the speed of data transmission and processing, the situation is completely different - we would need at least the speed of Mika Häkkinen's racing car. Nevertheless, we must ensure that the power of decision-making does not run out and that the engine does not start to falter before reaching the finish line. How can we expect to create the most competitive economic area in the world if we do not have the courage to liberalise competition within it? The liberalisation of the telecommunications and energy sectors that has already been approved will help create new jobs and reduce prices for both industry and consumers. Similarly, removing obstacles for small and medium-sized enterprises - whether these are complex procedures imposed by the authorities, access to venture capital or tax issues - is essential for greater competitiveness and prosperity. Improving global competitiveness also includes adequate tax harmonisation and the modernisation of our social security systems so that at least those EU member states with particularly high tax pressures can reduce the rates that slow down the employment process. The foundations are laid through training and research. It is right to try to quickly create knowledge infrastructures that can be made available to businesses, schools and private individuals at reasonable prices or free of charge. It is particularly important to strive to create and maintain sufficient resources to foster the development of promising employment sectors. These naturally include the technology sector, e-commerce, tourism and, for example, care for the elderly, given the undeniable continued ageing of the population. Parliament, the Commission and the Council must remember two important things: regardless of whether it is training and research, developing competitiveness or removing obstacles to entrepreneurship, these are tasks that fall within the competence of the member states.

By establishing a sector reserved for public postal operators on the basis of weight and price limits, the Postal Directive enabled gradual and controlled liberalisation. The sudden reduction of these limits calls into question the balance between the public service obligation and the economic viability of postal services. In the face of a process of globalisation in which the pursuit of profitability and profit is increasingly at odds with the aim of regional balance and social cohesion, I would like to reiterate our commitment to public service in the European Union, whether it concerns the post office today, the railways tomorrow, or health the day after tomorrow. Mr President, like other Scottish Members of this House, representatives of Scotland, I too raise my voice to protest against anything that leads to a decline in the quality of rural life in remote areas. The postal service and the post office are an essential feature of life in rural communities throughout Europe, and not least in Scotland. It would be disastrous if measures were taken, intentionally or even inadvertently, to destroy that. I don't think anyone wants that. I don't think the Commission wants to declare war on the Scottish or Greek islands. But I think it could cause great damage purely by accident. The point is to determine the speed and methods by which the gradual liberalization of postal services should proceed. If the targets are set too low for the continued existence of the postal service monopoly, it would become uneconomical to maintain universality of service at an affordable price in remote areas. The key is to strike a balance between universality and affordability. The very clear message to the Commission today from all sides of the House is that the Commission should proceed carefully. The Commission should not, for example, make a sudden jump from 350 grams to just 50 grams, as some Members have suggested. On the contrary, it should proceed cautiously. I can imagine that anything under 150 grams would be extremely unwise under these circumstances. The solidarity and cohesion of people throughout Europe depend on the idea that one can send a letter anywhere and that this letter will be delivered everywhere for an affordable stamp fee. Stick to universality and affordability! Mr President! To guarantee a high-quality universal postal service, it must be maintained as a public service at all costs. The universal service, which comprises an offer of high-quality postal services at affordable prices, provided anywhere in the territory, forms the basis of the operation of the entire postal system and must lead to a single tariff throughout the national territory. But for this to happen, it must be maintained as a public service. This is the only way to guarantee that the network, from collection to delivery, is all-encompassing and cannot be fragmented or used only partially, and can be used as the postal operators see fit. However, as we know, the Commission has since commissioned studies on the basis of the directive on common rules for Community postal services, which it has not informed the European Parliament of, and therefore nothing is known about the consequences of its application, either in terms of services for citizens or for current European postal operators, whether in economic terms or in terms of employment.

This explains the importance of the proposals we are presenting to this end. The Commission's communication lists a series of objectives and proposals that take into account the need to continue the efforts made in the areas of control and surveillance, to adopt new technical measures in the area of selective fishing methods, to monitor the implementation of current legislation, etc. However, in its communication, the Commission also mentions that it lacks the power to enforce this legislation.
