However, existing measures and appropriate means are not lacking: the Commission has at its disposal a whole arsenal of mandatory provisions, measures, and decisions (of international and Community origin) already in force in the sectors of fisheries and marine environmental protection. Efficiency and hyperregulation do not go hand in hand. Maritime professionals, it must be remembered, are willing to apply Community legislation provided that it is applied equitably in all Member States, that it is technically acceptable and applicable, and that it has a real scientific basis. I find it unacceptable that, in the Committee on Fisheries, one of the European Commission officials dared to publicly state that the financial resources provided by the Commission to certain scientific bodies allow their conclusions to be controlled. This is a very serious deviation: the Commission, obviously, should not arrogate to itself any right to steer the conclusions of scientists in order to implement whatever policy it deems appropriate, taking into account only its own interests. Regarding reducing the pressure exerted by fishing activity on resources, it is important to emphasize the international nature of this obligation. What would be the point of reducing our European fishing fleet if, at the same time, third countries maintained their pressure on fishing resources? Furthermore, it must be noted that the progressive globalization of trade has considerably reduced the effectiveness of controls and monitoring of fishing activities. Transshipment has become a very common practice, and it is not uncommon for fishery products from a Member State that cannot be sold in the Union due to exceeding TACs to be marketed as imported products or as originating from another Member State. The latter case is very common in companies whose capital originates in a Member State other than the flag of the fishing vessel (this is, in fact, a covert form of "quota-hoping"). Food safety related to seafood also plays a key role. It is necessary to preserve the positive image of these products and prevent unsafe food products from being marketed in the European Union. Therefore, the Members of the Europe of the Nations Group will vote against this report, which fails to identify the shortcomings of the Commission's communication and which increases the Natura 2000 obligations for the fisheries sector. The vote is closed. Adjournment of the session. The session is adjourned. Resumed

The primary objective of this reflection is to identify the instruments available to the international community to stabilize the international monetary and financial system. From this perspective, Mr. Bolkestein, the proposed resolution does not isolate the issue of the Tobin tax. If you read it carefully, this proposed tax on capital flows is one instrument among others to try to force international investors to behave responsibly in the financial markets. Secondly, the resolution does not say that we want an initiative based solely on a European basis. This is why we explicitly refer to the autumn session of the International Monetary Fund so that the European Union—that is, the Commission, but also the Council—can take a position on how to defend the opportunity to stabilize the international financial and monetary system and introduce international taxation. I would not like there to be any confusion in this debate. We, as environmentalists, do not want a resolution that is merely an alibi. The point is not to add another study to the dozens already conducted—the Commission's would certainly be interesting—but to obtain from the Commission and the Council, that is, from each of the governments that make up the Union, a clear political stance, positive or negative, to determine whether they are willing to defend in the relevant public forums, primarily the International Monetary Fund, the appropriateness of such a tax on the other instruments necessary for the stability of the international monetary system. As for the argument that this initiative will increase uncertainty, as far as I know, very short-term capital movements serve precisely the purpose of playing with uncertainty and betting on the evolutions between currencies or between different short-term financial assets. This argument, therefore, does not seem relevant to me. I will not go further into the underlying debate. I think everyone has their own arguments. I draw your attention, however, not only to paragraph 9 of the resolution but also to paragraph 10. This is clearly a political position, and we hope, within a very clear timeframe, the preparations for the autumn session of the International Monetary Fund, and we ask, if this resolution is voted on tomorrow in plenary, that the Commission and the Council appear before Parliament to tell us what positions they would defend on this occasion. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, my group is extremely pleased that such a debate is taking place today, even more so since we have spared no effort with colleagues from different groups to achieve it. Naturally, we do not all have the same approach, and I believe that our debate and the motions for resolutions we submitted at the beginning demonstrate this. That said, we are not, as far as we are concerned, indifferent to the step forward represented by the compromise resolution, which invites the Commission to submit a report within six months. We believe that the European Parliament can thus play its part by taking the initiative, albeit timidly, on this issue, although of course—and I agree with the previous speaker—if paragraph 9 were to be challenged, this resolution would clearly lose its essence. Our debate does indeed touch on a vital question that more and more citizens are legitimately asking: What place should be given to humankind and the financial sphere in today's economy?

Generally speaking, we can say that the first is left-wing and shows social concerns, as well as examining economic problems, while this document, which Mr Katiforis did not see fit to support - and I think he did well - is a hybrid report in which, starting from a structure with social concerns, the main conclusions have been drawn. What was Mr Katiforis proposing and which was removed from the report? He proposed an ambitious report, in an optimistic Europe, which sought to quantify the objectives for the results that were to be achieved. In fact, Europe has advanced thanks to programmes with quantified objectives. For example, why was the proposal withdrawn that the working population in Europe should reach 75% of the population, when it is currently 60%? A rate of 60% is very low compared to that of Japan or the United States and with such a modest employment rate we certainly cannot produce as much as those countries. We must therefore increase the employment rate with competitive jobs. As argued in the run-up to the Lisbon Summit, we need to prepare a scientifically trained workforce to handle new technologies; and investment needs to grow at a faster rate. We are very familiar with the idea put forward by my colleague, Mr von Wogau, that what is needed is a flexible workforce. I wanted to counter this argument with the Portuguese example, where labour laws are not flexible and where the unemployment rate is less than 5% - and has continued to fall in recent years - because investment is increasing (with Community aid, of course) at a much higher rate than the European Union average. We therefore want a Europe with economic growth, but one that is attentive to social issues. Mr President, like many other Members, I would like to thank Mr Katiforis for his interesting report. Reading the text and looking at the panorama of the European economy that emerges from it, I get a very worrying impression. The investment rate is too low, unemployment remains at excessively high levels and growth remains insufficient. That is why it is probably not surprising that the euro continues to lose ground against other currencies, despite rumours that the ECB is secretly buying euros to support their value. The rapporteur notes that stability is not an end in itself; I agree. There is too much talk about stability, convergence and coordination, and too little about the factors that can induce innovation and development. In my eyes, cooperation within the EMU is like a clumsy colossus struggling to keep pace with such a mobile economy. However, my conclusions are completely different from those of the previous speaker. I believe that we need to focus on human resources, partly through a macro-policy that generates demand and new job opportunities, partly - but perhaps above all - through measures on the ground, in terms of training, democratisation of businesses and improved social conditions.

If we continue to get bogged down in proposals that have so far produced mediocre results, I do not see how we will move forward, nor what the Commission will be able to do. The same applies to enlargement, which represents its own end without a much more effective reform of the European Union and its structures, and to the proposals that the Commission could also have made during the IGC. Mr President, I would like to end on a positive note, perhaps contrary to the opinion of some colleagues, regarding the telegram you sent to the Austrian government. Your position has convinced us; you were right not to isolate that country even further. However, we will see in practice what concrete actions this will lead to. I repeat, Mr President, this is a somewhat short-sighted vision in our opinion. What it lacks, above all, is a boost in the sectors I mentioned, for example the Balkans. Can we continue to exclude the Balkans from enlargement, without considering that Croatia, Macedonia and other countries also have the right to be part of our Europe? Madam President, Mr Prodi, I applaud your proposal to radically decentralise the Union's activities, but I ask you: why are you then presenting a centralising body of laws? I remember the speech your predecessor gave five years ago. Mr Santer made the same promises as you – 'less and better' – but what we ultimately got was 'much more and much worse'. I do not think you are capable of keeping your promises. You talk about decentralisation, but you act like a centraliser. This body of laws is nothing more than a monotonous list of issues over which citizens will lose all influence; it is you yourself, Mr Prodi, who is taking this influence away from citizens, even on social issues. You talk about increasing transparency, but you are presenting proposals aimed at concealing documents that are currently accessible. Your Commission is made up of 20 people who are the only ones in the EU who can propose reducing the volume of legislation. No local politician has this power once a law has been adopted in Brussels. That is why the collection of laws published by the Commission should at least be accompanied by an equally voluminous collection of competences that are referred to the Member States and the democratic power of citizens, otherwise the volume of legislation adopted in Brussels will continue to grow. We have adopted 10,000 laws and as many legislative amendments; the candidate countries have received 26,000 documents, which, for the Polish parliament, for example, represents 140,000 pages to examine. Already today, this figure is far, far too high. Brussels must make fewer decisions and give more powers in this area to citizens, regions and Member States; only decisions on cross-border issues on which national parliaments can no longer legislate effectively should be the responsibility of Brussels.

Secondly, it would be necessary for the doctrine of human rights to cease being instrumentalized as it is today, an ideological war machine in the hands of a caste that arrogates to itself the right to unilaterally decree who represents human rights and who stands outside its sphere, which allows it to deny all legitimacy and, if necessary, all freedom to those whom the single thought has designated as politically incorrect. There is no freedom for the enemies of freedom, said two centuries ago the promoters of revolutionary terror, of that revolution that was, unfortunately, the matrix of all modern totalitarianisms. There are no human rights for the enemies of human rights, say today the incense-bearers of the new world order, who reign almost exclusively in financial circles, in international institutions, in the media and cultural networks, in educational institutions—and I am being modest. What remains, for example, of the human right of the Austrian to freely choose his destiny if that choice is dictated to him by those who decide in his place what is appropriate or inappropriate to do, and if his leaders, who come from a legal and legitimate process, are received in an insulting manner, as they were recently received in your country, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, Mr. Minister of Portugal? I don't know if you are here to hear me. What will remain of the human rights of those who sympathize with the Flemish Bloc, one of the most important in the Flemish region, if the Belgian Parliament tomorrow adopts the incredible, indecent, ignominious bill emanating from its main political competitor, the Popular Union, which plainly seeks the dissolution of its rival? What remains of the right to critical study of our history when authors and editors are being persecuted, as the young historian Jean Plantin was yesterday before the Court of Appeal in my city of Lyon, the target of absurd, arrogant, and insulting demands from the Supreme Court prosecutor Jean-Olivier Viout, a self-satisfied expression of single-mindedness and intellectual conformism? What a strange conception of human rights that fraudulently equates peaceful patriotism with bellicose nationalism, legitimate protest against immigration policy with I don't know what kind of xenophobia, and the necessary defense of identities with racism! What are the human rights of the millions of French voters of the National Front, deprived of any political representation, vilified daily, as was the case on Monday, on state television channels they must pay for with their taxes, when the mere legitimately exasperated expression of one of our colleagues, Mr. Le Pen, serves as a pretext for inhuman condemnations, violating the law, violating justice, equity, and morality? And today, contrary to the clearest texts, they seek to deprive this representative of our millions of fellow citizens of the mandate he owes to their votes and not to the favors of those in power. In short, Ladies and Gentlemen, I will believe your speech on human rights in Europe when you recognize for your political adversaries the same rights you grant yourselves.

I do not expect a rubber-stamping or nodding-off of everything you will be confronted with in the coming years. Rather, I am counting on the European Parliament not only to be a critical observer, as it was in this case, but also to play an active role in ensuring that the Union makes progress in the fight against crime. Votes: Mr Goebbels, excuse me, I have the impression that you are getting ahead of yourself, as there was an oral amendment to Amendment 37 proposing to rephrase the words "with a high credit rating based on a recognized credit rating scale," and you had requested such an amendment. Madam President, I beg your pardon; I was first thinking of Amendment 36, which logically comes before Amendment 37. But we are now discussing Amendment 37, and here we have a similar problem. A high credit rating is required not for the bodies, but for the instruments. The text therefore reads: "instruments with a high rating base on a recognized rating scale are subject to reliable and verifiable valuation." Once again, I apologize for this error. Are there any objections to this oral amendment? (Parliament agrees with the oral amendment.) (By successive votes, Parliament adopts the two draft legislative resolutions.) Madam President, I asked for the floor just before the opening of the sitting to say something solely out of respect for you, as President of this Chamber, a Chamber of all those present here. For the second time in two weeks, visits to this Chamber intended to denounce conditions—which I respect and fully agree with, as I support freedom of expression for all—have led to attacks against individuals, parties like the one I represent, and institutions. I consider such behavior, especially in your presence, Madam President, to be dishonest, and I reject it emphatically, all the more so as we are approaching an election campaign. Therefore, above all, out of the respect you deserve, I cannot accept such practices and I categorically reject them. That was a personal remark, I am told. We will note this in the Minutes. Madam President, above all out of respect for you, a respect I consider you worthy of, and out of respect for this Chamber, I did not want to explicitly address the specific issue I was discussing, but I do so now, as a Member of this Parliament, as Secretary General of a political party from the Basque Country, and as an ordinary citizen of this country, because of the particularly serious accusations against individuals and parties such as mine, with a long democratic tradition and a conscientious respect for and defense of human rights for very many years. Madam President, I would like to express my concern that this sincere defense of human rights just put forward by Mr. Gorka Knörr does not seem to prevent his government from counting on the parliamentary cooperation of a political group that not only does not condemn violence against citizens and property, but supports and encourages it. I see that Mr Gorostiaga Atxalandabaso is requesting the floor on the same subject. We will not open a debate now.

In its report to the summit, the Commission set quantitative targets for development in the areas of employment, unemployment, and female employment. In its report, the Commission also set a target for reducing poverty problems within Europe over the next ten years. I think it's a good thing that common objectives are emphasized, because countries' policies in this area will differ—they must. In some EU countries—by not mentioning any, I'm not forgetting any—we are struggling with high youth unemployment. In other countries, such as my own country, Denmark, youth unemployment is very low. Yes, there is even a struggle between employers and educational institutions to attract young people. There are differences between countries in terms of problems, systems, cultures, and traditions, and therefore there must be differences in the choice of means to achieve the common goals of greater employment and less social isolation. The design of employment policy ensures this through the exchange of experiences and ideas from the Luxembourg process. Although there are many common features in the problems we will face in the coming years, both with regard to employment policy and social policy, I must say that there are some common challenges and others that each of us must resolve separately. It is of the utmost importance that countries not only avoid hindering each other in solving social problems, but rather collaborate and inspire each other. I would like to emphasize both the importance of pursuing common objectives and also of each country maintaining its sovereignty and responsibilities in setting its social and employment policies. We must also maintain a certain level of competition between systems to ensure dynamism and development in the design of social and employment policies. Mr. President, as a representative of Flanders and on behalf of what I would call the nationalist regions represented in the European Free Alliance, I was struck by your advocacy of a strong pro-European approach in which each of the fifteen Member States does not try to gain power, but rather in which cooperation becomes stronger. You pointed out the existence of fifteen distinct public opinions, but in practice there are many more, since there are major internal differences within the Member States themselves. Is it necessary for me, as a Belgian, to point out the difference in opinion between Flanders and Wallonia? Is it necessary for me to point out that there is a difference between the former East Germany and West Germany? Furthermore, there is a danger of a dualism emerging in our public opinion due to globalization. Instead of the former differences between the "have-nots" and the "haves," today we have differences between those who can keep pace with this society and those who cannot or who simply abandon it.

I would therefore like to reiterate my congratulations to the rapporteur, Mr Langen, for the work accomplished, thank all the speakers and, of course, commend the action of Vice-President Provan during the conciliation procedure, which effectively contributed to achieving a positive result. I also welcome the Council's reasonable and flexible action. SAVE The next item is the report (A5-0010/2000) by Mrs Ahern, on behalf of Parliament's delegation to the Conciliation Committee, on the joint draft decision, approved by the Conciliation Committee, of the European Parliament and the Council adopting a multiannual programme to promote energy efficiency - SAVE (C5-0334/1999 - 1997/0371(COD)). Madam President, I would like to thank the Council and the Commission for this useful and thorough conciliation procedure, which took place entirely in a good atmosphere, which is not always the case. I am pleased to say that I can consider the final outcome of this conciliation to be satisfactory for Parliament, since the joint text has incorporated all its amendments, both in full and after redrafting. The sum finally allocated to the programme also represents a considerable improvement on the Council's proposal at second reading, a proposal that we considered totally unacceptable, and we have made significant progress in this regard. I therefore propose that this House agree to adopt the proposals relating to SAVE and the conclusions reached at the conciliation at third reading. I would like to remind the House that Parliament adopted, at second reading, this report, which contains eight amendments, including a reinstatement of the Commission's original budget. The Commission accepted five of the proposed amendments, including the budget allocation, and I thank the Commission for its continued support for the budget during the conciliation procedure, given that the Council's proposal was unacceptable. During the procedure, agreement was reached on the studies and actions to be carried out to design, implement, supplement, and evaluate Community measures. Compromise wording was agreed on five other amendments, including legislative and non-legislative measures, the inclusion of local energy centres and, very importantly, energy audit schemes in the review of progress on energy efficiency. I hope you will all agree that this is important progress. Parliament firmly defended the issue of the financial envelope in the face of the Council's very meager opening offer. In the end, we had to meet several times before the Council increased the sum and made a substantial offer. We achieved an increase of €2 million over the amount originally proposed, which was a decisive increase that I recommend to you and which, as the Commission has confirmed, will enable the implementation of the programme. This was important for us. I would like to point out, however, that this budget is and has always been modest and that, consequently, the financing of this programme is more symbolic than real. It is mainly the Member States that finance energy savings. We must bear this in mind when we approve this program. It would be unfortunate if our community achievements were more symbolism than reality, because there is enthusiasm at the local level for actions, including community actions, to promote energy conservation.

I am satisfied with the rapporteur's approach to state aid and I congratulate him on it. There is indeed too often a tendency to castigate state aid as measures that distort competition. It is true that an effective competition policy is a prerequisite for the proper functioning of the internal market and economic and monetary union. However, as the rapporteur points out, such aid is sometimes essential and can, beyond the survival of a particular company, contribute to sustainable development (Article 6 of the Treaty), services of general interest (Article 16) and economic and social cohesion (Article 158). It is clear, however, that it must be monitored, a task that falls to the European Commission. The aid allocated each year by the Member States of the Union to the sectors in question reached a total of €95 billion during the period 1995-1997, 40% of which went to the manufacturing sector. This aid has decreased considerably compared to the previous period, 1993-1995 (a drop of 13% in the total amount and from 3.8% to 2.6% in the amount of aid to the manufacturing sector). This decline in aid is mainly explained by the reduction in aid granted to the new German Länder. I regret, like the rapporteur, that the figures presented in the report do not cover all state aid. The European Commission must address these shortcomings as quickly as possible. It must also cooperate with the Member States to improve the quality of the data in a timely manner, that is, for the ninth report. It would be a good idea for the Commission to publish a register showing the amount of state aid per Member State. I also regret that the European Parliament is completely excluded from the Advisory Committee on State Aid. To compensate for this situation, the European Commission must produce, and produce, regular reports to us. I will conclude with one aspect of the use of State aid that seems particularly dangerous to me: aid that leads to the relocation of companies from one Member State to another, with the risk of a hunt for subsidies that does nothing to achieve the EU's common objectives. That is why I hope that the next report on State aid will include an assessment of the effect of such aid on employment, as well as on the industrial and craft sectors in the beneficiary countries. Langen report (A5-0073/1999) In the important debate on competition, I spoke this morning about Mr Langen's text on the application in 1998 of the 6th Steel Aid Code. As the Court of Justice recognised in its order of 3 May 1996, the steel sector is particularly sensitive to competitive disruption. This is why it was legitimate to introduce a system of aid for this sector with the aim of ensuring the survival of successful companies, even though Article 4(c) of the ECSC Treaty prohibits any State aid to the steel industry. This is, in fact, the purpose of the 6th Code on Aid to the Steel Industry.

I do not want to make any changes to the text of the common position. The manufacturer is responsible, must be responsible, and the final user must be able to hand in the car free of charge. In my opinion, there are many unjustified fears. The automotive industry lobby has often created confusion. I would like to reiterate to you once again that, as experience shows, the costs of treatment must be passed on. They are not that high. In my country, they are estimated at around 150 guilders per car. This starts from day one, and at the same time, the treatment of old cars can be carried out. Likewise, a large industry can be created right now to ensure that car scrapyards, which were once common in our Member States, no longer exist. Therefore, I do not want to make any changes to the compromise reached in this regard. I think it is positive that we are passing the legislation presented to us as soon as possible. This is good because the nine million cars produced each year in Europe can then also be properly recycled, and this will benefit everyone. Mr. President, the current proposal is important in our commitment to preventing the production of hazardous waste from end-of-life vehicles and is important in promoting the recycling and recovery of materials from scrapped vehicles. Therefore, I believe it is essential from an environmental perspective that the ban on the use of toxic heavy metals be fully implemented and that we do not weaken the responsibility of manufacturers. By doing so, we eliminate the incentives for manufacturers to build and manufacture cars that produce less waste. The common position, achieved with great effort in the Council, which the Commission endorsed and which was also ratified by Parliament's Environment Committee, fully meets environmental requirements. Therefore, I find the amendments tabled by members of the Environment Committee, which aim to weaken environmental requirements and, fundamentally, moderate the responsibility of car manufacturers, very strange and incomprehensible. If these amendments are adopted, I truly believe we will have thrown Parliament's credibility on environmental issues out the window. Until now, this Parliament has acted positively as a catalyst in environmental protection, and if the amendments tabled by Mr. Florenz and Mr. Lange are adopted, we will now be a negative environmental factor in this case. Added to this is the fact that if we soften manufacturers' liability in this case, this will have serious repercussions in other areas in the future, such as the upcoming directive on electronic and computer waste. Therefore, I would like to recommend to the Members of this Parliament, regardless of their political affiliation, that they vote against the amendments tabled to the common position, which will weaken the environmental standard and soften manufacturers' liability.

As Members of Parliament, we must emphasize with particular emphasis that the work begun to consolidate fundamental rights is becoming even more important. It is increasingly important that respect for and integrity of human dignity and minority rights, including the rights of all persons residing within the European Union, become an essential part of the principles of the rule of law in the European Union, and therefore we must ensure that the Charter of Fundamental Rights becomes legally binding. This Charter must not remain a mere declaration. It is also important that Austrian democratic forces be supported, as we have no intention on our part to isolate Austria. We know that the majority of Austrians respect these values. Austrians have also organized demonstrations; not all of them have taken place outside Austria. Certainly, many citizens who actively abstain from elections by voting for nonexistent candidates and who have long desired a change in Austrian politics have also been mobilized. In my opinion, Parliament must support these democratic forces. I also call on the President of Austria to examine all possibilities of forming a government composed of democratic forces. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I simply want to underline the value of a position such as the one just recalled by the Chairman of our Group, Mr. Francis Wurtz. I value the statements of the Council Presidency and the position of the 14 states that have rejected official contacts with the Austrian government in the event that Jörg Haider's party were included. Our comment is even more important because, as you know, we substantially disagree with the policies pursued by this Europe: its economic and social policies, its democratic deficit, the involvement of these same states in the dramatic war in the Balkans. This disagreement underscores even more, if possible, today's assessment: an exceptional element, because the danger of a resurgence of an irrational and neo-Nazi component in Europe is exceptional. This danger does not affect Austria, it affects Europe. We are talking about us, not Austria. We are aware of the social causes that, along with unemployment and uncertainty, contribute to fostering trends in this direction. We are aware of the cultural causes—xenophobic, racist—but we cannot fail to recognize in the inability and unwillingness of these far-right forces to settle accounts with Nazism the possibility of creating an explosive mixture in Europe. It speaks of the Alpine arc, it speaks of all our states: conditions are being created under which a danger to European democracy and civilization could be reborn. The Presidency's position has shown awareness of this civilizational tragedy. Europe shows that it has not forgotten Auschwitz; Europe finds a soul. Now, however, it should be consistent with its actions, and the first to be consistent should be the Commission, which, on the contrary, has demonstrated on this issue a lack of transparency and a weakness that make the value of the Presidency's position even more evident.

However, the item was withdrawn from the Budget Committee's agenda last night without any debate or vote. Therefore, it should be removed from today's agenda. That makes sense, Mr. Wynn. The report is therefore withdrawn. Mr. Chairman, I presume that the comments Ms. Lynne made yesterday about health and safety in this building related to the pipes because there is a foul odor on the fifth floor of the tower block. This issue needs to be addressed because it clearly indicates a serious failing. I do not want to keep harping on the problems in this building, but this is a serious matter of concern. Ms. Ahern, we have noted this. I would ask you to refer this specific case, which concerns the fans on a particular floor, to the Quaestors, who are in fact responsible for these types of problems. However, we will also raise it with our departments. Thank you very much. (The minutes are adopted) Reform of European competition policy The next item is the joint debate on the following reports: A5-0069/1999 by Mr von Wogau, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Commission White Paper on the modernisation of the rules implementing Articles 85 and 86 of the EC Treaty (COM(1999) 101 - C5-0105/1999 - 1999/2108(COS)); A5-0078/1999 by Mr Rapkay, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the 28th report from the Commission on competition policy (1998) (SEC(1999)743 - C5-0121/1999 - 1999/2124(COS)); A5-0087/1999 by Mr Jonckheer, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the seventh report on State aid in the manufactured goods sector and certain other sectors of the European Union (COM(1999) 148 - C5-0107/1999 - 1999/2110(COS)); A5-0073/1999 by Mr Langen, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Commission report on the application in 1998 of its Decision No 2496/96/ECSC of 18 December 1996 establishing Community rules for aid to the steel industry (Steel Aid Code) (COM(1999)094 - C5-0104/1999 - 1999/2107(COS)). Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today we are holding an important debate on the European Union's competition policy. We are debating a highly controversial plan to modernise European antitrust law, namely the von Wogau report, a subject that is far more controversial than the vote in the Committee on Economic Affairs appears to indicate. I would like to say at the outset that, for my part, and in this specific case, I believe the Commission's proposal to be flawed and that it remains to be determined whether the concept of modernisation is truly justified with regard to the content of the White Paper on Articles 81 and 82 or whether, in this case, a step backwards would not be the appropriate concept. However, today we are also discussing the report on State aid and the general report on competition policy for 1998, and my contribution to this joint discussion concerns the latter report.

The legal obligation to achieve zero emissions and to cease discharges within 20 years would in fact mean a ban on the use of all the substances identified. These provisions risk creating enormous problems for transboundary basins and candidate countries and, consequently, complicating enlargement. I would like to mention one sector in particular which I follow very closely, agriculture, the main consumer of water: it must, as it has already begun to do, assume its share on the basis of the polluter-pays principle, but account must also be taken of specific features and constraints, particularly in arid regions. As regards the amendments on radioactive substances, I am in favour of controls, but the question arises as to the legal basis which falls within the scope of the EURATOM Treaty. Andersson report (A5-0033/2000) The EDD Group was unable to vote in favour of the Andersson report. It certainly contains valid points; among other things, it is admitted, on page 15, in the explanatory statement that "the different levels of development and the different traditions of the Member States in the field of social protection make uniform harmonisation impossible". The concept of "uniform harmonisation" is one of those hastily put together expressions which obscure the process of integration which is being discussed. It is also true, as stated in the explanatory statement, that harmonisation would be harmful, since "it would impose greater efforts on the weaker Member States and, like competition, would push the more socially developed States to proceed with cuts in social protection systems. Such harmonisation would benefit no one". And yet, that is how things are: a social model is created, which in reality involves harmonisation, and uniform harmonisation at that. In point D. it is stressed that "the union can bring added value by defining truly binding and effective convergence criteria", and further on in the report it is pointed out that the development of this convergence process is promoted through discussions between the ECOFIN Council and the Council of Ministers for Social Affairs and Employment, and finally in point 7 it is stressed that "the process aimed at creating social convergence must be accompanied by effective and ambitious fiscal convergence". And here we come to the heart of the matter: this social harmonisation project does not concern social policy, but is a continuation of the European Union's EMU project which is of very particular interest to the three countries that are outside it, and which can be saved from this Titanic, namely Great Britain, Sweden and Denmark, which is why it is important for us to underline that we cannot support a proposal whose fundamental basis is to expand the EMU project. Mr President, I voted in favour of the Commission's measure on the modernisation of social protection because, in my opinion, it goes in the direction - although not quite there - of finally providing European legislation in the social and pension fields.

Now, we believe—and I believe this is the Commission's interpretation—that the entire approximation process, at the level of assessing the acquis aimed at the island's comprehensive integration into the European Union in the event of a future accession, requires the participation, as soon as possible, of the northern communities of the island and the possibility that the European Union, in its efforts to assess the conditions for accession, may also have access to elements that will allow it to substantiate the accession project itself. On the other hand, this means that, on the part of the Council, we must encourage—and I believe this Parliament could do so as well—the Commission's participation in this effort. I believe we cannot fail to send a message of confidence to the Commission regarding its role in this regard. Finally, I believe that we must continue to actively collaborate—and this is also the intention of the Presidency—with the United Nations, given the skill, intelligence, and ability with which the Secretary-General and the United Nations structure itself have been able to guide this debate and, in particular, have sought to contribute to the harmonization of positions between the parties. As I said at the beginning, it is evident that the conclusions of the European Summit in Helsinki in December last year had a clear impact on the evolution of the positions of the various parties in the process. The Government of Nicosia expressed its satisfaction with the Helsinki conclusions, which offer the possibility of accession to the European Union without first resolving the division of the island. However, I cannot help but notice that these same authorities express concern about the pressure they may face to resolve the issues raised by this division, which, as is evident, entail some concessions. This is related to the developments that have taken place regarding population transfers and the possibility of a related reorganization in the event of a different solution for the island. On the other hand, Turkish Cypriots fear—and it's also not worth hiding—that Turkey's candidacy for the European Union will induce Ankara to soften its position on the matter. I believe that, regardless of whether these may be some of the misgivings harbored by the two communities regarding this rapprochement, these aspects, which could lead to a negative interpretation of the situation by the authorities on both sides, could also be the underlying reason for harboring some hope for a final solution. For this final solution, one of the most important elements characterizing relations in that region and in this period will clearly be essential: the extraordinarily positive development of relations between Athens and Ankara and the extremely important role played in them by the Greek Foreign Minister, George Papandreou, and the Turkish Foreign Minister, Ismail Cem. We believe that within this framework, the conditions for a positive development have been created. For our part, as President of the Council, we will continue to closely monitor these developments and will continue to cooperate with the Secretary-General and his personal representative in this regard.

Mr Swoboda's balanced and praiseworthy report very concretely supports this surprising and pleasing conclusion. The European Union knows what it has to do in Macedonia: to help this recent regional haven for thousands of war refugees properly play its role as a stimulator of the desired stability pact for the Balkans. Mr President, I have been concerned about the fate of Macedonia for eight years and I would like to contradict Mr Dupuis. What we are doing here is in no way a masterpiece of hypocrisy. We intervened at the right time and I think the Macedonians are very happy about it. So stop being so hateful and water down your wine. I think we should approach this matter in a more positive way. Macedonia did not participate in the war. On the other hand, it suffered greatly from the war its neighbors were waging and from the sanctions that were rightly imposed on them. It is still suffering from this. It also suffered from the influx of refugees during the Kosovo war. Therefore, it must also be said that Macedonia's development has, surprisingly enough, continued to evolve on a democratic basis. This is a country that has to overcome serious inter-ethnic problems internally and is succeeding in doing so more and more successfully. I would like to make it clear that we can congratulate Macedonia on having drawn up and now implementing exemplary legislation on respect for minorities. Taking into account the 30% of Albanian speakers in government action, in government policy and in society is the essential condition for peaceful coexistence in Macedonia. I am pleased that the wish expressed by Mr Swoboda in his report can be fulfilled at the beginning of March, namely that an EU delegation will finally be established there and that we can finally restore the image of the European Union there. The launch of negotiations on the stability and association process is, in my view, the logical conclusion of the positive developments that have taken place in this country. As part of our political commitment, Macedonia must finally be able to see in practice that its own highly commendable regional cooperation is being rewarded by the effective implementation of regional projects. I will mention just two of a smaller scale: the rapid resolution of the problem of the border crossing into Kosovo at Blace and the development of Corridor 8, which runs from Albania to Bulgaria via Macedonia. I find the report by my colleague Swoboda remarkable and I can only fully support it. Mr President, I too would like to congratulate our colleague Swoboda on his report. I think it is good that so many of us support the approach he has chosen. It is a structural approach to stability in the region and it is also the content of the planned agreement with the Republic of Macedonia that we are debating today. While the practical implementation of the Stability Pact has yet to be initiated, the Commission has moved quickly to finalise the new instrument called the Stabilisation and Association Agreement.

The European Union must exercise all its powers, through all its bodies, to resolve these and other disputes. Mr President, earlier this week, President Prodi announced that full employment would be one of the Commission's strategic objectives for the next five years. He acknowledged that there are currently 15 million Europeans seeking work and that unemployment is the main source of poverty and social exclusion. Moreover, the Portuguese Presidency considers combating unemployment a top priority. But all too often, these political priorities are not reflected in day-to-day politics. A typical case is the Commission's decision to approve the ABB-Alstom merger. The new company has declared its intention to develop a restructuring plan aimed at achieving savings. This global restructuring plan could result in the loss of up to 12,000 jobs. Particularly in my region of the UK, the employment consequences of the merger were severe, as a result of ABB-Alstom's announcement that it would save 270 jobs in the UK, 95 of which would be lost in Stafford and 112 in Rugby. The company's failure to inform the works council of the merger proposals is particularly worrying. This is particularly important in the case of large international companies, where decisions are made remotely from the employee. Point 17 of the Community Charter of the Fundamental Social Rights of Workers stresses the need for consultation, adding that this applies particularly to companies with establishments in two or more Member States. In my view, this is not just a matter for a Community Charter. EU law could not be clearer on this issue. In such a situation, the Commission would do well to base its decision not simply on whether a merger would distort competition, but also on taking into account the social and economic consequences. We need a more coordinated policy on these issues. What we also urgently need is a study to assess the impact of mergers in every situation. Only in this way will Article 127 of the Treaty be respected. I welcome Commissioner Liikanen's statement, but I also expect the support of this Parliament to ensure that the laws we have adopted on workers' rights are strictly implemented and that assessments of the impact of proposed mergers are taken for granted. I have received seven motions for resolutions tabled pursuant to Rule 37(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The vote will take place this evening. The debate is closed. (The sitting adjourned at 3:50 p.m. and resumed at 4:05 p.m.) Topic and matter of priority debate The next item is the debate on topical, urgent and major subjects. Racist and xenophobic incidents in El Ejido (Spain) The next item is the joint debate on the following motions for resolutions: B5-0149/2000 by Mr Galeote Quecedo and others, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, on the racist and xenophobic incidents in the El Ejido area (Spain); B5-0159/2000 by Mr Gasòliba i Böhm and Mr Sánchez García, on behalf of the Group of the European Liberal, Democrat and Reform Party, on the racist and xenophobic incidents in El Ejido (Spain); B5-0162/2000 by Mrs Díez González and others, on behalf of the Group of the Party of European Socialists, on the outbreak of racism and xenophobia in El Ejido (Almería);

Unfortunately, the European Commission has already made progress in its guidelines, and Parliament's position carries little weight in the programmes for the 2000-2006 period. However, it is important to stress the need for these funds to prioritize the development of the countries and regions facing the greatest difficulties and the outermost regions, such as the Azores and Madeira regions in Portugal, with a view to achieving economic and social cohesion. The truth is that the Commission's guidelines do not fully meet these objectives. Furthermore, it is important that there be specific guidelines and sufficient funding in the areas of creating quality jobs with rights, as well as the effective promotion of equal rights and opportunities, in support for the social and solidarity economy, rural development, small and medium-sized enterprises, and improving the quality of life of urban populations in disadvantaged areas, particularly in the social housing sector, with a view to sustainable urban development. While the content of Article 158 of the EC Treaty is intended to promote the harmonious development of all the communities, it must be said that the complete elimination of disparities is still a long way off. In some cases, such as the Italian regions falling under Objective 1, these disparities are even paradoxically increasing, above all due to the still weak capacity of the structural apparatus to approach Community procedures and because of the persistent tangle of procedures. Despite regulatory interventions, the flexibility of Community structures still needs to be achieved. Without administrative simplification first, it will be difficult to achieve the Community objectives of reforms characterized by efficiency and concentration. In this sense, the Commission document is deficient, lacking any recommendation to Member States to simplify national procedures and legislation regarding the presentation and examination of projects by national authorities, as well as regarding financing, implementation and control. SMEs, micro-enterprises and craftsmen in particular are still "weak subjects" because for them, the legislative and administrative constraints imposed by certain Member States, including Italy, constitute major obstacles to accessing the Structural Funds. A major handicap lies in the inability and impossibility of regions and other subjects to program in time. This is why the Commission, which should have consulted Parliament in time, by virtue of the Decision on the 97/99 Guidelines (Howitt Report), in fact found a kind of easy alibi in the constitution of the reduced programming phase within the Member States and published the Guidelines as early as July 1999, well before the newly elected Parliament began its legislative activities, thus preventing it from acting on the current range of guidelines. The interim evaluation of Article 42 of Regulation 1260/99 will therefore be of significant importance. The current guidelines generally lack the merit of being clear and transparent. However, they only touch on one important issue: the possibility of measuring progress made against verifiable objectives and in full harmony with Community policy strategies. They do not properly address the implications of enlargement, especially since they do not contain specific provisions or clarifications on this matter, either for regional and national authorities or for the candidate countries.

We all agree in condemning intolerance, but we also agree that we must look ahead, and the culprits need not be sought here, in this Parliament, or in many other parliaments: the culprits for what happened in El Ejido are this minority who wanted to satisfy their thirst for revenge against a few immigrants. But we must bear in mind that solutions never arise from revenge. Solutions must arise from effective cooperation between all authorities, aimed at social integration and respect for all those who work there, from a determined fight against illegal immigration and full respect for the rights of foreign workers working legally in El Ejido and throughout Europe. Mr President, this resolution is about solidarity with the democratic forces in Spain that are fighting for respect for human rights. All Spanish democrats who feel hurt by the events in their country have our full and unconditional support. Not only were immigrants victims of terrible riots, but Spain's democratic system has also been trampled upon, despite the enormous potential for development it has demonstrated over the past 20 years. Immigrant workers are indispensable to employers. Their working conditions are so harsh and inhumane that no Spaniard will accept them. Extremely low wages, a housing shortage—some live in cardboard shacks—a lack of access to social services, an effectively existing apartheid situation—all of this is shameful, unacceptable, and incompatible with the necessary respect for every human being. The events in El Ejido are nothing other than racist and xenophobic practices that are no longer permissible in today's Europe. The persecution of immigrants lasted four days. Women and children were beaten. Hundreds of immigrants, who had fled from all over, have taken refuge on a hill on the outskirts of the city. It is right to place Haider's Austria on the Index, but we must equally not tolerate small, local "Haiders" pursuing a policy of racist exclusion and ruthless economic domination. What happened in Spain could happen in all our Union countries if we are not vigilant. We all have a duty to clean up our own backyards. I support this motion for a resolution, in particular the paragraphs referring to Article 13 of the Treaty of Amsterdam, as well as paragraph 11 of this resolution, which establishes a link between the Structural Funds and the fight against exclusion. It would be a credit to the European Parliament to firmly condemn these events and support all proposals for respect for migrant workers in Spain and throughout the Union. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, the flames of racist and xenophobic violence are flaring up in the heart of Europe today. This violence is being fueled everywhere by extremist movements that are gaining influence. We must now take concrete measures to put an end to such violations of physical integrity. None of our societies in Europe can fully develop if there is a risk of hatred erupting among one part of its population against another.

I can only call on the Conference of Presidents to reach an agreement as quickly as possible on the correct comitological procedure for citations. This would considerably facilitate the future work of the rapporteurs of this House. A proposal for an amendment has also been put forward to the two reports by our colleague Mr De Palacio. I must unfortunately say that I will not be able to support this proposal because it affects the substance of the result we unanimously reached in the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, and I would like to adhere to this result, which was the result of lengthy discussions. In conclusion, I would like to thank all my colleagues who supported me in the Committee on Legal Affairs during the preparation of these reports, which were not exactly easy. I would particularly like to mention Mr Wieland, who assumed the thankless role of shadow rapporteur and who played a much greater role than is customary in the preparation of this report, contributing excellent and constructive ideas, without being able to take the laurels of rapporteurship. That is why I wanted to emphasize this point in this chamber. Mr President, I am pleased to have the opportunity, following the intervention of the rapporteur, Mrs Berger, to make some preliminary remarks before listening, with all due attention, to the following speakers and, if you will allow me, Mr President, to examine the individual amendments in more detail at the end of the debate. May I say that the Commission welcomes the support shown by the European Parliament for the two proposals on the freedom to provide services for third-country national workers, the subject we are currently debating? I particularly thank Mrs Berger for the work she has devoted to dealing with these two proposals, which are politically sensitive and legally challenging. I also wish to sincerely thank Mrs Palacio for the important contribution she has made as Chair of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market. The Commission particularly welcomes Parliament's suggestions for a more efficient procedure for issuing the services card. If the option is offered to apply for this card for one, several, or all Member States, the procedure becomes even more flexible. The Commission also agrees with the proposal to relax the validity period of the card. However, I believe that a period of three months of work is insufficient to prove that a worker is established in a Member State. The Commission can also approve the determination of cases in which an employment contract concluded between a service provider and his employee is abruptly terminated. The efficiency of the procedure for issuing this card means that companies providing cross-border services can genuinely exercise their rights within the territory of the internal market. We believe it is excessive to grant other Member States, for reasons of public policy, the systematic possibility of carrying out checks for the purpose of issuing a card.

To further strengthen the European Union's role in international development policy, we consider it fundamentally necessary to develop three types of measures. The first concerns increasing the effectiveness of its development policy. As is known, an overall evaluation of development policy was carried out in 1995, and a summary of this overall evaluation was presented during the German Presidency. The main conclusions emphasize the need for a more coherent European Union policy and a general strategic vision of development problems within the European Union. Particular emphasis is placed on the need for closer coordination and greater complementarity of measures, the harmonization and simplification of the organizational framework within which the Union's cooperation policy currently takes place, more effective aid management, and a review of its intervention mechanisms in particular, as well as the need to expand the evaluation system and to be more transparent about how this aid is used. A second aspect would be the need for greater complementarity between the European Union and the policies of individual Member States. As is well known, a significant proportion of aid is currently deployed through the actions of the Member States, which are not always complementary and coordinated. And it is precisely this inability to coordinate and ensure complementarity between the Member States' projects and the actions planned and implemented by the European Union institutions that is largely responsible for the wasted or ineffective use of aid from within the European Union. We also believe that it is essential that we are in a position, in the near future, to do everything possible to develop mechanisms for complementarity and coordination between the policies pursued by the Member States and those of the European Union. A third aspect that deserves emphasis is the strengthening and coherence of their policies, which is the central theme of today's debate. First and foremost, we are all aware that it is not enough to create more favourable conditions for aid; what is needed is better integration of it with other European Union actions, so that development objectives can be achieved not only through aid and assistance, but above all through a more integrated view of the individual actions contributing to them. As is well known, a Council resolution was adopted in June 1997, and the Commission undertook to submit evaluation reports. The first report was submitted to the Council in May 1999, and it already sets out some aspects of the coordination of policies, particularly in the areas of peacekeeping, food security, fisheries, and migration. However, as is also known, a Commission communication on coherence is expected to accompany the communication on "development policy." Of course, the contributions that the Commission intends to present on this topic in the coming months, even during the Portuguese Presidency, can also be incorporated into this debate. It is clear that policy coherence will always remain limited, and a certain degree of inconsistency between policies is also an element of balance and balancing of the contradictory and opposing interests at work within the Union. Only in this way is it possible to address a certain degree of inconsistency between policies.

This was never our intention. The fact that we are opening negotiations first and foremost with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia shows that we can and do differentiate. With regard to the regional aid mentioned in the report, we also believe that our technical and financial support should also benefit, among other things, projects with a cross-border or regional dimension. We support the inclusion of an evolution clause on the accession perspective in the Stabilisation and Association Agreement. Such a clause reflects the European Union's position on its relations with the Western Balkan countries, as set out in the conclusions of the Cologne European Council. We also consider the greatest possible decentralisation of our aid programmes to be necessary. As Members of the House are aware, we are currently drafting a new regulation regarding European Union assistance to the Western Balkan countries in order to simplify and streamline the management of the programmes and to consolidate all measures into one regulation. I know that there is concern in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and elsewhere about the end of the PHARE programme in those countries, and in particular about the abandonment of the PHARE name. I note with considerable concern what Members have said on this issue. I will look again at this issue, although I would point out that having two PHARE programmes can really cause confusion. I would like to stress, however, that our support for the integration of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and its neighbouring countries into the European family, whatever the name of the programme, is greater than ever. I am sure that Members of this House share my delight that Macedonia has reached this stage in a relatively short space of time. I hope that the other countries in the region will redouble their efforts to be able to make similar progress. I look forward to the further debates we will have on this subject in the coming years, and I hope that the successes of our efforts in the Balkans will be a central focus, because for me the Balkans are a touchstone of what Europe can achieve on its own doorstep. Thank you, Commissioner Patten. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon. Agreement on committee procedures The next item is the report (A5-0021/2000) by Mrs Frassoni, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the agreement between the European Parliament and the Commission on the procedures for implementing the new Council Decision of 28 June 1999 - 'comitology' (1999/468/EC). Mr President, by adopting this agreement between the European Parliament and the Commission on the procedures for implementing the Council decision on comitology, we are bringing to a close a matter that has occupied Parliament and a number of passionate advocates of this issue, scattered throughout the various institutions of the European Union and openly described by some as masochists, for about two years. Since 1993, the procedures for exercising the implementing powers conferred on the Commission, and in particular the inscrutable and even dubious committee system, have sown discord and mistrust between the institutions, which threatened to have serious repercussions for the legislative process.

As is known, the Commission should have already submitted, by 1998, new proposals on the revision of Directive 97/67 on postal services, aimed at guaranteeing the maintenance of the universal service, ensuring its economic sustainability, normalising the gradual liberalisation of the postal services market and taking into account the repercussions on the categories concerned, including workers and users. To this end, the Commission has had studies carried out on the cost of universal service, the consequences of the liberalisation of cross-border and advertising postal services, the repercussions of the reduction of the weight and value limits of the exclusive sector, the impact of the liberalisation of the remaining phases - beyond distribution - of the postal service, and the overall assessment of the results of the studies. Mr President, the question therefore arises - and, in the absence of Commissioner Bolkestein, I ask the expert Commissioner Monti, who I believe will wish to express his opinion - why not examine, in these studies, the socio-economic impact of the various foreseeable scenarios for liberalisation in each of the Member States? Indeed, postal services are very different in Greece, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands or Belgium. Following liberalisation, how will the universal postal service be financed and operated properly in a country like mine, Greece, which has a particular morphology of the territory, taking into account the numerous islands, often inhabited? How will the body responsible for the universal postal service survive in my country once the cross-border service, which in Greece corresponds to 25 percent and elsewhere to less than 5 percent, has been liberalised? How will the transfer of the national sector to a foreign country, which Mr McCartin also mentioned, be managed? Since this is a very likely eventuality, given that technological progress is making it increasingly simple and profitable, we should consider further liberalisation, gradually and controlled, with the relative setting of weight and value limits. But what will these limits be? Will companies - always skilled at selective exploitation - perhaps be granted the right to easily circumvent the weight limits, given that it is not possible to check the content of letters? In any case, Mr President and Commissioner, we ask the Commission to show its cards and to present its proposals, analysing the foreseeable developments from every point of view and for all Member States. It goes without saying that liberalisation is not an end in itself, but only a means to improve services. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the proposed liberalisation of traditional national postal services inevitably leads to the question of what activities the post office will consider its core business in the future. In other words: what services will the post office want to continue to offer? What activities will it be able to carry out jointly at international level? What areas will it intend to divest? In order to answer this question, it must be borne in mind that the old monopoly is no longer a de facto monopoly following the emergence of numerous courier services and the introduction of technological developments such as fax and e-mail. On the other hand, employment is of fundamental importance in the case of the liberalisation of postal services.

I would like to know what Europe and you, Mr Solana, are doing now, or intend to do in the near future, to avert this threat of war: it can still be prevented today - tomorrow it may already be too late. I would also like to know whether, in this context, something could not be done to encourage the Iraqi Government to make a humanitarian gesture, that is, to provide information on the whereabouts of the 615 missing Kuwaitis or, if they are in its power, to release them. As we sit here, hundreds of thousands of people are in grave danger because of the floods in Mozambique. This did not happen suddenly. The floods have been going on for weeks, and only now does the need for action seem to have arisen. The practical support from the Community and the Member States has so far been more than modest. For some time, many of us have warned that the European Union is spending too much time on its potentially dangerous and essentially political project of creating military decision-making structures, instead of concentrating its efforts on improving its civilian instruments, particularly for humanitarian aid. I acknowledge Mr. Patten's efforts in this direction, but it is very regrettable that the governments of the Member States have not invested as much time in analyzing their capacities for disaster relief and humanitarian aid as they have in the dangerous business of creating military capacities that ultimately only create structures parallel to NATO and thus undermine it. Of course, there is a connection between the availability of equipment and personnel and humanitarian aid, but serious deficiencies in the military sphere exist in the armed forces of many European countries and have existed for some time. NATO has set about addressing these. So far, I have not heard a convincing security policy explanation as to why the European Union must establish autonomous, decision-making capacities for the deployment of armed forces outside NATO structures if it does not want to create bodies that will compete with NATO. After all, the EU Member States are either full members of NATO or sit at the table in the Euro-Atlantic Partnership Council. NATO is predominantly European in character. In conclusion, I would simply like to ask you, Mr Solana, what is the point of having the much-heralded strategic planning and early warning unit in the Council Secretariat when we are caught completely by surprise when another humanitarian catastrophe befalls us? Mr President, Mr High Representative, Mr Commissioner, we have noted the particularly reserved and almost complacent attitude of the international community in general, and the European Union in particular, towards the war in Chechnya. What has happened and is still happening in Chechnya is comparable to genocide. How else can one describe the complete destruction of a regional capital with 400,000 inhabitants, the incessant and excessive shelling of towns, villages, and residential areas where the entire civilian population was present—perhaps mixed with a few Chechen fighters? What should one call the shameful concentration camp-like filtration camps in which the population is subjected to the worst humiliations and from which healthy men between the ages of 15 and 65 rarely emerge alive?

I share his impatience to ensure the full implementation of reform mechanisms and change practices. I wish I could tell him honestly that we will be drafting and presenting communication proposals before 2001 and certainly implementing them before 2002, but he should know that consultation procedures and deadlines are legally required and we must respect them. I do not use that as an excuse. The very positive and constructive response resulting from the consultation last month gives us great encouragement, and I believe, therefore, that although there may be a slight delay in compiling and implementing the reforms, they will nevertheless be strengthened by the breadth of understanding and commitment that will result from this consultation, which we will conduct assiduously. I would like to see it all happen much more quickly. It had better be done absolutely properly. Madam President, we admire Mr. Kinnock's vision and realism because, while he holds out the promise of a successful and perfectly functioning administration, he does not fail to highlight the difficulties that will arise and which we must already expect. Mr. Prodi pointed out that he wanted to disengage from certain tasks. Policy priorities will therefore have to be defined. I think it is more important to first determine what we want to do before disengaging, to avoid alienating a large number of people. That is my opinion. Furthermore, the enlargement of the Union is one of the major challenges. I would also like to point out that maintaining peace will require greater efforts to involve a greater number of people in this area. The rather bureaucratic approach we are currently experiencing, particularly in our overall development cooperation, will have to resolutely give way to cooperation for peace. Can Mr. Kinnock explain what he expects from the Council and Parliament regarding the timing of such priorities? I thank Mrs. Maes not only for the statement she has just made, but also for the continued commitment she has shown to change since she joined this House. I would like to assure her that our behavior is not guided by any desire to shirk certain tasks. We are focusing on essential tasks, on priorities, not with the aim of evading any obligation, but to absolutely guarantee that we can fully meet the central obligations we have. One of these obligations is very clear—and I agree with Mrs. Maes here—and that is the preparation for an effective, serene, and smooth enlargement, an enlargement that will serve the mutual interests of both the peoples of the acceding countries and the citizens of the existing Union. Ensuring that we are able to fulfil this absolutely critical role as agents of the widest possible enlargement is one of the reasons why we must ensure that we focus very strongly and very intensely on our priorities.

There is no equivocal silence from the Council on this matter, Mr Wurtz. The Council assumes full responsibility for its reading of the situation in Cyprus. It was this situation and this reading that led it, in Luxembourg at the end of 1997, to initiate the process of the Republic of Cyprus's accession to the European Union. I would like you to understand that, regardless of the more or less emotional decisions taken on this type of issue, the daily routine of international negotiations normally requires governments, and I say governments, I mean all governments, to have a slightly more flexible reading. We need, in fact, more emotional positions to maintain the scenario in which all these issues are projected on the human level. But we must also bear in mind that it is thanks to the rational nature of political positions and flexibility in negotiation that we can find solutions that will enable us to overcome major differences, which have ultimately been the cause of some of the great tragedies in history. Regardless of the culprits—we are not here to draw up a list of culprits; the relevant UN resolutions in this area are clear—I believe that we must take advantage, without emotion and with greater rationality, of the opportunities offered by the new situation. The Helsinki European Council had the courage to take certain decisions, and I believe that various parts of these decisions already take due account of these opportunities to the extent that they can, as I said at the beginning of my opening remarks, constitute a window of opportunity. It is not by exploiting tensions in this phase of negotiations, which is a delicate, sensitive phase, that we will be able to achieve concrete results. It is precisely through discreet work, work in support of the mission of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General of the United Nations that we must continue. The European Union's position on this matter is unequivocal, ladies and gentlemen, and I believe that it is not worthwhile to engage in second readings on possible sentences that might be found in the Council's speech or in another position. We are not, in this Parliament, playing for political correctness; we are playing for what is right internationally and for what are the concrete positions defined by the Council, for a long time and consistently, and which the European Commission has also followed with prudence, attention and pragmatism. When we speak at this time of the need to involve the community of the northern part of Cyprus in an exchange of information, particularly on the path towards the future accession of the Republic of Cyprus to the European Union, we must be aware that we are trying to find formulas of a practical nature that will allow us to overcome the obstacles on the path to a political solution. We are not looking for subterfuges and we are not seeking to create, through practical solutions, any models that present recognition of a political nature.

Technical assistance is still needed, however. Particular attention should also be paid to disseminating results and mutual learning through best practices and mainstreaming. I have ensured that this report receives the broadest possible support. This objective led to a reduction in the number of amendments – from 100 in committee to 22 in plenary – which has opened up numerous opportunities for compromise. We even managed to reach a compromise on the issue of asylum seekers. In this connection, however, I ask Madam President to hold the vote on the EQUAL report on Wednesday instead of Tuesday, so that we can still work on some details. I believe it is important that this Community initiative can begin on time and that this report enjoys broad support in this House, so that the Commission is also obliged to take Parliament's constructive proposals into consideration. The resources allocated to EQUAL have in fact been set aside by the European Parliament so that the expectations of parliamentarians can also be reflected in the Community initiative. In this regard, the European Parliament's insistence that any amendment to the essential points can only take place after a new hearing by the House is also justified. EQUAL must deserve its name; that is my firm intention. It must guarantee equal opportunities for all disadvantaged people in the European Union. It must prevent the dislocation of our society. It must prevent marginalisation from becoming a part of everyday life. It must offer everyone the opportunity to benefit from a common initiative, regardless of their age, gender or origin. That is my intention, and I ask this House to give this report its broadest support. Madam President, the fact that we are holding this debate on the new Urban Initiative is an achievement in itself, as is my presence here with you this evening, since Air France cancelled my flight at 2:10 p.m., but I am here! Exactly a year ago, when the Commission presented its Agenda 2000 proposals, it scrapped the Urban Initiative. Yet we, as politicians, knew that there was strong support for continuing the initiative in the year 2000. Therefore, Parliament can claim to have waged a productive lobbying campaign to put Urban back on the agenda and to have succeeded in changing the minds of the Commission and the Council. Urban policy has always been at the forefront of EU policy. In my Member State, for example, we are developing a strategic approach in a White Paper, and a government task force on urban development is examining the problems of urban communities.
