Eight out of ten people in Europe live in urban areas, so it's only right that we help our most disadvantaged communities address the all-too-familiar problems of deprivation, social exclusion, unemployment, crime, drug abuse, and all the issues that come with them. For example, in my area of Manchester, the Urban Community Initiative has been successful.

Above all, integration mechanisms should be created. Perhaps most important is the development of an infrastructure capable of enhancing the participation of non-expansive sectors and peripheral population groups. Therefore, I believe that investments should be made in computer equipment for primary schools, a broadband network for sparsely populated areas, public technology libraries, and a public sector that must not be diminished but, on the contrary, strengthened. Mr President, the agenda for the European Council in Lisbon, which will take place on 23 and 24 March, is enough to make one dizzy. This is true, for example, of the chapter headings alone, which mention a Europe of innovation and knowledge, structural reforms, competitiveness, the European social model, employment, social cohesion, macroeconomic policies, and sustainable economic growth. It is therefore not surprising that, among the numerous contributions by the Presidency, the Commission, and the Member States, there is a tendency at the moment to disperse in all directions. This approach could lead to two entirely different outcomes: either it would facilitate a comprehensive exchange of highly stimulating ideas, which each would then attempt to implement in its own country, perhaps leading to joint action in the new field of electronic commerce—and this possibility would not be such a bad thing after all—or the Council would be keen to produce results that would transfer further powers to Europe, which would mean even more centralization and bureaucracy, precisely the opposite of what is actually needed. Reading the preparatory documents, we have some concerns about this. They suggest—forgive this gibberish, which is not my own—that there is a need for better convergence between the Cologne Process on the coordination of macroeconomic policies, the Cardiff Process on structural reforms, and the Luxembourg Process on the coordination of employment policies, while also giving substance to the Employment Pact and the multilateral surveillance of budgetary policies. How can such better convergence of all these different processes be ensured? The conclusion of the Council Presidency document of January 12 provides the key. The Broad Economic Policy Guidelines—which currently have the status of mere annual recommendations from the Council to the Member States—need to be reformed to broaden their scope and, above all, to further develop their character as a framework document. The word "framework" is obviously intended here to have a dual meaning: summary and commitment. With these comprehensive documents, aren't we reinventing the GOSPLAN? This question is legitimate, especially when one reads the French contribution, which goes even further toward dirigisme by proposing that a whole range of national policies, for example, in the areas of employment, social protection, and SMEs, be coordinated in Brussels and that a host of quantified indicators be set, which would then have to be monitored. Such centralised control would lead to further breaches of the principle of subsidiarity, to further standardisation of details, to further coordination imposed on the countries despite their different situations, and ultimately to new rigid rules in addition to those in the area of the single currency.

Italy, for example, has encountered difficulties in the use of structural funds in recent years, mainly due to excessive bureaucracy, a lack of information and the almost complete absence of involvement of economic and social operators at local level. There are therefore two points to which I would like to draw the Commission's attention: first, it is important to make the best use of consultation as an instrument for coordination and participation in the decisions of local and regional operators, precisely with the aim of avoiding imbalances and inequalities. Second, it is essential to simplify and make more transparent administrative processes, which too often are so long and unnecessarily complex that they hinder access to funds, something that European small and medium-sized enterprises are particularly concerned about. I conclude, Mr President, by stating that it is rather serious that the Commission, in its communication, has paid little attention to territorial pacts and, above all, to the methods for combating unemployment among women and young people. Mr President, like my colleague, Mr Evans, I am delighted that my maiden speech to this House is on such an important subject, particularly because I represent a part of the UK, the West Midlands, which has so far benefited from Objective 2 funding. But the report before Parliament this evening is a prime example of how, if we are not careful, we can create ideas that sound grandiose but lack the substance to be relevant to the people who directly benefit from them. The report itself is well-intentioned but, as so often happens when we deal with these matters, lacks clarity about its purpose and a sound basis for its operation. That is why my group and I are proposing three key amendments and additions to the text. This is not about taking anything away from the proposal but about making it more relevant to those it is intended to guide. Let me explain our thinking. First, we are concerned about the proper use of the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund. Past experience shows that we should and must, as elected representatives of European taxpayers, demand financial probity and transparency in the disbursement and monitoring of the allocated sums. Our amendments and additions are therefore aimed at establishing indicators of what is known as "value for money" in the process of granting credits. Second, we see all too often that enormous sums are spent on projects whose outcome is inevitably uncertain at the beginning of the programme period. But halfway through or at the end of that period, there is no effective way to terminate the project if it has not proven successful. Our additions therefore require the provision of practical and implementable exit strategies, so that not only can we have the necessary insurance against ongoing costs that taxpayers often have to bear, but we can also avoid the syndrome of getting stuck in a bad deal. Finally, we call for a change in the balance and method of disbursement of funds.

I would also like to praise the Council's sensible and flexible attitude. Save The next item is the report by Mrs Ahern (A5-0010/2000), on behalf of Parliament's delegation to the Conciliation Committee, on the joint text approved by the Conciliation Committee for a European Parliament and Council decision adopting a multiannual programme to promote energy efficiency - Save (C5-0334/1999 - 1997/0371(COD)). Madam President, I would like to thank the Council and the Commission for the successful and thorough conduct of the conciliation procedure, during which a good atmosphere prevailed throughout, which is not always the case. I am pleased to say that I consider the final result very satisfactory for Parliament, since all its amendments have been incorporated in full or in revised form into the joint text. The financial resources ultimately allocated to the programme also represent a significant improvement on the Council's proposal at second reading, which we considered totally unacceptable; we did make some progress there. I therefore propose that this House accept the proposals on SAVE and the conclusion of the conciliation at third reading. I would remind the House that at second reading we adopted this report with eight amendments, including the reinstatement of the amount originally proposed by the Commission. The Commission accepted five of the proposed amendments, including the appropriations, and I thank the Commission for its continued support on the budgetary issue during the conciliation procedure, as the Council's proposal was unacceptable. During the conciliation process, agreement was reached on the studies and actions to prepare, implement, supplement, and evaluate Community action. Furthermore, compromise wording was found for five other amendments, including legislative and non-legislative measures, the inclusion of local energy centers, and—very importantly—energy balance systems in monitoring progress in energy efficiency. I hope you all agree that this is a tremendous step forward. On the issue of funding, Parliament staunchly defended its position in the face of the Council's extremely meager initial offer. We had to hold several meetings on this before the Council finally increased the appropriations to a significant amount. We secured an increase of EUR 2 million over the initial amount, which represents a substantial increase in the budget. I can commend this budget to you, and the Commission has promised to follow it in implementing the program. This played an important role in our deliberations. However, I would like to make it clear that this is and always has been a very modest budget, and that the funding is more symbolic than it reflects real needs. The financing of energy savings still comes largely from the Member States. We must keep this in mind when we adopt this program. If what we can achieve at the Community level is more symbolic than real, that's unfortunate, because there's a lot of enthusiasm at the local level for energy-saving measures, including Community measures. But the Community can do one thing: bring local stakeholders together, so that the wheel isn't reinvented in every region.

Considering that the European Social Fund's contribution for the period 2000-2006 will amount to 2.487 billion euros and that the EQUAL initiative is jointly financed with the Member States, what will Greece's contribution rate be? - (EL) The EQUAL initiative is not limited to specific groups of people. It aims to address discrimination in the workplace. The decision to launch this initiative was taken in Berlin, and there it was decided that it would take into consideration and include in its actions the occupational groups of asylum seekers. I mention this as an important aspect of this initiative. The Community Initiative Programme of each Member State must comply with regulations, which are the same as the regulations of the European Social Fund; in other words, the EQUAL initiative complies with the regulations of the European Social Fund. It has been submitted to Parliament, and we await Parliament's opinion next month. I must emphasize that the EQUAL initiative responds to national needs and national plans, which are defined in accordance with the agreed European strategy. National governments are primarily responsible for setting up the joint agencies, submitting proposals, selecting the people who will implement the programs—and also for oversight in the first instance. Within the European Commission, the Directorate-General for Employment has responsibility for implementation, while financial oversight will, of course, be exercised by the Directorate-General for Financial Control, as well as by the European Anti-Fraud Office and the Court of Auditors. The final question concerns the amount granted. Greece has been granted 98 million ECUs, and the mandatory participation is 80%, while for the island regions, and especially the more remote Greek islands, the initiative's participation reaches 85%, with a corresponding share of 15%. Mr. President, I am of the opinion that the guidelines for the Community initiative EQUAL, and especially the four actions described therein, lead to a very complex and, paradoxically, opaque bureaucratic structure. For example, one wonders how a development partnership can demonstrate its spirit of collaboration or capacity for representation, as stated in Action 2 in paragraph 33 of the guidelines. Furthermore, the mandatory nature of interstate collaboration and the complex requirements for planning and implementing a development partnership inevitably lead to large organizations, which are the only ones capable of meeting such demands. This, however, contradicts the proclaimed intention of the general objectives, which contemplate decentralized action plans, specifically in the area of local government and rural areas. Moreover, at the same time, it makes the participation of the truly most disadvantaged—such as asylum seekers, migrants, and others—impossible or merely symbolic. Finally, considering the overall amount, which is rather small—2.8 billion euros for 15 countries and such ambitious targets—I fear that all we will ultimately achieve is to demonstrate that unemployment is a very bad thing. (EL) First of all, I would say that since we are at the stage of being drafted by Parliament, it will really help us a lot if we receive concrete proposals, which we will take into consideration. Secondly, I have to say that the objective of the EQUAL initiative is not to reduce unemployment. This initiative cannot address the issue of reducing unemployment, nor can it address support for job creation.

The Commission has been urged, and will do so in the first half of next year, to submit a report on the progress of the transposition of the decision into the Member States' domestic law, and also on whether the seriousness of the matter is reflected in the actions of the States. It has already been pointed out that this framework decision is a decision adopted in the field of criminal law. To that extent, this novelty, this step, must be acknowledged, even though you, Mr. Schulz, have indicated that supplementing such an old Convention is not a very bold step. Regarding your question as to whether, in the Commission's view, the framework decision rests on a legal basis that is sufficiently market-based: in the Commission's view, the correct legal basis is applied. Furthermore, the framework decision must be supplemented in the future by other legal acts. The Commission will submit a proposal for a regulation on cooperation between all competent authorities and cooperation with Europol. This proposal should establish an obligation to cooperate and regulate the obligation of national authorities to report cases of counterfeit currency and to hand over seized counterfeit currency to the European Central Bank for identification and classification, so that effective action can be taken. On the issue of coordination of the various measures: since the beginning of 1998, the Commission (and henceforth, OLAF will do so) has been collaborating with experts in the field from the Member States, the European Central Bank, and Europol to combat counterfeiting early and effectively. On the Commission's side, a few weeks ago, Mr. Karras, as you have already pointed out, a proposal was presented for an information campaign on the euro, to which at least €32 million would be allocated. This is a volume of resources that can be effectively deployed, in other words, a large volume of resources; of course, the protection of the euro against counterfeiting will occupy a prominent place in this information campaign. I believe that this debate also contributes to warning all counterfeiters who think their time has come at this very late hour because the EU is no longer awake, thanks to this debate shortly before midnight. Thank you very much, Commissioner Schreyer. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12:00. (The sitting was suspended at 11:50 p.m.) Resumption of the sitting. The minutes of yesterday's sitting have been distributed. Are there any comments? (The minutes were approved) Mr. President, I wish to make a comment concerning a meeting that took place last night between several Members of this Parliament, regardless of group. Several Vice-Presidents and Quaestors participated in it, and the architects who built this Chamber were also present, to seek ways of further improving the conditions under which our work is carried out. We discovered, at that meeting, that the curtain behind you, Mr. President, actually hides a large window. Now, it seems that if it were opened, we could contemplate a magnificent spectacle over the river; but we were told that it was kept closed to avoid backlighting, so that the chamber would be better illuminated during the debates.

The size, unpredictability, and irrationality of the global foreign exchange markets are making it increasingly difficult to control economies at the national and regional levels. Computer-controlled sales programs were enough to transform a random flash on a screen into an avalanche burying jobs, lives, and entire industries in every corner of the globe. The only arguments against this are: First, the efficiency of the foreign exchange markets would be compromised—hardly imaginable, given the enormous pace at which capital is moved back and forth, accompanied by the destruction of jobs throughout the world, in East Asia, Europe, and Latin America. Mr. Chirac once described those involved in this business as the AIDS virus of the global economy. We need to throw a little sand in the gears of currency speculators, stockbrokers, and options traders. Of course, this cannot be achieved by any single country or monetary union, but it is possible at the international level and through global cooperation. Europe, Japan, and the United States, the euro, the yen, and the dollar, would, in my view, constitute such a bloc. I am disappointed with the PPE. I thought the members would at least read the resolutions they are about to vote on. Yes, I support such a tax, but we will not be voting on that tomorrow. Tomorrow we will simply decide whether to task the Commission with investigating this area and examining what steps and conditions would be necessary for the introduction of such a tax. As far as I understand, the Commissioner also opposes such a tax. However, I cannot understand why he does not welcome a study on this topic, since the results could ultimately support his position. There is nothing worse than a preconceived opinion. According to a survey by "War on Want," 47% of all citizens in the United Kingdom support this tax. In France, this proposal has met with an overwhelming response, particularly in relation to the call for the revenue to be used to reduce debt and alleviate poverty in developing countries. This issue can no longer be ignored by Parliament, the Council, and the Commission. A large part of the public now demands a better answer than: "There has never been a tax like this before." In the new millennium, with its new problems that require global solutions, citizens demand sound arguments as to why such a tax cannot be introduced at present, and they do not want to hear the reasons that have previously opposed it. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a political compromise resolution on the benefits of taxing international financial transactions would be a first step toward the essential overhaul of numerous international regulations. One of the main demands of the protesters in Seattle was precisely the introduction of this type of tax, and this is no coincidence. Proposing it now would be a strong signal from the rich European countries that they are willing to abandon their selfish attitude, Commissioner. In everyone's view, such a solidarity tax is a laudable measure that does not hinder trade but primarily targets speculative transactions and their harmful effects, distinguished colleagues from the right-wing parties.

Does the Commission intend to adopt an action plan to increase women's active participation in environmental decision-making? Since 1988, the Commission has had an action plan for equal opportunities for women and men. The current program, which runs from 1997 to 2000, aims to develop a culture that integrates masculine and feminine values and takes into account the specific needs of each sex. One of the program's objectives is to prepare and monitor methods, strategies, and measures that promote equitable distribution of the sexes in decision-making processes, including senior positions. Within the framework of this program, each Directorate-General prepares a specific action plan. One of the objectives of the action plan is to increase the number of women in management positions. The new Commission aims to double the number of women in management positions during its term of office. The Directorate-General for the Environment, where currently 60 percent of directors and 20 percent of department heads are women, is particularly active in this area. Our policy is to encourage the incorporation of women into administrative positions, in order to create a pool of suitable candidates for future management positions. Currently, 24.5 percent of our category A employees are women. We hope that this proportion will continue to grow. In addition, we make efforts to attract qualified women to participate in our discussion forums. As for our external partners, we can only set good examples and urge them to make efforts to democratize their decision-making processes. Regarding more general issues regarding the integration of the perspective of equal opportunities between men and women, you are surely aware that this principle is enshrined in the Treaty of Amsterdam. Article 3 of the Treaty stipulates that the Community, in all matters relating to that article, shall aim to eliminate deficiencies and promote equal opportunities for men and women. The Commission supports the efforts being made in this area and is studying what specific measures can be adopted in environmental matters. Obviously, I would like to take this opportunity to say that I value the role of the European Parliament's Committee on Women's Rights and, especially, that of its President. Let me just recall that when the current Committee was approved, the Committee on Women's Rights asked each Commissioner how they would address equal opportunities between men and women in their area of work. We will closely monitor each of the Commissioners; in this way, I want to warn the others as well. Thank you for your reply. I interpret it as a yes, as a necessary action plan; an action plan to incorporate more women in specific environmental fields. Let me also say that the Beijing Declaration underlines the importance of having the institutional capacity to include the equal opportunities perspective in all environmental programs.

Now that things are clear, we must hope that the improved climate in relations between the European Union and Turkey and in Greek-Turkish relations will have a positive impact on the Turkish Cypriot community and that it will lift its refusal to send representatives to the accession negotiations. The presence of such representatives would in no way prejudge the final political solution. Quite the contrary. It would enable the interests of all to be promoted at a time when Cyprus, by joining the European Union, is about to take a decisive turn in its history. Mr President, I would also like to join the other speakers in expressing joy at the improved opportunities for the continued development of Cyprus as relations between Turkey and the EU and between Turkey and Greece improve. The EU must, in my view, contribute constructively to this development. I also believe - and this point has already been mentioned - that certain problems relating to the Financial Regulation need to be resolved. I am referring here to the pre-accession appropriations, which I believe fall under heading 7. Last year, the House exceptionally agreed to place the appropriations for this expenditure under heading 4, so that Cyprus and Malta are not treated as equals with the candidate countries of Central and Eastern Europe, although they should be, in accordance with the declarations made at the Helsinki Summit. Resources must therefore be allocated under heading 7, for which the Financial Perspective will have to be revised. That is the salient point. It is essential that the appropriations for pre-accession aid for Cyprus and Malta come from heading 7 and that the Financial Perspective is revised, because if the Council rejects this principle, it will be acting in contradiction with its own decisions taken in Helsinki in December. As for the amount in the Brok report – EUR 130 million – I would like to state, on behalf of the Liberal Group, that we must first negotiate the size of this amount. The main thing here is to ensure a multiannual programme, which falls under the appropriate heading, in order to begin preparations for the accession of Cyprus and Malta. Mr President, the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance supports the decision adopted by the Helsinki European Council that the resolution of the conflict cannot be a prerequisite for the accession of Cyprus. Strong pressure must be maintained on the Cypriot government, but the will of the majority of the population cannot be blackmailed by another part of it, even if we have serious doubts about the representativeness of the government of this part of the island. It is clear that the window of opportunity – the "janela de oportunidades" (window of opportunity) of which the Presidency spoke – must be exploited to the fullest. However, we are also convinced that although Greek-Turkish relations have improved, this cannot be enough.

Berger Report (A5-0007/2000) This proposal for a directive aims to establish the conditions for the posting of third-country nationals employed in the context of cross-border provision of services. Third-country nationals legally resident in a Member State do not enjoy the right to free movement within the European Union. Until now, non-EU workers have been seriously hampered by obstacles to their free movement within the European Union. It is therefore positive that the movement of workers within the European Union is being facilitated, even if they are third-country nationals. However, the proposal for a directive only concerns their movement to another Member State if they are posted on behalf of an employer established in a country where they have their habitual residence, so that the possibility of movement is limited to the period of posting, and only in the Member State to which they were posted. This means that the fundamental concern of this proposal is not to solve the problem of the movement of these workers but only to create better conditions for companies providing services. On the other hand, the Berger report introduces, in the name of simplifying procedures, far-reaching and questionable changes, in particular the creation of a common information system giving access to cards issued by the authorities of all Member States Berger Report (A5-0007/2000) and Berger Report (A5-0012/2000) . It is with the greatest satisfaction that I welcome the two proposals for directives which aim to facilitate the free movement of workers who are nationals of third countries while also facilitating the free movement of services. Essentially, these proposals introduce the EC/Services Card, which will enable nearly 5 million third-country nationals legally resident in a Member State of the European Union to provide services in other Member States in the future, something currently hampered by problems such as obtaining visas and work permits. The first proposal for a directive will allow companies established in a Member State that employ third-country national workers to temporarily post those employees to another Member State to provide services. Under the proposed provisions, the employer would simply be required to apply for a Services Card for each worker concerned. Logically, to be eligible for such a card, the worker must be legally resident in a Member State and covered by a social security scheme. The second proposal grants the same rights to self-employed third-country nationals. While I agree with the European Commission's proposals in substance, it is true that some provisions could be confusing. This is why I am voting in favor of the amendments tabled by the rapporteur. This will clarify the provisions and thus prevent any abuse! Other amendments aim to simplify administrative procedures, for example by allowing Member States to designate a single authority responsible for issuing cards. Such a change seemed essential to me to avoid the administrative burdens that too often hamper the proper implementation of new provisions.

That is precisely our task for the Balkans. The Union must demonstrate to the Balkans and the rest of the world its ability to expand the area of security, peace, and freedom and to assume a leading role on the world stage. We will, of course, return once again to enlargement, which must be achieved by simultaneously expanding the area of security, peace, and freedom. We have promised much in this direction, but I believe we can keep our promises, even though an extremely difficult road lies ahead. The enlargement that will accompany us for the entire five years and beyond—I am thinking of the hopes of the candidate countries—must be based on secure and objective criteria, but we must also offer guarantees to the citizens of those countries and, even more so, to our own citizens. Enlargement will be characterized by friendship, impartiality, and openness, but also by a lack of compromise. I repeat: we must offer guarantees to the citizens of the candidate countries, but even more so to the public in our own countries. Our responsibility does not end with enlargement, nor does it end with the Balkans. There are several other crucial problems: our relationship with Ukraine, our relationship with Russia, our relationship with our neighboring countries, and the major problem of our relationship with the southern Mediterranean, which will be crucial for Europe's history and for the peace and security of future European generations. In this sense, we have a responsibility towards the entire African continent. Hopes have recently been pinned on Africa; offers have been made to Africa, but nothing concrete has yet been achieved there. In recent years, Africa has not seen a transition from totalitarian to democratic regimes, but rather the reverse, from democracy to totalitarianism. For us, Africa is a worrying source of conflict. We therefore have another task to fulfil at the international level, one already mentioned by the Commissioner responsible for Trade: we must work for the resumption of the Millennium Round, with the comprehensive willingness we had already adopted and proposed before Seattle, but which we were unable to put into practice – the willingness to address some problems of fundamental importance to the poorest countries, concerning not only debt relief but also the unilateral opening of trade with the world's poorest countries. We must find another solution, otherwise events like those in Seattle will be repeated time and again, preventing the Union from playing a positive role in history. The Union's actions, wherever it is in the world, must be guided by respect for the principles of freedom, respect for human rights, and the rights of minorities. Let us remember that we, the European Union, are a union of minorities: we are all minorities in Europe. Even among the Fifteen of us, concerns are palpable, and these may well be repeated in the coming decade. I am speaking of Austria, where the Commission has lived up to its role of working for the cohesion of the Union, but it has done so uncompromisingly and as guardian of the Treaties, ready to punish even the smallest breach of the principles of democracy, the rule of law and respect for minorities.

I, too, would like to move toward a linear career system, as the current system of categories no longer suits the needs of our institutions. It certainly blocks the advancement and mobility of people with proven abilities. Those of you who, during the course of this debate, have praised Commission officials, who typically and for the most part are completely upright, highly capable, and excellent workers, have made absolutely accurate comments. While the White Paper on the strategy for reform will outline our thinking on these and other issues, it is clear that detail and precision are essential. Therefore, a series of communications will appear over the coming months. Each of them will be available to this Parliament for reflection and response. In the meantime, it is clear that we will need to work closely with Parliament, as an institution, on key issues, especially pay and pensions and the review of the staff regulations. Regarding this last issue, we are considering whether it would be useful to adopt a framework regulation that would establish common provisions for the most important issues such as salaries, conditions, staff representation rights, etc., but would allow the different institutions to act by issuing regulations for other matters. Parliament's initial impressions on this idea would be particularly welcome. I conclude by referring to paragraph 15 of the resolution before Parliament concerning the resources needed for our policies for change. This is certainly of the utmost importance. We are confident that a significant "reform dividend" will emerge as the reform measures begin to bring about greater efficiency and better management of the use of resources. It is very clear, however, that some sectors of the Commission's services are already stretched to the limit. Parliament has frequently commented on this circumstance. Secondly, it is also clear that the reform will require some new investment in technological and skills training. Thirdly, it is very clear that further preparations for enlargement must be undertaken. These are already having an impact on the availability of resources. It is also clear that, if we take on new tasks—which the Council and Parliament will ask us to do—we will have to identify the so-called "negative priorities" and abandon them in order to create savings. A fundamental element of the reform will therefore be a more rigorous procedure for linking the priority-setting process to the allocation of resources under an activity-based management system. I would like to emphasize, however, that while the Commission will certainly introduce internal discipline in priority-setting, it can only be fully effective if Parliament and the Council share it and adopt an equally strict attitude toward what is required of the Commission. The Commission therefore welcomes paragraph 15 of Mr. van Hulten's report. I conclude, Mr. President, by thanking the House for its attention during an inevitably long intervention and by expressing my gratitude to the rapporteur, the Committee on Budgetary Control, and the other committees that gave their opinions. We look forward to continuing to work closely with this Assembly in finalizing the reform strategy package and, most importantly, to continuing to work with this Assembly on its implementation over the years, which will be necessary in complex situations of this type.

So from many fragments we are giving meaning to Lisbon. I believe we are giving it precisely because the Portuguese Presidency has pulled the strings of unification, putting together the different pieces of the mosaic. We now have this heritage and I hope that, in Lisbon, we will find the unity to put it into practice, because I believe we need it and we will also have unexpected fruits from it. Thank you very much, Mr President of the Commission, thank you very much, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, for your significant contribution to an important and interesting debate. I have received six motions for resolutions, tabled pursuant to Rule 37, paragraph 2, of the Rules of Procedure. The vote will take place on Wednesday at 12 noon. The debate is closed. (The sitting, suspended at 8.15 p.m., resumed at 9 p.m.) Before resuming the sitting, I would like to make an observation that I usually make in night sittings, but since faces change, many of those present are not yet aware of it. I ask you to help ensure that the proceedings are carried out smoothly by adhering to the speaking time that has been granted to you. There are three reasons for this. The first is the old rule of every party: the later it gets, the more fun it is - but that does not apply to the Plenary. The second reason is that the interpreters, sitting behind the glass in the booths, also want to go to sleep. The third reason is that in addition to the interpreters, there are many other people who work behind the scenes and who have to stay until the end of the sitting, for example to ensure that the minutes are ready for tomorrow morning. So, please stick to the speaking time that has been granted to you, so that we can proceed quickly. Environmental dimension in the development process of developing countries The next item is the recommendation for second reading (A5-0051/2000) of the Committee on Development and Cooperation on the common position adopted by the Council (12485/1/1999 - C5-0013/2000 - 1999/0020(COD)) with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on measures to promote full integration of the environmental dimension into the development process of developing countries (Rapporteur: Mr A. Wijkman). Mr President, since the Brundtland Report of 1987 we have known that a policy aimed solely at economic growth is not and cannot be sustainable in the long term. The challenge facing us all, therefore, is to integrate social sensitivity and ecological sensitivity. This implies, among other things, the impossibility of considering ecological sensitivity as a sectoral problem, and the need for any negative consequences of industrial production, transport and construction to be addressed already at the design stage, minimising their impact through measures of various kinds. The Rio Conference led to the development of an action programme in which, sector by sector, the main problems in this context are listed and solutions are proposed to ensure the protection of the environment and natural resources. Although it is a document of several hundred pages, it remains a generic programme.

Modernization of social protection The next item is the report (A5-0033/2000) by Mr. Andersson, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the Commission communication: A concerted strategy to modernize social protection (COM(1999) 347 - C5-0253/1999 - 1999/2182(COS)). (SV) Mr. President, social protection is an important issue. This is an obvious consequence of cooperation at Community level. The basis is monetary cooperation, which was then followed by macroeconomic cooperation and cooperation in matters related to employment policy. It is now obvious to continue with the social protection system. These sectors are interdependent. Economic stability serves as a basis for growth and can lead to an increase in employment. It also makes it possible to develop the welfare state. However, the opposite situation can also occur: a well-developed social protection policy can contribute to increasing employment and growth. Social security is, in other words, a productive factor. There are differences within the Community regarding social protection. Many of these differences have historical antecedents. However, today we face a number of common challenges. For example, demographic development, in which not only is the number of elderly people increasing but the birth rate is also declining. The labor market is also changing. Women are increasingly entering the labor market. Another challenge is technological development. We must address these challenges together. The Commission communication proposes increased exchange of experiences, the formation of a high-level group, and benchmarking. Furthermore, the social protection report is published annually and examined alongside the employment report. This is beneficial, but not enough. We propose a procedure similar to the Luxembourg Process. Clear guidelines and indicators are needed, while Member States must establish methods in their national action plans. We created a common model, but we maintained the principle of subsidiarity. Social convergence is a process that will develop over a long period of time. Therefore, Parliament must be involved in this work, not by making it part of the high-level group, but by allowing representatives of Parliament to follow the work of the high-level group and submit proposals related to the development of the process. The Commission's proposal, like cooperation on employment matters, is based on four pillars. These are: making systems employment-friendly, making the pension system sustainable in the long term, promoting social inclusion, and ensuring high-quality and sustainable healthcare. All of this is important. In our report, we particularly emphasized the importance of combating poverty at EU level and of finding indicators, as soon as possible, so that we can make progress in this area. Equal opportunities between men and women do not have a single pillar. Here, mainstreaming applies. For this reason, aspects related to equal opportunities must be found in all four pillars. This is what we have done. We propose many things, for example, moving to an individualized social protection system, maternity leave allowing parents to access social security benefits, better opportunities to coordinate family and work life, and retirement pensions ensuring decent living standards.

It's about harmonizing examination regulations, but actually also about minimum standards. In a sense, I regret that. Naturally, traffic safety on roads, rails, and inland waterways is extremely important, and given the international nature of these transports, it's necessary to harmonize training courses for safety advisors and the requirements, for example, in the upcoming new ADR. I consider this to be just as important as its implementation. Of course, there are good reasons why we must pay particular attention to this problem. Think of the accidents that have occurred on the roads in recent years. For example, in Belgium, the Netherlands, and other countries, vehicles transporting dangerous goods continued to drive despite the fog and were not parked at the side of the road, as would have been required under the circumstances. Or think of the skippers of Eastern European ships that anchor here alongside others and clearly pose a danger. Furthermore, inspections in Belgian, Finnish, and Japanese ports show that 50% of containers, some of which contain dangerous cargo, are not delivered properly. In short, a serious problem. Regarding safety advisors, some countries have required companies to have one since January 1 of this year. Implementation is currently fraught with difficulties, particularly in small businesses, as they cannot afford such a position. They either sell their cargo or mix it with other cargo, which leads to a host of problems. Therefore, these activities must be documented in annual reports or operational analyses, and possibly included in ISO 9002 certification. The real work has been done; now it's time for implementation. Allow me one final point. Regarding this implementation, we must also reach appropriate agreements with the Eastern European countries, as they will not accede to the relevant conventions until July 1, 2001, i.e., in a year and a half. This will give them a temporary competitive advantage. Although I don't think this is a bad thing in itself, we should give particular priority to the safety aspects of the transport of dangerous goods by road, rail, and inland waterways, incorporate this part of the acquis as soon as possible, and submit it to the applicant states. Madam President, Parliament rightly regularly addresses the issue of transport safety. The ever-increasing volume of goods transported through Europe poses an overt or covert danger to personnel and society. Those exposed to this danger must therefore meet high standards. The relevant standards enshrined in another Directive, 95/35/EC, should enable people to be advised responsibly on the transport of dangerous goods. I am pleased to note that there is also agreement with the Council on minimum requirements for their examination, although I would have preferred uniform, binding standards and regulations with the aim of ensuring internationally equivalent qualifications. However, this does not seem feasible. All in all, I consider the amendment proposed by the rapporteur to be logical in every respect and can therefore fully support it. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to congratulate Mr Koch on his reports, which may be technical, but are of great importance for safety.

Do you believe, Commissioner, that the data we have on infant mortality in Kosovo—the highest in Europe—and, in general, the image of the misfortune and human disaster in Kosovo are not already seriously damaging our credibility and calling into question our ability to carry out what we have promised? And, Commissioner, is the so-called humanitarian military intervention justified by the current image of the humanitarian disaster in Kosovo? Don't you think such inertia cannot be justified when this very right to life is at risk on the European continent itself? I do not believe that our reconstruction agency, nor the operational units before it, which have made enormous efforts in Kosovo, would consider the suggestion that their intervention has consisted of sitting idly by, as an accurate description of their work. I am sure the honourable Member did not mean that. It goes without saying that the honourable Member is right in stating that the credibility of the Union will depend on what happens, not only in Kosovo, but throughout the entire Balkan region. I am very concerned that the aid we provide arrives as quickly as possible and in a way that maximizes our assistance. I would just like to make two observations about the situation in Kosovo, which we are addressing with all the enthusiasm we can together with the WHO. First, I am sure the Honorable Member recognizes that during the 1990s, the Government in Belgrade cut funding for Kosovo's health service, and many Albanians found they were not receiving any health care. As a result, a parallel health system was created through the Mother Teresa Society. We are therefore talking not only about the consequences of the conflict, but about the consequences of years of neglect and chronic underinvestment. Second, and I am sure the Honorable Member will also recognize this, some of the tragic stories coming out of Kosovo over the past few weeks were not about infant mortality during childbirth, but about infant mortality after the birth of a healthy child. These are cases in which women have tragically killed their own children during or before hostilities. We are talking about a horrific story in Kosovo. We must make every effort in the field of health care, among others, to restore standards that approach a civilized approach and civilized behavior, but it will not be an easy task. Commissioner, I must thank you for your response to my colleague's first question and also to the supplementary question. However, my contacts in Kosovo tell me that the food parcels distributed, among others, through ECHO are often of very poor quality. In some cases, insects have even been found in the food. Are you aware of this? Are you prepared to do something to prevent it? This is my first supplementary question. My second question concerns your mention of the reconstruction of the Mitrovica hospital.

Retroactive legislation is perverse legislation, unfair legislation, and often unworkable legislation. Most democratic parliaments in the free world reject it out of principle unless there is an overwhelming public interest, which is clearly not the case here. This is why I have requested a roll-call vote on this matter. We will be able to see who is prepared to vote in favor of retroactive legislation of dubious legality, which would represent a costly burden for future car buyers and a devastating blow to the European automotive industry. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, once again I would like to briefly recall the economic implications of this directive and renew my support for the amendments tabled by my colleague Bernd Lange. These amendments precisely have the advantage—I wish to emphasize this point—of reconciling environmental obligations with economic imperatives. The Council's common position has been that car manufacturers should bear all or a significant part of the cost of recovery and recycling. But as Mr. Lange rightly said, this solution is not at all fair to European manufacturers. Because I am from a country with many car manufacturers, I can tell you that it is not possible to impose on them, retroactively, the full financial burden of all their brand vehicles currently in use, that is, the cost burden imposed by 80% of the European car fleet. This solution is unacceptable because these manufacturers were unable to integrate the environmental requirements we impose on them today into their manufacturing processes and costs. The common position puts European manufacturers at a disadvantage compared to manufacturers new to the European market. Undoubtedly, if we are not here to defend a particular national interest, a particular industrial lobby, but rather we are here to build a competitive Europe on the global market and to defend jobs in the economic sectors in which we are truly competitive. For this reason, I ask you, the honourable Members, to support the amendments tabled by Bernd Lange, which will have the support of the Group of the Party of European Socialists because they effectively reconcile all the interests at hand—economic interests and environmental obligations—while leaving Member States free as to how these obligations are implemented. These amendments provide that the systems currently applied in the Member States—and there are some that work very well—should continue to operate. Mr. President, Commissioner, the proposal for a directive on end-of-life vehicles before us today seeks, on the one hand, to guarantee a high level of environmental protection in the European Union and, on the other, to preserve the proper functioning of the internal market in this sector. A word about historic and vintage vehicles: they should be excluded from the scope of this directive, because, I think we will all agree on that. Automobiles are also part of our cultural heritage. That said, one of the obstacles concerns Article 12, i.e. the date of application of the directive.

Over the past year, the Member States of the Union have thus, quite naturally, decided to implement concrete measures designed to strengthen the capacity for action of their armed forces, and the informal summit in Sintra, held the day before yesterday in your presence, has just confirmed the main guidelines. I have two questions on this subject, to which your knowledge of the issues and the players involved should enable you to provide enlightening answers for the continuation of our discussions and our work. The first question concerns the formation of this rapid intervention force of 60,000 men, capable, as you have said, of being deployed to carry out peacekeeping and peacebuilding missions, and capable of maintaining them over the long term if necessary. For the benefit of our colleagues, I must point out here that the corresponding contingents must then be divided into thirds: one third to prepare for the mission, one third to carry it out, and one third to get back into shape, following often difficult trials for both personnel and equipment. This explains why the first figures given in the press, setting the volume of forces to be constituted at around 200,000 men, are close to reality, which has not failed to surprise the uninitiated. My first question will be simple and more direct, perhaps, Mr High Representative, than that of the colleagues who preceded me. You know the French proverb "No money, no Switzerland." Do you really think that the governments of the Union are prepared to pay the corresponding price at a time when many of them remain, in appearance at least, determined to continue to reap what ten years ago were called "the dividends of peace." My second question will be of a more technical nature, but it is important for the most harmonious possible transfer to the European Union of the responsibilities of the Atlantic Alliance and the Western European Union. You have indicated to us, in this area, the establishment of three committees, a political and security committee which started today, the military committee. Then, you mentioned its relations with third countries that are members of the Atlantic Alliance or associate members of Western Europe, but which are not members of the European Union. In the operation of the interim institutions whose establishment has just been decided, can you tell us, Mr. High Representative, what status you envisage conferring on the members of the Alliance and the States associated with the WEU, I repeat, which are not yet members of the European Union? Could they, for example, have a place, at least as observers, within the various political and security committees or the military committee? You know that they are worried about this risk of being isolated and I want to say that I understand their desire to participate with you in the completion of this construction. Mr President, Mr Secretary-General of the Council, as you will understand, we in this House have followed with great interest the information you have given us on the outcome of the informal meeting of Defence Ministers held in Sintra and its importance in the process of European integration in matters of security and defence.

And until now, the restrictions affecting the free movement of non-EU workers within the European Union have been severe. Thus, it is positive that the movement of workers within the European Union is being facilitated, even if they are third-country nationals. However, the proposed directive aims only to allow their transfer to another Member State when they are seconded for the account of an employer established in the country of their habitual residence. Therefore, the possibility of movement is limited to the period of the secondment and only to the Member State to which they are posted. This means that this proposal is not primarily concerned with resolving the problem of the movement of these workers, but only with creating better conditions for service providers. Furthermore, the Berger report, in the name of simplifying procedures, introduces deeply questionable amendments, one example of which is the creation of a common information system for accessing cards issued by an entity in any Member State. Berger Report (A5-0007/2000) and Berger Report (A5-0012/2000). (FR) I wholeheartedly welcome the two proposals for directives designed to facilitate the free movement of workers from third countries and also the free movement of services. Essentially, these proposals introduce the EC services provision card, which will in the future allow some 5 million third-country nationals legally residing in a Member State of the European Union to provide services to other Member States, something that currently prevents problems such as obtaining visas and work permits. The first proposal for a directive will allow companies established in a Member State that employ workers who are nationals of a third country to temporarily transfer those employees to another Member State to provide services. Under the provisions envisaged, the employer will only need to apply for one services provision card for each worker. Obviously, to be eligible for this card, the worker must legally reside in a Member State and be covered by a social security scheme. The second proposal grants the same rights to independent workers who are nationals of a third country. Although I fundamentally agree with the European Commission's proposals, I recognize that some provisions could create confusion. I will therefore vote in favor of the amendments tabled by the rapporteur. This will clarify the provisions and prevent abuse. Other amendments aim to simplify administrative procedures, for example by authorizing Member States to designate a single competent authority for issuing the card. This amendment seems to me essential to avoid the administrative slowness that too often hinders the proper implementation of new provisions. I cannot but welcome the adoption of these amended directives, because it would be impossible for us to tolerate any longer the fact that people legally established in the European Union face so many difficulties.

Scotland as a country is larger than some Member States. It has many remote communities on the mainland that are accessible only by road, sometimes poorly connected by public transport, sometimes by none at all. These communities depend for their survival on having local facilities, such as a school, a post office, and a shop. The elderly in particular depend on the latter two. They are frequently located in the same location, each service being made more viable by the presence of the other. Scotland also has numerous island communities, some of which can be reached by air, but which mostly rely on sea ferries. It has been calculated that the actual cost of carrying a letter from Edinburgh to the central Highlands is approximately ten times that of carrying the same letter from one side of London to the other. And it is approximately four times what is actually charged for postage. The more remote the community, the greater the difference. This gives an idea of the problem. It is not opposing liberalization to ask that it be carried out in a way that takes these factors into account and allows for the continuation of a universal and affordable postal service. It is for all our remote and island communities, no matter where they are located in the European Union, and not just for the people of Scotland, that I ask you to preserve the lifeline offered by your postal services. Mr. President, I consider it a privilege to substitute for my colleague, Commissioner Bolkestein, on the occasion of such a high-quality debate on postal services. I will try to respond to the debate based on the information provided by Commissioner Bolkestein. I would like to reiterate that he will be available to Parliament's Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism on Monday. Some Members, such as Mr. Stenmarck, complain that there have been delays with the new proposal. Others believe that after all, a brief pause after the first step towards liberalization is not so bad. This is, for example, the position expressed by Mr. Berthu. The Commission's position is that the new proposal was delayed primarily due to internal problems within the Commission, which I am sure Parliament is not entirely unaware of. But we believe there is a legal obligation to submit a proposal. Commissioner Bolkenstein intends to submit such a proposal to the Commission for approval in the first half of this year. The planned date of 1 January 2003 for implementing the next steps remains feasible. The proposal will take into account the studies carried out and will focus in particular on aspects such as the universality of the service, to which I will return in a second. As regards the existing directive and its implementation, almost all Member States have adopted the necessary legal measures to transpose the directive. There are some problems relating to the structure of the regulatory authority and its independence. The implementation deadline for Member States is January 2003.

We are working as effectively and competently as possible." So, dear Member States, we believe that the time has now come for the Common Foreign and Security Policy to build a bridge between the Council's conclusions, between meter-long communiqués, and what we can actually achieve in this area. I believe that if we can achieve this, the role of the High Representative will be made considerably easier and the living conditions of many, many people around the world will be considerably improved. Thank you very much, Commissioner Patten! Thank you also for providing us with examples of your British humor, even on this very difficult topic. It also makes it a little more interesting. Women in the decision-making process. Next on the agenda are the statements by the Council and the Commission on women in the decision-making process. Mr President, I would like to begin my contribution by thanking the Minister and President-in-Office of the Council for participating in this debate and for her interesting remarks on the subject. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for her presence here and for the words she addressed us. In general, the various political groups agree on the evident underrepresentation of women in decision-making, both in the political and economic and social spheres. No one today disputes that women must participate in political life, in political parties and institutions, but we are finding it difficult to agree on the form in which this participation should be achieved. Equality between men and women, which most profoundly affects the lives of women and, consequently, society in general, means equality in work, both in access to employment—which presupposes equal training—and in equal pay for equal work, which has been so often called for and is still so far from reality. We are convinced that women's participation in decision-making will benefit society as a whole. Women always offer a perspective different from that of men, which enriches and perfects the overall vision of the best solutions to everyday problems, which people like us who are actively involved in politics are committed to solving. But the difficulty lies in finding the right solution that allows for a greater presence of women in positions of responsibility and thus in decision-making processes. In some European Union countries, mandatory quotas have been adopted by law, which directly achieves a more balanced representation of women. However, this may not be the best solution, because there is not always a sufficient number of women willing to enter a problematic, competitive world that they consider essentially masculine, having traditionally been the preserve of men. The proportion of women in political parties does not reach 50%, nor in the world of work and the social sphere. It is much lower, and it is precisely this grassroots participation that we should encourage to facilitate women's presence. Furthermore, there must be a clear and real will to ensure that there are more women who are able and willing to assume responsibility and duties in political life, that is, in the decision-making process.

In truth, a hierarchy of oppression has been created. Until all individuals are recognised as equal before the law, this inequality will cause discrimination and human rights will be eroded. In the process of enlargement of the Union, we have rightly placed the emphasis on human rights and the protection of minorities. We must not abandon this commitment. But we must also look in the mirror and recognise our inadequacies. Yes, the conventions have been signed, but action is needed. I would like to propose continuous checks on the observance of human rights, eternal vigilance, not only outside our borders, but also within. That is why I am in favour of each Member State submitting an annual report, listing any accusations made against it and the measures taken. Because what happens in each Member State happens to each of us. What happens in another part of the world concerns us all. Pinochet in Chile is as important as Haider in Austria. Human rights and civil liberties are inextricably linked. Human rights are not isolated, they are linked to our development policies, our economic policies, our home affairs policies, in fact they are at the heart of our democratic functions. I would like to reiterate what Commissioner Patten said: we must engage, we must inform, we must educate and in this way bring about real and lasting change. Mr President, 'Europe is about ideals, values and principles. We must give space to the spiritual history of Europe. We must jointly restore the values that unite Europe. Spiritual values have spread from Europe to the rest of the world. We must live with our consciences'. That is what the President of the Czech Republic, Václav Havel, said in this Chamber three hours ago. In a particularly edifying speech, filled with insight into the human soul, wisdom, knowledge of history and insight into Europe's spiritual and Christian heritage, he was able to point to the sources of inspiration for our work on human dignity and human rights. We should be grateful that in our Europe there are heads of state like Václav Havel. I would like to focus on two aspects. First, civil society. Havel recalled that in Eastern Europe, communist regimes systematically destroyed civil society: popular movements, churches, independent trade unions. This is also what is happening in China with the Falun Gong movement and with the Catholic and Protestant churches. This is what is happening with Lamaism in Tibet. We must never forget the defense of civil society. I would also like to talk about the death penalty. The European Union, just like Sweden where I come from, has built its vision of the human being on the basis of equality, uniqueness and the inviolability of human dignity. According to this principle, the human being must always have the possibility of reform. Tell that to the government of the United States, to the government of Russia and to the government of China! Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, I believe that the line that the Member States of the European Union should follow in Geneva is to give priority to the situations in Kosovo, Mexico, Saudi Arabia, Sierra Leone and China.

Mr President, this cannot continue; something must be done about this situation. Mr President, the Treaty of Amsterdam set out an important objective for the Union, a task that all parliamentarians, the Council, and the Commission must assume during this parliamentary term: the creation, as I have already said, of an area of freedom, security, and justice. The Tampere Council, the driving force and originator of this objective, proposed certain objectives, but the five-year period envisaged for the implementation of Title IV of the Treaty is too long to wait for the urgent solutions that certain problems require. My first consideration is that Parliament cannot be sidelined when the important decisions are taken in this area, and its participation in the decision-making process must be guaranteed, particularly when it concerns a citizens' project, as the Commissioner rightly said. My second consideration is the need to make rapid progress in adopting a common asylum system, adopting common procedural standards and, above all, putting an end to the current confusion between immigration for political and economic reasons. The aliens laws recently adopted in my country, Spain, and in Belgium remind us of the urgent need to communitize immigration policy. My third and final reflection relates to the Union's external policy on immigration and asylum. We must not and cannot give the impression that the Union is solely concerned with defending itself against an avalanche of refugees and economic immigrants. We must advocate a policy of development cooperation with our eastern and Mediterranean neighbors, but we must do so conscientiously, using economic means and in close collaboration with public institutions that work together to protect citizens who see their most fundamental rights violated or who wish to emigrate because their most basic needs are at stake. Finally, with regard to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, European citizens must make their citizenship known. It is not enough to have the euro or employment, nor even security. They need the "European soul," as a distinguished Spanish professor has said. Mr. President, contrary to some previous speakers, I would like to reiterate the words of our Portuguese ministers and the remarks of Mr. Vitorino. As Mr. Ceyhun said, these gentlemen's statements were music to our ears. Just as in music, fine-tuning and coordination are necessary. Many of us are very optimistic about the six months ahead. The citizens of Europe will be listening to our tune, and they will want to hear the right tune. As mentioned this afternoon, it will take some time before we can resolve the discordant notes we heard during the European elections and over the past few months. The Treaty of Amsterdam and the Tampere Council continued the project of creating an area of freedom, security, and justice within the European Union. However, one area is of enormous importance, and in this area Parliament must be involved: scrutiny.

Finally, we need to go further in development aid policies in the least developed countries. In budgetary and financial matters, regarding debt, aid to sensitive sectors such as food and humanitarian security or education and health, in the field of the environment, investment or access to information and new technologies, as well as in the trade sector, while at the same time ensuring overall coherence of development policies with other Community policies and also between them and the related policies pursued by the Member States. We cannot be content to give continuity to what, in the past, has proven insufficient and wrong. Mr President, today, after listening to the Council and the Commission, I had to look at my agenda. It actually says 'Coherence of the various Union policies with development policy'. But we have not heard a single word about it, and I think that is extremely embarrassing. We have been waiting for years for a report on coherence. It should have been tabled in writing today, and after hearing Commissioner Nielson's speech, I can easily imagine that it will meet with strong opposition within the Commission. I know that the Commissioner himself has strong and very rational views on the issue of coherence, and I would have liked to hear them today. Since the joint motion for a resolution suggests a number of effective mechanisms to ensure coherence, I would like to mention just one more in the short time I have, namely that the Commission should also start evaluating new and relevant legislation in this area. I would also like to focus on the catastrophic effect that the common agricultural policy has on developing countries. Beef is dumped in the Sahel countries and South Africa, tomato paste in West Africa, milk powder in Jamaica - the examples are, we hope, all well known. And in any case they are only too well known to the affected producers in the ACP countries who have to destroy their products because they cannot compete with products subsidised by the European Union. European taxpayers pay €40 billion a year to support EU agriculture. This money helps to slow down the development of the agricultural sector in developing countries, where 69% of the total workforce is concentrated in agriculture, compared to 1.7% in the European Union. Add to this the fact that the agricultural sector contributes 34% of the gross national product of developing countries, compared to 5.3% for the European Union. There is neither coherence nor decency. Why do neither the Council nor the Commission want to admit this? Mr President, the way in which political decisions are reached is undoubtedly crucial. Yesterday, the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and the Foreign Secretary made statements on the British Government's policy on the voting system in the Council. They noted that the United Kingdom, France and Germany currently far outnumber the other countries of the European Union in terms of population.

The first aspect concerns the fight against poverty, which I believe is starting to become a very embarrassing story for the Union and the Member States. Although we have made a commitment in the Treaty and at the UN conferences in Rio and Copenhagen to eradicate poverty worldwide, in reality the budget for development cooperation is being cut, contrary to the declared intentions. This is a trend that must be stopped. First of all, we must proceed with debt cancellation. We must move from words to deeds. I hope that we will be able to take a leading role in this task. The second aspect concerns the fact that, in many situations, we say that the ACP countries must learn the fundamentals of democracy. In paragraphs 2 and 3 of the resolution, it is called for working methods to be developed and optimised within the framework of the new Convention, and for the ACP countries to be encouraged to contribute to the debate with a plurality of political opinions. That is fine, I can only endorse it. At the same time, however, we must ask ourselves how we ourselves manage democracy. How do things work in the European Parliament's delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Assembly? In contrast to the way things work in Parliament and its committees, where rapporteurs are ultimately designated and then appointed, in the delegation to the Joint Assembly there are no rules. The two large groups share out all the reports, general reports, etc. It is precisely to change this undemocratic way of functioning that the Verts/ALE Group has tabled Amendment No 6. In this amendment, we call for the appointment of rapporteurs for all reports, including working groups and general reports, to be carried out in accordance with clear and democratic rules. In this respect, account must be taken of the small groups and the aspect of representativeness. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to congratulate Mr Corrie on the quality of his report, which accurately reflects the tenor of the discussions in the Joint Assembly, of which he has co-chaired very effectively. The eradication of poverty was at the heart of our work and, to achieve this ambitious objective, many of those who spoke had drawn attention to the need to preserve an essential instrument, namely the preferential agreements between the European Union and the ACP countries, within the framework of the Lomé Conventions. The challenge was formidable. Globalisation, the liberalisation of trade, as well as the pre-eminence of the WTO and the globalist philosophy for which it is the vehicle, were jeopardising the very essence of the dialogue between North and South. We can therefore only welcome the conclusion of the new Development Partnership Agreement and, for my part, I am convinced that the work of the last Joint Assembly has had a decisive influence on unblocking the negotiations, as has the new climate created by the events in Seattle. However, while I am pleased with the renewal of the agreements, what attracts my attention above all is the new wind that is now blowing in our relations and which is evident in the balanced nature of the negotiations now coming to a close.

Oil hits the beaches, and then politicians and ministers show up and take care of the disposal themselves, even with a small bucket. But when a tough directive is up for debate two weeks later, yesterday's good words have been forgotten. We won't be able to rule out accidents 100%, but we can make precautions as optimal as possible. This consistent directive is an important step towards that. I also hope that my liberal colleagues will perhaps consider by tomorrow whether they can participate again in the second reading—also for reasons of parliamentary identity—as they did in the first reading. Because we will then go into the conciliation procedure anyway, and we will have to see how far the Council can go. I believe that, for environmental and competitive reasons, as well as in light of what was decided two months ago, in January, we should adopt these proposals tomorrow with a broad majority, as we debated them in committee. Mr. President, Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, congratulations on your report. You just said it: this directive is urgently needed. It is a sensible directive. Ports need reception facilities. Inspections are finally being carried out. Member States must also impose sanctions for non-compliance with the rules. This is extremely important and serves environmental protection. Investments are already being made in anticipation of the directive. In Antwerp, for example, a large facility is currently being built not far from where I live, which was previously missing. In a sense, therefore, this directive is already effective. We disagree on one point, which Mr. Jarzembowski also raised. How do you charge the disposal costs to the ship? We agree on the principle, namely the polluter pays principle. However, should the polluter automatically pay the port dues in full or make a significant contribution, or should we opt for a flexible arrangement, as now proposed by the Council? Which solution offers the most effective economic incentive, as you have said? I have spoken to several people about this. Viewpoints differ, and apparently the approach in practice is quite different. Even between ports within the same region, there are differences, and different percentages apply. Some ports change their percentages literally at the last minute. It would therefore probably be best for us as a Parliament not to commit to a specific percentage. A flexible system under these circumstances must, as you said, involve a substantial contribution to the costs. 0.01% is certainly not a substantial contribution. With a flexible element left open, incentives must be offered to those who behave in an environmentally friendly manner. The prerequisite is that the Commission carefully monitors the whole thing and checks whether the system is working. If the directive's objectives are not met, you should intervene with the Commission, take steps, propose changes, and ensure that the system is actually working. We must save this directive at all costs, maintain it, and get it through. Let us hope that we do not jeopardize it by taking an overly fundamental stance on one particular point. Mr. President, not so long ago, it was widely believed that waste was completely disposed of when it was dumped at sea or incinerated.

Particularly in recent months, there has been discussion about the role that the Development Council can play in the field of Union policy. As is well known, there is a clear difference between development policy and other policy areas at Union level – one need only think of the difficult conditions under which the inclusion or exclusion of the EDF in the budget was decided – and it is difficult to imagine that we can achieve greater coherence in European Union policies without a more active and more involved role for the Development Council in advising on political decisions that are primarily development-related and are taken in other councils, in other decision-making centres – whether the Agriculture and Fisheries Councils or the Environment Councils – but in which the Development Council has so far had no opportunity to be heard or to intervene.
