Consequently, without a more active role for the Development Council in the overall coordination of political decisions that directly affect the European Union's development policy and are taken at the periphery of its decision-making centre, it will certainly be difficult to achieve a more coherent European Union policy in the field of development objectives. Here, too, the European Parliament's input and reflections will be relevant and welcome. I would like to begin by highlighting the successful conclusion of the negotiations between the EU and the ACP states. Participating in these negotiations was an extremely positive experience. I saw how the Member States worked together as a team, and that was very gratifying. In the end, both sides were very satisfied, not only because the negotiations were concluded, but because we all realized that together, the EU and the 71 ACP states, we had achieved something. The world needs such experiences, and this is a very positive signal with regard to the discussion on the issue of globalization. I would like to outline some of the most important innovations in the new agreement. Corruption is openly addressed, and for the first time, we are creating a framework within which the problem of immigration can be addressed. We are promoting participatory approaches and ensuring consultation with civil society on the reforms and policies that the EU intends to promote. We are placing greater emphasis on poverty reduction at the heart of our development policy. The allocation of resources is based not only on an assessment of a country's needs, but also on its policies. To promote private sector development, we are establishing an investment facility. We are rationalizing instruments and introducing a new system of dynamic programming so that the Community and recipient countries can regularly make adjustments to cooperation programs. We are decentralizing administrative and, in some cases, financial responsibilities to the local level to enable more effective cooperation. We are improving the policy framework for trade and investment development. We are expanding cooperation in all areas important for trade, including new areas such as labor standards and the link between the environment and trade. I am sure that, in light of the events in Seattle, you will welcome the importance of these agreements. Let me highlight some of the key points. First, the agreement on political issues.

This is the meaning of an amendment that we have tabled, which gives priority to all the languages of the Community and which will condition our agreement on the second directive. The situation is quite different with the first proposal. The original text could have received our assent insofar as it stemmed from a legitimate concern to update existing legislation. The text of the report - and I commend the work of our colleague Schmidt - however, cannot receive our approval for several reasons. Firstly, it favours far too many products based on indices that no longer have any connection with the real economy, derivative products that will contribute to increasing the financial bubble that our colleague Lipietz spoke about just now. Secondly, like him, I believe that we should not favour excessive concentration in funds that would ultimately prove to be a Trojan horse for American pension funds. So, obviously, no reciprocity is planned in favour of European UCITS. We will also oppose the removal of the power given to Member States to increase to 35%... (The President cut off the speaker) Mr President, this is a vital issue for Europe. A Europe that is living with a time bomb ready to explode at any moment, namely pensions, must take all measures to encourage savings and maximize the returns that European citizens can obtain from their savings. I welcome Mr Schmidt's report, which contains many interesting developments. UCITS are a success story in the European Union. They are safe products marketed cross-border. However, it is time to update the legislation. Mr Schmidt has done an excellent job in this regard. I will not surprise anyone by saying that I would have much preferred that Mr Schmidt's report had not undergone so many changes during its passage through Parliament. But I urge this House to take a balanced and wholesome approach to this issue. The radical step forward in this report is to allow UCITS to invest in over-the-counter derivatives. I challenge anyone here to assess the products that will be used by UCITS. We are not talking about speculation, but about reducing the risks and increasing the returns on investments made by ordinary European citizens. Mr Schmidt deserves applause for receiving the support of Parliament on the issue of over-the-counter derivatives. We must not be afraid to move forward, to react to changes in the market. Yes, we must continue to ensure that UCITS remain a balanced and safe product for consumers. The report provides entirely adequate protection for consumers. But a series of amendments go too far in restricting the use of over-the-counter derivatives. I have the feeling that they will be an interesting addition to SICAV portfolios, and that they can only help everyone, everywhere in Europe, to achieve a high return on their savings. I greet Mr. Schmidt. Thank you, Mr. Kuckelkorn. Dear colleagues, I would like to share with you the information I have just received about the curtain and the window.

Both countries are also eligible for financial assistance from the MEDA program (B7-4012). In its first and second readings of the 2000 budget, the European Parliament emphasized that the new title "Pre-accession Strategy for the Countries of Central and Eastern Europe" (B7-0), proposed by the Commission in the preliminary draft budget, should not only refer to the associated countries of Central and Eastern Europe, but should also be extended to other third countries such as Malta and Cyprus. However, since the Council refused to negotiate the necessary revision of the ceiling in heading 7 (pre-accession) of the financial perspective, Parliament exceptionally accepted—I emphasize this explicitly—the financing of this expenditure under heading 4 (external actions) of the financial perspective in 2000. At the same time, the European Parliament created a new chapter, "Cooperation with Mediterranean third countries" (B7-04). Within this chapter, two new articles on the pre-accession strategy for Malta and Cyprus have been created and marked "pm" until the Commission, in implementation of the Helsinki decisions, provides the necessary legal bases and the ceiling for heading 7 of the financial perspective has been revised. This proposal for a regulation should be one of these legal bases! I welcome Mr Brok's report, which supports, with amendments, the Commission's proposals for preparing Cyprus and Malta for EU membership. Under this package, a total of approximately EUR 15 million will be granted to the two countries this year. However, it is regrettable that the Commission has bypassed multiannual funding and instead decided to allocate funds on an annual basis. This is bound to have an impact on Malta's and Cyprus's ability to plan their expenditure. The appropriation will provide technical and financial assistance to enable the two islands to make the necessary adoption of the Community acquis. Given the advanced status of these two countries compared to other candidate countries, it should not be difficult for them to be technically and administratively ready for membership at the end of the five-year programme. Cederschiöld Report (A5-0020/2000) As a member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs during the previous parliamentary term, I welcome the adoption of this framework decision on strengthening the protection of our single currency. The Union must use all the means at its disposal to ensure effective protection of the euro against counterfeiting. Consumers and businesspeople are not yet truly familiar with the euro. Counterfeit money can therefore be circulated relatively easily in supermarkets, exchange bureaus, and banks without being immediately noticed. The fact that the coins will have a national side will make their identification even more difficult. The Euro Information Centres, which already play a vital role in raising public awareness of the single currency, must intensify their campaign to raise public awareness of the risks of counterfeiting. At another level, cooperation between Community and national institutions must be ensured and an information system for collecting and exchanging data on counterfeiting must be established. Likewise, criminal law measures must be taken to ensure the protection of the euro from the very beginning. In this context, the European Parliament has presented a draft framework decision on strengthening criminal protection against counterfeiting.

Hence, complementary measures are required, such as the obligation for criminal investigation officers to testify, whenever desired, in any criminal trial in which their material is used. My group also cannot accept that the Council's proposal breaches the principle of proportionality. It is clear that the scope of application is not subject to restrictions. The Convention does not only apply to the fight against serious crime and organized crime. It does not even appear anywhere that it is limited to criminal law. Therefore, it is not inconceivable that the European Union will end up killing mosquitoes with cannonballs and that citizens' rights will vanish in the smoke of gunpowder. Mr. President, the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters that we are examining today contains the bare minimum necessary for rapid and effective cooperation between the various judicial or investigative bodies. It deals with notifications, the exchange of information, the temporary transfer of detainees, the restitution of property, statements by videoconference, investigative activities and undercover calls, wiretapping, etc. This is the minimum on which an agreement could be reached, and it goes without saying that if some amendments are accepted, such as Amendments 32 or 81, the revised Amendment 70 or 71, the entire Convention will be reduced to the mere exchange of notifications or information and, in fact, should be thrown into the wastebasket, and we would vote against it. I hope that the common sense of the Members of the various groups will lead them to reject these amendments. Furthermore, the fact that it has not been transformed into a framework agreement and has remained within the scope of conventions is a defeat for Parliament. As Commissioner Vitorino will have seen from the various interventions, there is a growing need to develop a framework of common rules, that is, to stop moving forward in this way, with this scattered order, with these small agreements covering different sectors such as investigations and others. On the contrary, a minimum of secure rules, valid within the Community, with an obvious increase in guarantees to the highest levels, is absolutely necessary, precisely to protect ourselves in view of enlargement. I think about what this Community, these agreements, or judicial relations would become if, for example, a fascist country like Turkey were to join the European Union: I would be truly perplexed. It is necessary to establish a corpus juris—everyone has said so—and common rules, especially procedural ones, that guarantee a common rule of law throughout the Community. It is obvious that this is a matter for the Intergovernmental Conference and that it is an aspiration to which Parliament can contribute in a limited way, since everything depends on the Council and the Commission. I believe that this first semester, in which the Commissioner is Portuguese and the Presidency is held by Portugal, is an excellent opportunity to give an initial push to this common aspiration.

I also ask that the Commission, within the framework of the projects that have been presented, ensure that the environmental pillar of European Union policy is included in its projects and that, indeed, the objective of reducing CO2 emissions, for example, can be a pilot added value for projects that have been proposed. I am thinking particularly here of some of the infrastructure projects under construction. We know that some Member States are hesitating between rail and road crossings in fragile areas like the Pyrenees—I am thinking of the Aspe Valley. But I am also thinking of my region, where my Member State is still hesitating between building a rail crossing and proposing a second motorway, the A32. Therefore, here too, I will ask the Commission to be particularly vigilant to ensure genuine cohesion between the various policies, and especially in the Interreg programs that are being presented. Mr. President, I voted in favor of the Decourrière report on the Community initiative INTERREG, not least because of the response Commissioner Barnier gave to certain Members who spoke and asked that this program should, if possible, pay even more attention to border regions whose boundaries are marked by the sea. This is not only because I was born in Genoa, a city on the seashore, but above all because the borders of the regions bordered by the sea are also borders. These borders lead us to the States of Africa and the Middle East: we must take greater account of the fact that it is also important to develop coastal regions everywhere in Europe. (FR) As a Member of the European Parliament from a border region, I welcome this third Interreg initiative with great interest. The difficulties encountered in the past by border regions, both land and sea, which have been economically, socially, and culturally isolated, cannot be sufficiently recalled. Due to the presence of borders, these regions have become peripheral areas of the states of which they are part, which has all too often led national authorities, within the framework of national policy, to neglect these regions. For this reason, the Community initiative Interreg was established in 1990. The objective of this program was to stimulate cross-border, transnational, and interregional cooperation, as well as a balanced development of the Community area, in order to strengthen economic and social cohesion within the Union. Interreg essentially aims to finance joint actions in the areas of SME development, training and education, cultural exchanges, health issues, environmental protection and improvement, energy networks, transport, and telecommunications. I emphasize the fact that interregional cooperation helps to associate local and regional authorities with the process of European integration. It is necessary to promote more active participation of local and regional authorities in Community initiatives, taking into account the fact that local and regional authorities often have very limited capacities for cooperation due to the diversity of legal frameworks and the disparity in levels of development on both sides of the border. Within the framework of cross-border cooperation, increasing importance must be given to improving the operating conditions of small and medium-sized enterprises that create jobs. Similarly, and given that 50% of unemployment is attributable to structural unemployment, the resources made available through Interreg must be sufficiently significant to complement national measures aimed at promoting employment.

In the light of these facts, does the Council intend to call into question the funding for the reconstruction of Kosovo, as requested by the European Parliament? What other practical measures does the Council intend to take to put an end to ethnic cleansing? Honourable Member, I would like to say that I have the greatest sympathy for the concern inherent in the issue you have raised. We truly share your concerns about the threatening situation within Kosovo for ethnic minorities, both Serb and Roma, and about the cases of discrimination, siege and intimidation that continue to occur in that territory. The Council has always stressed the need to bring to justice all those who have perpetrated and continue to perpetrate such acts. It also reiterated, in its December conclusions, the need to fully implement Security Council Resolution 12/99 and consistently supported the efforts of Bernard Kouchner to implement measures to ensure effective protection of minorities in that territory and, in particular, effective implementation of measures to preserve the multi-ethnicity of the territory itself. In our contacts with leading political figures among the Albanians of Kosovo, we have stressed - as the Portuguese Prime Minister recently did - that the persecution of the Serb, Gypsy and other ethnic groups is totally unacceptable. It will not be tolerated and must stop immediately. It has been communicated and explicitly reiterated to the leaders of Kosovo that international support will depend largely on the treatment of non-Albanian minorities. This seems to me to be of the utmost importance; the European Union will maintain the sense of conditionality inherent in this position and the same goes for the Council. We have fully supported the efforts of the United Nations mission and the international security force in Kosovo to prevent new outbreaks of violence against minorities and to protect threatened populations. KFOR and the UNMIK police consider one of their primary tasks to be the suppression of all forms of ill-treatment based on ethnic origin. In this context, the Council welcomed in its December conclusions the substantial contributions announced by the European Commission which, together with others of a similar nature offered by Member States, will contribute indirectly to the normalisation of the situation. However, Honourable Member, the Council is also aware that the overall means made available to the international structures responsible in Kosovo do not correspond, in terms of mobilisation of the various Member States, to what would be desirable and this has limited the structures' effective capacity to intervene on the ground. However, we will not stop focusing all our attention on this problem, because the entire credibility of the Albanian authorities and representative structures on the territory also depends on the ability of these same structures to prove that they are capable of applying measures that guarantee multi-ethnicity within the said territory. Thank you, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council.

We have a duty to protect this kind of thing and denounce other practices. Mr President, Commissioner, I heard this morning on the French national radio that the liberalization of the Post Office would practically only be a matter of hours or days and that it was irremediable, as happened with our Swedish, Dutch and German friends. This worries us greatly and is the reason why we requested this debate today. The Commission has, in fact, committed to a universal postal service, and the European Parliament has shown on several occasions that the postal service is indeed, as some colleagues have already said, an essential factor in social and territorial cohesion. In this regard, I would perhaps like to address our Swedish colleague to ask him what he thinks of the study that was carried out and which shows that, in fact, in more remote areas of Sweden, the postal service is rather poor, in terms of delivery. So we don't want this postal service. The economic interest of the postal service was recognized by the Treaty of Amsterdam, and we believe that it goes well beyond delivery. It is the service that remains closest to citizens and that we call "public service," which allows every inhabitant of European territory to be served, and this achievement must remain a Community achievement. The recognition by the European Union of a high-quality postal service, for everyone, remains relevant today, and we are increasingly concerned. This is why we are asking today not to have any unpleasant surprises on Monday in the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism. We recall that Parliament's positions were clearly defined and that the Green group supported them. This resolution of January 14, 1999, requested that before any further liberalization of this key sector, which still affects 1.7 million employees, the Commission provide impact studies of this liberalization. However, we are not convinced that the studies available today can implement this liberalisation, and we are worried because we know very well that this liberalisation without an impact study would lead to thousands of job losses, which we absolutely do not want. We are committed to our public service, to our universal postal service, because we know, and we are the representatives of the citizens here too, that citizens are committed to this service and the Commission committed itself, during Mr Bolkestein's hearing, to preserving this universal service in the European Union. I will not repeat the various comments he made during his hearing; I believe we all still remember them. We also maintain that we are waiting for this genuine assessment before any final decision, as stipulated in the directive and the revision of the 1997 directive. We will not accept a date for the liberalisation of all postal activities until the Commission has given us a guarantee that the universal service will be integrated into this directive and that the public postal service will be maintained in the States which consider this service essential to the citizen.

Parliament has always viewed the social economy as an important potential provider of employment opportunities. These amendments are consistent with Parliament's view that social exclusion is a serious problem requiring constructive action. We hope that those considering rejecting these amendments will be able to provide both Parliament and their job-seeking citizens with sound reasons for their decision. Mrs. Flautre's report also highlighted an area where coordination is severely lacking, even though it is precisely here that considerable coordination is needed. The Commission's proposals relate to the four pillars of the employment strategy and the five areas of action of the European Social Fund. However, the lack of concrete guidelines is all the more regrettable given that the idea of linking ESF interventions with the employment strategy is being implemented for the first time in the 2000-2006 programming period. This omission certainly gives the impression that the Commission, too, is unaware of how to ensure the fullest possible coordination between ESF assistance, which is subject to review after three and a half years, and the Member States' annual National Action Plans for Employment. We hope that the Commission can convince us that this is merely an oversight that will be corrected without delay. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development considers the proposal submitted by the Commission in fulfillment of its mandate to be a sensible starting point. However, I would like to stress that this starting point highlights the challenges we face: how to maintain the population in rural areas in the face of changes in all types of economic activities resulting from the declining importance of the agricultural sector among the various sources of income for rural society. This, combined with deficiencies in infrastructure and services and a generally very scarce, highly seasonal, and poorly diversified range of jobs, is increasing the rate of migration from rural areas. The consequences are immediate. Young people are migrating, those who find training and employment outside rural areas, which has a very negative impact on these regions. This lack of infrastructure, in turn, is an obstacle to the establishment of businesses and the creation of jobs. It is important to remember that rural areas account for almost four-fifths of the European Union's territory. Agriculture provides only 5.5% of the Union's jobs. Furthermore, three-quarters of our farmers are part-time farmers and rely on additional sources of income. For this reason, one of the most important and far-reaching objectives that we in the European Union should set ourselves is to make efforts to create new jobs in rural areas outside the agricultural sector, including in rural tourism, sport, culture, resource rehabilitation, business conversion, new technologies, services, etc. However, although agriculture no longer plays an exclusive role, it remains important, not only to prevent the economic and social decline of rural areas and the creation of more ghost towns, but also because farmers have a fundamental role to play in managing the territory, preserving biodiversity and protecting the environment. We therefore advocate an agricultural policy and rural development that is consistent with our objectives and that, as we enter the 21st century, rural areas must be competitive and multifunctional, both in terms of agriculture and in terms of opening up to a variety of non-agricultural activities.

The problem concerns Danes, or citizens of other States, residing outside the territory of Denmark. Question No 37, by the Honourable Member (H-0791/99): Subject: Working Time Directive Can the Commission say what measures it intends to take to ensure a level of protection, equivalent to that provided by the 1993 Working Time Directive, for hospital doctors in training who are excluded from that Directive and from the Council's proposal for amendment thereto (COM(98)0662-C4-0715/98-98/0318(SYN))? There is a proposal for a directive to amend the Directive as regards the working time of hospital doctors in training. The content of the proposal concerns the weekly working time of doctors, which is on average 48 hours, with the possibility of negotiating an extension to 54 hours. In this regard, there is agreement between the Council, the Commission and the Parliament on the content, while there is disagreement between the three institutions regarding the transition period needed to implement the directive. The Parliament's proposal envisages a period of 4 years, the Commission's proposal of 7 years and, finally, the Council's proposal advocates a transition period of 13 years. This proposal is still being discussed between the Council and Parliament under the codecision procedure. Despite this disagreement, it should be stressed that there is agreement between the three institutions on the content and that every effort is being made to ensure that such an important and sensitive issue, which involves an exceptionally large number of doctors working throughout Europe, can receive a common solution. Question No 38, by the Honourable Member (H-0805/99): Subject: Measures to achieve equality between men and women One of the groups of Commissioners communicated by President Prodi has as its objective the promotion of measures to achieve equality between men and women (mainstreaming). Which Commissioners form the group? How many times has it met so far? What concrete measures have been discussed? The question concerns separate issues. It concerns the specific committee set up by the Commission on equal opportunities. The Commissioners who are members of this committee are President Prodi, Vice-President Kinnock, Commissioner Reading and myself. The sessions of this committee are public and the first of these took place on 11 January 2000. Three important subjects were addressed: the first discussion held on the fifth programme for women, in which I had the opportunity to present an initial analysis of it; Commissioner Busquin's report on research and women's participation in research and science; and finally Commissioner Kinnock's statement informing the Commission of the commitment to ensuring that the gender dimension is taken into account in the general reform process now under way within the Community. Thank you for your reply, Commissioner. I must, however, regret the fact that this working group took so long to meet, despite the great importance of the issue having led us to trust that the new Commission, from the outset, would work in every area useful for achieving greater equality between men and women. I hope that in the future the situation may change and that the meetings of this working group will be more frequent, because there are so many issues that require the Commission's intervention, so as to facilitate and speed up the implementation, in the shortest possible time, of measures that guarantee greater equality between the two sexes.

Following the events that led to the resignation of the previous Commission, great expectations have been generated. Sometimes I get the impression that proposals are more well-received in this Parliament the more radical they sound. On the other hand, the situation is not resolved overnight with a clean slate, and the difficulties begin as soon as the time comes to implement the measures, as soon as the details have to be discussed. This is possibly the explanation why we in the Committee on Budgetary Control had more difficulties than expected with this matter. Despite this, the results can now be seen, and I would like to expressly thank Mr. van Hulten for his work on this report. If this report loses its consistency again through the acceptance of amendments, we are giving the Commission a clear and obvious advantage on several crucial points. Let me tell you the main advantages. We do not want financial controls to be abolished. It must remain possible for the auditor to examine resource allocations and payments before they are actually made, although not in every case, but only when there is some uncertainty or risk. This is why the Commission sends out the wrong signals, for example, when it changes the name of the Directorate-General for Financial Control to Directorate-General for Audit. Changing the Commission's organizational chart is easy, but it will be more complicated when the Commission turns to the texts, particularly the budgetary regulation. I haven't counted it exactly, but the Community's budgetary procedure and its implementing provisions refer in almost 100 different places to the financial controller, its independence, and the tasks assigned to it. This cannot be ignored or circumvented, not even with so-called soft law, as was once heard at a meeting of our committee. Regardless of such legal considerations, it would be an unforgivable mistake, given the nature of the matter, to abolish financial oversight in the traditional sense at the very moment when the Commission's competent authorities in this area are no longer alone, but are integrated into a chain of operational oversight and investigation mechanisms. According to our forecasts, three mechanisms will eventually influence each other in the future: the prior independent oversight of the financial controller; the accompanying and complementary oversight of the audit service, still being established, also known as the Audit Service; and, finally, the oversight of the new anti-fraud office, OLAF, which will look for any signs of irregularities. It is positive that Mr. van Hulten's report establishes the connection between the three areas and highlights the main shortcomings that need to be addressed. I will simply state that disciplinary procedures are insufficient, particularly when it comes to holding officials accountable for misconduct, including in financial matters. There is a large gray area and many unclear points when it comes to imposing criminal sanctions, and in this regard, the Commission's announcements are rather vague.

If such rules exist, who is responsible for ensuring their compliance, and what are they doing to fulfill that responsibility? Mr. President, I would like to raise again the issue of the status of assistants to Members, which we have always considered a priority, and to inform you that, as Italian members of the Group and responding to the invitation of the Group Chairman, Mr. Barón Crespo, we have sent the Quaestors the contracts we have with our assistants. I believe this is a concrete gesture to try to resolve this matter. Consequently, I would like to suggest to the Presidency of Parliament that it reflect on the appropriateness of the Presidency itself asking all Members to do the same. Mr. President, first of all, let me say that I am completely in favor of a status for assistants. Yesterday, when I arrived at Parliament, I was given a document regarding a demonstration that had been called by the assistants outside the Parliamentary building. As all colleagues will know—and many of you have contacted me for this reason over the past six months—all demonstrations and events of this nature are first filtered through Parliament's Comart Committee. As a non-controversial example, no trade exhibitions are permitted here in Parliament for obvious reasons. Following the letter I received yesterday, I immediately informed those present that we would propose authorizing a meeting or demonstration, probably in the near future and possibly next month. But all demonstrations must be carried out in a way that does not interfere with the smooth running of Parliament's business. Yesterday afternoon, I signed a letter at the Parliament's Bureau meeting informing those present about this. But as far as I have also been able to gather, they were verbally informed of this decision by the Committee of Group Chairs last Thursday, so they were aware of it. We have nothing against those present telling us how they feel, nor do we have anything against them gathering during Parliament's next part-session. But there was a misunderstanding, since they received a letter from someone else that led them to believe they had authorization. But all demonstrations are first reviewed by the so-called Comart Committee. As you can see, we attend many demonstrations around Parliament, relating to different countries or for other reasons. This is not an attempt at censorship or to go against the genuine and justified principle that we should have a statute for those attending. Thank you very much, Mrs. Banotti. I think your intervention can clarify many of the issues raised. Mr. President, I wanted to point out an important point of principle. Personally, I find it scandalous that some Members of this Parliament criticize the demonstrations instead of seeking a solution to the problem, which involves fair conditions, fair salaries, and fair working hours.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, having taken note of the Commission communication on the INTERREG III Community initiative, and having recalled that I took part in the vote on Mr Decourrière's report within the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, I feel it is important not only to reiterate our agreement in principle with the initiative in its current form but also, particularly in the context of INTERREG III B, to urge the Commission to recognise activities which are leading to the renewal of landscapes damaged by agricultural prices and in which numerous associations, particularly hunting associations, are making a major contribution in my country. I would also like to expressly support the comments made by the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, particularly with regard to the disappointment at the exclusion of the outermost regions from Strand A of the programme, the regret at the vague selection criteria for the implementation arrangements for Strand III C, and finally, the question of the participation of Members of Parliament in the work of the Observatory for Cross-Border, Transregional and Interregional Cooperation. I also have serious reservations about the tendency in the Commission's communication on INTERREG III and III B to attribute environmental protection exclusively to the development of Natura 2000. This often seems to me to be an overly abstract means of protecting ecosystems, whose users are in danger of being excluded or severely restricted. Finally, I would like to stress, and appeal in advance for the understanding of the Commission and the Council of Ministers concerned, that it would be advisable to provide European representatives with better information about the procedures involved in implementing INTERREG dossiers and, moreover, about similar initiatives. It would be even better to involve them more closely in the drafting and implementation of the programs in question, as otherwise they find it difficult to play their role vis-à-vis local authorities, national authorities, and even citizens. Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for the EQUAL report, Ms Stenzel, most sincerely for her efforts to make this difficult subject understandable to us all. EQUAL is an extremely complicated program because it attempts to merge various old programs while adopting a new approach, and to do so with fewer resources than were available for the previous funds. That is not so easy. However, the number of people reached by these programs has not really decreased. That is why it is difficult to strike a balance, not only between the individual countries and the individual sub-sectors, but especially between the target groups listed in the program. And that is essentially what we have been struggling with up to now. Some have said that one group should get more than another. I have personally focused primarily on the position of disabled and elderly people in the program, who, I believe, might have been occasionally overlooked if the European Parliament hadn't paid close attention to them. Although other groups are listed, the Member States, in particular, are on the lookout. One Member State I know, for example, wants to allocate a significant portion of the entire program to a single area: refugees.

This project has been long and complex. It will also be important to actively promote research into the use of renewable energy sources in the future. Although the new directive is valid, some shortcomings must also be highlighted, such as the use of peat, which must not be considered a fossil fuel. However, if it is not possible to classify it as a renewable, non-fossil energy source, a new ad hoc category must be created, taking into account the environmental tax in particular. It is not right that peat should be assessed using the same parameters as, for example, hard coal. The development of renewable energy sources is one of the tools that would allow the Union to reduce its dependence on imported energy sources. Research plays a key role, especially in view of the next round of negotiations for the enlargement of the EU. Dependence on imported energy sources affects some Eastern European countries most, which are still heavily dependent on the model introduced during the Soviet era. The European Union must be able to respect the Kyoto Agreements. It is clear that we are all concerned about the environment and the future of our children: that is why we must promote the rational use of renewable energy sources. However, we must remember that we cannot yet base our basic energy production on renewable sources. That is why we need nuclear energy to protect the atmosphere. Mr President, on behalf of the PSE political group, I am delighted with the outcome of the conciliation procedure on the ALTENER II programme. First of all, however, I would like to warmly thank the rapporteur, Mr Langen, who has done an excellent job with this report. I would also like to thank Mr Provan, chairman of our delegation to the conciliation committee, because, as Mr Langen has already said, this procedure was a very difficult battle. The outcome of the conciliation today also bears the clear imprint of the European Parliament. Mr Langen pointed out that the Council had taken up a number of the contents and requests of Parliament and that on the most controversial point, the financial allocation of the multiannual programme for the promotion of renewable energy sources in the Community, we still managed to meet the Council almost halfway. I would like to reiterate that we are not satisfied with this, but that we accepted the compromise because we considered it essential that the programme could be launched very soon. In the coming years, in fact, the aim is to double the share of renewable energy sources, bringing it to at least 12% of total energy consumption. Given this declared objective of the European Union, the only EU programme aimed exclusively at promoting renewable energy sources, the ALTENER programme, plays a truly decisive role. The new five-year programme aims first of all to expand the initiatives of the ALTENER I programme, including the intensification of the exchange of information and experience between operators in the renewable energy sector, the consolidation of existing local and regional energy agencies, the creation of new agencies and the promotion of existing networks. These are just a few examples. However, it seems to me that the ALTENER II programme is particularly important because for the first time it includes initiatives to facilitate the market penetration of renewable energy and to implement, monitor and control the Community strategy and action plan.

This has nothing to do with a lack of commitment to improving human rights, but rather demonstrates our usual concern for the right strategy so that we can achieve real results. I would like to illustrate these efforts by looking at three controversial issues: the death penalty, Cuba, and China. I will include one or two personal views in my remarks, even though this may be unwise. We are currently exploring the possibility of submitting a resolution on the death penalty to the Human Rights Commission. This has always been a matter of great personal interest to me, and I have consistently opposed the death penalty. Spurred on by Amnesty International and others, abolishing the death penalty was one of my first official actions as Governor of Hong Kong. We know what happened recently at the UN General Assembly. We were forced to put our motion on hold on the death penalty to prevent the adoption of a resolution containing completely unacceptable arguments that would have resulted in human rights not being universally applied and valid everywhere. The stage in New York is different from the one in Geneva. The issues of sovereignty and humanitarian intervention, which were discussed in New York last year, were such sensitive areas that they influenced all other topics. This certainly also affected the discussion on a moratorium on the death penalty. However, the debate in Geneva will primarily focus on human rights issues. Therefore, progress may be more likely in Geneva. The second point concerns Cuba. I want to address this issue directly because we in Europe are unfairly criticized for not taking human rights violations there seriously enough. We are deeply concerned about the measures the Cuban government has taken over the past year to curtail citizens' freedom. These include, for example, changes to the penal code and the extension of the death penalty. We are also deeply concerned about the recent increase in political imprisonment. We are monitoring the human rights situation through NGO reports and the work of our human rights working group set up in the EU embassies in Havana. We have regularly informed the Cuban authorities about the points we have criticized, and this Parliament has done likewise. However, I believe it is wrong to isolate Cuba. We want a just and open society in Cuba, a Cuba in which the principles of a market economy and the rule of law are respected, and treaties are honored. We want to promote the transition to democracy and strengthen respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. Many of these positions also apply to my third topic: China. I am, quite simply, in favor of making our position vis-à-vis China clear. A different stance would not only be convenient and nonsensical, it would be offensive to more than one-fifth of humanity. I hope that China will develop peacefully toward a free and pluralistic society in which people who advocate for democracy or belong to a religious community are not put behind bars. So how should we proceed? In any case, we should engage in intensive trade with China and hope that we can admit China into the World Trade Organization under reasonable conditions.

We agree on this point and I believe that the result we are delivering this evening, despite the lack of funding, will serve to widely relaunch this strategy and this opportunity for Europe that determines an economic and development factor: culture, therefore, the institutional and organizational component of a large community as presupposes economic development, and not the other way around, as Europe perhaps envisaged in the past, with a cultural habit. Man, culture have priority, and this culture can induce economic development. Let us observe this result, rejoice in it and award ourselves a certificate of great openness in the face of a useful strategy. Madam President, allow me, first of all, to thank Mr. Graça Moura for having managed to slip into the texture of this conciliatory fabric. It seems to me that, beginning the conciliatory process relating to Culture 2000, it is entirely appropriate that a poet guides us in our efforts. Once again, because these consultations are not entirely without difficulties, we must thank Vice-President Imbeni for his exemplary ability to negotiate a complex issue: ensuring that cultural spending is done wisely and is granted to us, within our Community. The fundamental question, I believe, facing Parliament, the Commission and the Council is this: what is Europe? What does it mean and what does it bring us beyond the parameters of our national borders? Europe is made up of its citizens, its history and now its collectivity, but this is why Culture 2000 is so important to us: I bet that when we ask the question "what is Europe", we answer with "our art, our literature and our heritage". This is what Culture 2000 represents. This programme offers the possibility of maintaining a European identity in the 21st century, an identity that avoids the echoes of division, war, poverty, opportunity, and poverty in reality. More than that, and this is more prosaic, Madam President, it means that we are able to learn the lessons of previous political initiatives by implementing them in new comprehensive, horizontal programmes that benefit our creative industries to the extent that they need it. It encourages mobility, and it opens the doors of culture to the socially disadvantaged and excluded. My only regret is that we do not have sufficient funding, in promoting this programme, to achieve our aspirations and guarantee our capacity to deliver. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have now reached the end of a long journey. After the conciliation stage, our institutions can now formally adopt the new "Culture 2000" framework programme. We will thus have a tool that is perfectly suited to developing, over the next five years, a clear, well-structured and, I am sure, fruitful action in favor of the cultural sector. It is with satisfaction that I welcome this happy ending here today and I thank you.

We are doing this; the resources and programs are there. I need—I must make this clear to you—this financial regulation, which is pending here for a decision, so that we can even begin. The financial regulation is the legal framework that enables us to address the priorities set out in the accession partnerships with Malta and Cyprus. I cannot begin anything until we have that, because I lack the legal basis. If the complained-about lack of coherence has anything to do with this point, then I must say that this regulation is merely a legal framework and nothing more. You will find the details of this legal framework in the priorities of the accession partnerships, which were adopted last year by the Commission and Council and are now being implemented in the corresponding programming and project management. I would say quite the opposite: there are many areas in European policy where one can complain about a lack of coherence. In this case, I would also like to acknowledge, on behalf of the Commission and the Council, that we have developed a very clear, transparent, and coherent policy. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, since the Commissioner has explained to us in an extraordinarily coherent manner that the lack of coherence was the responsibility of the then President-in-Office of the Council and his Minister of State for Europe, perhaps you could help us and the Commissioner so that this decision can be taken here. A helpful solution would be if you could answer my questions about the financial perspective up to 2004 and heading B7 in the affirmative, or at least express that—as the Commissioner will also try to do in the Commission—the Portuguese Presidency intends to make up for the lack of coherence of that time through such an effort. Mr President, I think the question raised by the honourable Member and my friend Elmar Brok will be carefully examined by the Council. I believe the criticism leveled at the previous Presidency is unjustified. In my view, the previous Presidency did an excellent job in defining the financial perspective, regardless of the people involved. In any case, this is an important issue, and at Council level we will definitely support the Commission's proposals on this matter. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I understand; Mr Brok was actually referring to an even earlier presidency. Mr President, I put a specific question to Commissioner Verheugen about the Meda financial instrument, but he did not answer it. I would sincerely ask him to do so, because the voting on various amendments before us will depend on his answer. Mr Poos, I apologize. There was a ambiguity precisely at the point where you asked me the question. With Meda, Malta and Cyprus can participate in the cross-regional programs, but not in the country-specific ones because their incomes are too high. Thank you very much, Commissioner Verheugen! The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday. Question Time (Council) The next item is Question Time (B5-0009/2000). We will deal with questions to the Council.

However, according to the SCRS investigation, the 6.4 kg rule was inadequately enforced in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. WWF reports that, according to Italian, French, and Spanish customs services, illegal bluefin tuna catches and landings of juveniles are increasing. I cannot and do not want to elaborate further on this. We are all pressed for time. Mr. President, I would like to once again congratulate our rapporteur, Mr. Gallagher. Thank you, Commissioner Fischler. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11:00 a.m. Fisheries and the Environment: 2nd Report following Bergen The next item is the report (A5-0016/2000) by Mr Varela Suanzes-Carpegna, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the second report from the Commission to the Council and the European Parliament on the implementation of the conclusions of the Ministerial Meeting on Fisheries and the Environment held in Bergen on 13 and 14 March 1997 (COM(1999) 270 - C5-0156/1999 - 1999/2150(COS)). Mr President, Mr Fischler, ladies and gentlemen, the report I am presenting concerns the important issue of integrating the environment-fisheries binomial, which was discussed at the ministerial meeting in Bergen. Personally, this integration has always concerned me, because we would be doing a disservice to the fishing industry and the fishermen of tomorrow if we failed to emphasize the need to conserve stocks and, ultimately, to engage in responsible fishing. Failure to do so would mean not only bread today but hunger tomorrow for our fishermen and European citizens, but – even more seriously – for all of humanity. The Common Fisheries Policy is theoretically very demanding and rigorous in this area, perhaps more so than many people – many Europeans and many non-Europeans alike – can imagine. For this reason, I have called on the European Commission to publish an inventory of all the Common Fisheries Policy measures for the conservation and protection of stocks, in order to disseminate our protective measures. We have also asked DG4 of our Parliament to prepare a systematic study of these measures for the members of our Committee on Fisheries. The revision of the Common Fisheries Policy in 2002 is the greatest challenge within a fixed timeframe for a comprehensive review, a modernization—or updating, if you will—of the Common Fisheries Policy as a whole. I insist on the whole, and consequently also on the protection of fishery resources being taken into account in the Common Fisheries Policy. This is the essence of my request to the European Commission and to the services of our Parliament. I do not believe that the state of the stocks or the scandalous current discard system are a good example of the goodness of the system, which, in my view, therefore requires significant improvements. I cannot and do not want to dwell on this too much; we are all aware of the relentlessness of the clock and also the working hours of interpreters. Therefore, I would like to remind you that Bergen represents a very important example of what the creation of a genuine maritime policy must look like. As the President-in-Office of the Council said to our committee when he announced that the current Portuguese Presidency wanted to ensure that fishing was seen as a policy aimed at preserving our sustainable resources, that must be our objective in Europe and on the planet.

The same applies to Amendment 2, which we would also consider acceptable with a slight modification, as the underlying idea seems correct to us. Amendment 4 has more or less the same characteristics. On this specific point, we could possibly give Mr Bourlanges greater satisfaction. We have already asked the Council to include in its decision a statement from the Commission establishing this element of conditionality. What we are proposing specifically, regarding the second tranche, is that the exact amount and the time at which the second tranche will be implemented should be decided, taking into account Kosovo's external financial needs and the contribution of other bilateral donors. In other words, we are not imposing conditionality, or we believe it is more effective not to impose conditionality from the outset, but we are imposing it when the second tranche is eventually granted. This way, we would not have any problems acting immediately, we would not create problems for the people of Kosovo, but, on the other hand, we would force other donors to make their financial effort in the same way that we do. Mrs. Dührkop raised a third problem, in the area of multiannual programs. The projects are, as a reminder, multiannual. The programs must, of course, take into account annual budgetary contributions. Finally, I would like to make a comment on the requests for additional information that you are requesting from us. On the one hand, we have been asked to provide Parliament with the progress of calls for tenders and in this regard, I can tell you that the Commission already had the opportunity, last week, to provide Parliament's Committee on Budgets with the latest statement of contracts and payments made since the task force was set up in Kosovo. The Commission can undertake to continue to keep Parliament regularly informed of published calls for tenders. We also hope that they will be published on the Internet, in order to ensure the greatest transparency on this specific point. A second point on which I would like to comment is the remaining information that may be important for Parliament regarding the implementation of macroeconomic assistance. In this regard, I also inform you that the Commission is willing to regularly inform the chairmen of the various parliamentary committees concerned, on a confidential basis, if the nature of the information provided so requires, and on the various schemes that are implemented for macroeconomic assistance operations. I thank you, ladies and gentlemen, and I hope that, with the Council's final decision, we will be able to release these funds and make a positive contribution that will allow us to continue the important effort that everyone is making to improve the coexistence and peace that we all desire. Mr President, I welcome the convergence of views that exists between Parliament, the Committee on Budgets in particular, and the Commission, and I assure you that, for our part, we will always be faithful to the meeting to help the Commission carry out its task.

These are some of the main reasons why we do not agree with the motion for a resolution before us. The European Parliament Labour abstained from the final vote on the Leinen Dimitrakopoulous report. The text is too ambitious, and the British Labour EP believes that the Intergovernmental Conference should primarily deal with the issues still outstanding after Amsterdam, in order to prepare for enlargement, without going too far away from these issues. Work is currently being done hard on reform, and for the time being this must remain a priority if we are to ensure the consolidation and strengthening of the Community institutions. A broadening of the agenda and a drastic revision of the Treaties would carry a risk of destabilisation. The key element of the text, as amended, is the call for a Charter of Fundamental Rights to be attached to the Treaties. In our view this would be a heavy legislative burden, whereas it would be preferable to have a written political declaration explaining to citizens what their rights are. Our priorities (so-called "left-overs") must be: the number and responsibilities of Commissioners the weighting of votes in the Council the extension of qualified majority voting in some areas, to the benefit of the UK and Europe (but excluding Treaty changes, defence issues, border control and taxation), with consequent extension of codecision where qualified majority voting applies. In addition to this, we believe that the proposal to introduce the concept of "flexibility" and to increase cooperation is not appropriate at the present time. The Amsterdam provisions have not been sufficiently tested, and extending the option of opting out could weaken the European Union at a time when we are talking about enlargement and candidate countries are being asked to accept the single market and other European laws. In order to influence the developments underway, the European Parliament must adopt a more constructive attitude towards the agenda of the Intergovernmental Conference than the line which emerges from this resolution, which is excessively full of disappointment and defeatism towards the decision taken in Helsinki in December 1999. The European Parliament and its Committee on Constitutional Affairs should instead have concentrated more precisely on a well-defined number of aspects not included in the Helsinki decision, indicating the elements considered most urgent to be addressed, including the question of public prosecution for crimes committed against the institutions of the Union and their financial interests. We Swedish Christian Democrats are also opposed to the threat to delay enlargement to the East if the scope of the Intergovernmental Conference is not substantially extended, well beyond what the Intergovernmental Conference in Amsterdam left unresolved in 1997. The most important task of the forthcoming Intergovernmental Conference will be to reform the Union with a view to its enlargement to the new Member States. I therefore naturally agree that Parliament should now give its formal green light to the opening of the Intergovernmental Conference. However, I believe that this conference should be limited to those aspects which are indispensable for enlargement. For the rest, I refer to my explanation of vote of 18 November 1999, in which I clarify my position on the supranational character and common defence.

The Commission would like to see a greater role for the Joint Assembly, particularly in promoting broader political dialogue with our development partners. The Commission shares the rapporteur's view that the fight against poverty must continue to be a priority objective of development policy and that it must continue to play a key role. However, in order to develop, countries must be actively involved in the global economic system. In the area of trade with our development partners, the Commission is quite prepared to ensure that the particular economic and social frameworks of the ACP countries are taken into account in any new arrangement. Mrs. Lucas said that the Stabex and Sysmin systems should be continued. I personally do not believe this. These systems have proven inadequate because they actually benefit only a very small number of the 71 countries concerned. These systems are too slow, and it is therefore normal that the developing countries have said "yes" to the new system that will be used in the future, because it will be more flexible. Regarding the future accession of certain countries to the Lomé Convention, such as East Timor, I can only repeat what I recently said before the European Parliament's Committee on Development, namely that the door is open to them. It is up to the candidate countries to decide for themselves whether they wish to apply. We will then take a position on them. Regarding Cuba's application for accession to the Lomé Convention, the Commission noted that, on the basis of their recent statement, the ACP states will support Cuba's application. The EU has always advocated a constructive attitude towards Cuba - the EU's common position demonstrates this - but it must be recognized that the discussions will be complicated. Regarding Côte d'Ivoire, I can announce that the €28 million has been repaid in full, in accordance with the agreement reached following the investigation into the financial irregularities identified. As regards the financing of the European Development Fund through the budget, I would like to state that this is currently under review. For its part, the Commission is in favour of it, but we cannot, at this stage, make any new statements about when this will be possible or how it will be achieved. Regarding Article 366A, I would like to say that a new procedure was created, during the negotiations on a new partnership agreement, for examining cases of violations of human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law. As is already the case today, Parliament will continue, after the adoption of the Treaty of Amsterdam and on the basis of Article 300, to be kept fully informed of all decisions taken, and the Commission will continue to take into account the resolutions adopted by Parliament on this matter. There is no provision for such decisions to follow the procedure of asking Parliament to issue a concurring opinion. This would require an amendment to the Treaty of Amsterdam, which has just been signed.

However, precisely, the entire Commission communication is built on the opposite premise, according to which it would be necessary, under the pretext of better defending people, to ever further limit their scope for autonomous choice through new regulations, new policy integrations or new binding legal structures such as the draft charter, quite wrongly called, of fundamental rights. I emphasize "quite wrongly" because, in fact, it will reduce these rights. In the Europe of Nations Group, our principles are quite different. We want to defend the countries of Europe, but also respect the choices of the people. This is not at all squaring the circle. We must indeed move away from outdated federalist models, the models of those whose ideas, in European matters, come all the way from the Memoirs of Jean Monnet. On the contrary, we must open the European institutions to the modern world by inventing a dynamic of variable geometry that respects nations. This is the great idea on the new governance that we would have liked to find in your communication, Mr President, unfortunately, it was not there. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, you claim to be shaping a new Europe, but you are, alas, lacking one essential condition: trust. You cannot, in fact, attract the trust of millions of Europeans when you are not worthy of it. And how could you be worthy of trust after the mad cow disease affair, after the resignation of the Santer Commission for corruption? You bear the responsibility for millions of unemployed and millions of poor people, for the precariousness and growing poverty because of your ultra-trade and ultra-liberal policies, because of the forced march towards the single currency. You wanted and organized the disappearance of internal borders and you have thus delivered Europe to the explosion of crime and insecurity, to the surge of uncontrolled immigration. Today you propose giving all decision-making power to a handful of civil servants by making states, local authorities and NGOs, all of whom are placed on an equal footing in their submission to Brussels, mere executors of decisions made from above. Not once in your fourteen-page document are national parliaments mentioned, even though they are composed of elected representatives of the people. But it is true that they have no role in your strategy. You do not even dare to call a spade a spade and you take refuge behind pseudo-trendy semantics to call "governance" what is nothing other than a federal, autocratic and centralized government. After having, for years, tried to convince by talking about shared sovereignty, you now admit your ultimate goal: to sell off all European sovereignty, whether national or collective, to a world government, in which you do not even hope to obtain a leading position. Finally, you dare to condemn and punish, or allow others to condemn and punish, the free and democratic vote of millions of Austrians simply because you don't like the result. And at the same time, you support Communist China and trade with countries that have been openly violating human rights for decades. Even today, MEPs are protesting against a telegram from Mr Prodi to Chancellor Schüssel, which, however, is clearly not a show of sympathy, but a political maneuver.

Here we are in an area where the principle of subsidiarity applies in full. Each Member State has a primary duty to define its own responsibilities towards children. As regards the responsibility of the Union as such, I believe it is necessary for children's rights to be recognised in the Charter, taking into account the areas in which the Union can bring added value to the promotion of the social, economic and also civic situation, in the broadest sense, of children. I hope that we will be able to meet the challenge that the honourable Member has launched to the Commission and to the whole Convention. Mr President, I have had the honour of listening to the Commissioner on this issue on several occasions and I fully share his approach. However, I would like to ask a slightly different question. We have just heard Commissioner Barnier say that he is keen to improve communication with citizens and to focus the Commission's information policy on the main issues that the Community is dealing with this year. Would the Commissioner be in favour of allocating part of the Commission's information budget to a campaign to raise awareness among citizens about the Citizens' Charter? It is very important that citizens feel part of this process. I know that the Convention itself will do a lot in this area, but it does not have the resources that the Commission has. Will the Commission consider using the information budget to ensure that citizens participate in the debate? The Commission's policy is to promote an open and broad dialogue on the Charter of Fundamental Rights, not only with non-governmental organisations, but also with citizens, on a project as far-reaching as the Charter. I can assure you that the Commission will do its utmost to launch a debate on the future Charter of Fundamental Rights. If we end up with a clear text, easy for citizens to read, and at the same time legally binding, we will kill two birds with one stone: the two are not mutually exclusive. The challenge is to ensure that both are ensured in the final version of the Charter. I am very pleased to know that I can count on your support. Question No. 40, by the Honourable Member (H-0095/00): Subject: Articles 6(1), 7(1) and 7(2) of the Treaty on European Union Article 6(1) of the Treaty states that the Union is founded on the principles of liberty, democracy and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. From statements made in recent years it is clear that Jörg Haider and his party (Freiheitliche Partei Österreichs - FPÖ) do not respect human rights and fundamental freedoms in relation to third-country nationals and minorities residing in Austria. Accordingly, can the Commission indicate when it intends to propose, pursuant to Article 7(1), that "the existence of a serious and persistent breach by a Member State of the principles referred to in Article 6(1)" be contested and to urge the Council, acting by a qualified majority, to suspend certain of Austria's rights under the Treaty, including the right to vote of Austria's representative in the Council?

This term, moreover, seems to have been dropped from the Commission's vocabulary, whereas liberal and American references abound. Romano Prodi invokes the highly controversial concept of "governance," controversial because it prioritizes dirigism over the proper functioning of democracy and because it refers to the term defined by the IMF, whose ideological content is entirely shaped by liberalism and monetarism. This is not a mere semantic difference. Reading this document, one is struck by the thought that it is only about the completion of the internal market and the goal of general deregulation, and not about the reorientation of European politics hoped for by our fellow citizens. Romano Prodi speaks only of "mechanisms" and "structures," but he does not describe balanced projects that correspond to the wishes of our peoples. Enlargement appears to be an end in itself; However, if no social policy, no common values, and no institution to strengthen cohesion and further democratize the Union are adopted, the Europe left behind at the end of Prodi's presidency could be a simple common market within a generalized globalization, rather than the community of shared destiny we hoped for. Finally, the leniency shown by Romano Prodi toward Austria in the name of purely formal compliance with the law—which, incidentally, in no way obliges him to send a message of congratulations—would in itself justify a vote of no confidence. The European Union does not hold back from clearly announcing its expansionist ambitions. The Commission's objective for the next five-year period is to become a "player on the world stage" capable of playing a "primary leadership role in the world." The European Union has not changed in its essence. From the outset, its actions were determined by a few dozen large economic and financial corporations and their interest groups. But the Prodi Commission now wants to transform the European Union in order to assert a common claim to leadership on the world stage with the United States, with which it simultaneously competes and rivals. This new imperial policy entails a reform of European and national institutions, the strengthening of state power, fiercer competition, a European army, and the redistribution of financial resources. That anyone still dares to speak of defending a "European social model" is a shameful lie, because the more the European Union opposes the United States, the more it becomes its faithful reflection. We vote against these goals because we oppose such policies in Parliament and in the streets. The drafting of a European Charter of Fundamental Rights would be the only small glimmer of hope in this policy, but again, there is no provision for making this a matter for the peoples of Europe and allowing them to decide on it democratically. We abstained from voting on the resolution for the following reasons: First, the resolution does not sufficiently demonstrate the vagueness of the priorities and commitments reflected in the Commission's programme. Furthermore, we believe that the main issue facing the Commission in setting priorities for the next five years relates to its role in interinstitutional relations within the EU—and this is where both the programme and the resolution are lacking.

It is clear that we need to convert old methods of social spending into new economic and social opportunities. We need to free ourselves from the policies and methods that have condemned a generation of Europeans to be second-class citizens on the world stage, and to do so we need to enable Europe and its people to develop their full potential. If Lisbon succeeds in achieving these objectives that have been discussed today, it will be an important step forward in unleashing the dynamic to which I have referred. Prime Minister, we too would like to believe with you, and with the Portuguese Presidency, that the construction of Europe must be the construction of a civilisation whose economic and social prosperity is based on the valorisation of knowledge, cultural diversity and cohesion, a civilisation that plays an active role in promoting a more balanced, more peaceful and more supportive world order. And we would also like to believe with you that there is a clear and general awareness of the fact that the extent of the foreseeable transformations in terms of qualifications needed to face the new technological challenges that companies are dealing with also includes, at the same time, the risk of new processes of social exclusion, to quote your words once again. We would like to believe it, but we can't. Why? Because we know that the new economy certainly allows the emergence of new employment opportunities for creative people and for computer scientists. The feverish agitation with which new investors are always appearing and with which the phenomenon of start-ups is developing is before our eyes, but we are also equally aware of the continuous turnover of personnel at telephone exchanges, due to the appalling working conditions prevailing in these new sanctuaries of Taylorism in which hundreds of thousands of dependent workers are employed. We know that more than half of the jobs created in the Union at present are precarious, temporary, forced rather than chosen part-time and that, by virtue of this, they cannot guarantee those who occupy them the conditions of personal autonomy - and often not even an income - that would guarantee a decent life. We know that new technologies in themselves do not generate more democracy, but only more individual and collective autonomy for the most socially integrated citizens. We know that the privatization of public services jeopardises social, territorial and regional cohesion, and we also know that the Commission proposes to accelerate it. We know that UNICE, on behalf of employers, is announcing very clearly from now on the tone of the preparatory documents for the European Business Summit, scheduled for Brussels in June: public authorities will be asked to remove all social, regulatory and fiscal obstacles to the development of the business world, but also to invest massively in the consolidation of demand. And finally, we know that those who pride themselves on providing answers to the needs of citizens must first of all guarantee their full participation in choices regarding public policies. All things that we know well. Yet we have read or heard nothing to suggest that the recommendation of the High Level Expert Group, according to which the full economic success of the information society presupposes that it is fuelled by the real needs of the citizen, rather than by the market forces of technology companies alone, will be taken into account.

Therefore, Madam Vice-President, following the electoral victory of a certain party in a large country, you would make my evening even more enjoyable if you were to say: we can support the rapporteur's Amendment No 3! I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on this extremely important issue and also express my thanks to the Commissioner and the Commission for this proposal. We welcome the fact that, among other things, the Portuguese Presidency has set itself the goal of doing something about the scandalous state of road safety in the European Union. I know that these figures are well known, but let me quickly remind you: 43 000 citizens are killed in road accidents every year. This means that practically a medium-sized town is wiped out every year. We welcome the initiative presented because it at least makes an attempt to ensure that commercial vehicles are as safe as possible and comply with Community legislation. Commercial vehicle traffic on European roads is constantly increasing, both in terms of number and size. In our view, there are three reasons why this proposal is so important. First, there is the safety argument, which has already been mentioned. The second argument, which my colleague, Mr Jarzembowski, has already explained, is fair competition and the need to create a level playing field throughout the Community. Third, there are the positive environmental aspects, as this proposal will make it possible to use quieter and less polluting vehicles in the future. Random checks must be carried out throughout the EU. In my country, the United Kingdom, such a system is already in operation with very positive results. While this proposal will inevitably have negative consequences for the black sheep among hauliers, other road users, in particular the vast majority of lorry drivers, vehicle owners, and hauliers who are conscientious about the quality, safety, and compliance with environmental standards of their vehicles, will benefit from it. I welcome this initiative and hope it will be implemented as soon as possible. Mr President, Ms de Palacio, The amendment of the directive on annual roadworthiness tests for commercial vehicles is a matter of urgency and importance. The rapporteur has also ultimately reached a good conclusion here. Commercial vehicles cover a great many kilometers each year, and their condition cannot be effectively monitored through annual inspections alone. Unannounced roadside inspections are also necessary because dilapidated heavy goods vehicles from third countries often travel within the Union, posing a serious safety risk. The amendment of the directive aims to significantly increase road safety if the regulations are properly complied with and if penalties can be imposed for violations that are effective, targeted, and dissuasive. The effectiveness of the directive will be increased if Member States can consult on the harmonisation of penalties. However, this must not delay the rapid implementation of the directive. One argument for the rapid amendment of the directive is a recent case in Finland. Police and supervisory authorities recently inspected 62 heavy goods vehicles in eastern Finland, of which 30 were fined and 16 were given warnings.
