It marks the beginning of a contractual stabilization of the countries of the former Yugoslavia. These are the countries that are not yet eligible for a pre-accession agreement. In fact, the current agreement is a kind of "pre-pre-agreement," but with a view to future accession. This union of countries through active treaties is an excellent instrument, provided that the agreed provisions are resolutely respected and the desired stabilization is thus achieved. Macedonia remains a potential powder keg, and its entire history bears witness to this. Yet it has the ambition to shake off this reputation. To achieve this, it needs internal stability. The new government wants to tackle the issue, and the agreement can be a timetable for reform, including a direct role and an equal position for the Albanian minority. The country especially needs calm now, to restore order to the situation and find the path to greater prosperity. We Social Democrats call on the opposition to behave in accordance with these notions. They must also contribute to the Macedonian model so highly praised here. But the country also and above all needs external stability. What good is internal stability if the surrounding area is unstable? This stability is necessary in relations with Yugoslavia, Kosovo, Albania, and Bulgaria. The region must recognize that Macedonia exists and will continue to exist. External stability means open borders and regional cooperation. Minorities and majorities must have opportunities for cultural and human exchange. Macedonia's stability is closely linked to developments in neighboring countries. The Kosovo problem is well known, and the international community is present there en masse. It seems that the Albania factor is underestimated. The Union believes that the time is not yet right to sign a Stability and Association Agreement with this country. But what is needed then? It is precisely the arguments put forward for concluding such an agreement with Macedonia and not with Albania that concern us and lead us to say that a wait-and-see attitude on the part of the Union towards Albania is unacceptable. What does the Commission do with this consideration? Yugoslavia is also a weak link in terms of stability and therefore poses a threat to a stable Macedonia. We must wait and see how the situation develops. Belgrade's mood is becoming increasingly unpredictable. However, we support the Council's decision to change the direction of sanctions. This, at last, is a serious attempt to support the opposition, which is preparing for a new round of demonstrations. What else will the Union do in this regard if the opposition's demand for early elections is accepted? What more can we do and what more can we undertake to support this opposition? Mr President, Commissioner, the Kosovo affair has hopefully marked the end of an era in which the rights of peoples could be interpreted in a way that left dictators free to persecute minorities in the most terrible ways, as long as these persecutions took place "within the nation".

The rapporteur has informed Parliament that the Council's common position incorporates six of the ten amendments to the text tabled by Parliament at first reading, as well as the substance of Parliament's other amendments. Consequently, my group will support the common position and hopes for swift enactment of legislation, which will provide us with another tool in our fight to ensure that transport within the Union achieves the highest possible level of safety. My group will also support any initiative aimed at improving transport safety. We still have a lot to do in this area, as current events show. Madam President, I would like to make a few remarks. First, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his extremely precise technical work on this file, and secondly, the Commission for the proposal it has put forward. This concerns the harmonization of examination requirements, but also of minimum requirements. In a certain sense, this is a shame. The importance of safety on the road, on the rails, or on waterways is naturally paramount, and due to the international nature of these modes of transport, we must also harmonize the training of safety advisors, as well as, in particular, the requirements of the new ADR, which should soon come into force. This is important, but compliance with these measures is just as important, and there are naturally several reasons why we must pay particular attention to this. Let us examine the road accidents of recent years. For example, in Belgium, the Netherlands, and certain other countries, during foggy weather, with trucks transporting dangerous goods, when in such conditions they should have stayed on the side of the road. Or boatmen and their ships from Eastern Europe who moor their boats side by side, making dangerous situations all the more obvious. Furthermore, an investigation conducted in Belgian, Finnish, and Japanese ports revealed that 50 percent of containers with partially dangerous cargo were not properly unloaded. In short, the subject is very important. If we look at the situation of safety advisors, since January 1, in some countries, companies must have such an advisor. Compliance with this principle currently poses significant problems, especially for smaller companies that cannot afford it financially. They will either dispose of their cargo or mix it with other cargo, which creates a series of problems. For this reason, there are requests that these activities be developed in the form of annual reports, company analyses, and possibly included in ISO 9002 certificates. The work is done; it is still a matter of ensuring compliance. Allow me to raise one last point. With regard to this compliance, satisfactory agreements must also be concluded with the Eastern European countries, because it is not until July 1, 2001, in a little over a year and a half, that they will adhere to the current conventions.

However, my experience is that these branches of production manage quite well. They often have too much capital and are often overindulged. I have seen computer companies treated with incredible condescension. I believe, on the contrary, that resources should be used to try to prevent the disintegration of society, a division of society into two sectors: a new economy and an old one. Integration mechanisms should be created specifically. Perhaps the most important thing would be the creation of an infrastructure that would provide opportunities for the non-expansive branches of the economy and for population groups on the periphery. For this reason, I believe we should focus on computers in daycare centers, broadband cabling in sparsely populated areas, technologically focused public libraries, and on not weakening the public sector. Mr. President, the agenda of the Lisbon Council, to be held on March 23 and 24, is staggering. At the chapter headings alone, we see mention of the Europe of innovation and knowledge, structural reforms, competitiveness, the European social model, employment, social cohesion, macroeconomic policies, and sustainable growth. On that basis, it is hardly surprising that the many contributions from the Commission Presidency and the Member States tend, for now, to be scattered in all directions. This exercise could end in two very different ways: either it allows for a broad exchange of stimulating ideas, which each will then try to implement in their own countries, possibly with joint initiatives in the new field of electronic exchange—and that scenario would not be such a bad one after all—or the Council insists on announcing results in terms of the transfer of powers to Europe, and we will head towards greater centralization and bureaucracy, in other words, the exact opposite of what is needed. Reading the preparatory documents gives us some apprehensions in this regard. We learned that—pardon the jargon, but it's not mine—we must achieve better convergence of the Cologne process regarding macroeconomic policy coordination, the Cardiff process regarding structural reforms, and the Luxembourg process regarding employment policy coordination, while also enriching the content of the employment pact and the multilateral monitoring of budgetary policies. But how can we achieve better convergence of all these very different processes? The conclusion of the Presidency document dated January 12 provides the key. We would need to reform the broad economic policy guidelines, the GOPs, which currently only have the status of annual recommendations from the Council to the Member States, to broaden their scope and, above all, to strengthen their status as a "framework" document. Apparently, the word "framework" should be understood here with its double meaning of synthesis and obligation.

I think we should congratulate ourselves on this. But what arguments did the Commission, and specifically Commissioner Monika Wulf-Mathies and Director-General Eneko Landaburu, have for not having the URBAN program? Their argument was compelling. The urban issue is so important that we cannot limit it and almost undervalue it with a program that has very little budget. Today we have the program, and therefore, I believe we have achieved something important, that hallmark of the European Union: URBAN. But I wanted to address Commissioner Barnier to support the arguments of the Commissioner and the Director-General, because I believe they were quite right. The urban dimension must be incorporated much more deeply into all the Structural Funds. The budgetary level required by our cities—home to 80% of the European population and which are becoming a large part of both the good and the bad that we have in Europe—I believe precisely demands that this European dimension be taken into account and that this URBAN program not be used as a justification for failing to conduct in-depth analysis, for failing to prioritize, and therefore for failing to introduce an infinitely larger budget allocation for programs that affect cities through all European funds. Therefore, I believe it is unnecessary to list the number of factors that demand this investment in urban areas, factors that are the order of the day, and I would like to convey to the Commissioner that we await his sensitivity in this regard. In embracing the cross-sectoral approach embodied in the new EQUAL initiative, it is crucial that the programme seek to combat the various forms of discrimination against people with disabilities, particularly physical barriers in the workplace, which affect people with limited mobility, visual information systems, which exclude blind workers, and employment systems that slam the door on people with learning difficulties or mental health problems. Disability organizations and non-disabled representatives of people with disabilities must take a genuine interest in every stage of decision-making. This is why this Parliament has proposed paragraphs 10 and 15 of the regulation to ensure that Member States cannot leave out any of the groups targeted by this initiative. People with disabilities have already been left out of the list too often. Because people with disabilities do not form a homogeneous group—for example, many deaf people are considered a linguistic minority discriminated against for having their own language and culture—it is necessary to allow for the definition of certain associations that are specific to a disability or a particular group, as stipulated in Section 9. EQUAL remains crucial in regions, like my own in the east of England, that are left out of the main Objective 1 grants. We have benefited from an extra incentive to resume funding for Community initiatives, which has had an excellent record of response. Former ADAPT projects include projects such as CORE, which developed new supply chains for the automotive industry in Bedfordshire, and projects aimed at improving the standards of small businesses in Hertfordshire, Essex.

Until now, Member States calculated this GDP according to the ESA 79 methodology. The last assessment available to us was transmitted in September 1999 and relates to the 1998 financial year. If this Regulation is adopted, the notification of March 2000, the first assessment of the deficit for the 1999 financial year, will therefore already be made according to this new system. As is well known, the Member States have done their duty—if one can put it that way—by calculating and compiling their national accounts in accordance with the ESA 95 and have already published their corresponding assessments. This required, in addition to the introduction of the new methodology, the nominal revision of most aggregates and accounting transactions, both because of the aforementioned methodological changes and because of the improved statistical information incorporated into the estimates. These changes may, of course, alter the government deficits in the context of the Member States' national accounts. I would like to briefly outline the five areas in which the most significant changes will occur. First, the adjustments to the definition of what is understood as the institutional sector of public administrations according to ESA 95. This is important because the government deficit refers to the revenue, if any, of all public administrations. The lack of precise criteria for its definition would lead to discrepancies in the assessments of government deficits by Member States. Second, the government deficit – or, as the case may be, the government surplus – corresponds to the designated balance of need or financing capacity of the ESA 95 public administrations sector. Third, public investment corresponds to the gross fixed capital formation of the public administrations sector according to ESA 95. Fourth, the ESA 95 defines government debt as well as the flows or interest resulting from these liabilities or assets. Fifth and finally, the aggregate to which the government deficit refers is gross domestic product at market prices, as defined by the 1995 System of National and Regional Accounts. Ultimately, I believe this Commission proposal is a correct and concrete adjustment of the criteria laid down in the 1995 System of National and Regional Accounts, which I therefore agree with in its entirety, as set out by the Commission. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let me say at the outset that my group welcomes this proposal because it will make the statistical basis for an economic and monetary union oriented towards stability and real growth more harmonised, more directly comparable, and more accurate. We have already heard the various sectors. For me, it is crucial that, from now on, statistical data are more reliable and comparable. This is necessary because we must be able to rely on one another: the various institutions of the European Union and all the Member States within the monetary union. Adapting the procedure is important for two reasons. First, for the internal market. Reliable and directly comparable data and statistics are generally of great importance for an accurate representation of the situation and developments in a single market. Secondly, for Economic and Monetary Union. The 1993 regulation on the application of the Protocol must be aligned with the methodology of the European System of National and Regional Accounts.

Thus, today we are witnessing a clear consolidation of the essential core of "Thatcherite" orientations, albeit softened by welfare measures. And this is not done by force of proclaimed conservative principles, under the guise of a supposedly globalizing pragmatism and in the name of a deified competitiveness. Therefore, it is not enough to call for the coordination of social policies or to insist on the innovation and knowledge society or on information technologies, however important they may be. It is essential to abandon this monetarist and antisocial perspective and definitively place the human person at the forefront of priorities and policies. My Group, which attaches particular importance to social issues, and taking into account the upcoming extraordinary Council, met last week in Lisbon precisely for the purpose of analyzing and debating these problems. There we had the opportunity to debate and hear from workers' representatives and trade unionists from Portugal and other parts of Europe, and we met, in particular, with representatives from ABB and Michelin, as well as with promoters of the job marches. We drew conclusions based on 14 points that we will officially communicate to the Council Presidency. For us, it is essential to adopt macroeconomic policy measures based on boosting demand and public investment and respecting renovated public services, aimed at full employment and guaranteeing an employment level of around 75% in 2010. It is necessary to guarantee a more labor-friendly income distribution, ensure the taxation of speculative capital movements, and combat tax fraud and evasion. It is necessary to hinder mergers and company relocations, particularly when they are aimed at and accompanied by layoffs. It is necessary to move forward with reducing working hours without reducing wages and without deteriorating job quality. It is necessary to reconsider the Union's financial perspectives, to decisively support small and medium-sized enterprises, to firmly commit to a revamped education system and to more and better vocational training, and to put an end to the discrimination that primarily affects women and young people. In light of this, and of the ability to formulate concrete objectives, duly expressed in figures and with a timetable in this crucial area, we will analyze and assess the results of the Lisbon Summit. Mr. President, the Lisbon Summit will generate a new repertoire of fine words. These words will be well received; however, the fundamental problem lies in the existence of an Economic and Monetary Union that puts the fight against inflation before employment. The Central Bank has stated that price increases must always remain below 2%; the Stability Pact stipulates that the annual budget deficit must not exceed 1%. There is no requirement that the unemployment rate be below 5% or—even better—below 2% or 1%. It is the price of money that must not rise, it is public spending that must not increase. A country may wish to limit unemployment through public investment, however, such an action is prohibited.

But who will ultimately pay the costs? Regardless of which system is adopted, it will be the consumer who pays the price. To best pursue environmental objectives, we should entrust the producers with both the task of collecting the money and of scrapping and recycling used cars. The producers have persuaded the Honourable Members Florenz and Lange to table amendments that significantly weaken the original proposals. Do not be fooled by the car manufacturers! If you want this directive to be as effective as possible, use your vote to reject these amendments. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this debate, contrary to what we might think, is not of a technical nature. It has become eminently political. Yesterday, we honoured our institution with a political debate. Today, it would be a disgrace for us if 314 Members were to give in to the power of the lobby of certain car manufacturers. By asking consumers to bear half the cost of taking back end-of-life vehicles, as set out in Amendment 38, while the common position provides that the entire cost of taking back is to be borne by the producer, for the first time Parliament would not present itself as the guarantor of the protection of consumers and European citizens, but would become in some way a sounding board for lobbies. We cannot accept this. It would be a precedent that would leave the door open to all kinds of pressure in many other areas. It would also be the first time that Parliament would water down a position of the Council, while in general, it seems to me, we are mainly criticising the positions of the Council. For example, the system of free take-back of old vehicles and the increase in the percentage of vehicles for recycling will proportionally increase recycling activities and the number of jobs. Therefore, for the consumer, for the environment, for the new jobs to be created in the recycling sector, there is absolutely no need to amend the Council's common position, which, as it stands, is fully acceptable. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we all agree that we need to think about how end-of-life vehicles are to be treated in Europe, but in this case the Council has not set an example of a good European environmental policy. The German Presidency has behaved shamefully in dealing with this issue. Firstly, Environment Minister Trittin has not sufficiently agreed on a common line with his government colleagues, then Chancellor Schröder has meddled in this matter without any knowledge of the facts and with the grace of an elephant in a china shop. The decision taken by the Finnish Presidency in June was also not the best that could have been achieved. There are some weaknesses: the main one, in my opinion, is that insufficient consideration is given to the situation of SMEs, but the car industry is not made up exclusively of large companies. In the supply sector in particular, SMEs play a leading role and we must also protect the interests of those employed in these companies, as well as more than two million people are employed in this sector.

With the exception of Amendment 76, where I made a mistake because I intended to vote in favor, my votes could be explained by the following fictitious narrative: Draft environmental directive adopted: "Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the obligation to maintain a temperature of at least 18 degrees Celsius in winter in the streets, squares and gardens of European towns and cities." Main principles of the directive: a) Every town must equip itself with sufficient energy and technological resources to achieve this objective by 2012; b) The costs will be fully passed on to all town residents as part of the electricity price. A Member from Northern Europe commented: "This directive would be unfair, because the costs for a resident of Stockholm, for example, would be 200 times higher than those for a resident of Naples." A Member from Southern Europe commented: "Nevertheless, this is competitiveness and a level playing field." (The fiction ends here.) The Member, who now explains his voting behavior, considers it positive that there is a Community directive on water, but believes that Europe cannot be built on environmental dogmatism, but rather that we are falling into the caricature of legislation. Countries with periods of flooding and drought, such as the Mediterranean countries, cannot be treated in the same way as countries with a northern rainfall regime. On the other hand, a Europe that makes water transfers between different watersheds virtually impossible in the future would lack solidarity. It should be recalled once again that we are working on a project for the political unification of the entire continent. Drinking, eating, washing ourselves, cultivating fields, and much more: we need water for every activity in our daily lives. This water is wrongly considered an immutable and inexhaustible resource, since something as simple as turning on a tap is seemingly self-evident. But this source is in danger of drying up... All scientific studies now clearly conclude that water will be the key challenge of the coming years, and this will happen tomorrow. But tomorrow will be too late. We must clearly define the rules of the game today, before we all become losers. By adopting the Water Directive today, February 16, the European Parliament will be reaffirming its commitment to protecting surface water, coastal waters, inland waters, and groundwater. Europe now has a framework that will enable it to counteract the deterioration of water quality, promote the sustainable use of water, protect ecosystems, contribute to the fight against floods and droughts, and stop the discharge of dangerous substances. This is a lifebuoy that we are throwing into the water. I am extremely satisfied with this ambitious proposal for a framework directive on water policy. The environmental disaster currently ravaging the banks of the Danube reminds us—if it were still necessary—that human negligence all too often endangers natural resources, such as water. The aim of this 1997 proposal for a directive is to put an end to the fragmentation that has characterized water legislation to date and to better protect surface, coastal, and inland waters, as well as groundwater. The proposal provides a framework for counteracting further deterioration, protecting ecosystems, promoting the sustainable use of water resources, contributing to the fight against floods and droughts, and gradually reducing the discharge of hazardous substances.

It is precisely this diversity of penal policies that must be addressed. Legislating well therefore means trying to develop real criteria for judicial convergence. It is also an opportunity to look in the face at the reality of Europe's prisons, which are often overcrowded: these are places of non-law, unworthy of the idea we have of ourselves. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as you know, all our countries have abolished the death penalty for a long time. I assure you, however, that with almost a thousand suicides in prison every year, they have not truly abolished it. Mr President, judicial cooperation is undoubtedly essential for free-market Europe, but it must take place in the strictest respect for those principles that are the foundation of our civilisation: the fundamental human rights and freedoms, provided for by the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. We can only thank the committees of Parliament, which have profoundly modified in a guaranteeist sense - through the introduction of numerous amendments - a report that, as initially set out, did not convince us at all. I address the Honourable Schultz to reiterate that the amendments are always presented by us not in a personal capacity or for personal reasons but in the context of a general political interest. If it is then a question of making a list of the people under investigation, or searching for the people under investigation, we could also find them among the rapporteurs, including the author of the report on this convention. I therefore believe that the Honourable Schultz could have spared himself certain forays. As I was saying, numerous amendments have been inserted that guarantee the rights of defence - I am thinking here of the obligation to request the judge for wiretapping - or the prohibition of the accumulation of investigative functions with judicial ones with regard to joint investigative teams. In short, Parliament wanted the convention to concern exclusively criminal matters; the limitation on freedom and fundamental rights provided for in the convention can only be limited to criminal matters. We need clear rules. Of course, the Council has acted in an uncoordinated manner, has changed its opinion during the proceedings, is absent. On the other hand, I thank Commissioner Vitorino for his presence in the Chamber during the debate. As I was saying, we need clear rules to have a fair trial in Europe - without an invasion of wiretaps, without the illicit use of video conferences - so that trials with magistrates who, instead of administering justice, play politics no longer happen in Europe, so that the real guilty parties are punished and not the innocent people who are inconvenient to someone. Mr President, the draft convention on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between EU Member States is about to be adopted by the Council. In the opinion of many, it was about time; Indeed, according to the action plan designed to combat organised crime and adopted by the Council in April 1997, work on the draft MLA Convention should have been concluded by the end of 1997. It will still be some time before the Convention enters into force, as ratification by the Member States is required.

I would also like to point out that our intention to set up an observatory is not new. Such an observatory already existed under LEADER I and LEADER II. Its sole purpose is to maintain active links between the individual groups participating in LEADER. The funding of the observatory cannot exceed 2% of the LEADER budget. As regards the possibility of financing projects that include training and education activities, I would point out that this is a point that is now integrated into the new rural development policy and therefore, in our opinion, no longer needs to be addressed under LEADER. I will now turn to the substance of the report. Point 14 calls on the Commission to submit an evaluation report on LEADER II to the European Parliament as soon as possible. In my opinion, there is little point in doing so at this stage, as it is still possible to use LEADER II funds until the end of 2001. We therefore believe it is more appropriate to carry out the evaluation once the programme has ended. We will certainly do so and submit a report on the matter to Parliament. In point 18, Parliament proposes to collect a sort of compendium or guide of positive actions carried out under LEADER I and II. I would like to inform you that it already exists, it has been compiled by the Commission and I can send it to anyone who is interested. In point 21, Parliament stresses that it is now necessary to approve the guidelines for LEADER+ with due speed, so that the programmes can be launched. I fully agree with the request. As soon as the opinion is adopted here in Parliament, the guidelines for LEADER+ will be submitted to the STAR Committee, so that the Member States can confirm the provisional approval given on 14 November. I expect the Commission to then be able to approve the final version of the guidelines in March/April. As soon as it is published in the Official Journal, there will only be a few months left, six to be precise, to present the LEADER+ programmes. I think it is important to underline that expenditure under LEADER+ can be financed from that moment, that is, when the Commission programme is available. For programmes submitted before 30 April this year, there is also the possibility of retroactively setting the start date of eligibility for funding to 1 January. Finally, in point 20, the draft resolution essentially contains seven amendments to the guidelines. After having examined them in detail, I confirm that the proposals put forward in points 2, 4, 5 and 7 are acceptable to the Commission and will be accepted. The proposal in point 6 can also be accepted, at least in part, as it reiterates that the Commission must approve programmes under LEADER+ within a maximum of five months. We believe that the amendment indicated in point 1 should now be considered superfluous as, following consultations with the representatives of the Member States in the STAR Committee, this point has already been reformulated, as desired by Parliament. Therefore, only the amendment reported in point 3 remains. The Commission cannot but agree with the request, given that it corresponds exactly to what it itself had initially proposed.

However, let us also draw some conclusions. The electoral system that best fits this model is the zipper system, as voluntarily applied in Sweden. I would say that where possible, it should be voluntarily; and where there is reluctance, it should be imposed. I hope that the best practices of these countries can also be continued through benchmarking in the fifth action program, Madam Minister and Commissioner, since I believe it is time for our parties to understand this. Mr. President, I would also like to congratulate the Commissioner and the President-in-Office of the Council for their comprehensive interventions and, above all, for their proposals. Since it has been said that men generally do not participate in debates concerning women's rights, I thought I would contribute to today's debate the opinion of a man, a contemporary politician and intellectual, Francis Fukuyama. In an article entitled "If Women Ruled the World," he defends the conviction that greater participation of women in politics would lead to a world much less prone to violence. Athena, the goddess of Wisdom and War, may have been a model for women for the ancients, but women's influence today can be an effective catalyst against war and for peace. There are, therefore, compelling reasons, beyond justice between the sexes, that advocate a fair and balanced distribution of public office, as well as political and economic power, between men and women. The entire life of women is interwoven with the offering and protection of life and the environment, with dialogue, with reconciliation, with the understanding of opposing points of view, with the resolution of differences through peaceful means. These women's values can constitute an alternative to the contemporary culture of violence and form the basis for a new political culture and a more just and prosperous society for all. It is therefore necessary for the Intergovernmental Conference to introduce into the new Treaty the principle of gender balance in the composition of all institutional bodies of the European Union, as well as in all democratic institutions and in the political decision-making bodies of all Member States. Mr. President, why should women enjoy their proportional share in the political decision-making process? And how should we achieve this? As to whether they should and why they should, we can quickly reach an agreement. It is a requirement of simple justice and democracy and, therefore, a criterion of political legitimacy. However, when we have to answer the question of how, our opinions clash. Are information activities, education, and the establishment of practical requirements sufficient, or should we apply preferential treatment, such as quotas on the electoral lists of political parties? Should the state, and therefore the legislative branch, impose such measures on political parties? Or should we even consider a system that reserves 50% of seats for women in elected bodies? This debate, which in some parts of Europe and here too is followed by the French rallying cry of parité, is essentially about the foundation of democracy itself and the political significance we want to give to being a woman.

This is undoubtedly the result of a complex negotiation in which both parties made substantial concessions, which is true for the European Union, particularly in the areas of good governance and trade. But it is above all the result of a strengthening of the ACP group, which has clearly found a new soul after Seattle. I would like to emphasize that a new way of approaching these issues seems to me to be emerging, particularly in the area of trade. We must adopt an approach in this area. Finally, we must go further in policies to support the development of developing countries. On the financial and budgetary levels, in terms of debt, support for sensitive sectors such as food and humanitarian security or education and health, as well as in the areas of the environment, investment or access to information and new technologies, as in the area of trade, while simultaneously ensuring perfect coherence of development policies with other Community policies and also between them and those implemented by the Member States. We cannot simply continue with something that has proven insufficient and wrong in the past. Mr President, after listening to the Council and the Commission today, I absolutely must reread the agenda I have. It normally refers to "the coherence of the various Union policies with development policy." However, we have not heard a single word on this subject; I find that very distressing. We have been waiting years for a report on coherence. It should have been available in writing today, but after hearing Mr Nielson's speech, I can easily imagine that he is facing very powerful opposing forces within the Commission. I am aware that the Commissioner has particularly strong and very considered views on coherence, and I would have liked to hear them today. Since the joint motion for a resolution proposes a number of effective mechanisms to ensure consistency, I will, given the very short speaking time I have been given, limit myself to mentioning one more, namely that the Commission should also carry out an evaluation of the relevant new legislation in this area. I would particularly like to highlight the catastrophic consequences that the EU's common agricultural policy has for developing countries. I believe we are all familiar with examples: dumping of beef in the Sahel and South Africa, of tomato puree in West Africa, of milk powder in Jamaica. These are things that the affected producers in the ACP countries know inside out – they who have to destroy their own products in order to compete with subsidised EU products. The contribution of European taxpayers to support European agriculture amounts to EUR 40 billion annually. This money contributes to hindering the development of the agricultural sector in developing countries where agriculture represents 69% of the total workforce compared to 1.7% in the EU.

This does not mean that we sympathize with Haider. The CSU MEPs have not the slightest sympathy for Haider, the leader of the FPÖ. As politicians, we must rather ask ourselves why 27% of the Austrian population voted for a party like the FPÖ in the October 1999 elections. We must debate the reasons behind this and try to combat the reasons that lead to such results. Only by debating the arguments and policies of the FPÖ can the radicalization of politics in Austria be prevented. In contrast, the European Parliament's resolution does not in any way question the basis of the Austrian election result and does not put forward any potential solutions. For these reasons, the CSU European Group opposes this resolution. "For he knew what this joyful crowd ignored, and which one can read in books, that the plague bacillus never dies or disappears, that it can remain dormant for decades in furniture and linen, that it waits patiently in bedrooms, cellars, trunks, handkerchiefs and papers, and that, perhaps, the day would come when, to the misfortune and the lesson of men, the plague would awaken its rats and send them to die in a happy city." It is with these sentences that Albert Camus, at the end of a long allegorical story describing the difficult fight of the inhabitants of Oran against the plague, reminds us, at the end of the Second World War, that the fight against Nazism, "the brown plague" as it was then called, could not involve a definitive victory. That racial hatred, xenophobic violence, fear, and the rejection of difference, because they are rooted in the most sordid aspects of humanity, can resurface at any time and dominate any human group. It is in this sense that the events we are witnessing in Austria must be considered tragic. For the first time since the Second World War, an openly pro-Nazi, racist, and xenophobic party is on the threshold of power in a European country. Faced with this threat, which carries within it the negation of the very idea at the heart of European integration, nothing should count: neither legal quibbles over what the treaty allows or does not allow, nor legitimate questions about the right to interfere, nor the paltry respect for formal democracy, and especially not the feeling of helplessness that grips us in the face of an event that we reject with all the strength of our convictions, but over which we cannot control. Elected from a French overseas department, Réunion, a land of crossbreeding and mixing, whose population has been forged over the last three centuries by the successive arrival of Europeans, Black people from Africa or Madagascar, indentured laborers from India or Pakistan, or even Chinese, I experience every day the profound truth of Saint-Exupéry's words: "If you differ from me, my brother, far from harming me, you enrich me!"

The objective of this proposed regulation is to establish the first implementation program for the pre-accession strategy for Cyprus and Malta, starting in 2000 and for a period of five years (2000-2004). The proposal therefore aims to facilitate legislative approximation to the Community acquis and the correct implementation of that acquis. This is a new step within the framework of the Helsinki European Council held last December. At that Council, in view of the progress made by Malta, it was decided to open bilateral conferences starting in February 2000, that is, before the end of the month, in order to begin negotiations on the conditions for accession to the European Union and on the necessary adjustments that must be made. With regard to Cyprus, while the Council confirmed "that a political solution will facilitate Cyprus's accession to the European Union," "this does not, however, constitute a precondition for its decision on accession," and I welcome this. Indeed, I have always considered the approach of making the start of negotiations with Cyprus conditional on the search for a solution to the situation affecting the third part of the territory of this Republic, occupied by Turkey, to be totally unfair. In general, it is true that the socioeconomic situation of these two countries is much more favorable than that of other candidate countries. However, they have been able to benefit from technical and financial assistance from the European Union for the transposition of the Community acquis. This technical and financial assistance was provided until the end of 1999, within the framework of the four financial protocols (B7-4011). Both countries are also beneficiaries of financial assistance from the MEDA program (B7-4012). In its first and second readings of the 2000 budget, the European Parliament emphasized that the new heading "pre-accession" (B7-0) proposed by the Commission in the preliminary draft budget should not be limited to the associated countries of Central and Eastern Europe, since it should also include Malta and Cyprus. However, given the Council's refusal to negotiate the necessary revision of the ceiling of Heading 7 (pre-accession) of the Financial Perspective, the European Parliament agreed, on an exceptional basis—I would like to emphasize this fact—to finance the corresponding expenditure from Heading 4 (external measures) of the Financial Perspective for the year 2000. At the same time, the European Parliament created a new chapter on the "pre-accession strategy for the Mediterranean countries" (B7-04). Within this chapter, two new articles were created on the pre-accession strategy for Malta and Cyprus, pending the Commission's presentation, in accordance with the Helsinki European Council, of the legal bases and the revision of the ceiling of Heading 7 of the Financial Perspective. This proposal for a regulation should constitute one of these legal bases! (EN) I welcome Mr. Brok's report, which strengthens with amendments the Commission's proposals aimed at preparing Cyprus and Malta for European Union membership. The package will allocate a total of around EUR 15 million to both countries this year. It is regrettable, however, that the Commission has avoided multinational funding and has instead decided to allocate funds on an annual basis.

The melody that will be played will be one that the citizens of Europe listen to, and they will want to hear the right one. As it was described this afternoon, it will go a long way toward making us forget the unpleasant melodies we heard at the time of the European elections and over the past few months. The Treaty of Amsterdam and the Tampere Council are developing the project for an area of freedom, security, and justice. There is one aspect, however, that is extremely important and in which this Parliament must participate: scrutiny. There is so much legislation—and I take this opportunity to congratulate the Portuguese Presidency on its programme presented to us last week—that we must have absolute certainty that it is being followed closely, that the Members of the European Parliament, the Members of the national parliaments, and the citizens of Europe are aware of all that it entails. Furthermore, we must ensure that it is, in all its details, applicable, appropriate, and useful to each of the different countries. I would like to draw attention to certain aspects of the resolutions before us this afternoon, one or two of which have already been mentioned. I welcome the move towards recognition of judicial systems between different countries and cooperation in criminal matters. The citizens of Europe will not be indifferent to this and they will be pleased by it. However, the Commission and the Council should be aware that many Members of this House have reservations, for example, about the Eurodac system. We recognize the Council's leading role in this matter, but reservations exist, and I am sure that the Council will be keen to listen to what the elected Members present here have to say when the subject is discussed in more detail. Mr. Schulz said that he was not sure how to define the word scoreboard. Every Englishman or Briton, or anyone who follows a cricket match, knows what a scoreboard is. The scoreboard, or scoreboard, tells the spectators the score of the match; It must follow developments, it must be very clear and very visible. I have no doubt that Commissioner Vitorino will ensure that this is the case. I hope that at the end of the six months, the music will still be playing and that citizens will still be listening. Mr President, allow me to welcome the President-in-Office and his colleague from the Ministry of Justice, Mr Costa. I would like to thank them for the welcome they gave my committee last week in Lisbon and for the constructive meetings we had. Amsterdam and Tampere gave us a lot of work to do together, as Mrs Terrón's excellent draft resolution today shows. I would like to make three fairly brief points. The first is that it is time we had a considered dialogue between the Council and the European Parliament. It has been just six months since the Treaty of Amsterdam required our two organisations to work hand in hand: we have sized each other up, we have had a few minor spats, but now it is time to actually work together.

Since the adoption of Directive 86/611, the investment fund sector has continued to evolve, requiring current regulations to be modernized. The new proposals aim to ensure the highest level of investor protection, a conditio sine qua non for market integration following the introduction of the euro. Given that an average European family allocates its savings to investment funds, the proposals contain provisions relating to prudent management—I want to emphasize this—prudent management in terms of investment policy and risk diversification. Both proposals constitute a unified whole. The first expands the range of instruments in which an "undertaking for collective investment in transferable securities" (UCITS) can invest. As has already been pointed out in this session, UCITS are one of the most important players in modern capital markets. Thanks to their presence, the number of non-professional investors able to participate in these markets has been increasing, without prejudice to the principle of risk-sharing and appropriate supervision. Since the possibility of opting for diversified investment options is provided, individual investors can benefit from all the advantages offered by new investment techniques. The second proposal expands the role that these important intermediary bodies can play in the European Union's capital markets with regard to the development of the investment fund sector. Since it is now possible to create branches and provide certain cross-border services, these bodies can finally make use of the freedoms enshrined in the Treaty of Rome that have been denied to them for all these years. The Commission welcomes many of the clarifications proposed by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and will adopt many of its ideas. More specifically, the Commission will adopt—and I am now using the most recent numbering—Amendments 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 13, 19, and 21 with regard to the first proposal and Amendments 23, 28, and 32 with regard to the second proposal, as these are clearly useful clarifications and improvements. Furthermore, I value the ideas expressed in Amendments 1, 10, 11, 14, 18, and 20, although they will need to be reformulated. I also agree with the underlying idea of limiting counterparty risk to a maximum percentage, as set out in Amendments 17, 36, and 45. I can similarly accept the content of the second paragraph of Amendment 47. All the amendments I have just mentioned relate to the first proposal. Regarding the second proposal, we can adopt the ideas expressed in Amendments 24, 25, 29, 30, 41, and parts of Amendment 27, as they contain sensible suggestions, provided their wording is adapted. In other words, the Commission is willing to adopt their content but proposes modifying their wording. Furthermore, I note the request from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs to prepare a codification of the full text once it has been adopted. This request is reflected in Amendments 7 and 22 to the first and second proposals, respectively.

By undertaking such an innovation in our organization, I am confident that we will be able to match—or even surpass—the success and increased employee motivation resulting from similar innovations in various public and private sector administrations over the past decade or so. I believe that the end of the centralized system will certainly not result in any relaxation of effective financial control, but will increase its effectiveness and its relationship to operational tasks. Financial control will be absolutely guaranteed by the way we will introduce the changes and because we will introduce a fully independent and fully professional internal audit service. As I said before, our ambition is to maximize the value of our money without any loss of security. We are also interested in the value for the people who work for us. Changes in financial management and control will greatly increase the possibility of doing all of this. I also thank—at the risk of being repetitive—Ms. Theato for the constant attention she has paid to these matters and for truly acting—if I may put it that way—as a midwife for many of the changes whose possible implementation we are examining. I hope she will come to feel proud of the offspring she has at least partly engendered. First of all, I am not sure that what I heard from the interpreter is correct, as it does not seem possible to me that someone as expert as Ms. Theato could speak of the abolition of independent financial control. Obviously, the Financial Regulation grants a certain degree of independence to the current Auditor. However, given the mix of financial management, control, and audit roles in the current mandate, it is very difficult to consider it an inflexible role, no matter how great the integrity of the person occupying it. So the changes we intend to make—in line, as I say, with the strong and clear recommendations of the Committee of Independent Experts—are not in any way negative. Coherence, consistency, and universally valid standards in a decentralized system of financial control are guaranteed by a number of measures. One is to ensure the highest quality training; another is to ensure that no Directorate-General can assume powers in matters of financial control unless—and until—the audit service is absolutely certain of the soundness of the system; another is the creation of a central financial service, as you will see in the White Paper, to ensure the establishment and supervision of such standards; and there is also, for greater certainty, the precautionary approach of having an effective and independent internal audit service. I will not go into all the details in an answer to a parliamentary question of this kind, but I am sure that, after examining it, Mrs. Theato will be able to see that in the details of the White Paper, there are very solid guarantees. There will also be evidence that we have taken into account the protests expressed in this Assembly, particularly in the Committee on Budgetary Control, which is important in relation to the use of ex ante approvals in the Directorates-General.

Second, we must see what each country's capabilities are so that this overall force of 60,000 troops can be distributed in an orderly and efficient manner among the fifteen countries. Third, we must see what the differences are between the Headline Goal and what each country can contribute. It is possible, ladies and gentlemen, that we do not have enough capabilities in the fifteen countries and that they will all have to make an additional effort to meet the needs we have proposed. How are we going to do this? We want to do this by convening a conference of the fifteen countries to see what differences remain between the objectives set and the means at our disposal to achieve them and to see how what we lack is distributed among the fifteen countries that form the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, we want to set the timetable so that, during the French Presidency, in December 2000, we can conclude this process with a major conference generating forces from all countries so that needs and capabilities are equivalent and so that we can therefore sincerely say that we already have the plan for what we must do from the end of 2000 to 2003, the date at which we have decided that the capabilities will be in operation. Ladies and gentlemen, this is what we are doing, this is what we are committed to. I believe that we have worked well in these last months, these last weeks, and I think that we will be able to work during the remainder of the year 2000 during the Portuguese Presidency - which is truly doing an extraordinary, magnificent job - and continue during the French Presidency, which, without a doubt, will continue to work with the same promptness and capacity that it has shown on other occasions. I wanted to tell you that in the meantime, there will be at least four European Councils: Lisbon, Feria, and two European Councils during the French Presidency. At these Councils, the Heads of State and Government are also willing to continue examining these issues so that we do not miss the boat and are in a position, by 2003, to implement what we have agreed upon, if necessary. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, I believe that in this area we are working with determination, with energy, and with the broad support of all governments and all Heads of State and Government. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to add two more things. The European Union has an obligation to carry out this entire operation while maintaining contact with the third countries to which I referred, countries which, although geographically members of Europe, are not yet part of the European Union. These are countries with which we must work, with which we must integrate because, if a crisis arises, God forbid, all forces and all countries will be more than welcome. Then, we must be able to establish a fluid and transparent relationship with NATO. The operations that we will have to carry out in the future will be of three types: the first resumes operations in which European forces participate within the framework of NATO; the second resumes operations in which European forces participate and are led, but using NATO assets and infrastructure; the third resumes operations in which Europeans will act alone.

Deeply concerned by the continuing human rights violations in Tibet and with a view to supporting the Dalai Lama's proposal to establish a dialogue with the Chinese Government with a view to resolving the Tibetan situation, the Inter-Group Working Group on Tibet therefore calls on the Commission to appoint a Delegate for Tibetan Affairs, who will deal, within the framework of the European Union, with issues relating to that country and who will endeavour to bring the Tibetan and Chinese authorities or their representatives into dialogue. When does the Commission intend to appoint this Delegate for Tibetan Affairs? I call Mr Patten, on behalf of the Commission. The concerns expressed by the European Parliament about Tibet are widely shared. I have long believed in the need to firmly and sincerely present our views on human rights, including in Tibet, to the Chinese authorities. This is what the European Union did last month at the EU-China summit in Beijing, where we lobbied the Chinese on a range of human rights issues, including in Tibet. Once again, we invited the Chinese to enter into a dialogue with the Dalai Lama. Once again, I invite the Chinese to do so. We will continue to raise the issue of Tibet with the Chinese authorities. We are also taking other actions: during the EU-China human rights dialogue, we emphasized a range of practical measures, including sending experts on missions to Tibet, planning development aid programs, and activities related to health, education, and training for Tibetans. The appointment of an EU special envoy for Tibet would primarily rest with the Council, and the European Parliament could raise the issue directly with him. As far as I am concerned, I am not sure that our efforts would gain much from this in practical terms. It is unlikely that it will have a great impact on the Chinese authorities, and we already have effective channels of communication with the Tibetan community in exile. I would also like to avoid an exponential growth in the number of special envoys, however laudable the cause. Mr. President, Mr. Patten, you obviously have excellent experience of China because of your background, and you are certainly aware of the efforts the Tibetans are making to establish dialogues, all of which have been avoided so far. If your response is limited to telling us to contact Mr. CFSP, Mr. Solana, I fear that this is a one-sided orientation in foreign policy. Your approach, which I readily advocate for its consistency, is inspired by the theme of human rights. I completely agree: we must address the issue of human rights. Detention, torture, the mutilation of young women and other similar practices are all topics for completely interminable discussions. If we reduce all this to saying that the Council is competent in these matters, I fear that human rights issues will not come sufficiently to the fore. The possibility of emphasizing, on the one hand, the economy and trade while including the issue of human rights would be a measure for which we would actually rely on the partnership of the European Commission and not say that it is the Council's business.

I therefore support Mr Swoboda's well-founded report – we are used to nothing less from him – and hence also my words of praise for the respectable Republic of Macedonia. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, please allow me first to express my personal appreciation to the rapporteur, Mr Swoboda, for the quality of his work. Today, we are issuing a positive opinion on the opening of negotiations on a Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Macedonia. We do so in the awareness that this decision, the first ever relating to this region, is concretely embedded in an entirely new phase in our relations with the Balkans. It is itself a factor in this new phase, or rather, a policy that sees the future integration of this region into the European Union as the only possibility for a peaceful solution to its conflicts. Our agreement to the negotiations, as proposed in the rapporteur's explanatory memorandum, is based on our conviction that it is right to combine, in Union policy, both a regional dimension and specific recognition of the efforts and achievements of each Member State in aligning itself with the acquis communautaire. I believe that this dual objective must be pursued. Therefore, on the one hand, it is necessary to support programmes relating, for example, to infrastructure, to prepare the creation of a free trade area – for which it is still too early – and to promote forms of economic and commercial cooperation between the Balkan countries. On the other hand, it is inadvisable to create a model for a closer integration policy with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia at this stage. Moreover, for a number of reasons, we cannot help but adopt a positive opinion. As we observed during our missions to Skopje, in the former Republic of Yugoslavia, considerable progress has been made in the economic sphere, on the road to democracy, and in the area of interethnic coexistence – a rather difficult and conflict-ridden area in the Balkans. On the other hand, the war in neighboring Kosovo has taken a heavy toll there, both in terms of the provision of logistics for NATO forces and in declining exports to Northern Europe. In conclusion, I would like to stress that these developments are undoubtedly difficult, fluid, and uncertain, and that they require constant vigilance on our part at the various stages, which must be reflected in regular, targeted checks. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to take this opportunity to express the enthusiastic and optimistic welcome given to the opening of negotiations with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia by the Group of Liberals, Democrats and Reformists for Europe. I sincerely hope that this agreement, in the broad lines outlined by the rapporteur, Mr Swoboda, will serve as an example and be extended as soon as possible to other countries, in particular Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Montenegro, Kosovo, and, as soon as possible, to Serbia. We are convinced that the rapid initiation and swift conclusion of these negotiations is the only way to bring about peace in the region – the peace that has not been automatic since the end of the war in Kosovo – and thus to prevent the conditions for further disintegration from arising again and the resumption of chaos and violence, leading to instability in Europe, if not the world.

The public's acceptance of such prices without panicking about financial transactions can be explained by overly optimistic expectations of future profits. Speculative activities are growing beyond all bounds and, in turn, fueling profits that will one day prove to be fictitious. Excessive optimism will be followed by disillusionment and fear, resulting in a stock market crash and, possibly, an economic crisis. The risk is too great to ignore. We must face it, however difficult it may seem. Modern economics has provided us with a remarkable tool in the proposal by Tobin and others, which we could use if we had the political will to start acting. That is what we lack, Commissioner: the political will to start tackling speculation. But blissful admiration or resignation in the face of market forces, the professions of faith of the liberals - and I regret that Mr. Gasòliba i Böhm is no longer among us - cannot continue to characterize democracy indefinitely, because they are leading us straight to catastrophe! Madam President, Mr. Bolkestein, it is quite incredible to see the extent to which ignorance permeates this discussion. It took a Greek colleague to finally tell us what this Tobin tax meant. You reject it out of hand because you understand nothing about it. It is perfectly clear that the right is opposed to taxes; otherwise, it would never have dared to transfer these millions, even billions, to Switzerland. This has become clear. Now, I call on you - in full knowledge of the facts - to help stop speculative financial capital, to finally support long-term projects with long-term capital. This has never been done in Southeast Asia, it has never been done in Europe, and, considering their financial management, I can understand why our Austrian colleague Karas is no longer here. It's the same mess. We need a Tobin tax to be able to intervene via a fiscal instrument. Madam President, I am revolted by the political ignorance of this Commission, that is, Commissioner Bolkestein. Given his position on the Tobin tax, he should really ask himself why he is here. Madam President, I too had a bit of the impression of a ghostly debate. It is probably no coincidence that no conservatives are present anymore, because the idea of free markets that they defended no longer has anything to do with the august principles of the social market economy that have brought so much prosperity to Western Europe in recent decades. If we continue to assert the sacrosanct nature of markets—such is the ideology—and even to maintain that any intervention in the functioning of these markets is opposed to progress and economic growth, we are most certainly on the wrong track and this could take on very dangerous proportions. At present, capital holders are still amassing colossal fortunes that need to be reinvested.

I condemn the false arguments with which both sides have attempted to mislead Members and the public in the context of this difficult and, in some cases, highly technical issue. I therefore particularly appreciate the interventions of my group colleagues, who helped make some compromises possible. Above all, I would like to express my special gratitude for the tremendous work done by our rapporteur, Mrs. Lienemann, and for her cooperative attitude, even though disagreements still exist on some points. I would also like to express my gratitude to the representatives of the European Commission, who have always been available to advise us and offer technical assistance. If the representatives of the Council of Ministers adopt the same constructive attitude, I have no doubt that, in the conciliation procedure, we will all succeed in reaching an even more appropriate solution for the protection of Europe's aquatic environment. Mr. President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Ms. Lienemann for the excellent work she has presented and for the effort she has made to bridge the gaps that separate us on the issue of water. The Water Framework Directive is a necessary initiative. However, and given that the idea of solidarity is intrinsic to the process of European integration, this directive must take into account that water resources must be understood as a factor of social cohesion. Water—no one doubts this—is a good of general interest. However, in the case of Spain and other southern countries, which have irregular climates, the management of water resources requires political approaches to rationalize their use and other solidarity-based measures. Therefore, we believe that this Framework Directive should advocate for the use of water that overcomes territorial imbalances, and, to this end, I request your support for Amendment 95, presented by our Group. We want to ensure that Article 1 of the Directive promotes the sustainable, efficient, fair, and equitable use of water. I will now briefly review the main issues on which the Spanish Socialist delegation maintains some divergence from certain positions defended here. This is the case with water transfers. We would prefer that the future Framework Directive not leave the possibility of implementing them subject to Community supervision. We believe that, given the hydrographic characteristics of the Spanish State, where structural water transfers are carried out, it should be the country's authorities who decide on the resources of their own territory, a decision that, of course, should always be made based on the criteria of seeking cohesion and the rational use of water. Regarding one of the most controversial points of our debate, that of pricing, the Spanish Socialists have been advocating that, while respecting the "polluter pays" principle, the Directive should advocate affordable pricing policies for all consumption levels. It is clear that in Spain, a full water cost recovery policy would not have the same impact as in Central and Northern European countries. Spaniards would see the price of water rise for its various uses, precisely due to the scarcity of water resources and the internalization of environmental costs that will be necessary within the framework of the Directive.

I spoke about the extraordinary European Council and Portugal's intention to hold it; I spoke about it from a future perspective, because there are two complementary ways of addressing the issue of social exclusion: one is the set of measures to be adopted immediately in order to combat its concrete effects, the second is the creation of conditions of competitiveness at international level that allow us to improve the economic fabric within the Union with positive consequences on the problems of social exclusion. However, the Portuguese Presidency does not have miracle recipes to respond in six months to issues that have always been ongoing. There is a willingness to work in these areas, on the proposal of the Commission, in all areas of Community competence and of course it is possible - and it is in our interest - to encourage as a whole the initiatives that will be presented, in particular, by non-governmental organizations, but also thanks to the traditional intergovernmental coordination in these areas. However, it must be borne in mind, Honourable Member, that it is not possible to operate in an area with such a large financial impact solely and exclusively through measures proposed by a Presidency in office for only six months. For this reason, we believe that only measures envisaged as part of long-term strategies - although we know, it is true, that in the long term some homeless people may have died - will allow us to launch sustainable policies at European Union level. And it is to these strategies that we will try to contribute in the best possible way during our six-month term. Question No 12, by the Honourable Member (H-0801/99): Subject: Portuguese Presidency and development policy Will the President-in-Office of the Council make a statement on the priorities of the Portuguese Presidency with regard to development policy, the Lomé Convention and the way of dealing with famine situations? I would like to thank the Presidency for the comprehensive answer given to my question, and in particular the Minister who spoke in the Committee on Development last week in Brussels to explain the issue. However, there are still some problems to be resolved. There does not seem to have been any emphasis on the fight against AIDS in the programme. The AIDS situation in Africa has become so serious that more people die from this disease than in conflicts. I hope that the Minister will devote some time to this particular issue. There are drugs available in the United States, but the price charged does not make them accessible to the people of Africa. I would like to ask the Minister what exactly he is doing about the situation that is developing in Ethiopia, where there is drought, the harvests have failed and where in six months we will inevitably return to the situation that existed a few years ago, characterised by famine and the deaths of thousands of people. At the same time, there is a war going on between Eritrea and Ethiopia and the European arms industry is sending its weapons, after which we will send bread. Honourable Member, first of all I would like to make it clear to you that I do not agree with your interpretation of my colleague's speech at the meeting of the Committee on Development and Cooperation.

Duration of the regulation: In order to avoid a conciliation procedure, the Commission rejects Amendment 12 and its proposal for an unlimited period of validity for the regulations. In our view, the seven-year period proposed by the Council is an acceptable compromise. Bank guarantees: For the reasons already stated, the Commission rejects Amendment 8 on bank guarantees. We reject specific provisions in certain budget lines because this runs counter to our common objective of simplifying and standardizing our administrative procedures. Furthermore, following a decision taken by the Commission in 1999, we consider that this issue has essentially been settled. With regard to the other amendments, our position is as follows: The Commission welcomes and supports Amendments 7 and 10. We can also accept Amendment 4. We reject Amendments 2, 3, and 6 because we believe that the underlying concepts have already been taken into account elsewhere in the regulation following first reading. In the interest of clear and concise legislation, we should refrain from proposing these amendments. Amendment 1 is not supported because, in our view, it adds little of significance. Given the Council's negative opinion on this amendment, the Commission also advocates its deletion. Finally, we reject Amendment 5 because we consider the phrase "serious doubts" to be too subjective and fear that it could make implementation of the regulation very difficult. Furthermore, the objective of this amendment—namely, the prevention of projects with negative social, cultural, or economic impacts, as well as negative environmental consequences—is already addressed in Article 4(5) on impact assessments. Thank you, Commissioner Nielson! The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12:00 noon. Ship-generated waste and cargo residues. Now, Mr Jarzembowski, here comes the moment of glory! The next item is the recommendation for second reading (A5-0043/2000) by Mr Bouwman, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, on the Council common position for adopting a European Parliament and Council directive on port reception facilities for ship-generated waste and cargo residues. Mr President, Commissioner, we are debating a directive today that is necessary, indeed desperately needed. In recent weeks, we have discussed the Erika accident. This also included proposals for various new, short-term measures, such as double-hulled hulls, controls, supervision by inspection bodies, and so on. The total oil pollution of the sea caused by such disasters amounts to around 3%. Twice that percentage is attributable to normal shipping operations. But that's not all. In the Netherlands, for example, and in other countries too, 49% of the waste on our beaches is washed up directly from the sea. Tourists account for only 15%, while a large proportion are of unknown and cannot be precisely located. Given the enormous economic damage, the deterioration of habitats vital to seabirds, fish, and other living creatures—in short, given that our environment is at stake—this directive is urgently needed. I need say nothing more about the reasons for this directive.

Added to this is the lack of transparency. Everything is being done to conceal the chain of responsibility, the identity of the owners, and the true decision-makers as much as possible. This is no longer acceptable. We must achieve real and significant changes in all these areas, including setting a deadline for the new standards, which include the double hull, failing which, in turn, will result in a ban on docking in ports or sailing in the territorial waters of the Member States. Furthermore, we must ensure more rigorous procedures for issuing seaworthiness certificates and monitoring the condition and maintenance of ships. Finally, we must ensure that, in the event of a disaster, all those responsible are held accountable for compensation. In this case, I am thinking in particular of the Total-Fina group. The European Union can put forward the same ideas to the International Maritime Organization. This would demonstrate its worth in the eyes of a public that, this time, expects clear and concrete action. Mr President, Commissioner, As a Member of Parliament from the Vendée department on the French Atlantic coast, I would first like to express the indignation felt by the population affected by the Erika oil spill at the devastating consequences, caused not by a natural disaster like the hurricane that also hit us, but by a crime. In this hour of need, there was a wonderful outpouring of solidarity: at the local, national, and transnational levels. Now, the population affected, those who have lost everything, particularly those professionals who make their living from the sea and tourism and whose activities are in jeopardy for years to come, expect not only that those responsible for the damage make good, but also that everything possible is done to learn from their current misfortune so that others do not become victims of similar crimes tomorrow. We are now paying the price for our omissions. Because our states, with the blessing of the Community, no longer considered it useful to maintain their own merchant fleets and allowed valuable shipbuilding expertise to be lost, we no longer have clear ship traceability and are forced to watch as our waters are plied by dilapidated vessels flying flags of convenience, serving the short-term interests of multinational corporations. This chain of irresponsibility, from irresponsible charterers to untraceable shipowners to compliant certification bodies, must be brought to an end. We are in a difficult situation today. These matters obviously need to be regulated globally, but the current IMO rules are woefully inadequate and far too lax, and despite previous disasters, neither our countries nor the Community have seriously attempted to make them stricter. Certainly, there is the International Fund for the Protection of the Environment from Petroleum Pollution (FIPOL), but it blurs the lines of responsibility, and the fund's ceiling on compensation is completely inadequate and urgently needs to be changed. The issue of flags of convenience must be reexamined within the IMO. It is up to the Member States and the Community to take the initiative in this regard. Let me remind you that the Erika was sailing under the flag of convenience of a state that is a candidate for EU accession.

If these funds help to eliminate the backlogs of regions, cities, and population groups, or if health and the environment are improved, my group is satisfied. It is a matter of solidarity and progress. But the fact that ever more money is allocated does not guarantee that spending will improve accordingly. The cities and regions that benefit from the funds have meanwhile gained experience on the ground. They find it extremely difficult to spend the money on the objectives for which they need it most. The results are generally good when it comes to economic growth and infrastructure, but social objectives and the environment are not always approved. Because there is great uncertainty about how the rules are laid out, municipalities and regions spend fortunes hiring the services of expert offices to assess the extent to which European Commission officials are willing to approve their plans. In some cases, I have the impression that it is not about solidarity or solving the most pressing problems, but about maintaining interests and propaganda in favor of the benefits of the European Union. It seems that the main objective now is to build and paint a propaganda billboard stating that the project in question is co-financed by the European Union.
