Far too much money is wasted on propaganda and consulting firms, on consultation and control, and far too much money is returning to the country from which it came. After the accession of the new Member States, with their 100 million inhabitants whose standard of living is one-third or two-thirds of the average in the current Member States of the European Union, this waste will arouse even more objections. In the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism, the United Left Group agreed with the rapporteur for the opinion on Leader, Mr Nogueira Román. He rightly noted that it is not a good idea to spread these funds across all rural areas. Between innovation projects and concentrating funds on combating backwardness, we opt for the latter objective because it contributes more to equality. Innovation in regions where things are already going well is already profitable and is taking place, even without European contributions. A second point to be aware of is the abuse of power and cronyism that regional and municipal administrations can be guilty of. The focus is on local groups in which authorities, non-profit organizations, and for-profit companies cooperate. The discussion focused on the distribution key to be used. In particular, a variant reminiscent of the Dutch polder model, organized structural cooperation between authorities, unions, and entrepreneurs, was discussed. Let us not forget that elections to municipal councils and regional parliaments are intended to represent the entire population. In fact, it would be a matter of these bodies carrying out an examination and taking into account the wishes of sectoral organisations and environmental movements.

It is in this spirit, almost provocatively, that we have tabled an amendment suggesting the transfer of competences for South-East Europe from foreign affairs to enlargement. The more rapid and direct involvement of South-East Europe in the life of the European institutions has led us to also suggest that a limited number of observers be accepted, sent by national parliaments to the European Parliament, and that staff from those countries be allowed to work at the Court of Justice and the Commission. However, to encourage the evolution of the region towards a more democratic and market-based society, we are above all convinced that immediate and concrete steps must be taken to intensify the fight against corruption and to make international aid for reconstruction and development more efficient. That is why we have tabled some amendments, which I hope Parliament will accept: first, to offer the former Republic of Macedonia a zero customs tariff for its exports to the European Union and compensation for the progressive reduction of customs duties applied by Macedonia on European products, provided that the principle of joint customs control at Macedonia's borders is accepted; second, that the former Republic of Macedonia be encouraged, with adequate financial support, to progressively link its currency to the euro as a first step towards a Europeanisation of the entire Macedonian economy, and this with the further aim of eliminating any possible corruption in the banking system; third, that the aid and assistance that the world must give to the region, and therefore also to Macedonia, have a marked multilateral character, without conditioning the recipient country to direct obligations towards the donor country. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we hope that the agreement will achieve all the goals it sets itself, but we cannot delude ourselves that peace, stability and prosperity in south-eastern Europe can be achieved without addressing issues of much broader problems, which we are trying to remove: I am referring to the future constitutional state of Kosovo, the need to involve Serbia in the reconciliation process in the region and - why not? - the renegotiation of relations between the European Union, NATO and the UN, in the light of the new balance to be found between humanitarian interference and state sovereignty, which I believe will have to change the UN Charter itself. Mr President, Commissioner, the war in Kosovo has created a climate of great instability. This instability is a particular feature of relations between the European Union and the Western Balkans. Since then, expectations have been particularly high, both in that region and in our countries. In that region because, whether we like it or not, beyond the request for direct aid, the question that arises is: what does Europe intend to do with us? Is there a possibility of accession? These are very heartfelt questions in all the countries in question. Expectations are also high here, in the European Union. If we act correctly, this could be the first proof of the existence of a real common foreign and security policy.

Therefore, following the incorporation of Declaration No 31 into the Treaty of Amsterdam, the European Union institutions undertook extensive negotiations and consultations, which ultimately culminated in the new Council Decision, which, although it amends the old system in substantial ways, does not, in our view, satisfy the requirements. In particular, the Decision introduces a rudimentary right of scrutiny for Parliament, that is, the possibility of 'ringing the alarm' when a measure implementing an act adopted under the codecision procedure infringes the implementing powers conferred on the Commission. During the lengthy interinstitutional negotiations, in which Parliament was actively involved thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Adelaide Aglietta, the aim was for the European Parliament and the Commission to conclude an interinstitutional agreement on the modalities for implementing certain aspects of the new Decision. This was done, firstly, to clarify certain points which the Council was not prepared to include in the decision, and secondly, to regulate the information and control system with regard to implementing measures more precisely. During the trialogue on 6 October 1999 in Strasbourg, the Presidents of the European Parliament and the Commission approved the proposal to conclude this agreement swiftly. We believe that we have fulfilled this obligation, which was relatively easy for us, given that a climate of trust and mutual respect prevailed throughout the negotiations with the Commission. The agreement essentially deals with two points. Firstly, the information of the European Parliament, as a conditio sine qua non for the effective exercise of its right of intervention under Article 8 of the decision. To date, this information has been provided on paper and in an unsystematic manner, and has often been unusable for our services, partly through the fault of Parliament itself. From now on, this information will be ensured by an electronic system called CIRCA, to which the European Parliament has access, and which represents a real innovation not only for us but also—I am sure—for the Commission. Secondly, Article 8 of the Council Decision does not specify the procedure or the deadline within which the European Parliament must "ring the alarm bell," that is, exercise its limited powers of scrutiny. Points 6 and 7 of the agreement stipulate that the European Parliament will generally adopt its reasoned resolution in plenary and will have one month to exercise its right of intervention before the Commission adopts the draft implementing measure. However, we are all aware that it is not always possible to wait a month before adopting an implementing measure. Therefore, the agreement expressly provides for an urgency procedure within which the committee responsible can intervene. Finally, I would like to stress that we must wait and see how the agreement works in practice before we can judge whether it is a good agreement or not. The European Parliament will have to equip itself with tools it does not currently have to ensure efficient implementation procedures and effective oversight, and the Commission will have to accept a reorganization of some of its procedures to ensure effective oversight and genuine information to Parliament.

There is no clear consensus within the People's Party group on the issue of supporting mandatory quotas. Some members even oppose them. Personally, I don't want to feel like a quota; I don't want to think that I'm in a certain position only because I was born a woman. This is a feeling men will never have, and a fundamental difference. I would also like to thank the Minister and the Commissioner for their contributions, and I agree with the latter that it's time for fine words to be translated into action. We all know how small the representation of women is in decision-making at all levels; we know the statistics, and they speak volumes. I agree that accurate statistics are also necessary, because we will only know that we are slowly overcoming the problems by seeing the numbers change. With systematic monitoring, we will be able to identify this. Mainstreaming is a long-term commitment. In the meantime, we need positive action, which means applying quotas and similar measures. We can learn from the successes mentioned, not only by looking at the actual number of elected female representatives, but also at the impact they had on the composition of government, to demonstrate that everyone benefits from a truly representative system. I am pleased that the proportion of women in the National Assembly in Wales, which I represent, is 40%. This is the result of positive action by the political parties; on the other hand, there are only four women from Wales in the House of Commons, which amounts to just 10% of all representatives. Therefore, statements of principle and support in principle are not enough, as they do not work. If we have faith in the principle of equal representation of women and men in decision-making structures, we ourselves must participate in the measures necessary to implement it. Mr. President, at the Second International Socialist Women's Conference in Copenhagen in 1910, it was decided to link the main demand, women's suffrage, to the entire women's question. Furthermore, as stated in the resolution, "Women's Day should be given an international character and be well prepared." It is also noteworthy that Women's Day was subsequently banned in all countries where fascism and racism came to power, as well as between the wars. In 1910, women's suffrage was on the agenda. Today, we are focused on increasing women's participation in decision-making. Women are not a homogeneous group. They belong to different social classes and have different individual needs and interests. However, the general and consistent rule is that, regardless of where we are, regardless of class, race, or religion, whether at home or at work, we are subordinate to men in all areas of society—with few individual exceptions, it should probably be added. In my home country, Sweden, several political parties have voluntarily introduced quotas for election to political bodies and for holding political office in recent years. This has led to an increasing number of women in political decision-making, which in turn has opened up new opportunities for research.

In September, we committed to carrying out reform with the presentation of the White Paper, and today we are fulfilling that commitment, in the terms we have made to you. The Commission wants to be judged by the facts, only by the facts, on the basis of what we are going to achieve. However, I remind you—this is my final reflection—that the Commission is not the only Community institution. Parliament and the Council are also called upon to fully accept the challenge of these reforms. The Commission has resolutely paved the way: I hope that all the institutions will follow it to the end, serving European citizens, for an ever stronger and more transparent Europe. I am pleased to be here with President Prodi and my colleague Michele Schreyer to present the White Paper "Reform of the Commission," approved by the Commission this morning. As you will see in the document, which will be available to you today, the unprecedented consultation of Commission staff, this Parliament, and the Council that has taken place since the adoption of the consultation document in January has been very productive, and useful improvements have resulted. Along with Romano Prodi, I express my gratitude to this House and to the many people who have dedicated their time and effort to providing us with their constructive responses. The White Paper places reform in its proper political framework. Systems and structures have been created in the Commission over 40 years, during which time there have been successful enlargements. The Treaties have been revised, this Parliament and the Council have assigned the Commission new management tasks, and many other major changes have taken place in our Union, on our continent, and in the world. These realities, together with the prospect of further enlargements, strongly advocate modernizing the Commission so that this essential institution can carry out its primary tasks of policymaking and formulation, implementation of the Treaties, and management of public resources, and do so with maximum effectiveness, responsibility, and democratic accountability. Naturally, the continued independence and strength of the Commission are fundamental to that mission, as this Assembly has repeatedly recognized. Reform and renewal are also essential to that end. The Commission is not and will not be a secretariat of any kind, and that is clear to all institutions—that is something that is perfectly understood everywhere. But the Commission exists to serve the Union and its people with high standards of performance. That is what citizens have a right to expect and what the people who work for the Commission want to deliver and will deliver. As the Assembly must, of course, know, the Commission cannot achieve these objectives alone. All institutions of the European Union will have to address the issues raised by reform and do so honestly and responsibly. I know that my colleagues and I can count on the support of many members of this Assembly from all political parties.

A small step, he said, nonetheless welcome, to which the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs has rightly sought to impose further limits and precautions in the name of defending the fundamental rights of individuals, recognized in the Member States and in the Union itself, even though they are not yet enshrined in a Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which we trust will soon be published. These limits and precautions are appropriate because, unfortunately, not all public authorities always specifically respect all the rights in force in all Member States. Perhaps there has been an excess of caution at some specific points in the Commission's proposals, such as when it sought to grant detained defendants the option of consenting to or refusing temporary transfer to another Member State of the Union for the purposes of investigation. Personally, I do not consider it acceptable, for example, to allow Mr. Pinochet to choose whether or not to travel to Spain for a confrontation. Or when it has been intended that the witness or expert—and not just the person under investigation and the accused—may also be assisted by counsel during remote questioning. However, these are minor errors that the rapporteur has unwittingly made, and which the vote of this House will remedy. The rapporteur has made a commendable effort, which must be acknowledged and for which I am grateful. The overall result is appreciable, and I hope the Council will take it seriously. As has been said, one point remains unresolved, the most delicate: it concerns Article 18 of the Convention concerning wiretapping of communications carried out in a Member State and carried out directly by another Member State, without requesting the assistance of the State where the wiretapping takes place, something that is possible today thanks to modern technologies. The issue is highly controversial, as it is a potential source of abuse. It could be argued that the complex regulation proposed is better than nothing, but the Commission found it insufficient and disturbing. Consequently, when the contradictory news about ECHELON evokes the specter of Big Brother, it merits further, and probably more comprehensive, reflection on the means and systems through which, on the one hand, individuals' rights are protected and, on the other, effective, yet correct and legitimate, crime suppression is enabled. The objective, therefore, is to achieve, as far as possible, a delicate balance between effective combating crime and respect for human freedom and dignity. This objective, today, is not only the responsibility of individual States but has become a hallmark of the Union's policy, which aspires to become a common area of freedom, justice, and security. It is a distant goal, but it can be achieved in progressive stages.

And, above all, and with this I conclude, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we must be able to express this in plain language, clearly, changing to a certain extent the jargon we use, because we cannot ask Europeans, who are living through times of profound change, to join us and be enthusiastic about us if we continue to maintain a completely closed language and turn our backs on them. This is the fundamental means of increasing and reinforcing the trust that, in any case, I hope can be measured in the upcoming European elections. Mr. President of the Commission, allow me to say, on behalf of my group, that we firmly support the starting point, the core of the analysis and the strategy you are presenting to the House today; namely, that the stakes are now undeniably political. And it is political, because we are making progress. Although we have not yet finished constructing all the basic pieces, we are moving from that kind of functional construction of Europe toward a political perspective that poses a greater challenge. The challenge of enlargement is political. The challenge of creating an area of justice and home affairs, of addressing asylum, immigration, and crime, is highly political. The challenge of a common defense and external security policy is highly political. And because it is political, it is more complex. Because it is political, it is more susceptible to sovereignty. Because it is more susceptible to sovereignty, it is more susceptible to voters and citizens. We must therefore find a way to move forward until we achieve these political goals and objectives, to overcome not only skepticism, but also the greatest enemy of all, which is the apathy you mentioned. The means to achieve this are not easy, but they are real. I applaud your view that we need more synergy between our institutions, not only between the Commission and Parliament, but also between them and the Council to highlight the scale of the political challenge. We need more dialogue, not only among ourselves, but also with civil society. More explanation is needed to understand what Europe is all about. We must overcome fears and anxieties, because in many cases, the greatest fear is fear itself. Perhaps with more dialogue and explanations, we can overcome some of these fears. My group is particularly attracted to the creative possibilities you have suggested regarding the prospect of presenting a White Paper next spring, addressing the issue of governance. When we look at the Europe of networks you describe, it is very important that Europe focus on its main themes, that we have the courage to focus on the areas where Europe could fall behind. In this way, we could convince the population that Europe, in its governance, is not something directed exclusively from Brussels, in an attempt to concentrate and absorb more powers, more decisions, and more authority. This is the political core of the challenge, and I believe you have explained it perfectly before this House today. For my group, enlargement is the first priority against which all other possible reforms must be measured, whether governance, the Intergovernmental Conference, or the reform of the institutions.

The Lisbon Summit therefore begins with this legacy and must further develop it in those aspects where it is not yet consolidated – and there are quite a few of them, because we do not yet have a single internal market in the areas we want to advance in Lisbon. Due to delays, there is no single internal market, for example, in public and private services, or in transparency and the use of modern technologies to truly complete the markets in terms of information and thus efficiency. This is where the necessary productivity increase must begin to achieve long-term economic development without inflation. However, we must be careful. We may be fragmenting this debate on Lisbon, but we must always keep in mind a very precise objective: we must create the economic and social conditions for sustainable growth. We have already mentioned the economic conditions, namely efficiency and productivity; the social conditions are about avoiding fragmentation and income disparities in our society – one of the greatest dangers. I repeat, because we should be mindful of this: income inequality has been widening in Europe recently. This problem will be insoluble, if not today, then tomorrow. This gives rise to both market and public responsibility. In Lisbon, we must make some very concrete decisions. In this regard, since reference has been made to the United States on several occasions, I would like to emphasize one particular aspect. In the United States, this new market, this innovation, and its dissemination—the tremendous leap forward is that this is an innovation, namely in telematics, which is bringing knowledge to the peripheries—are by no means solely due to private initiative. Significant public investment has been made at the federal, state, and local levels. Enormous sums have been invested in modern infrastructure. Please note: in this regard, our immediate—I repeat, immediate—obligation at the public and other levels is to establish telematic links, that is, the channels for these new information carriers. The market, private individuals, and companies will provide the infrastructure, while we are obliged to create the new information highways. Therefore, the commitment mentioned by Prime Minister Guterres to equip all schools with computers and to connect even the peripheral areas cannot be left exclusively to the market, because the market simply won't do it, and because, on the other hand, without these measures, we will not achieve the new, necessary productivity targets. We must therefore avoid a crisis in the peripheral economies, which in no way means centralization or centralized planning, but rather opening up the same opportunities to the peripheral economy as to the centralized economy. For this reason, the program must be directed at schools; this is why we must target an entire age group and insist on it, work to ensure that not a single person in this age group is left without this new form of literacy. Therefore, there is a precise strategy for Lisbon. In my opinion, Lisbon is primarily about sowing new courage for employment and growth, in the knowledge that we are capable of doing so; So we have to move towards this model based on safe equilibria.

I would like to focus in particular on one chapter that seems somewhat lacking to me: social policy. This would not be so bad if significant progress had been made over the past five years, but this has not been the case. However, in the area of social policy, the Commission and Parliament have the opportunity to achieve a great deal. I am thinking in particular of Chapter 1 of Title XI of the Treaty, and specifically the issue of working conditions and the improvement of the working environment. Regarding the health and safety of workers, a directive dating from 1989 is currently in force. In my view, and in the view of my group, this directive should be reviewed, particularly on the basis of a comprehensive study published by the Dublin Foundation in 1997. This study identified a general deterioration in working conditions in a number of important areas. This is something that deserves consideration, and I would like the Commission to give this matter serious consideration and determine how this directive needs to be amended to improve the situation. I do not want to go into the details of the content now, but rather deal with the processes involved in the legislative programme, that is to say, the presentation of the programme and its implementation. In this regard, I would like to set out two emphatic demands of the Green Group, which I would like to see Parliament adopt. However, today they will be expressed here simply as emphatic demands. Firstly, when a resolution is adopted by the House, particularly on the initiative of the European Parliament, then in my opinion the democratic rules of the game require that such a demand be seriously followed up by the Commission within a reasonable time. In the field of the environment, for example, we have a White Paper on civil liability for environmental damage. This is significant progress, but I would like to point out that this White Paper dates back to a Parliament resolution of 1994, that is, six years ago. And after the White Paper, it will certainly be a long time before a directive is published. This clearly shows that the process is very slow, and I believe a report is needed to explain why it is taking so long. Secondly, if a legislative proposal is announced in the legislative program but is not implemented in the current year, the reasons for this must be explained. Here's an example. Today, a proposal for a directive on electrical and electronic waste is being announced. This proposal has been discussed several times, but it has never been adopted. We know that this happened under pressure from the US administration, which is threatening to take the matter to the WTO, but it would be sensible, fair, democratic, and transparent if the Commission were to explain to us what is happening behind the scenes and why the proposal for this directive is taking so long. Allow me, President Prodi, to express my fears and anxieties about the approach of your program for 2000, which you have called a turning point—and not just because it contains no truly innovative proposals. What concerns us, rather, is the programmatic, semi-ideological approach of this work plan, your servile and uncritical adoption of the US model – that antisocial and drug-fuelled development model that keeps people above suspicion, such as Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, awake at night.

The third objective is urban and rural development within the framework of a balanced spatial planning policy. The guidelines are, moreover, based on two horizontal principles: the development of rural areas – and the issue of sustainable transport infrastructure, Madam Rapporteur, which has long been close to my heart, particularly since my time as my country's Environment Minister, falls within the scope of rural development for me – and the second principle is equal opportunities, particularly between women and men, as well as the European employment strategy and Economic and Monetary Union. Madam Rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, in response to the concerns you expressed during the debate, I would like to say that the guidelines stress the importance of establishing integrated development and conversion strategies so that the priorities mentioned can achieve the greatest possible synergy between the measures and enable effective decentralized partnerships. You are concerned because this partnership appears to have been ignored. However, it is clearly mentioned on page 5 of these guidelines, and I would like to point out, because you asked me to, that for me, and I have been in charge of a region long enough to be able to judge this, this partnership is a very effective instrument for mobilizing intellectual resources at local level – both those in the public sector – city and municipal councils, schools and the social sector, clubs and associations – and those in the private sector. And territorial pacts are, to respond to a comment by Mrs Angelilli, one of the forms of this decentralized partnership. The guidelines are organized according to thematic priorities so that they can be taken into account within the framework of each objective to varying degrees, depending on the specific situation of each Member State or its regions. Now, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to respond briefly to some of your comments; firstly, on the procedure. It is true that the matter was brought to your attention late. I would, however, like to recall that after the Commission adopted the guidelines in draft form in February 1999, following a new procedure that simplified the submission of opinions on the text, my predecessor, Mrs Monika Wulf-Mathies, immediately forwarded them to Parliament. However, due to the European elections then approaching, your House was unable to begin examining the guidelines until after the text had been finally adopted in July 1999. Today, I can assure you, ladies and gentlemen, that we are only at the beginning of the negotiations on the programmes – the chairman of the committee, Mr Hatzidakis, has already asked me about this – and that your comments can therefore actually be taken into account by most Member States. I can also tell you that the Commission will take your House's opinion, as expressed in this report, into account when adopting the guidelines for the mandatory mid-term review. Now, to the substantive aspects of the guidelines. Madam Rapporteur, you have emphasized that this is about setting targets for a series of often very precisely defined European objectives. I cannot mention them all here: the introduction of cross-sectoral measures, more efficient use of public funds, support for the various partners in the joint development of regional or national programs, etc. The Commission takes note of this, but some of these targets or questions do not belong here, but rather in the Vademecum or the methodological document, for example.

We therefore propose to amend the legislation as follows. First, what is built thanks to LIFE funds should be reserved exclusively for public bodies, even at the cost of entrusting, through a tender, the management of the sites in question to associations recognized for the protection of nature. At stake is the continuity of the projects started, since private law associations can disappear or resell. It is aberrant from a philosophical point of view, as well as questionable from a legal point of view, that 100 percent of public money should be used to build a private land heritage, even with the claim of protecting the environment. Second, the selection and allocation criteria of LIFE funds should be defined, in order to avoid any suspicion of clientelism or ostracism. Third, prior consultation of the users and interested bodies should be required. For example, in France, the LIFE-Nature project for Grand-Lieu, developed without any consultation, has turned out to be a real ecological catastrophe: the operations intended to clear the downstream watercourse, Acheneau, of mud, and carried out in violation of French water law, have caused it to silt up, destroying spawning grounds, invading wetlands and causing other consequences that I will spare you. In reality, all that was achieved was a 3-kilometer shift of the mud at a cost of 6 million francs: a remedy that turned out to be worse than the disease, a predictable consequence and announced by all the operators on the site. The result? A lawsuit and a restoration cost higher than the sum allocated by the program. This is what we want to avoid. Fourthly, representatives of Parliament should be included in the committee responsible for the follow-up, and at least one MEP from each political group. MEPs must monitor the use of the funds for which they voted: this seems more than legitimate to me. Fifthly, a scientific, technical and financial report on the LIFE operations carried out should be published annually. Sixthly, there should be a serious and regular evaluation of the programmes. Seventhly, the use of these funds should be allowed in cases of environmental emergencies, for example, reforestation after a storm, restoration of natural spaces after an oil spill, etc. Here, Mr President, rapporteur, is the concrete, sensible, simple-to-implement proposal, designed to limit conflicts at local level and to justify the correct use of public funds, which we are putting forward before any increase ? of at least 40 percent! ? of the funds allocated to LIFE. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would firstly like to congratulate Mrs Lienemann on the report she has drawn up, but also the Commission because this report, this position, improves the texts currently in force. Furthermore, it has a more acceptable, clearer and more transparent structure. I would also like to congratulate the Commission services, because the evaluation, monitoring and follow-up of the LIFE programme reasonably guarantee the selection and implementation of projects. However, I would like to focus on a few aspects. Firstly, on its continuity, in which, in principle, I believe.

From the Community institutions, we are obliged to work to overcome these border scars, which contradict the spirit of European unity. The economic and social cohesion we advocate is embodied, through the Interreg initiative, in territorial cohesion and the integration of border areas and the peripheries of our continent. From its inception, Interreg has been at the heart of a genuine Community policy for territorial planning and a truly polycentric conception of European territory. The European Parliament, in agreement with this initiative, only regrets that we have to adopt a resolution on it when we still have not seen the evaluation of Interreg II. However, we are aware that it is not advisable to delay the implementation of this third edition any further, since it would jeopardize the success of several projects and the continuity of projects already underway. The success of Interreg is evident, as expressed by the local, regional, and national authorities that have participated in co-financed projects. Learning together, innovating, sharing projects and good practices, mutual understanding and tolerance—these are some of the lessons this initiative offers those involved. There are a whole series of interesting issues surrounding it: the observatory, the principle of concentration... I would like to focus on the management bodies. We need to seek common, interregional, and transnational management bodies, in which all local and regional authorities, as well as economic and social stakeholders, actively participate. Cases of parallel projects on both sides of the border should not be repeated. We need to create a cross-border culture, and to do so, we need to innovate in administrative cooperation, imaginatively overcoming existing barriers and overcoming the difficulties posed by the different levels of competence of each Member State, each region, and each municipality. It cannot be that a project cannot be implemented due to difficulties in dialogue. During the committee debates, we have also noted the difficulty of coordinating Interreg with other annual or biannual financial instruments, such as MEDA, TACIS, or PHARE. This Parliament's motion for a resolution has been very attentive to these difficulties, presenting the Commission with proposals capable of resolving them and setting reasonable deadlines for it to make the necessary modifications. Mr. President, I wish to speak in this debate because the URBAN initiative has been very successful, particularly in Ireland, and I am pleased that the European Union continues to contribute in this area. It is very sad that hundreds of communities, if not thousands, suffer from such profound poverty and disadvantage. Even in the wealthiest Member States and cities, large numbers of people live in ghettos, in situations where there are inadequate facilities, where education is quite poor, where physical infrastructure is underdeveloped, and where drugs and other problems are widespread. It seems to me that, for the European Union to demonstrate that it truly helps the citizens of the European Union, it must work with the Member States to make it clear that the EU works for its citizens and their families.

It is very useful. It is an excellent contribution from Mr. Swoboda and his colleagues. We are very grateful to him for having been at the forefront of this matter, as are some of his colleagues, some of whom are present in the House this evening - Mrs. Pack, Mr. Lagendijk, and others. I am very pleased that our general relations with FYROM are so good. Perhaps Mr. Dupuis, as well as his interpreter, will forgive me for using this expression in the spirit of entente cordiale. The excellent representative of the European Union in that country has contributed to this. He has been a great friend of the European Parliament and an excellent servant of the Commission. The best example of the quality of our relations is the imminent start of negotiations on the Stabilization and Association Agreement. As is also FYROM's cooperation with regard to the reconstruction of Kosovo. I thank the Macedonian authorities for their assistance in recent weeks in addressing the considerable difficulties in supplying electricity to Kosovo. Like some Members, I recognize the stabilizing role that country played during the tragedy in the Balkans, particularly with regard to the integration of the Albanian minority into the political and social life of the country. A few weeks ago, I met with the newly elected President Georgievski and, like others, was extremely impressed by his commitment to multi-ethnicity and pluralism. Allow me to present to you the state of play of these negotiations, which other countries in the region—as Mr. Lagendijk said—are observing with immense interest. On 24 January this year, the Council adopted its negotiating directives for a Stabilization and Association Agreement with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. This represents the most important step forward in the Stabilization and Association Process for the Western Balkans initiated by the Commission in May 1999. Allow me to clarify the main elements of these draft directives. They include the inclusion in the agreement of arrangements establishing a political dialogue with FYROM. They include provisions for improving regional cooperation, including the prospect of establishing free trade areas between the countries of the region, although I would like to make it clear that this is not an attempt to recreate the state of Yugoslavia. They include the prospect of establishing a free trade area between the European Union and these countries within 10 years of the agreement's entry into force. They include provisions on the movement of workers, freedom of establishment, the provision of services, current payments, and capital movements. They include a commitment by FYROM to approximate its legislation to that of the European Community, particularly in key areas of the internal market; and they include provisions for cooperation with FYROM in a wide range of areas, including justice and home affairs. We are now making the necessary preparations within the Commission so that negotiations can begin in March. I am due to visit FYROM during the second week of March.

After two European Parliament elections and a major new reform of the Union Treaties, our relations with the Czech Republic have developed extremely dynamically. An association agreement is in force and a joint parliamentary committee has been set up with delegates from the European and Czech Parliaments. In 1996, your country submitted its official application to join the Union. Finally, in 1998, accession negotiations were officially opened. The process of European integration and enlargement has accelerated dramatically since the fall of the Iron Curtain. The end of the artificial separation of Europe marks the beginning of a new era. We are facing a historic challenge that offers various prospects for all Europeans. Mr President, you, who were also the founder and signatory of Charter 77 - the human rights movement that represented and asserted fundamental values in a dark period in the history of your people - are a powerful symbol of these developments. For defending the freedom and dignity of the person, you were sentenced to almost five years in prison by a communist regime. But you never lost hope and history has proved you right. Ten years have passed since the "velvet revolution" claimed Havel na HRAD. For ten years, as President, you represented first democratic Czechoslovakia and then the Czech Republic. Reconciliation with your neighbours has always been an essential objective for you, which you have defended with firmness and perseverance. We consider you to be a first-class European. Today, the Czech Republic is preparing to become a member of our Union. Experience has taught us, and you, Mr President, will agree, that the process of enlargement of the Union is not always free of pitfalls, for both sides. The Czech Republic will therefore have to make considerable efforts to meet all the conditions for membership. The European Union, for its part, will have to adapt its institutions and its policy in view of enlargement. It has already taken a major step forward under Agenda 2000. The next stage, which is institutional reform, will begin this year at the new Intergovernmental Conference, of which the European Parliament is an active part. Our responsibility as Members is to ensure maximum openness and transparency so that, at the appropriate time, the citizens of the European Union and those of the Czech Republic approve, through their representatives, the accession of the Czech Republic to the European Union. Mr President, it is with great pleasure that I give you the floor. (Applause) Mr President, on behalf of the European Parliament, I would like to thank you warmly for the strong message you have addressed to us and, moreover, the applause of my colleagues shows how much we appreciated your words. I would like to thank you for reminding us that different nationalities are perfectly compatible with European membership. Starting from your personal experience, you have shown us that European membership cannot be imposed, as it is a spontaneous and natural path. Your words have struck me: they express what we all feel deeply.

I declare the session of the European Parliament suspended. (The sitting was adjourned at 12:25 p.m.) Resumption of the session I declare the session of the European Parliament, which was suspended on Thursday, 3 February 2000, resumed. Adoption of the Minutes of the previous sitting The Minutes of the sitting of Thursday, 3 February, have been distributed. Are there any comments? I note from your reaction that many Members have not received these Minutes, and it is quite obvious that you cannot adopt Minutes that you have not received. I therefore propose that they be submitted for your approval tomorrow morning, since you clearly do not have them, and for that I apologize. The adoption of the Minutes is therefore postponed. Madam President, this is a procedural motion. This morning, the BBC reported that a British Member of this House, who holds a senior position within its delegation, continues to provide strategic advice to private clients without declaring who they are in the Register of Financial Interests. The citizens of Europe have a right to expect their representatives not to mix public interests with private benefits. However, they can only be certain that this is not the case if the information is both publicly available and easily accessible. Madam President, since these matters are currently before the Quaestors, may I ask you to use your influence both to ensure that the Register of Financial Interests is updated and amended to cover cases of this kind and, importantly, to ensure that this Register is not only open to scrutiny by this House but also published on the internet? Thank you, Mr Davies. I will take this up with the College of Quaestors. Madam President, this is a point of order. As today marks the first Valentine's Day of the new millennium, I hope you will agree that it would be appropriate for this Parliament to mark the day by making a firm commitment to tackle cardiovascular disease, which is the leading cause of death in Europe. I urge Member States to align themselves with the commitment made today during the Winning Hearts Conference, namely that every child born in the new millennium has the right to live at least to the age of 65 without suffering from preventable cardiovascular disease. Happy Valentine's Day! Madam President, I rise pursuant to Rule 9 of the Rules of Procedure of this House and refer to the point raised by Mr. Davies regarding the very serious allegations broadcast on BBC radio this morning. I would appreciate your assurance that you will order an inquiry to ensure that the two Members named in this particular BBC interview are not running their companies from this Parliament or parliamentary offices, as that would be very serious indeed. The double standards pursued in the past by the British Conservatives have brought the UK House of Commons into disrepute, and such behaviour would very likely have a similar impact on this Parliament.

And he does the same. We discussed it, we expressed unanimity, with the exception of the EPP Group and the European Liberal Democrats and Reformists Party, and I myself noted—as my dear fellow Presidents will recall—that it is not a question of whether you are for or against the Todin tax, but of whether you dare to understand what the Commission and the Council think about it. That is not asking too much. Therefore, I reiterate the proposal to maintain this oral question to the Commission and the Council in order to know once and for all what the position of those two bodies is regarding this relatively modest proposal, but one that would send an important signal to public opinion, especially after the shock caused by the failure of the Seattle Conference. The proposal of the EPP-ED Group to remove the oral question on the capital tax from the agenda was voted on. (Parliament rejected the proposal by 164 votes in favor, 166 votes against, and 7 abstentions) Madam President, I would like to thank Mr. Poettering for the publicity he has just given to this debate. Thank you. Madam President, has my vote, which could not be cast electronically because I do not have my card, been counted? My vote was "in favor." Madam President, the Presidency has announced the result of the vote. No changes can be made. Madam President, in the previous vote—and I will abide by your decision on this matter—on the question of the Commission's strategic plan, I indicated that I would have liked to speak before the vote on behalf of my group. This did not happen. I would be grateful if, at the close of this item, I could give an explanation of the vote on behalf of my group. This is an important matter. It would be useful if the record of the House would record how people perceive what we have done in the light of their own political analyses. Madam President, I do not wish to resume the debate, but I had also requested the floor to give my opinion on Mr. Barón Crespo's amendment. You did not mention me either. I am sorry, but the vote has been taken, the decision has been taken, and therefore, let us leave it at that. I am very sorry, Mr. Hänsch, Mr. Cox, I did not realize that you were requesting the floor. In these circumstances, I believe the positions are clear and will be reflected in the Minutes. When the approval of the Minutes of today's sitting is discussed tomorrow, if you feel that the positions have not been explained well enough, you may request amendments. I think it is a good formula. Of course, the Minutes of tomorrow's sitting will record all the additional explanations. I believe this formula is better than proceeding now with explanations of vote, which would take a long time. Mr. Hänsch, Mr. Cox, is that okay with you? Madam President, if the voting record correctly records how my Group voted, I neither wish nor can raise any objections.

Values must come before power. We therefore deplore what is happening in Austria. Even more, we are shaken by it. We are deeply disappointed. We call on the ÖVP to further examine alternative solutions. We continue to insist on Article 6 of the Treaty. We continue to combat the trivialization of the extreme right. If the coalition were to be formed after all, we call on our ÖVP colleagues to guarantee in their programs, as well as in their words and actions, respect for the principles and values that form the foundations of European integration. Madam President, dear colleagues, Austria faces a heavy responsibility. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that in this Parliament we are largely in agreement in our rejection of Haider and his policies, but it is equally clear that opinions diverge on the question of how best to combat this policy. Have you even considered the repercussions in Austria of this debate and the statement made last weekend by the Council Presidency? Have you asked yourself whether we share the responsibility for the future development of the political situation in Austria if we decide to pass judgment on this matter? Have you even asked yourself what would happen if the wish of one of our colleagues were granted and elections were held in Austria in the coming days? Observers unanimously agree that Haider would emerge even stronger. Who could want such a thing? Do we not have a responsibility to carefully consider how to combat such a policy? Europe is a community governed by the rule of law. Among the principles we must uphold are democracy, respect for human rights, and the rule of law. The democratic requirement implies that one can deplore election results but must respect them, and that is why we must respect the decision taken by the Austrians for reasons inherent in their policy. The rule of law requires that the Council Presidency not express itself as it did, in a way that contradicts the Treaties. Political intelligence dictates not isolating the ÖVP but supporting it, as an undeniably democratic party, respectful of the rule of law and having proven its European commitment, so that Austria remains just as undeniably a member of this European Community. That is why we must support our colleagues from the ÖVP in this difficult situation, and isolation is the completely wrong path. (Applause) Madam President, where I come from, they say that a Welshman always takes three tries. This is indeed the third time – as you will notice in the course of this debate – that I have indicated my desire to respond very briefly to what has been an excellent, and at times disturbing, debate. First of all, I would like to thank, on behalf of President Prodi and my colleagues in the Commission, several Members of this House for their support and understanding of the position taken by the Commission in the statement we made yesterday.

I also support a move towards a linear career system, as the current system of career categories no longer meets the needs of our institutions. It certainly blocks the advancement and mobility of people with proven high potential. Those Members who have duly praised Commission staff during this debate, the vast majority of whom are normally distinguished by their hard work, high integrity, and efficiency, are absolutely right in their comments. The White Paper on the reform strategy will contain a detailed presentation of our approaches to this and other issues; precision in detail is, of course, paramount. There will therefore be several communications on this topic in the coming months, and each one will be open to debate and discussion in this Chamber. It is now absolutely clear that we must work closely with Parliament as an institution on key issues of common interest, in particular on salaries and pensions and the Staff Regulations. In connection with this last point, we are considering the usefulness of adopting a framework regulation containing general provisions on key issues such as remuneration, employment conditions, staff representation rights, etc., but empowering individual institutions to introduce implementing rules on other matters. Initial thoughts from the plenary on this consultative approach would be particularly welcome. Finally, I would like to address paragraph 15 of the draft resolution before you, which addresses the resource requirements of our reform strategies. This is a very important point. We are certain that we will enjoy a significant "reform dividend" once the modernization measures have translated into increased efficiency and better management of resources. However, it is absolutely clear that parts of the Commission's services are already operating at full capacity. This has been raised several times by Parliament. Second, it is equally clear that the reform will require some new investment in training and technology. Third, there is absolutely no doubt that preparations for enlargement must be intensified. They are already impacting the availability of funds. It is also clear that, as we take on new tasks—which will certainly be presented to us by the Council and Parliament—we will have to identify and eliminate so-called "negative priorities" in order to create additional capacity. A central feature of our reform will therefore be more decisive action to link priority setting with decisions on resources, based on activity-based budgeting. However, I would like to emphasize that, while the internal discipline in setting priorities is being introduced by the Commission, it can only be effective if Parliament and the Council also take it into account and demonstrate a similarly determined attitude towards the Commission's demands. For this reason, the Commission welcomes paragraph 15 of the van Hulten report. Mr President, I would like to conclude by thanking the House for its attention during what was inevitably a lengthy speech. At the same time, I would like to express my sincere gratitude to the rapporteur, the Committee on Budgetary Control, and the other committees that submitted their opinions. We look forward to working closely with the plenary in finalising the reform strategy package and, more importantly, to continued good cooperation over the years required to tackle such difficult tasks.

It is simply acknowledging their inferiority. But as far as I know, we have never felt inferior to men, and even more so in politics. So I believe that we are all fighting this battle to help our compatriots gain access to decision-making power, to access positions of responsibility in the political sphere, but I believe that this will only happen with a real revolution in mentalities. We must all be strong enough together to force our political leaders to impose of their own accord the participation of women in political decision-making powers. (SV) Mr President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, "half the sky is held up by women," an enlightened man once said. But when it comes to important decisions and priority issues, women's voices are lacking. Women, who constitute more than half the population, are largely underrepresented in the fields of politics, economics and social action. This is unacceptable in a democracy. When it comes to gender equality, nowhere is the gap between law and practice more stark than in decision-making bodies. To achieve balance, a concrete action plan with a fixed timeframe is needed. An important part of this plan would be a benchmarking system that can ensure the full participation of women in power structures and decision-making processes. I am therefore pleased that the Commissioner supports such a system. I propose that European targets for women's participation in decision-making processes be based on the average achieved in the three most advanced Member States, with an annual report provided by all Member States. These reports would then be evaluated. Women are the primary victims of human rights violations—including rape and sexual abuse, domestic abuse, and the trafficking of women—yet they are underrepresented in the judicial and legislative institutions responsible for prosecuting these crimes. As a result, they are not considered a priority, and the perpetrators are often not prosecuted. Women are also the most numerous victims of armed conflicts, yet they remain absent from efforts to preserve peace, resolve conflicts, and rebuild. This is why we urge Member States, in the text of the resolution, to increase the number of women involved in all these peace-building activities. Equal participation of women and men in decision-making processes is not only a matter of social justice and democracy; it is also a necessity in order to fully utilize women's experiences and knowledge. Not utilizing women's capabilities in decision-making is an unacceptable waste. Women must not only "hold up half the sky," but also have the right to take their share of responsibility in decisions that affect the entire planet. Mr. President, I would like to congratulate the Council Presidency and the Commissioner for their excellent interventions. We have high expectations of your action. We are entering a millennium and a century that we hope will be decisive for women and for their ability to occupy decision-making positions.

If a Directorate-General considers this to be a relevant and effective way of increasing financial control, the ex ante system can be used. Naturally, there are different requirements across the Commission depending on the number and nature of the financial transactions that Directorates-General must carry out. The White Paper also takes this into account, but where there is a desire and demonstrated need to use this system, it can certainly be done. Finally, with regard to the transition, I share Mrs. Theato's reservations about so-called "soft rules." That is something we have already discussed, and the Honourable Member knows that I distinguish between various forms of codes that can have a positive effect and can eventually be converted into—we could say, I suppose—"mandatory rules." But in that regard, I see no possibility of soft rules, which is why, during the transition period, there will be full compliance with the current financial regulation until the legislation is amended through a properly democratic process in this House and in the Council. The White Paper contains absolute guarantees and provisions in this regard. However, in addition—and this is very important, because it is a transition period—there will be training, advice, support, and guarantees: the new head of the audit unit will take office on 1 May, and with that and a host of other guarantees, I believe we can be sure, as far as humanly possible, that there will be a completely secure system even during the transition period. I must make two further observations, because this is a key issue for the reform. The first is that there are those who feel—for reasons I fully understand—that in this transition there is a danger of irresponsibility or inertia. Irresponsibility, because there is a feeling in some quarters that there will not be sufficient control and discipline. I completely reject this, and I base my opinion simply on the criteria of Commission officials, the responsibility of the Directors-General, and the guarantees we have introduced into the system. Inertia would be a result solely of anxiety, and we are doing everything we can in terms of support and training to reduce the possibility of this occurring. Finally, the system we currently have—as the Committee of Independent Experts very firmly stated—is already unsustainable. In fact, the Court of Auditors has deemed it a fiction. In any case, there will have to be a change, which would entail a transition period, because there is no possibility of inventing any system that would allow us to move from one system to another from one Friday to the next Monday. To the extent that is possible with all the information at our disposal and all the design capacity we have, I am confident that we have installed—or will install—based on our proposals a system that will provide the Union, its taxpayers, and this House with complete security.

Greater control at national level, by national governments over national banks, but also greater control at international level, for example through the International Monetary Fund. I therefore believe that the causes of the problem can best be addressed if, on the one hand, good governance practices are duly respected in the countries concerned and, on the other hand, greater control is ensured at national and international level to prevent these uncontrolled phenomena. Madam President, several Members of Parliament have said that more money should be made available for large-scale projects. Mrs Kreissl-Dörfler, for example, spoke, in English, of "long-term financing for long-term projects". That is an absolutely obvious request. My response to this request is that first of all the countries should keep their promise to allocate 0.7% of their gross national product to development aid and cooperation, so that a much larger volume of funding can be used for long-term projects in the way specifically provided for this purpose, that is to say through contributions to development cooperation, and not through the Tobin tax, which would be an artificial and probably harmful form of financing. Madam President, I would like to conclude my speech here. As regards the resolution, for which I have seen a proposal, the Commission is waiting to hear the result of the vote in Parliament before defining its position. Thank you for giving me the opportunity to take part in this evening's debate. I have received four motions for resolutions under Rule 40(5) of the Rules of Procedure. Madam President, I regret that I do not have your command of French. However, I would be happy if Commissioner Bolkestein would listen for a moment, which I do not think is possible given that he is speaking to Mrs Randzio-Plath. Could you remind him that I still have something to say? Mr Bolkestein, I want to say something! Unfortunately, I do not speak as good a Dutch as you do. However, I would like to make a few comments to you. The fact that we are in favour of the Tobin tax does not represent an initiative by Parliament against the Commission. We want to explore the possibilities of introducing this tax as one of many possible instruments and we hope that you will be on our side in this. Politically, I always have my doubts when people say that an initiative is not necessary, that we do not want it, that we cannot implement it. It is not your job to decide on this, but ours. This shows to some extent the new awareness that has arisen in Parliament. I would like to discuss this with you, nothing more, nothing less. However, we can immediately drop any other option; I regard you as a serious Commissioner who intends to carry out your work with commitment and as such I respect you. I ask you in turn to respect us Members who intend to take our tasks, including the Tobin tax, with the same seriousness! Madam President, it seems that there has been an oversight and that the list of resolutions tabled, which you yourself have just mentioned, does not include the joint compromise resolution tabled by the PSE, the Liberals, the GUE Group, the Greens and Mr Kuntz and Mr Coûteaux.

This coordination does not exist at the moment, nor has the Commission yet presented any concrete proposals for improving it. Here in Parliament, we are waiting for the Commission to submit a more detailed report on this matter to our parliamentary committee as soon as possible. It is of crucial importance to ensure that local businesses, organizations, and other stakeholders are involved in the practical implementation of the programs. Experience shows that cooperation projects must be better planned, that their monitoring must be more precise, and that they must be more cost-effective. Many projects have been left halfway and have become ineffective in the web of administration and bureaucracy. The parties must also be required to commit to the projects and fulfill their obligations. Our group is reintroducing several amendments that were rejected by the parliamentary committee during the preparations. I would like to submit for consideration the report on URBAN, in whose arguments the rapporteur has plausibly addressed the Commission's guidelines regarding the establishment of a minimum sum of €500 per inhabitant. This should not be pursued as a mechanical objective, but must be adapted to the specific conditions of the target region. This perspective is so important that it must be included in the conclusions, and not remain a mere argument. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, INTERREG is one of the Structural Funds. It will not only finance projects in one region, in one country, but also in neighboring regions, in two or more countries. Unfortunately, this is true only for part of the resources, that is, only for the EU's internal borders. However, regions located along borders with third countries in particular need a functioning instrument for cross-border cooperation. The regulation is misleading, as if this were also the case. However, this is not the case. The fact is that the Commission has not amended the regulation for years, although Parliament has long demanded it. Looking ahead, this means that for these regions, a further deterioration in the form of outdated development of marginal areas will once again occur. Since 1996, Parliament has been calling for a fund to be set up for cooperation with third countries to eliminate difficulties. Nothing has happened. The difficulties continue to drag on, to the detriment of the affected regions. Parliament is once again calling for improved cross-border cooperation, and we hope that a common fund will be set up and that the regulation will be amended once again in collaboration with the other Commissioners. We want a Europe for citizens, not a Europe of bureaucrats. Mr. President, a third of European Union funds are spent on funds for all kinds of development objectives. My group is delighted if this helps bridge the gap with the most disadvantaged regions, cities, and population groups, or if health conditions and living conditions are improved. It is a question of solidarity and progress. But distributing ever more money is no guarantee that it will be spent increasingly better.

It would have been better if we had tried to reach a compromise by formulating a common position. I believe that, in doing so, the European Parliament is being excluded from the debate at a time when a particularly interesting development is taking place in the European Union, in which a broad socio-economic programme is being developed much more clearly. The Portuguese Presidency has presented a broad programme document for the extraordinary summit in Lisbon. The Commission has taken the same approach in its five-year programme, also mentioning one of the four priorities. The document that the Commission has produced for the Lisbon summit also refers to a broad approach that covers many areas. I am convinced that this is the right path: the development of a broad socio-economic approach within the European Union, also because it is from this economic entity that politics arises. I believe that, in this respect, the European Parliament will be able to play a limited role both in Lisbon and in the context of the meeting to which we are invited in June. But what positions should we take there? Should we simply admit that we are still stuck in the old political oppositions that exist? Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank the House for the seriousness and thoroughness with which it has worked. The expert hearings and the debates in committee have provided us with additional information of considerable quality. Furthermore, during this afternoon's debate, significant divergences were identified as to possible policies. I believe, however, that I can discern some elements of consensus. We all agree that the current economic situation is positive and that we must try to move forward and exploit the current opportunity in order to improve circumstances and achieve a clear improvement in employment. I would like to dwell only briefly on these issues and instead go into the last point which I believe to be the priority in today's debate. Yesterday, as some of you have noted, the Committee on Economic Affairs illustrated the improvement in the economic situation in Europe. We can assume that this positive trend, already highlighted in the outlook in November, could even prove better than initially expected. Employment growth continues at a good pace. It is true that inflation, despite yesterday's figures, must be controlled - we have reached around 2 percent according to the latest data from December - but it is also true that underlying inflation highlights that inflationary tensions are due to very specific elements, such as the rise in the price of oil and, of course, the trend in the exchange rate. When presenting the report, we already referred to the possible risks to growth. We highlighted the possibility of experiencing difficulties in American growth and therefore in other areas of the world, as well as the possibility of a certain recovery in inflation. This recovery in inflation could be significant especially if it ends up generating cost inflation. For this reason, we reiterate the need for a wage policy compatible with the definitions of inflation that we intend to establish.

Allow me to thank Mr Andersson for his response to his main question and to answer it as follows. Firstly, Finland and Denmark have exceptions to the principle of free movement of goods until 2003. These countries are taking preparatory measures to be ready for free access for alcoholic products by the year 2003. In the case of Sweden, the situation is somewhat different. In 1995, it was decided to introduce a five-year derogation period, which is now expiring. I have not yet heard any arguments on the basis of which the Commission should consider extending this period. Secondly, we are maintaining a process of ongoing consultation with the Swedish Government. I can inform Mr. Andersson that I will be going to Stockholm on 6 March to hold talks with Minister Ringholm, with members of the Swedish Parliament and, upon request, with the Prime Minister or other ministers, with a view to continuing the debate on this issue, which – I fully understand – is the subject of intense political passion in Sweden. Thirdly, I naturally understand very well the importance of the health aspect of this issue. I repeat once again that Professor Lindgren of Lund University has stated that, whatever developments may occur with regard to import restrictions, alcohol consumption in Sweden will remain unchanged. The question then, of course, is where the quantity of alcohol that is not brought in by travelers arriving in the country comes from. The answer is either it is smuggled in or the alcohol is produced by the Swedes themselves, and, as Mr. Andersson knows, this is a particularly dangerous and harmful process. That said, Mr. Andersson seems to think that the health situation improves if alcohol imports are restricted. In this case, however, not only Sweden but all European Union countries should start from the principle of banning all alcohol sales. We have seen a similar example in the United States. Mr. Andersson is certainly aware of what was called prohibition. He also knows what resulted in mafia activities in the United States, where prohibition was eventually ended. This simply means that we must, of course, protect health, but not by banning alcohol, because that serves no purpose. Mr President, this is, in fact, revenue from the Swedish alcohol monopoly, and if the Swedish government says that it must cover costs in the health sector in this way, this still proves that it is a distortion of competition, since other countries have to finance their own costs in the sector without having a monopoly on alcohol. What I would like to know is whether you are also aware of any studies that show that moderate consumption of quality alcohol, for example Franconian wine or Bavarian beer, is good for health and would therefore reduce the burden on the Swedish budget. I understand that Mr Posselt has started to look at the fiscal aspects of this matter. I also understand that the high taxation of alcoholic products in Sweden dates back to 1638 and that, since then, the state has received a significant portion of its tax revenue from the sale of alcoholic products.

But my criticism, or rather, to put it bluntly, my anger, is directed exclusively at those who have caused and are still causing such reactions, Messrs. Schüssel and Haider and their parties... ... as well as their representatives in the European Parliament. Mr Poettering, I find it interesting that you are in a situation almost as difficult as I am today, although for different reasons. Today you have to defend something that you do not actually want to defend - Mr Schüssel - and you have to take note that this same Schüssel, as I have heard, was recently excluded from the top of the Christian Democratic Party representatives. Mr Poettering also argued that the spell cast by Haider could only be broken by integrating him into the political system. I maintain, however, that Haider, like other far-right movements, cannot and does not want to be integrated into this political system, into our political system, and into this Europe. Anyone who feeds on prejudices against foreigners and minorities and feeds such prejudices, anyone who has pettiness and anti-liberalism in his political program, anyone who behaves rudely and contemptuously in international relations, anyone who has never clearly and unequivocally distanced himself from National Socialism, certainly has no intention or willingness to integrate! (Applause) It is the great historical fault of the conservatives to voluntarily huddle with the wolf waiting to be eaten by it. But in this way the wolf is fed, instead of being kept at bay, and the ÖVP is forced to sacrifice itself. I fully understand that Europe and the civilized world want to have as little to do as possible with such a government. But there is also another Austria, the Austria that, with thousands and thousands of citizens, demonstrated against the participation of the FPÖ in the government, the Austria that will continue to demonstrate against that government. I ask this Europe to give that Austria its support and its help. (Applause) The stronger this Europe becomes and the more vigilant it is against authoritarian tendencies within it, the more effectively we will be able to fight against the roots of right-wing extremism. Because Europe is and remains the greatest guarantee against xenophobia and demagogy, yes, even against the return to barbarism. Support the Austrian people against this government! (Applause) Mr President, this is a historic moment because we see that the European Union is finally becoming a community of values and principles. This is becoming all the clearer now, when the government of a Member State is about to be formed with the support of a party that, as is well known, does not respect these values. I would also like to stress that the concerns expressed by the fourteen Member States of the Council are justified. The fact that this issue concerns the composition of a government of a Member State of the European Union means that it also falls within the competence of the Council and, therefore, cannot be regarded as a purely internal affair of Austria. As Members of the European Parliament we need to do more to highlight the importance of the work done in strengthening fundamental rights.

This would force all major industries in EU countries to pay billions of pounds or euros, and this cost would be passed on to the price and therefore to buyers of new cars. Since European car manufacturers started production decades earlier than Japanese, Korean and other manufacturers, they would be burdened more heavily, to the advantage of their competitors in other countries. I congratulate Mr Florenz, Mr Lange and the other Members who have tried to bridge the party divide and reach a compromise based on sharing the costs, and I ask you to support the amendment tabled on behalf of myself and my colleagues from Germany, Italy, Ireland, Spain, Sweden and the UK to remove the retrospective aspect of the provision. Retrospective laws are bad laws, unjust laws and often unworkable laws. Most democratic parliaments in the free world reject them in principle unless they are in the public interest, which is not the case here. That is why I have asked for a roll-call vote. We want to see who is prepared to vote in favour of a retroactive law, of dubious legality, which would place a heavy economic burden on all future car buyers and would have a devastating effect on the European car industry. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to briefly recall once again the economic stakes of this directive and reiterate my support for the amendments tabled by my colleague, Bernd Lange. Indeed, these amendments have the advantage - and I would like to insist on this point - of reconciling environmental requirements and economic imperatives. The Council, in its common position, said that car manufacturers should bear, in full or in large part, the costs of take-back and recycling. But as Mr Lange rightly said, this solution is completely unfair to European manufacturers. Coming from a country where there are actually car manufacturers, and I can assure you that it is not possible to impose on them, retroactively, the full cost assumption of all vehicles of their brand currently in circulation, that is, in fact, to assume costs imposed by 80 percent of the European car fleet. This solution is unacceptable because these manufacturers have not been able to integrate into their production processes and their cost prices the environmental requirements that we impose on them today. The common position puts European manufacturers at a disadvantage compared to manufacturers who have recently entered the European market. Of course, we are not here to defend this or that national interest, this or that industrial lobby, but to build a competitive Europe on the world market and to defend jobs in the economic sectors in which we are actually competitive.
