That is why, ladies and gentlemen, I ask you to support the amendments tabled by Mr Bernd Lange, which will be supported by the Group of the Party of European Socialists because they do indeed reconcile all the interests at stake - economic interests and environmental requirements - while leaving the Member States free to decide how to apply these requirements; the amendments in question provide that the systems in force in the Member States, and there are some that work very well, can continue to function.

I hope that the decisions taken in Helsinki will lead to progress on the Cyprus issue and that a new era of hope will dawn for Cyprus. I would welcome Turkey now playing a constructive role in the Cyprus issue. I am pleased that both the Council and the Commission welcome the UN's efforts to launch proximity talks between the two communities in Cyprus, with the aim of promoting reconciliation and confidence-building between them. I welcome the Commission's support for the bi-zonal, bi-communal, federal Cyprus that the United Nations has long championed and that both the Greek and Turkish sides in Cyprus should work hard to build. I am pleased about the political thaw in relations between the Greek and Turkish governments. I hope this will have a positive impact on the Cyprus talks. I also hope that some of the aid available to Cyprus in preparation for accession will be used to promote this reconciliation and the building of trust, and that both sides of the separated communities in Cyprus will accept and use this money in the spirit in which it is given. All of us in the European institutions – in Parliament, the Council, and the Commission – should do our utmost to help Cyprus find a peaceful solution that can reunite the two communities that have been separated for so many years. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President-in-Office of the Council and Commissioner Verheugen, the regulation on accession aid is not exactly a showcase for the Commission's coherent work. This cobbled-together of auxiliary constructions strikes me as rather amateurish. This applies both to the substantive formulation and the financial aspect. I believe we can therefore hardly present the Union's accession activities to the citizens of Cyprus and Malta as proof that it is worthwhile to join. Václav Havel rightly said today that the political quality of the European Union is measured by what it brings to the individual. From the perspective of civil society, what a regulation achieves is crucial. This regulation is not exactly a winning strategy in this regard. It contains clauses on external control and is provisional, and that is no way to shine. The quality of aid is measured by the following criteria: Is it decentralized, is it transparent, is it close to the people, and does it work? Nevertheless, for the divided island of Cyprus, this pre-accession strategy as a whole represents a major political challenge. In my view, it is the task of the European Union to use all its instruments, including this one, to contribute to a political solution to the conflict on the island. At this point, I must say that the European Parliament's amendment is particularly important to me. The Commission and the Council are also delivering very hopeful speeches today. I am very, very pleased that we are moving in the same direction.

Today's adoptions are not only contrary to the Treaty and grant the Union's bodies more powers than they deserve, but above all, they will have the opposite effect. These sanctions will not weaken Mr. Haider or the FPÖ; quite the contrary; they will strengthen them. We will achieve exactly the opposite of what we seek. This is not the way to combat racism and the rise of the extreme right. The Danish Liberal Members of the European Parliament insist that today's adoption does NOT constitute, IN ANY WAY, Parliament's support for the diplomatic sanctions decided by the fourteen Prime Ministers against Austria. This is why the Danish Liberal Members of the Assembly supported the Liberal Members' very firm disavowal of any form of xenophobia in Austria and elsewhere. We attach great importance to the possible use of the new provisions of the Treaty of Amsterdam, which allow for the deprivation of voting rights in the EU Council of Ministers of any country that, through its actions, violates the fundamental rights of citizens through discrimination, etc. (Article 7). The participation of the Freedom Party in the Austrian government represents a dangerous development for the political future of the European Union. This is the "belly of the beast," which, unfortunately, is appearing on the political scene more than at any time since the Second World War. The European Parliament and the governments of the Union are obliged to politically isolate a government in which admirers of Nazism and advocates of xenophobia participate. The European Union bears great responsibility - and with it, the members of the two main political currents, the Social Democrats and the Christian Democrats - because by dogmatically clinging to the harsh financial policies of the EMU, by dismembering the welfare state, by deifying unbridled competition, it has marginalized large sections of society and offers far-right demagogues like Haider the opportunity to enlist supporters in their neo-Nazi adventure. Since the European Parliament's rules of procedure do not allow us to present our own resolution condemning Haider's party, as well as all parties in any European country that propagate racist, xenophobic and anti-migrant worker infamies, we voted for the compromise resolution, without approving several of its recitals or terms, to show our solidarity with those in Austria itself who oppose the Austrian far right and its demagogy. Our vote in no way signifies an endorsement of the parties that signed this compromise resolution, nor of their current policies, nor of their future attitude in the event of a worsening threat from the extreme right. Some of these parties, which claim to be republican and democratic, are adopting, out of complacency or electoral calculation, the demagogy of the extreme right, if only by blaming, openly or hypocritically, the presence of immigrant workers for unemployment and making their lives more difficult. More generally, those of the signatory parties that lead or have led the governments of various countries in the European Union bear their share of responsibility for the influence acquired by the extreme right by pursuing a policy that, out of devotion to the interests of big business, refuses to take measures likely to eradicate unemployment and the poverty it causes and thus facilitates the xenophobic demagogy of the extreme right.

We believe it is necessary to coordinate the development objectives and management mechanisms of actions 2 and 3 financed by LEADER with the remaining actions financed in the same areas by other Community programmes for interregional and international cooperation and partnership, such as INTERREG, SAPARD, PHARE, TACIS and MEDA. - (DE) Mr President, rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, before examining the EQUAL report in more detail, I would like to focus on the fundamental aspects of the employment guidelines on which the report is based. The main objectives of an EU-wide employment policy have been identified as employability, entrepreneurship and adaptability. These objectives, it seems, should ensure that workers become as useful and usable as possible for the economy. However, an approach that aims to truly and effectively eliminate discrimination should have as its aim the self-determination of individuals. But then it would no longer be a question of promoting economic usability but rather of equal rights. Mrs Stenzel's report, however, is well developed, at least within the framework of the intended orientations. All asylum seekers and refugees should be explicitly included in the programmes, which should be a given. The Conservatives, however, voted against in committee. I would ask them the following question: is the aim of your policy to marginalise people? What is behind the idea of banning those who want to work? Doesn't that contradict the orientation of "employability?" It is also noteworthy that it is a mainstreaming programme, because the report still has a serious shortcoming. It is emphasised that women should be given more opportunities on the labour market by building more childcare centres. Anyone who lets men pursue their career advancement in peace and is concerned only with nurseries, without questioning the unequal distribution of reproductive activity, has unfortunately not understood what mainstreaming means! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism has adopted this opinion on the EQUAL report in its final deliberation with no votes against and only one abstention. I would like to point this out explicitly at the beginning of my speech to highlight the difference in positions with respect to the Committee on Employment, which is responsible for the report. The approval of the opinion by all political groups is based on the conclusions in which the issues of regional policy, transport and tourism are linked to aspects of combating all forms of discrimination and inequality in the context of the labour market. The Members of the Committee on Regional Policy have also, of course, highlighted a number of critical points in the Commission's proposal: firstly, the insufficient clarification of the thematic guidelines for the activities of development partnerships; secondly, the fact that rigorous selection criteria for the evaluation of proposed projects have not yet been defined by the Commission; thirdly, the amount of administrative burden, probably excessive, for the management of projects by the Commission and the technical assistance bodies.

The Commission can undertake to inform Parliament regularly about the published invitations to tender. We would like them to appear on the Internet as well, so as to ensure maximum transparency on this specific point. Another issue raised concerns the remaining information that could be important for Parliament on macroeconomic assistance. I would like to inform you that the Commission is prepared to inform the Chairmen of the various parliamentary committees concerned on a regular basis on a confidential basis - should the nature of the information provided so require - on the various initiatives undertaken for macroeconomic assistance operations. I thank you, ladies and gentlemen, and I hope that with the final decision of the Council it will be possible to release these funds and make a positive contribution that will allow us to continue the considerable effort made by several parties in Kosovo with a view to achieving better peace and coexistence. Mr President, I am pleased that the views of Parliament, and of the Committee on Budgets in particular, and of the Commission are convergent. We assure you that we will always remain faithful to every commitment aimed at supporting the Commission in carrying out its task. However, after listening to the Commissioner, I am a little concerned about the commitments made by the services in the Committee on Budgets. It was clearly established - I am not saying it was a good thing or a bad thing, but it was a contract - between the Commission services and the Committee on Budgets that there was convergence on Amendments Nos 4 and 7, that is, that there was agreement on the idea of making the release of the second tranche of macro-financial aid conditional on compliance with the commitments made by the donors. Now, listening to Commissioner Solbes, I understand that this commitment should have been taken with moderation. Commissioner, an agreement is an agreement. Are you confirming or not the agreement accepted by your services in the Committee on Budgets, or are you toning down this condition, which would mean breaking the commitment made to us? No, Mr Bourlanges, I think it is a fundamental problem, relating to the way in which we formally conclude the compromise that we have accepted. I have made a proposal and I repeat it: the Commission will state the following in the Council decision: "The exact amount and timing of implementation of the second tranche will be decided in due course taking into account developments in Kosovo's external financing needs and contributions from other bilateral donors." In this way, we believe we are fully respecting what has been concluded. I simply ask the Commission, before releasing the second tranche, to inform the Committee on Budgets. I fully agree. It will be done. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11.00. ALTENER The next item is the debate on the report (A5-0011/2000) by Mr Langen on the joint text approved by the Conciliation Committee for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council adopting a multiannual programme for the promotion of renewable energy sources in the Community - ALTENER (C5-0333/1999 - 1997/0370(COD)). Mr President, although I am not present in the Chamber, I would like to thank Mr Langen for his commitment to getting this programme through both Parliament and the Council.

The events of recent years have certainly heightened awareness of the threats to food safety and human health and given cause for concern. Parliament's prompt response must undoubtedly be seen by all citizens as the most important guarantee for the future, for you, as Members of Parliament, have thereby established a framework for food quality to which the Member States must adhere. However, even in this crucial area of administration, Parliament is aware of the principle of subsidiarity and calls on the Member States to assume and live up to their responsibilities. With Agenda 2000, I believe we are placing emphasis on policies of direct concern to citizens, such as food safety, water quality, environmental protection, and rural development. If we implement this agenda with commitment and determination, the first years of the new millennium will become a milestone in the implementation of policies that are close to the people and reflect the needs of the Community. I particularly welcome the proposed new, strict approval procedures for additives in animal feed. Anyone who demonstrably violates these rules must be severely punished. I pay tribute to Mr. Byrne, the new Commissioner responsible for food safety. He has a difficult task, but he has responded quickly and effectively to the demands of this House and to the concerns of consumers. I am particularly pleased that my home country, Ireland, is leading the way in implementing the new food legislation based on the principle of traceability. This will establish Ireland as a center of excellence for the food production of the future. Mr. President, Commissioner, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent work and, in particular, express my satisfaction at the unanimity that prevailed within the group on this point. It is therefore envisaged that the Commission will replace the current authorisations by regulation with authorisations linked to the person responsible for placing the additive in question on the market, and that this will happen simultaneously for all the additives concerned. It is necessary to restore a coherent legal framework. As early as October 1999, the Commission proposed introducing a legal basis for replacing authorisations in Directive 70/524/EEC. However, we must ensure that no distortions of competition arise, as Mr Kindermann and Ms Auroi have already stressed. In my opinion, clear labelling of genetically modified feed additives is necessary to ensure that the final consumer has the choice and is guaranteed to choose a food containing or without GMOs. Consumers must be able to make a free, informed decision. This proposal has no financial implications for the Community budget, Commissioner. Therefore, there must be complete transparency for producers and consumers in the area of food safety. I am convinced that the Commission can agree with the rapporteur, who – I would remind you – was unanimously supported in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Mr President, since the BSE era, we in this House have repeatedly said that animal nutrition is one of the most important and primary elements for the safe production of food, for the health and protection of consumers. We are therefore pleased that the Commission is presenting a proposal on feed additives.

Question No. 6 (H-0122/00): Subject: Ethnic cleansing of Serbs in Kosovo. Since the end of the bombing of Yugoslavia by NATO and the EU, arguing that it was intended to prevent the ethnic cleansing of Kosovo Albanians by Serbs, and since the deployment of KFOR on 12 June 1999, 200,000 Serbs living in Kosovo have been expelled and 768 killed. This ethnic cleansing is therefore far more 'thorough' than that carried out by the Serbs. In recent days, Serbs have once again been murdered with impunity by members of Kosovo Albanian mafia groups. What decision will the Council take to put an end to this ethnic cleansing once and for all and to guarantee respect for human rights for the entire population of Kosovo, regardless of race or creed? Mr. President, forgive me, but when you hear the Council representative talk like that, you really wonder how far the hypocrisy, the permissiveness, and the complicity have gone. In the house of the hanged man, they don't talk about the rope, as the saying goes. Yugoslavia was a peaceful country, a guarantor of stability and peace. After the interventions of NATO and, initially, Germany, the events we know about occurred. So, it is not the government in Belgrade that is responsible, but NATO; the imperialists and their interventions are responsible. What is the situation today? UN Security Council Resolution 1244 was disregarded in every respect, which proves that it was a trap. 350,000 Serbs, Gypsies, and members of other nationalities besides the Kosovo Albanians have been expelled, 900 murdered, and 800 kidnapped. Eight months later, the Security Council resolution is still being brutally violated. For example, not only was the KLA not disarmed within three months, as the resolution actually stipulated, but contrary to Mr. Kouchner's claims in the European Parliament, it was equipped with modern equipment and designated the "Kosovo Protection Corps." Finally, since the Minister mentioned Mr. Kouchner, I would like to point out that, with his 25 orders, he also disregarded Yugoslavia's sovereignty and the Security Council resolution. He introduced a separate currency, his own judiciary... (The President interrupted the speaker.) Let's face the facts, Mr. President. I would like to thank the Minister for his answer, but also recall that, statistically, more violence is being committed in Kosovo today than before the NATO bombings. It is worrying that the bombings have exacerbated the situation, and it should be acknowledged that NATO and the European Union were wrong in taking this measure. The Minister was quite right – and I agree with him – to speak about Belgrade's guilt, but we must not forget that the intelligence services of the US, Germany, France, Italy, and Great Britain supplied weapons and money to the KLA, a mafia, to contribute to the problems in this region. Therefore, we are all guilty. I would like to ask you a follow-up question because of its relevance to the overall context. Don't you think it would be beneficial to lift the blockade against Serbia so that there is greater economic normality in the region, and Kosovo, as a province of Serbia, also benefits from this?

This is certainly something that benefits everyone. To ensure that the Treaty is respected and that we support what has been described as the Community machinery, we are taking the measures we presented yesterday in our statement. And we will continue to do so, Madam President, impartially. It is our duty. It is also a matter of conviction. My final point is this: we understand the context of this fundamental debate. There are several people here who, like me, have grown accustomed over many years to Herr Haider's offensive statements, to the xenophobia of many elements of his policy, and to the strategy he has developed of alternating aggressive statements with apologies, sometimes on successive days. We understand that, and we also remember his sometimes short and selective memory of Nazism. And when we remember that, like many Members of all stripes in this House, my instinct and that of my colleagues is naturally awakened. But the Commission must act on the basis of values and laws, not solely on the basis of instinct. And that is the basis of the conclusion we reached yesterday morning. We therefore support that conclusion while continuing to defend values and the law. Without fragility, without complacency, without ambiguity, but in the service of the entire Union and of each of the Union's Member States and their peoples. We will continue to do so energetically and consistently and, as Mr. Cox said in the debate, we will maintain close vigilance. Given that Mr. Da Costa is listening to these remarks from the back of the House, I wonder if Mr. Kinnock could confirm that the Commission supports the view explicitly stated by Mr. Da Costa today and in the recent Presidency statement on behalf of the Heads of State and Government. Does the Commission support the Council? (EN) Madam President, when the Commission said yesterday morning that it takes note of the views expressed in a joint statement by 14 Member States and that it shares the concerns that gave rise to that opinion, I think we can assume that since yesterday morning, as soon as it was able to address the issue, the Commission has maintained an opinion consistent with that of 14 of the Member States. Thank you, Commissioner Kinnock. I believe we have just had a great political debate, commensurate with the situation and what we could have expected. I thank you, ladies and gentlemen. The debate on problems of topicality, urgency, and particular importance is now closed. The vote will take place at 11:00. Recourse to the precautionary principle. In accordance with the agenda, the Commission now makes a statement on recourse to the precautionary principle. (EN) To begin with, I wish to say that I am pleased to introduce this communication on recourse to the precautionary principle, which was drafted in collaboration with Mr. Byrne and Mr. Liikanen. The precautionary principle is not a new concept.

Indeed, these programs have been important elements of participatory democracy, of the citizen-led approach to Europe. For all these reasons, the LEADER+ concept must retain all the positive aspects of previous programs. Consequently, a compelling question arises: after ten years of success for these programs, why continue to limit LEADER+ to an experimental role? Are there so many other European initiatives that can boast of having carried out 800 specific, original experiments with notable success? How much longer will the Commission relegate LEADER+ to an experimental role, instead of incorporating it into the general concept of mainstreaming rural development? Furthermore, I have doubts about the limited orientations to which the Commission wants to reduce LEADER+. At a time when, Commissioner, after Seattle, we Europeans are fighting for the multifunctionality of rural development projects, why remain locked into a few reductive criteria, with extremely inadequate resources? This is an environmentalist speaking to you: the precautionary principle and stable development require a much more diversified and multifaceted approach. In this regard, the Commission proposes further reducing the cooperation actions of local action groups, limiting them solely to the countries that are candidates for enlargement. It would be much better to have strengthened coordination between LEADER+ and Community cooperation and partnership programs, such as INTERREG, PHARE, SAPARD, or MEDA, as, incidentally, proposed by the Committee on Regional Policy. Indeed, it is good to show solidarity with Eastern Europe, but it is not enough. We must not abandon the tradition established by previous programs with the countries of the South, particularly those in the Mediterranean area. Therefore, once again, we can emphasize that what is lacking in the field of agriculture and rural development is codecision, which would truly allow us to have the necessary means to advance programs of this type, which require cooperation and cross-cutting action. Mr. President, I would like to make a few very brief remarks. We are debating the program period and the orientation of the four Community initiatives without having a single essential and comprehensive evaluation of the previous period available. This is very negative. Generally, the programs and objectives are overly optimistic, yet the results are not always sufficient, and yet the opacity and complexity of the projects often leave a very wide margin for mismanagement and even fraud. The Community initiatives we are discussing can play an important role under certain conditions. But they must not be subjected to the objectives and aspirations of a more general, negative social and economic policy, and must be allowed to develop their independent role. For example, the adaptation of the EQUAL program to the objectives of employability and the flexibilization of labor relations transforms the initiative into a new version of labor agreements. The extension of the LEADER initiative to all areas of the Union carries an even greater danger of marginalizing less-advantaged regions in favor of more developed ones. The INTERREG initiative should include eligible regions, with particular emphasis on border, island, mountainous, and non-mountainous regions such as the province of Arta in Greece, which is exempt from Annex I of the Commission's communication.

On all these issues, I will do my best to follow your recommendations. I would also like to highlight the political conclusions, which, incidentally, all Members are already familiar with, but whose main elements I would like to recall. Ladies and gentlemen, significant progress has been made on the path to real convergence, especially in the four cohesion Member States, but also, Mr. Pohjamo, and I say this frankly, in the Objective 2 regions, which have experienced certain delays in their development, particularly with regard to infrastructure. This is the first political point. Second political point: the Structural Funds have made and will continue to make a significant contribution to this convergence process. All the macroeconomic models we work with indicate, for the past decade, that more than a third of the convergence achieved in underdeveloped regions would not have occurred without the Structural Funds. However, I have taken careful note, with regard in particular to the outermost regions, Mrs. Sudre, Mr. Fruteau, and also Mr. Nogueira Román, that you state that much remains to be done—and here is my third point—regarding the plan to improve the content of the employment recovery, the fight against social exclusion, which is particularly serious and unbearable in many of our regions, and the integration of women and young people into the labor market. The fourth political point is the enlargement of the Union: the great political and humanist project of the coming years for our institutions, and also the greatest challenge for cohesion policy in Europe, a point on which Mr. Van Dam has insisted. I would say that in Berlin and in the financial instruments made available to us, what could be a cohesion policy for the first countries that will join us is taking shape. I am thinking in particular of the ISPA, for whose implementation I will be responsible in the coming weeks. As you can see, ladies and gentlemen, we have just launched our new programming, and we are already reflecting together on the impact of the enlargement of the Union on our structural policy. This sixth periodic report, on which Mr. Berend has issued an overall positive assessment, constitutes for us, at least for me, a good basis for reflection. I would therefore like to thank you very sincerely for this contribution to the reflection we have initiated for the next guidelines, as well as for the successful implementation of the guidelines for the period 2000-2006. Thank you very much, Commissioner. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 12:00. (The sitting adjourned at 8:25 p.m.) Approval of the Minutes of the previous sitting. The minutes of the previous sitting have been distributed. Are there any objections? Mr. President, I am responding to an invitation made yesterday afternoon by the President of the Assembly to speak on behalf of my group on a matter referred to in the minutes.

If it's any consolation, Ireland doesn't have its own channel yet either. Apparently, there are some technical problems that are difficult to solve, but we are working on it. Thank you very much for giving me the opportunity to clarify this. I'm not sure our Dutch colleagues are fully convinced, because our Irish colleagues also cannot receive a national channel. I think we need to study what should be done to ensure that all our colleagues can access their own channel. I thank you, Mrs. Banotti, and I extend my thanks to the other Quaestors, for the efforts you are going to make in this regard. Madam President, I would like to point out to Mr. Wurtz that the Brezhnev doctrine of limited sovereignty is not Commission doctrine, and that, unless proven otherwise, we are not within the scope of Articles 6 and 7. Consequently, Austria has every right to form a government, and the President of the Commission has every right, and even the duty, to express his best wishes to Austria. Mr. Wurtz should perhaps remember that not so long ago, some of his party's colleagues, French communist mayors, were sending bulldozers into immigrant homes in France. Order of Business The next step is the debate on the final draft agenda as established by the Conference of Presidents, in accordance with Rule 110 of the Rules of Procedure. a) Sittings of 14 to 18 February 2000 in Strasbourg Wednesday: President. Since the Council will not be able to attend on Wednesday afternoon, several groups—European People's Party, European Socialists, Liberals, Greens, United Left—have requested that we deal in a single discussion with the Council declaration on the Cyprus question and Mr. Brok's report on the pre-accession strategy for Cyprus and Malta, and that we advance these two items, together with Mr. Swoboda's report, on the agenda. Therefore, for Wednesday, we would have the two Council statements on the coherence of Union policies with development policy and the UN session on "Human Rights", followed by the single discussion on Cyprus, and then the opinions of Mr. Swoboda, Mr. Corrie, Ms. Frassoni, and Mr. Knörr Borràs. Who wishes to present this request on behalf of these groups? As no one wishes to speak, I put this request to the vote. (Parliament agreed) Thursday: President.— Regarding current, urgent, and important issues, I have several amendments. Regarding human rights, I have two requests for inclusion: one from the Liberal Group for the subheading entitled "Cambodia", and another from the Green Group for the subheading entitled "Pinochet". As you know, the section on "Human Rights" cannot cover more than five topics. Currently, there are four items listed in the final draft agenda. Therefore, we can only consider one more.

In Europe, after the Cadiz disaster or the Urquiola off the Spanish coast in 1976, or the Torrey Canyon disaster in the same year, or so many other cases that have occurred, we really began to legislate in this regard in 1994 and 1995, and especially in recent years. Moreover, in recent years the focus has been fundamentally on passenger transport safety. That is the reality. I believe that a major effort must now be urgently made to address the new problems arising, among other things, from North American legislation, with the safety of the maritime transport of dangerous goods being a top priority. I have raised a number of issues which, if you wish, we can discuss in more detail at a meeting with the committee responsible for this matter, or when I present the concrete initiatives to you in the coming months. My stated intention is that we begin the discussion at the end of March, which also coincides with the Council of Ministers, and that, of course, we already have texts to discuss before the end of the Portuguese Presidency's six-month term. Flags of convenience are a problem, but not the only one. Romania is not a flag of convenience, yet it has a very high rate of incidents during inspections—more so than flags of convenience. Malta and Cyprus have applied to join the Community. We must make our demands on this issue, and this is what will be negotiated. This will force us to rethink the European Union registers and address the famous problem that will certainly arise again: the demand for a Community register. I think this is difficult, but in any case, the registers of the European Union countries must be reviewed. With regard to controls, a highly key issue, as Mr. Hatzidakis said, the first thing we need to do is examine how the existing legislation has worked. Because we already have legislation. According to the information provided to me by the Commission, this legislation is not sufficiently applied in many Member States due to a lack of staff, resources, and inspectors. The problem is not that only 25% are inspected, but how the selection is carried out, how the ships posing the greatest risk are identified: based on the age of the ships or on the flags' risk history. Unfortunately, that 25% is sometimes covered by flags known to meet all the requirements: inspections are faster, and the work is easier to carry out. Therefore, it will be less a question of making changes than of adopting measures to monitor what is already being done, apart from some additional requirements regarding inspections, particularly depending on the age of the various ships. There are also SOLAS (International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea) and MARPOL (International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships), two conventions of the International Maritime Organization that must, in due course, be made compulsory in all EU Member States, and whose application must be monitored. As regards the question of Union inspectors, I believe that the principle of subsidiarity justifies allowing these inspections to be carried out by the Member States, although this does not mean that the Commission does not have to monitor whether the Member States are carrying out their task properly.

If their financial responsibility is compromised, greater control will undoubtedly be exercised. Finally, coordination among maritime authorities is necessary to achieve a kind of European mechanism analogous to the Coast Guard that monitors the coasts of the United States. First of all, I would like to thank the colleagues in my group who deal with the environment and who have addressed this problem together with the team in charge of transport. This disaster is as much an environmental disaster as it is a transport disaster, and it is not limited to one sector. Once again, we find ourselves in this Parliament debating yet another maritime disaster. I could rattle off the list of disasters that have affected that industry in the 10 years I have been in this Parliament, but I only have three minutes. There is no doubt that it is time not only for the Member States, but also for that toothless tiger called the International Maritime Organization, and for the oil companies and shipowners—who bear no less responsibility—to assume their responsibilities by taking measures to put an end to these ecological and human tragedies that are repeated year after year. How many more Erikas must we endure before those in power provide us with proper and effective port State control throughout the European Union, not just in certain areas? How much more pollution must we endure before the industry provides us with vessels with segregated tanks and double hulls? How many more seabirds must die before shipping companies stop cleaning their tanks at sea, which, as our resolution points out, causes more pollution than any Erika-type disaster? While I recognize that some progress has been made in areas such as port State control and minimum crew regulations, we are still facing what our late colleague Ken Stewart called "ships of shame entering and leaving our EU waters: rusty buckets and poorly crewed people." Member States need to act quickly and decisively. Our governments need to provide the financial resources necessary to provide us with effective control and also to stop dragging their feet on the issue of maritime safety. The Erika has not claimed human lives, but it may have ruined the livelihoods of many people. Just like the Sea Empress, just like the Braer. There is no doubt that all three left us with an ecological disaster. My group expresses its condolences to the people of Brittany who have seen their area ravaged by this disaster, as it has also expressed on previous occasions to the people of West Wales and the Shetland Islands. Is it not time we stopped expressing condolences and started issuing requests to rid these vessels of shame for the sake of the safety of the seas? Otherwise, later this year we will be debating a new motion for a resolution when another flag-of-convenience tanker sinks and spews its crude oil into the sea.

Expressing our solidarity, as the European Parliament, means first and foremost acting to secure the immediate release of emergency aid for families affected by the oil spill and, at the same time, demanding a qualitative strengthening, at European and international levels, of maritime transport safety rules and regulations to establish much more frequent checks and significantly more dissuasive sanctions for offenders. Our proposals relate in particular to the age of oil tankers. Of those checked and found to be in violation last year, 15 were twenty years old or older, some over thirty or even older. This is no longer tolerable. Furthermore, flags of convenience. According to the International Transport Workers' Federation, more than 40 percent of the ships that sank in 1998 flew flags of convenience, a symbol of profit and the exploitation of human beings to the detriment of safety. This is no longer tolerable. Finally, the lack of transparency. Every effort is being made to make the chain of responsibilities and the identity of the owners and those who truly make decisions as opaque as possible. This is no longer tolerable. At all these levels, we must achieve real and significant changes, including setting a deadline for compliance with the new standards, including double hulls, under penalty of being prohibited from anchoring in Member States' ports or crossing their territorial waters. We must also achieve greater rigor both in the issuance of seaworthiness certificates and in checking the age and maintenance of vessels. Finally, we must ensure that all those responsible for a catastrophe contribute to repairs. In this case, I am thinking, in particular, of the Total-Fina group. The European Union, Mr. President, can make the same representation to the International Maritime Organization. This will demonstrate its usefulness to a public that this time expects clear and concrete actions. Mr. President, Commissioner, as a representative of the French Atlantic coast, a representative of Vendée, I would like first of all to express the sense of rebellion of the populations who were victims of the Erika oil spill in the face of disasters caused not by a natural catastrophe like the hurricane that just struck us, but by a crime. With urgency, in the face of adversity, a magnificent surge of solidarity has emerged: local solidarity, national solidarity, intergovernmental solidarity. What the affected populations, those who have lost everything, particularly among seafarers and tourism professionals, whose activity is compromised for several years, now expect is not only that the polluters repair the damage they have caused, but also that everything necessary be done to ensure that their current misfortune serves others in the future, preventing the repetition of similar crimes. We are paying—it is more than evident—the price of our negligence. Because our States, with the blessing of the Community, have not seen fit to continue having their own merchant fleets and have allowed rigorous expertise in shipbuilding to disappear, we no longer have clear vessel traceability and we see veritable junk ships sailing our waters under flags of convenience, at the mercy of the short-term interests of multinational companies.

When the treaties enter into force and what their final form will be depends not only on this recommendation but also on implementation by the contracting parties. In the United States, the WIPO Treaty has already become law in the form of the Digital Millennium Corporate Act, and this legislative measure has succeeded in maintaining the delicate balance sought by WIPO. The EU, too, must make progress in its legislation in accordance with the agreements reached within WIPO. It is also worrying that the opinions adopted by the previous Parliament do not support WIPO's balanced system. The opinion on the Copyright Directive at first reading was skewed, and the balance was shifted in a way that is detrimental to Europe. The proposed recommendations do not promote the position of culture in Europe; on the contrary, the amendments introduced by Parliament improve the opportunities for media corporations established in the existing market to restructure their existing market shares of over 80% through rigid and overly extensive copyright regulations. So I'm not talking about Charlotte Cederschiöld's recommendation, which I consider an excellent document, but about the last Parliament's treatment of the issue of copyright. I would also like to thank Ms. Cederschiöld in particular for clearly defining, for example, the term "cached copies" in her report. The WIPO Treaty deliberately omitted to address this type of reproduction. If these technical copies are subject to protection, data transmissions will become unnecessarily more expensive and complicated—as the recommendation rightly states. It's as if a postman had to pay a license fee when delivering a book to a consumer. The real advantage of culture is being able to transport art and knowledge safely and easily from the artist directly to the user, the consumer. This new environment is, above all, a tremendous opportunity to create and disseminate culture in a different way than ever before. It is essential to take the interests of all parties into account. Parliament endeavored to do justice to this aspect in its recommendation. Mr. President, First of all, I would like to compliment the rapporteur on her work. The Commission considers that she worked swiftly and accurately. This is not unimportant. The Commission would like to commend the rapporteur. I would like to say at the outset that the Commission agrees with the conclusions in the draft recommendation and therefore supports Parliament's ratification. I would like to stress the importance of both treaties. With the WIPO Copyright Treaty and the WIPO Performances and Phonograms Treaty, we are making progress in the international protection of copyright and related rights, and thus significantly improving the Berne Convention and the Rome Treaties. Both treaties contribute to better protection of works and other things, but also allow public access to content offered on the networks. Both treaties expressly allow the Community to become a party and to have a significant say in the control of this area. The Community's approval of the Treaties is therefore crucial because it demonstrates its commitment to intellectual property rights.

The third inconsistency relates to human rights. They claim to want to protect them. Developing countries are encouraged to respect them. They even pass numerous resolutions condemning every violation of them. We also echo the protests and the international campaigns. Yet, at the same time, the arms trade is allowed to develop, without even bothering to limit the trade in the most atrocious weapons: anti-personnel mines, for example. Nor is much done to truly prevent human rights violations. The fourth inconsistency in the European Union's cooperation policy is this: how can they hope to help development by plundering the natural resources of the countries they help? The European Union must leave its fish to local fishermen to feed local populations, instead of systematically destroying the seabed with its intensive fishing. Raw materials must be left to local producers for processing. Let's not even talk about oil, since we are unfortunately familiar with the policies of groups such as Elf and Total in Africa. To go further, and this will perhaps be the fifth inconsistency, we call for respect for biodiversity, among other reasons to allow everyone to produce with their own seeds and preserve natural wealth. However, at the same time, and we saw this again during the recent negotiations, ACP countries are being forced to sign the TRIPS agreements, when these agreements risk being extended to living organisms. This extension would therefore mean the death of biodiversity and a return to de facto slavery for small farmers in the South at the mercy of multinationals. On the other hand, and this is a sixth inconsistency, the implementation of the existing Treaties is not defended. Thus, on the one hand, a budget allocation is being voted for the fight against AIDS, and on the other, nothing is being done to enforce compulsory licensing within the framework of the aforementioned TRIPS, which would therefore allow developing countries to produce their own medicines and stem the catastrophe caused by AIDS. Similarly, during the WTO negotiations, and when the Schwaiger report noted, in its second section, that large sectors of the population in developing countries, especially the poorest, barely benefit from the current process of trade liberalization, the European Union continues to defend trade liberalization and, admittedly, ends, after a few years of transition, the favorable regime granted to ACP countries when it should have been strengthened, especially for the poorest countries. The eighth inconsistency is political and practical. It is always said: think globally and act locally. However, local development agents are neglected, preferring to argue with national governments and subsidize Northern NGOs at the expense of local programs of Southern NGOs. Agriculture and the environment are other issues, other inconsistencies that could also have been mentioned, without forgetting research, emigration, and health. In short, the goal is to help developing countries while simultaneously encouraging market liberalization, even though it is recognized that this goes against that goal.

What should be done with this money? Human rights deserve special mention. The West has fought for human rights in Kosovo. What is happening now in the region? The mass expulsions orchestrated by the Serbs have ended, but despite this, unacceptable situations occur practically every day in which people are killed or prevented from living where and how they want. Attacks against Serbs, Roma, and Bosnians are reported every day, while attacks against Albanians continue. I was actually appalled by the news, if true, that an Albanian doctor, who undoubtedly worked in very difficult conditions at the hospital in the Serbian part of Mitrovica, was forced to stop treating his people there because he received constant death threats. These incidents and situations we cannot tolerate. I have received news—I don't know if it's true or not—that Serbs continue to exploit a mine in Kosovo, on the Serbian side. Rumor has it that Serbian militias are still active. It makes no difference to me whether it's a Serb, a Roma, a Bosnian, or an Albanian who receives threats or is killed in Kosovo. It makes no difference to me who tries to divide and separate Kosovo. What matters to me is that the bodies we fund achieve what we want to achieve, namely, a multiethnic Kosovo, a Kosovo of coexistence. We need more police forces, since the current forces are insufficient. We need an independent judiciary—which is extremely difficult—and we also need resources for the High Commissioner for Human Rights. All of this must be done, and the sooner the better. If we delay providing aid, the situation will worsen, with the risk of new conflicts and crises erupting. For this reason, I think it is right that we have acted swiftly, that we have recognized the urgent nature of the operation and that we are releasing the funds. However, we want to see actions and we also want to see results in Kosovo. Therefore, I ask the Commission to ensure that the money is used for effective purposes, especially for organizing the police and the justice system. Mr. President, first of all, thank you very much to the honourable Members, and especially the rapporteur, for the speed with which you have dealt with this issue. It will undoubtedly allow us to release the funds to Kosovo quickly and address the concerns that both Mr. Swoboda and Ms. Pack have raised. In tonight's debate, I believe I can discern three fundamental types of concern. First, although much progress has been made, and we could refer to customs administration, banking administration, and tax administration, it is true that we must move forward. Move forward to finance what? There we have the first point of some disagreement. In some of your amendments, you propose that the types of entities eligible for EU funding be more limited. For example, in Amendments 3 and 5.

This is certainly the best boost we can give to democracy in Europe. If, in this way, we abandon the culture of the 1950s and embark on the new century, we will be able to say that we have had a very fine time. Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Michiel Van Hulten on his first report. It was a real hazing, but, as popular wisdom says, the best way to learn to swim is to jump right in. Dear colleague, after such an ordeal, I think you can qualify for the Olympic Games! In my opinion, two points deserve the particular attention of my group. First, there is the individual responsibility of Commissioners. This point must be settled at the Intergovernmental Conference. We certainly do not want this important issue to be left entirely to the discretion of the Council. We have therefore tabled an amendment asking whether it would not be possible to reach an agreement between the Commission and Parliament so that we have a kind of retirement position rather than leaving our fate in the hands of the Council. The second point, which my colleague, Mr Mulder, has already mentioned, is that, according to the European Liberal, Democratic and Reform Party, Parliament should also be scrutinised by independent experts. This would go a long way towards restoring the confidence of European citizens in our institution. We can only be both a credible opponent and a credible partner of the reformed Commission if we acknowledge our wrongdoings and put our house in order within the European Parliament. Only by reforming all the European institutions will we achieve the democratic, dynamic and transparent Europe that our citizens deserve. Mr President, I too would like to congratulate my colleague, Mr van Hulten, on the first piece of work he is presenting to the House. I am convinced that this will serve him, among other things, to make his second report more flexible and to seek greater consensus among the different groups. The process of reforming the Commission, which citizens are demanding, cannot now be postponed. This Parliament has heard on numerous occasions, including from Commission presidents, the desire for reform. Now it seems that this is becoming more serious. After the resignation of a Commission and the highlighting of an almost unlimited number of shortcomings by a committee of experts, Mr Prodi's promise on 14 September to present a comprehensive reform plan to this House by February is logical. Parliament is anxiously awaiting this comprehensive reform program. The report we are now debating attempts to give political force to many of the recommendations of the committee of experts appointed by this Parliament. Mr. Prodi stated that he would act in any case, that he would of course prefer to succeed, but that the fear of not achieving his goal would not prevent him from acting. Therefore, we ask that his program be courageous, because, if it is, I can assure him that Parliament will be on the Commission's side in this reform process.

Mr. President, I too would like to begin by thanking Corrie for her excellent report, which, in my opinion, adequately describes and summarizes the work carried out at the ACP-EU Joint Assembly in 1999. My time is short, and I want to address two issues. The first concerns the fight against poverty, which, in my opinion, is beginning to become an embarrassing story for both the EU and the Member States. Despite our commitments, both in the Treaty and at the UN meetings in Rio and Copenhagen, to work to end poverty, in reality, cuts are being made to development aid budgets, contrary to what has been said to be done. This trend must be halted. We must start by canceling debts. We must start putting action behind words. I would like us to play a major role in this work. The other issue is that, on many occasions, we say that the ACP countries must learn the fundamentals of democracy. Points 2 and 3 of the resolution call for the development and improvement of working methods within the framework of the new convention. ACP countries will be urged to allow many political parties to express their views. In my opinion, this is very good, and I fully support it. However, we must also ask ourselves how we ourselves understand democracy. How does it work in the European Parliament's Delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Assembly? Contrary to how things work here in the European Parliament and in parliamentary committees, where rapporteurs are proposed and appointed for reports, there are no rules in this Delegation to the Joint Assembly. The two main groups share all the reports between them. To change this undemocratic situation, the Greens/European Free Alliance (ALE) Group has tabled Amendment 6. In it, we call for the rapporteurs of general reports and reports, in addition to the members of working groups, to be appointed according to clear and democratic rules. In this context, we must take into account the small groups and their representativeness. Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Mr. Corrie on the quality of his report, which accurately reflects the content of the debates in the Joint Assembly, whose Co-Chairman he effectively assumed. The eradication of poverty has been the central theme of our work, and to achieve this ambitious goal, many speakers drew attention to the need to preserve a fundamental tool: I am referring to the preferential agreements between the European Union and the ACP countries, within the framework of the Lomé Conventions. This was a considerable challenge. Globalization, trade liberalization, as well as the preeminence of the WTO and the globalist philosophy it embodies, threatened the very essence of North-South dialogue.

We must put an end to the cascade of irresponsibility, irresponsible charterers, untraceable shipowners, and complacent certification societies at all costs. However, today we are immersed in the greatest confusion. These issues must be addressed—it is abundantly clear—at the global level, but the current IMO international standards are highly inadequate and much more lax, and neither our countries nor the Community have made any effort to make them more rigorous, despite recent catastrophes. It is true that the International Oil Pollution Fund (IOPF) exists, but it dilutes responsibilities and its level of requirements is totally inadequate, and it must be reviewed. The issue of flags of convenience within the IMO framework must be reviewed urgently. It is up to the Member States and the Community to take the necessary initiatives to this end. I must recall that the Erika flew the flag of convenience of a candidate State for accession to the Union. On the other hand, Community directives exist, but they are not implemented or are poorly implemented due to a lack of sufficient national controllers. This shortcoming must be remedied urgently. A directive on maritime safety has been in preparation for many years, but it is moving very slowly. From this perspective, there is unacceptable inertia and an unacceptable shortcoming on the part of the Commission. The date for presenting the Commission communication on this essential issue, perpetually postponed and now scheduled for July, must be brought forward. As for the substantive provisions to be established, they must be particularly clear and strict. I will mention three that our group considers to be priorities. First, the liability of oil cargo owners must be clearly established, and victims of pollution must be able to unambiguously bring legal action against those responsible. The best prevention for the future is for charterers to know that if they are not extraordinarily vigilant about the safety of the vessels they choose, they will receive severe civil, criminal, and financial penalties. Secondly, the requirement for double hulls for oil tankers allowed to sail in Community waters must be imposed as quickly as possible and should not be left to the Greek calends. Thirdly, a strict age limit for vessels allowed to sail in Community waters must be quickly established. This could be fifteen years at most. If a sufficiently clear, strict, and rigorous Community regulatory framework is not available, Member States that wish to do so should be authorized to do so in order to protect their populations and their territories, just as the United States has been able to draw on the lessons of the Exxon Valdez disaster by requiring double hulls and closing its waters to all vessels over twenty years old. Thus, the United States denied the Erika access to its waters. Had the Community done the same, a huge catastrophe would have been avoided.

In the Commission's view, the Convention responsible for drawing up the Charter of Fundamental Rights must take into account the terms of reference set for it by the Cologne European Council. This does not mean, however, that the Convention should limit itself to a mere codifying function consisting in bringing together rights already existing in various sources. As I have already had occasion to state before this Parliament, the Commission is convinced that the Convention must, where appropriate, be able to adapt and develop these rights in the light of current circumstances, particularly technical and social developments. However, given the mandate and ultimate purpose of the text to be submitted to the Heads of State or Government, this option must be used with caution and only on a case-by-case basis. The rights conferred by this Charter apply to at least two categories of persons. Some are for the benefit of all persons residing in the Union, while others are reserved for Union citizens. It is also conceivable that certain economic and social rights might be granted only to Union citizens and, under certain conditions, to nationals of third countries. At this stage, when the process of drafting the Charter is still in its early stages, it is premature to consider its content in detail. What is certain, however, is that the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women will certainly be among the rights guaranteed by the future Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, since it is already enshrined in the EU Treaty and secondary legislation and is undoubtedly part of the constitutional traditions common to the Member States. As I have also already stated before this Parliament, the Commission is in favour of incorporating this Charter into the Treaty. However, it is aware that the final decision on this matter rests with the Heads of State or Government. The Convention's task, therefore, is not easy, to draw up an ambitious and politically significant text that can be readily incorporated into the Treaties. In its opinion on the convening of an Intergovernmental Conference to amend the Treaties, the Commission points out that the European Council will have to decide in the course of 2000 on the inclusion of certain subjects on the agenda of the Intergovernmental Conference, in particular the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Commissioner, it is of the utmost importance that, at the beginning of this new century, the citizens of Europe, men and women, are called upon to redefine their rights and responsibilities. We hope that the important decision of the Cologne Council will truly be given effect to. Globalization, on the one hand, and enlargement, on the other, only make the enshrinement of these rights all the more urgent. Seattle has provided an opportunity for serious reflection on many related issues, and we hope that the Nice European Council will not be in vain. However, in order to ensure the participation of citizens in this new project, we would like to know what plan the European institutions, and specifically the European Commission, are proposing for the social and democratic model of Europe in the 21st century. Having heard something of your general approach, I would now like to ask you what place children, as autonomous individuals, have in the European Commission's project for a new model of society for the 21st century. Mr President, Madam Members of Parliament, I must state quite clearly that, in my opinion and in line with what President Prodi said this morning, the drafting of the Charter is a politically very significant process because it demonstrates that the Union places the fundamental rights of its citizens above all other political concerns for the future of our common project.

At that time, reflecting the widespread outcry over the disastrous consequences of this disaster, the Council expressed its concern about the safety of oil tankers and the associated environmental protection. The Council was not insensitive to these types of issues and the need to take further action in this area. The importance for the Council of taking further action at Community level, and in its own work with international organizations, was emphasized at the time. As you know, as it currently stands, Community legislation requires port authorities to carry out inspections on board all foreign vessels, including those flying flags of convenience, and to detain them if they fail to meet international standards. There is a 1995 directive on this subject. Looking to the future, the Council noted that the reflection process currently underway at Commission level should soon result in a communication on oil tanker safety and new proposals aimed at strengthening controls and the qualifications of inspection bodies. It is also planned to strengthen the structures of oil tankers using Community ports. These matters are being monitored by the Council of Transport Ministers, and I can assure you, on behalf of the Council, that we will, in all likelihood, give the highest priority to the proposals that the Commission will present in this area. This seems essential to us in terms of environmental protection. Of course, Parliament will also be called upon to express its opinion on these proposals, given that these are matters subject to codecision. I am pleased that the Council is reflecting on this issue. The President of the Council comes from a country, Portugal, which is directly threatened by a situation of this kind. If we think too hard, by next summer, an oil tanker subjected to such conditions could very well sink off the coast of the Algarve, destroying the Portuguese summer tourist industry and, with a bit of luck, the sea currents could carry this pollution as far as the island of Madeira - because they follow that direction - and, moreover, also destroy tourism in the Canary Islands. Does the President-in-Office of the Council not believe that we should stop thinking and start taking drastic measures in this matter, bearing in mind that today we already have the necessary means to control this type of oil tanker on the high seas? In any case, the story of the Erika is one that seems comical. A French ship, flying the Maltese flag, with an Indian crew, with a navigation certificate issued by Italy, in Sicily, and whose last inspection was, I believe, carried out in Bulgaria. The ship was sinking, the captain saw it clearly and knew that it would not even reach the nearest port. I believe this should not be allowed. The damage could be catastrophic for your country, Mr. President, and for mine too, Spain.

This type of procedure is common practice because programmes or legislative measures are too often endowed with inadequate funding for their ambitions! Böge report (A5-0023/2000) As a Member of the European Parliament, and above all as a citizen-consumer, I welcome the European Commission's proposal, which marks a further step towards improving food safety in the European Union. The proposal is twofold: firstly, it involves amending the 1991 Council Directive on health policy conditions by deleting the provisions relating to scrapie, and secondly, it involves establishing a new regulation laying down provisions for the prevention and control of certain transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) or BSE-type diseases affecting sheep and other animal species. The positive aspect of the new legislation is that it creates a specific legal basis for the control of scrapie. I am even more pleased as this was one of the main requests contained in the monitoring and evaluation report following the mad cow disease crisis. I also believe it is essential, in the interests of consistency, to merge the existing legislation on trot disease, limited to trade in sheep and goats, into a single mechanism complete with new provisions regulating TSEs affecting all animals in the European Union as a whole, with the aim of preventing the consumption of food products or animal feed. Such regulation is also appropriate because doubts remain about trot disease in sheep. According to some scientific hypotheses, this disease may have evolved to the point of mutating into BSE in cattle and thus be the cause of the BSE epizootic. Beyond the clarifications and strengthening that are necessary, in particular with regard to the identification and control of scrapie, the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down provisions for the prevention and control of certain TSEs represents a significant improvement. It is a guarantee for European citizens who have repeatedly expressed their concerns about European food policy, concerns which, taken up by the European Parliament, have been listened to. The discussions on the precautionary principle, traceability, responsibility and transparency have led the European Commission to present a White Paper on food safety, which offers various points for reflection and in particular has proposed the creation of an independent European Food Authority. All this is part of a European strategy aimed at regaining consumer confidence. It is up to us as European leaders to demonstrate that the single market and the free movement of goods can be combined with food safety! Cederschiöld report (A5-0008/2000) Mr President, I voted in favour of this measure on the reorganisation of legislation on copyright because I believe that this is one of the most important areas in which the European Parliament operates. I am of the opinion that the product of the intellect is much more important than buildings, than tangible products, which we can see and touch, while from intellect and science, which cannot be touched with our hands, come results of great importance that we, as the European Community, should support much more actively, not only through the protection of patents but by granting concessions and support to scientists, to those who - taking advantage of the teachings received - work to give future generations something much more important than what we have had in the past.

For this reason, we support Amendments 78 and 79, which outline minimum secure standards on wiretapping and videoconferencing. On the one hand, we are eagerly awaiting the outcome of this vote in order to prevent this entire agreement—which, I repeat, already establishes minimum standards—from being emptied of any content. On the other hand, we are in favor of awaiting any proposals that may come from the Commission so that this minimum Community law can finally be drawn up. Mr. President, there is no doubt that, in the face of the growing phenomenon of organized crime on an international scale, Member States should cooperate with each other as much as possible, or rather, the institutional conditions should be established to launch a concrete and effective process of cooperation in the judicial field. A process that, however, must go through all the necessary stages to avoid untimely overriding of legitimate national indications in matters of justice, over which Member States are sovereign, and above all to avoid overriding of measures that end up disregarding the fundamental rights of citizens. Consequently, it is necessary to proceed with caution with a text like the Council's, which, as the rapporteur has also emphasized, after years of debate, now seeks to resolve everything in a very few months. Furthermore—and I share Mr. Di Pietro's assessments—the Council's text even seems too rich in contradictions, incoherent wording, and gaps. Obviously, justice, more than any other sector, cannot be treated in an incoherent and contradictory manner. In our group's opinion, the report as a whole also seems highly questionable, despite the introduction of some corrective amendments sensitive to the protection of personal freedoms and respect for national sovereignty. The report addresses overly heterogeneous subjects, lacks gradation, and proceeds by approximation. In conclusion, we will vote against this report, reiterating that the Europe we desire must be a Europe of rights and guarantees: rights and guarantees that require gradual and responsible reflection, as well as very serious in-depth analysis. First, we must establish the general rules and institutional certainties, and only then can we proceed to the establishment of practical agreements. Mr. President, on behalf of the Members of the Bonino List, I wish to confirm the position we held in the Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Home Affairs, and consequently, I also announce the vote on behalf of our Members: a vote against this report, or rather, a vote against the Convention on which the report is based. Nevertheless, I would like to thank and commend the rapporteur for his work, who listened very carefully to what we discussed in committee, particularly regarding the issue of the right to a defense, both at the national level and in the area of European legal assistance cooperation in criminal matters. The committee and the rapporteur have accepted nine of the eleven amendments we tabled, which are based specifically on the right to a defense.

I have not yet heard of any arguments suggesting that the Commission should extend this deadline. Secondly, we maintain regular contact with the Swedish government. I can inform Mr. Andersson that I will travel to Stockholm on Monday, March 6, to hold talks with Minister Ringholm, with members of the Swedish Parliament, and possibly also with the Prime Minister or other ministers, to further discuss this matter, which—I am fully aware of this—is of enormous political interest in Sweden. Thirdly, I naturally understand the importance of the health aspect in this regard. I would like to reiterate that, according to Professor Lindgren of Lund University, alcohol consumption in Sweden will remain constant, whatever the outcome of import restrictions. Then, of course, the question arises as to where the quantities of alcohol not imported by travelers come from. The answer is that this alcohol is smuggled or produced by the Swedes themselves. I need not point out to you, Mr. Andersson, how extremely dangerous and harmful this process is. Well then, Mr. Andersson obviously thinks that health will improve if we restrict alcohol imports. In that case, not only Sweden, but all countries in the European Union would have to start from the principle of banning all sales of alcohol. The United States has set an example of this. Mr. Andersson will be familiar with what was then called prohibition. And he also knows how it affected mafia activities in the United States, where the prohibition was eventually repealed. All I'm saying is that health must, of course, be protected, but not with an alcohol ban, because that achieves nothing. Mr. President, the reality is that it's about the revenue from the Swedish alcohol monopoly, and when the Swedish government says it has to use it to cover health costs, that is proof that it is a distortion of competition, because other countries have to finance their own health costs without having an alcohol monopoly. My question is whether you are aware of any studies that show that moderate consumption of high-quality alcohol, such as Franconian wine or Bavarian beer, is actually beneficial to health and would therefore even ease the burden on the Swedish state budget. If I understood Mr. Posselt correctly, he is referring to the fiscal aspects of this matter. As far as I know, the high taxes on alcoholic beverages in Sweden date back to 1638, and since then, the state has derived a significant portion of its tax revenue from the sale of alcoholic beverages. As is well known, Sweden currently holds a state monopoly, which in itself is not in compliance with EU law. Now, as far as the healing effects of alcohol are concerned—which, I believe, is what Mr. Posselt was talking about—I can wholeheartedly agree with him: In my opinion, a good bottle of wine can be extremely beneficial to health and, in company, can also certainly lift one's spirits. Perhaps Mr Posselt, Mr Andersson and myself can meet at the Parliament bar for a glass of aquavit in the next few days.

These are the consequences! Therefore, we can only call on the Commission to continue its appeasing efforts and to pay tribute to those who are committed to preserving the independence and sovereignty of the Austrian people and are doing everything possible to ensure that this people remains free and continues to show solidarity with other peoples. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate is marked by hypocrisy: the Council is disregarding the Treaty and is applying a procedure that is absolutely not covered by Articles 6 and 7, which allow a country to be condemned in the event of serious and repeated violations. In the present case, there are no serious and repeated violations by Austria. There are risks—we are all aware of this—but at present there are absolutely no violations, neither serious nor repeated. If the criteria of Articles 6 and 7, the Copenhagen criteria—which the countries of Eastern Europe are required to comply with—were applied to our institutions, to the European Union, then this European Union would almost certainly not be able to become a member. When it comes to serious and repeated violations, perhaps we should mention specific Member States such as Italy and France, the country most and third most frequently condemned by the Council of Europe and the Strasbourg Court, respectively. We should, dear colleagues from Belgium, speak of the Dutroux affair, of the many children who have been kidnapped, abused, raped, and murdered by prominent figures in that country, and of the relevant proceedings that produce no results and always fizzle out. Dear colleagues, with a third of the Members of Parliament, we could force the Council and the Commission to address this. We could ask ourselves why the Austrians are resisting a party rule that has corrupted and depraved their country for ten or thirteen years, but which is also depraving and driving Italy, Belgium, and other member states of the Union into corruption. We should really be asking ourselves, ladies and gentlemen, why 76% of Belgians have absolutely no confidence in their country's justice system, why 56% of French people have absolutely no confidence in their justice system, why 53% of Italians have absolutely no confidence in their justice system... (The President cut off the speaker.) Madam President, my group, the EDD, and my party in particular, are deeply affected by this debate. We cannot and do not support Mr Haider's views and policies in any way. We deplore his references to the Third Reich. But we also deplore the fact that Parliament intends to interfere in the policies of an elected government of a country, especially when that country is part of the European Union. My party at home is certainly not racist, but we do not particularly like the European Union dictating to us or interfering either. Will you interfere in the British Parliament if we are elected? Madam President, the Austrian people voted and elected Mr Haider to their Parliament. I believe Mr Haider received 28% of the vote, so there will be a coalition government.

We not only regret the events in Austria, we are upset and deeply disappointed. We call on the ÖVP to ultimately consider other solutions. We repeatedly return to Article 6 of the Treaty. We continue to fight against the trivialization of the extreme right. Should the coalition nevertheless come into being, we appeal to our colleagues in the ÖVP to guarantee, both in their programs and in word and deed, respect for the principles and values that form the foundation of European integration. Austria faces a great responsibility. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is obvious that we in this Parliament largely agree in our rejection of Haider and his policies, but it is equally clear that we have different views on how these policies can be most effectively combated. Have you ever asked yourself what impact this debate here and the Council Presidency's statement last weekend are having in Austria itself? Have you ever asked yourselves whether we are not also responsible for how the political situation in Austria develops if we presume to judge it here? Have you ever asked yourself what would happen if a colleague's wish were granted and elections were held in Austria in the next few days? According to all observers, Haider would become even stronger. Who could want that? Don't we have a responsibility to consider how we combat this policy?
