Europe is a community based on the rule of law. The principles we must uphold include democracy, respect for human rights, and the rule of law. Part of the democratic precept is that one may not approve of electoral decisions but must respect them, and therefore we must respect them when Austrians decide the way they do for reasons inherent in their politics. It is a matter of the rule of law that the Council Presidency does not express itself in the way it did, in a way that contradicts the treaties. It is a matter of political wisdom not to isolate the ÖVP, but rather to support the ÖVP, as an undoubtedly democratic, constitutional, and clearly European party, in ensuring that Austria remains just as undoubtedly a member of this European Community. Therefore, our ÖVP colleagues must have our support in this difficult situation, and isolation is absolutely the wrong approach! (Applause) Madam President, at home, we say, "a Welshman needs three attempts," and three times, as you will have noticed in the course of this debate, I have expressed the wish to briefly address this excellent and at times moving debate. First of all, on behalf of President Prodi and my colleagues in the Commission, I would like to thank a number of Members of this House for the support and understanding that a number of Members of this House have shown for the Commission's position, which we expressed in our statement yesterday. I must, of course, also respond to the fact that during the debate—and I will resort to some of the terms used—there has been talk of the Commission's ambiguity, complacency, and cautious behavior.

Food safety therefore requires complete transparency for producers and consumers. I am convinced that the Commission will be able to follow the path indicated by the rapporteur, who, let us not forget, obtained unanimity in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Mr President, since the time of BSE, it has been repeated in this House that animal feed is one of the fundamental elements for safe food production, for safeguarding health and protecting consumers. We therefore welcome the proposal presented by the Commission on additives for animal feed. The committee on whose behalf I speak, namely the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, on the assumption that the chairman of the Committee on Agriculture in his capacity as rapporteur would have produced an excellent report, decided in December to withdraw its opinion. Nevertheless, I would like to make a few comments and take a position on a few points. Firstly, on the question of the legal basis. Even though we have a new regulation in this Parliament - and it may well be that, given the ambitions of the Chairman of the Committee on Agriculture, there will increasingly be problems of competence in legislative matters between the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on the Environment - in cases of conflict of this kind, I believe that one thing must always be borne in mind: the cohesion of this Parliament is decisive and the legal basis is, in my view, fundamental. Therefore - and I cannot help but reiterate, Commissioner Byrne - I condemn the choice of legal basis. Even though it is only a legal basis taken from previous directives, it is a mistake to retain it. The Treaty of Amsterdam is extremely clear on this point: if human health is involved, the legal basis to be chosen is Article 152. I must point out to the Legal Affairs Committee of this Parliament that it is not enough to examine the Commission's proposal and note that health and consumer protection are not mentioned. Therefore, the political group to which I belong - as Mr Kindermann has already said - will vote in favour of the change of legal basis tomorrow and I hope that the other political groups will do the same. Commissioner Byrne, for the sake of transparency and positive cooperation, I urge you to welcome and approve the change of legal basis. Otherwise, if we follow the indications of the Legal Affairs Committee, we will be opening the door to manipulation. By leaving the choice of legal basis to the Commission on the basis of the fact that health protection policy is not mentioned in the text, Article 37 has been used. Allow me to briefly touch on two more points. As regards genetically modified microorganisms in feed, I think it is unacceptable to refer to vertical legislation and say that sooner or later other rules will be needed. At the moment we do not have them! Therefore, in the absence of different legislation, every time we approve rules we must also deal with genetically modified organisms, mention them expressly and insist that they are declared on the label. This is what the rapporteur did and it is a positive indication.

On the other hand, if the new round of negotiations of the World Trade Organisation were to begin during the Portuguese Presidency - which is not at all certain - we will of course ensure that the presence of Community production on international markets is consolidated and that there is a greater balance between Community agricultural exports and the preservation of the multifunctional European agriculture I have just mentioned. The Portuguese Presidency will also attach great importance to the deepening of food safety policy and I think that the Portuguese Minister for Foreign Affairs, and President-in-Office of the Council of the European Union, has already referred to this aspect here this morning. The role of food safety, insofar as it is linked in particular to public health, is a fundamental element that our Presidency must develop and is, moreover, one of the priorities of our programme. We will develop it along four parallel lines, within the "Consumer Protection" Council and the "Internal Market" Council. The Portuguese Presidency will present a report on this matter to the European Council in Santa Maria da Feira, which will be held in June this year, particularly in the light of what the Commission set out a few days ago in its White Paper. We believe that the work to be done on this basis for the establishment of a European agency is essential to give credibility to the internal market, to consolidate confidence in this market, to resolve some of the tensions that have arisen between Member States in this area and also - why not say it - to define a common attitude of the European Union in relations with third countries in areas that are linked to food safety. This is the objective that we intend to achieve during the Portuguese Presidency and we hope, in the end, to be able to present the result of our efforts to this House. I thank the President-in-Office for his response. I am sure that he is aware of the very serious threat posed to the European model based on family farms, especially for farmers in the beef and sheep meat sector who should now sell their products at prices equal to or lower than production costs. I would like to ask what new initiatives the Council can take to safeguard their interests in the upcoming world trade talks, in particular against the type of production practised on ranches and farms in the United States and New Zealand, where economies of scale make it extremely difficult for European farmers to compete with the production methods applied on their farms, and where, of course, European food safety standards are not applied. I fully understand your concerns and I realise how much more effort and more coherence is needed in this respect, including within the European Union. We also need to think about the consequences, especially in terms of financing and compensation for farmers. However, as you know, this is a matter for the European Commission and it will be up to the Commission to take it forward. The Council has limited capacity to intervene in this area. Mr President, I too would like to welcome the President-in-Office of the Council to the Chamber.

Commissioner: Andalusia is not Lapland. I would like to hear the Commissioner's opinion on Amendment 45. It may have slipped my mind when she announced the list. (EN) I accept the amendment. Thank you very much, Mrs. Wallström. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday at 11:30. Financial instrument for the environment (Life) The next item is the debate on the recommendation for second reading (A4-0014/2000), on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, concerning the common position adopted by the Council with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the financial instrument for the environment (Life) (Rapporteur: Mrs. Lienemann). (FR) Mr. President, we have already had the opportunity to examine that report at first reading, and in committee I understood that there was a broad consensus within this House. LIFE is the only budget line for direct intervention in environmental matters included in the Community budget, and it must be acknowledged that it falls short of our ambitions, as the amounts allocated to it have remained frozen for several years. Despite the increase that took place when we renewed the first LIFE program to move to the second, the appropriations were maintained as they were. It turns out that, increasingly, regions, various operators, companies, and associations are submitting LIFE projects for both LIFE-NATURE and LIFE-ENVIRONMENT. These projects are of very high quality, as, after being submitted to the relevant committees, they all agree that they would merit European Union support, yet we cannot fund them due to a lack of budget allocations. We must also remember that the rate of consumption of appropriations in this budget is exceptional within the Community budget. It is therefore clear that this is a tool very well adapted to the policies we wish to pursue. I will place particular emphasis on the area of LIFE-Nature. We know that a series of directives relating to "Habitats" and "Migratory Birds" are encountering difficulties in their implementation in the European Union: with LIFE-NATURE, we should be able to support policies that demonstrate the feasibility, legitimacy, and capacity to achieve the objectives set by these directives. And we are losing that legitimacy due to a lack of funding, allowing the idea to spread that our European directives are neither reasonable nor enforceable. The debates taking place today focus on two major issues: first, comitology, a perennial debate within our Assembly. However, our Parliament wanted to implement policies that are resolved more through management committees and advisory committees, which provide a certain degree of flexibility to the Commission and limit the Council's power to block and, I would say, enforce intergovernmental philosophy over the Community philosophy of which we are guarantors here in the European Parliament. But these debates about comitology arise with respect to most of the European Union's financial programs and financial instruments. It seems to me—and the contacts we've had tend to demonstrate this—that it's easier to reconcile points of view on comitology than on the budget.

I also propose that the withdrawal of salmon showing clinical signs of the disease should be immediate. The procedures already existing in Community legislation for the introduction of additional control measures will be used to introduce the withdrawal plans; these plans will be based on the actual health conditions of the salmon in order to minimise the possible environmental impact. In this respect I accept Amendments Nos 7 and 8, the latter with a slight modification. I also support Amendment No 9, but I think it needs to be better worded to also include environmental issues and disease eradication and control strategies. I do not think I can accept Amendments Nos 12 and 13 as they seem to me to be aimed at zeroing the risk. I believe that this objective is very difficult to achieve without causing the closure of farms in the sector. I would like to know the Parliament's opinion on these amendments and whether it thinks this approach is the best way forward. I can also partially accept Amendment No 13. 11. Finally, I would like to stress that we will continue to strive to maintain a high level of public health protection in accordance with our Treaty obligations. I believe that moving forward we must propose measures in line with this objective. We will continue to work to eradicate the disease, for the benefit of both the environment and the salmon industry. I would be extremely grateful if Parliament would recognise our efforts by accepting this proposal. Thank you, Commissioner Byrne. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow at 11.00. Protection of juvenile fish The next item is the debate on report A5-0035/2000 by Mr Gallagher, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the proposal for a Council regulation amending for the fourth time Regulation (EC) No 1624/94 laying down certain technical measures for the conservation of fishery resources in the Mediterranean and amending for the fourth time Regulation (EC) No 1624/94 laying down certain technical measures for the conservation of fishery resources in the Mediterranean. 850/98 for the conservation of fishery resources through technical measures for the protection of juveniles of marine organisms (COM(1999)552 - C5-0040/2000 - 1999/0222(CNS)). The proposal under consideration, outlined in the introduction, is very important. My colleagues in the Committee on Fisheries and in Parliament know that our work on technical conservation measures is based on concrete technical advice. The institution responsible for providing this advice, based on reliable scientific evidence, is the Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). This intergovernmental fisheries organisation, of which the European Union is a member, is responsible for the conservation of tuna and tuna-like species in the Atlantic and adjacent seas, including the Mediterranean. It was established in March 1969 and, although formally required to meet every two years, it meets every year. It takes decisions based on scientific information and then makes recommendations for the conservation of fish resources. ICCAT operates through four permanent committees, made up of national experts, which deal with research and statistics, finance and administration, compliance, and conservation and management measures. There are also four working groups, which deal respectively with tropical tuna, northern temperate tuna, southern temperate tuna and other species.

While taking into account the new rules introduced by the Treaty of Amsterdam, which provide for its entry into force once at least half of the Member States have adopted the Convention, I would like to call on the Member States to do their utmost to ratify this Convention swiftly. Unfortunately, the experience of past ratifications of European Union conventions in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters is disappointing. This Convention will not create a new or different system of mutual assistance; it is intended to build on well-established and tried-and-tested mechanisms which have been in operation for a long time, such as those provided for in the 1959 Council of Europe Convention on Mutual Assistance and the Benelux Treaty. The draft drawn up by the Council contains provisions on several issues which have been discussed by many Members of the Parliament. An important achievement of the Convention is that, where possible, Member States to which a request is made comply with all formalities and procedures indicated by the requesting Member State. This is particularly important for the possibility of using the evidence obtained in court. Furthermore, requests can be made directly between competent authorities without having to go through central authorities. Generally speaking, there are two types of provisions: those which impose an obligation to offer assistance - such as the provisions on telephone and videoconferencing, controlled deliveries and the interception of telecommunications - and those which do not impose any obligation but simply establish a legal framework for Member States wishing to cooperate in the prescribed manner - for example, the provisions on joint investigation teams, covert operations and the sending and offering of procedural documents. The Commission particularly welcomes the inclusion of provisions dealing with new or modern investigative techniques, given their effectiveness in combating organised crime, which, by virtue of its location, can take advantage of open borders. It is all too easy to get carried away by the obvious need to improve the effectiveness of criminal investigations. However, we must not forget an essential aspect of any action on criminal procedures: the rights of the defence. I very much appreciate the fact that the report by Mr Di Pietro, to whom I pay tribute for the excellent work he has done in such a short time, includes defence rights among its key points. At present, it is up to the Member States alone to ensure that these rights are respected under the supervision of the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. It remains to be seen whether this will change with the new Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, the preparation of which has just begun. We must recognise that Article 18 concerns a clearly controversial decision. The article has been carefully drafted, in the course of lengthy debates in the Council, to ensure the effectiveness of intelligence activities and the inclusion of criminal investigations. As regards criminal investigations, for which I am responsible, I note the call made by several Members of the European Parliament to the Commission and the Council to consider this issue and address it on a common legal basis, given the importance that the interception of telecommunications can have as evidence before the court. The Commission is fully aware that the project before us is neither perfect nor ideal, but we must be realistic.

Additional recommendations on this approach are also contained in the second report of the Committee of Wise Men. Likewise, the Commission, through Mr Barnier and Mr Vitorino, and certain Member States are firmly in favour of it. I urge you, ladies and gentlemen, to vote in favour of this report, which was adopted by a large majority by the Committee on Budgetary Control. We can once again demonstrate that this Parliament is active in preventing mismanagement and, in particular, fraud, and in condemning it where necessary. Mr President, I am pleased to be able to speak on this report and I congratulate Mrs Theato. I believe that this is a report in which cooperation between the committees has worked very well, and the result, which we have received today, is a sober and calm report on an extremely delicate subject. Sobriety and calm are particularly necessary for the development of Article 280.4. Because if we had to award a prize to the most difficult article to understand, the least clear, the most confusing, whatever name you want to give it, the competition would undoubtedly be very fierce since the Treaty is a collection of complex articles, but it goes without saying that this article is a serious candidate for this prize. It is also a particularly delicate issue because, as Mrs Theato so rightly said, it is the protection of the Community's financial interests that is at stake. We are all aware, and this Parliament was the first to be concerned, with the need to protect the Community's financial interests. But let us be careful and, as the French say: "let's not throw the baby out with the bathwater." In other words, in the context of protecting the Community's financial interests, we must respect not only, and Mrs Theato pointed this out, the powers of the national States, but also other points that concern citizens, that concern essential guarantees. The conclusions of the Theato report fully back them up. Therefore, as Chair of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market and, of course, as an MEP, I hope that tomorrow this report will enjoy the support of Parliament, by a large majority, and that it will be properly implemented by the Commission. Mr President, as Mrs Theato said, this is a critical report. It was proposed by the Committee on Budgetary Control and it is an own-initiative report. One of the reasons why we were so keen to highlight this aspect was that the European Union, whether we like it or not, has a reputation for fraud and mismanagement, a reputation that is exaggerated, but it exists. We must do something about this situation. Some of the measures we have put in place in the past have not been respected by some Member States - let us not forget that the Member States are responsible for implementing some 80% of the EU budget.

I don't quite understand what the Commissioner said. At this point, the mudflat at Stregrennan, added to the Special Protection Area at the Commission's request, has been completely destroyed. It is clear that the activities that took place there are in flagrant violation of European directives. You say that there will be no further funding. I would like to know if you intend, at this point, to completely stop funding until a proper investigation takes place. If not, why not? If so, when exactly will you do so? Is it correct and appropriate that the department that owns the company is also the licensing authority and the one that, in the first place, receives EU funds and pays them to a company that it wholly owns? Is this right and appropriate? What is your opinion on this? All EU funding for the project must be stopped because it is in flagrant violation of EU directives. Even the area designated by the Commissioners as a Special Protection Area has been destroyed. Compensation after the fact will not repair the damage caused. The first legal challenge followed the start of the port development work in early autumn 1999, without the compensatory habitat improvements having been implemented. As a result, the Irish authorities agreed to reinstate the removal of Spartina anglica, but this time by mechanical means. The use of mechanical means brought with it an additional legal challenge—this is what I referred to in my first reply—based on the argument that mechanical removal would damage the mudflats and lead to the proliferation of environmentally harmful Spartina anglica in the estuary. To date, this legal challenge has not produced any conclusive results. The adoption of the necessary compensatory measures is a matter for the national authorities and does not require prior approval from the Commission. The Commission's role is to ensure full compliance with the standards required by the Birds Directive, and it is clear that harmful compensatory measures in themselves would be problematic. In this case, the Commission proposes to seek further clarification from the Irish authorities on the latest situation with respect to compensatory measures and the potential problems of mechanical removal of cordgrass. At this time, we are not prepared to propose the discontinuation of structural fund funding. Mr. President, the specific case raised by Ms. McKenna is unfortunately not an isolated one. There are other examples of damage caused to the conservation of Special Scientific Areas as a result of EU funding. Will the Commission consider issuing instructions to all Member States stating that if, in the future, it discovers that European environmental directives have been breached or that adequate environmental assessments have not been carried out, it will not only stop all future funding but also withdraw funds already allocated; in other words, it will demand repayment of the sums paid to the Member States? Only such a measure will discourage this practice in the future.

The right approach to the problem of speculation, in my view, is to eliminate the real causes of financial disorder, not to try to suppress only the symptoms by introducing obstacles to the functioning of the markets. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to briefly reconstruct the procedure and ideological tactics that led to this oral question, also because I know how many Social Democrats in Parliament, and not only the experts in economic and financial policy, share our criticism. We know the problem. It is instability on the markets caused by speculation. However, those who tabled the oral question should be reminded that - as the Commissioner has explained incisively - not all instability is the result of speculation. The Tobin tax could not have prevented the EEA crises of 1992 and 1993 or the South-East Asian currency crisis of 1997. The authors of the oral question do not propose any solution, but call for a new tax, more bureaucracy and a measure that is contrary to market mechanisms. They propose an intergroup assessment in the Chamber, excluding the competent parliamentary committee, in contradiction to several decisions of Parliament. This question, I say bluntly, is in my opinion ideologically motivated and does not seek solutions. I believe this is the wrong path. Why do we reject the Tobin tax and regard it with such suspicion? Firstly, as the Commissioner has already said, because it represents a heavy burden on the capital markets. Even a minimum tax would have a heavy impact on the capital markets, since such a tax on speculation would significantly reduce the profitability of investments. Furthermore, such a measure would seriously undermine the development of financial markets, by counteracting the principle of free movement of capital which is one of the core elements of the internal market. Secondly, capital invested for speculative purposes is difficult to identify. Thirdly, fiscal measures can be easily circumvented if they are not introduced with the same system in all countries, because too many loopholes remain open. Fourthly, such a measure is difficult to apply from a technical point of view and involves a high degree of bureaucracy and administrative burdens with the impossibility of effective control. The measure we should adopt is part of the resolution under consideration today. It is about strengthening banking supervision, clarifying liability for transactions, creating a regulatory framework at international level, assessing national laws in order to verify whether they comply with the Basel Committee rules and understanding how the latter can be more widely disseminated. With regard to this resolution, I have serious doubts on a fundamental point which we cannot accept in this form. I am referring to paragraph 9. From the Commissioner's intervention we deduce that the Commission's examination will end with a rejection of the Tobin tax. If this assessment, the current debate and the arguments proposed are of the tenor that has emerged and which I share, even the fact that the Commission is dealing with it for another six months with the resulting uncertainty that will have repercussions on the financial and capital markets represents a lack of responsibility.

On China, we should not abandon the issue simply because discussions on the matter might be stalled. However, it is imperative that the EU speak and act together, and threats of trade sanctions should strengthen our resolve rather than weaken it. However, if the decisions that may eventually be taken in Geneva are to have full expression, then the office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights must be given the necessary resources. UN financial resources are distributed sparingly, and as a result, many vital programs rely on voluntary contributions to survive. Resources are also needed to promote practical cooperation and human rights, strategic planning, priority setting, and strengthening communications between the donor community and UN Member States. To this end, the High Commissioner recently launched an annual appeal for US$53 million to enable her office to carry out these tasks. The European Union and its Member States should take the initiative and contribute significantly to the provision of these funds. In doing so, not only would we embarrass the United States, which should assume its responsibilities with regard to the financing of the United Nations, but we would also demonstrate that our commitment to the defence of human rights is more than just rhetoric. Mr President, this debate is primarily about the preparations for the upcoming annual UN Human Rights Assembly and the efforts of the Commission and the Council on this occasion. I must say first of all that I am very pleased with the contribution made so far by Mr Patten and the Minister, and I also think it is good that China and Cuba are also being discussed. Cuba remains the last dictatorship in South America and we should not forget that, despite all the sympathy that some here and there may feel for Cuba. This is a dictatorship and therefore not a democracy. In the two minutes allotted to me, I ask for your attention to focus on two countries to which I feel particularly attached. The first is Indonesia. We are obviously very pleased that Indonesia now has a new government and that Mr. Wahid and Mrs. Sukarnoputri are respectively President and Vice-President. We are also pleased that the situation in Timor is slowly moving in the right direction. I would like to point out, however, that in the Moluccas, an archipelago just north of Timor, the violence is still not under control. Thousands have died there over the past two years. Tens of thousands have fled. The situation is not well under control. I know that tomorrow or the day after there will be a whole programme on Dutch television devoted to this, and that people are asking there for observers to be sent to the region so that they can see exactly what is happening there, so that the facts can at least be recorded, especially for later on when human rights commissions can go there. My urgent request is this, and it is a point that has been mentioned several times in resolutions: can you not consider sending observers to the Moluccas?

We make a positive overall assessment of NATO's intervention and share the view of NATO's actions. Regarding the political prisoners in Serbia, it is clear, Your Honor, that when I refer to the fact that Mr. Milosevic in that country today does not behave in accordance with the standards of a decent society on the international level, I am referring not only to what Mr. Milosevic does to his fellow citizens, but also to the situations he maintains, particularly regarding political prisoners, attacks on democratic rights, the opposition's right of access to the media, and the facilities that should be granted to non-governmental organizations to operate, particularly in the area of defending human rights. However, all this is only one of the many aspects of Mr. Milosevic's extremely pernicious actions within Yugoslav society, and the European Union naturally cannot but be concerned about this situation. For this reason, as long as Yugoslavia does not behave internationally in a way that meets the values that, in our opinion, we must defend, it will maintain all sanctions. Question No. 7 by (H-0035/00): Subject: Drafting of the Charter of Fundamental Rights Expressing civil society's satisfaction with the drafting of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, but also the hope that it will respond to the challenges facing Europe in the 21st century, the Council is asked to reply to the following: What is its opinion on the content of the Charter? Which citizens does it refer to (those of the European Union or of all European countries; will it include citizens of the enlargement and immigrants, etc.)? Will it reflect the European Union's acquis communautaire, or will it have a broader programmatic nature? What mechanisms will it use to clearly establish gender equality? What is the Council's view of incorporating the Charter into the Treaty on European Union? I thank the President-in-Office for his presentation of the problems and for the reassurances he has given me about the progress of the work. You understand, Mr. President-in-Office, that my question is not without meaning, since the Council is a political body of the European Union, and European citizens, men and women, want to know your vision of the democratic and social model of 21st-century Europe. I would like, additionally, to ask whether the Portuguese Presidency has planned for the inclusion of children's rights, as autonomous entities, in the issues to be addressed and in the rights that will be incorporated into the Charter. As I have said, we do not control, Your Honor, the process of drafting the Charter of Fundamental Rights. This matter is a matter for the members of that group, who will not refer it to the Council until there is consensus on the content of the Charter.

In this regard, I would like to thank the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism for accepting one of my amendments to add the EDF to the list of these Funds. The outermost regions, in particular the four French overseas departments, must be able to coordinate INTERREG III and the EDF so that they too can finance cooperation projects with their ACP neighbours in their respective geographical areas. I would also ask the Commission to reconsider the limited opportunities offered to the outermost and island regions on the basis of the guidelines presented in the communication. These regions must be able to benefit fully from INTERREG III, like the other regions of the Union, especially since the REGIS programme intended for them has been abandoned. Finally, I would like to express my regret at the limited financial allocation for strand C, intended for interregional cooperation, whose Community added value is nevertheless undeniable. Mr President, I am speaking on the EQUAL report and on the issue of equal opportunities for men and women, although I must admit that it is sometimes cumbersome and tedious to talk about a trite and hackneyed topic like this, especially for someone my age. However, it is necessary to reiterate once again that equality does not exist. Perhaps a breakthrough in this area could lead to changes in other areas. For me, equality does not mean that the two spouses work all the time and leave the children with a babysitter, that is, an immigrant, who has not managed to find another job. That is not a big step forward compared to the times of the Sun King: no, equality means that everyone participates in family and working life. Unfortunately, trends are not going in this direction, but in the opposite direction. It therefore seems to me that point 7 contains a decidedly central element: "The EQUAL initiative will be used as a laboratory to develop and promote new methods of implementing employment policies". Let us hope it can work. Mr President, I would just like to say, for the record, that if I am not in the Chamber when the Committee responds - not that I have asked specific questions, but I hope that the Committee has listened to my speech - it will be because at the same time as the debate in the Chamber there is a meeting of the Committee on Women's Rights and Equal Opportunities on the issue of women in decision-making. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, those who deal with rural areas know that the LEADER programmes, both LEADER I and LEADER II - and I hope the same will also be true for LEADER+ - are among the flattering results achieved by the European Union with its programmes. This success is also due to the strong participation that the basic concept of the LEADER programmes has aroused among the population involved in the activities. I am pleased that this same approach has also been followed for LEADER+. However, there is one problem that we must address together. Since LEADER acts as a laboratory, with a bottom-up approach, an extraordinary number of ideas have developed in recent years within LEADER I and II which, of course, in the long run no longer turn out to be so new or particularly effective.

Reconciling the two objectives is not easy. It does not happen automatically. There may be certain contradictions between the two, and there is no indication that the Commission has identified these contradictions or suggested ways of overcoming them. As for the other side of the agenda, Mr President of the Commission, namely cohesion and regional development, we have certainly made considerable achievements in this area. However, there are also lagging regions, particularly island regions, to which more attention should be paid. With regard to fisheries, there is nothing in your programme to suggest that any lessons for the future have been learned from the devastating overfishing that has led to the disappearance of entire species. In these matters, perhaps greater vigilance and more esprit de finesse are needed. Madam President, first of all, I would like to reiterate the cautionary words expressed by many of my colleagues with regard to this five-year programme. Despite ambitious long-term goals, we must not lose sight of the present. The leader of my group, Mr. Poettering, emphasized this very emphatically in his opening speech. The Union must not take on a whole range of new tasks without having a successful European economy as a basic prerequisite. This prerequisite is clearly the internal market. And what is the current state of development of the internal market? I would like to remind Mr. Prodi and his colleagues, who are still here, of the results of the Commission's own study of 3,000 European companies. Almost 40% of them state that measures to comply with national regulations for their products and services entail additional costs for them. This is what the Commission itself stated in its study. These are classic symptoms of the continued obstruction by national governments – bureaucracy that prevents market entry. The Commission's program displays a worrying complacency when it comes to completing the internal market. We must work persistently to remove further barriers in all areas, increase pressure on Member States that are failing to implement the necessary measures to complete the internal market, and include crucial new areas such as financial services. Only with an internal market as a solid foundation can we successfully enlarge the Union. An enlarged Europe must build on the Union's existing strengths. Extending the internal market to an enlarged Union should be an achievement of tremendous proportions. Finally, on behalf of all my Conservative colleagues—and we are the second largest national delegation in this Parliament—let me assure you that we will fully support the Commission and Mr Prodi in carrying out this historic task. Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, Commissioner, Commissioners, dear colleagues, Let me begin with a quote: "The Commission will continue the preparatory work on a European Charter of Fundamental Rights and will put forward proposals for the implementation of an ambitious program. In particular, the Commission will propose the development of a genuine European asylum and immigration policy, and it advocates strengthening mutual legal assistance and judicial cooperation and developing an effective approach to combating all forms of crime." That is the entire program for the next five years on internal security, freedoms, citizens' rights, and judicial cooperation.

Its funds have been invested in one of the most deprived neighborhoods in the United Kingdom, Moss Side. The Millennium Youth Park project is helping young people reengage in the rehabilitation of their own community, and in addition to helping small businesses and supporting social policy, we are beginning to see the restoration of a very depressed urban community. The activities carried out within the framework of the URBAN initiative have been raised among the general public through an active advertising campaign in local supermarkets and well-known British pubs. This is the kind of good practice that should be replicated throughout the EU in terms of communication and advertising. The specific guidelines governing this initiative have been broadly defined to accommodate local and regional diversity. We agree that they should be indicative in nature, allowing maximum flexibility to ensure we focus on specific programs. In committee, we do not favor reducing their number to 50. We support an overall reduction, but we believe that the arbitrary figure of 50 is not the key factor. Instead, we should focus on high-quality projects that act as a catalyst for change and renewal, attract inward investment in the form of loans and venture capital, and achieve a multiplier effect. Member States should be able to propose a reasonable number of measures that do not exceed the financial limits of their allocations. We need to make good use of local indicators and statistics on deprivation and hygiene when designating local URBAN programs so that we can effectively focus on the most affected areas. The UK's Local Deprivation Index is a very good example of a statistic and a widely used criterion that contributes to establishing not only EU aid programs, but also regional and national ones. We should recognize this index as an instrument and resource to complement EU criteria. I urge you to take ownership of local indicators to achieve this. The most deprived urban neighborhoods face numerous problems: high unemployment rates, precarious and often poorly paid employment, poverty, and social exclusion. Lack of hygiene, poor housing, and an environment of drug addiction often exacerbate these problems. As a result, unstable communities emerge, where crime, drug trafficking, and gangs eventually infiltrate. Many urban areas know this all too well. These complex problems worsen the quality of life of urban residents, even though these areas have the potential to create growth and prosperity. This is why I call in my report for the measures included in the URBAN programme to go beyond providing a single solution to a single problem: these areas do not have individual problems. We should encourage communities in urban areas to submit integrated action plans to address their specific urban problems, using EU resources as an added value to local measures. I would like to see these measures also include improving hygiene and combating discrimination, as mandated by the Amsterdam Treaty.

As we sit here, hundreds of thousands of people are in enormous danger from flooding in Mozambique. This did not just happen. The flooding has been going on for weeks, yet only now does the need appear to be being assessed. The level of practical assistance from the Community and Member States has been pathetic. For a long time, many of us have warned that the European Union was spending far too much time on its potentially damaging and essentially political project of establishing military decision-making structures. It should have concentrated instead on improving its civilian instruments, particularly those for humanitarian intervention. I acknowledge Mr. Patten's efforts in this direction, but what a pity that Member State governments have not spent as much time defining their capacity to provide disaster relief and humanitarian assistance as they are spending on the dangerous business of creating military structures that will ultimately duplicate and undermine NATO's capabilities. Of course, there is a link between military resources and humanitarian assistance, and there are serious military deficiencies in the armed forces of many European countries. They are not new, but NATO is already addressing them. I have not yet heard a convincing security policy explanation as to why the European Union needs to define autonomous decision-making capabilities for use by military forces outside NATO structures, unless it is to create bodies that will compete with NATO. After all, EU member states are either full members of NATO or they sit at the Euro-Atlantic Partnership Council. NATO is largely European. Finally, Mr. Solana, I would just like to ask you what the point is of having the much-heralded political planning and early warning cell within the Council Secretariat if we are surprised by yet another humanitarian catastrophe. Mr President, Mr High Representative, Mr Commissioner, regarding the war in Chechnya, we have all noted the particularly restrained and almost accommodating reaction of the international community in general, and of the European Union in particular. However, what happened, and what is still happening in Chechnya, amounts to genocide. How else can we describe the complete annihilation of a regional capital of 400,000 inhabitants, the incessant and disproportionate bombardment of towns, villages, and neighborhoods, where the entire civilian population may have been mixed with a few Chechen fighters? How can we describe the sinister filtration camps, comparable to concentration camps, in which the population suffers the worst humiliations and from which able-bodied men aged 15 to 65 rarely emerge alive? How can we describe the rapes, looting, arson, and deportations, known as "cleansing," which recall the worst episodes of the European Middle Ages? And what about the blanket of silence that has fallen over Russian and international journalists, and the banishment of humanitarian organizations and any international commission of inquiry into the sites of the massacres?

Social policy coordination and dialogue are good things, but we must avoid tarring everyone with the same brush; we must maintain a plurality of solutions. Mr President, Commissioner, with regard to the strategy outlined here, concerning the modernization of social security, I would nevertheless like to raise a few points, some positive and others in the form of a question. I find the movement that is slowly but surely spreading to the dossier to be positive. This seems good to me. It also seems useful to me. I also find the broad outlines of the communication concerning the strategic approach to be positive. We also hope that the four objectives mentioned therein can be achieved in a reasonable manner. We would also like to emphasize the interest in the way in which this dossier has been approached, on the one hand through the "Luxembourg-style" process, the guidelines, but we also believe that the interest lies in the fact that, as Mrs Van Lancker has already pointed out, directives are being put forward with regard to atypical work, self-employed workers without employees, etc. However, we foresee two problems for which solutions will have to be found. The first is that we are talking about downward adjustment of social security, where we are hoping for convergence at the same level. I would like to give some examples here from the survey recently conducted by the Dutch professional movement on social security reforms within the European Union. It emerges from this study that adjustments are taking place everywhere, but that many of these adjustments, even the majority, turn out to be downward adjustments, the rest being improvements. The vast majority of these adjustments are focused on pensions; there are eleven limitations and two improvements. For unemployment benefits, we see six limitations and five improvements. The reasons for these adjustments are, for example, the improvement of working conditions, the reduction of social security expenditure, but also policy competition and the EMU criteria. This policy competition is mainly found in the Nordic countries. The greatest stability and even improvements in social security are concentrated in the southern countries. All in all, we also observe a limited role for the social partners in this entire process. This does not seem very positive and means that the convergence strategy must be geared towards the best approaches. If I may put it this way, we do not always enjoy a cappuccino. Mr. President, I, in turn, would like to congratulate the Commission and the rapporteur. The committee because it has taken a further step towards convergence in social security, and the rapporteur for the quality of the report he has submitted. European Union policy includes, in addition to economic and employment policy, also a social policy. To date, however, this has remained limited in both intentions and means. But under the influence of the free movement of workers, the internal market, and the euro, labor markets are also integrating.

Thanks to the principle of partnership and parity, as well as parliamentary assistance through the Joint Assembly, this is a global model. It is good that in this jubilee year, which also allows us to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the cooperation initiated by the Lomé Convention, we are about to witness the conclusion of a new partnership agreement which also enhances the role of the Joint Assembly, transformed into a genuine parliamentary assembly, both for the EU and the ACP. In this retrospective, I would therefore like not to limit myself to the year 1999. Indeed, my colleague Corrie has already alluded to it admirably. Most of the things that affect us today are the result of fundamental transformations observed since the end of the 1980s in most parts of the world. This process of transformation has also led to extremely violent upheavals in developing countries. They continue to feel the side effects today. ACP cooperation is a dynamic process. From Lomé I to Lomé VI, there has been clear progress in the successive contents of the agreement. At the same time, the number of partner states has increased significantly and now stands at 71. Particularly noteworthy is the enlargement to Namibia and South Africa, which has greatly affected all those who took part. Now Cuba is knocking at the door. If this country is accepted into the ACP-EU Community, this will constitute a significant step forward that will inevitably initiate a process of change in Cuba itself. ACP cooperation therefore remains of great interest, and not only because of the new emphases contained in the agreement. The fight against poverty and support for sustainable economic, social and cultural development are important objectives with a view to building democratic societies in the ACP countries that respect human rights. This includes, in particular, strengthening democratic institutions. In this regard, the history of the Joint Assembly impressively attests to a positive development. While the people who once represented ACP countries at the negotiating table were mainly members of government, civil servants, or ambassadors, today almost three-quarters of our interlocutors are elected members of a parliamentary assembly. If this representation by parliamentarians were soon to be increased to 100%, as the new agreement calls for, we should celebrate the event. Unfortunately, the ongoing democratization processes go much less unnoticed than the various crises that arise in these countries. Therefore, they receive much less attention. Regional cooperation or integration is a specialty of ACP multilateral cooperation. One of the wishes included in the long list of expectations of the European Parliament will finally be realized. Soon, the Joint Assembly will also be able to hold regional meetings. We have already heard about this. Strengthened regional cooperation can help prevent the outbreak of ethnic, economic, social or religious conflicts and thus have a preventive effect. For the same reason, the European Parliament has always spoken out in favour of civil society participation in the decision-making process and the management of cooperation and has always stressed the importance of decentralised cooperation. The strengthening of contacts between the Joint Assembly and the social partners, as provided for in the new agreement, is once again a step in the right direction. However, there remains one small drawback: the European Development Fund is still not integrated into the European budget.

Madam Deputy, I recognize that all the efforts made in Kosovo in this area are insufficient. I don't think anyone has the slightest doubt about that. I do not want to link this issue to the comments I made about the period "before" and "after" NATO's intervention; we will probably return to this point at another point during Question Time. However, I would like to tell you that the European Union is aware that the financial resources channeled to Kosovo correspond to what was possible, to the extent possible. We must understand that our responsibility in this region is a responsibility shared with the international community. It is a responsibility in which the European Union has a determined role, but we cannot claim to quickly rebuild structures that were already not in the best condition before the military action in Kosovo, as you rightly pointed out. Moreover, it does not seem to me, Madam, that the military actions in Kosovo contributed to such significant destruction of health structures, which have a direct effect on the current situation. The current situation is essentially linked to the dramatic situation regarding displaced populations, it is linked to a set of economic factors and the level of satisfaction of basic health needs resulting from the general decay of the organizational structure of the Kosovo administration. This is the basic question underlying the entire current situation. There will be no solution to the problem of children's health, nor to other development problems in the region, until we resolve the political problem, which must be done within the framework of a United Nations resolution. I would like to broaden the debate a little by mentioning the situation in Mitrovica. The international community has rebuilt the hospital there with European assistance, but the building is located in the northern part of the city, which makes access to it problematic for Kosovar Albanians. This means that Kosovar Albanians continue to be deprived of medical care. This situation is repeated in other parts of the country, causing tensions between Kosovar Albanians and Serbs, with mistrust between the populations being general, with some not wanting to be treated by others and vice versa. I understand that you say, and you are right to say so, that the European Union must work within the framework of a broader international cooperation association. But what lever will you use to change the situation? What will you do to ensure that Kosovar Albanians can also receive treatment in a hospital, particularly in Mitrovica? Mr. Deputy, the issue of Mitrovica is well known. It is a very specific situation, where inter-ethnic tension has reached a level of seriousness that is fortunately absent in other areas of Kosovo. I fully understand your concern. I would like to tell you, however, that Mr. Bernard Kouchner acted along a line that aims to preserve what underlies the United Nations resolution on the matter, in an attempt to create the conditions for multi-ethnic structures that can serve the different communities, including at the level of the different dimensions of the administration.

Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner Patten, I would like to thank you for your speech, especially Commissioner Patten, whose analysis I fully share. Therefore, I will not repeat anything he said. I would simply like to make three observations, which Commissioner Patten may perhaps see in a similar light, but which, for various reasons, cannot be expressed as openly as they would by a Member of Parliament. First, I believe that we can be pleased about the agreements that exist between Israel and the Palestinian Authority. But we now have enough agreements: Oslo, Wye Plantation, Sharm-el-Sheik. That is enough; they only need to be implemented. However, I share the scepticism of my colleague, Mr Salafranca, when he says that there was bad news from Israel this week, namely that this latest agreement cannot be implemented on time. The second point concerns the resumption of negotiations between Syria and Israel. I consider this very encouraging news. But we also learned this week that Mr. Barak is not going to Washington, and therefore the negotiations cannot continue. I want to state quite clearly: If the Golan Heights are returned to Syria, the problem in this region will be solved. Regarding the question of the referendum, which several colleagues have raised: We must consider whether a referendum is always necessary to fulfill obligations under international law! In Germany, people would probably be very pleased if we said we would hold a referendum on payments to the European Union, and we would make it dependent on whether the German people are willing to pay. That would be a similar situation. Third and final point: the role of the European Union. I really want to emphasize the outstanding role Special Envoy Moratino has played in the region, and also the funding we have provided there, Commissioner Patten. You know that you will always find support in this Parliament, including for your proposal. We will be there if it is to be funded. But we also have a political role to play, and Mr. Moratinos cannot play that role alone in this region. The Council Presidency must take action; Mr. CFSP must travel to the region, and we must invite the protagonists of the peace process ourselves, as the Russians did. Then we will have played a role commensurate with our participation and our contribution. Mr. President, Commissioner Patten, ladies and gentlemen, the peace talks that recently began in the United States between Israel and Syria represent a turning point in the history of the Middle East, one we have been waiting for for 50 years and one that will certainly be difficult to overcome. There will be no meeting in Shepherdstown today, but we can hope, as Commissioner Patten said earlier, that this postponement of negotiations due to the latest Syrian demands is merely a minor setback on the road to a peace agreement that will profoundly change the entire Middle East. This is precisely the content of our resolution: the hope for a fair and balanced agreement, based on the preservation of sovereignty and the right to live in security within secure and recognized borders.

Competition must bring supply and demand into balance, creating an optimal distribution of resources and economic factors. But optimal efficiency does not necessarily come about by itself. In order to prevent abuse, framework conditions are needed, such as competition rules. This essentially only prevents abuse, but competition alone cannot achieve socially legitimate objectives. Yes to competition; reduce aid where necessary and possible! And precisely because aid occupies a large part of the 1998 Competition Report, even though there is the report by my colleague Jonckheer, I still want to speak on this issue: it is certainly possible and must also be permissible to grant aid to small and medium-sized enterprises active in research and development, in training, in regional policy, in environmental policy. Aid must be permitted for these objectives, provided it does not lead to unacceptable distortions of competition. And it is precisely here, even more than in the law on cartels and mergers, that it is particularly important to make reasonable decisions. Aid should therefore not be demonised, it should be considered in a differentiated manner, and it should also be assessed on the basis of its contribution to achieving the objectives mentioned. This last observation was not so much addressed to the Commission as to my fellow Members of the PPE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the report I am about to present to you is an opinion on the Commission's annual report on state aid in force in the European Union, for which the Community is competent under Articles 87, 88 and 89 of the Treaties. The Commission's report is essentially descriptive and illustrates the evolution of state aid in the manufacturing sector and in other sectors, according to different typologies, as well as the methods of financing and the objectives pursued. As regards the quantitative aspects of the report, I would refer to the explanatory memorandum and would simply point out that, on average, the annual amount for the period in question amounts to EUR 95 billion, a decrease of around 13% compared with the period 1993-1995. This decrease is essentially the result of the reduction in aid in the Federal Republic of Germany. In short, the declared level of state aid is on average more or less stable over the period in question, standing at around 1.2 percent of Community GDP, roughly equivalent, and this is a coincidence, to the annual budget of the Community. That said, the differences between Member States are high and can be measured in different ways, notably as a percentage of added value or per employee. I also think it is interesting to add state aid to Community interventions which can in a certain sense be assimilated to state aid. It will then be clearly noted that at the top are the four countries which are beneficiaries, among other things, of the Cohesion Fund. I now come to the propositional part of the report. First of all, we note that according to the Commission, the data, as presented in the Commission's annual report, are too aggregated to allow an in-depth assessment of state aid policy, a legitimate situation but delicate from the point of view of national interests and undoubtedly important with regard to compliance with competition, also in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty.

We always come back to the same fundamental problem of Europe: our economic life is not dynamic enough and it does not sufficiently encourage individual initiative. The economy must be strong so that we can take care of our loved ones and the environment. This is not politics, but simple life logic. As for the use of credits now, it is positive that they are centralized because scattering them will eventually evaporate them. Now we must concentrate our efforts on solving the problems of large and medium-sized cities since they do not have enough critical mass. We will also be able to give additional impetus to the surrounding rural areas. We often forget that the problems of the cities and those of the countryside actually go hand in hand. Everything is based on encouraging individual innovation and entrepreneurship because the mobilization of the masses, which begins with individuals, leads to an internal renewal of the area. Granting credits without a healthy and independent economy would be like pouring water into a well: there will be enough to drink for a while, but the next day the well will be empty again. Mr. President, with the implementation of Interreg III, European cooperation policy is entering a new phase. Internal borders are no longer the only focus of our concerns; external borders are too. In the context of globalization and the cultural openness that characterizes the current situation, the European Union needs instruments that will enable it to strengthen its links and channels of communication with neighboring regions, particularly eastern and southern Europe. The Union's borders must no longer constitute an obstacle to balanced development, but - on the contrary - an opportunity, a bridge to make cooperation more fruitful. With the amendments approved in committee, Parliament has attempted to complement the Commission's work by introducing new elements into the list of aid recipient areas, particularly for the external and maritime borders of southern Europe. In its draft guidelines, the Commission recognizes that these borders require more attention than in the past. This is due to the process of enlargement to the east and the process of closer integration with the countries of the Mediterranean basin. As President Prodi pointed out when he outlined the strategic objectives for 2000-2005, the revival of the Barcelona Process is a priority for the Union, and the Interreg III initiative can contribute to the pursuit of this strategic objective. While we welcome the excellent work accomplished by the rapporteur, we only hope that the Commission will take due account of the proposals put forward by Parliament, thus respecting the commitments made in the framework of the code of conduct for the implementation of structural policies, and that it will confirm, through the necessary amendments, the conversion of this Community initiative so that it is no longer simply an instrument of internal redistribution but constitutes an opportunity to revive and enhance relations with neighboring countries. Mr President, since this year, the Structural Funds have been allocated a sum of around 200 billion euros until 2006. Only 5.75% of this sum is reserved for the Community initiatives Interreg, Leader, Urban and Equal.
